-----Original Message-----
From: Staci Ehrens [mailto:sehrens@worldnet.att.net]
Sent: Tuesday, April 30, 2002 10:54 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Florida Breast Cancer License Tag-Bill Signing


Dear Governor Bush:

As I write you this letter I am still so deeply moved after being a part
of the bill signing ceremony for the breast cancer research license
plate.  What an incredible honor to have had this chance to meet with
you, Lt. Governor Brogan, and the many legislators that attended.

When I came up with the license tag idea, I never envisioned having a
once in a lifetime opportunity of meeting you directly.  To give you a
little background as to the significance of this tag on a personal
level, my mother is a survivor and has been my inspiration throughout
this very long process.  This has been a labor of love for myself, as
well as the Coalition.

For me, the most proud moments were the day the license tag was approved
from the Legislators and April 29, 2002 at bill signing.  It is hard to
put into words all the emotions I felt.  I am most grateful for our
lobbyist Ronald Book who took on this cause pro bono and worked
tirelessly to ensure the legislative passage of HB441.

Research is the only way we can learn the causes of this disease and
hopefully find out how to "End Breast Cancer" forever.  This tag will be
an added weapon in this fight.

Thank you Governor Bush for launching the breast cancer research license
plate, Florida will shine a little brighter.

Thank you for caring,

Staci Ehrenkrantz
8218 SW 81 Court
Miami, Fl.  33143

From:	MROESSER@aol.com
Sent:	Wednesday, May 1, 2002 7:22 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Re: Cap on public school class size on November's ballot

First rule of brainstorming - all ideas are considered. Here's two crazy thoughts.  
1) Corporations pay millions of dollars to put their name on a stadium, i.e., Raymond James Stadium or the First Union Center.  What if company's could put their name on a school, like Tropicana Middle School.  The company would be responsible for subsidizing some or all of that school's operating budget.
2) The State of Florida could be the first school to enter into exclusive contracts with big name (deep pocketed) corporations/vendors and allow a) only Coca Cola machines in all high schools, b) fruit juice companies in middle or elementary schools. c) All sports teams would exclusively use only Gatorade or Poweraide sports drinks. d) Nike or Reebok or Adidas would supply all uniforms for all the public school system. e) The public school system would use only McGraw Hill textbooks. f) Cleaning supply company's would have the exclusive contracts to supply all cleaning supplies..  The possibilities are endless.  

All these exclusive contracts would be for subsidizing the State's education budget.  It would enable you to, as you put it in your t.v. commercials, pay teachers more, hire more teachers, etc. 

Desperate times call for desperate (creative out of the box) thinking.  Is it not a fact that if 9-11 didn't happen our education budget, our state's budget, wouldn't be in the shape it's in now?

I often wake up in the middle of the night with thoughts like these.  Have a blessed day!

Mark Roesser, MBA

May 1, 2002

Dear Governor Bush:

My message in this letter is simple:  I am truly outraged by Senator
King's
attempt to poison the Everglades restoration funding bill with his
amendment to strangle citizen input to development debates.  His
underhanded gamesmanship that tacked a citizen-hostile amendment to the
Everglades funding bill -- so cherished by Florida's citizens -- is
downright shameful.

I've been following Florida state politics for four (4) years now.  Some
state legislature actions have been laudable.  But far more often, the
pattern is that of the Florida legislature concocting secret and
not-so-secret plans to trample citizens' rights and interests.  I am
disillusioned, disappointed and not proud of what I see.

I urge you to do the right thing.  Veto HB 813 and demand that the
legislature strip out King's amendment and bring you a clean bill,
untainted less-than-honorable shenanigans.

Sincerely,



Barbara Seeley Curtis

Thank you for the follow up, Chirs.

This was a 16-year on-going legal battle solved in 1 visit and 8 phone calls
by the Office of the Ombudsman.  Additionally, our Office recently used Mr.
Koblick as a volunteer/consultant in an issue involving the Smithsonian
Marine Station in Fort Pierce - to everyone's benefit and satisfaction.  

This is Alternative Dispute Resolution at work.  Cheers.

Benji

PS - Last month, Governor Bush signed Executive Order 87-02 requiring his
Agencies to mainstream ADR in to the fabric of their organizations. I believe
the long-term benefits of this EO will be dramatic and profound.

-----Original Message-----
From: Ross, Lucia T. [mailto:Lucia.T.Ross@dep.state.fl.us]
Sent: Wednesday, May 01, 2002 8:13 AM
To: baurk@eog.state.fl.us; mark.busse@myflorida.com;
hirste@eog.state.fl.us; jiminef@eog.state.fl.us;
mandy.thomas@myflorida.com
Subject: Everglades Restoration Project wins int'l award


FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE				                  CONTACT:
Lucia Ross
May 1, 2002
(850) 488-1073

EVERGLADES RESTORATION PROJECT ONE OF SIX RECOGNIZED AT INTERNATIONAL
ENGINEERING COMPETITION
--SFWMD engineers awarded for their engineering excellence--

TALLAHASSEE -- The South Florida Water Management District was among six
finalists recognized at the annual Outstanding Projects and Leaders (OPAL)
awards gala April 27 in Los Angeles in the prestigious American Society of
Civil Engineers (ASCE) 2002 Outstanding Civil Engineering Achievement
competition for two major components of the Everglades Construction Project:
Stormwater Treatment Areas 1 West and  2. The completion of these two STAs
is
a significant milestone in the overall Everglades restoration program. 
	"This is a well-deserved recognition for the professional engineers
involved with restoring America's Everglades," said DEP Secretary David B.
Struhs. "Their work is known and respected worldwide. Along with the
recognized high quality of their work, they continue to accomplish their
mission both on time and on budget."
Dr. H. Gerard Schwartz Jr., P.E., president of the ASCE, presented a
finalist
trophy to District Deputy Executive Director Joe Schweigart at the black-tie
event, recognizing the STAs for their engineering and mechanical excellence,
as well as the project's benefits to the environment and society.
Schweigart
accepted it on behalf of the more than 50 District engineers and support
staff, as well as over 30 consultant firms and contractors, who worked on
the
3 ½ -year, $180 million project. The Everglades Construction Project was
showcased in a video at the ceremony. 
"To be recognized as building one of the best civil engineering projects in
the world is a tremendous honor for the District," said South Florida Water
Management District Governing Board Chair Trudi Williams. "The success of
the
STAs reflects the high standard of excellence, creativity and commitment of
our staff and contractors to meet an immense challenge." 
(more)


Established in 1960, the Outstanding Civil Engineering Achievement award
annually recognizes the project that best illustrates superior civil
engineering achievement and represents a significant contribution to civil
engineering progress and society. The award honors the team of engineers
rather than an individual. 
The six finalists were selected from a number of very strong projects
among 33 entries from around the world.  The other finalists were
Bibliotheca
Alexandrina in Alexandria, Egypt; JFK Terminal 4 in Jamaica, New York; the
I-15 Design/Build Reconstruction  Project in Salt Lake City, Utah; the
Experience Music Project in Seattle, Washington; and the Seven Oaks Dam in
Highland, California. The overall winner was the Utah Department of
Transportation for the I-15 Design/Build Reconstruction Project. 
The 1994 Everglades Forever Act mandated construction of six stormwater
treatment areas to improve water quality in the Everglades, including STA
1-West and STA-2.  These large, constructed wetlands reduce the level of
phosphorus entering the Everglades using naturally occurring biological
processes and large pumps that enhance the outward flow of treated water.
These six STAs will remove more than 160 metrics tons or phosphorus per year
when fully operational.
STA-1 West, in central Palm Beach County, removes phosphorus from
agricultural stormwater prior to entering the Arthur R. Marshall Loxahatchee
National Wildlife Refuge, also known as Water Conservation Area 1. STA-2, in
southern Palm Beach County, filters and discharges water to Water
Conservation Area 2A. Each system covers more than 10 square miles of land.

-30-


From:	John Gonzalez <jgonzalez@arcmc.org>
Sent:	Wednesday, May 1, 2002 9:55 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	DOE Cutbacks to the Developmentally Disabled

We have learned that Department of Education staff has asked that funds be taken from the Adult Handicapped Fund in order to address deficits in the VR and Blind Services Programs.   It is extremely unfair to adults with disabilities that one of the programs benefiting them should be compromised in order to benefit another.  The individuals who receive the benefits of the Adult Basic Education provided through the Adult Handicapped Fund are those who will likely never be able to be competitively employed, and therefore, not able to benefit from VR services.  In Miami-Dade, approximately 2,863 adults with disabilities are registered at 25+ agencies.  Each receives an average of 25-30 hours of educational services weekly.  While we recognize that there are many competing funding priorities, we urge you NOT to reduce funding for the DOE’s Adult Handicapped Program.
 
 
 
John B. Gonzalez 
Administrator
ARC of Martin County
2001 S. Kanner Highway
Stuart, FL 34994
(772)283-2525
(772)286-6808 fax

From: Nina Oviedo [mailto:oviedon@sso.org]

To: Brian Yablonski (E-mail); Frank R. Jimenez (E-mail); KaS (E-mail)
Cc: Jeb Bush
Subject: Pataki Letter/request
Importance: High


Gov. Pataki has sent a letter to Republican Governors asking the Governors to join him in renouncing the latest wave of brutal attacks in Israel.  According to Pataki’s Washington Director, The White House supports the effort and Pataki would appreciate Gov’s help on this matter.  It is a bipartisan initiative; Governor Gray Davis is working on his colleagues.
 
I have attached the statement in Word Doc and have included below.  Pls advise.
 
 
   Governors’ Declaration of Principles
 
 
1. We, Governors representing individual states of the United States of America, declare our steadfast support for the State of Israel and for peace in the Middle East.
 
2. We wholeheartedly deplore and reject acts of terrorism and the deliberate targeting of innocent civilians, and call for an immediate end to the campaign of incitement, terror and violence, particularly homicide bombings, which have claimed countless innocent lives, and derailed the peace process.
 
3. We recognize that the United States and Israel are allies in the defense of freedom, tolerance and democracy; when those ideals are attacked anywhere, they are attacked everywhere.
 
4. We stand in solidarity with the people of Israel and renew our commitment to a viable, lasting and secure peace.
 
5. We support the President’s call upon all parties in the region to do their utmost to fight terrorism and to achieve peace in the region.
 
 
____________________________________
                    Governor
 
State of ____________________

Dear Governor Bush: 

I was very interested in the message you sent out yesterday.  I believe it was last week when First Coast News did a piece on your school funding initiatives in response the ads the State is running.  They interviewed two teachers and Terry Brady...Terry Brady being the focus of the piece.  The piece was not a positive piece for your school programs.  The reporter only briefly mentioned that Terry was associated with the Democratic Party (which she is HIGHLY associated with in town) and only said the additional funding wasn't enough, not mentioning how it compared to prior administrations and their increases (or lack of)....I meant to e-mail Vivian since she is out of town to tell her.  I'll copy her on this e-mail. 
Somehow, we will have to get the local media to be fair and balanced!!!  Do you have numbers available to publicize on the prior administrations' per student increases??? That was the focus on that piece. 

When I was with Sysco, I had two hotels in Orlando I had to call on.  Before 9/11 the hotel off International Drive was wondering how to meet sales budgets, and after 9/11 it was not even a thought.  On my last visit to them in March they were booked up!!!!  The other hotel catered to the business traveler, and they, too, were seeing business increase on my March visit. 

Just thought I would let you know the person on the street's perspective! 
Robin Tilton

Subject:	Tax Breaks for Corporations......STOP

This is addressed to our Govenor, Jeb Bus,  Senator McKan, and Speaker Mr. Feeney:

I want you to know how angry I am at the thought of the bill you are considering  that will give $400 million in tax breaks to corporations.  Don't get me wrong I have supported some tax incentives for corporations in the past, they have gotten out of hand, and now we are in a position where we can not afford it.  Just like we do at home when you are short you have to stop giving your money away.  We need to create more taxes not give tax breaks.

No one wants to pay more but reality is we need it to support education, health care and the programs to keep our people safe.    Also I do not approve of spending the trust fund money that was set aside for a specific purpose.

Also we need more money for TANF  to give services like counseling, drug treatment etc. to the people on welfare so they can get ahead and overcome family and life situations.

Thanks for hearing my thoughts


 

Namaste, 
Nita Schmellick

From:	Jimenez, Frank <Frank.Jimenez@MyFlorida.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, May 1, 2002 2:09 PM

Subject:	FW: Florida leads SE in Clean Air Act requirements



-----Original Message-----
From: Ross, Lucia T. [mailto:Lucia.T.Ross@dep.state.fl.us]
Sent: Wednesday, May 01, 2002 1:28 PM
To: baurk@eog.state.fl.us; mark.busse@myflorida.com;
hirste@eog.state.fl.us; jiminef@eog.state.fl.us;
mandy.thomas@myflorida.com
Subject: Florida leads SE in Clean Air Act requirements


FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE					CONTACT:
Lucia
Ross
May 1, 2002
(850) 488-1073

Florida leads the Southeast in meeting Clean Air Act requirements
-- EPA report cites success in controlling large sources of pollution --

	TALLAHASSEE -- According to a recent report by the U.S.
Environmental
Protection Agency, Florida is the first state in the Southeast, and only one
of three in the country, to have issued all federally required permits to
its
large stationary sources of air pollution.  Since the passage of the current
Clean Air Act in 1990, Florida has issued permits to 452 facilities compared
to a combined total of 330 in the only other states to achieve 100 percent
success -- Oregon and South Dakota.

	"I am grateful that the state's aggressive efforts have been
recognized," said Department of Environmental Protection Secretary David B.
Struhs.  "By meeting all of these air pollution  permitting requirements in
a
timely fashion, Floridians have documented proof that they are breathing
cleaner air because these large plants are operating within federal as well
as state clean air laws."

	These large facilities, such as electric power plants, are regulated
under Title V of the Clean Air Act and each state is responsible for
developing and implementing these operating permits.  Practices contributing
to the Department's effective program included strategic management and
fostering state and local partnerships.  

In addition, workshops involving communities and industry were held to
answer
questions and concerns regarding these permits.  Among the six states
singled
out for detailed review in the report, Florida was the only state among the
six to issue 100 percent of required permits employing a process that is, on
average, one year shorter.

"Over the last three years, the administration of Gov. Jeb Bush has made
unprecedented progress to improve Florida's air quality," said Deputy
Secretary for Regulatory Programs Allan Bedwell.  "The EPA report confirms
that our permitting process enables us to work with industry to reduce air
pollution - efficiently and effectively."

The report, entitled EPA and State Progress in Issuing Title V Permits was
produced by the EPA's Office of Inspector General.


-30-

From:	Lisa.Snell@reason.org
Sent:	Wednesday, May 1, 2002 2:43 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	The Philadelphia Experiment

Jeb,

Just in case you are not already overwhelmed by the media coverage of the Philadelphia school privatization experiment, Reason Foundation weighs in with a new policy brief, "Education Management Organizatons (EMOs) Provide Choice, Competition, and Innovation," released today and written by Dr. Guilbert C. Hentschke, professor of education and management at the University of Southern California's Rossier School of Education, Scot Oschman, a Ph.D. candidate at USC's Rossier School of Education, and myself. Available at: <http://www.rppi.org/pb21.pdf>.

As David Adamany, the president of Temple University, which was assigned five schools near its North Philadelphia campus, told the Associated Press, "We're not sure we're excited yet. It will depend on the nature of the contracts."

Indeed, in many ways the success or the failure of the Philadelphia experiment hinges on the flexibility of the contracts and the degree to which the individual managers are free to implement their own business models.  In policy brief 21, we explore how EMOs represent an innovative management tool that school administrators can use to raise student achievement. We explore the unique advantages that for-profit education companies have over most school districts such as a focus on education research and development. We argue that strong school-management contracts that give EMOs maximum flexibility to implement their business models, coupled with careful contract monitoring and clear performance measures, can result in better outcomes for students.  


In addition, for more information about one of the lesser-known Philadelphia school managers, Universal Cos., see Monday's LA Times feature article below courtesy of Education Week's Daily News.

"Kenny Gamble spent the 1960s and '70s as a chart-topping songwriter and producer. Lately he's been trying to chart a new direction for his boyhood neighborhood in South Philadelphia. His Universal Cos. has built homes, developed new shops and sponsored job training. Progress has often been grudging, but the group has gained enough of a foothold to dramatically raise its sights: It is hoping to construct 2,000 homes in the next half decade. Ask Gamble to isolate the key factor in success and his answer is unequivocal: Fix the local public schools. Starting next September, Gamble's Universal Cos. will take control of two neighborhood schools. " <http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/nation/la-000030518apr29.column?coll=la%2Dheadlines%2Dnation>


For more thoughtful market analysis of the Philadelphia experiment see today's Eduventures, The Education Economy, by Peter Stokes, which also has extensive coverage of the likelihood of Edison and other manager's success. See, <http://www.eduventures.com/news/education_economy/index.cfm> (access requires registration, but this is a good resource). I excerpt from today's piece below:

Good News/Bad News - Edison Wins While Losing

Edison wins 20 schools in Philadelphia, four times as many as any other provider competing for the city's schools. The bad news: Edison's stock is hovering at five dollars.

These are tricky times in education markets, and industry observers are apt to feel as though they are watching a tennis game - craning their necks first one way (the good news) and then the other (the bad news). On April 24, 2002, in their piece, "The Philadelphia Experiment: For-Profit Charter School Managers Step into the National Spotlight," Eduventures Analyst Sean Gallagher and Senior Analyst Jim McVety assess the impact of the Philadelphia School Reform Commission's recent announcement regarding the awarding of 30 out of a total of 42 schools to for-profit third-party managers, including: Edison - 20 schools, Chancellor Beacon - 5 schools, Victory Schools - 3 schools, Universal Companies - 2 schools.

The remaining schools will be managed by non-profits, including Temple University (five schools), University of Pennsylvania (three schools), and Foundations, Inc. (four schools).

"By assigning the Philadelphia schools to a variety of for-profit and non-profit providers, the Commission has created a microcosm of charter management market competition," write Gallagher and McVety. "It will provide an opportunity to examine the differing models of pedagogy and management as they operate side by side."

Gallagher and McVety note that the campaign in Philadelphia has already cost Edison substantially in terms of market cap. The long publicity war waged in the city has also undoubtedly tarnished Edison's image. As Edison's president and CEO Chris Whittle observed last October at an Eduventures event, "Other companies have competitors, we have enemies." The fact that Wall Street was expecting Edison to win as many as 45 schools has left investors with little to cheer about following the much smaller win. A recent downgrading by Merrill Lynch has resulted in a sharp sell-off of Edison's stock.

As Gallagher and McVety point out, however, the emphasis on Edison is misplaced. Something larger is at stake in Philadelphia. "The acceptance and success of for-profit managers nationwide may hinge on the quality of the results that this collective group of managers is able to deliver," they write. Ultimately, it will come down to educational performance rather than share price performance, and when it does, it will be the group of providers as a whole that will be judged.


Finally, on a less serious note, I have heard from various sources that for-profit education companies do not really like the label "Education Management Organizations."  In reality, they do not really operate like "HMOs" and they certainly do not want to share any negative connotations with HMOs. Yet, EMO is a sticky label, and it may be too late in the game to shed the label. Any thoughts on alternatives?

At Reason Foundation we are largely agnostic about which kind of choice-oriented school reform is best. We think the more competitive school-choice experiments there are the better it is for parents and children. Thanks you for your continued support of Reason's education work.

Best,

Lisa


Lisa Snell
Director Education and Child Welfare Program
Reason Foundation
3415 S. Sepulveda Blvd. #400
Los Angeles, CA 90034
www.reason.org
www.RPPI.org
www.reason.com
310-391-2245


Reason Public Policy Institute is a think tank promoting choice, competition, and a dynamic market economy as the foundation for human dignity and progress.

Subject: URGENT - ABE FUNDS IN JEOPARDY
Importance: High



The Legislature is in special session and the Adult Handicapped Fund is once
again under siege.  This time it doesn't appear to be the legislature's
fault, but rather, is at the request of the new VR Director, who is also in
charge of this program.  TIME IS OF THE UTMOST IMPORTANT.  Please send the
following message to the following people.

THE MESSAGE:

We have learned that Department of Education staff has asked that funds be
taken from the Adult Handicapped Fund in order to address deficits in the VR
and Blind Services Programs.   It is extremely unfair to adults with
disabilities that one of the programs benefiting them should be compromised
in order to benefit another.  The individuals who receive the benefits of
the Adult Basic Education provided through the Adult Handicapped Fund are
those who will likely never be able to be competitively employed, and
therefore, not able to benefit from VR services.  In Miami-Dade,
approximately 2,863 adults with disabilities are registered at 25+ agencies.
Each receives an average of 25-30 hours of educational services weekly.
While we recognize that there are many competing funding priorities, we urge
you NOT to reduce funding for the DOE's Adult Handicapped Program.

E-MAIL THE MESSAGE TO:

Loretta Costin, Director, DVR                costinl@vr.doe.state.fl.us
Governor Jeb Bush                               jeb@jeb.org
Sen. Alex Villalobos
villalobos.alex.web@leg.state.fl.us

portilla.alex.web@leg.state.fl.us

From:	glenna higginbotham <princessglenna@hotmail.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, May 1, 2002 3:41 PM
To:	Jeb Bush; costinl@vr.doe.state.fl.us; villalobos.alex.web@leg.state.fl.us; portilla.alex.web@leg.state.fl.us; Pruitt.ken.web@leg.state.fl.us; jones.daryl.web@leg.state.fl.us; Mitchell.Richard.web@leg.state.fl.us; lynn.evelyn.web@leg.state.fl.us; arza.Ralph.web@leg.state.fl.us; Lacasa.carlos@leg.state.fl.us
Subject:	Adult Basic Education Funds

It is with great concern that I write this letter.  I have learned that the 
Department of Education has asked that funds be taken from the Adult 
Handicapped Fund in order to address deficits in the VR and Blind Services 
Programs.  It is EXTREMELY unfair to the adults with disabilities that the 
monies of one prof the programs benefiting those individuals should be 
compromised in order to benefit another program.  The individuals who 
receive the benefits of the Adult Basic Education provided through the Adult 
Handicapped Fund are those individuals who will most likely never be able to 
be compretitively employed.  Therefore, those individuals would not benefit 
from VR services.  In Miami Dade there are approximately 2,863 adults with 
disabilities registerer at over 25 different agencies.  Each of these 
agencies receives an average of 25-30 hours of educational services weekly.  
I understand that there are many competing funding priorities.  However, I 
urge you NOT to reduce the funding for the Department of Education's Adult 
Handicapped Program.
Thank you.
Sincerely
Glenna Higginbotham

From:	Pat Richards <prichards@ahsonline.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, May 1, 2002 4:13 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	ADULT HANDICAPPED FUND

Dear Governor Bush, 
 
We have learned that Department of Education staff has asked that funds be taken from the Adult Handicapped Fund in order to address deficits in the VR and Blind Services Programs.  It is extremely  unfair to adults with disabilities that one of the programs benefiting them should be compromised in order to benefit another.  The individuals who receive the benefits of the Adult Basic Education provided through the Adult Handicapped Fund are those who will likely never be able to be competitively employed, and therefore, not able to benefit from VR services.  In Miami-Dade, approximately 2,863 adults with disabilities are registered at 25+ agencies.  Each receives an average of 25-30 hours of educational services weekly.  While we recognize that there are many competing funding priorities, we urge you NOT to reduce funding for the DOE's Adult Handicapped Program.
 
Sincerely,
 
Jon Fisher, State Director
Florida Operations
American Habilitation Services, Inc.

From: Phillips, Matilde [mailto:Matilde.Phillips@dbpr.state.fl.us]
Sent: Wednesday, May 01, 2002 5:10 PM
To: Phillips, Matilde
Subject: Letter from Kim Binkley-Seyer



Welcome back to Tallahassee! DBPR has had an exciting few weeks since you were last in town. As you begin this very important special session, we wanted to take a moment to update you on the latest activity from our agency.

We attended the prestigious ComputerWorld Honors ceremony in San Francisco. DBPR's reengineering and technical project was recognized as one of the top 75 most innovative projects of its type in the entire world! It was a monumental honor to represent the state of Florida among such a distinguished group of worldwide technology bellwethers. 

We participated in the Florida Association of Electrical Contractors spring conference in Crystal River, the Northeast Florida Builders Association trade show in Jacksonville and the Tallahassee Board of Realtors meeting. At each of these events, we demonstrated our new online services and helped licensees activate accounts and familiarize themselves with our new service channels. 

I had the great pleasure of assisting our Division of Alcoholic Beverages and Tobacco on Spring Break patrol. From March 11, 2002 - April 14, 2002, over 700,000 student visitors came to our state. Our law enforcement agents annually join forces with local law enforcement in Daytona and Panama City to combat underage drinking and false identification activity. Amazingly, we made a total of 4,284 arrests and seized over 7,500 pieces of false identification in just over 30 days. 

I was honored to be a keynote speaker at a great event in St. Petersburg, Bridging the Digital Bay 2002. This event brought together over 500 business leaders and executives from the bay area technology corridor to celebrate Florida's successes and plan for our future. Additionally, DBPR spoke with professional board groups including Employee Leasing, Geology and Cosmetology to discuss project benefits, as each of these groups will come online later this month. 

We had the great pleasure of visiting with editorial boards around the state, including the Tampa Tribune, the Florida Times-Union and the Sarasota News Herald. In fact, I have enclosed an editorial that the Tallahassee Democrat ran while you were gone. We are excited about the positive changes that are occurring at DBPR and we are seeking every available outlet to share this message.

And the message is obviously being heard because we have groups coming to tour our new Customer Contact Center on a weekly basis. Since you were last here, we have hosted the Australian Tax Office, the Florida Departments of Education, Revenue and Juvenile Justice, the Construction Industry Licensing Board and Landscape Architecture Board and representatives from the Alcoholic Beverage and Tobacco industry. 

DBPR is by far the best place to be in state government. Under your continued leadership, we are revolutionizing the way public sector businesses are run. It is our mission to reach out to as many stakeholders as possible and we need your help. If you know of events and/or groups in your districts that we should be talking with, please let us know. Call me directly at any time or contact our Office of Legislative Affairs at 850.487.4827. Good luck with the work that lies ahead of you. Please do not hesitate to call me if you need anything. 

Sincerely, 
Kim Binkley-Seyer

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Published in the Tallahassee Democrat on Saturday, April 13, 2002
Floridians are benefiting from concept of e-government
By Kimberly Binkley-Seyer
SPECIAL TO THE DEMOCRAT

What comes to mind when you hear the word "Internet?" If you are like most people, you think of e-mail, Web sites and online shopping.

As a taxpayer, what should come to mind is the revolution underway within Florida's government, where the Internet is opening up more cost effective and efficient ways for public agencies to

improve the services they provide. A new era of "e-government" is living up to the potential for improving government services, shrinking paperwork, and reducing the time and effort it takes to do business with government.

The Florida Department of Business and Professional Regulation (DBPR) is just one example of how e-government can benefit citizens. One out of every 16 Floridians holds a license issued by DBPR. The department issues almost 200 different types of licenses for businesses and occupations, ranging from construction companies and realtors, to hotel owners and restaurateurs.

In carrying out its mission to protect consumers from unscrupulous or unqualified service providers, DBPR annually reviews millions of new license applications and renewals. This process historically forced applicants to often wait several weeks to receive a response to their mail-in application.

Despite the enormous amount of information that DBPR collects, Floridians lacked a convenient way of verifying that an accountant or re-modeler they want to hire was legitimate. The Internet and e-government provide a better way.

In a public-private partnership, DBPR has joined with Accenture, a leading provider of management and technology solutions, to move the entire professional and business licensing and renewal process online. The innovative "eLicensing" project - accessible 24 hours a day at www.myflorida.com - streamlines more than 60 databases into one integrated program. The nearly 200 licensing categories for the professions regulated by DBPR will be moved onto the centralized system over two years.

Many license categories, such as those in the real estate and construction industries, are already available. The remaining licenses will all be online in the next few months.

As these licensing categories come online, they are supported by a new customer contact center that will have more than 150 customer service representatives to serve the citizens of Florida.

Renewal and application processing times have been reduced to minutes, rather than days - and sometimes weeks. Applicants can also pay their fees with a credit card. The services are available 24 hours a day, 7 days a week via secure Internet connections.

The advantages of putting this system online stretch beyond providing convenience for licensed businesses and professionals. Any resident with Internet access will soon be able to verify the validity of a license holder by searching the DBPR website by name or line of business. The site also will contain the history behind a particular license, including past complaints.

While DBPR has taken aggressive measures to protect the privacy of licensees, state law clearly directs that licensing information be made available to the public, so that consumers can protect themselves in the free marketplace. Until DBPR began using the power of the Internet, there was no real way to ensure that Floridians could get convenient access to this information.

There are further benefits to our state, such as opportunities for DBPR employees to focus their energies and talents less on paperwork and more on customer service. Along with greater opportunities to support our customers, employee skills are enhanced as they learn how to use new, innovative systems.

Perhaps most important, these improvements will yield substantive savings to Florida taxpayers. It is estimated that this e-government solution will save the state more than $90 million dollars over nine years. We are proud to be a part of Governor Bush's plan to make state government more efficient and customer friendly.

This is the way of the future - a government that is more friendly, open and responsive. We should all be proud that Florida is leading the way.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Kim Binkley-Seyer is Secretary of the Florida Department of Business and Professional Regulation. 

###

From: Langford, Brandi 
Sent: Wednesday, May 01, 2002 4:53 PM
To: Shanahan, Kathleen; DiBenigno, Arlene; Hampton, Betty; Bayliss, Slater; Busse, Mark
Cc: Clark, Roy
Subject: Eglin Pilot


Roy Clark is getting the pilot’s information in case we would like to do a note or phone call to the family.
Eglin pilot declared dead after search for crashed jet in Gulf
PUBLISHED WEDNESDAY, MAY 1, 2002 - 2:55 p.m.
Louis Cooper
Pensacola News-Journal
The pilot of an Eglin Air Force Base F-15C Eagle jet fighter that crashed into the Gulf of Mexico was declared dead Wednesday after a fruitless day of searching.
U.S. Air Force Maj. James A. Duricy's jet crashed at about 9:15 a.m. Tuesday about 60 miles south of Panama City. Along with an F-16 and a KC-135, the plane was conducting a test of new air-to-air missile. The weapon was not armed.
The search was officially called off at 11:30 a.m. Wednesday. 
Duricy's age, hometown and family status were not released. He received his commission after graduating from the U.S. Air Force Academy in May 1989.
Lois Walsh, spokeswoman for the 46th Test Wing at Eglin's Air Armament Center, said personnel with Duricy's 40th Flight Test Squadron were so saddened by the loss none of the unit's planes flew Wednesday.
``You can imagine the emotions everyone is going through in that squadron,'' Walsh said. 
``I've been here 14 years, and this is the first death that I am aware of.''
The first sign of trouble in Tuesday's mission came when the F-16's pilot sent several radio transmissions to Duricy that went unanswered. That pilot soon found debris on the water's surface.
The U.S. Cost Guard led the search, coordinating efforts from its 8th District headquarters in New Orleans. The cutter Seahawk from Carrabelle spent the night searching for the wreckage and pilot, according to Petty Officer Kyle Niemi.
``The Seahawk was searching last night, and it was replaced by the Cobia (from Mobile) this morning'' along with a Falcon jet, he said. The Cobia, like the Seahawk, is an 87-foot cutter.
An investigation board has been formed to investigate the incident. An initial report is due in 30 days.

proposed language offered as a compromise:

" No more than 10 percent of the money's deposited in the trust fund of the
Division of Florida Land Sales, Condominiums, and Mobile Homes shall be
transferred to the office of the Secretary for the Department of Business
and Professional Regulation or to other parts of the Department during any
fiscal year without the prior specific authorization by the Legislature in
the General Appropriations Act.	
Added:

Excluded from this 10 percent transfer restriction shall be the transfer of
the following expenses directly related to the Division: 1) charges from the
office of the general counsel and the Division of Administrative hearings
incurred directly for the compliance, enforcement and legal services of the
Division as specifically requested by staff of the Division, 2) Division of
technology expenses incurred directly for the use and maintenance of the
Division standard, recurring, technology expenses, 3) charges incurred
directly for the collection of the revenue for the Division, 4) charges from
the Departments centralized call center, licensing unit and its compliance
and enforcement unit expended directly on the Division."

Subject:	chinese fable

Monantaro testimony reminds me of the story we once heard, you may want to
use at some point tomorrow if needed:

American businessman is visiting China to observe their industry and
econonmy.  Officials take him out to watch the construction of a massive
dam.  As they are standing over the construction site, the American
businessman observes 200 workers with shovels building up the dam.  He
suggests to the Chinese officials that with a couple of steam shovels they
could get this job done at half the cost in half the time.  The Chinese
Official says, "But what would happen to all these workers?"  To that the
American says, "Oh, well if its jobs, and not a dam, you wish to create,
then why not give them all spoons?"

From:	Bishop, David <David.Bishop@MyFlorida.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, May 1, 2002 9:44 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	RE: amendment to Economic Development bill

 Governor,
Our attorney believes this amendment violates the Single Subject Act since
it is not related to economic development.  In addition, she is concerned
that the amendment weakens the academic background needed to be a licensed
general contractor.  It removes the requirement that to be a licensed
general contractor a person "shall show completion of an equal number of
courses in the appropriate field or engineering, architecture, or building
construction."  Essentially, we believe that if this amendment becomes law,
you could have a BA in art education and still be qualified to be a licensed
contractor in Florida.  

What would you like us to do?

Please note: Florida has a very broad public records law.
Most written communications to or from state officials

From:	Virtualusa@aol.com
Sent:	Thursday, May 2, 2002 12:09 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	IMPORTANT

It is with great concern that I write this letter.  I have learned that the Department of Education has asked that funds be taken from the Adult Handicapped Fund in order to address deficits in the VR and Blind Services Programs.  It is EXTREMELY unfair to the adults with disabilities that the monies of one prof the programs benefiting those individuals should be compromised in order to benefit another program.  The individuals who receive the benefits of the Adult Basic Education provided through the Adult Handicapped Fund are those individuals who will most likely never be able to be compretitively employed.  Therefore, those individuals would not benefit from VR services.  In Miami Dade there are approximately 2,863 adults with disabilities registerer at over 25 different agencies.  Each of these agencies receives an average of 25-30 hours of educational services weekly.  I understand that there are many competing funding priorities.  However, I urge you NOT to reduce the funding for the Department of Education's Adult Handicapped Program.  
Thank you. 
Sincerely 

MITCHELL P.KORUS

On Wed, 1 May 2002 17:51:40 -0400 "Shaw, Julie" <ShawJ@dms.state.fl.us>
writes:

Hi Berthy,  I got your message asking for details on our budget and how
we are faring.  Here is the breakdown.  All of our budget requests were
matched by the Governor, House and Senate with the exception of the
Clearinghouse (CH) on Disability Information.

CH - House: Item #422 = 1 FTE included in a total allocation of $123,158
CH - Senate: Item #741 = 1 FTE included in total allocation of $234,817
CH - Governor = 1 FTE and expenses totaling $250,000

The FTE with salaries and benefits costs $48,372.

The House allocation is insufficient to maintain the program and continue
in implementation efforts.  The CH also serves as the fiscal base for the
grant.  We are providing in-kind services but the House proposal will
only pay for rent, phones, and maintenance of server and the 1 position. 
No printing, marketing, web site deployment, software purchases,
implementation of multiple languages and more could be funded.

The DMS plan is that we believe the Senate will feel strongly about the
CH and would ask for their proposal to be matched.  The $234,817 can be
made sufficient with the elimination of a few expenses, if necessary. 
The issue is headed to Conference Committee.  Our challenge (DMS) is to
keep it on the radar screen because it is such a small issue compared to
other items and various strategies between the House and Senate.

From:	Roberta and Steven Robbins <robbinsfamily1@juno.com>
Sent:	Thursday, May 2, 2002 7:13 AM

Subject:	2 urgent  messages

Dear Friends:
 
We have learned that Department of Education staff has asked that funds be
taken from the Adult Handicapped Fund in order to address deficits in the VR
and Blind Services Programs.   It is extremely unfair to adults with
disabilities that one of the programs benefiting them should be compromised
in order to benefit another.  The individuals who receive the benefits of
the Adult Basic Education provided through the Adult Handicapped Fund are
those who will likely never be able to be competitively employed, and
therefore, not able to benefit from VR services.  In Miami-Dade,
approximately 2,863 adults with disabilities are registered at 25+ agencies.
Each receives an average of 25-30 hours of educational services weekly.
While we recognize that there are many competing funding priorities, we urge
you NOT to reduce funding for the DOE's Adult Handicapped Program.
 
AND PLEASE:
 
"SUPPORT THE GOVERNOR'S $90 MILLION BUDGET REQUEST FOR THE
DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES PROGRAM "
 

Thank you for your time,
 
Roberta Robbins

From:	Dayle Olson <dolson@bacbrevard.com>
Sent:	Thursday, May 2, 2002 7:56 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Adult Handicapped Funds
Attachments:	Dayle Olson.vcf

Dear Gov. Bush

I realize that budgeting items are some of the most difficult for the Legislature to make.  However, I am highly concerned about the potential of Adult Handicapped Funds being cut.  I become most concerned when funds for some of Floridas most vulnerable citizens are being viewed as areas to potentially "...rob Peter to pay Paul."  Many of the individuals who would be most hurt from these cuts are citizens who cannot advocate for themselves, are in critical need of meaningful programs and who do not have the opportunities to have a fulfilled life without programs that use the Adult Handicapped Funds. 

Thus I hope there will be tremendous consideration given to not cutting the Adult Handicapped Funds.

Dayle Olson

Dayle Olson
President
Brevard Achievement Center
1845 Cogswell Street
Rockledge, Florida  32955
dolson@bacbrevard.com

-----Original Message-----
From: Gilmore, Scott M. [mailto:SMGILMORE@Fahlgren.com]
Sent: Wednesday, May 01, 2002 8:17 PM
To: 'Dana, Pam'
Cc: 'Austin Mott'; 'Fred Lounsberry'; 'Sharon Creedon'
Subject: RE: Bobby Bowden Commercial


Thanks, Pam. 

VISIT FLORIDA's in-state campaign kicked in this week so you'll be seeing
and hearing a lot of FLA USA through June. This is in addition to the
ongoing recovery co-op programs funded by the $20 million economic stimulus
budget.

As you may be aware, we've filmed two additional TV commercials for the
in-state campaign. One features Derrick Brooks and John Lynch of the Tampa
Bay Buccaneers and the other features NASCAR driver Mark Martin. Both are in
editing now and these two commercials will soon be added to the rotation
that includes Jennifer Capriati. On the radio side, Andy Garcia will be
included in both English (and Spanish) along with Coach Bowden. 

African American and Hispanic programs are in place to supplement our reach
to these important audiences beyond our general market efforts. These
programs include television, radio and newspaper.
 
In our negotiations with the media, we requested a commitment for a 1:1
match of "bonus" spots resulting in one extra commercial for every paid
spot. In order to receive these bonus spots, the media required us to
provide public service announcements rather than running our celebrity
creative as bonus. So we've produced fresh, new PSAs for both radio and TV.

Outdoor boards are also part of the in-state program. And, of course, the
radio spots featuring the Governor are running now out of state.

We'll continue sending you samples of the new work as it's completed. 

We appreciate your assistance and that of the Governor's Office of External
Affairs in lining up the celebrities.

Please let me know if you have questions.

Thanks very much for your continued support.

From:	McDonough, Jim <Jim.McDonough@MyFlorida.com>
Sent:	Thursday, May 2, 2002 8:33 AM
To:	'Zan100@aol.com'
Cc:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	FW: DARE
Attachments:	DARE INFO FLDRUGCZAR.doc; Feasibility Study Fact Sheet.doc


Dear Shannon,

	Thank you again for writing to Governor Bush.  As I mentioned in an
earlier email to you, I have taken some time to look into the issues you
mentioned in your correspondence.  This includes visiting with DARE
officials, a meeting with the Florida Board overseeing drug prevention
efforts in Florida, discussions and phone calls with coalition leaders, law
enforcement officials, students, and others.  

	You have raised a number of valid questions.  The officer who talked
to your daughter and her class, although not identified in your email, may
have inadvertently given ideas for drug abuse while trying to warn of the
dangers of them.  If you will tell me which school on which date, I will ask
that the lesson plan be reviewed.

	I have enclosed below a response I received from DARE that both
mentions the criticisms of DARE and their response to it.  The statement
that they are moving to scientifically proven methods of prevention is
correct.  I have verified that through other sources, to include discussions
with some of the leading scientists in this field.  I also know some of the
institutions they have partnered with, and they are among the most respected
in the nation.  I also traveled to Miami to meet with the incoming Director
for the Southeastern United States.  He is superb and I believe will bring a
great deal of effectiveness to his position.

	Aside from all of that, let me just share with you some of the
comments I heard from other parents, school officials, treatment providers,
prevention specialists, and law enforcement experts.  I will try to condense
them, but the themes were well developed and repeated across the spectrum by
a number of them.  Their flow goes something like this.

		DARE in the beginning may not have been steeped in the
science of prevention, but the field itself was undeveloped until very
recently.  Nor can we substantiate those things that did not happen (i.e.,
how many children were prevented from using drugs by the program) in the
past years.  But DARE came along at a time when no one else was attempting
to explain to children the problems of drug abuse.  Certainly the limited
exposure to a DARE class was not enough in itself to ensure a lifetime of
protection, but the dearth of other efforts does not diminish, thereof, the
importance of at least one message being given.  

		Moreover, DARE was and remains a critical link in the
connection between law enforcement and prevention.  In recent years, law
enforcement officials have come to appreciate how important the entire
integration of law enforcement, prevention, and treatment is.  DARE provides
one element of that connectivity, and to separate it would be a step back in
our overall approach to drug control.

		Finially, with the institution of best practices, which DARE
is now undertaking, with a great deal of effort invested in evaluation of
the effectiveness of the program, we can expect to see a vital system at
work.  In instances where there is little else to cover this need (and rural
areas was often cited as an example) and where the family does not reinforce
(indeed sometimes send a contrary message) the view that drug abuse is
harmful, DARE education becomes even more important.

		You apparantly have done an excellent job in raising your
6th grade child to be aware of the dangers of drugs.  Congratulations on
having done that.  Other families, however, are not so diligent.  DARE has
probably helped them in the past, and with their new methods of instruction,
shoulld be helpful in the future.

		Again, thank you for writing.  


	
Sincerely,


	
Jim McDonough


> Dear Governor Bush:
>
> My TWELVE year old little girl, who is in sixth grade, [elementary
> school
> here] informed me that she learned you could inject heroin in between
> toes,
> in belly buttons and behind ears in order to avoid detection from
> authorities.  I thought surely she learned this from a peer.  Sadly, it
> was
> the school "educating" my child with information we do not feel she
> needs to
> know at this young age, frankly my husband and I have made it through
> life
> quite well without having this knowledge.  This in no way is drug
> prevention!
>  It was taught by a School Resource Officer/DARE officer and her
> teacher.
> For the record, I opted my child out of this program and she has changed
> to a
> new teacher.  I have reviewed the DARE materials.  I did some research
> only
> to find the state does not sanction DARE, it is  neither a proven nor
> promising program, it was panned by a Federal Department of Justice
> report
> and the General Accounting Office reported, "There is little evidence so
> far
> that {D.A.R.E and other "resistance training" programs] have reduced the
> use
> of drugs by adolescents" [U.S. GAO/GGD-93-82].
>
> My question is why is the state and Federal government continuing to
> fund a
> program they KNOW does not work when used correctly?   Please stop
> funding
> programs KNOWN not to work.  I am working on the local level to change
> my
> district.  I have met with the Sheriff and requested they drop DARE next
>
> year, I have asked the school district to discontinue allowing
> principals to
> choose whatever program they want when the district has an adopted
> curriculum
> [for the record that program, Here's Looking at you 2000, is also not
> proven
> or promising].  My fourteen year old was just recently provided a
> worksheet
> that told her it was normal to want to "be one of the crowd".  It then
> went
> on to say "How can you be "one of the crowd and resist doing drugs?"
> Governor, we have taught her to RUN, don't walk to the nearest exit!
>
> I realize that my children are not immune from daily pressures, but in
> some
> ways I believe the "education" they are receiving in the arena of drug
> education seems to send them a message that this behavior is the norm.
> I
> don't see any real reality check for kids by telling them that drug
> and/or
> alcohol can ruin your life and those you love, that they might only try
> something once and be a prisoner to something forever and that it simply
> is
> not worth it.
>
> I know this issue is personal and I genuinely do not wish to cause any
> undue
> pain.  If I have, I am sorry.  I simply feel that when an issue such as
> DARE
> is recognized as not working then the funds should stop which would
> ensure
> the program is stopped.
>
> Respectfully,
> Shannon

> Also, below, please find a good memo from The Heritage Foundation on the
> positive impact of the depreciation tax deferral.  It rejects static
> analysis and, among other things, estimates that Florida could create
> 10,500 new jobs (or 2,100 new jobs per year) over the next five years
> because of the bonus depreciation.
> 
> 
> 
> --------------------------------------------------------------------------
> --------------------------------------------------------------------------
> --------------------------------------------------------------------------
> ----------------------------
> 
> 
>  <<...OLE_Obj...>> 
> 
> DEPRECIATION TAX BREAKS FOR BUSINESS MEANS STRONGER REVENUES FOR STATE
> GOVERNMENTS  by Bill W. Beach
> 
> Some state governments are concerned that allowing businesses to reduce
> their taxes by accelerating some of their depreciation will cut deeply
> into state revenues. This concern is misplaced. Rather than hurt, lower
> business taxes leads to greater prosperity, which means stronger state
> revenues.
> 
> In the purely static world of revenue accountants, any tax relief cuts
> government's revenues. But, in the world we actually live in, lower
> businesses taxes leads to greater economic growth, more jobs, and stronger
> revenues. 
> 
> Indeed, Congress's recently enacted economic stimulus legislation will
> lead to thousands of new jobs all across the country. Additional job
> growth means stronger sales and state income tax revenues, more income
> from property tax levies, and healthier revenues from business profits and
> franchise taxes.
> 	Remember:
> 		*	The 30% depreciation allowance for businesses will
> create thousands of new jobs, primarily in the first three years. These
> new jobs will create new income from which new income taxes can be drawn.
> That means that state revenues from income taxes will rise because there
> is a larger base of revenue built on these new jobs.
> 		*	Businesses income should also rise, which will
> strengthen revenues from state profits or franchise taxes. Accelerated
> depreciation will lower the cost of capital, which should lead to business
> buying more equipment and expanding their activities. The big beneficiary
> of higher business activity should be the state sales and use tax.
> 		*	Yet another beneficiary of this pro-growth tax law
> change is the state budget. Decreasing the cost of capital should lead to
> lower interest rates. That means that state general obligation and revenue
> bonds will cost state government less in the future, not more. Of course,
> anytime state borrowing costs fall, the chances are better that state
> surpluses will grow. Again, a growing economy supports better, not worse,
> fiscal performance by state governments. 
> 			 <<...OLE_Obj...>> 
> 			 <<...OLE_Obj...>> 
> 
> 	-Bill W. Beach <http://www.heritage.org/STAFF/beach.htm> is Director
> of the Center for Data Analysis at The Heritage Foundation.
> 
> 
>

-----Original Message-----
From: Muniz, Katie [mailto:Katie.Muniz@MyFlorida.com]
Sent: Thursday, May 02, 2002 8:05 AM
To: Jeb Bush; Shanahan, Kathleen; Jimenez, Frank; Yablonski, Brian;
Brown, Brewser; PRESS OFFICE
Cc: Grant, Wendy; Bill Edmonds (E-mail); Branker, Laura
Subject: Tampa Trib -One Florida


Jeb's One Florida Program Is A Winner For Minorities

Published: May 2, 2002 
T he hard numbers continue to show that despite all protests, Gov. Jeb
Bush's One Florida plan is notably helping minorities. 
The governor took a lot of grief when he abruptly adopted the plan to
eliminate racial quotas. The move was aimed at defusing a referendum
campaign to eliminate affirmative action, which would have greatly
restricted the state's ability to aid minorities. 
So the governor adopted a plan that guarantees the top 20 percent of
students in every high school senior class are accepted into a state
university if those students have taken preparatory classes. 
The plan also eliminated set-aside hiring of minority contractors by
agencies that report to the governor. Instead, the governor gave a clear
directive to the agencies: Minority businesses should be hired when
possible, records will be kept on minority hiring and agency heads will be
held accountable for the department's performance. 
For his good efforts, the governor was accused of abandoning minorities. Two
lawmakers protested in his office. Opponents still depict him as
unsympathetic to minorities. 
This is simply not true. The governor is committed to diversity, as his
appointments and policies show. If he made a mistake with One Florida, it
was rushing ahead without waiting to build support. 
One Florida was designed to help minorities. Statistics show it is working.
Consider how it has affected state contracts: 
Since One Florida was adopted, state spending with certified minority
businesses has more than doubled and most of that increase has come in the
governor's agencies. These departments, which fall under his One Florida
rule, have nearly tripled their annual certified minority spending, compared
to that of the prior administration. 
In fiscal year 1998-1999, the governor's agencies spent $151 million with
minority businesses. By 2000-2001, that figure had increased 160 percent to
$392 million. And the figure is on track to be even higher this fiscal year.

The state also has increased spending on nonprofit organizations that
benefit minority populations. 
As we've reported before, One Florida has not hurt minority enrollment in
the state university system. This year 1,250 more minority students entered
the systems than the year before One Florida took effect. And minority
enrollment continues to be about 36 percent of the entering classes. 
Clearly, One Florida has not resulted in the resegregation of the state
university system, as some critics claimed it would. 
It certainly appears the governor has developed an intelligent, quota-free
way to aid minorities, and perhaps it's time to clear Gov. Bush of the
charge - the lie - that he is indifferent to the plight of minorities.

From:	Jeb Bush
Sent:	Thursday, May 2, 2002 1:01 PM

From: Dana, Pam

To: Shanahan, Kathleen; 'jeb@jeb.org'
Cc: Polito, Kelley; Hartman, Jean
Subject: FW: Enterprise Florida


See below, a letter from George Koehn to me regarding EFI's request to scale
down their performance measurements required under OTTED contract.  I do not
want to water down their performance standards to a point which doesn't
challenge them...however, I am okay to find a suitable middle ground of
measurement.  I am not sure who told George that OTTED refused to adjust
standards as it is not true and I will let him know this.  I can always
excuse their not meeting measurements as it is my discretion as director.
My main wish is for EFI to set challenging goals and then do what they can
to meet them.  If they can not, then I will evaluate whether their not
meeting them was justifyable.

On a side, the real hurdle for EFI on performance measurements is the Senate
and House staff who have voiced discontent w/ reducing measurements.

From:	KLowe36386@aol.com
Sent:	Thursday, May 2, 2002 3:24 PM
To:	costinl@vr.doe.state.fl.us; Jeb Bush; sullivan.don.web@leg.state.fl.us; carlton.lisa.web@leg.state.fl.us; villalobos.alex.web@leg.state.fl.us; Pruitt.ken.web@leg.state.fl.us; Mitchell.Richard.web@leg.state.fl.us
Subject:	Adults with Disabilities Funding

We have learned that Department of Education staff has asked that funds
be taken from the Adult Handicapped Fund in order to address deficits in
the VR and Blind Services Programs.   It is extremely unfair to adults
with disabilities that one of the programs benefiting them should be
compromised in order to benefit another.  The individuals who receive
the benefits of the Adult Basic Education provided through the Adult
Handicapped Fund are those who will likely never be able to be
competitively employed, and therefore, not able to benefit from VR
services.  In Miami-Dade, approximately 2,863 adults with disabilities
are registered at 25+ agencies.  Each receives an average of 25-30 hours
of educational services weekly.  While we recognize that there are many
competing funding priorities, we urge you NOT to reduce funding for the
DOE's Adult Handicapped Program.

In Brevard County over 329 students are being served daily and trying improve the quality of their lives.   The ABE program instruction advances their skills of self-determination and vastly improves the quality of their lives.  Besides, this is their right as citizens of this state!

In addition, individuals with disabilities must have a place to enhance skills for the rest of their lives and to prepare for supported employment before going to VR for services.  

It is inexplicable why this population's rights must continuously be the subject of the financial climate of the times and constantly be put at risk.  

Brevard County, as a result of the performance-based funding approach started two years ago, is making great strides toward improving and enhancing the self-determination of our ABE clients.  

Thank you.

From:	Charles Lee <chlee2@earthlink.net>

Subject:	RE: Everglades Bill, HB 813

Jeb:

The Everglades bill has been transmitted to you; obviously we hope you will soon sign this important legislation.

In response to some of the concerns raised by others about the "standing" amendment put on this bill by Sen. King, I have prepared the attached two page analysis (MS word format) which I think is helpful in explaining the actual limited nature of the changes to "standing" caused by the amendment to this bill. 

As I have said previously, I think that the angst caused to some by this amendment is best answered by an approach which says "we will carefully monitor its impact and advocate any corrective changes found necessary". 



Charles

From:	paul sayers <ps3073@worldnet.att.net>
Sent:	Thursday, May 2, 2002 4:44 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	FPL  Power Plant, Parrish, FL

Governor Bush

It is time to require the FPL plant located in Manatee County to install an
SCR
emission control system. The plant has operated for about 30 years as a high
load auxiliary supply facility. As such, it has historically operated at
relatively
low average percentage of peak output capacity. That has changed and the use
of the plant has increased enough to increase pollution by 20%. There is no
good reason to allow any increase in pollution when there is an effective
and
economic method to control/reduce emissions such as SCR. Also, now that
natural gas will be available to that plant it should be the required fuel
for at
least 60% of the produced power regardless of demand levels or fuel costs.

Many of us in Manatee County gave our time, expertise and money to defeat
Orimulsion. We believe that the next step must be taken: Require FPL to meet
stricter emission control standards.

Respectfully;

Paul Sayers
Parrish, FL
Chairman, Manatee County Planning Commission

-----Original Message-----
From: CDEAlliance [mailto:kids@cdealliance.org]
Sent: Monday, April 29, 2002 10:38 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Early Chidhood


Dear Gov. Bush,
 
It was good to see you in Jacksonville recently.  I am excited to see your interest in early childhood initiatives.  There are a couple of things I want to bring to your attention just in case no one else has.
 
First, you may remember the discussion about the very good tape that David Lawrence has made for parents regarding the development of their children.  It really is excellent, however I was a little concerned to see that former Gov. Lawton Chiles and the present mayor of Miami were given all the credit for the work being done in early childhood.  If he is giving it away to all the PBS stations, I would feel better if he would either add you to the credits or take that segment out of the tape.  It may be a small thing, but it could influence many voting parents.
 
Second, the surprised look on your face when I mentioned the effect of removing 4 year olds from the private and faith-based sector would have on infant/toddler care, told me that no one has explained the bigger picture to you.  Butch Cronon and I have been trying to explain this to the partnership board for the last couple of months.  The child care infrastructure is very fragile.  Parents simply cannot afford the true cost of care.  Butch opened his infant room back up recently and had to charge parents over $200 per week to cover the cost of that room.  If more money is designated to 4 year old pre-k without careful consideration of financial cause and effect on the 70 to 80% of private centers, it could cause great harm.
 
If you receive the $41million from the legislature you are asking for, please do not give it to the Partnership Board to decide how to spend without first letting Butch and I explain our concerns to you more fully.  I realize you are very busy, but this is truly important and I would appreciate your consideration of my request.  Thank you again for giving me a chance to make a difference for young children and for inclusion of our faith and values in what we teach.
 
Sincerely,
Ellen McKinley
 
PS  I will let you know by the end of May how the Jacksonville model is working out.  If it is accepted, it will be the first time I know of that a consortium of providers from the public schools, Head Start, the university system, central agencies, and faith-based have worked together.

the F-22 Raptor and F-35 Joint Strike Fighter.  I know that you are aware of
the importance of both of these weapons programs in maintaining US defense
presence worldwide, as well as providing high value jobs and advanced
technology to our defense industry.

Unison will be hosting a visit from the Showcase of Power on Friday here in
our Jacksonville facility on May 3.  The Showcase of Power, sponsored by
engine maker Pratt & Whitney, is a mobile exhibit intended to educate the
public on the importance of the F-22 and F-35 JSF engine programs in support
of American technology, jobs and freedom.  The exhibit features a
surround-sound theater so visitors can experience the thrill of flight, and
a full-size engine model with system maintainability and sustainability
demonstrations.  It is all housed in a 75' long tractor trailer truck.  I
saw this exhibit at our facility in Fort Worth and it is an impressive
sight.

I am hopeful that you can join all of our employees at our facility on May 3
at 11:00 AM to learn more about these critical propulsion systems.  We look
forward to a fun and informative event.


Best regards,
Brian Wenzel
Marketing Communications Manager
Unison Industries
7575 Baymeadows Way
Jacksonville, FL 32256
TEL:  904-739-4178
FAX:  904-739-4006
wenzel_br@unisonindustries.com

-----Original Message----- 
From: Jack Levine [mailto:martycfc@nettally.com] 
Sent: Thursday, May 02, 2002 6:31 PM 
To: ADVOCATE ALERT 
Subject: ADVOCATE ALERT - Rilya Wilson Update 

Dear Child Advocate: 

The complicated circumstances surrounding the Rilya Wilson case are changing by the hour. The Kansas City police could not verify the identity of the body found last April based on the insufficient palm prints sent from Miami, so DNA testing is now planned. We've learned that over the past 15-months, the missing Miami 5-year-old was not cared for by a grandmother, but a godmother.  Miami dependency court authorities, the state attorney, police, and the Department of Children & Families are all launching full investigations into the case history and possible whereabouts of the child. By the time you read this note, we're certain a cascade of other information will have poured forth.

This morning's inaugural meeting of the House Select Committee on Oversight of the Department of Children & Families - a short 45-minute orientation session - barely addressed the Wilson case or the growing crisis in protection of children. Committee Chair Sandra Murman announced a second more intensive hearing for next Thursday, May 9th, during which testimony will be accepted. Upon adjournment today, however, the media surged to interview Secretary Kate Kearney and others who have responsibilities in the Rilya Wilson case. To her credit, Secretary Kearney is accepting a full measure of responsibility for the inadequate case neglect, and has pledged a thorough review of the cases of all children in protective custody.

The sense of tension over the fate of Rilya is intensified by the feeling that there may be hundreds, if not thousands, of other children in our child protection system who are not being properly supervised, not receiving the services they need, and may be in some danger. This is a crisis of confidence which must be recognized and corrected.  New laws will not solve the problem. Like a cookbook without groceries, laws without resources are ineffective. 

The media is a hungry beast. Its appetite is voracious, especially when a case unfolds with the intrigue and intensity of this one. It is our job as advocates is to put faces on the facts, and put the facts in context of real need. Our intent is to leverage the circumstances of today's outrage into policy and program improvements.

The invitations are pouring in. I am appearing on the O'Reilly Factor tonight, Thursday, which broadcasts on FOX NEWS at 8:00 PM Eastern and repeats at 11:00PM. Calls for interviews are being received from across the nation and several from Europe! We are honored to be asked to translate today's crisis into words which inform and inspire action.

Having your support and feedback is vital and valued.....Feel free to forward our Advocate Alerts to your network. Please keep us posted.....we'll do the same......

Jack Levine 
Center for Florida's Children 
center@floridakids.com

> 
> Greetings,
> 
> The Agency for Health Care Administration would like to thank you for your
> generous participation in the policy development and rule making process.
> We value your input and recognize the importance of the Home and
> Community-Based Services, and their impact on the individuals they serve.
> The formal notice of our intent to promulgate the Developmental Services
> Waiver Services Coverage and Limitations Handbook into rule,   is
> scheduled to appear in the May 3, 2002, issue of the Florida
> Administrative Weekly.  
> 
> The hearing will be held at the Agency headquarters, located at 2727 Mahan
> Drive, Tallahassee, on Tuesday, May 28, 2002.  Specific suggestions for
> changes will be accepted between 10 a.m. and noon in Conference Room D of
> Building # 3.  Comments by e-mail, letter, etc., will also be accepted
> prior to the rule hearing; attendance is not required.  By public request,
> we plan to establish a conference call during the hearing, linking
> Conference Room D with the local Developmental Disabilities' District
> offices. 
> 
> For those who may be uncertain about what has been done since the handbook
> workshops were held January - March, please allow me to provide some
> clarification and information regarding the rule promulgation process.
> Public input has been acknowledged and reviewed.  As a result of this
> input, and other review processes within the Agency, the original version
> of the handbook underwent some meaningful revisions.  We were able to
> incorporate many of the comments and recommendations received by phone,
> e-mail and during the workshops, and additional appendices have been
> included in this version of the handbook.  Comments and recommendations
> not incorporated were noted, or are being referred to the  "Redesign
> Committee."  The compilation of public input will be sent to you in a
> second e-mail today.
> 
> Because the redesign process is also a lengthy one, we expect the
> promulgation of the handbook into rule will take place by July 1, 2002,
> and the committee's redesign activities will continue over the next year.
> Any changes to the waiver services, resulting from the outcome of the
> redesign efforts, will necessitate appropriate revisions to the handbook
> and rule and possibly the waiver itself.  
> 
> You are receiving sections of the revised handbook as attachments, to this
> mass e-mail distribution today.  This version reflects changes made to the
> January 2002 version.  Please note, new language is identified with an
> underline and deleted language is identified with a strike-through. Since
> this is an edit draft, you will notice blank areas in the documents.  It
> will be reformatted later, when all edits are complete.  If you have any
> questions or concerns, about the documents, please do not hesitate to
> contact us. 
> 
> 
> Michelle K. Brantley
> Bureau Chief
> Medicaid Health Systems Development
> Agency for Health Care Administration

From:	James Clark <anark@istal.com>
Sent:	Thursday, May 2, 2002 8:46 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Appointment to federal position
Attachments:	WEP_24a.doc

Dear Governor Bush.

I was informed that Agriculture was going inside to fill the position of
Administrator for Food and Nutrition.  Following the interview, I think it
was a wise decision as I was viewed as too conservative by Deputy Secretary
Bose, and it would have been uncomfortable for both of us.  I deeply
appreciate your assistance and efforts in my behalf.

I have some time now and I hope that I can be of assistance to you in your
campaign.  

I am finishing a paper for City University of New York on Mayor Giuliani's
welfare reform initiatives.  I spent time in the city meeting with welfare
officials and have a draft of the first part of the report.  I am attaching
it to this email as I believe the Mayor did some things that were unique and
may represent things that your Workforce and Technical Skills folks should
examine. 

I am working on a second part of the New York story that addresses
initiatives he took to stem welfare fraud.  These too were unique and unlike
anything I saw in the my time as welfare reform director for Governor
Martinez or as Secretary in South Carolina.  I will pass that along to you
also when it is complete.

Judge Kearny was on the tube today defending her department against
accusations of failing to protect children.  I had lunch with her and two of
her deputies two years ago and gave her some suggestions on things she might
do to address the child protection issue.  I believe she has taken action on
many of the issues that I suggested.

The issue of confidentiality (today's featured subject) is one that I had to
address in South Carolina.  I worked with the General Assembly to alter the
law in a manner that allowed me to discuss issues with more freedom.  After
passage, I was allowed to discuss issues that were known by virtue of being
reported in the press, to answer allegations made by persons accused of
abuse and to meet behind closed doors with members who wanted more knowledge
of a particular case.  Another initiative that I started was to initiate a
high level committee of department lawyers, advocates and others to discuss
each case of a child who died or dissapeared to ascertain if there was a
need for training, legislation, or personnel actions.  This helped the cases
"stay alive" and also allowed the training staff to use case history for
case oriented training.

You can never win these issues by attempting to shield yourself behind a
need to keep information confidential or by denying the seriousness of the
issue.  The public wants someone to pay for any harm that comes to an abused
child and when government officials appear to concealing information or not
recognizing the horror of an act it often becomes time for falling on
swords.  If you want a copy of the five pages of suggestions that I gave the
judge let me know. 

If you will put me in touch with your Campaign Director I will meet with
them to see how I might be my time to use in your behalf.  Thank you again
for all of your assistance and kindness.


Jim Clark

Subject:	Additional Corporate Tax Breaks

corporate tax break over the next three years.  I support reasonable efforts 
to enhance economic development, however the extent of this action is 
excessive.

Jeb-

Highly recommend a dear friend who was a former navy captain who retired
after 27 years of service in the Navy.  Bill Dickson was born in Escambia
County and still resides there.  He flew over 250 missions off the USS
Nimitz, Enterprise and Kitty Hawk as a squadron commander in Veitnam.  After
Vietnam he became the CO of the Naval Aviation School Command and after that
he became the CO of the Pensacola Naval Air Station.

I know Bill from his post-Navy career at Sacred Heart Hospital in Pensacola.
This guy is rock solid.

tony

-----Original Message-----
From: Edgar R Schneider [mailto:hansachsthegreat@juno.com]

Thank you for your response to my e-letter, in which I expressed concern
about the way in which the INS handled what I think was a questionable
entry into this country by a Russian family.  (The response was signed by
Armando Vilaboy.)  I only have one question.  

Mr. Vilaboy's letter told me to contact the local INS enforcement office,
and gave a phone number.  In my original e-mail, I mentioned no names,
but said that I would gladly furnish that information should you share my
concern.  Is there a particular INS enforcement officer that I should
contact?  Would there be someone there who would know of the suspicions
that I wrote about in contacting you?  I am asking because I do not want
to have to unnecessarily call them up blindly.

BTW, the phone number given to me, in Mr. Vilaboy's letter, for your
local office, is no longer in service.

Ed  ("Edgar", if you must be formal)
