-----Original Message-----
From: literarychick28@netscape.net [mailto:literarychick28@netscape.net]
Sent: Thursday, May 02, 2002 1:32 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: re: school interview


Hello Governor Bush,
Thank you very much for agreeing to do this interview. Here is a list of questions that I had prepared about issues facing students as well as your experiences.

-Why do you think that it is important to support the Florida Virtual School? IT HAS THE POTENTIAL OF HELPING TO REDEFINE EDUCATION. IT IS STUDENT CENTERED AND CAN BE USED IN SO MANY WAYS .... REMEDIATION, HONORS/AP CLASSES FOR STUDENTS WHO CAN'T ACCESS THEM, ETC.

-Do you foresee other schools of a similar design popping up around the country? YES BUT IN OUR STATE IT IS MY HOPE THAT WE DON'T TRY TO REINVENT THE WHEEL AND CONTINUE TO SUPPORT FLORIDA VIRTUAL SCHOOL.

-Do you think that online learning would have been beneficial when you were growing up or perhaps would have benefited your children? GOSH, I AM SO OLD I CAN REMEMBER BLACK AND WHITE TELEVISIONS! ON LINE LEARNING WOULD HAVE BEEN VERY USEFUL TO ME.

-Do you think that the Virtual School will be able to issue diplomas to its students in the near future? I HOPE SO.

-Many critics argue that FLVS is not an effective educational medium because of the lack of interaction among students and faculty. However, AP (Advanced Placement) scores among Virtual School students exceed the national average by nearly nine percent. What is your comment about this apparent contradiction? THE VIRTUAL SCHOOL IS NOT FOR EVERYONE. BUT IT IS A GOOD MEANS TO ACCELERATE LEARNING FOR KIDS THAT DON'T NEED AS MUCH ATTENTION.

-There has been a considerable amount of media coverage on the recent cell phone controversies facing school districts across America. Some believe that students should be allowed to keep these devices on campus as long as they are not turned on, whereas others protest that such technologies would serve as nothing but a distraction. Where do you stand and why? I HAVE NOT FOLLOWED THE ISSUE BUT NOW i WILL!

-The SWAT (Students Working Against Tobacco) program, which was founded under the Chiles administration, received a considerable budget cut in October, with a large portion of that money being redistributed to enhance road development. Do you think that it will be important to restore the funds for this program? THE TOBACCO PROGRAM IS DOING FINE. WE ARE SPENDING $39 MILLION DOLLARS. THAT WAS WHAT IS BEING SPENT LAST YEAR. THAT IS A LOT OF DOUGH!

-If funding is not able to be replaced, what are some of the initiatives that can be taken to continue efforts to decrease youth smoking? TEEN SMOKING IS DOWN IN OUR STATE WHICH IS A GOOD THING.

-Due to increased security after September 11, do you think that there has been a decrease in youth involvement in the government, such as the TeenPact program for Christian homeschoolers or the senate page program, in which Stephen York, a Florida Virtual School student, participates? I HAVE NOT NOTICED A DECLINE IN YOUTH INVOLVEMENT. IN FACT, I THINK THERE HAS BEEN MORE CIVIC INVOLVEMENT THAN BEFORE THAT I HOPE CAN BE SUSTAINED.

-I am sure that you are aware of the teacher shortage facing the state of Florida. What would you say to high schoolers or college students to encourage them to pursue a career in the field of education? THE LAWS OF SUPPLY AND DEMAND APPLY TO THE TEACHING PROFESSION. THERE WILL BE GREAT OPPORTUNITIES IN TEACHING IN THE NEXT DECADE. TEACHING IS A VERY NOBLE PROFESSION!

-What factors influenced your decision to attend the college that you did? I WENT TO HIGH SCHOOL IN THE NORTHEAST US AND WANTED TO GO BACK HOME SO I ATTENDED THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS. 

-What is something that you now know that you wish you would have known while in school? I KNOW NOW NOT TO BE IN QUITE THE RUSH I WAS IN BACK THEN. I GRADUATED IN 2.5 YEARS.

-Your mother seems to be a pretty amazing woman. What is the most important piece of advice that she gave you, and have you shared this with your own children? LOVE MY WIFE AND CHILDREN MORE THAN LIFE ITSELF. THAT IS EASY TO DO!

-What advice would you give to the siblings of particularly high achievers? WORK HARD.

-Growing up in a political family, when did you decide that this would be the area that you would go into? What other fields had you considered? I FIRST GOT INVOLVED IN POLITICS TO HELP MY DAD WHO I TRULY LOVE. I OVERCAME MY FEARS OF SPEAKING IN PUBLIC AND BEGAN TO UNDERSTAND THE JOYS OF SERVICE BY WATCHING MY DAD IN HIS PUBLIC SERVICE. IN 1993 I DECIDED TO MAKE THE LEAP. I HAD BEEN IN THE PRIVATE SECTOR UNTIL THEN.

-Has it been difficult to maintain your own identity instead of just being one of “the Bush boys?” I STOPPED WORRYING ABOUT WHAT PEOPLE THINK A WHILE BACK AND NOW FOCUS ON HOW I CAN SERVE AND HELP OTHERS.

-Integrity is an important quality for all of humanity, but especially those who have achieved celebrity status as political figures. What suggestions do you have for the next generation of voters who are exposed to negative campaigning and apparent lack of morality on the part of some elected officials? SAY WHAT YOU ARE GOING TO DO AND DO WHAT YOU SAID YOU WOULD DO. DON'T VEER FROM PRINCIPLE. BE HONEST WITH YOURSELF. SHOW HUMILITY. FIGHT HARD BUT FIGHT FAIR.

-What do you think of such government based shows as NBC’S “The West Wing?” Do you feel that these give an accurate portrayal of political life? I DON'T WATCH WEST WING.

-What is one of your stronger contributions that you would like to see communicated, but that you fear may be overshadowed by other platforms in the upcoming campaign? MOVING OUR STATE TOWARDS RISING STUDENT ACHIEVEMENT BEING THE MISSION AND CALLING OF ALL FLORIDIANS. 


Once again, I wanted to thank you very much for your time. I am also a student writer for the St. Petersburg Times and would like to run some of your comments as a follow-up to some of the other articles that I had written.

Thank you,
Autumn Siegel
Literarychick28@netscape.net

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
TO: St. Petersburg Times
RE:  Database designed to track drug use (May 2, 2002)
 
  I gladly support the state of Florida, Gov. Jeb Bush and James McDonough in supporting efforts to a database tracking system regarding drug use. Drugs such as OxyContin, Codeine, Morphine and other opiates are highly addictive and have the potential to destroy lives. Their intended purpose is to relieve pain.  Unfortunately, drug abuse and addiction is a very serious problem in our country today.  We need to examine new ways to deal with this ever growing problem.  This database would be closed to the public.  The goal is to assist law enforcement agencies, doctors and Department of Health employees in making sure people aren't abusing legal drugs.  This protects patients and the doctors and creates a win-win for both.  
I pray for our leaders in government to use their talents, titles and positions to benefit the welfare of our nation. By working together, the stepping stones are being laid in a way that touches us all, directly or indirectly.   
 
 
Sharon Blair
7364 118th Drive
Largo,  Fl. 33773
727-535-1206 
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

----- Original Message ----- 
From: McDonough, Jim <mailto:Jim.McDonough@MyFlorida.com>

Sent: Thursday, May 02, 2002 3:15 PM
Subject: RE: FROM: SHARON BLAIR

    Thanks.  I'm glad you're in support.  Write the St. Pete Times, if you will; they are about to do an editorial opposing it.

-----Original Message-----
From: Sharon Blair [mailto:jblair02@tampabay.rr.com]
Sent: Thursday, May 02, 2002 1:44 PM
To: McDonough, Jim
Subject: FROM: SHARON BLAIR


Jim,
 
   Hello.  I hope you are doing well.
 
I read in today's St.Petersburg Times, (Thursday, May 2, 2002) the front page article in regards to the database that would monitor drug use.  (Prior to Jennifer's latest detox in February at PAR) 
Jennifer had been receiving methadone (pill form)  by a local pain management doctor.  This alarmed me greatly that a patient can walk into a doctor's office and walk out with a prescription for the highly addictive drug methadone.  Addicts love doctors like this. This doctor needs to be monitored who he is giving methadone to.  Here is the doctor's name Jennifer went to and received methadone.
 
Mark Kantzler, DO.,  PA
5318  Duhme Road
Maderia Florida  33708
Phone: (727) 398-3011
 
Currently, Jennifer is on daily methadone at PAR by Dr. Benson. Jennifer told me her dosage had to be increased last week from 65 mg. to 68 mg. per day.  She was going into symptoms of withdrawal
(uncomfortable, sweating, etc.).  She said her body gets used to the dose and then requires more.
There must be some other answer to Jennifer's opiate addiction.
 
 I continue praying daily for Jennifer and asking God's help and intervention.  My grandson, Trey, needs his mother to be healthy and sober. I do not have all the answers to all the complexities of Jennifer's addiction. 
 
This I do know:  An addict can refuse drug treatment for their drug addiction.  Families can do nothing but watch the addiction progress.  There is The Marchman Act.  It's good for a 72 hour window of assessment / observation.  That's as good as it gets. That is why I wrote the Jennifer Act. 
 
I support the plan to track doctors who prescribe methadone and all opiates, including OxyContin, morphine and codeine. 
 
Sincerely,
 
Sharon Blair

From:	tom barnette <tom@eatours.com>
Sent:	Friday, May 3, 2002 12:24 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Re: New Orleans Pow Wow fup

FYI

Basically it is this - as you know, Thom Stork was employed by SeaWorld
until last January/February.  Since then he has become the Director of the
Florida Aquarium in Tampa.  Thus, because he will be residing in Tampa he is
no longer eligible to sit on the commission representing the Orlando region.
Instead, in order to be on the commission he must fill a seat in my region.

The only seat beoming available is the one I am currently in and it is open
as of June 30th.  I understand that I have the option to apply for
reappointment.  I also understand from Austin Mott that Thom Stork plans to
apply for my seat.    So, I have decided that if you feel  it would better
suit the needs of the commission and Florida for Thom to take this seat then
I am prepared to astep aside.

You should know that my preference is to stay in my current position.
However, I serve at your pleasure and for the State and I will support any
decision you make.   Austin has indicated  he is waiting for me to advise
him if I plan to reapply or not.  I told him I would let him know in due
time.

I have taken enough of your time tonight.

Thanks,

Tom

From: TonyVillamil@aol.com [mailto:TonyVillamil@aol.com]

To: smorrell@mail.barry.edu; Samacmanus@aol.com; mlasaga@stratinfo.com; holcombe@coss.fsu.edu; hankf@fishkind.com; bdickens@psc.state.fl.us; abryan@miami.edu; sbrown2@ecm.rjf.com; ctwest@ufl.edu; chudere@fiu.edu; rharper@uwf.edu

From:	Jeb Bush
Sent:	Friday, May 3, 2002 9:16 AM
To:	'WrightC3@brevard.k12.fl.us'
Subject:	FW: EDUCATION !!

Ms. Wright, I have no clue who is providing you with information but let me set the record straight.

I have never said teachers are doing a lousy job. I fully understand the challenges you face which is why we continue to increase funding for programs like the national board certification for teachers (we are approaching the number state in the country).

Funding is higher today than it was prior to me being governor. For the upcoming budget year, we will see close to a 9% increase, which is equal to 6% per student and over $1 billion. For the four years, the total increase will be 27% and over $3 billion. These increases are greater than my predecessor's first or second term. Taking into consideration student population growth and inflation, the numbers are higher than before. 

We are not in the bottom five states in terms of per student funding and that funding is increasing.

Finally, the corporate tax issue is not a tax cut but a tax deferral which only will come into play if a business invests which will increase the chance of job creation. The money will come back to government. 

Thanks for allowing me to correct the record. I appreciate your writing.

Jeb Bush 

***********************************************************
Please note: Florida has a very broad public records law.
Most written communications to or from state officials
regarding state business are public records available to the
public and media upon request.   Your e-mail communications
may therefore be subject to public disclosure. 



-----Original Message-----
From: Wright, Cathy@UPark [mailto:WrightC3@brevard.k12.fl.us]
Sent: Friday, May 03, 2002 8:45 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: EDUCATION !!


Dear Governor Bush,
262 million     tax savings for corporations.  Yes, by all means, let's give
Big Business more money.  
It's a pity that money couldn't go into education, creating more teaching
jobs to help get funding back to where it was before you became governor.  I
am a teacher in a Title 1 school - I've been here for 28 years and I'm not
going anywhere - but if I was just starting out I sure wouldn't go into
teaching.  Last year you said Teachers in the state of Florida are doing a
lousy job.  Well, I think we perform miracles every day - and we will
continue to - but the more children in each class, the harder it will be to
give each and every child the attention he needs.  Studies have shown time
and time again that class size has a huge effect on achievement. That's
tried and true.  You see, the more children you put in a class, the less
time a teacher has to work induvidually with those children who are in
danger of being left behind. 
Education funding in Florida is in the bottom 5 states on money spent per
student. I can't imagine how anyone could give himself the title "Education
Governor" & spend so little on education!! Seems to me that title should be
earned.  

How will this tax cut help in the overall plan - "No child left behind?"

Sincerely,
Cathy S. Wright
From:	Milton & Berthy Aponte <apontemb@juno.com>

AponteMB@juno.com>
To: kelly_leah@bcpsgw.broward.k12.fl.us
Date: Fri, 3 May 2002 08:20:35 -0400
Subject: Adults with Disabilities Funds in Jeopardy
 
Leah:  
 
Thanks for the information.  I am not very familiar with the adult handicapped fund. Based on the e-mail information and some familiarity with the programs, I am not sure that you will agree with me, but as usual, I must be honest.  
 
To begin, I do not agree with the attitude reflected in statement that reads "those 22 and older transitioning to adult day programs".  Instead, the attitude should for VR and the school system to facilitate and encourage for "those over 22 and older should" transitio to employment and other integrated community alternatives.  The reality is that specially with students that have significant disabilities, the schools and VR continue to emphasize adult day training programs as opposed to employment or other integrated alternatives, during transitioning IE PLANS & meetings. This perpetuates segregation, isolation, and dependency.   People with disabilities will never have equality, unless the system gives then the opportunity.  
 
That attitude, and the paradigm needs to change.  We need to work in changing the system to one that believes that even people with most significant disabilities can be employable, if they have the proper support, services, education and encouragement.  
 
Berthy

On 2 May 2002 12:51:40 -0400 "Kelly Leah" <kelly_leah@bcpsgw.broward.k12.fl.us> writes:

garner support.

From: Meryl Eisenberg on 2, May 2002,  2:41 AM
Subject: Adults with Disabilities Funds in Jeopardy
To: Mulvihill Patrick
File(s): text.html
 
 
Hi Pat,
 
Would appreciate your sending this email to  Jeanne at Deerfield Beach High
School and anyone else who may have connections in advocating for state
dollars for adults with disabilities. ( If the state decides to eliminate the
funding or take 14 million off the 18 million pot, there would be barely any
$$ in Broward to provide services to adults in day training programs or
off-campus programs to those 22 and older transitioning to adult day programs
like Goodwill, Lucanus or the off-campus programs  that support those who are
on the Medicaid waiver in agencies and those are the waiting list in our
off-campus programs or those whom VR does not make eligible for services.  We
have had a  waiting list for months in our day programs as well.    Time is of
the essence.
 
The Legislature is in a special session and the Adult Handicapped Fund is once
again under siege.  This time it appears that the Governor wants to take the 
Adult Handicapped  Funds in order to address deficits in the VR and Blind
Services Programs. (VR needs to get a state match of federal funds so they
want to attach these funds to VR instead of the school systems throughout the
state.)    
It is extremely unfair to adults with disabilities that one of the programs
benefiting them should be compromised in order to benefit another.  The
individuals who receive the benefits of the Adults with Disabilities Funds are
those who likely never will be able to be competitively employed and
therefore, not be able to benefit from VR Services.  In Broward County alone ,
approximately 1300 adults with disabilities are registered at 18 agencies. 
Each receives an average of 25-30 hours of educational services weekly.  While
there are many competitive funding opportunities, we urge you not to reduce
funding for the DOE's Adult Handicapped Program-
 
Email the message to:
 
Senator Ken  Pruitt     Pruitt.kenweb@leg.state.fl.us
Representative Evelyn Lynn    Lynn.evelynweb@leg.state.fl.us
Representative Carlos Lacasa    Lacasa.carlos@leg.state.fl.us
 
 
and probably Senator Donald Sullivan as well.
 
Appreciate any follow-though you may be able to do with our agency partners or
parent advocates.
 
Thanks,
 
Meryl

From:	Carolyn_Kieswetter@doh.state.fl.us
Sent:	Friday, May 3, 2002 9:43 AM
To:	Jeb Bush; mckay.john.web@leg.state.fl.us; feeney.tom@leg.state.fl.us
Subject:	Florida Budget

It has been called to my attention that our state stands to lose $400 million over the next three years due to the possible linking of state law with the tax break in the federal "2002 Job Creation and Worker Assistance Act."  It also appears that you can stop this from happening by "decoupling" state law from the federal law.  In the early 1980s, responding to a similar federal change, some 21 states (including Florida) decoupled from federal depreciation rules. Please do it again.

the

Broward and the Palm Beaches.  It is comprised of Chairman, CEOs,
Presidents
and Chief Operating Officers.  Primarily the leaders of this thriving
community.  Furthermore, community leaders such as Ed Easton (my partner
and

the

Governor's international efforts.

-----Original Message-----
From: Brantley, Michelle K. 
Sent: Thursday, May 02, 2002 5:29 PM
To: 'crw@custom-mobility.com'
Cc: Steaple, Alanna
Subject: RE: FW: RECENT MEDICAID ISSUES


Dear Mr. Widmann,

Governor Bush appreciates hearing from you about Medicaid's reimbursement
methodology and asked us to respond.

Medicaid respects your concerns regarding its wheelchair payment policy. In
the coming weeks, Medicaid will be meeting with several of the customized
wheelchair providers to discuss the above-mentioned issue. From the meeting,
Medicaid desires to have a wheelchair reimbursement plan of action that
allows the wheelchair provider to continue to provide quality services to
Medicaid's wheelchair recipients in a cost effective manner.

If you have additional questions, please contact Alanna J. Steaple of my
staff at (850)922-7306.

Sincerely,

Michelle Brantley
Chief, Health Systems Development
Agency for Health Care Administration

From:	William Buckey <buckeyw@sso.org>
Sent:	Friday, May 3, 2002 11:02 AM
To:	Nina Oviedo; Jeb Bush
Cc:	Kathleen Shanahan (E-mail)
Subject:	RE: HR3831

The bill has 65 co-sponsors, but will not go anywhere this session.  
 
There is sentiment for some change in the current policy--which is 50 years old--but right now this legislation is seen as too expensive.  
 
The good news is that this should begin more serious dialogue on making the reserve retirement system more attractive (for recruiting and retention) and equitable to those who are bearing an increasing share of the national defense.  
 
One thing to keep in mind is that with the current 60-year mark there are many service members who die before receiving any benefits at all.
-----Original Message-----

-----Original Message-----
From: Suzi [mailto:suzifly@gate.net]
Sent: Wednesday, May 01, 2002 9:12 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: HR3831
Dear JEB:
       I am writing to ask you to please support HR3831. A bill has been presented before congress, HR 3831, Reducing the Retirement Age for Reserves and Guard from age 60 to 55.  Presently reservist/guard who have served their country for upwards to 33-36 years and forced from the duty at age 55 or younger, can not collect any retirement benefits until age 60. 
My husband Bob Harper served 30 years in the Air Force Reserves in Florida and retired 6 years ago when he was 50. He retired as a Senior Master Sargeant with many accommodations. He did this while he performed his regular duties at work and is still ready to serve when called upon.   Please support HR3831.
 
Suzi Harper

public and media upon request.   Your e-mail communications
may therefore be subject to public disclosure. 



-----Original Message-----
From: Dr. Kate Howze [mailto:Kate@earlychildhood.net]
Sent: Friday, May 03, 2002 11:51 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: proviso language on 4-year-olds


As a voter and taxpayer in Florida for almost 30 years, I am appalled that 
you would ask for proviso language giving 4-year-olds high priority on 
School Readiness Funds in line 2235 of the budget. This move, at the last 
minute and without benefit of the opportunity for public input, is a 
political maneuver to avoid attention being paid to the issue. Further, 
should this proviso language be implemented, it will set a dangerous 
precedent that totally ignores parent need AND parent choice, and further 
fractures the system of early childhood services in the state of Florida. 
PLEASE take time to listen to folks in the trenches regarding School 
Readiness. They know what they're doing and they deserve to be heard.

Kate Howze, Ed.D.
President/CEO

Lakeland, FL 33802-0368

-----Original Message-----
From: David Lawrence [mailto:dlawrence@childreadiness.org]
Sent: Friday, May 03, 2002 7:20 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: RE: A forthcoming proviso


Governor:

It does make sense to prioritize, but what I fear is that we are pitting 
one genuinely needy group against another. Overall, when we are talking 
about serving only those children who fall within the 150 percent federal 
poverty level (and most states are at 185 percent in the first place), 
this doesn't really get at the true quality needs for so many families. 
I'd love to have the chance to convince you of the affordable wisdom of 
supporting the constitutional amendment.

Thanks.

Dave Lawrence

This self coverage on the second $250 of insurance deductible does work, and it can work for the state and give you millions (small in the totality of the state budget) but as Senator Dirksen said, a million here and a million there . . . -----Original Message-----
From: Paul Ferguson <paulferguson@worldnet.att.net>
To: Jeb Bush <jeb@jeb.org>
Sent: Wed May 01 07:08:56 2002
Subject: Insurance Savings

I have a proposal that will help you save the state of Florida
approximately
$175 PER employee, state wide.
It is very simple. Instead of the current $300 to $500 deductible, the
state
would self insure the next $250.00.
I know this sounds impossible, but after 12 months of hard work, a
friend of
mine and I finally convinced our county
commission to implement the program and in the first 12 months, we saved
$386,000 NET, an average saving
of $190 PER employee.

We had one helluva fight, with our Democrat County Commissioner, Judy
Johnson and our risk management department
 battling right to the end, and every employee battling, but they
finally
saw that:

(a) it cost the employees no loss in benefits and no additional out of
pocket cost to them, and
(b) it reflected a net savings to the county.

I am now battling to get the city of Ocala and our school board to
implement
it.

I have no idea how many employees the state has (I am afraid to ask),
but
wouldn't it be
interesting just to look at the facts and figures to see if my friend
who
conceived the plan is
correct?   He has convinced several other governmental agencies to make
the
trial and let
him prove the results.

He would be happy to provide you more information if you are interested.

From:	Robin Ronne <RRONNE@tampachamber.com>
Sent:	Friday, May 3, 2002 2:57 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Monday's Great Celebration

Governor, good afternoon!  I just received the release that the Senate had
passed the tax conformance measure and hopefully the House will follow suit.
Your dedication and leadership in these critically important economic
development issues continue to move Florida in the direction it must move in
order to remain competitive - thank you for all you do on our behalf!

And thank you for all of your hard work on the Citigroup "Teachers are
Heroes" grant.  It hardly seems possible that the process began over a year
ago on April 10th of 2001 when you responded to my request for a
recommendation on placing a contribution to a not-for-profit
organization/program of high quality, high impact and visibility that would
provide an overall benefit on a statewide basis.  Once again, your direction
and coordination have led directly to Monday's announcement and celebration.
And once again, we will have proven the critics wrong when they say "there
goes the Governor's Office, Enterprise Florida and the Tampa Committee of
One Hundred attracting more of those low-paying, dead-end back-office call
center jobs"!
Nothing could be further from the truth, and when global financial services
companies that provide our citizens with high quality, high paying jobs with
career ladders here in Tampa, Florida, making significant capital
investments in facilities and equipment, but more importantly, providing
significant support to much needed programs in the communities in which they
are located, then that's the real essence of economic development - build
towards the top, but never forget that the entire foundation at the very
lowest level needs to be strong and sustainable in term of the basic
fundamentals, especially education.

My only regret is that I won't be able to join you, George Seegers and Lou
Buccino at the celebration, since I will be in Salt Lake City at the first
CoreNet Global Summit (merger between IDRC and NACORE) where I will moderate
a panel on "Leading Edge Location Strategies" with Mark Klender of Deloitte
and Touche/Fantus, Mike Edwards of Intel, and Dan Malachuk of Arthur
Anderson, and I won't return until Thursday morning.  However, Tampa Chamber
President Kim Scheeler and Chairman Sandy MacKinnon will be there to
represent the Chamber/Committee of One Hundred.  

But rest assured, I'll be there in spirit - and look forward to catching up
with you when I return, as we have several additional great project
announcements upcoming in the next several weeks.  

Kindest regards, 

Robin Ronne

Greater Tampa Chamber of Commerce Committee of One Hundred

From:	Jimmy Morales <jmorales@swmwas.com>
Sent:	Friday, May 3, 2002 4:15 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Fwd: FW: Budget Update
Attachments:	FW: Budget Update

Governor,

After 5 ½ years in office here in Miami, I can tell you we suffer from a serious housing crisis.  A recent study we did shows that just in the area of affordable rentals for low-income families, we have a current need for approximately 20,000 new units.  Our waiting lists for elderly housing are now in excess of 10 years.

That is why I am so disturbed by the attached e-mail.  I can assure you that if there is any surplus in housing funds, we in Miami alone could spend it all to provide for our citizens, not to mention the need that exists elsewhere in the state.  Rather than re-allocate any surplus elsewhere, we need to get more proactive and creative in spending those funds and creating the much need housing.  I would be glad to work with you on that.  But let's save that money in the budget so that we can address very serious needs.

I hope this e-mail finds you well.  My heart goes out to you and your family on the issues with your daughter.  Raising children is never easy.  Our daughter was diagnosed with autism at age 3 and it has been a struggle ever since.  We will keep you and your family in our prayers.

Still hoping to see you on el 20 de mayo!

-----Original Message-----
From: Linda Foy [mailto:lfoy@cdsi.org]
Sent: Friday, May 03, 2002 4:06 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Four year olds


Governor Bush, please delite the line concerning four year olds in the
proviso language, line 2235.  There are many unintended consequences
that will ensue. . . increased emphasis on fours will dry up already
difficult to find care for infants and special needs children.  This
legislation could split families so that a working mom has care for a
four year old but none for younger children in the family.  School
readiness begins before birth, not at four.  The idea of universal care
is laudable but for all children, especially those most vulnerable,
infants.  Please continue the trend to give local control to coalitions,
do not mandate care for all four-year olds.

Linda Foy
Marion, Citrus, Sumter, Hernando and Lake counties.

-----Original Message-----
From: Pam Parmenter [mailto:pparmenter@projectchildcare.org]
Sent: Friday, May 03, 2002 3:51 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: Carol Hunt
Subject: School Readiness Dollars



Pam Parmenter 
Quality Assurance Director 
Project Child Care 
399 6th Avenue West 
Bradenton, FL  34205 


Dear Governor: 

I ask that you take another look at the budget proviso line item 2235.  Local coalitions should be making the decisions about how to spend the dollars allocated to them. The dollars should not be used as a political football.  Lives are at stake here.  The foundation for school readiness is set before the age of three.  Four-year-olds are on the tail-end of school readiness.  George Farkus from Penn State University has found that the amount and type of vocabulary a three-year old has is a direct predictor of later school success.  We need to remember that all funding for all children birth through twelve years of age now funnels through the Partnership for School Readiness to the local coalitions. While providing quality opportunities for four-year olds is critical, what will we say to the working poor who have children of several ages, only one of whom may qualify for services if line item 2235 is finalized?  What will you say when Florida workers cannot work because they do not have access to safe child care? 

Universal PreK has its merits.  However, it must be funded well to work, and funded with committed dollars that do not sacrifice infant and toddler safety.  Nor should the commitment of dollars to four-year olds contribute to higher rates of eventual crime and non-success in school from the children home alone before and after school because the parent or parents could not afford child care.  Talk about investigations - we'll have many more Rilya's on our hands!

Your leadership on this issue is critical at this point in time.  The language in line 2235 sets a dangerous precedent.  It will contribute to unsafe and/or non-existant care for infants and toddlers, and will provide a higher number of children home alone with little or no access to tutoring, supervision, qualilty language, or caring adults to help shape the character of these future voters.

Sincerely, 

Pam Parmenter 
7809 36th Ave E 
Palmetto, FL  34221

-----Original Message-----
From: Carol Hunt [mailto:chunt@projectchildcare.org]
Sent: Friday, May 03, 2002 2:51 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Proviso language for 4 yr old




Dear Governor Bush, 

I am deeply concerned about the proviso language giving priority to eligible four year old children after those who are TANF eligible.  I do not feel this is in the best interest of children, the school readiness system and especially for families.  Parents do not generally request child care services for one child in the family, and school readiness begins at birth, not 4 years of age.  

Please do not approve the proviso unless there is adequate financial resources to support the new priority.  If this passes, there will be many more unsupervised babies in jeopardy.

Thank you for your consideration. 

Carol Hunt 
Executive Director 
Project Child Care

-----Original Message-----
From: Pirdev@aol.com [mailto:Pirdev@aol.com]

kottkamp.jeff@leg.state.fl.us; mckay.john.web@leg.state.fl.us
Subject: Do not pass proviso language; adequately fund children 0-5


To those of you responsible for providing funds so that we can prepare 
children to be ready for school:

The greatest amount of learning takes place between birth and three years of 
age.  Please do not short change these children in order to provide funding 
for all four year olds.  That too is important.  But provide  additional 
funding to serve all four years olds.  Do not take money from the babies in 
order to help their four year old siblings.

Please face up to your obligations and provide enough money to do the job 
properly.

If you really mean that children are Florida's future, fund services for our 
future.  Provide adequate funding for school readiness so that we can help 
children to be ready for school. 

Respectfully,

Giovanna Deveny, Chair
School Readiness Coalition of Sarasota County, Inc.

Venice, Florida 34293-6030

-----Original Message-----
From: Beverly Esposito [mailto:besposito@fcforum.org]
Sent: Friday, May 03, 2002 2:52 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: School Readiness Proviso


The Partnership for School Readiness has drafted proviso language to
prioritize services for four-year-old children.  We believe that it is
crucial to remove the language that states that the second priority
group be " 4 year old children from families that meet the financial
eligibility requirements of s. 411.01(6), Florida Statutes."  This
language takes away local control and decision-making.  Please remember
that school readiness begins at birth.  In some cases, even age 4 is too
late.

-----Original Message-----
From: Karen Deringer [mailto:karen@cscpbc.org]
Sent: Friday, May 03, 2002 2:24 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: Tana Ebbole; Marlene Passell; Central File
Subject: Palm Beach County Working families


 
Dear Governor Bush, 
 
We are concerned about the proviso language for four year olds. We know you originally proposed additional funding to target four year olds which could be a good target population to serve if additional funds are limited.  However, to create this as a priority without additional funds just creates one more hoop for already overwhelmed School Readiness Coalitions to jump through and one more string attached to an already empty bucket.  It also takes away our Coalition's ability to set priorities for our County.
 
We have over 2000 children on the waiting list for working poor child care in Palm Beach County.  Those children are a priority whether 4 months or 4 years of age. Their parents need to have child care to work.  
 
We support your efforts to recognize early childhood and the connection between Pre-Kindergarten to ready children as they enter school.  Hopefully you and the legislature can find resources to begin to address the overwhelming need for services for the working families in Florida.  Sincerely, 
 
 
Karen Deringer
Planning and Policy Director
Children's Services Council of Palm Beach County
1919 N. Flagler Drive
West Palm Beach, FL 33407

From: Horne, Jim [mailto:Jim.Horne@flboe.org]
Sent: Friday, May 03, 2002 11:18 AM
To: Roberts, Edwin A.
Subject: 


Ed Roberts
Editorial Page Editor
The Tampa Tribune
Mr. Roberts:
I wanted to thank you for yesterday's ("Jeb's One Florida Program Is A
Winner For Minorities"). It was an excellent argument.
It has been my hope that as the facts and the evidence mounted regarding the
One Florida Initiative - as it became clear the initiative was working for
the benefit of all Floridians - that the public would come to recognize it
as a true reform.
I am grateful to you for providing guidance to the reading public and for
helping Floridians recognize the good work that is being done though One
Florida.
One Florida, like all government programs, must be held up to scrutiny. No
program, however well-intentioned, should be free from criticism. One
Florida has, as you noted, gathered criticism that has not always been on
target. Some of its critics have not fairly characterized the mission of the
initiative or the motives of Gov. Jeb Bush in creating it.
Therefore it gave me great comfort to read your words today. We are working
hard to make this reform a powerful tool for opening opportunities for every
Florida child. All of us in education were pleased to see the value of our
work being recognized on your pages.
Sincerely,

Jim  Horne
Secretary of Education

Barb, I wanted to pass on some good news in our overall FL communications
campaign.

I was contacted by Heather Paltz (with Accenture's Enterprise Integration
Marketing organization) that the FL DBPR project will be awarded first
place in the prestigious EAI Journal awards as the best B2B EAI solution.

category from all Accenture award applications submitted across all market
units.  Heather highlighted this will be very positive publicity and is the
first time an award has been made to a system integrator solution.

and notified by the EAI Journal organization.  Heather said we are not
supposed to say anything until the official announcement is made May 15.

internal eGovernment postcard to share this news.  If you need to

-----Original Message-----
From: Dianne & Jerry Cox [mailto:coxnhsd@earthlink.net]
Sent: Friday, May 03, 2002 9:04 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Fw: Scams Target Veterans for Identity Theft


This is awful.  People in the military suffers enough with health problems from service, military hospitals that have shut down etc.  I see in our paper they are trying to get a bill passed so this is corrected.  Hope it does.
 
 



Scams Target Veterans for Identity Theft 

Army News Service reports that soldiers separating from the military 
should avoid filing their Department of Defense Form 214 (Military 
Discharge) with their local county courthouse. Transition counselors 
are advising soldiers to safeguard their personal information to 
guard against credit fraud. Identity theft is the fastest growing 
crime in the U.S. today, according to the Federal Trade Commission 
(FTC), and servicemembers are inviting targets because everything is 
tied to their Social Security numbers. In a recent case, a Navy 
retiree received a phone call from American Express stating that 
someone was trying to cash a $9,000 check in his name made out to an 
unknown person. Investigation revealed that the retiree's lawyer had 
stolen his identity. The lawyer also had a laptop with several 
thousand military names, Social Security numbers and other 
information on it. The common link among the veterans on the list 
was that they had filed their DD-214s with their county courthouse. 
Once the DD 214 is filed at a courthouse, it becomes a public record. 
Servicemembers are advised to safeguard their DD-214 form as they 
would any vital papers, such as placing it in a safe deposit box. For 
more on legal issues, visit 
http://www.military.com/Resources/ResourceFileView?file=Active_Benefits_Law. 
htm 



James M. Ellis 
MWR Policy 
Program Analyst 
(703) 602-5009

From: Cheetahs41@aol.com [mailto:Cheetahs41@aol.com]

Subject: My school's Sept. 11 Memorial Garden


Dear Governor Bush: 

My school is dedicating a memorial garden for the victims of September 11 on Friday, May 10, 2001, at 8:30 a.m.  I got to thinking and I thought it would be nice if I invited you to come.  Our art teacher, Mrs. Boni Meddock, designed it and the students and teachers participated in the making of it.  Each of us put a piece of glass into an American flag mosaic and our fifth graders made stepping stone mosaics.  Some students even competed by writing an essay or four verse poem about September 11, why we're proud of our country, or we could make up our own topic about the USA.  The winners, one person from each classroom, (I won for my class!) got to plant something in the memorial garden.  We also get to be at the dedication ceremony!  We're even trying to get people from television stations  to come too! 

I think that my school would appreciate it if you and Mrs. Bush could come.  I know this is short notice, but I thought I would invite you anyway.  If you need to reach Mrs. Meddock, her e-mail address is bmeddock@mail.volusia.k12.fl.us. Thanks for your time Governor Bush!  Good luck in the election! 

Sincerely, 

Shayna Hart 
Fourth Grader at Forest Lake Elementary School 
1600 Doyle Rd.

-----Original Message-----
From: Randy Niewenhous [mailto:Randy_Niewenhous@dcf.state.fl.us]
Sent: Friday, May 03, 2002 7:58 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: SECRETARY KEARNEY


Governor: I am writing to you about Secretary Kearney. I am 57 years old,
spent 26 years as a United States Marine, and have worked steadily since my
retirement from the Corps in '95. In that span of time, I have observed
many leaders?some good, some not so good. The Marine Corps hammers the
principle of leadership by example into the fiber of those entrusted with
the care of young Marines.  In the almost three years I have worked with
Secretary Kearney, she has epitomized the essence of that principle.  In
the face of unrelenting attacks on herself and the organization she leads,
she has held her head high, and fought smart and hard, while at the same
time demonstrating an example of moral courage under fire worthy of
emulation by the best. As hurtful, and unfair as the recent personal
attacks have been, I am sure that it is the horrific event?the child?that
haunts her most. She isn't perfect; none of us are, but she has suited up
daily to do a job, I am embarrassed to say, that I, and most, wouldn't
accept.  As I watch the current furor, I am reminded of Theodore
Roosevelt's marvelously powerful piece entitled "The Man in the Arena." I
have a copy on my office wall.  I am also reminded of my best friend's less
elegant, but equally powerful, and relevant saying: "on their best day, her
critics couldn't carry her jockstrap." Respectfully,

Randy Niewenhous
Dept of Children and Families

From: Bob Cooper [mailto:cooperb@madison.k12.fl.us]
Sent: Monday, April 29, 2002 2:02 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Green Card


Governor Bush:

I need help for a former exchange student who is now at the University of 
Central Florida finishing up next year in computer graphics and design.

Bard Gunnerud from Oslo, Norway came to the U.S. in 1996 as an exchange 
student living with me and attending Madison County High School here in 
Madison, Florida. While here he did outstanding work here in the Art 
Department and he received a full scholarship from NFCC here in Madison. He 
returned to Oslo and finished his high school work then returned here and 
finished his AA degree at NFCC. He then went on to UCF in Orlando where he 
is working to finish his BFA in computer animation and design.

Since he is a foreign student he is not allowed to work because he has no 
Green Card. Consequently he has to return every summer to work to earn 
spending money for the time he is here going to school.

Norway, being such a small country, has no need for a person with his 
skills. So, I would like for him to get his Green Card so he can fulfill 
his dream of working with movies and/or television to use his skills. Is 
there a way that you could help him get his card OR tell us where to start 
the procedure to obtain one. I know that he will be graduation in the one 
or one and a half years. If you can please help us in any way both Bard and 
I would certainly appreciate it.

Since school is finished for this year, Bard is leaving tomorrow for Oslo 
to work for the summer. I am going over to Norway and Germany on June 11th 
and I would certainly like to tell him how we can start to get his card.

Thanks for you help in this matter.

Sincerely,

Bob Cooper, Madison County High School TV Production teacher

eleven (11) new Ford Crown Victoria's. It was even more amusing to see
that of the eleven vehicles delivered, SIX of them will be given to the
five City Commissioners and one (the red one) to the City Manager -
leaving only five cars for the police department.

In addition, we wonder what happened to the FEMA money that Opa-locka
received for the vehicles damaged by the "No-Name Storm" that flooded us
out a few years ago. The police department's rank and file are, on the
most part, hard working and dedicated to their profession. But the
City's administration - including the elected officials - have clearly
shown that they are interested in their own personal welfare and
self-aggrandizement and NOT the welfare of the citizens who elected
them. I have been a Florida police officer since 1968 and with Opa-locka
since 1981. I don't know of any other city or town in Florida that gives
city cars to it's elected officials yet Opa-locka, one of the poorest
communities in Miami-Dade County, does so with no thought to the needs
of the citizens. They feel it is their right to receive the exclusive
use of a $25,000 vehicle for a maximum of 15 hours work per month, while
the Police Department has to beg used cars from other agencies in order
to have enough vehicles to patrol the City.

I have attached the photo of the City Manager's new car, along with some
of the other Commission vehicles that are stored at the back (west)
fence at the City's Public Works Department. In addition, you can rest
assured that the five new vehicles at the police department will remain
parked and unused for a number of months because of the ineffectuality
of the Chief of Police in finding the funding necessary to equip these
vehicles with the necessary emergency equipment and markings.

In order to turn this Police Department around, I suggest that the
following:
1. Enough money to purchase the equipment necessary to do the job -
including new vehicles, lap-top computers, Radios, sirens and light
bars.

2. Enough manpower (we were 51 sworn officers in 1993 and are now 30
full-time sworn in 2002) to effectively respond to the needs of the
community in a proactive manner.

3. Police leadership that has the ability and willingness to perform
their jobs in an efficient and prompt manner.
A. The Chief of Police, though presenting a good public image, has shown
himself to be a stumbling block to the progress of the Department - he
has procrastinated on necessary action in order to receive donated
(free) equipment and failed to act in a timely manner on personnel
actions, causing us to have to retain incompetent or undesirable
employees because of the time constraints involved in disciplinary
action.
He has shown a racist attitude in his promotions in that the #1 position
on the last Sergeant's exam was, and still is, held by a white officer,
yet Wilson promoted the #3 position (a black officer) to the rank of
Sergeant in - of all places Internal Affairs - who was arrested in
Atlanta, GA for urinating in the lobby of a major hotel while
intoxicated, then - one week before his promotion - was sent home
because he reported to work intoxicated and was asleep behind the wheel
of his car in the Police department parking lot.
He promoted an officer to Lieutenant in charge of Patrol who was
arrested several times in Miami-Dade County  - once for D.U.I. and once
for chasing someone with his firearm over a parking space.
B. The "Major" in the Criminal Investigations Division was appointed to
her rank by the former Chief of Police (Craig Collins) because she is
the mother of his illegitimate child and she needed the money. Her track
record as a Division Commander and as a supervisor in general -  has
shown a lack of ability and understanding and an unwillingness to listen
to subordinates who might have valid suggestions to solving particular
problems.

4. A financial (Administrative) officer in the Police Department to keep
track of ALL expenditures and all revenues generated by the Department
and compare it to the Line Item authorizations in the City Budget.

In order to solve the City's financial problems, we need
1. An oversight board to guide and instruct our self-agrandizing City
Commission into how to put the needs of the citizens first.
2. A complete line-by-line review of the City's financial expenditures -
along with contact of the vendors that received funds from the City.
A. We have a Director of Finance who has consistently been unwilling or
unable to cooperate with the Police Department when asked to produce an
accounting of various police grants and the Law Enforcement Trust
Account.

3. A new City Manager who is willing to work with the City employees and
their various bargaining representatives to meet the needs of the
Citizens and the employees who provide the City Services.
A. The current manager eliminated 11 police positions and 14 other
positions in the City and caused an over-all 12.5% reduction in salary
(from a 40 hour to a 35 hour work week) in order to meet "severe budget
shortfalls", but had the nerve to ask for - and RECEIVE - an increase in
salary and benefits for himself and the City Attorney of approximately
$60,000!

This City CAN come back and be the fine, friendly blue-collar community
it was before the Mayor Robert B. Ingram years. It just takes some
funding and equipment to "prime the pump" and elected officials who will
put the needs of the community first - not buy into the on-going
attitude of "what's in it for me?"

Sincerely,

Tony Lacks

--
F. A. "Tony" Lacks

The funding that was appropriated was not for the faith based dorms, the six
the bill required DOC to set up, but for "transitional" faith based beds in
the community.  currently, the state funds part of the Kairos program,
Kairos and DOC were both under the impression that the new faith dorms would
be funded the same way, but ultimately, they were not and the money went to
transitional beds.  i think this was one of the issues brad raised last year
in objection to the bill.

Governor:

As we were preparing our presentation to some North Carolina legislators, we used the following three quotes about the FCT program.  You have supported and protected this program, and I thought you might like to see how others feel about it...

"In the last three years, the City of Jacksonville has doubled its park space to become one of the largest city park systems  in the nation. Our Preservation Project has had numerous partners, but none as helpful as the Florida Communities Trust. Together we've changed the face of our city - forever." 
Mayor John Delaney, City of Jacksonville

"The Florida Communities Trust Program has been a tremendous asset to the City of Tampa's urban open space programs like its 'Ribbon of Green' land acquisition plan along the Hillsborough River shoreline. FCT alone provided our City with $12,727,500, which allowed the City to leverage other local and State open space/environmental grant programs for its land acquisition." 
Mayor Dick Greco, City of Tampa

"TPL's partnerships with local land conservation grant programs have never been better exemplified than in the Florida Communities Trust. FCT's ability to empower communities to achieve their vision and preserve their natural and cultural character is changing the face of Florida's landscape.  The Trust for Public Land points to FCT as a model for communities all over the nation."

Will Rogers, President 
The Trust for Public Land

Governor Jeb Bush
The Capitol
Tallahassee, FL 32399
 
Dear Jeb
 
Thanks for the email.  I have never seen such a fast response in the 45 years I have been working with Governors.  I truly do appreciate it.
 
The people in Glades County desperately need this project.  It is my understanding that INS can contract with such a facility as they are doing so currently.  It is also my understanding that they can not commit or enter into an agreement to place detainees in any facility more six months into the future.  Our contractor is anticipating the completion of this project in August or September of 2003.  Therefore, Glades County will in January or February enter into discussions with INS to house detainees.
 
At the present time they are not asking for an INS commitment.  They want a meeting to discuss INS requirements so that we build the facility to their standards.  Of course we also want to impress on them our progress in that bonds are being sold with a projected closing of July 1st and settlement on July 11th.
 
We would very much appreciate having a meeting arranged with a responsible INS official in Washington by the Governors office instead of being arranged by congressional representatives.  I am attaching my original summary of the project which might be helpful in discussions with INS.  
 
Have a nice day and thanks again.
 
 
David Tews

-----Original Message-----
From: Nancy Watkins [mailto:nwatkins@robertwatkins.com]
Sent: Tuesday, April 30, 2002 5:44 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Requested info re: an HCC budget matter
Sensitivity: Private


Dear Governor Bush,
Robert and I very much enjoyed see you in Tampa on the 17th and especially
appreciated your candid insight into where we are as we move toward November
5th. We look forward to continuing to work on the successful and rewarding
effort of your re-election.
As you may recall, we spoke briefly after that meeting about an issue
concerning Hillsborough Community College, for which I serve as a member of
the District Board of Trustees (currently as chairman) thanks to your
original appointment of me in 1999. You told me you thought it was in the
current budget but I have been watching very closely and am fairly certain
it is not there. I recognize that legislation is not my business thought and
may be missing it.  But staff at HCC also tell me they can't find it either.
I have attached the talk sheet that has been used for promoting the sale and
transfer of the W.T. Edwards property to HCC. The talk sheet explains that
we are asking for a special appropriation to PECO that will enable HCC to
purchase the property from the Department of Children and Families, which
will allow them to use to proceeds of the sale to build a sexual predator
facility.
The property has been recently appraised at approximately $8 million.
Having the appropriation go to the College through PECO puts us in the
drivers seat in closing the sale. Plus, it permits you and the Legislature
to show additional funds allocated to education, while protecting Floridians
from sexual predators.
There are precedents for colleges using PECO to purchase state lands and for
special appropriations to PECO.
I am told we have support of this approach from Amy Baker (CFO of the Dept.
of Children and Families), and Colleen Castille (your Director of Cabinet
Affairs)
Again, this appropriation does not appear to be in either the House or
Senate budgets. However, Rep. Murman indicated that she will be on the look
out for money that becomes available in the closing minutes of the Session.
I am sure that if we have your support we will attain the appropriation.
It is important to note that we cannot jeopardize any of the College's
existing PECO projects in order to fund this request. In addition, we do not
wish to reduce the community college system's PECO appropriation in order to
fund this request.
Please let me know if you have any questions or suggestions. Thank you for
your attention and support of this matter.

Yours truly,

Nancy

-----Original Message-----
From: Chris Corr [mailto:ccorr@joe.com]
Sent: Thursday, May 02, 2002 12:44 PM
To: Jeb Bush; Slater Bayliss
Subject: Southwest Airlines Adopt-A-Pilot


				Gov Bush - as brief as I can, here's a great Bush-Brogan success story...maybe you could participate.

				A 5th grade student at West Riverside Elementary School (a mostly urban, minority public elementary school) in Jacksonville was recently notified that he won a national essay contest sponsored by Southwest Airlines.  

				Southwest has sponsored a national mentoring program, through its pilots, for a number of years.  It started through its partnership in America's Promise (Colin Powell) and continues...Laura Bush was involved in TX, where SW is based.  The essay contest, a component of the mentoring program, asked students to write a 100-word essay on how their teachers go "above and beyond."  SW got 2500 essays from around the US.  A Jax public school 5th grader, who has had health, incl open heart surgery, and learning difficulties...and can only write with the assistance of a computer, won.  Even more, this is a public school that was a D school until recently when, inspired by Gov. Bush's mentoring initiative, area business leaders began mentoring the school through the "Partnerships to Advance School Success (PASS)" program.  The school improved to a "C" in 2001 and teachers/administrators expect a "B" this year.

				Southwest is awarding the winner's 5th grade class a round-trip from Jacksonville to New Orleans.  The students of the West Riverside 5th grade class (plus parents) will fly, with the student's mentor-pilot, to New Orleans for the day and study the geography and history of the French Quarter, Cajun dancing, the Mississippi River, etc.  This will be the 1st time that some of these students, and even their parents, have flown on an airplane.  The trip will happen on May 8th.  A send-off event is planned for approx. 9 am at the Jacksonville Airport.

				I know the your normally intense schedule is especially intense with special session and this is short notice,...however, this is a great success story that originates from your leadership...its about improving Florida education, mentoring, promoting tourism/business in Florida (w Southwest), an inspirational young student...the fact that its at the urban and formerly neglected West Riverside is even more impressive.

				I think you should consider: a) a quick trip to Jax on the morning of May 8th to lead the send-off celebration for the 5th grade class; or, b) a congratulatory letter/proclamation that can be read at the event.

				Southwest has extensive media is involved in the send off.  CBS/CH4 will accompany the class on the trip.

				Thanks.




				----- Forwarded by Chris Corr/St-Joe on 05/02/2002 12:00 PM -----


	Linda Jones-PR <Linda.Jones-PR@wnco.com>
			05/01/2002 03:10 PM
					
	To:	Chris Corr/St-Joe@St-Joe
	cc:	Jerry Ray/St-Joe@St-Joe
	Subject:	Southwest Airlines Adopt-A-Pilot	


				Nice talking to you this morning, Chris.  We have been pleased to work
				with you on the May 8 SWA Adopt-A-Pilot/West Riverside educational
				field trip from Jacksonville to New Orleans.  The enthusiasm and excited
				from the school is overwhelming!

				Attached is background information on the Adopt-A-Pilot which is
				celebrating its fifth anniversary.  The program kicked off nationally in
				Washington in 1997 with the Sec. of Education and Sec. of
				Transportation.  The four-week long program has more than doubled each
				year with 325+ pilots volunteering their time to be role models to 
				elementary school students coast to coast.

				Please let me know if you have further questions.

				Linda B. Jones
				Southwest Airlines
				Public Relations

-----Original Message-----
From: Aaron Weeks [mailto:aweeks@sfwmd.gov]
Sent: Wednesday, May 01, 2002 1:37 PM
To: fvfoutreach@netscape.net; BBA2002@bellsouth.net
Subject: Outreach Contract Signing Event



I am pleased to extend an invitation to Governor Jeb Bush to attend the
kick-off and ceremonial contract signing for the South Florida Water
Management District (SFWMD) Business Management and Technical Assistance
Initiative.  We would like to host the Governor for this event on either
May 16 or May 17, 2002, his calendar permintting.  If the Governor is
unable to attend we would be pleased if he could send his special
assistant, Wendy Grant, to represent him.

The District is poised to approve at its Governing Board meeting on May
9, 2002 a contract with the Florida Venture Foundation (FVF) and the
Black Business Association (BBA) to provide management and technical
assistance to small businesses in Dade and Broward counties.  This
assistance, which will consist of outreach, technical assistance, and
access to capital and bonding, will be available to small firms located
in Dade, Broward and Monroe counties.  The District recognizes the
particular ability of the FVF and the BBA to inclusively  outreach to
the business community and expects services to be provided to a diverse
group of firms.

The initiative will serve to increase the capacity of ready willing and
able small contractors available for SFWMD contracting opportunities,
particularly in the area of everglades restoration.  In the spirit of
One Florida, this is a race/gender neutral approach to diversity which
provides firms the skills and tools necessary to better compete for
contract opportunities without goals, quotas, or governmental
programs.   This is an historic partnership between government and the
non-profit community to provide services that will help the District
accomplish all the objectives of everglades restoration.

We hope you or a representative from your staff will be able to attend.

-----Original Message-----
From: Martha Compton [mailto:Compton_M@popmail.firn.edu]
Sent: Thursday, May 02, 2002 2:35 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: What is wrong with education?


PLEASE RESPOND TO THIS MESSAGE AFTER YOU HAVE READ IT!

I grew up in a small southern town where I was able to take advantage of the
American precept which says that I can do anything I am able or willing to
do.  Everything I learned was from public education and it was wonderful and
so rewarding.  After graduating from high school I chose to enter the field
of education by becoming a teacher. I truly believed I could make a
difference.  My goal was to become a high school mathematics teacher.  I
have been a public educator for almost 16 years and I have experienced and
seen quite a bit throughout this time spent teaching and learning.  I have
become frustrated and, almost at times, would have thrown in the towel if it
were not for my children who have now enter the public school system.

I have worked for six different superintendents and for several different
principals.   Some changes occurred because of elections and pure politics
and others, not due to incompetence on my part, but due to a greater desire
to experience rich and rare opportunities.  I have been selected teacher of
the year and also county teacher of the year and have earned a specialist
degree in mathematics education.  I share this simply to help you understand
that my concerns are true and straightforward and not one of vindication or
assault.

I have determined over the years that the counties and schools rich with
high moral and achievement are the ones that have somehow selected awesome
administrators and leaders that are focused in on the real meaning of
education.  From this observation I can truly say that I believe politics is
³killing² our public schools.


You talk about increased funding and teacher retention initiatives.......

The legislature may increase funding, but because of the loop holes,
earmarks, or superintendent and principal authority, it is rarely seen at
the classroom or teacher level.  I talk only for the school systems who are
not politically lucky!

I want to share a couple of examples that I have experienced this year:

    Over the past three years as a group, teachers have always voted on how
our lottery dollars should be used.  One year we had just re implemented a
music program that had been greatly missed and chose to use the entire sum
on music equipment.  the next year we agreed to purchase the Accelerated
Reading program and several hundred books and tests.  This year however, the
rules changed.  The teachers did not get to decide how our lottery dollars
were to be spend.  We were informed four days before the event that over $5,
500  were to be spent for what we called an "FCAT Blowout"  where inflatable
were to be rented.   This event was to reward student two days BEFORE the
FCAT.  The teachers were not given the opportunity to come together as a
group to spend this money or even vote on this decision.  We were informed
however that the Advisory Board had chosen to spend it and did not need
teacher input..    I WANT TO KNOW WHAT THE LAW SAYS ABOUT THIS!!  WHEN YOU
RESPOND WILL YOU INCLUDE COMMENTS ABOUT THIS!  Their was so much more we
needed to do with this money.  I agree we need to reward children, but why
not reward them after the FCAT is over for being on time and working hard.
Why should we waste on inflatable moon walks and why $5,500  when money is
suppose to be so tight!

    During the 16 years I have been in education, the only dependable raise
I received was the one for completing a degree program.  There are many
years when we received nothing or maybe just 2% .  It is true that I did not
chose the profession because of the salary, but that does not mean that I
should not get the standard 3% living increase each year along with my
steps.  Each year we have to grovel for just step increases which, in our
county, not everyone gets.  If the governor wanted to make a difference for
educators, it would be LAW that teachers would receive at lease a 3% raise
and a step each year.  THAT WOULD MAKE A DIFFERENCE FOR ALL EDUCATORS.  This
year, because of insurance and only a step increase, I will be making less
than I made last year.  Yes I received the 850 bonus because there was not a
way for the county to weasel out of giving the money, but i ask you this.
What does a bonus do for my retirement.  If my salary never increases how
will my retirement fund increase?  At this point, you are probably arguing
that the September 11 incident created this mess.  Well, I will tell you
that the very devastating incident was just an excuse to let everyone off
the hook.  This has been going on for years.  All public (politics again)
leaders received their raises.  Do you know that our school board members ,
who received a raise this year, make more than a starting teacher in my
county and only meet about 16 times a year.  What does that say to a
teacher... that working from 7:30 - 3:00 everyday (many stay much longer)
managing and preparing 25 students and grading papers at night (not to
mention anytime in planning activities) is not as an important task as
meeting 16 times a year to decide on county issues????


You talk about increased student achievement through accountability.......

It is true that I believe that accountability is a good means to an end, but
we have lost sight of what the ³accountability² is doing to classroom.
Because the FCAT only tested reading and writing, what do you think happened
to science and social studies in most classes?  I guess you will find out
soon enough after seeing the results of the Science FCAT test.   There is
only so much time in a day to teach, so out of necessity, teachers have
learned how to teach FCAT skills and items only.   So, of course, scores are
getting higher.   


You talk about the Excellent Teaching Program.......

I believe that this is a wonderful opportunity and I did apply to become a
Nationally certified teacher.  One of the main highlights is the raise it
would give me and my family.  Because I am not a classroom teacher NOW I did
not have a mathematics class and had to ³borrow one.²  It was very difficult
to do the required assignments with this ONE class.  I thought I had done a
reasonable job on the portfolio, but I was not successful.  I hope in the
future there will be a category for technology specialist or technology
resource teacher.  I wish I had been teaching mathematics over the past few
years because it would have given me the opportunity to be successful in my
endeavor.  Hopefully my subject will be added soon.

In closing, I am a true Republican and supported Governor Bush and Lt.
Governor Brogan.  However, there is so much more that needs to be done to
help education.  Somethings are good, and some are bad.  The best advice I
can give both is to not only make changes in the law but make sure that it
is getting to the place where it needs to be and that is to teachers and
students.  Our teachers are the front line and everyone else are only around
as a support staff.  Legislatures, governors, superientendents, and
princiapls,  all of which seem to be getting raises and salary incresaes
each year, must be more precious to the education of our children than a
teacher. It seems that everyone believes that teachers are not vital to
education. 




Martha B. Compton
Chipley, FL  32428

-----Original Message-----
From: gburlew@digital.net [mailto:gburlew@digital.net]
Sent: Thursday, May 02, 2002 9:51 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Palm Bay High Winning Technology Student Association State Competition


Governor Bush,
    My name is Gil Burlew and I am a Teacher at Palm Bay High School Sci-Tech Center. In the 1999-2000 school year my student won the International Technology Education Association, Program of Excellence and I was named ITEA Teacher of year.  This past week my students won the Technology Student Association, State Leadership Conference in Daytona.  There are over 250,000 students involved in TSA here in Florida alone.  Students from all over this beautiful state compete in Radio Control Robotic, Transportation Modeling, Manufacturing Proto type, Structure Engineering, Desk Top Publication, Imaging Technology, Film Technology,  Research and Design of future Alt Vehicles and many others. My philosophy of teaching technology is hands on minds on. We do several TSA problem solving activities through out the year to prep the for the big dance.  Our students won a record breaking 27 Trophies.  We also won First Place Outstanding Chapter and the 2002 Spirit Award. Next month we are going to National in Denver Colorado.  At Nationals we will be competing against 3000 of the top students in the country in engineering and problem solving activities.  
    I realize you are a very busy man.  This may be a major thing to ask but my student deserve it.  Would you please in some way recognize my students for this Outstanding accomplishment.  Tomorrow when I'm at school I will send state results with names of students and the competition they won. Write them a letter or even come to the Sci Tech Center it is in Melbourne, Fl right by Florida Instituted if Technology. For most of my students this was the single most positive thing that has ever happened in their lives.  It will never happen again. In just two weeks my seniors will be gone but never will they be forgotten.  See we built a Dream Team in the Sci Tech Center and it will always be the place where we all come together as one.  Each student knew up front that success wasn't going to be found at the end of the road,  it was going to be found along the way.  Please understand this is top AP kids we have a good cross section of the student population of Palm Bay High.  These young men and woman are now the best of the best and know one can take that away from them.  They pave their way to success everyday through hard work, commitment and perseverance.   This dream team and shot for the stars. Funny as it may seem they became one.  Please help make this positive learning experience become an even more positive as a memory. They say no day is over if it makes a memory.   It would mean so much to have you recognize this outstanding group for their awesome achievement.  In just two short weeks my seniors will be gone but never will they be forgotten.  Thank you for your time and I appreciate what you do for Florida schools and more importantly for our future, our students.  
 
Yours in Technology,  
Former Teacher of the Year
Gil Burlew

-----Original Message-----
From: Burlew, Gil@Palm Bay High [mailto:BurlewG@brevard.k12.fl.us]
Sent: Friday, May 03, 2002 8:08 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Palm Bay State Award Winning Sci-Tech Center 



Governor Bush,
    My name is Gil Burlew and I am a Teacher at Palm Bay High School
Sci-Tech Center. In the 1999-2000 school year my students won the
International Technology Education Association, Program of Excellence and I
was named ITEA Teacher of year.  This past week my students won the
Technology Student Association, State Leadership Conference in Daytona.
There are over 250,000 students involved in TSA here in Florida alone.
Students from all over this beautiful state compete in Radio Control
Robotic, Transportation Modeling, Manufacturing Proto Type, Structural
Engineering, Desk Top Publication, Imaging Technology, Film Technology,
Research and Design of Future Alt Vehicles and many others. My philosophy of
teaching technology is "hands on-minds on". We do several TSA problem
solving activities through out the year to prep the students for the big
day.  Our students won a record breaking 27 trophies.  We also won First
Place Outstanding Chapter and the 2002 Spirit Award. Next month we are going
to the national competition in Denver, Colorado.  At Nationals we will be
competing against 3000 of the top students in the country in engineering and
problem solving activities.  
    I realize you are a very busy man.  This may be a major thing to ask but
my students deserve it.  Would you please, in some way, recognize my
students for this outstanding accomplishment.  Fore most of my students,
this was the single most positive thing that has ever happened in their
lives.  It will never happen again. In just two weeks my seniors will be
gone, but never will they be forgotten.  We built a "Dream Team" in the Sci
Tech Center and it will always be the place where we all come together.
Each student knew up front that success wasn't going to be found at the end
of the road,  it was going to be found along the way.  Please understand
these are not hand selected students.  We have a good cross section of the
student population of Palm Bay High.  These young men and woman are now the
best of the best and no one can take that away from them.  They paved their
way to success everyday through hard work, commitment and perseverance.
This "dream team" aimed for the stars. Funny as it may seem, they became
stars themselves.  Please help make this positive learning experience become
an even more positive one as a memory. They say no day is over if it makes a
memory.   It would mean so much to have you recognize this outstanding group
for their awesome achievement.  I will attach names of students and each
competition they won. 
	Thank you for your time and I appreciate what you do for Florida
schools and more importantly; for the future, for the students.  
 
Yours in Technology,  
Former Teacher of the Year
Gil Burlew

-----Original Message-----
From: JJRV@aol.com [mailto:JJRV@aol.com]
Sent: Friday, May 03, 2002 8:21 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Report From The Wind Storm Consortium of Florida


Governor Bush;


     The attached report comes from the Wind Storm Consortium. This Consortium was formed to help offer suggestions, to bring the Insurance Companies back to the state of Florida. We understand the problem the state has with having to underwrite wind storm insurance for new home owner. This report is 5 months of research and focus on this very important issue.

      Governor Bush, This consortium stand's ready, willing and able to help you and Secretary Steve Siebert in bringing back the private insurance companies to write wind storm insurance WITHOUT the state having to underwrite their policy's.

       Thank You, and have a good read.

Standing by to help,


Jay E. Jones, Consortium Chairman

-----Original Message-----
From: johnweyrick@juno.com [mailto:johnweyrick@juno.com]
Sent: Friday, May 03, 2002 9:04 AM
To: Jeb Bush; mschlued@orlandosentinel.com; gthomas@orlandosentinel.com; mcomas@orlandosentinel.com; dlynum@bellsouth.net; hhartage@hartsden.com
Subject: Please Help My Neighborhood


Dear Governor, Commissioners, and  folks at Orlando Sentinel, the children in my neighborhood need your help.
 
    I live in Orlando, in a nice little neighborhood, Haralson Estates, except for a polluted lake.  For 20 years, all efforts to clean up this lake have been thwarted by one property owner adjacent to the lake.  The city and county have agreed to provide some $200,000 worth of improvements, all studies have been completed, and the money is available, to no avail. 
 
    The property owner has been cited for lots of code violations, but he has some sort of ancient, mysterious sweetheart agreement that has been grand-fathered in, to prevent anyone or any government agency from any kind of easement to do any improvement.  The neighborhood has about 100 houses, and commercial development has encircled us with no playground for the children.  None whatsoever, and this is our only hope.
 
    City Commissioner Daisy Lynum and County Commissioner Homer Hartage have been trying to help us for years, but have been ineffective against this unusual arrangement. Common sense and decency have no effect on the property owner, and lawyers have been stymied by this unorthodox incongruity.  A nonresident, this Mr. Duncan shows no concern that his actions and defiance is adversely affecting a lot of people, especially kids.
 
    The actual name of the lake is Natasulga, but we all call it Lake Nasty.  The lake is on the north side of the 2800 block of Arlington, south of Colonial Drive, just east of John Young Parkway in Orlando.  You can't miss it, your eyes and nose won't let you. A horrible eyesore, our neighborhood association has finally got a hearing at City Hall Second Floor Council Chambers on May 8th at 9 A.M. Any help or encouragement would be appreciated.  
 
Thank you, it is sincerely to give our kids a place to play, and Governor, here's a special prayer for your daughter.
 
 
John Weyrick
2852 W. Harwood St.
Orlando, FL  32805
(407) 299-3717
