-----Original Message-----
From: William Harrison [mailto:wharrison@wgharrison.com]
Sent: Friday, May 03, 2002 11:15 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Tyndall AFB


Hey! I'm concerned about the affect of the possible Vieques mission relocation to Eglin. General Hodgekins indicated to me last week that move would likely close Tyndall's primary mission of pilot training. The Navy's proposal of conducting the training missions 3 times a year for 2 weeks each time would prevent Tyndall from training in the Gulf. Since Eglin controls the Gulf range, they will prohibit Tyndall from using the range during their training. It is my understanding that Tyndall uses the range more than all other users combined. The training missions would disrupt the Tyndall pilot training syllabus so that the pilots could not complete their training within the schedule outlined by the Air Force. 

I've talked with Brian Yablonski and Brett Doster about these concerns and they can give you more details. At your convenience, it might be useful for you to call General Hodgekins and cross-examine him about what Vieques-to-Eglin will really mean to Bay County.   

I'm proud of you! William

Hello Governor Bush,  I would like to tell you of the help I received from our Local Police Department in LaBelle.  I have a Group Home for Developmentally Delayed, housing 5 adults. I am worried that she is going to be in a situation of extreme difficulty if not helped, as her stealing is not just in the home.  I asked for the help of the LaBelle Sheriff  Steve Worley, who invited my client to have a tour of the jail as a deterrent measure.  Corporal Tracy McClain talked to my client and arranged for her to go into the jail. He were incredible, very assertive, but not aggressive in his approach to her problem, she was taken
into the jail to see what happens to offenders.  It has had a very positive effect on her and she has said she does not want to go there again under any circumstances.  I am hoping this will help in her behavior problem to eliminate her stealing.  I felt you needed to have a positive story about out law enforcement.  Thank you for your time.

-----Original Message-----
From: Carlos Perez [mailto:carlos@prostahelp.com]
Sent: Friday, May 03, 2002 1:13 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Coverage of Urinozinc-Prostahelp, dietary supplement for the prostate by Medicaid


May 3, 2002
 
Honorable Governor Jeb Bush
Tallahassee, Florida
 
Dear Jeb:
 
On May 2, 2002, I was in Tallahassee in separate meetings with John O. Agwunobi, M.D., Secretary of Health, and Ms. Mary Pat Moore, Assistant Deputy Secretary for Medicaid Operations, to discuss the possibility of Urinozinc-Prostahelp, dietary supplement for the prostate to be covered by Medicaid.
 
I presented to both of them a presentation letter along with a company packet of Urinozinc-Prostahelp, of which I am sending you a copy under separate cover via mail. 
 
Mr. Jerry Wells, Pharmacy Program Manager for the Medicaid Pharmacy Program, was also present during my meeting with Ms. Moore, and has been very much aware of this product for quite some time.  Although Mr. Wells is an active defender of drugs, he admitted to Ms. Moore and myself that Urinozinc-Prostahelp really works, and that he has personally used the product.  He further admitted Medicaid coverage of Urinozinc-Prostahelp could save Medicaid a lot of money.
 
I actually think, based on my experience of ten years in the Miami area that the Medicaid coverage of Urinozinc-Prostahelp could save Medicaid 30% to 40% of total monies spent on prostate drugs.  Please see the price comparison chart below:

Price Comparison

Drugs v. Dietary Supplement
Price per year Medicaid cost

Proscar
$1040.76

Hytrin 1 mg
$716.76

Hytrin 2 mg
$752.76

Hytrin 5 mg
$806.76

Cardura 1 mg, 2 mg, 3mg
$500.76

Cardura 5 mg
$518.76

Urinozinc-Prostahelp, dietary supplement for the prostate
$250.00
 
Mr. Wells raised the issue of the difficulties involved for the processing of payment for non-drug products. The whole situation regarding this product is now open and we are trying to find a solution that as a result will save Florida Medicaid millions of dollars and serving the purpose of helping seniors maintain a healthy prostate. 
 
Jeb, I sincerely hope a pilot program can be initiated in the Dade county area for one or two years in order to properly evaluate its results.
 
Another, issue raised during this meeting was that perhaps companies of other dietary supplements will argue that they also deserve the same treatment.  However, as I pointed out to them, Urinozinc-Prostahelp is the only dietary supplement for the prostate with a U.S. Patent, and the only one submitted to two clinical studies with excellent results as mentioned in their letter (see attachment).  Finally, you can be sure this is a win win situation for the state of Florida.
 
Sincerely yours,
 
 
Carlos Perez
President
Vitanergy, Inc.

-----Original Message-----
From: AccessLink [mailto:AccessLink@msn.com]
Sent: Friday, May 03, 2002 12:35 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Drugs


Dear Governor Bush,
 
I was deeply touched by your recent presentation to the drug treatment and prevention professionals and law enforcement officers summit.  We send you our good energy and your family will stay in our prayers.
 
Several years ago a dear friend, Maurice Sweeney, was found dead in the toilet of a McDonald's in central Dublin from an overdose of heroine.  Maurice was an incredibly talented artist and a wonderful human being.  His death changed my life forever.  Thereafter, whenever the opportunity arose, I have spoken out and worked to eradicate our society from this blight on our community.  
 
I wish to pass on to you one idea from Ireland that had a very profound, positive effect on users and potential users of drugs.  Radio Telefis Eireann (the Irish national TV station) completed a program on drug use.  It was so stark, horrific and visually descriptive that the station, and the Irish Department of Health, credited it's airing with a substantial downturn in drug use for several years.
 
The station interviewed drug users - almost all long-term drug users - in their homes (often these places were the streets, under bridges, wooded areas etc.) and offered them anonymity.  Some choose the anonymous route, but most choose to conduct the interviews without anonymity.  Those who did participate were, as far as I recall, immune for prosecution for drug use up to that point in time.  
 
The drug users where filmed preparing drugs, discussing drugs, and shooting drugs (usually heroine) into many parts of their bodies.  The most horrific part of all was where drug users, who had so abused their 'obvious' vein sources, were reduced to injecting drugs through the veins in their groin areas.  This was all raw footage.  The overwhelming dinginess of the lives of the drug users on the film, had the effect of portraying an image of people so hopeless, so degenerate, so helpless, and so fragile that it led the Department of Health to declare the project a great success.
 
Doing something like this in our great state to show to schools might be a help with our children.  If you wish, I will gladly get a copy of the video for you.
 
Governor, it has taken me a long time to get up the courage to write this to you.  I thought I'd just continue to pray for your family, for all families, and that that would be enough.  Now, I am convinced that I should no longer keep this idea to myself.  With all best wishes,
 
Ailish M. Nic Phaidin
 
 
Ailish M. Nic Phaidin, MPRII
President & CEO
Access Link International, Inc.
211 Cocoa Street, S.E., Palm Bay, FL. 32909
Tel:   + 321-952-2978;   Fax:   + 321-953-0234
 <mailto:Ailish@AccessLinkInternational.com> Ailish@AccessLinkInternational.com

-----Original Message-----
From: Rebecca Smith [mailto:rebecca@admorgan.com]
Sent: Friday, May 03, 2002 1:52 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Construction Industry - Economic Impact


Dear Governor:

I was attending the "heroes luncheon" this afternoon in Tampa when you
addressed the room.  It was a moving tribute to all of the men and women who
serve our Country.  You would have been very proud of our State as Gen.
Franks represented our local community and our Country with such eloquence.
Your comments were heard by 5,000 who attended today's event.

I was also reminded to follow up with you on the issues we have discussed
previously.

I have had the opportunity to speak with you in person about the issue
related to the construction industry.  Specifically, our company, The A.D.
Morgan Corporation, with offices in Tampa and Melbourne have had two of our
Construction Contracts for Dept of Juvenile Justice put on indefinite hold
($15 million).  As you will recall, these are 90% Federally funded with the
money available to spend now.  The Juvenile Justice project in Seffner($7.3
million)  has been ready  to break ground since December of 2001.  The
project was stopped two weeks prior to our notice to proceed.

This has been quite a challenge for our company and to date, we have not
been successful in  replacing that revenue for the year 2002. Additionally,
we are currently contracted for work at the Lowell Correctional Institution,
(Ocala)  with a need for budget approval for our contract to be continued.
My understanding is that the budget request from DOC does not have much
support at this time.

While my first concern is my company, I want to take the opportunity to once
again make certain that you are aware that your directive to "boost the
economy through construction is NOT what is being funded".  Small business
comprises the heartbeat of our state.  As a small business employer of 50
people, responsible for their families, I must tell you that without
construction project funding for state projects, we will take a huge loss as
well as loose employees.  Our annual revenue is appx $50 million, we are in
our 14th year of business, this is our worst year yet.

With all that you are responsible for, please check to make certain that
construction funding is getting the attention you intended.  We need your
help.  Please let me know who I should speak with regarding funding for the
contracts we currently hold.

Sincerely and
with my full support,

Rebecca Smith, President
The A.D. Morgan Corporation

PS  I was having dinner with Congressman Sonny Montgomery on my recent trip
to Washington.  He asked about you and sends his best.  He also, encouraged
me to make certain to follow up and let you know what was happening with our
contracts.

Thanks again for your attention.  See you in Tampa on your next visit if not
the Republican Victory Committee Dinner.

>Governor, as a native of Miami and long involved with the DCF on a personal and professional level . . I can only continue to say the weakest link in our children’s service agencies  is DCF.  Rilya’s situation is not the only problem. I monitor sites for a variety of reasons . . .I work supposedly in tandem with the licensing unit for child care and family child care homes . . .I could tell you stories that would make you cry.  There are many of us trying to improve the quality of care offered in our early care and education environments and then there are those of us who are just working for a paycheck.  To Blame Chuck Auslander or Judge Kearney is not reasonable- the standards for hiring staff are dismal you get the caliber of people you recruit and pay for.  The good ones that stay rise to the top and are replaced again and again in the field.  When my sister did her internship (she is a psychologist) she found case files hidden in the drop ceiling, when she was injured by an orderly at a DCF facility they settled out of court with her because the attorney discovered the employees training file was a forgery.  I have made it my business to know the law and respect the intent of statute, I have had caseworkers tell me I was full  . . well figure out the rest.  This is not new, there were problems when Jim Towey was DA, Anita Bock did her damnest to make it work after the restructuring, I can’t fault any of those who are “at the top” - it is the belligerent,  barely educated case workers who should be given an extensive psych profile before they are ever allowed to have any semblance of authority over others.  The level of education is documentable but not relevant (or in some instances valid  . . .but that’s another subject). The supervisors are examples in learned helplessness, they expect work to be done by these people . . .LOOK AT THE ATTIITUDE OF THE CASE WORKER IN RILYA’S CASE!!  She is obviously unaffected by her previous demotions, and probation and subsequent firing . . .GEEZ. . .look how long it took before she could be fired . . .and it wasn’t because of this child but others.  I’m sorry I am upset . .If we can’t get control of the very office that holds the standards and the enforcement (ha ha) of these standards for the industry

From:	Robert Janauskas <wishfer@worldnet.att.net>
Sent:	Saturday, May 4, 2002 8:36 AM
To:	wishfer@att.net
Subject:	Re: Re:Florida State Attorney General's Office and the Timberlake Homeowners Association

Importance:	High

Dear Sharon, 
 
Thanks for your willingness to try to help these folks. You've spent an enormous amount of time and energy pursuing these matters with appropriate officials and we're doing the best we can to get this important message delivered. 
 
So far, no interest has been shown.  
 
Have you tried the ACLU in Miami? 
 
Also, there is a Miami Alternative Dispute Resolution group. I don't remember exactly where it's located? Because of all the system problems I've been having the last couple of weeks I've been out of the loop, so to speak. 
 
I saved access to the ADR group but lost it while trying to save my computer from total destruction. I'll check around to see if I can find it again and will let you know. You'll probably find it in the Yellow Pages of your telephone book under? No matter what word you use for yellow pages they seem to refer you somewhere else but I'd try; Mediation?  
 
I had a message from our CONDO chair Humberto in Miami but lost that, too. I think he said he had contacted several Hispanic organizations about this Timberlake situation because of the discrimination and possible civil rights violations being perpetrated upon these Florida residents. Keep in touch with him. Both of you are closest to the action down there. 
 
BTW, I'm going to send this to Gov Bush. He does read his mail private e-mail and sometimes sends out a terse reply. 
 
Sometimes it's very difficult for 'government' to comprehend these situations. I think they have the impression that some people deal in conspiracies so they sluff this stuff aside. 
 
I'm specifically concerned about Florida and have been for several years because of state endorsement of the enticements from the stakeholders and industry partisans to convince people to relocate while Caveat Emptor not Full Disclosure are the "Buy Words" during real estate transactions. 
 
While, I'm sure, there are thousands of content Citizens living in CID's in our state the failure to disclose before and after contract is a stupid way to run a railroad.
 
That's we tried so hard to have our Property Reform Task Force enacted during the recent legislative session but it fell on deaf ears at the Executive and Legislative levels of government. 
 
It's very sad, really! 
 
Apparently, the Hispanic's in the Miami area are taking it on the chin by unscrupulous individuals. I hope Governor Bush really listens this time and empower's the AG to conduct an appropriate investigation of the situation you've aluded to in your dealings with Tay and others down there.  
 
It's simply amazing that some lawyer hasn't taken up this cause and filed a class action lawsuit to expose this fraud. 
 
Well, we'll see if justice for the Citizens of Florida previal. At the moment, the scales are tipped in the wrong direction.  
 
As you know, along with yours, you can't see addresses on the Bcc line because they are suppressed. So it might look as if the message is going nowhere but I guarantee you it is far-reaching.  
 
Keep the faith. Maybe we'll get to the bottom of this terrible situation and expose what's going on down there. 
 
As you know, CBS 20/20 did a segment on HOA's a couple of weeks ago which upset the industry partisans, like the Community Association Institute which has come into private partnership with the Department of Business and Professional Regulation in Florida. 
 
We're still waiting for a response from Governor Bush, et al., about our concerns over this matter. As long as the CAI, a trade organization,  and it's legislative action committee's are running the show in Tallahassee we'll continue to have a difficult time achieving our goals and objectives to protect homeowners rights.  
 
I think CAI was part of a conspiracy to find the worst neighors in America which was shown on ABC 48 Hours the other day. Dan Rather got sucked in by these partisans. I suppose he doesn't know any better? 
 
Have a nice weekend.
 
The best to you and yours, 
Bob, 
Ocala, FL

From:	Marti G Leib <martil1@juno.com>
Sent:	Saturday, May 4, 2002 9:45 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Liza McFadden Meeting

Good Morning Jeb:
I don't know if Liza has had a chance to inform you as yet, but we 
met for about an hour this past Thursday, May 2 at her office at the
Capitol. What a great lady she is.  I brought her a copy of my book
"Resurrection of America: A Plan and Vision for Launching Communities on
Pathways of New Ethics, Morals, Values and Meanings for the Benefit of
Our Children." The time is right for a book such as this to help
capitalize on the "unity" and cohesiveness  of Americans since the
tragedies of 9/11.

Liza was quite taken aback with the fact I had written the book in such a
short period of time and had it in pre-publication form to give to her by
our meeting.  I also felt she was quite impressed with the content and
mentioned how the book was so detailed and flowed so well. It was a good
meeting and I hope I was able to impart to her the significance of the
book, it's intent and potential to try and make a difference in some way.
I have been communicating with a publisher on the west coast but have not
made any final decisions as yet. Of course I am wanting the "best deal"
which will get me major distribution and marketing and that which will
help me get this out to the masses.

After the meeting I delievered a copy of the book along with a request to
you to consider writing a preface/liner note for the book, and some
letters the kids at H.E.M. Club sent to you, to Georgia your
receptionist.  I hope you received them. Knowing you may not have the
time to read the book, I have asked Liza  to let you know her thoughts on
the book and the message and content. I also let her know of my request
for your consideration of liner notes and she emailed me she "would check
to see if you did things like this and get right back with me". I did not
hear from her on Friday, but I am certain she is on the case for me
knowing that she is very adept at her job. I am also trying to acquire
liner notes from notables such as Oprah Winfrey, Bill O'Reilly, Billy
Graham etc. 

Jeb, when I received a letter from Tara Wainright declining my request
for a meeting with you, she told me another  individual from your office
would be contacting me soon for a meeting.  I have not been contacted as
yet and wondered if these plans were still in motion. I am certain  Liza
can enlighten you ...whatever you do Jeb, please keep education Florida's
#1 priority....we'll find a way together to make everyone else realize,
it must be.

Keep up the good work and thank you for all your support and
encouragement and for all you do for the children of Florida.

Marti Garlow-Leib

-----Original Message-----
From: Hial1211@aol.com [mailto:Hial1211@aol.com]
Sent: Saturday, May 04, 2002 9:58 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Three Strikes 


Hi, is this going to include the 16-17 year old? Like the 10-20-Life? A brochure like the 10-20-Life would be good.  I distribute them at all of my events and crime watch meetings.  Carmen


House Bills 1393, 1395, 1397, 1399, and 1401 will re-enact the portions of the Three-Strike Violent Felony Offender Act of 1999.  The law requires mandatory prison terms for felons who commit a third violent felony within five years, drug traffickers, repeat rapists, and other violent criminals who violently assault law enforcement officers and people over 65 years old.  In addition to providing tough, mandatory prison terms, these five bills require public-service announcements explaining these mandatory prison sentences to advise the public and would-be violent criminals of the punishment they will receive if they commit these crimes

CharmT@tampabay.rr.com; MVankl@aol.com; Elysia6206@aol.com; rhw@interserv.com; Swidmayer@NBHD.org; MYWOLFBO@aol.com; burtner@nersp.nerdc.ufl.edu; jtabak@nova.edu; toniv.fddc@nettally.com; susiew@fha.org; TPFDMDPA@aol.com; MIC7513@aol.com; ruchin@nova.edu; Nanhrich1@aol.com; creelm@fdhc.state.fl.us; brantlem@fdhc.state.fl.us; Carl_Littlefield@dcf.state.fl.us; Kathleen_Kearney@dcf.state.fl.us; Sam_Navarro@dcf.state.fl.us; Susan_Dickerson@dcf.state.fl.us; Jeb Bush; AvantiSupport@aol.com; mcigales@bellsouth.net; cacao_gifts@yahoo.com; APerezvier@aol.com; PtoP1086@aol.com; ilianahernandez88@yahoo.com; filc@polaris.net; board@ncd.gov; staff@ncd.gov; FishinPapo@aol.com; ChickenRicken@aol.com; ADiaz0426@aol.com
Subject:	Re: DS Handbook (edit Version)

Dear Arlene,

Thank you for your thorough revision of the DS Handbook draft and for providing excellent suggestions.  Your suggestions have prompted me to take advantage of this opportunity to share with you and others my son's and my own personal experience with the Department in Miami (District 11), which has been so negative that I cannot help but remember how nice our lives used to be prior to the Home and Community Based Services Waiver.  While my son has been fortunate enough to meet some excellent professionals as support providers, our experience has been negatively impacted by Best Buddies, a provider of supported employment services.  Ironically, Best Buddies is a company that profits under the pretense that it helps individuals with developmental disabilities.  Best Buddies disregarded my son's disability when taking disciplinary action against him.  My son was terminated from his job at Best Buddies 11 months ago at the same time that Best Buddies suddenly and unfairly terminated his supported employment services without any due process rights.  The Department has allowed Best Buddies to discriminate against my son, to violate his rights, and the Department has participated in intentional discrimination against the very same client that they were supposed to be protecting.  Of course, Best Buddies is much more powerful than my son and I could ever be.  The Department watched in silence while we have continued to request assistance from those in the supervisory capacity to investigate our allegations and to order a change.  However, the Department refused to act on the knowledge and engaged in deliberate indifference, both considered intentional discrimination under the law.  The Department chose to ignore the truth and accepted false statements provided by Best Buddies and by my son's previous independent support coordinator, who hiding behind her incompetence as an independent support coordinator, found it easier to join Best Buddies in the discrimination than to face the truth of her own incompetence and neglect for her own client.  The Department and those in the supervisory capacity that could have chosen to stand by the truth and do something about it have demonstrated the same level of incompetence, negligence and intentional discrimination against my son.

Regarding the provision of supported employment services, it is my opinion that the Department allows many of the providers of this critical service to continue to treat clients, not as clients, but as second class citizens, and to continue the previous trend of placement in sheltered workshops (or "sweat shops" as I and others call them) while being funded as providers of supported employment services.  It has been our experience that the funding for supported employment services is misused by many of these providers and the supported employment services are not provided in a manner that is individualized and in community-based competitive employment settings.  

It is sad to see that no matter how much money is appropriated for Home and Community Based Services Waiver, in my opinion, the culture of the Department continues to be one of "give the client a fish so that he can eat for one day, rather than teach the client how to fish so that he can eat for the rest of his/her life."  There is no initiative, no creativity, no coordination of services, no entrepreneurial ideas for individuals with disabilities and no true goal for independence.  Quite the contrary, it seems that the goal continues to be "dependence."

It is my opinion that it is important for those who have loved ones with developmental disabilities to be fully aware that the Department rarely acts in a manner that would protect the health, safety, and/or welfare of a client. Quite the contrary, for the first time in my life, after my son is almost 25 years of age, I am considering obtaining some type of limited guardianship mainly to protect my son from the Department or, in the alternative, get as far away from the Department as we possibly can! It is also my opinion, based in our own personal experience, that the Advocacy Center for Persons with Disabilities, Florida's "protection and advocacy" agency, is rarely interested in the rights of individuals with developmental disabilities, especially in the area of access to supported employment and protection from discrimination.  It makes me sick to think what happens to those clients who have no one who can speak on their behalf, no one who can defend their rights and no one to turn to, so we pray for those individuals with disabilities and their families every night. Fortunately for my son, that's not his case and no one will ever silenced us.

Thank you again,


Lilliam Rangel-Diaz
Miami, Florida

From:	Sangenwhi@aol.com
Sent:	Saturday, May 4, 2002 7:01 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Transp. Disadvantaged Funding

Dear Governor Bush:

Please lead our state legislature in adequately funding the Transportation Disadvantaged Trust Fund.  Ask the senate to pass the house version of S.B. 100 and ask both houses to ratify the House position on line item 2102.  Then ask them to approve E - 69 and E - 70.  As our population ages, traffic gets more congested, more aged people become disabled, these measures are more needed than ever.  The TD program is the only affordable transportation available for many of our state's residents so they can access health care, job training and paid employment.  Lack of such service only costs tax payers more money with increased Medicaid expense and nursing home expense.

Thank you. 

Sincerely yours,       ......Sandra G. White

From:	Cushquina@aol.com
Sent:	Sunday, May 5, 2002 8:28 AM
To:	DVRcostinl@vr.doe.state.fl.us; Jeb Bush; Lacasa.carlos@leg.state.fl.us
Cc:	Posey.bill.sen.s15@leg.state.fl.us; futch.howard.web@leg.state.fl.us; Ball.randy@leg.state.fl.us; Haridopolos.mike@leg.state.fl.us; Needelman.mitch@leg.state.fl.us; Allen.bob@leg.state.fl.us; Jeb Bush; Fl_governor@eog.state.fl.us; Mckay.john.web@leg.state.fl.us; Feeney.tom@leg.state.fl.us
Subject:	Adult Funds


We have learned that Department of Education staff has asked that funds
be taken from the Adult Handicapped Fund in order to address deficits in
the VR and Blind Services Programs.   It is extremely unfair to adults
with disabilities that one of the programs benefiting them should be
compromised in order to benefit another.  The individuals who receive
the benefits of the Adult Basic Education provided through the Adult
Handicapped Fund are those who will likely never be able to be
competitively employed, and therefore, not able to benefit from VR
services.  In Miami-Dade, approximately 2,863 adults with disabilities
are registered at 25+ agencies.  Each receives an average of 25-30 hours
of educational services weekly.  While we recognize that there are many
competing funding priorities, we urge you NOT to reduce funding for the
DOE's Adult Handicapped Program.

In Brevard County over 329 students are being served daily and trying improve the quality of their lives.   The ABE program instruction advances their skills of self-determination and vastly improves the quality of their lives.  Besides, this is their right as citizens of this state!

In addition, individuals with disabilities must have a place to enhance skills for the rest of their lives and to prepare for supported employment before going to VR for services.  

It is inexplicable why this population's rights must continuously be the subject of the financial climate of the times and constantly be put at risk.  

Brevard County, as a result of the performance-based funding approach started two years ago, is making great strides toward improving and enhancing the self-determination of our ABE clients.  

We have a daughter who is neurologically compromised, and boderline mentally retarded.  ALthough to look at our daughter one might say she is a typically developing teenager.  To speak to her, you may even be deceived at first, however she will never be any older than an 8 year old mentally.  We want her to succeed in life, if  budget cuts come to these programs, our daughter has little chance of success as an adult.  As long as we are alive we will continue to provide for her, but just as many parents fear, what will happen to her after we are gone.  DOesn't our child have a right to dream of a future just the same as any other child?  Without Adult Ed opportunities many children have little hope of being independent or succeeding. 

Please look at your children regardless of their age, imagine every opportunity for them to be successful being challenged.   Imagine your child growing up with  reduced educational opportunities, voc tech programs (that may actually give our children a chance at independence ) being reduced or eliminated.  The future for our children looks pretty bleak:  Reduced educational opportunities/vocational opportunities = no job = no health insurance, no health insurance = no physician care/medication = no chance of survival.  Please, do not reduce our children's  chance for a future, they deserve a fair chance too. 

Thank you.

Sincerely,

Terry A. Tomaka

Norman and Terry Tomaka
1977 Player CIrcle North
Melbourne, FL 32935

                RE:  Outreach Funding

Dear Ms. Blalock:

I have served on Healthy Kids, now known as the KidCare Advisory Committee, 
for Sarasota County since the program began.  I also serve now as the Chair 
of the School Readiness Coalition of Sarasota County.

It is terribly frustrating for those of us who are trying to make life better 
for the least of our children when budgets are cut.  What is even more 
frustrating and hard to understand is the expenditure for marketing trinkets 
when dollars are scarce.

The need in Sarasota County is for a full-time KidCare Outreach Coordinator.  
If we really mean to serve needy families, we need to reach out to them with 
knowledgeable human beings.  Things such as clever devices will not do the 
job.  It is one-on-one human contact that will bring families into the 
program.

I am sending copies of this letter to the Governor and our Legislative 
Delegation by email.  The need is great.  Our  elected representatives need 
to make this happen for kids.

Please adequately fund the KidCare Program so that Outreach Coordinators can 
serve our families.

                    Thank you.

                    Giovanna Deveny

From:	UWaySB6@aol.com
Sent:	Sunday, May 5, 2002 1:34 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Re: Proviso language--serving all 4 tr olds

Dear Jeb,
Thank you for your response.  
I still want to reiterate the point that local coalitions have been given the authority to construct the delivery of early care and learning services to eligible children, 0-5 within their locale.  I would not want to negatively disrupt an already underfunded mandate.  It would require an incredible amount of funding, not to mention overall infrastructure, to serve all eligible 4 year olds across the state. This is a commitment that should be made by our state, but not at the expense of younger, eligible children. 

Although I remain optimistic and will  continue to "press" for more funding for the Readiness mandate, I have been made all too aware of the unavailability of the funding required to really make readiness for all children a reality.  It is frustrating, because we know through the brain research and longitudinal studies that we will continue to have children starting kindergarten significantly behind, with odds against them to ultimately "catch up".  We know the cost of social promotion, remediation, juvenile deliquency, drop outs, and crime but can't seem to make the obvious connect.

Thanks, as always, for your willingness to listen and respond.
Your friend, and fan,
Carol

Floridians
from sexual predators.

for

Dept.
of Children and Families), and Colleen Castille (your Director of
Cabinet
Affairs)

Senate budgets. However, Rep. Murman indicated that she will be on the
look
out for money that becomes available in the closing minutes of the
Session.
I am sure that if we have your support we will attain the appropriation.
It is important to note that we cannot jeopardize any of the College's
existing PECO projects in order to fund this request. In addition, we do
not
wish to reduce the community college system's PECO appropriation in
order to
fund this request.
Please let me know if you have any questions or suggestions. Thank you
for
your attention and support of this matter.

Yours truly,

Nancy

  <http://www.orlandosentinel.com/images/standard/small_logo.gif> 	
http://www.orlandosentinel.com/news/local/orl-ocjoey04050402may04.story 

'All I want is to graduate'

By April Hunt
Sentinel Staff Writer

May 4, 2002

ST. CLOUD -- Since August, Joey Meyer has awakened with the vision of walking triumphantly across the stage this spring and grasping his high-school diploma.

His parents had struggled to motivate their 17-year-old son with Down syndrome to enjoy school. So they prodded him to do his schoolwork by reinforcing how proud he would feel balancing a mortarboard on his head and donning the maroon-and-golden gown along with the rest of the St. Cloud High School Class of 2002.

Joey kept up his end of the bargain, but school district officials say there has been an unfortunate mistake -- he doesn't have the credits to graduate. They say his parents misunderstood the requirements, and the school regrets it didn't catch the mix-up sooner.

The bottom line: Joey won't be marching to "Pomp and Circumstance" on May 20 at Disney's Wide World of Sports.

Now, disappointed and bewildered, Joey has been sitting in a lawn chair under a beach umbrella on his front lawn across from East Lake Tohopekaliga and protesting the turn of events. A homemade sign pleads "Let Joe Graduate" and urges passing motorists to "Honk for Joey." When they do, he waves and smiles, but the smile is a dimmer version of the one in the photo of him in graduation garb.

"All I want is to graduate. It has been hard," said Joey, who sips iced tea to ward off the heat and takes breaks to play with his skateboard.

Many cars that stream past his Lakeshore Boulevard home blare their horns. Others stop in front of the historic 1914 home to get the full story. When he is feeling hopeful, Joey yells to supporters, "Vote for me."

His parents Bob and Sharon Meyer have assured him he is not being punished for something he did wrong. Still, Joey doesn't understand what has happened.

His parents paid the $40-plus to rent the cap and gown. His photo in graduation attire will appear in the Bulldogs' school yearbook, and his name is included on the T-shirts listing the senior class.

"In his eyes, we lied to him," said Bob Meyer, who made the sign when Joey originally wanted to picket at the school. "He is so hurt by this whole thing."

Osceola County School Superintendent Blaine Muse said he is sympathetic and admitted that school officials are partly to blame. Last fall, the district sent home a standard letter to Joey's parents, reminding them that special-education students who attended school for four years, earned the required credits and were at least 18 could participate in graduation in the spring.

Bob Meyer sent the form back, saying Joey, who turns 18 on May 14, would graduate this year. School officials, however, didn't realize until two weeks ago that Joey didn't qualify because he is four credits shy of the 22 required credits and has only been at the school for three years.

Muse said because of that, the school and Joey's parents share the blame. But, he added, it isn't enough to persuade him to alter school policy for just one student.

"The other students are walking because they met the requirements. He did not," Muse said.

The Meyers argue that an official could change their son's individual education program so he could participate in the ceremony. After all, they said, Joey doesn't need the diploma. He isn't going on to college or applying for any jobs where he will need those credits, they said.

That is why they support their son when he says he won't go back to St. Cloud High next year. It will be hard enough to get Joey, who has been out sick twice this week with a virus, to finish this year, his parents said.

That response doesn't surprise Sylvia Smith, an official with the Advocacy Center for Persons with Disabilities in Tallahassee. Smith, who is reviewing a complaint from the Meyers against the school district, said it is critical for teens with disabilities to be able to plan for their future.

All teenagers are still defining how they will fit into the world at large. But for a student like Joey, that work requires a lot more planning by parents and the school, to make sure they realize they will have a place by earning it.

"It is such a critical time," Smith said. "It sounds like a cruel practical joke."

Joey has been so sick and upset that his mom and dad fret he may not feel better for tonight's prom at the Wyndham Palace Hotel, even though some of the girls in his class have promised to save dances for him.

And his parents worry that Joey will refuse to attend graduation to see his sister Tiffany, who has cerebral palsy and has been in the special-education program as well, get her diploma.

"They're taking from him something that is so important," said Bob Meyer, who then asked his son what he thinks.

"I want to graduate," Joey answered with a shrug. "I just want to graduate."

April Hunt can be reached at 407-931-5940 or ahunt@orlandosentinel.com.



Copyright © 2002, Orlando  <http://orlandosentinel.com/> Sentinel

-----Original Message-----
From: Zan100@aol.com [mailto:Zan100@aol.com]
Sent: Sunday, May 05, 2002 12:07 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: JebBush
Subject: FCAT/Drug Czar


Dear Governor Bush:

During my research on DARE,  I discovered a speech by your drug czar, James McDonough, to District School Superintendents.  The speech was given on Thursday, March 7, 10:45am at the Ramada Inn North according to the information provided by the following website when searching McDonough.  http://www.myflorida.com/myflorida/government/governorinitiatives/drugcontrol/presentation.doc  The final paragraph of his speech is as follows:

Closing

"Our job is not to pass more work to you or your teachers.  We are cognizant of the demands and pressures in your classrooms.  And yet, we are together responsible for the growth and healthy development of our children.  We are working with you.  That is why I have asked the Department of Children and Families, Health and Education to work cooperatively to develop alcohol and other drug, tobacco and violence prevention and education passages for consideration in the preparation and test materials for the Florida Comprehensive Assessment Test (FCAT).  This is a statewide activity and a specific strategy recommended in the Florida Prevention System:  A Vision for the Prevention Component of the Florida Drug Control Strategy.  The work on this has begun, and we expect to begin delivery by 2004."

Although we do not have a problem with a proven or promising drug awareness/prevention program, we became somewhat concerned when we learned drug prevention questions are to be placed on a test children must pass in order to graduate.  After our local school district taught our elementary school aged child where to inject heroin to avoid detection we pulled her from the "drug prevention education" being provided in this area.  We have always spoke to our kids about the ill effects of drugs and bad choices but our instruction  might not match the "correct" answers on the FCAT.  We cannot agree with the state testing children on drug prevention, particularly on a test which is supposed to measure academic achievement.  
       But even putting our disagreement with Mr. McDonough on the matter of FCAT drug prevention testing aside, recent history leads me to honestly say that we would not trust DCF to design a drug prevention test for our children.  
       We strongly support you. We also support accountabililty but frankly, based on  history, DCF appears to be a dysfunctional department with an accountability deficit.   
       Because of our concerns, we would greatly appreciate it if your could ask your staff to obtain a sample of  FCAT questions for different grade levels. 

Respectfully,
Shannon and Scott Knox

Governor,
I am glad you are concerned about the uninsured in this state, as the Miami Herald states. Because if this Heathcare Bill is allowed to stand...I will be one of the uninsured, as well as thousands of other presently insured, hard working, taxpaying, self-employed citizens. 
 
If the issue is covering small business' medical needs -- that's an industry problem. If small businesses are being formed by sick people just to get small-business rates, why has the industry so aggressively sought our business, and still seek our  business? The insurance industry has enough remedies under current law to deal with this issue without putting the gun in our elected officials' hand and asking them to pull the trigger.

 
I can't see how throwing thousands of otherwise insured people out on the street will reduce the number of uninsured in this state.
I will be the first one to tell you Governor, this state needs insurance reform, it needs its uninsured covered, but like any doctor oath's, lets make sure we first do no harm in our solution to these problems.
 
 
Governor, if you allow this bill to stand, please advise me on your justifications....I will need to weight them closely for my own peace of mind if for nothing else.
 
ex animo
 
davidfarrar

Subject: Receipt for visit / Sunday, 05 May 2002

Gov Bush,

The Fla Commission on Human Relations has asked me for proof that I
attempted to contact them via official channels (e.g., phone calls or
visits to the Florida State Capitol) by the statutory one year deadline.

My records indicate that I visited your office on 01-25-2001, shortly
before 5 pm, only two months after an alleged incident of mistreatment,
about which we spoke in your recent visit to Lakeland.

Please forward the FCHR this proof that I visited your office on or about 
this date and requested help for this particular alleged racial
mistreatment. Please also send me a copy of the receipt of my visit by
posta mail to my address below.

Thank you.

-----Original Message-----
From: Pleusm@deland.org [mailto:Pleusm@deland.org]
Sent: Sunday, May 05, 2002 5:56 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: floreza@eog.state.fl.us
Subject: Patient Self Referral Act
Importance: High


 
Dear Governor Bush:  
 
As you may be aware, our community has been greatly concerned with the proposal by the Legislative to restrict Kidney Dialysis labs.  The Patient Self Referral Act, which was defeated during the regular session, is now being forwarded to you for signature.  From the City's perspective, this bill is poor public policy.  There is no other state that seeks to restrict a company from owning labs as well as clinics, because they like some care about what is actually in the patient's best interests.  
 
Before signing this bill, the City of DeLand would encourage you to hear both sides of the story by contacting DaVita Labs in DeLand.  Hear from them first hand what the lobbyist, who pushed this bill through, have neglected to tell the Legislature.  Please Governor, almost 300 jobs will be eliminated by the stroke of your pen; we are counting on you!.  I would encourage you to contact DaVita Labs and talk to Michael Haun, President or Maria Torres, Vice-President.  They can be reached at (386) 738-1809.
 
Thank you for your time and consideration!
 
 
 
Michael Pleus
Assistant City Manager
City of DeLand
120 South Florida Avenue
DeLand, Florida 32720
 
Phone  (386) 740-5706
Fax      (386) 740-6869
Email    pleusm@deland.org
 
From:	Pleusm@deland.org
Sent:	Sunday, May 5, 2002 7:57 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Disability Presumption

  
Governor:
 
There are two other issues which DeLand would request that you consider our position, in addition to the Patient Self Referral Act.  
 
Transportation Outreach Program
It goes without saying that the process this year had some flaws.  However, those of us who were ranked by the TOP Advisory Council only followed the process dictated by the Legislature and as such would ask that they honor it this time around before changing it.  In short, we are seeking $400,000 to help fund an Inter-modal Transit Facility in DeLand.  This 4000 square feet facility would accommodate both short and long haul transit, serve as the west-side super stop for VOTRAN, and feed into the commuter rail proposed by Congressman Mica.  The $400,000 would be combined with a City match and $2,000,000 that Congressman Mica is seeking for us at the federal level and has been included in the House Transportation Appropriations Bill.
 
Disability Presumption for Municipal Law Enforcement Officers
Soon, the Legislature will send to you for signature CS/CS/SB 108.  As you are no doubt aware, rising costs in the insurance market have caused a significant increase in premiums.  As we work with our employees to resolve their work-related injuries, we always have their best interest at heart.  However, we feel strongly that their injuries and consequently the benefits awarded should be based upon the weight of the evidence and not a presumption that heart disease and hypertension are job related.  Therefore, we would request that you veto this bill and asked the Legislature to try and better define the problem (if there is one) and come up with solutions that are more focused and in the best interest of everyone (i.e. the public at large, the City, and the police officers)  and not just one constituent group (the unions).  
 
Thanks again for your time and consideration on a Sunday!  mpp
 
Michael Pleus
Assistant City Manager
City of DeLand
120 South Florida Avenue
DeLand, Florida 32720
 
Phone  (386) 740-5706
Fax      (386) 740-6869
Email   pleusm@deland.org

> You allow yourself to fear death!

> Text of note left with bombs in Illinois, Iowa  
>  
> Following is the letter attached to pipe bombs left in mailboxes in Iowa
> and Illinois. Spelling and punctuation errors are preserved from the
> original:
>        
>        Mailboxes are exploding! Why, you ask?
>        Attention people.
>        You do things because you can and want (desire) to
>        If the government controls what you want to do, they control what
> you can do.
>        If you are under the impression that death exists, and you fear it,
> you do anything to avoid it. (This is the same way pain operates.
> Naturally we strive to avoid negative emotion/pain.)
>        You allow yourself to fear death! 
>        World authorities allowed, and still allow you to fear death! 
>        In avoiding death you are forced to conform, if you fail to
> conform, you suffer mentally and physically. (Are world powers utilizing
> the natural survival instinct in a way that allows them to capitalize on
> the people?)
>        To "live" (avoid death) in this society you are forced to
> conform/slave away.
>        I'm here to help you realize/ understand that you will live no
> matter what! It is up to you people to open your hearts and minds. There
> is no such thing as death. The people I've dismissed from this reality are
> not at all dead.
>        Conforming to the boundaries, and restrictions imposed by the
> government only reduces the substance in your lives. When 1% of the nation
> controls 99% of the nations total wealth, is it a wonder why there are
> control problems?
>        The United States strives to provide freedom for their people. Do
> we really have personal freedom? I've lived here for many years, and I see
> much limitation. Does the definition of freedom include limitation? I've
> learned about the history of various civilizations in history, and I see
> more and more limitation. Do you people enjoy this trend of limitation? If
> not, change it!
>        As long as you are uninformed about death you will continue to say
> "how high", when the government tells you to "jump". As long as the
> government is uninformed about death they will continue tell you to "jump"
> Is the government uninformed about death, or are they pretending?
>        You have been missing how things are, for very long. I'm obtaining
> your attention in the only way I can. More info is on its way. More
> "attention getters' are on the way. If I could, I would change only one
> person, unfortunately the resources are not accessible. It seems killing a
> single famous person would get the same media attention as killing
> numerous un-famous humans. There is less risk of being detained,
> associated with dismissing certain people.
>        Sincerely,
>        Someone Who Cares
>        PS. More info. will be delivered to various locations around the
> country.

		Governor,
		 
		I want to make my services available to help in anyway I can.  I did a number of TV interviews yesterday locally and stressed that this error was not systemic and that there are thousands of dedicated case workers saving children’s lives everyday in this system.
		 
		I have a number of ideas and strategies that I would recommend that center around moving to CBC quicker and streamlining the DCF state office to be a top notch oversight group. And I have more.

From:	Nellonthemove@aol.com
Sent:	Sunday, May 5, 2002 10:39 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Flag Bill

Dear Governor Bush:
There is a bill before you at this time to all anyone to fly a flag anyway they please without any restriction or standards by Homeowner Association. I plead with you to not take away the Homeowner Associations right to set standard's of how the flag can be displayed. No one wishes to deny any citizen the right to fly the American Flag, but I do think an Association has the right to set standards for how the flag is to be displayed in a respectful way. 
No doubt you have, and will again live in a community with Deed Restriction. This is something we choose to do, and in those restrictions we decide how certain things will be done in our community. By choice. Get the picture? Therefore, I ask you to veto the bill to allow anyone to fly a flag any way they choose, if they live in a Deed Restricted Community. 

                                     Thank You, Nell Arnold

From: Edward N. Ryan Jr. CET CIT [mailto:Ryan_CET@prodigy.net]
Sent: Monday, May 06, 2002 1:37 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Your upcoming election


Dear Governor Bush;
I thought it time to drop you a note and inform you that I will not be
voting for you in your bid for a second term. And I though it important
that you should know why. I was a very avid supporter of you in your
unsuccessful run for governor against Gov. Childs, and when you finally
won the seat 4 years ago. But frankly I have been very disappointed in
your performance. Especially as it pertains to the Manatee issue in
Brevard County. Your actions have directly affected my home values and
my quality of life. I find it amusing that the left is slamming your
environmental record, despite the fact that you threw them the Florida
Marine Industry, in the name of the manatee. I want you to know that I
will not vote for you, but I will not vote for your democratic opponent
either. For the first time since I was 21 years of age my vote for
Governor of this state will be blank. From what I have heard from
friends and family, you stand a very good chance of losing Brevard
County, one of your strongholds. I believe that it is time that you
stood behind members of the Marine Industry...on the unemployment line. 

Sincerely, 

Edward N. Ryan Jr. CET CIT
