-----Original Message-----
From: Ellen Bryan [mailto:eibryan@msn.com]
Sent: Monday, May 06, 2002 10:11 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: This is My Documentation on My Problem I Told You I Had!


Dear Governor Jeb, Sir,
 
    As I've seen you on T.V. lately, discussing your daughter's illness, I have cried TEARS along with you about your own daughter's problem. I truly understand, Sir, like you, how horrible it is to FIGHT a long-going, seemingly never-ending condition of one you love so much! 
 
     As I shared with you in an earlier message, I'm still dealing with the my oldest daughter, Virginia "Ginger" Bryan Martin, whose case you had investigated for me in 1998.  Ginger was diagnosed as bi-polar/manic depressive--our problem here just happens to be mental illness, COMPOUNDED by how inept Children & Families and the Polk County court system handles this type of abuse cases by REPEATEDLY just SENDING THE KIDS BACK "HOME" TO BE DAMAGED MORE!!
 
     My younger daughter, Julie (Bryan) Harter, (a/k/a "Lady Gator Trapper" and high school teacher) whom you met, keeps reminding me, 
 
"Mama, Jeb said for you to let him know IF HE COULD HELP, SO JUST SEND IT--and just see if HE can do anything for us to help these kids!!"  I then remind her about just how BUSY you already are!!
 
     Sir, I apologize ahead of time for any errors, the long length of this narrative and over emotional wordings because it has taken all night since 2 Sunday afternoon to get this ready for you. The injustice of the system has been a wrenching experience on me for years as I see how the cases of children--mine as well as many others--have been so MISHANDLED!!
 
    THANK YOU, in advance, for placing this in your ombudsman's hands. Ours Sir, is AN EXTREMELY BAD, COMPLICATED MESS that needs INVESTIGATING!!  I would not be writing you like this again, if this were not the case. It is with much personal agony that I write these facts, as I know believe them to be, to you!
 
     Please, call me, if I can answer any questions as someone tries to digest all this. My home number is: (863) 858-8792,  Work at Sleepy Hill Middle School: (863) 815-6577 Ext. 249, and my Cell: (863) 944-1894.
 
     I've attached my Education Vita to this document so your ombudsman can check out my credibility, and also there are attached some documents telling the history of the most recent events.
 
     I'M REALLY AT A LOSS ON JUST WHAT TO DO NOW--TODAY--BECAUSE I was just told by the case worker yesterday (Sunday) afternoon, that there's a COURT SESSION AT 1 P.M. TODAY,  Monday 6th, to decide the FOSTER HOME PLACEMENT for MY GRANDDAUGHTER, AMANDA ELLEN MARTIN, who just turned 14 May 1st.  
 
     I have called in for a substitute at school today and will be calling around to see IF I CAN POSSIBLY GET AN ATTORNEY ON SUCH SHORT NOTICE for the 1 P.M. hearing! This will possibly mean me having to refinance my home again, but after you read my session with Judge Strickland later in this document, you'll understand why I just can't make myself go before him again without an attorney to speak for me.
 
    Amanda (and the other kids) have ENDURED (for the last FOUR YEARS and ELEVEN MONTHS--since they were put back with their mother the SECOND TIME) the constant physical, mental, and emotional abuse and NEGLECT from their bi-polar/manic depressive mother, until Amanda is incorrigible, very sexually active and a repeated "run-away"! 
 
    Now, the Department is just "BOUNCING" her from place to place when Amanda needs intense, straight-forward discipline blended with LOVE!  
 
    IMPORTANT:  C & F's pattern is to just continue to "Bounce" this type kid from Foster Home to Foster Home until they "age-out" of the system--and I won't have that for these kids WHO WERE DOING WELL here with me, until the Foster Care system returned them to "mom" to be destroyed!!
 
      Governor Sir, I keep telling the Department of Children and Families that Amanda needs to be in a special facility until she can get the mental health/Christian counseling that she so DESPARATELY NEEDS to get "back on track" BEFORE SHE BECOMES PREGNANT--and there's another baby to deal with! 
 
     This WAS a wonderful, good child who loved her Lord and was a pleasure to all who knew her when she lived here. C & F keeps telling me that "there are no facilities to help children like this, but regular Foster homes", since Cornerstone, (a non-lock-up girl's facility below Mulberry with NOT MUCH LEADERSHIP and a BAD reputation), now refuses Amanda since she also  ran from there last week and was missing for TWO and ONE-HALF DAYS.
 
     I gave the C & F Protective Services Investigator case worker, Mr. Charles Brantley, all the information on "POTTER'S HOUSE" in Lake Placid, FL.  It is a state-approved facility, run by a Christian couple that has a VERY HIGH SUCCESS RATE with incorrigible, run-aways, and even pregnant young girls! Potter's House also faxed their information to Mr. Brantley.  But, I can't get him to call there to see IF they can help Amanda--instead of moving here from foster home to foster home.
 
     I have now been RESTRAINED from being able to HELP my grandchildren, even though they have been placed in MY CUSTODY THREE TIMES in their young lives and these kids have lived here, on my farm with me successfully for over 6 years of their childhood!  I DO NOT UNDERSTAND THIS!!
 
    Just as before when the system WORKED AGAINST ME TO SEND THESE KIDS "HOME"--THE BOTTOM LINE IS MONEY!!  They don't want their budget to be eaten up with kids like these who have MENTAL ILLNESS in their backgrounds!!  Kids who need lots of counseling and mental meds ARE expense to raise! It all boils back to DOLLARS!  Also, Ginger seems to have the uncanny luck to keep getting by doing so many things that others can't get by with.  
 
     Since Mr. Brantley had repeatedly told me at 7 P.M. last night that "we can't keep her in Juvenile Detention--even to stop her from running away and being on the streets and possibly getting hurt.  Since she has NO criminal charges against her that would be violating Amanda's civil rights because we have no criminal grounds to hold her on. 
 
     During that phone call, I told Mr. Brantley, "I'm fed up with the Department just passing this kid around, I'm really to WRITE GOVERNOR JEB BUSH AND/OR I'm going to call Channel 8 in Tampa and provide them with the necessary information to do an "Investigative Report" on my grandchildren's situation."
 
    Then, magically, three hours later at 10 P.M. Mr. Brantley called me back to inform me that "Amanda WAS being held at Juvenile Detention!"  Even though I was glad that she wouldn't be living on the streets and running again--for last night at least, I couldn't understand their SUDDEN CHANGE so that now Amanda would stay in Juvenile Detention! Brantley went on the explain that "Amanda does have a criminal charge of "lewd sexual behavior" on her AND it's also on the young boy that she had sex with who also was 13 years old at the time of the incidents, LAST JULY!!"  
 
     Mr. Brantley had to tell me this several times because I just didn't understand it! If there was NO criminal charge on her at 7 P.M. from last July, HOW could there be one on her at 10 P.M.??  Brantley went on to say that Amanda would "go before a judge at 8 o'clock Sunday morning."
 
    As I went to church Sunday morning, I called Mr. Brantley's cell phone to see what the 8 A.M. judge did.  He said the judge RELEASED Amanda into his (Brantley's) care FROM the Detention Center and he was now in his office, trying to find a foster home placement for her! I got angry and asked IF they couldn't hold her because there was NO criminal charges at 7 P.M., and then how did they "FIND" the criminal charges on the computer by 10 P.M. last night so they COULD hold her in J.D.?  HOW could a judge OVERLOOK those same charges in this morning's hearing and not retain her in Detention?  He grew frustrated with my questions and said, "I don't know, we may 'get it' from the District Attorney's office on Monday morning, but right now, I've just got to find a place for Amanda to stay!"
 
    Later, as I came home from church yesterday (Sunday) afternoon, I called Charles Brantley again.  He was STILL in his office looking for a Foster Care dependency placement for Amanda. He said Amanda was asleep there in his office and she did spend the night in Juvenile Detention.'' 
 
     I asked him if he had ever made the call to Potter's House.  He said, "No!  Amanda's right here, it would be difficult to talk with them with her in the room."  I said, "May I speak to Amanda?"  He answered, "Well, she's asleep."  I said, "Well, now would be a good time to go to the next office and call Potter House, wouldn't it?"
 
     This time, I just LOST IT!  I said, "You folks must THINK that I'm really stupid! I'm begging you to hold Amanda in a lock-up facility to KEEP HER SAFE AND UNPREGNANT until she gets some counseling because she's continually running away for sex on the streets.  You say, 'Can't do!'  Then, criminal charges pop-up on a computer screen at 10 P.M. when it's time for you all to go home and you haven't found her a "placement"? You are just covering your butts, so IF I get a MEDIA investigation going on about all this 'flipping kids around in family foster homes', you can say, "A JUDGE DECIDED THAT AMANDA IS TO BE PLACED IN A FOSTER HOME--NOT C & F." (which, by the way, she'll run from anyway--SHE'S told you that and done that now, several times!).  But, really YOU HAVE PLACED her in a foster family home, BECAUSE YOU KNOW WHAT STRINGS TO PULL and WHEN to pull up WHAT on a computer, but you make it LOOK like a judge decides--but you feed him the info he uses to make his decisions!!  That disgusts me!"
 
    Governor, I want to state something very clearly...Mr. Charles Brantley IS the best of ALL the many C & F workers I've had to deal with since 1991 while I've TRIED to protect and rear these children!  I believe he is being "pulled in many directions" with trying to do what is right while, at times, having to dance to the dictates of his superiors!  I do believe he has my grandchildren's best interests at heart.  
 
     I have told Brantley all along that "THE DEPARTMENT WILL AT SOME POINT, PULL YOU BACK MR. BRANTLEY FROM FULLY USING THE INFORMATION YOU'VE GATHERED IN INVESTIGATING THIS HORRIBLE CASE. BECAUSE TO PROSECUTE MY DAUGHTER TO THE FULLEST EXTENT, WOULD BE THEIR TOTAL ADMISSION THAT THEY WERE WRONG WITH ALL THE WORK THAT THEY DID IN ORDER TO RAM ROD THE FIVE AND ONE-HALF HOURS TRIAL IN JUNE, 1997, that sent these kids back into a hell--THEY WORKED TOO HARD TO ACCOMPLISH REUNIFICATION in 1997, to MAKE A FULL ADMISSION OF THEIR GROSS ERRORS that has and WILL continue to damage my grandchildren's lives permanently--THEY WILL NEVER ADMIT THAT!''
 
     Now, let me share with you the events that led up to me NOT EVEN BE CONSIDERED AS A PLACEMENT NOW even though these kids lived here with me successfully for over 6 years of their childhood:
 
I.  On March 14 around 2:00 P.M., Mr. Charles Brantley called me while at was at school teaching in my classroom to say that Amanda (then just 13) HAD TRIED TO COMMIT SUICIDE!  
 
     Mr. Brantley has not only handled complicated Amanda's case, but also investigated several abuses by their mother of her older brother, Jonathan, as well.  We finally got the help Jonathan so badly needed for his "HUFFING" addiction and he is currently adjudicated to the Adolescent Treatment Center near Sea World for mental and drug rehabilitation until he's 19 next January, at least.  
 
     (Note: Amanda and her mother have had MANY VIOLENT PHYSICAL FIGHTS!  Even one with a knife--which was investigated by C & F and Deputies in November of last year! (See attachments for details.)  The result was that, in their wisdom, C & F decided to "ALLOW" Ginger to "let me have Amanda voluntary", but with no paperwork, no Medical Permission for Treatment--nothing, but a verbal agreement, and no way to get the child medical assistance when/if she needed it. Amanda DID come live with me the first three weeks in December. Her grades went from Ds and Fs to As, Bs, and Cs!! But, it all blew up, when I mailed Ginger an AGREEMENT (attached) for her to sign so I would have Permission to get her treated AFTER I discovered that NONE OF THESE FOUR CHILDREN WERE TAKEN TO A DOCTOR OR DENTIST IN THE ALMOST FIVE YEARS THAT THEY HAVE BEEN GONE FROM MY HOME!!  THAT IS A CRIME AND TOTAL MEDICAL NEGLECT!)
 
    In his call to my school, Mr. Brantley went on to say that Amanda had skipped school with a boy for MANY days and when Ginger finally decided to do something about it, Amanda cut her wrist with a box blade after she and Ginger fought in Ginger's car in Bartow Middle School's parking lot. She was taken to Crisis Stabilization by ambulance on Wednesday, March 13. Mr. Brantley said Amanda was still in Crisis Stabilization Unit in Bartow and he had to PLACE her somewhere. He asked IF I would take both Amanda and Joshua (16 years old) back into my home for a Shelter Placement? He said C & F had to remove Josh too, because "IF ONE CHILD IS IN DANGER, then of course the other one is also!" He asked if I would not teach the next day and be in the dependency hearing in Bartow at 1 P.M.?
 
    Of course, I said to him, "YES!!", Then I added "but the Department should have never put those kids back in 1997 with my mentally ill daughter from me in the first place, because now all we have is MORE DAMAGED KIDS!!  DO YOU REALIZE THAT THIS IS THEIR THIRD (3RD) TIME BEING LEGALLY REMOVED FROM THEIR MOTHER??  And EVEN THOUGH FOSTER CARE 'CLEANED OUT THEIR FILE ON GINGER' after the kids were sent back the second time so she could GET A TEACHING JOB LAST YEAR, Ginger couldn't hold it because the students got volatile with her!  WHY CAN'T YOU GUYS AT C & F WAKE-UP and see my sick daughter is destroying these children? Are you going to keep putting them back there--UNTIL I BURY ONE OF THEM--OR GINGER??  GOD FORBID!!"
 
    That same night, Thursday, March 14, at 10 P.M., the tired case worker arrived at my home with Josh and Amanda and each had only a backpack of their belongings (to this day "mom" refuses to give them their things and C & F COULD get the law and go in and get these children's personal belongings. Mr. Brantley said he had to get the Sheriff's Department to even help him get Josh and his things out  from my uncooperative daughter at her paramour's (Dave Young, PR man for Bartow Ford) home.  Mr. Brantley said he was sorry that they were getting to me so late at night. He asked did I make arrangements to be in court the next day and I said, "Yes!" 
 
So the kids were actually placed here BEFORE the judge ordered it the next day!
 
II.  On the next day, Friday, March 15, Judge Roger Alcott presided in Juvenile Court.  He asked me from the bench IF he should recuse?  (Because he had been my deceased husband's and my attorney and also HAD BEEN MY DAUGHTER'S ATTORNEY DURING THE 5 AND 1/2 HOURS trial that resulted in the kids being given back to their mother in June, 1997.)  (MANY TIMES I HAVE ALSO WONDERED JUST HOW ATTORNEY ALCOTT WAS ALLOWED to represent Ginger, when he had been my attorney first and was privy to family history information...but it happened!)  I answered, "Yes sir, Judge Alcott, that's exactly what you should do!"
-------------------------------
 
- Now, Governor Jeb, it is important to be able to fully understand the recent events for you to know this history, so you and your ombudsman can understand what's happening in the courts here in Polk County:
 
   A few years back, it was in the paper here that Attorney Roger Alcott was up for your appointing him Judge. I sat at this computer then and decided NOT to write the following information and send it to you, Governor, because I decided to let God above judge Roger Alcott and not "tattle" to you about his early misconduct as a professional that might stop him from becoming a judge. I felt that was the RIGHT THING TO DO for me not to interfere... Never did I dream that I would live to regret that decision!
   
    STORY BEHIND THE STORY:  In the late '70s, Roger Alcott represented my deceased husband and I with some legal matters and we paid him off. Then in the early 1980s, my husband (Thomas C. Bryan, Sr.) was diagnosed with the same mental illness--bipolar/manic depressive--that my daughter Ginger has also been diagnosed with and after much alcoholism and many other problems, Tom divorced me after 27 years of marriage on September 26, 1985. 
 
    Fifty-nine days later, on December 2, 1985, Tom was very drunk as he chased me in his truck and he passed me losing control. I WATCHED IN HORROR as Tom's truck's bumper hit a huge oak tree 16 foot off the ground and then it flipped and killed him. It took me years and years to get beyond the grief of all that!
 
    I began to get attorney bills from Roger Alcott. I called Mr. Alcott's office and said, "Roger, Tom and I paid you off, what is this bill for??"
    Roger answered, "Ellen, months ago, I cleared up some bad checks written by Tom's girlfriend, Betty Fountain, for Tom."
    I answered, "But, Roger, you were Tom and MY lawyer. I didn't even know he had a girlfriend at that time, we were married--and you KNEW that! You have broken your fiduciary with me. This is NOT right!! IF you ever send me another bill for representing my husband's girlfriend, I'll go to the Florida Bar and report you!"
 
    Needless to say, no more bills ever came. 
 
--------------------------
 
Back to March 15, happenings:
 
III.  After Judge Alcott recused, we were told to wait and we all would be told which judge and what courtroom we would go to. At 3:45 we convened in another section of the courthouse with Judge Kornstein presiding. Ginger had a friend with her, Mrs. Shirley Porter, who Ginger asked the Judge to place the kids with--even after they had been moved in with me on Thursday night.
 
   After a short explanation of Amanda's situation by the C & F Attorney, Mr. Lazaro and the case worker, Mr. Charles Brantley, I was quickly given dependency custody of BOTH Amanda and Josh. This was the THIRD TIME in their short lives that they have been placed with me! I leave with a signed "SHELTER ORDER" in my hands.
 
     Mr. Brantley then told me that it was "only a FORMALITY to go back to court again on Monday because Judge Kornstein hadn't been a Juvenile Judge and it had to go through one. He also told me to go to Bartow Middle and Senior High and withdraw both kids on Monday morning so I could put Amanda into my middle school with me and put Josh in high school here. 
 
    So, all weekend, Amanda, Josh and I rearranged their old bedrooms and got used to our new situation on my farm.  We had a lot of catching up to do because the kids have not been allowed to see me much see 1997.  Maybe their birthdays and at Christmas. Amanda had been difficult to deal with on Saturday--she wanted to phone all the boys for hours and didn't like it when I limited her, but Sunday she had settled in and was more like her old self of almost 5 years ago.
 
    Then, at 9:10 P.M. Amanda ran away with a boyfriend who is now having to answer to the court about his actions in this! The Deputies later found her about 15 miles away in the bedroom of this 17 year old boyfriend. The Deputies call me, saying they were taking her to the Lakeland Regional Hospital because the deputies felt that she may still be suicidal. At 4 A.M., she was released to me and we came home to bed.
 
     The next morning, I got someone to stay with Josh and Amanda and left to WITHDRAW the kids from their Bartow schools and to go to the court hearing. After getting all the withdrawal papers for Josh, I ran out of time and couldn't get Amanda's withdrawal then so I went straight to Juvenile Court by 1 P.M.  As I arrived, we were told that Mr. Brantley, the case worker, had TWO cases at the same time period and I really began to get worried. Only he knew all the details on all the kinds of abuses that these kids had endured. WHY WAS HE SCHEDULED FOR COURT IN TWO PLACES AT ONCE??  WOULD HE BE WITH ME, when we were before the judge??
 
(Now, I start to really wish that I wasn't still paying off my big mortgage and that I had a "Cracker-Jack" attorney with me for my representation!!)  
 
     After a wait, we were told to go over into another part of the Courthouse, which was strange, where Judge J. Tim Strickland would be REVIEWING our Shelter Order.
 
   There was only the pertinent parties in the room. No other cases were being heard there. I looked around and couldn't see the usual stenographer or even a recording machine and wondered what kind of record was being kept of this particular hearing. They began, and sure enough, Mr. Brantley, the case worker was NOT PRESENT.  He was still down in the other part of courthouse do the other case scheduled at that SAME TIME. I started to ask Mr. Lazaro, C & F attorney, IF we could wait on Mr. Brantley to begin, but things had begun being said, so I just stood quietly before the bench.
 
    My daughter, Ginger, had an attorney, Mr. John Griffin with her. I wondered how her boyfriend, Dave Young PR man for Bartow Ford, had come up with the money so quickly. (I never believe much Ginger says, but Ginger later confided to her sister that even though Dave had told Ginger for months that he DID NOT WANT HER KIDS THERE ANYMORE, he had cashed in a C D just so Ginger could have representation to fight and prevent ME from getting the kids!)
 
    Mr. Griffin started hammering points showing that they wanted the kids MOVED from me. At this point I began to become physically sick. Mr. Brantley said that this hearing was "just a formality"...what was happening?
 
     I felt a little better when Judge Strickland make the very clear statement that, 
 
     "We're NOT HERE to change the placement of the kids who were just placed with Grandmother on Friday, we are here just to review the Shelter Order."
 
    Mr. Brantley was STILL NOT in the Courtroom and my uneasy feeling would NOT go away. Mr. Griffin kept on about Ginger not wanting the kids with me again. Finally, Ginger stepped forward and handed some papers to Judge Strickland, he concentrated on them for a few minutes.
 
------------------------------
     Now, Governor Jeb, this is the hard part for me to share...This is WHY I've been so unset since March 18th.  THE AWFUL THINGS THAT HAPPENED IN THIS SECTION IS WHAT FINALLY GAVE ME THE DRIVE TO INVOLVE YOU AGAIN IN THIS:
 
    I still don't know EXACTLY what papers Judge Strickland was reading that Ginger handled to him. (I've repeatedly asked Mr. Brantley to ask the Court for clarification to NO AVAIL!!)
 
    I still MUST know WHAT Ginger had that would turn the Judge from me!!  I KNOW I'm an "approved" adult because I teach 106 sixth graders in my classes EACH DAY and teach in a school with over 1,000 students!
 
    IF I'M O.K. for the school system, then what's wrong here?  And WHY won't they tell me the problem?
 
    At Ginger's Arraignment on April 10, they set her abuse on Amanda trial for July 8, and since this her THIRD time around, aren't they planning to Terminate her parental rights?  So, it looks like they would be praying to find someone to take these two troubled kids and finish raising them.  OR, ARE THEY PLANNING ON SENDING THESE CHILDREN BACK FOR MORE??  Again--what's going on here??
 
     (Note:  Mr. Brantley said his investigation was hampered because most of C & F files on Ginger were sorted out or had been tossed out.  He asked me SEVERAL TIMES IF I WOULD BE WILLING TO SHARE what documents I've accumulated through all these years of "court sessions"?  I said, I'd do what you need to help these kids!  So, on April 21, my younger daughter, Julie, and I went to Bartow after school and met with Mr. Brantley at his office with my huge storage tub of documentation since 1991 tracking the abuse cases of Ginger and her ex-husband, Curtiss Martin.  From 5 P.M. until 8 o'clock, Mr. Brantley had me search--especially for items about Ginger's and the kids' mental evaluations over the years.  I took them out of many five-inch notebooks, he copied what he wanted, I put them back into the notebooks and Julie collated his copies chronologically for him.  When we finished working at 8 P. M., he had a stack of copies almost 12 inches high.
 
    As Julie drove us home, Mr. Brantley called, excitedly saying he may have found what Ginger had used against me in court to get the kids removed from my home in March.  I still say that just need to petition the Judge for it.
    
    He thought maybe is was a statement by Judge Curry after the 1997 trial that I "was NOT for REUNIFICATION and was NOT helping the children to get ready for that."
 
   Well, Governor, as a mother, a teacher, grandmother...I will still say that even today.  When there was enough evidence to REMOVE kids TWICE by then...WHAT do people need before that say, "Don't send them home--A CHILD'S BODY??  So, yes--guilty as charged, because as her mother, I KNOW just how sick Ginger is...I'll never be for reunification--can't people see the DISFUNCTION OF ALL FOUR CHILDREN NOW??  Something caused those bad changes when they were doing O.K. with me!
---------
     There is one more possible thing that Ginger's papers MIGHT have been:
 
      Foster Care decided to send the kids back to Ginger only AFTER Dave Young, her paramour appeared on the scene to provide the financial support that Ginger was not able to do. Foster Care had all four kids, Ginger and myself (and maybe Curtiss ? ) evaluated by a psychologist in Winter Haven, named Linda Munro. My evaluation was not very positive.  This was not long after Ginger wanted to divorce Curt and I paid for it, thinking after 17 years of being married to an alcoholic, Ginger would get better when he was out of her life.  Later it was discovered that Ms. Munro had DATED THE CHILDREN'S FATHER IN HIGH SCHOOL, AND HER MOTHER IS BEST FRIEND WITH THE PATERNAL GRANDMOTHER!
______________________________
 
But, Judge Strickland leaned back in his chair and addressing the attendants there in court, he said,
 
     "You know, ALL THIS IS, IS A MOTHER-DAUGHTER FIGHT!"  Still talking to those in the courtroom Strickland mockingly said, "Yes, we can have all these 'mother-daughter' fights...less see now, on Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursdays, we can have mother-daughter fights... and then on Fridays...yes, then on Fridays we can have ALL our REGULAR court cases!  Don't you all think that would work out?" 
 
Of course, no one answered...
 
     Governor, Sir, I do NOT have words to tell you how I was feeling! Just writing this to you now, I am crying as I relive it!! I'll always remember looking up at that courtroom ceiling and saying in my mind, "God, are YOU hearing this?? You know my heart, you KNOW my love for Ginger and that the only way I'm able to help her, is to help her kids not be hurt by her in any way. 
 
     Just HOW can this man, who's a JUDGE, MOCK ME like this when he doesn't know all the hurts of the past 19 years I've endured with and because of my daughter? 
 
     He doesn't know the large mortgage I carry here at retirement age.
 
     He doesn't know that I COULD HAVE retired last June, IF I had not chosen to keep these abused grandchildren for SIX YEARS!
 
     He certainly wouldn't recognize how I'm STILL struggling to fight the system who caused them even more hurt--he believes this is 'just a mother-daughter' fight!
 
     WHY and HOW can this judge be doing this, when mere minutes ago he clearly said, "We're NOT HERE to change this placement!"
 
     Mr. Lazaro tried to make a point or two, but it was plain to see that something that the Judge had read had CHANGED his mind. I made myself speak up, determined to try to make him see that poor Joshua desperately needed back on his meds for mental concentration so he could focus in school because WHY would a GIFTED child with a very high I.Q. fail three or four times??
 
    I quoted all of Joshua's bad grades, bad behavior, and about the many morning he was LATE for school, etc., from the withdrawal papers I had just gotten from Bartow High.  I tried to tell Judge Strickland of the MANY days he had missed school or been in the school's in-suspension, etc. The Judge just made light of it, with some comment like, "That's not so bad, do you think?"
 
    Then I said, "Well, Judge, I do know Josh is crying out for help because he's in a very bad situation at home because Josh wrote, F-U-C-K about twenty feet across in the middle of the football field!"
 
     Judge Strickland looked at me with a small smile on his face and said, "Now, don't you think that's just normal for boys to do?" He waited for my answer...I finally managed to say, "No! Sir, as an educator of 31 years, I really DON'T BELIEVE that that is a 'normal' thing for a boy to do!"
 
     IMPORTANT:  Judge Strickland indicated with his arm that I was to hand him the papers in my hand.  He didn't know it was withdrawal papers, he just wanted whatever I had.  I handed them up to the judge.  He looked at them for a minute, then...
 
       As I was still reaching for my papers back with my arm up in the air to grasp them, Judge Strickland asked Mr. Brantley (who had finally came into the courtroom from the other case THAT HAD BEEN SCHEDULED AT THE SAME TIME SLOT IN ANOTHER PART OF THE COURTHOUSE).  
 
      JUDGE STRICKLAND HANDLED MY PAPERS ABOUT JOSH'S WITHDRAWAL TO GINGER'S ATTORNEY, MR. GRIFFIN, IGNORING THAT MY HAND WAS STILL OUT TO GET MY PAPERS BACK!!
 
     Mr. Brantley seemed as astonished as I. The next thing I knew, I heard the Judge questioning Brantley if there was ANOTHER PLACEMENT FOR JOSH AND AMANDA--OTHER THAN MY HOME!  Mr. Brantley mentioned Ginger's friend and the Judge asked if he had done a home study. Brantley said, No. The judge said, "Well, I think you need to get on it, I want them moved today!"  It was then after 4 P.M. 
 
     Governor, I'll always remember looking up and screaming in my mind, "God, WHERE are you?? HOW can this be happening??  These kids NEED STABILITY that ONLY I as their Guardian for over SIX YEARS can give them now!  God, what's happening here...someone's been paid off here...this just isn't right!
 
Then...during the long drive home--to tell my two grandchildren who had just gotten settled back in their bedrooms for over six years for THREE DAYS that Mr. Brantley would be coming for them--shortly--to move them to ANOTHER HOME!  Dear God, I don't think I can do this one!!  
 
Then...insult added to injury:  Mr. Brantley calls after I get home and tell the kids they are leaving me.  He WANTS ME TO BRING THEM TO HIM!  Just WHAT do these people think I'm made of?   
 
Thank God, Julie is still here and she goes ballistic and yells to him on the phone, "Just what else can you guys think of to put my mother through today??  I'll bring my niece and nephew to you!"
 
But, then...when the dust settles...pieces of conversations and bits of isolated facts began to come together:
 
How could Ginger WORK there in this courthouse for several years now--as a paid GUARDIAN for old people with those in authority thoroughly aware of the then TWO times that her four kids had been TAKEN AWAY FROM HER by the Courts??
 
Which one of the players possibly gave Ginger a document that stopped me from being considered as a placement for these kids?
 
WHY would Judge Charles Curry ALLOW GINGER TO be a GUARDIAN and HANDLE THE FUNDS, the LEGAL BUSINESS, AND MAKE MEDICAL DECISIONS FOR MANY OLD PEOPLE in his court knowing all the many ABUSES that Pediatricians, etc. testified in front of him about things Ginger had done to her own children that he heard in that 5 and 1/2 hour trial in 1997 in his Court?
 
Just what role did all this play in MY BEING SHUT OUT OF KEEPING THE KIDS with no clear explanation??
 
Why, at one point early last fall, did Ginger have a man to deliver an expensive electric cart for a disabled person to my house for me to "keep".  In typical Ginger fashion, I had NOT asked for it, she just wanted it kept here.  She left it here for some time, with me constantly sending messages through her sister for her to come get it! (Even though this hurts, I try never to deal directly with Ginger because she can be so cruel and her remarks sting long after she's gone.) Ginger finally indicated "it belongs to one of 'my old ladies', but you might need it some day with your bad knees, Mama."
 
SO WHAT'S GOING ON HERE???????????
 
ARE THE BEST THINGS FOR KIDS BEING UTILIZED BY OUR SYSTEMS??
 
****************
Each of Ginger's four children are troubled and carry mental/emotional problems as follows:
 
1.  Melisa Lynn Martin, Ginger's oldest is nineteen and not working or going to college.  Melisa was in home through Foster Care placement from 9 to 15 years old. Melisa was under several psychiatric and other mental health counselors while in my home and was on several different medications for mental/emotional distrubances.  After being sent back to her mother, Melisa has lived with several men, but she now has a 31 year old alcoholic paramour who has a 12 year old daughter living with his mother. Melisa miscarried his baby back after Christmas.  Thus, Melisa is patterning her life just like her mother's and living with someone because she is not capable of supporting herself.
 
2.  Jonathan "Jon" Curtiss Martin, 18 last January.  He only lived with me for about 6 months when he was turned back to his mother from my home by Foster Care workers although he did make pretty good grades then and was in the Gifted program. Jon was under several psychiatric and other mental health counselors while in my home and was on several different medications for mental/emotional distrubances, including Prozac. While Ginger had him, Jon was in more than 10 drug rehabs for "huffing" different substances in order to--an I quote him, "hurt my mother as she has hurt me!"  C & F investigated several incidents of violence between Ginger and Jon last year and Jon was finally adjudicated dependant by C & F last fall after Ginger moved him into an unfurnished apartment with no furniture.  Ginger's paramour, Dave would not allow Jon to live with them anymore. According to Jon, Ginger refused to give him his Social Security card and other items he needed to get employment--thus Jon began to steal items to support himself and his drug habits. Jon was caught stealing and placed in Juvenile Detention in Bartow last December through January after he ran from THREE adjudicated TEEN CHALLANGE programs! I heard Ginger scream at Judge Prince in January that she was "no longer responsible for Jon and all he needed was jail", then she left the courtroom! Judge Prince then asked me what Jon needed. I said BOTH mental and drug counseling! Jon was finally adjudicated to a mental/drug rehab (Adolescent Treatment Center near Sea World in Orlando) where I visit and write to him now regularly. His counselor, Luz ??, shared with me that Jon is a very disturbed young man and she is very concerned for his future and that Jon has "MANY ISSUES that he needs to settle with his mother, but that Jon refuses to be in any counseling sessions with Ginger at all!"
 
3.  Joshua Lynn Martin, now 16 1/2 was also under mental health counseling while in my placement for over 6 years, and was also on a lot of medications. Joshua was also in the Gifted Program and made good grades while here. He, more than both the girls, FEARED going back to his mom. Josh has FAILED several grades in the 4 years and 11 months he's be back under Ginger's care. Josh ONLY HAS 4 CREDITS IN HIGH SCHOOL AND HE SHOULD HAVE ABOUT 16 BY his age.  Josh has buried all of these hurts internally. I truly worry that he will never be fully functional, and even though very bright, not be able to hold down a job and work. Josh has been dabbling in Witchcraft lately.
 
4.  Amanda Ellen Martin, became 14 last week--and is going on a very street-wise 35! Much of this document has been about Amanda.  All the above descriptions of Amanda are the TOTAL OPPOSITE of the Amanda that left here in 1997.  Amanda was then quiet, settled, well-like by peers and adults and pretty mature for her age.  What a crime has been done to change this child into what she is now! I only pray that a miracle can transpire that will serve to turn Amanda around--to her former self!
 
Thank you to anyone long-suffering enough to read all this mess...
 
I PRAY you can help us before it's totally TOO late fpr any of these children...
 
I am NOT a militant or someone just looking for a cause to beat a drum over. 
 
My "cause" has always been children--for 31 years...but, if I fail my own blood, what possible good can I be to those I teach at school?
 
My grandchildren are my HEART--and America's FUTURE!!  
 
Sincerely yours,
 
Ellen Irene Bryan, as always--a/k/a Your very own Personal Encourager - 
                                                 Your "Florida Sunshine 'GIRL' "

From: Joan Spainhower [mailto:Spainhowerj@elderaffairs.org]

Subject: NY Times Article on Elder Ready


 


May 5, 2002
Florida Redoubles Effort to Accommodate Aged
By DANA CANEDY
UNEDIN, Fla. ? Evelyn Kusk used to fret about crossing a busy intersection
here on her way to the bank and the grocery store. She is 85 and not as
speedy as she used to be.

"Every time, I'd run even to make it halfway," said Mrs. Kusk, a retired
seamstress from Brooklyn. "I'm getting old, so I don't run that fast."

But Mrs. Kusk has been able to relax a bit lately. In recent months, the
city has begun adjusting its traffic lights to give pedestrians 15 seconds
more to cross the street. It has also been putting in wider sidewalks,
shelters for bus stops and stop signs with bigger, easier-to-read letters.

That is not all. Elderly residents like Mrs. Kusk, who walks and cycles
around town and insists on being independent, can now find emergency call
boxes on sidewalks and a ready supply of church volunteers to escort them on
errands and visits to the doctor. In addition, Mayor Tom Anderson says, a
$1.7 million center for the elderly, largely state-financed, will offer
computer and fitness classes, a dinner theater and line dancing. The city
has also begun providing many low-income elderly residents property-tax
breaks beyond those allowed by the state.

What has gotten into Dunedin (pronounced duh-NEE-din), a town of 35,000 on
the Gulf of Mexico 25 miles west of Tampa?

The answer is that it is in the middle of a half-million-dollar effort to
make life safer, easier and more appealing to people 65 and older. The
reasons have to do partly with some hard generational truths, partly with
enlightened self-interest. 

Dunedin is one of more than 40 Florida communities working to be certified
as "elder ready" under a program introduced in 2000 by Gov. Jeb Bush and the
state's Department of Elder Affairs. The program, Communities for a
Lifetime, is the country's most comprehensive effort to encourage
independent living by older people, whom Dunedin and the rest of Florida
have in abundance.

Communities that meet the program's guidelines will get state help in
marketing themselves to retirees, who will then, the thinking goes, buy
homes there, pay taxes there and stimulate the local economy. 

"Once you explain the concept to people ? that the whole purpose is to allow
elders to remain in their homes with dignity, security and purpose in an
elder-friendly environment ? then it makes sense for a community to begin to
prepare," said Peg Cummings, Dunedin's coordinator.

Cities in Florida and elsewhere have for years been making adjustments for
the elderly, like adding handrails to showers in hotels and, since adoption
of the Americans With Disabilities Act in 1990, ramps to buildings. But
under Florida's program, communities are making comprehensive changes.

"In the 50's, people said, `We need to set up an infrastructure to handle
all these children,' " said Bentley Lipscomb, director of the Florida AARP.
"Well, now it's the reverse."

Florida often confronts issues concerning the aging long before the rest of
the country, and for good reason. By at least one measure, it is the
nation's oldest state: in the 2000 census, its 2.8 million residents 65 or
older accounted for 17.6 percent of its population, compared with 12.4
percent for the nation as a whole. In Dunedin, 40 percent of the residents
are at least 65.

Census projections put Florida's figure at 26.3 percent by 2025, with the
national figure 18 percent.

"Florida is looked at as the incubator as to what the rest of the country
will look like in 20 years," said Terry F. White, secretary of the
Department of Elder Affairs. "Because of this, we need to be better prepared
than the rest of the nation."

To gain "elder ready" status, a city must demonstrate that it has made
changes to help the aged in categories including transportation, medical
services and law enforcement. A city that wins approval will be permitted to
post signs proclaiming itself elder-friendly and receive promotional support
from the state.

Under guidelines issued by the Department of Elder Affairs, the
participating cities themselves assess everything from ambulance response
times to whether the police department trains officers to spot schemes that
bilk the elderly.

The state also encourages communities to look for ways to make everyday life
easier for older people, like asking banks to install A.T.M.'s with large
buttons and encouraging grocery stores to include checkout lanes exclusively
for the elderly.

"This is the most comprehensive program I've heard of," said Charles Jarvis,
chairman of the United Seniors Association, an advocacy group. "When Florida
moves in a particular direction, other states follow." 

Cities seeking certification are permitted to pick and choose among the
state guidelines. 

"This isn't a `one size fits all' state," said Cathy Brown, executive
director of the Council on Aging of St. Johns County, which includes St.
Augustine, one of the participating cities. "The whole point is to have each
community say, `This is what we need in our community.' "

So communities begin by evaluating what changes would most improve the lives
of elderly people locally. St. Augustine has refurbished its senior
citizens' center and added new services there. 

The city also plans to build low-income housing for older residents, and
strengthen in-home services for them, she said.

Other cities, however, are still deciding whether to join the initiative.
But in the cities where changes are already under way, people like Donald
Blades voice appreciation.

"This isn't just elder-friendly," said Mr. Blades, 83, of Dunedin. "It's
just plain friendly."


# # #

-----Original Message-----
From: Zan100@aol.com [mailto:Zan100@aol.com]
Sent: Sunday, May 05, 2002 12:07 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: JebBush
Subject: FCAT/Drug Czar


Dear Governor Bush:

During my research on DARE,  I discovered a speech by your drug czar, James McDonough, to District School Superintendents.  The speech was given on Thursday, March 7, 10:45am at the Ramada Inn North according to the information provided by the following website when searching McDonough.  http://www.myflorida.com/myflorida/government/governorinitiatives/drugcontrol/presentation.doc  The final paragraph of his speech is as follows:

Closing

"Our job is not to pass more work to you or your teachers.  We are cognizant of the demands and pressures in your classrooms.  And yet, we are together responsible for the growth and healthy development of our children.  We are working with you.  That is why I have asked the Department of Children and Families, Health and Education to work cooperatively to develop alcohol and other drug, tobacco and violence prevention and education passages for consideration in the preparation and test materials for the Florida Comprehensive Assessment Test (FCAT).  This is a statewide activity and a specific strategy recommended in the Florida Prevention System:  A Vision for the Prevention Component of the Florida Drug Control Strategy.  The work on this has begun, and we expect to begin delivery by 2004."

Although we do not have a problem with a proven or promising drug awareness/prevention program, we became somewhat concerned when we learned drug prevention questions are to be placed on a test children must pass in order to graduate.  After our local school district taught our elementary school aged child where to inject heroin to avoid detection we pulled her from the "drug prevention education" being provided in this area.  We have always spoke to our kids about the ill effects of drugs and bad choices but our instruction  might not match the "correct" answers on the FCAT.  We cannot agree with the state testing children on drug prevention, particularly on a test which is supposed to measure academic achievement.  
       But even putting our disagreement with Mr. McDonough on the matter of FCAT drug prevention testing aside, recent history leads me to honestly say that we would not trust DCF to design a drug prevention test for our children.  
       We strongly support you. We also support accountabililty but frankly, based on  history, DCF appears to be a dysfunctional department with an accountability deficit.   
       Because of our concerns, we would greatly appreciate it if your could ask your staff to obtain a sample of  FCAT questions for different grade levels. 

Respectfully,
Shannon and Scott Knox

-----Original Message-----
From: Phyllis Kalifeh [mailto:pkalifeh@fcforum.org]
Sent: Sunday, May 05, 2002 7:50 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Line 2235 School Readiness Proviso
Importance: High


Dear Governor Bush, 

The proposed language by the House for school readiness proviso (line 2235) -- last sentence, fourth paragraph regarding prioritizing services for four year olds is well-intentioned in our efforts to meet school readiness goals.  However, there are unintended consequences and its impact on families is detrimental as follows: 


1.  Families who are eligible for services but have more than one eligible child would not be able to receive help for the other children (infants, toddlers, or school-age children).  The impact of that policy decision could prevent a parent's ability to work 
and force some families back on public assistance for the child care priority alone.  Throughout the history of these programs, families have been served as a unit. 


2.  School readiness does not just happen the year prior to kindergarten.  Research supports that the earlier the intervention for high-risk children, the better the outcomes for school readiness.  I know that is your goal as well and we applaud you for that. 


3.  This policy would appear unfair to the thousands of families on the waiting list for care.  We have been averaging over 40,000 eligible children per month. 


Even more critical, however, the priorities as stated in proviso would make children who are at-risk of abuse or neglect THIRD on the list for service!  Given the headlines and criticism about our system of protection for children, this simply doesn't make sense.  Nor do I believe that is your intention, Governor Bush. 


The priority as stated in proposed budget is as follows: 


1.  Children transitioning from welfare. 
2.  Four year olds who are eligible by income. 
3.  Children referred who are at-risk of abuse and/or neglect. 


Governor, please reconsider your support of this proposed proviso language.  We worked diligently to get support of your requested increase for school readiness.  If we had been successful, this would make sense.  And we sincerely thank you for your efforts to secure new dollars.  However, with over 40,000 eligible children on the waiting list, I fear for the safety and well-being of at-risk children in our state as well as the damaging effect this has on families with more than one eligible child. 


I know you care about children and I appreciate your support of school readiness.  Please reconsider.  Thank you Governor. 


Sincerely, 


Phyllis Kalifeh 
Florida Children's Forum

From:	Chris Corr <ccorr@joe.com>
Sent:	Monday, May 6, 2002 8:42 AM
To:	Jeb Bush; steve.seibert@dca.state.fl.us; henderc@dms.state.fl.us; denver.stutler@dep.state.fl.us; david.struhs@dep.state.fl.us; tom.barry@dot.state.fl.us; feeney.tom@leg.state.fl.us; danap@eog.state.fl.us
Subject:	In Case you Missed it...

I thought you might like to see this editorial from the Panama City News Herald, concering the West Bay Area Sector Plan.
As you know, the sector plan was developed to support the proposed relocation of the Panama City - Bay County
International Airport.


	Sunday, May 5, 2002

Our View
Politics at its best 
WEST BAY: The vision takes shape.

From Congress on down, elected officials tend to focus on the moment. They're bored stiff by the kind of policy tree-plantings in which the fruits ripen on some successor's watch. Their calendar doesn't go past the next election - nor, often, does the electorate's patience. 
So this week when the Bay County Commission approves the broad draft of a 100-year West Bay sector plan, assuming it does, the public service most exalted by civics textbooks will be on rare display. 
The document is a long-term agreement between regulators and the regulated - in this case the County Commission, which makes land-use rules, and the St. Joe Co., which owns virtually all the land. 
They're saying that to the best of their knowledge, this is the most responsible development vision they can imagine for a time when they're all dead. 
The plan before the commission on Tuesday is responsible. It promotes land uses not only compatible with each other, but with regional growth trends, with a wondrous environment and habitat, and with job-creating industrialization contingent on a new regional airport. 
Sector planning is a new concept in Florida. To see if works, the Legislature authorized five local governments statewide to adopt the broader planning framework as pilot projects. The plan drafted by St. Joe and the County Commission faces still more refinement this summer. Then it must pass muster with the state Department of Community Affairs. Eventually, though, the state and county will have the same vision for West Bay's 78,000 acres. 
Some changes will be necessary over time. No one can really imagine a hundred years off. St. Joe's most realistic projections encompass only the next quarter-century. By then, the new airport and adjacent industry would be in place, as would some low-density residential development and a network of controlled-access roads. 
Future commissioners can't be prohibited from attempting piecemeal changes in trade for immediate political gain. But they will do so in the knowledge that they chip away at Bay County's dream. 
One way to imagine the future is to change the past. Imagine if Panama City Beach had been developed under such far-sightedness; 25 years is a short time compared to the changes that come within that time. 
The West Bay model is not easily adopted by others, however. Cooperation of the property owners - or owner, fortunately, in the West Bay process - makes the work so much easier and not heavy-handed. A joint effort on the heavily plotted beach likely is impossible to achieve in a meaningful way. 
Nonetheless, the West Bay plan demonstrates that the best interest of property owners and the best interest of the larger community really can be the same. In this case, the same can be said for politics. 

© The News Herald

Sent from my BlackBerry Wireless Handheld (www.BlackBerry.net)


-----Original Message-----
From: Wells, Jerry <wellsj@fdhc.state.fl.us>
To: Medows, Rhonda M.D. <medowsr@fdhc.state.fl.us>
CC: Kitchens, George <kitcheng@fdhc.state.fl.us>; Moore, Mary Pat
<moorem@fdhc.state.fl.us>
Sent: Mon May 06 07:26:27 2002
Subject: RE: RE: Coverage of Urinozinc-Prostahelp, dietary supplement for
the prostate by Medicaid fup

Dr. Perez presents a self serving view of our meeting.  We do not dispute
that "saw palmetto extract" is effective in relieving the symptoms of BPH.
However, potential savings for Medicaid are not in the millions of dollars
since total spending for approved drugs in this category only represents
about two million and we get good rebates on these.  There could be some
savings but these should not be overstated.  Dr. Perez' specific formulation
may or may not offer improvement over other saw palmetto products.

Making payment for a product marketed as a nutritional supplement is
potentially problematic in that other marketers would insist on equal access
to Medicaid funding for their various "nutitional supplement" products with
disclaimed but clearly medical treatment marketing intent for everything
from headache and depression to cancer.  In addition, these products do not
have NDC (national drug code) listings which are required for claims
processing.  HIPAA will prohibit assignment of local billing codes and
require use of NDC's for claims processing later this year.  There are
dozens of products marketed with a "nutritional supplement" disclaimer that
make a variety of health benefit claims, some with some documentation and
others with only anecdotal support, but none with FDA approval.
Jerry

-----Original Message-----
From: Carlos Perez [mailto:carlos@prostahelp.com]
Sent: Friday, May 03, 2002 1:13 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Coverage of Urinozinc-Prostahelp, dietary supplement for the
prostate by Medicaid


May 3, 2002
 
Honorable Governor Jeb Bush
Tallahassee, Florida
 
Dear Jeb:
 
On May 2, 2002, I was in Tallahassee in separate meetings with John O.
Agwunobi, M.D., Secretary of Health, and Ms. Mary Pat Moore, Assistant
Deputy Secretary for Medicaid Operations, to discuss the possibility of
Urinozinc-Prostahelp, dietary supplement for the prostate to be covered by
Medicaid.
 
I presented to both of them a presentation letter along with a company
packet of Urinozinc-Prostahelp, of which I am sending you a copy under
separate cover via mail. 
 
Mr. Jerry Wells, Pharmacy Program Manager for the Medicaid Pharmacy Program,
was also present during my meeting with Ms. Moore, and has been very much
aware of this product for quite some time.  Although Mr. Wells is an active
defender of drugs, he admitted to Ms. Moore and myself that
Urinozinc-Prostahelp really works, and that he has personally used the
product.  He further admitted Medicaid coverage of Urinozinc-Prostahelp
could save Medicaid a lot of money.
 
I actually think, based on my experience of ten years in the Miami area that
the Medicaid coverage of Urinozinc-Prostahelp could save Medicaid 30% to 40%
of total monies spent on prostate drugs.  Please see the price comparison
chart below:
Price Comparison
Drugs v. Dietary Supplement
Price per year Medicaid cost
Proscar
$1040.76
Hytrin 1 mg
$716.76
Hytrin 2 mg
$752.76
Hytrin 5 mg
$806.76
Cardura 1 mg, 2 mg, 3mg
$500.76
Cardura 5 mg
$518.76
Urinozinc-Prostahelp, dietary supplement for the prostate
$250.00
 
Mr. Wells raised the issue of the difficulties involved for the processing
of payment for non-drug products. The whole situation regarding this product
is now open and we are trying to find a solution that as a result will save
Florida Medicaid millions of dollars and serving the purpose of helping
seniors maintain a healthy prostate. 
 
Jeb, I sincerely hope a pilot program can be initiated in the Dade county
area for one or two years in order to properly evaluate its results.
 
Another, issue raised during this meeting was that perhaps companies of
other dietary supplements will argue that they also deserve the same
treatment.  However, as I pointed out to them, Urinozinc-Prostahelp is the
only dietary supplement for the prostate with a U.S. Patent, and the only
one submitted to two clinical studies with excellent results as mentioned in
their letter (see attachment).  Finally, you can be sure this is a win win
situation for the state of Florida.
 
Sincerely yours,
 
 
Carlos Perez
President
Vitanergy, Inc.

Jacksonville has a firm commitment to assisting our Community Resource
Manager.  There is no better way to get out there and show how committed WE

----- Forwarded by Doreen Rutledge/D10/DCF on 05/06/02 10:09 AM -----
                                                                                                                   
                    Gail Killeen                                                                                   
                                         To:     Doreen Rutledge/D10/DCF@DCF                                       
                    05/06/02 09:50       cc:                                                                       
                    AM                   Subject:     Re: May is Diaper and Formula month!(Document link: Doreen   
                                         Rutledge)                                                                 
                                                                                                                   



14 churches collected diapers and baby misc items for us on May 5.  They
have until May 10 to finish their collections.  Some wanted to do the
entire month of May.  Many designated diaper drive coordinators at the
churches noted on their form that their place of business would also
collect.  All had a choice of delivering to us or being contacted for a
pick-up after May 10.  One church has delivered their donations already.
We have an ample supply of stuffed baby/toddler diaper bags and loose baby
items on hand (Jr League and Prudential Financial Services).  Catholic
Charities provides baby formula/baby food bags on-going.  Turn around time
from CC is less than one hour, if we run out of formula/food.

FANG has committed to doing a diaper drive in conjunction with Operation
Christmas Stocking in December. I also talked with TV12 about doing a
diaper drive in their viewing area but have not heard back yet (see below
e-mail sent to TV 12).

. . I enjoyed talking with you on the phone last week.  It is exciting to
know that Channel 12 may work with us on a Diaper Drive for children in
foster care.  Here is some information regarding a future diaper drive:
More than 1,300 abandoned, neglected or abused children are currently in
foster care in Baker, Clay, Duval, Nassau and St. Johns Counties.  45%
or more of children in foster care are in diapers.  When they come in to
care, they usually have just the clothes they are wearing, and no personal
belongings, much less diapers.  The average newborn to one year old uses
8-10 diapers a day.  Older children who have been severely neglected or
that have special medical needs and wear diapers are especially in need
of diapers. Older children may use 4 - 6 diapers a day. At an average of
six diapers
per child, 365 days a year, that equals 2,190 diapers per child, or
1,281,150 diapers
a year for 585 children.

Imagine what a diaper drive would do to help all these children.  There are
so many
fun ways that we could kick off this project. Perhaps Channel 12
personalities (the dads or dads to be) could have a diaper changing contest
on the air to see who was the fastest change artist.   This project would
blend well with Mother's Day, Father's Day, or on its own.
I hope that you will consider this worthwhile endeavor.  Please feel
free to contact me at 723-2143 or via e-mail to respond.  I look forward to
meeting with you to answer any questions you might have.  Thank you.

We also have two Jax Wal-Marts that call me to pick up packages year round,
and also two Target sources, one here in Jax and one in Orange Park.

I know you didn't ask, but the 2002 Back to School Party is 7/23 at
SkateWorld.  FP&L will again sponsor the party so every child in foster
care can skate free and Prudential again has committed to being the other
major sponsor.  We are meeting in two weeks to plan the party.


"How wonderful that nobody need wait a single moment before starting to
improve the world" - Anne Frank
Gail M. Killeen * Community Resources Rm 290 * 5920 Arlington Expressway *
Jacksonville, Fl 32211 * (904) 723-2143 * Suncom (904) 841-7243 * FAX:
(904) 723-5884


From:	Ilene Davis <ilenedavis@megabits.net>
Sent:	Monday, May 6, 2002 1:32 PM
To:	Posey, Bill; HARIDOPOLOS.MIKE; Jeb Bush
Subject:	maybe you can use this

 
I know I'm preaching to the choir so to speak, but maybe you can share this with the socialists on FL legislature, and with congress as well.
 
I bet Jim wouldn't have approved if those kids had stolen marbles, or money, to pay for vegetables.
 
True compassion comes from individuals who care, not politicians who steal from those who work hard to earn money for the needs of their OWN family.       I encourage you to read article by founder of Grameen Bank  (Orlando Sentinel, 5/6/02, guest column page) about helping people help themselves.   
 
I read a great book on growing companies that warned the problem with most companies is they put their best people in solving problems instead of creating new revenue.  The most that can be gained by cutting costs is what is being spent.  The most that can be gained by concentrating the best minds on growth of the company - on new ideas - new products - new methods - is UNLIMITED.
 
I don't know where florida stands nationally on PER CAPITA income or PER CAPITA wealth, but I'll bet even with being #5 in tech "jobs", we are low down the list.       Some people may move here late in life to die becuase of the estate tax benefits, but the intangible tax, the tax that encourages JOB PROVIDERS to live in florida, costs more for the very successful than many take as salaries.    
 
Any program that punishes the responsible to reward the irresponsible, or even taxes the rich to subsidize the poor, without a case by case review of how "the poor" got there.................. destroys the moral fabric of society.
 
ilene davis, taxpayer, financial advisor
 
RED MARBLES  


During the waning years of the depression in a small south eastern Idaho  
community, I used to stop by Brother Miller's roadside stand for  
farm-fresh produce as the season made it available.  Food and money were still  
extremely scarce and bartering was used, extensively.  


One particular day Brother Miller was bagging some early potatoes for  
me. I noticed a small boy, delicate of bone and feature, ragged but clean,  
hungrily apprising a basket of freshly picked green peas.  


I paid for my potatoes but was also drawn to the display of fresh green peas.  
I am a pushover for creamed peas and new potatoes.  Pondering the peas,  
I couldn't help overhearing the conversation between Brother Miller and  
the ragged boy next to me.  


"Hello Barry, how are you today?"  

"H'lo, Mr.  Miller.  Fine, thank ya.  Jus' admirin' them peas......  sure look good."  

"They are good, Barry.  How's your Ma?"  

"Fine.  Gittin' stronger alla' time."  

"Good.  Anything I can help you with?"  

"No, Sir.  Jus' admirin' them peas."  

"Would you like to take some home?"  

"No, Sir.  Got nuthin' to pay for 'em with."  

"Well, what have you to trade me for some of those peas?"  

"All I got's my prize marble here."  

"Is that right?  Let me see it."  

"Here 'tis.  She's a dandy."  

"I can see that.  Hmmmm, only thing is this one is blue and I sort of go  
for red. Do you have a red one like this at home?"  

"Not 'zackley .....but, almost."  

"Tell you what.  Take this sack of peas home with you and next trip this  
way let me look at that red marble."  

"Sure will.  Thanks, Mr.  Miller."  


Mrs.  Miller, who had been standing nearby, came over to help me.  
With a smile she said: "There are two other boys like him in our  
community, all three are in very poor circumstances.  


Jim just loves to bargain with them for peas, apples, tomatoes or  
whatever. When they come back with their red marbles, and they always do, he  
decides he doesn't like red after all and he sends them home with a bag of  
produce for a green marble or an orange one, perhaps."  


I left the stand, smiling to myself, impressed with this man.  A short  
time later I moved to Utah but I never forgot the story of this man, the boys 
and their bartering.  


Several years went by each more rapid than the previous one.  Just  
recently I had occasion to visit some old friends in that Idaho community and 
while I was there learned that Brother Miller had died.  
They were having his viewing that evening and knowing my friends wanted  
to go, I agreed to accompany them.  


Upon our arrival at the mortuary we fell into line to meet the relatives  
of the deceased and to offer whatever words of comfort we could. Ahead of  
us in line were three young men.  


One was in an army uniform and the other two wore nice haircuts, dark  
suits and white shirts...very professional looking.  
They approached Mrs.  Miller, standing smiling and composed, by her  
husband's casket.  Each of the young men hugged her, kissed her on the  
cheek, spoke briefly with her and moved on to the casket.  


Her misty light blue eyes followed them as, one by one, each young man  
stopped briefly and placed his own warm hand over the cold pale hand in  
the casket.  


Each left the mortuary, awkwardly, wiping his eyes.  


Our turn came to meet Mrs. Miller.  I told her who I was and mentioned  
the story she had told me about the marbles.  Eyes glistening she took my  
hand and led me to the casket.  "Those three young men, that just left, were  
the boys I told you about.  They just told me how they appreciated the  
things Jim "traded" them.  


Now, at last, when Jim could not change his mind about color or  
size...they came to pay their debt.  We've never had a great deal of the wealth of  
this world," she confided, "but, right now, Jim would consider himself the  
richest man in Idaho."  


With loving gentleness she lifted the lifeless fingers of her deceased  
husband. Resting underneath were three, magnificently shiny, red  marbles.  


Moral: We will not be remembered by our words, but by our kind deeds.  


May The Peace Of The Lord Be With You Always.  

And In All Ways!

From:	Dana, Pam <pam.dana@myflorida.com>
Sent:	Monday, May 6, 2002 11:45 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	citigroup

Importance:	High

For your meeting w/ Citigroup today, we are working w/ JAX community and EFI
on keeping Citigroup in JAX.   Below, you will find text from a letter I
sent to Jim King (Copied to George Seegers and Mayor Delaney) April 17.  We
stand ready to provide incentives to assist.  However, in order for us to
provide QTI for job expansions, the locals will have to put up a match.  So
far, the Mayor doesn't support providing incentives to encourage businesses
to grow on the South versus the North side of town.

CONFIDENTIALLY:  We are looking at using the remainder of the Closing Fund
($700K) as an incentive to keep Citigroup in Jacksonville.  This has not yet
been decided but it may be something for you to throw on the table if
discussions turn that direction.


-----------------------


The Honorable Jim King Jr.
State Senator
9485 Regency Square Blvd, Suite 108
Jacksonville, FL  32225

Dear Senator King:

On behalf of Governor Bush, thank you for your letter regarding Citigroup
and its Jacksonville operations.  George Seegers placed a call to the
Governor's Office and spoke with Kathleen Shanahan earlier this week to
discuss the company's long term plans as they relate to Jacksonville.
Kathleen immediately contacted my office to ensure we were aptly engaged.

While details are confidential per the company's request, Enterprise Florida
has been working with the company's consultant, as well as local economic
development leaders since February on Citigroup's growth and success in
Jacksonville.  Without all the facts before me, I can say that if Citigroup
were to expand its presence in Jacksonville, there are significant
incentives that the state could offer them--of course, if requested and
supported by the City of Jacksonville.  Such incentives include the
Qualified Targeted Industry (QTI) Tax Credit, Quick Response Training,
Incumbant Worker Training, Capital Investment Tax Credit, and the Closing
Fund. 
 
Please know, we greatly value the presence of Citigroup throughout our state
and stand ready to support their retention and continued expansion in any
way we are able.  Importantly, we will need to work closely and
cooperatively with Jacksonville leadership on this and therefore appreciate
your attention to this matter.  I would recommend that you place a call to
Mayor Delaney to affirm your support of the company in Jacksonville and your
readiness to assist in building its presence.  At that time, the Mayor can
outline those matters of concern to the City, if any.  I will ask the
Governor to consider doing the same.

Please do not hesitate to contact me directly if ever I can provide
assistance.  I can be reached on (850) 487-2568.

Sincerely,


Pamella J. Dana
Director
Office of Tourism, Trade, and Economic Development

-----Original Message-----
From: Lawrence G. Abele [mailto:labele@mailer.fsu.edu]
Sent: Monday, May 06, 2002 8:44 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: dalember@mailer.fsu.edu; Dianne Harrison; fleysief@mailer.fsu.edu; phayward@mailer.fsu.edu; RBRADLEY@odie.ISPA.FSU.EDU; Alvarez, Ralph; John.Winn@LASPBS.STATE.FL.US
Subject: graduation rates


Dear Governor,
        Thank you for your support of the school code bill as it would not have passed without your help.
        During the press conference you expressed some frustration at how long college students take to graduate and most of us in higher education agree.  We are taking steps to reduce the time to graduation but I did want to point out that we are doing a better job than it appears and part of the problem is how we define and report graduation rates.
        The term "time to graduation" is made up of many interrelated factors.  In the simplest case we could report a 70% 6 year rate but this is a 65% 4 year rate with another 5% of the students taking more time.   Also, the graduation rate in Florida is complicated as a result of our excellent job of articulation among institutions so that many students start at one institution and graduate at another yet these students are not counted at either institution.
        The chart below shows that at FSU (and most institutions in FL) most students do graduate in 4 years with an average of all students at 4.3 yrs.  How we report data affects our perception.  That said we are working hard to have all students graduate in 4 yrs or less.
        Thanks again for your support, Larry Abele
        
-- 

__________________________________
Lawrence G. Abele
Provost and Vice President for Academic Affairs
The Florida State University
212 Westcott Building
Tallahassee, FL 32306-1310
850/644-1765, phone
850/644-0172, fax

From:	Brown, Brewser <Brewser.Brown@MyFlorida.com>
Sent:	Monday, May 6, 2002 1:29 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	FW: Columns FCAT should oblige disabled

FYI

-----Original Message-----
From: Goff, Shan [mailto:GoffS@mail.doe.state.fl.us]
Sent: Monday, May 06, 2002 12:46 PM
To: 'Brown, Brewser'
Cc: Fisher, Thomas; Polland, Michele; Nabi, Doris
Subject: RE: Columns FCAT should oblige disabled


Sorry to be so tardy in my response. 

I think that the article is an accurate depiction of the situation with some
students who are not proficient/literate readers - for whatever reason
(e.g., dyslexia, provided a reader in lieu of effective reading instruction,
etc.).  The issue will still boil down to whether a standard diploma means
reading comprehension in Florida or not.  

Also highlighted here is that we (K-12) are perceived as keeping students
from getting access to colleges (who will assign students a full-time reader
as an accommodation) because they can't pass the HSCT or FCAT.  Remembering
that many states do not have standards for receipt of a high school diploma
(e.g., in Texas students with disabilities who complete their IEP goals get
the same diploma as students who take the TASS and high school courses) - I
believe NCLB will change that for all!

The School Code Rewrite does include the language about the disconnect
between classroom instructional and test accommodations.

Let me know if you need more!

-----Original Message-----
From: Brown, Brewser [mailto:Brewser.Brown@MyFlorida.com]

Subject: Columns FCAT should oblige disabled

-----Original Message-----
From: Ana Sotorrio [mailto:ASOTORRIO@miami-airport.com]
Sent: Friday, May 03, 2002 9:35 AM
To: pam.dana@myflorida.com
Cc: Manny Mencia; Miguel Southwell
Subject: International-to-International (ITI) Transit Program



Manny Mencia aked that we keep you posted on our meetings with U.S. Customs
regarding the implementation of the recently-issued Modified
International-to-International Transit Program.  I am pleased to report that
we met yesterday with Customs and the major international airlines operating
ITI flights at MIA and have agreed on the procedures for processing ITI
passengers and baggage.  The goal is to implement the modified procedures on
May 15 - the start of the peak summer travel season - provided we can make
certain minor facility modifications.   All the major issues with Customs
have been resolved, and they have been very cooperative.

Unfortunately, INS has not been as cooperative.  They did not attend the
scheduled meeting yesterday morning, however, we have a tentative meeting
scheduled for this afternoon.  At this point, we do not know how INS will
interpret the Modified ITI procedures issued jointly by the Justice
Department and the Treasury Department.  Because the inspection procedures
for ITI passengers are under INS' control, we cannot implement the modified
procedures without their cooperation and approval.  Our efforts to establish
a dialogue continue.

As you know, the issuance of the Modified ITI procedures is a major victory
for Miami International Airport and its international airlines operating ITI
flights.  One airline in particular, Iberia Airlines of Spain, was seriously
considering moving their Miami international connecting hub to another
country.  The modified ITI procedures were joyously welcomed by Iberia,
American Airlines, United Airlines, and others.  Hopefully, we will be able
to make progress with INS so that the Modified ITI procedures can be
implemented by May 15.

I hope you know how much we appreciate the Governor's support and active
participation on this issue.  Without his personal involvement, these
modified procedures would not have been possible.  Once again, you have our
deepest gratitude.

Please feel free to call me at (305) 876-7533 if you have any questions.  We
will continue to keep you posted.  Thank you.

From:	Hage, Jon <Jhage@charterschoolsusa.com>
Sent:	Monday, May 6, 2002 2:38 PM
To:	Hage, Jon
Subject:	WSJ Article on Charter Schools

May 3, 2002

 Wall Street Journal
 REVIEW & OUTLOOK
 Chokehold on Charters

Imagine a businessman who sees an opportunity to build a Burger King in
a
town that has never known anything but McDonald's. Then imagine that the

town's response is that he needs the permission of McDonald's
management.

That's precisely the model all too many states have imposed on charter
schools, one of the few innovations to come out of the public school
system.
And it looks as though it is about to get worse before it gets better,
as
the enemies of school choice agitate for "reforms" intended to claw back

political control.

New York state alone has almost two dozen restrictive bills now working
their way through the legislature. The one introduced by Assemblyman
Paul
Tonko, a Schenectady Democrat, would halt the opening of a dozen
charters
that have already been approved. As he puts it, "Charter schools drain
precious resources from public schools."

News flash: Charters are public schools.

But with one crucial difference. Charter schools were designed to work
outside the system, by giving parents more accountability and choice and

giving teachers and administrators more independence from the
bureaucracies
and unions. Clearly there is a huge public appetite for charters. From a

single charter school in St. Paul, Minnesota, serving just 20 students
10
years ago, America today has 2,357 charters serving 579,880 children.

The growing popularity of charters is precisely what is provoking the
education empire to strike back. As the Center for Education Reform
points
out, mostly this is a question of authority: In about half the 37 states

that allow charters, they remain hostage to state education departments
or
local school boards. That means that the people who decide whether a
charter
can open are often the same people who see charters as a threat to their

power.

Take the Vista Literacy Academy Charter School in California, which won
its
charter in the teeth of resistance from the local establishment. When
more
than 100 charter supporters turned out to persuade a reluctant Vista
school
board to approve their charter last year, the board moved their final
vote
to an 8 a.m. meeting -- when most parents would presumably be on their
way
to work. Undeterred, the parents threatened to mount a recall effort
against
any board member who voted "No." That seemed to persuade them; the board

voted 5-0 in favor.

But now the push has moved well beyond slowing down new charters. In
Michigan, political stalemate has given charters a reprieve from a bill
that
would have introduced more oversight from the state's Department of
Education -- but the political price was leaving intact a state cap on
the
number of charters. In Minnesota, the teachers unions say their aim is
to
force charters to "operate under the direction of locally elected
officials
with union representation." In Florida, the head of the School Board
Association wants to eliminate a charter applicant's ability to appeal a

denial from the local school board.

It speaks volumes about the charter movement that while it is parents
who
lead the effort to establish charters, the anti-charter agenda is pushed
by
school boards and teachers unions and the politicians who flack for
them.
And though these vested interests talk about standards and reform, what
they
really want is the control that would make charters indistinguishable
from
the one-size-fits-all approach of the education status quo. As one
anti-charter Tennessee legislator recently put it, "Says who we need
options?"

We don't pretend that charters are the answer to the education crisis
that
is leaving so many American children behind. But charters are one
answer,
and they do have the virtue of making money follow the child. The
hostility
that generates should remind us that to the education blob the enemy
isn't
merely vouchers. It's anything that takes money and power outside their
hands -- even if it's another public school.

 URL for this article:
http://online.wsj.com/article/0,,SB102038438579911600.djm,00.html

Hi,

Do you remember me? I'm the one who fought long and hard to get my elderly 
invalid stepmother, Naoma Hollis Innanen, back from the clutches of a young 
caregiver who took her away from all the family she had left.  Well, she 
died a year ago this last December. The caregiver got everything and we 
didn't even get her ashes so we could scatter them with our late father.

the house away and sold it off as well.  I got no help from the Volusia 
County DCF people, the sheriff or even the Titusville people when she was 
spirited off there.
