didn't listen to me then. You even attempted to fire the one really 
wonderful case worker who tried to help us. You didn't listen to her 
either. Now I see in the news that you have a missing little girl who's 
grandmother was blown off in a similar way to me.

Are you ready to listen now? I'm still here and I still am willing to help 
you but first you have to listen.

From:	Woodhouse16@aol.com
Sent:	Monday, May 6, 2002 6:34 PM
To:	villalobos.alex.web@leg.state.fl.us; costinl@vr.doe.state.fl.us; Jeb Bush
Subject:	from disabled students at Woodhouse

We are 16 disabled adults living at Woodhouse Group Home in Dania Beach, FL.  
We are writing in an attempt to discourage you from voting for a reduction in 
funding for Adults with Disabilities education in order to fund Vocational 
Rehab.  Our funding for all of the various programs and services that we 
receive are constantly under the threat of cuts.  Over the years, we have all 
attended and benefitted from adult education.  Billy G. has learned to add, 
subtract, and has increased his knowledge of Florida.  Ralph L. has learned 
to add values of coins and has received training and assistance in using 
Talking Books for the Blind.  At the Lighthouse for the Blind, Ralph attends 
the Broward County School's home economics class to learn how to cook and use 
the microwave.  Tony A. says he has learned to read and write.  Phillip S. 
has been learning to dial the area code when calling his relatives in Palm 
Beach.  Many of us have become proficient on the computer and use the 
internet regularly to find out about our community and to e mail friends, 
relatives and support coordinators. Due to our disabilities, it is difficult 
for others to understand our speech, so we need this.  

There is so much that we have gained over the years-
And none of this would be provided through Vocational Rehab.. 

We understand that some people benefit from V. R., but it isn't fair that we 
would lose services in order to help them.  There should be enough money for 
us all.  We already lost money two years ago when the adults with 
disabilities program went from being funded by FTE and the DOE, and went on a 
grant.  Then, this year, Governor Bush cut our grant money even more.

I feel education is very important for all of us at Woodhouse.  Do you 
realize that it is very important that we get as much education as we can 
get?  In the past, we weren't able to go to public school, and many of us 
didn't receive all of the help we should have.  It's sad to hear that you are 
thinking of not continuing with the education we have now.  I feel very str
ongly that this should not be discontinued because all of us are very 
important.  How would you feel if you were in our shoes?  Evidently you don't 
realize what I am talking about- because maybe you have never been to see an 
Adults with Disabilites education classroom.  Mr. Bush, please think about 
this before you allow them to take away our classrooms.  I am a registered 
voter like everyone else here, but I am speaking for those who can't speak 
for themselves.  Please find another way to find money besides taking it away 
from education.- Billy Gunn

-----Original Message-----
From: Moore, Tim <TimMoore@fdle.state.fl.us>

Subject: RE: DCF Scandals

Yes..... these checks can be done, either by "name checks" only or
preferably with fingerprints.  Remember, DCF did a namecheck only on
"Gerrilyn Graham" and got a negative reply since she had not used this alias
previously (it is one of many used by her).

i need to know the number of "caregivers".  Typically these  Florida
background checks are $15 each as established by Administrative Rule and
appropriated by law, but in this case, if the number isn't extremely large,
we will grandfather these in and  waive the Florida  fee to get these checks
current.   Then, DCF should establish a prospective policy immediately of
doing these checks prior to placement, for both relatives and non-relatives.


Finally we have convinced the FBI to provide federal criminal history
information for these purposes, but they will only provide if a fingerprint
card is submitted within 5 days after the "name check" is done.  The FBI
charges $24 per fingerprint check, and we do not have standing to solicit a
waiver.

 On a related note, while all DCF caseworkers are fingerprinted and checked
on original employment (as i understand it),  i would suggest that all DCF
caseworkers be checked again against both our criminal history file and
against the outstanding warrants file.  We stand ready to help make this
happen.

tim

-----Original Message-----
From: DeSantis8388@aol.com [mailto:DeSantis8388@aol.com]
Sent: Monday, May 06, 2002 1:43 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: DCF Scandals


Dear Governor Bush:

I am an attorney with 24 years of experience. I was employed by the  
Department of Children and Families (District 14) for fifteen months
ending 
February 2002.  I am sure you are aware of the  missing child case in
Miami, 
who did not receive the supervision required by law.  You are probably
aware 
the child was placed with someone with a criminal record. 

I can assure you from personal knowledge that failure to keep track of 
children is not an isolated incident at DCF.  Nor is placing children
with 
people with criminal records. While working in Bartow, I observed in
open 
court a case in which the department admitted that a  DCF protective
services 
worker  falsely  documented visits that were not made: in that case, the
case 
worker documented visiting a custodian-even though the custodian was
dead!  
Before I left, I observed that it was becoming common place for
protective 
services not to have seen the child for several months. (Though as of
last 
week there was a CYA order from the district office for every child to
be 
seen within 1 week). What I am describing here does even address the
category 
of misplaced children-children not necessarily missing, but unlocatable 
because the department did not keep records where they placed them!

In Polk County, the failure of a protective service worker to visit a
child 
would not make a blimp on a radar map.  Turnover of protective service 
workers is so rapid, they barely become familiar with their case loads
before 
they leave. They leave because of an abusive environment maintained by
middle 
management.  Duties best assigned to other parties are often assigned to
"PS" 
workers. Imagine assigning a rookie more than 100 cases (which
translates to 
100 monthly home visits and 400 supervised visits per month) in addition
to 
extensive writing of case plans and court appearances at judicial review

hearings. It is physically impossible to do their job completely. Middle

management offers them little help and relies on blaming the judicial
system 
(including one  of your appointees) for the mess they created.  If
anything 
goes visibly wrong, management scapegoats the case worker even when the
case 
worker may be correct. 

I doubt that Kathleen Kearney is aware how bad things are in District
14.  
Management's best skill is covering their mistakes. At DCF, employees
are 
told they  by management that we would never want to communicate with 
Kathleen Kearney, who the management  portrays as an irrational,
narcissist 
tyrant whose primary concern was getting her title correct on official
agency 
letterhead. When I was in private practice, I dealt with Kathleen
Kearney and 
she is not the person management described. I surmise the last thing 
management wanted is for the Secretary to know the truth.

What is the truth? Although DCF is a group of well intentioned social
workers 
, they  think they are not bound by the law. Historically, DCF was an
agency 
of social workers who were enjoined by the Florida Supreme Court from 
practicing law without a license.  The relics of the old system became
middle 
management, which perceives the agency as a turf war between the relics
and 
the legal system that oversees them.  The agency views legislative
mandates 
and judicial determinations with contempt. You made a fine appointment
with 
Roger Alcott. However, DCF would rather rationalize its failures by
blaming 
judges rather than bringing its practices in conformity with current
law. In 
the 15 months I was there, it would have been the uncommon case that met
any 
time standard set by the legislature. 

More importantly, DCF middle managers tend to make up their own law. The

legal division has no backbone and frivolous cases are often filed .
Even 
extreme conservatives would have to admit that the constitutional rights
of 
innocent parents are being trampled.  Taxpayer money is being wasted. 

To get more directly to my next point, a missing child is a terrible
thing. 
However, a much greater scandal is brewing. To state it simply, DCF is 
participating in a legal, but highly unseemly practice. The federal 
government pays a $4,000.00 incentive for each child, over a quota,
adopted 
out.  DCF gets its "inventory" of children to adopt out by terminating 
parental rights. DCF is filing lawsuits it knows it cannot win in an
attempt 
to obtain federal money. It hopes that some parents will sign surrenders
or 
default out of frustration with the system. The lead termination
attorney in 
Lakeland even publicly admitted he would take advantage of an
unrepresented 
person.   To give you an example, in one case I defended in private
practice, 
DCF tried to terminate one mother's rights because she repeatedly had
dirty 
laundry in her house! Our courts call termination of parental right
cases  
the equivalent of death penalty cases, and DCF is filing them to
subsidize 
their operating budget. Even when DCF loses these contested cases, the
public 
loses because of the  unwarranted trauma to the families and the legal
and 
court costs to state and local government are unconscionable.

One final point, before I go. DCF has a complete lack of understanding
of 
constitutional rights, I have personally seen a case where DCF insisted
it 
receive final divorce papers from a fundamentalist Christian as a
condition 
to the return of her daughter. This is not an isolated incident in
District 
15. The state has liability for such behavior under federal law. 

In summary, I once was opposed to privatization. DCF is so intrinsically

flawed, it must be totally abolished to serve the public. Privatization
may 
or may nor work better, but it will offer more accountability.


Sincerely,


Christopher DeSantis
561-879-4994

He has continuously adapted to and embraced many new challenges and has never let me down in our business or personal relationship.  He always represents his company well internally and externally.  I consistently receive positive comments on his positive attitude and professional manner from others.  His ability to perform at any level clearly stems from his natural ability that is truly genuine and sincere.

NEWS RELEASE from the United States Department of Defense

No. 228-02
(703)697-5131(media)
IMMEDIATE RELEASE
May 6, 2002
(703)428-0711(public/industry)

GENERAL OFFICER ANNOUNCEMENTS

GENERAL

Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld announced today that the
President has nominated Army Lt. Gen. James T. Hill, for
appointment to the rank of general with assignment as commander,
U.S. Southern Command, Miami, Fla.  Hill is currently serving as
the commanding general, I Corps and Fort Lewis, Fort Lewis,
Wash.

-----Original Message----- 
From: Jack Levine [mailto:martycfc@nettally.com] 
Sent: Monday, May 06, 2002 6:13 PM 
To: ADVOCATE ALERT 
Subject: Advocate Alert - Quick Two-Item Update 


Dear Child Advocate: 

This afternoon (Monday, May 6th), Governor Jeb Bush appointed a four-member Blue Ribbon Panel on Child Protection to review the performance of the child protection system in Miami-Dade County.  The panel members are: David Lawrence, President of the Early Childhood Initiatives Foundation (who will chair the panel); Sister Jeanne O'Laughlin, President of Barry University; Sara Herald, currently Chief Administrative Officer of Union Planters Bank and formerly Regional Vice-President of the Children's Home Society of Florida; and Carol Licko, a partner with Hogan and Hartson law firm, and former General Counsel for the Governor. 

The Panel is on a stringent time frame.  The Governor has asked for an interim report by May 20th, and a final report by June 3rd. We applaud the Governor for taking this assertive step and welcome the direct involvement of four such distinguished Floridians.  Given the intensity of nationwide interest in the plight of Rilya Wilson, and the depth of coverage of the series of missteps which have been documented in this case, it is essential that the community of Florida understand more about the intricacies of our child protection system.  

Advocates are eager to assist in this process, and are encouraged to communicate with the Governor and his staff regarding perceptions about the needs for system improvement, and opportunities for policy and program reform.  More information about the Blue Ribbon Panel (including the panel's mission/charge and members biographies) are available at www.myflorida.com.

READINESS PROVISO LANGUAGE UPDATE 

We reported Friday, May 3rd regarding proviso language being proposed in the budget which would target readiness funds for "four-year-olds", perhaps at the expense of services for children of other ages......We received unofficial word on Monday morning that the proposed language is "off the table" - meaning it is no longer being considered.  We do not have that on authority, however, so we're continued our advocacy on this matter of importance.....

WELCOME YOUR FEEDBACK AND VALUE YOUR SUPPORT. 

Jack Levine 
Center for Florida's Children 
center@floridakids.com

-----Original Message-----
From: info@gladescountyedc [mailto:info@gladescountyedc.com]
Sent: Friday, March 01, 2002 1:57 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Okeechobee Water way


I need your help, I realize this is a Federal issue, but maybe you can
direct to whom ever might assist us. Thanks so much, Hope all is well with
you and yours. Deb


Karen Estock of the Army Corp of Engineers in Clewiston has stated that
their funds have been cut in half. She has no money to clear the Okeechobee
Waterway. She has much less money to repair locks in dire need of
maintenance. Her funds come from a formula that relates to % of commercial
usage on the waterway, however, only 10% is commercial, 90% is recreational.
Shouldn't someone redo that formula so that funds are available to dredge
the sand bar that is in front of Port Myaka and in a couple of months boats
may not be able to pass. Stopping desperately needed traffic crossing the
state from ocean to gulf. The counties around the lake depend on its well
being from all angles, commercial, recreational, agricultural, environmental
. So can you please help with this. Thanks Glades County EDC director Debbie
Avery

Governor,

About ten days ago, the Appointments office sent out a memo requesting
additional candidates for the North Broward Hospital District.  Jim Blosser
figured my mom's background might make her an interesting candidate and
asked me to speak to my mother about applying.  After some research, she
decided it would be something she would be interested in applying for.  I
know you are familiar with her real estate development background, but she
also has served on a conciliatory & arbitration board, a national
scholarship panel as Florida's representative, chaired a social welfare
committee in Florida and been a religious education teacher.  I think this
involvement illustrates her commitment to addressing the needs of people in
our community.  Of course, since she's my mom...I only have great things to
say!  I just wanted to give you a heads up that she applied.  Thanks for
considering her and I understand that these are not easy decisions.

From:	David Farrar <farrardm@bellsouth.net>
Sent:	Monday, May 6, 2002 10:28 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Re: What is your suggestion?

Governor,
 
I will try to be brief.  But since this is not my area of expertise, I may be a trifle long...please bear with me.
 
I have briefly scanned through SB 46-I Health Care bill, mainly the "clean claim" section, the pilot health flex plan and the single insured provision.  
 
Since I view the primary reason for higher medical premiums almost exclusively on uncontrolled medical costs, forcing carriers to pay medical providers before a clean claim will simply allow the medical industry to gouge the consumer even more.  The clean claim proviso will make it even harder for carriers to hold down medical costs, or even develop an incentive to do so.
 
Governor, I am a court reporter. All I do all day long is take EUOs (examination under oaths) and IMEs (independent medical examination) testimony. Under our present structure there is no incentive for medical providers to cut costs. And as long as the insurance industry can simply go to the state and raise premiums to meet rising costs, they will not play their natural and vital role in reducing costs -- that leaves the consumer virtually powerless and defenseless. We should be passing laws that strengthen the insurance carrier's hands in making sure these medical costs are reasonable, necessary and affordable.  The mere fact that insurance carriers are not asking the Legislature for more tools to address rising medical costs tells me the direction of this bill is headed in the wrong direction.
 
The health flex pilot plan is designed to help provide medical coverage for the uninsured whose family gross income equals to or less than 200 percent of the federal poverty level..about $30,000 per year. I make around $60,000 a year, gross. I pay about $800 per month in medical coverage for my wife, daughter and myself. This amount is due to go up to $890 next year. I will not be able to afford 150 percent increase on this amount. I also will not qualify for your health flex plan at present, neither will a lot of other one-life groups. There is at present no safety net for us. The health flex plan must be far more developed to insure that no one is singled out to carry an unfair burden or be left behind.
 
That leave me with the single insured issue. I have nothing against joining a larger consumer group if the transition is seamless and harmless. I see nothing in this bill that assures me that bringing one-lifers into a larger consumer pool will be a simple matter of paperwork. I have paid into my present medical coverage for the past 15 years with very little medical expense. At my age, I am not a very good prospect to a new insurance carrier and an inticing target to jettison by my insurance carrier if given half a chance. The law must ensure the pooling of one-life groups is carried out in a transparent and professional manner.
 
Yes, Governor, there are good provisions in this bill, and insurance reform is needed. But this bill is premature in its design and puts people at risk needlessly. 
 
I know you will do your best to do what is right, as you have done before. But no irreversible harm will come from putting this reform bill off another year so adequate provisions can be made to protect all the people.
 
ex animo
 
davidfarrar

----- Original Message ----- 
From: Jeb Bush <mailto:jeb@jeb.org>

Sent: Sunday, May 05, 2002 6:02 PM
Subject: RE: I have been steamrolled


the bill has good provisions like the requirement to promptly pay provider, the health flex provision and others.  I have no taken a decision on the bill which will arrive in our office next week.
 
What is your suggestion of how to deal with the problems of single insured?
 

Jeb Bush

-----Original Message-----
From: David Farrar [mailto:farrardm@bellsouth.net]
Sent: Sunday, May 05, 2002 3:26 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: I have been steamrolled


Governor,
I am glad you are concerned about the uninsured in this state, as the Miami Herald states. Because if this Heathcare Bill is allowed to stand...I will be one of the uninsured, as well as thousands of other presently insured, hard working, taxpaying, self-employed citizens. 
 
If the issue is covering small business' medical needs -- that's an industry problem. If small businesses are being formed by sick people just to get small-business rates, why has the industry so aggressively sought our business, and still seek our  business? The insurance industry has enough remedies under current law to deal with this issue without putting the gun in our elected officials' hand and asking them to pull the trigger.

 
I can't see how throwing thousands of otherwise insured people out on the street will reduce the number of uninsured in this state.
I will be the first one to tell you Governor, this state needs insurance reform, it needs its uninsured covered, but like any doctor oath's, lets make sure we first do no harm in our solution to these problems.
 
 
Governor, if you allow this bill to stand, please advise me on your justifications....I will need to weight them closely for my own peace of mind if for nothing else.
 
ex animo
 
davidfarrar

From:	Jeb Bush
Sent:	Tuesday, May 7, 2002 6:41 AM
To:	Laura Branker (E-mail)
Subject:	FW: GOVERNOR, YOU JUST WILL NOT BELIEVE TODAY'S COURT HAPPENINGS!

 
 

Jeb Bush

-----Original Message-----
From: Ellen Bryan [mailto:eibryan@msn.com]
Sent: Tuesday, May 07, 2002 1:02 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: GOVERNOR, YOU JUST WILL NOT BELIEVE TODAY'S COURT HAPPENINGS!


Dear Governor Jeb,
 
     Jeb, Sir, I PROMISE NOT to write to you about EVERY LITTLE ISSUE that arises in this unending cycle of trouble, but I would like to share with you about how today's court session went--it had some very rough moments for me--from a surprising source--a Children and Families Attorney...read on: 
 
We were to be in Judge Roger Alcott's courtroom at 1:30 P.M. for Amanda's hearing.  When I walked in my daughter, Ginger, was already seated in a crowd and she hatefully said, getting louder and louder, "Just what are YOU doing here? You don't belong here! Judge Strickland has put you out of the loop! You are no longer to have anything to do with my children. Judge Strickland is going to THROW YOU OUT OF HIS COURTROOM... YOU ARE NOT supposed to be here! Judge Strickland is going to charge you with CONTEMPT OF COURT!" I just ignored her and sat down in an empty seat. Ginger made a few more quiet remarks then settled down.
 
After Judge Alcott handled the next case, with about 50 people in the room, he startled me when he said loudly, "Ms. Bryan, Ms. Bryan--WHAT are you doing here?" I didn't know that he was aware that I was even in the room.
 
I answered and said, "This is where the caseworker told me to be." 
 
He then asked my daughter and I to come forward so he could see why we were in his courtroom. Ginger answered saying that we were there to have a "Pick-up Order" hearing from Amanda's last run-away that had to be signed. Alcott said, "Well, I'm not going to do it. We'll call up stairs and see when Judge Strickland is available to hear it." So we were told to go upstairs.
 
As I moved outside into the hall, Ginger was ahead of me and she turned around towards me started getting very loud saying, "Have you received your papers yet? Melisa, Jon, Josh, Amanda and I ARE SUING YOU FOR YOUR HOUSE because of all your interference in our lives throughout the years! Why, you even managed to get me kicked out of college!" Having heard threats like this from Ginger before, I just tried to ignore her.
 
To get away from the scene, I just turned on my heel and went right back into the courtroom and waited for the caseworker, Mr. Charles Brantley, and the C & F attorney, Mr. Bob Hancock, to come out. There was another gentleman with them only identified as an "observer". Then I followed them out and lagged behind so Ginger couldn't say anything else to me. I trailed them up to the 7th floor to Judge Strickland's area. 
 
At this point I was worried because it was NOT possible to find an attorney this morning who would go with me to court on such short notice and make financial arrangements with me--so once again, I was alone. But, I had to find out where they have placed Amanda, so I went on up to Judge Strickland's courtroom anyway--dreading the embarrassment of being found in Contempt just because I want to know what happens with my grandchild that I raised for years.
 
After we five sat down in the foyer, the C & F attorney, Mr. Bob Hancock, told Mr. Brantley that he wanted to talk so they went into a witness room to confer. Then Ginger really lambasted me. I tried to ignore her, but she kept on. Then I told her to just look out and enjoy the view of the area from that high. When she began again, I turned to her and said, "You know Ginger, I wish I could go back and spend more time with you when you were young. I'd go over the story of Solomon, the one where he held the baby up with the sword and the two women were there."
 
Now, I know that she knows that scripture story, but it seemed to just go over her head and surprisingly she made no comment. She started fussing at me again so then I just got my purse and went down the hall to the next seating area.
 
In about 10 minutes, the men came out of their conference. Mr. Hancock, a Children and Families attorney, whom I had never spoken to before, walked over to me and said, "Mrs. Martin?"  I said, "No sir, I'm her mother, Ms. Bryan."
 
He introduced himself and sat down. The first thing he said was, "Now I've reviewed this file, and I have seen enough here and I think we ALL know where these two kids should be."
 
I'm thinking, now I surely hope he's means with me, but all he's really said is just so much double-talk and he probably had or will use those same lines on Ginger when he talks to her about me. Thus, the Department is safe, with NO commitment to anyone--whose who are really helping the children or those who are hurting them.
 
I said, "Sir, just what do you mean by that? Would you clarify that for me?" He drew back surprised and got flustered. 
 
Seeing he didn't know where I was coming from I said, "If you are saying that you can see from the records that my daughter is really sick mentally and these kids have been damaged during these years they were sent back with her and that they don't need to be with her now--I totally agree!"
 
He went on to share that although he had NOT gotten the children's evaluations back from the testors yet, the preliminary information shows that BOTH OF THE TWO KIDS ARE REALLY MESSED UP!" 
 
I answered saying, "Yes Sir, I'm totally aware of that! I was their Foster mother for years, and BECAUSE OF THAT I can help rebuild these kids BETTER than anyone else--IF you'll work with me! I have eleven years of dealing with the Department because of my daughter's ill treatment of my grandchildren. I have much time invested in them, a big mortgage and lots of love as well as many heart aches!"
 
After that, everything went South--in a hurry! Mr. Hancock fished out a 1997 document from his file that I, myself, had just provided to Mr. Brantley when we copied most of my reams of documents a couple of weeks ago to REPLACE ALL THE FILES THAT THEY DESTROYED AS THE KIDS WERE SENT BACK TO GINGER.
 
Mr. Brantley walked over then and said, "Ms. Bryan's own notes are in the margin of that sheet in her handwriting."
 
Then Mr. Hancock said, "As you can see from this document, the judge in 1997 wrote here that you were alienating the children from their mother."
 
I answered, "Sir, the judge only had the information gathered by your department's caseworker, who was later found to have benefited from getting the kids send back to mom by getting a brand-new Ford van..."
 
Before I could finished he got very angry, raised his voice and said, "I don't care about all of that! We are NOT going to go back and re-litigate what was done then!! ALL I'M INTERESTED IN IS TWO VERY MESSED UP TEENAGERS!" 
 
"But Sir," I said, "I KNOW what I'm talking about Governor Jeb Bush had an internal investigator look into this and.." 
 
Before I could finish my statement, Mr. Hancock interupted me while he was striking Ginger's C & F file hard with his hand, "JEB BUSH!  I DON'T CARE ABOUT JEB BUSH!  WHERE IS HE??  HE HAS NOTHING TO DO WITH THIS!! We're got two messed-up teenagers to deal with here!"
 
I interrupted him saying, "Yes, Sir...and that's exactly WHY I'm here--and going through all of this again! But, Sir, (I couldn't remember his name), since Mr. Brantley has told me repeatedly that all the documented abuse to the kids that we have on Ginger in the 1997 paperwork can't be USED AGAINST her NOW, HOW CAN YOU POSSIBILY USE A 1997 PAPER AGAINST ME, SO I CAN'T HAVE THE CHILDREN'S PLACEMENT IN MY HOME AFTER HAVING THEM FOR SIX YEARS??"   
 
Mr. Hancock really lost it then with me then saying, "We are just NOT going to deal with that old stuff!"
 
I said, "Then Sir, in the name of FAIRNESS, again, HOW can you use what a bad worker wrote then a judge put in a report about me, but NOT use all the evidence on my daughter abusing the children?"

He angrily got up and said, "I DON'T CARE ABOUT FAIRNESS, LADY!!  I KNOW what's in this file and IF you don't like this Department's views" then he began walking away..."GET YOU AN ATTORNEY AND GO TO COURT!"
 
I said loud enough for him to hear me as he walked away, "Sir, you said how messed up these two kids are, well, THEY WERE NOT LIKE THEY ARE NOW--when your Department sent them back to their mom. They were doing well in school and functioning in the community--in 4-H and all Church functions--not dysfunctioned like they are now... 
 
THAT'S WHY THIS DEPARTMENT OWES THESE CHILDREN THE BEST HELP THERE IS TO HELP THEM COME OUT OF SOME OF THIS DAMAGE--IF THEY CAN!!" 
 
By the time I finished by statements, he was back over where Ginger was and totally ignoring me...
 
After the emotional hurt Ginger had put me through and now this, I couldn't help it--I began to quietly cry. I tried to quit--knowing we would go into the courtroom soon so I went into the ladies' room to pull myself together. I couldn't understand how that conversation had gotten so bad--C & F and I MUST work together IF these kids ever have a chance for a life!!!
 
When I came out of the restroom, I was surprised to the see young man only identified as an "Observer" just outside the door waiting politely on me, to show me which way they had gone to the courtroom.
 
I took a back seat and saw that Ginger, Mr. Brantley and Mr. Hancock were already standing before the Judge. Judge Strickland looked up at me, made eye contact and then went on about their business. I was relieved that HE ALLOWED ME TO STAY AND LISTEN EVEN IF I COULDN'T HAVE A VIABLE SAY--at least I didn't get charged with CONTEMPT OF COURT like I've heard some do when the "parent" doesn't want them to stay!
 
The judge asked where Amanda was in placement and the answer was in a private home--a Foster home. Dear God, I think she'll run again--soon!!
 
There was quite a bit of discussion on Amanda's "Lewd Sex Acts" charge. Judge Strickland made it clear to Mr. Hancock and Mr. Brantley that under 16 years of age there is no "consent" by either party--boy or girl, and he was adamant that both Amanda and the young boy were to be charged and it was to be followed up on. It was brought out that Amanda's next court date is on the 17th, they didn't say for what.
 
When the session was over, I asked Mr. Hancock if he would please come back and talk to me.  He answered, "Why certainly."
 
I said (still not remembering his name), "Sir, you upset me earlier as we talked because my only purpose here is to HELP my grandkids!"
 
He then went into his routine again about how well versed he was on this file, (which was, by the way, only about an inch thick) mentally, I compared it to my plastic storage tub of the many 5-inch notebook chronicling years of hearings--court orders--abuse reports--etc. and thought, Mister, you don't know ANYTHING about this case!
 
I said to him, "You know, I really am a nice lady, and I would like to apologize about what happened between us before court. I just want you to know that you can't possibly know all that Ginger's put me and her children through the last nineteen years, (That being the age of Melisa, her oldest.) and I'm upset because IF WE CAN JUST TALK AND WORK TOGETHER, we can MAYBE HELP my grandchildren to RECOVER SOME from all they have been put through."
 
He was angry and started toward the courtroom doors. I hurriedly said, "Sir, Sir, I want to ask you WHEN may I have a VISIT with my grandchildren??"
 
As he shoved open the door he turned his head and looked at me hard and said very loudly as he went out into the hall, "Lady, YOU GET YOU AN ATTORNEY and get them to REQUEST A HEARING WITH A JUDGE FOR VISITATION!!
 
I thought, "Oh, dear God!! These people (the Department) are going to keep me AWAY from the kids just as Ginger as done these last five years!! That's way the kids have lost all of the ethics, manners, and character I was trying to build into them.  
 
By then Judge Strickland was gone and no one was left but the "Observer", and the lady Clerk of the Court and Mr. Brantley, who were talking.
 
I tried to get hold of my emotions as I waited for Mr. Brantley because he has been so respectful to me (even when things would get heated) I knew I could talk to him. 
 
He saw me crying and stopped walking towards the door.
 
 I said, "Charles WHAT did I do to set that man off--OR is he ALWAYS A JERK??"
 
Charles didn't answer, then as I was crying I told him, "That man just told me I HAVE TO GET AN ATTORNEY TO GET TO HAVE VISITATION--IS THAT TRUE?"
 
Mr. Brantley stopped still and really frowned and said, "Well, I think we'll have to negotiate that one with him." 
 
As I cried, both Mr. Brantley and the other gentleman saw me into the elevator and out of the courthouse.
They stopped to talk, as I walked on to my car and then it hit me why I was crying so easily...
I'd been up all night writing to Jeb, I hadn't had but an hour and one-half of sleep 
So then as I stopped crying as I came back to Lakeland,
 I began thinking:
 
Just WHAT have I accomplished today?
 
Somehow, without meaning to I messed up my relationship with the Department.
 
They STILL use all the paper documents as THEY SEE FIT.
 
   i.e. Using old, erroneous information about me "alienating the kids against Ginger"
 
        (written by a worker that got a payoff to send the kids back) against me,
 
         while C & F chooses to NOT USE ANY OF THE OLD EVIDENCE AGAINST GINGER!
 
Now, they are demanding that I MUST GET AN ATTORNEY 
 
TO BE ABLE TO VISIT MY OWN GRANDCHILDREN 
 
WHOM THEY HAVE PHYSICALLY PLACED IN MY HOME--THREE TIMES NOW, 
 
AND THEY GAVE ME "OUTSTANDING FOSTER HOME" AWARDS SIX YEARS IN A ROW...
 
Now, I'm the enemy...when in any other case AFTER TWO REMOVALS the children are PROTECTED 
 
by TERMINATING PARENTAL RIGHTS!!
 
Dear Lord, is there ANY SENSE IN ALL THIS??
 
And my final thought: I MISSED a day's work--with NO pay
 
      because I used all my sick days staying here with Jonathan
 
      for over a week last October, while he was BETWEEN DRUG REHABS...
 
Yes, Mr. Hancock, you TRULY don't know ANYTHING about this case!!
 
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 
One more time, GOVERNOR JEB, or GOVERNOR'S OMBUDSMAN, 
 
THANKS FOR READING THIS!
 
Gratefully yours, 
 
Ellen -- a/k/a Your "Florida Sunshine 'GIRL' "

-----Original Message-----
From: SLUPP40@aol.com [mailto:SLUPP40@aol.com]
Sent: Tuesday, May 07, 2002 6:43 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Hey from Ocean Springs, Ms


  Good luck with the selecting of our new county leaders. I reviewed the list of possible appointees. There is some good people on the list. There is also a few that would be bad news for Escambia County and Florida. I won't mention any names, but, I would stay clear of former county commissioners. ( they are former for a reason)
  Escambia County is very diverse from farm lands in the North end to our white sandy beaches and Navel Air Station on the South end. 

Good Luck to you and Escambia County

Steve Luppert

-----Original Message-----
From: Conchita Sarnoff [mailto:csarnoff@mindspring.com]
Sent: Monday, May 06, 2002 10:53 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: American Red Cross celebrating 10th Anniversary of Hurricane Andrew and 85th Anniversary of Red Cross
Importance: High


Dear Governor Bush,
 
I am honored to invite you to be our keynote speaker at the American Red Cross 85th Anniversary event celebrating both 85 years in existence and the 10th anniversary of Hurricane Andrew.
 
The event will be held on Friday, August 23, 2002 at 10:00 a.m. at the Homestead Speed Way in Homestead, Florida. 
 
'MASH' will be the backdrop theme for the event featuring invited and distinguished members of our local and state government, the military, celebrities including former 'MASH' celebrities, media and key corporate citizens who during those terrifying days in 1992 gave so much of their time and energy.  
 
Several current City and County administration officials will also attend since they play such a vital role in protecting our safety in times of national emergencies and duress.    
 
We look forward to having you as our guest of honor and keynote speaker at this important event. If you have any further questions please don't hesitate to contact me either via email at: csarnoff@mindspring.com or office phone:305.361.8936. 
 
In addition, if you would like to contact an American Red Cross employee who is active in this event committee please refer to Miss Annette Melara, director of communications at the American Red Cross in Miami email address: melaraA@usa.redcross.org <mailto:the melaraA@usa.redcross.org> . 
 
Thank you for your continued leadership, interest and support. 
 
Sincerely yours,
 
Conchita S. Sarnoff
Chair of Volunteer Communications Committee American Red Cross, Miami Chapter.

Buen dia Jeb!!

I understand that you will be meeting about the DD Redesign
recommendation today.  I know that you haven't asked, but I still
intended to write to you before the meeting about my thoughts and
impressions. Unfortunately, I haven't had the opportunity to do that.

issues.  I will like to send a few comments about the redesign.

First, as I mentioned to you before, I feel that the system is currently
in good hands. I feel comfortable with most of the recommendations made. 
Susan is knowledgeable about the issues.  She may lacks on the political
aspect that Carl had, but I think that with you as an involved leader we
can overcome that aspect.  She, and nobody else will ever be able to
satisfy everyone all the time.  Shelly, is very young, but is very smart
and sensitive. She is an extremely fast learner.  I do not know Larry
Pintacuda very much, but he has impressed me as a caring, and honest
person that wants to learn about our issues.

I have been a little disappointed with the fact that they are not
consistent with making sure that meeting ground rules are kept. This has
cause some hard feelings among some of the members. On our last meeting
again, they didn't go over the ground rules at the beginning of the
meeting. People from the public were getting involved in issues that had
been previously discussed and agreed by the redesign committee.  I
quietly mentioned it, but nothing was done.
 
As I think about your most recent issue with the 4 year old girl from
Miami, it scares me that we may encounter such situation with our
population as well.  This was not addressed during the redesign, but for
years I have brought up the issue of the Waiver Support Coordinators
(case managers) case notes.  Why can't the state mandate for every case
worker to have a visiting log were someone at the home/facility signs it?
 Instead, WSC and other case workers spend long hours writing case notes,
and as in the little girls case, they may had not even visited the home.
Therapist, home health aides, and others have a signing log, why can't
that substitute for most case notes?

I have to be at a meeting at 7:00 a.m. and must now get ready.  I wish I
had more time.

Carinos,

Berthy

-----Original Message-----
From: Hial1211@aol.com [mailto:Hial1211@aol.com]
Sent: Tuesday, May 07, 2002 7:27 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Miami Visit FYI


Good morning...I heard you were going to be at Homestead High on Thursday...unfortunately I will be out of town...but I wanted you to be aware that Homestead High is one of the schools participating in our Youth Crime Watch program, Battle of the Belts (a statewide initiative funded by the Safety Office FDOT) This school sadly lost 2 students in a crash recently, the report indicated that "had they been wearing their seat belt", they would have survived. My YCW coordinator, Philene Hart will be at the school that day, over seeing the events of the day along with the Homestead Police Dept. Therefore, I am giving you some statistics in case you are asked or if you want to comment.. ...Carmen
INFORMATION:
Traffic crashes are the number one killer of young people. Yet studies show that taking four seconds to buckle a safety belt reduces both the fatality rate and the serious injury rate by 50 to 75 percent in motor vehicle crashes.
It is recognized that a 10% increase in safety belt use throughout Florida will save approximately 200 lives per year, reduce horrific traffic injuries by over 6,000 and save Floridians approximately $385,000,000 in related cost.
Why High School Students? 
According to the National Highway Traffic Safety Association, about 54% of young people who die in vehicle crashes are not wearing seat belts.
Motor vehicle crashes were the leading cause of death for 15 to 20 year olds in the year 2000. Accounting for roughly 1/3 of all fatalities in this age group.
In the year 2000 - 3,594 drivers 15 to 20 years of age were killed in crashes, an additional 348,000 were injured.
The fatality rate for teenage drivers, based on estimated annual rates, is about 4 times as high as the rate for drivers 25 through 69 years old.
Youths age 16 to 20 have the highest traffic-related fatality rate of any age group.
Traffic accidents are the leading cause of disability and spinal cord injuries among youth.
A 16-year-old drive is 20 times more likely to have a traffic accident as the general population.
The leading cause of death among young Hispanics is failure in wearing a seat belt. It's the second leading cause of death for Afro-Americans.
The above statistics come from National Highway Traffic Safety Association & Teen Driver Safety Series
The school that achieves the highest overall increase in safety belt usage rate in the state will be presented a $500.00 cash award.

From: Shiver, Steve (CMO) 
Sent: Monday, May 06, 2002 7:35 AM
Subject: Good morning



I hope your weekend was a good one....
 
As you may have heard, Governor Bush announced the appointment of Jose "Pepe" Cancio to the Miami-Dade County Board of County Commissioners for District 12.  We will meet with him today and he will be sworn in officially on Tuesday.  On be-half of our Miami-Dade County team, I want to welcome him and please join me in that greeting should you see him in the office.
 
To update you on our budget process, we are still meeting diligently to try to meet the departmental savings plans that were put in to place as a result of the unforeseen expenses and revenue losses after September 11th.  While we are facing a very difficult time, I am confident we will be able to make it through this year.  However, our next fiscal year is a significant challenge.  As we go through the departmental meetings, we are looking a various ways of saving monies and I want to thank those of you who have sent me suggestions.  We are looking at all options at this point with an emphasis on not cutting service or programs that are currently in place.  Unfortunately, some of this may be unavoidable.  We are taking a look at some administrative efficiencies that may prove to save money as well as help many of you that are in this area and over burdened.  
 
I don't want to be an alarmist but I do think it is important that we are all kept as informed as possible.  Please feel free to email me if you have any questions or thoughts on how we can improve our service and achieve cost savings...
 
Have a great week.....
 
Steve Shiver
County Manager
"we're more than employees, we're neighbors"

	* First Annual MDWA Training Seminar -The Miami-Dade Women's Association will be celebrating its First Annual Women's Enrichment Seminar on Wednesday and Thursday, May 15 and 16, 2002, at the Fire Board Chambers, 9300 NW 41st Street, Miami, Florida. The goal of the seminar is to provide a learning environment for employees to develop and enhance their skills and career development in various areas. The MDWA's Women's Enrichment Seminar is an educational opportunity for our employees in the areas of public service, leadership, interview techniques, professional succession planning, charisma and emotional intelligence. Therefore, attendance of those whose schedules allow it can be considered beneficial to the County service. The registration deadline is Monday, May 13, 2002. (Please refer to the attached flyer for additional information.) Of course, you are required to maintain an appropriate level of staffing in your offices, so you are directed to use your professional judgment in granting appropriate leave. If you have any questions regarding the granting of leave, please contact the Employee Relations Department for clarification.  <http://www.co.miami-dade.fl.us/info/community/women.htm> http://www.co.miami-dade.fl.us/info/community/women.htm

	* May is Community Action Month, and Miami-Dade Community Action Agency (MDCAA) will celebrate 37 years of serving low-income individuals and families in our community by assisting them to become economically independent and self-sufficient. MDCAA is a proud member of the Community Action Partnership, which represents over 1,000 Community Action Agencies across the country who will also be celebrating their accomplishments and achievements. Community Action was born out of the Anti-Poverty Act signed by President Lyndon B. Johnson in 1964, today the spirit of Community Action lives on in the 1200 employees of MDCAA and the thousands of people who's lives have been changed by CAA. "Community Action changes peoples lives, embodies the spirit of hope, improves communities, and makes America a better place to live. We care about the entire community, and we are dedicated to helping people help themselves and each other"., this is the promise of Community Action W. David Allison-McPherson Department Information Officer Miami-Dade Community Action Agency (305) 347-4682

	* The Sheila Winitzer Central Administration Building Dedication May 10, 2002 at 10 a.m. On January 29, 2002, the Miami-Dade Board of County Commissioners passed a resolution naming the Miami-Dade Transit Central Administration Building for the late Sheila Winitzer. On May 10th at 10 a.m., we formally dedicate the facility as the Sheila Winitzer Central Administration Building. Ceremonies begin in the auditorium, then move to the patio and the lobby. A plaque commemorating Sheila's wonderful work during a life of serving the less fortunate will be mounted on the exterior of the building facing the patio. Pictures and mementos will grace the lobby. As a teacher of the developmentally disabled and as creator of programs to give mobility to the transportation disadvantaged, Sheila cared, listened, and always made things happen. She brought joy to the lives of everyone she touched. Many across the state and nation benefited from her life's work. Please join us on May 10th at 3300 N.W. 32nd Avenue as we pay tribute to our dear friend and colleague.

>-----Original Message----- 
>From: stoptripping@hotmail.com [mailto:stoptripping@hotmail.com] 
>Sent: Monday, May 06, 2002 1:05 PM 
>To: Jeb Bush 
>Subject: 'All I want is to graduate' 
> 
> 
>From: Julia Nichols 
> 
>Dear Governor- 
> 
>I know you're busy, but please read this article which appeared in the 
>Orlando Sentinel on Saturday, May 4, 2002. Is there anything that can be 
>done, perhaps by the Dept. of Education? 
> 
>Sincerely, 
> 
>Julia Nichols 
> 
>-------------------- 
>'All I want is to graduate' 
>-------------------- 
> 
>By April Hunt 
>Sentinel Staff Writer 
> 
>May 4, 2002 
> 
>ST. CLOUD -- Since August, Joey Meyer has awakened with the vision of 
>walking triumphantly across the stage this spring and grasping his 
>high-school diploma. 
> 
>His parents had struggled to motivate their 17-year-old son with Down 
>syndrome to enjoy school. So they prodded him to do his schoolwork by 
>reinforcing how proud he would feel balancing a mortarboard on his head 
>and donning the maroon-and-golden gown along with the rest of the St. 
>Cloud High School Class of 2002. 
> 
>Joey kept up his end of the bargain, but school district officials say 
>there has been an unfortunate mistake -- he doesn't have the credits to 
>graduate. They say his parents misunderstood the requirements, and the 
>school regrets it didn't catch the mix-up sooner. 
> 
>The bottom line: Joey won't be marching to "Pomp and Circumstance" on 
>May 20 at Disney's Wide World of Sports. 
> 
>Now, disappointed and bewildered, Joey has been sitting in a lawn chair 
>under a beach umbrella on his front lawn across from East Lake 
>Tohopekaliga and protesting the turn of events. A homemade sign pleads 
>"Let Joe Graduate" and urges passing motorists to "Honk for Joey." When 
>they do, he waves and smiles, but the smile is a dimmer version of the 
>one in the photo of him in graduation garb. 
> 
>"All I want is to graduate. It has been hard," said Joey, who sips iced 
>tea to ward off the heat and takes breaks to play with his skateboard. 
> 
>Many cars that stream past his Lakeshore Boulevard home blare their 
>horns. Others stop in front of the historic 1914 home to get the full 
>story. When he is feeling hopeful, Joey yells to supporters, "Vote for 
>me." 
> 
>His parents Bob and Sharon Meyer have assured him he is not being 
>punished for something he did wrong. Still, Joey doesn't understand what 
>has happened. 
> 
>His parents paid the $40-plus to rent the cap and gown. His photo in 
>graduation attire will appear in the Bulldogs' school yearbook, and his 
>name is included on the T-shirts listing the senior class. 
> 
>"In his eyes, we lied to him," said Bob Meyer, who made the sign when 
>Joey originally wanted to picket at the school. "He is so hurt by this 
>whole thing." 
> 
>Osceola County School Superintendent Blaine Muse said he is sympathetic 
>and admitted that school officials are partly to blame. Last fall, the 
>district sent home a standard letter to Joey's parents, reminding them 
>that special-education students who attended school for four years, 
>earned the required credits and were at least 18 could participate in 
>graduation in the spring. 
> 
>Bob Meyer sent the form back, saying Joey, who turns 18 on May 14, would 
>graduate this year. School officials, however, didn't realize until two 
>weeks ago that Joey didn't qualify because he is four credits shy of the 
>22 required credits and has only been at the school for three years. 
> 
>Muse said because of that, the school and Joey's parents share the 
>blame. But, he added, it isn't enough to persuade him to alter school 
>policy for just one student. 
> 
>"The other students are walking because they met the requirements. He 
>did not," Muse said. 
> 
>The Meyers argue that an official could change their son's individual 
>education program so he could participate in the ceremony. After all, 
>they said, Joey doesn't need the diploma. He isn't going on to college 
>or applying for any jobs where he will need those credits, they said. 
> 
>That is why they support their son when he says he won't go back to St. 
>Cloud High next year. It will be hard enough to get Joey, who has been 
>out sick twice this week with a virus, to finish this year, his parents 
>said. 
> 
>That response doesn't surprise Sylvia Smith, an official with the 
>Advocacy Center for Persons with Disabilities in Tallahassee. Smith, who 
>is reviewing a complaint from the Meyers against the school district, 
>said it is critical for teens with disabilities to be able to plan for 
>their future. 
> 
>All teenagers are still defining how they will fit into the world at 
>large. But for a student like Joey, that work requires a lot more 
>planning by parents and the school, to make sure they realize they will 
>have a place by earning it. 
> 
>"It is such a critical time," Smith said. "It sounds like a cruel 
>practical joke." 
> 
>Joey has been so sick and upset that his mom and dad fret he may not 
>feel better for tonight's prom at the Wyndham Palace Hotel, even though 
>some of the girls in his class have promised to save dances for him. 
> 
>And his parents worry that Joey will refuse to attend graduation to see 
>his sister Tiffany, who has cerebral palsy and has been in the 
>special-education program as well, get her diploma. 
> 
>"They're taking from him something that is so important," said Bob 
>Meyer, who then asked his son what he thinks. 
> 
>"I want to graduate," Joey answered with a shrug. "I just want to 
>graduate." 
> 
>April Hunt can be reached at 407-931-5940 or ahunt@orlandosentinel.com. 
> 
> 
>

> 
>Visit OrlandoSentinel.com

From:	Sherri <sherribrun@mpinet.net>
Sent:	Tuesday, May 7, 2002 8:39 AM

Subject:	Please support line item for budget item 2102

Dear Committee Members,

I urge you to please support the House Offer presented on 5/6/02 for Budget
Line Item 2102 to increase the Transportation Disadvantaged Trust Fund.  It
has not been increased in 8 years and we need trips to the doctor, work and
other activities of daily living in our community.

I have a small child, four years old.  I am totally blind.  I also have four
other teenaged kids and sometimes I need to go places with them.  I need to
take my four-year-old to the doctor, preschool, etc.  In some cases, I
cannot use the ADA transportation, so I must use ADA.  I am also active in
my community, Orlando, where we have many people who cannot drive
themselves.  Please consider these people when making your decision.

Most Sincerely,

Sherri Brun,
Acting President,
National Federation of the Blind Greater Orlando Chapter
407-898-6024

Commissioner,

The Offense Date on this case is 11/3/01 and per the information from
Representative Farentino the incident was not reported until the first week
in December (1 month later). The evidence was not submitted to the Tampa Lab
until 1/10/02.  The items submitted were a t-shirt from the child and paper
towels from a trash can in the house.  A standard from the subject was
submitted but no samples from the child's body were received.  

On 2/8/02 the Detective called and asked for a priority on the case.  The
case was examined the detective notified on 3/22.  No semen identified on
the T-shirt and a very limited amount of semen with very few sperm was
identified on the paper towels.  DNA testing is being done and should be
completed by the end of the week.  Based on the semen found it is very
possible that all that will be identified is the subject's profile and since
he was living in the house at the time, this will have no probative value. 

Please let me know if you need anything further.  Judy had passed on the
message from Representative Farentino's Office to me.  Do you want me to
contact them and let them know that it will be completed soon?  (The case
age is now 116 days, just over our standard)

Sue

From:	Flack, Christopher <Christopher.Flack@LASPBS.STATE.FL.US>
Sent:	Tuesday, May 7, 2002 9:31 AM
To:	Shanahan, Kathleen; DiBenigno, Arlene
Cc:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	RE: City of West Miami Wastewater Collection System Appropriation

This project did not meet the criteria established for wastewater projects this year and was vetoed last year.  Last year's criteria required that a project be approved through the water advisory panel, be funded the previous year, be under construction and serve an area that has a medium household income below the state average.  This years policy required that the projects be funded each of the last two years.  We have not told anyone what position the Governor might take on any of these projects, but have made it clear to the legislature which projects do and do not meet the criteria established.
 
The reason we have put these criteria in place regarding funding is because in the last three years the state has contributed $335 million towards the completion of these projects, and to complete the projects we have already started would cost close to $1b, so the policy was to complete those projects begun before starting new.  It is my understanding from the house that this project will be on the "final list" at $750,000.
-----Original Message-----
From: Shanahan, Kathleen [mailto:Kathleen.Shanahan@MyFlorida.com]

Subject: FW: City of West Miami Wastewater Collection System Appropriation

From:	Dana, Pam <pam.dana@myflorida.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, May 7, 2002 11:27 AM
To:	'fiba@fiba.net'
Cc:	Tony Villamil (E-mail); fiba; Shanahan, Kathleen; Oviedo, Nina; Muniz, Katie
Subject:	RE: INS proposal to limit tourist and prof visas
Attachments:	INS.doc

Thanks Pat for your email. The Governor has been actively engaged on this
issue as he clearly understands the importance of international visitors to
Florida.  As such, the Governor sent a letter of concern in late April to
INS Commissioner Ziglar which I am attaching below. I would appreciate it if
you could spread the word to your membership on the Governor's leadership in
this regard.

You should be aware that other states and their respective leadership have
been slow to respond to this issue.  It may behoove FIBA to reach out to
sister organizations to garner support with their elected leaders.

Pam

Pamella Dana, Director
Office of Tourism, Trade, and Economic Development
Executive Office of the Governor
2001 The Capitol
Tallahassee, FL  32399-0001

-----Original Message-----
From: fiba [mailto:fiba@fiba.net]
Sent: Tuesday, May 07, 2002 10:47 AM
To: pam.dana@myflorida.com
Cc: Tony Villamil (E-mail); fiba
Subject: INS proposal to limit tourist and prof visas


Dear Pam,

Following up on my conversation with Tony Villamil, FIBA  has become
concerned about the INS proposal which would provide a "default" business or
tourist visa of 30 days.  In reading the Federal Register, it appears that
the INS has flexibility, but it is uncertain how or if it will be exercised.

FIBA brought this to the attention of Senator Nelson, who has already
written a comment letter to the INS.  The comment period was only 30 days
and ends shortly, I believe on May 12th.

FYI, today I was speaking with a private banker from First Union in Miami.
She has a  customer from Latin America who has been coming to the U.S. for
the past 50 years. He owns a condominum in the Santa Maria, which is one of
the luxury condos on Brickell Avenue in Miami.  His experience makes it
appear that the INS is already enforcing the 30 day default rule because he
was given a 30 day visa. His question to the private banker was "Why do I
want to own a condo in Florida if I can only stay 30 days?".

I have also been told that one of the large domestic banks in Florida which
is active in real estate construction is  very concerned about the impact of
this regualtion on their business.  The 30-day visas could also impact the
ability of businessmen who want to open new banks or businesses in Florida,
because they would not be able to stay long enough to get their business
completed.

It goes without saying that there could also be a negative for Florida's
tourism.

FYI, I have attached the letter from Senator Nelson, as well as a comment
letter from Nino Lucio's firm (Nino is General Counsel of FIBA).

Although this is not directly a banking issue, the impact will be felt
across the Florida economy and will affect banks as well as other
industries.

Please let me know if there is anything FIBA can do to assist you,


Thank you,





Pat Roth
Exec Director
Florida International Bankers Assoc
80 SW 8 Street, Suite 2505
Miami, FL 33130
Tel: 305- 579 0086    Fax: 305 579 0969
email:  fiba@fiba.net         www.fiba.net

-----Original Message-----
From: Ross, Lucia T. [mailto:Lucia.T.Ross@dep.state.fl.us]
Sent: Tuesday, May 07, 2002 11:46 AM
To: baurk@eog.state.fl.us; mark.busse@myflorida.com;
hirste@eog.state.fl.us; jiminef@eog.state.fl.us;
mandy.thomas@myflorida.com
Subject: DEP, Cargill agree on long-term Mulberry solution


FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE				               CONTACT:
Lucia
Ross
May 7, 2002
(850) 488-1073

DEP, CARGILL AGREE TO LONG-TERM SOLUTION TO MULBERRY PHOSPHATE'S
ENVIRONMENTAL PROBLEMS

TALLAHASSEE - Department of Environmental Protection Deputy Secretary Allan
Bedwell today announced that DEP and Cargill Fertilizer, Inc. have reached
an
agreement that will further protect the Tampa Bay region's waterways and the
residents of the area surrounding the abandoned phosphate plant formerly
operated by the bankrupt Mulberry Corporation.  The end result of this
cooperative effort will be the permanent closing of the environmentally
dangerous phosphogypsum stack.

For the past several months, DEP has taken financial responsibility and
worked diligently to stabilize the Mulberry site and reduce the level of
acidic process water in the phosphogypsum stacks to the point where they
could withstand heavy rains. At least one spill has been averted by these
actions.  

 Pending approval of the federal bankruptcy court, Cargill will acquire the
existing plant facilities and the remainder of the site - the phosphogypsum
stack system - will remain under the control of a court appointed receiver
charged with ensuring the environmental security of the site. The DEP will
contract with Cargill to immediately initiate the closure of the
phosphogypsum stack system, the same system from which a catastrophic spill
(and subsequent massive fishkill) overflowed into the Alafia River in 1997. 

"What we have been able to accomplish up to this point has been
significant,"
said Bedwell, "but we can now, once and for all, ensure the environmental
security of this site. Last year we applied the band-aid, but now we must
perform the corrective surgery. We are pleased to work with Cargill to take
immediate action to provide long-term protection for the environment."

Since February 2001, the DEP has spent approximately $13 million to maintain
the environmental integrity of the site.  Without this new agreement, it is
estimated that Florida taxpayers would have to pay in excess of $50 million
to close the Mulberry facility. Now, thanks to DEP's successful negotiation
and pending court approval, the taxpayers will save between $20 to $25
million.

Cargill will immediately initiate the closure activities, which will take
approximately five years to complete, by mid-May. In order to protect the
environment, Cargill will use its industry-specific engineering and
operating
experience to secure the gypsum storage area and the system's water. Cargill
is expected to consume most of the 2 billion gallons of acidic process
wastewater from the site at its Bartow plant, which is adjacent to the
Mulberry Phosphate Corporation's property.


-30-

The Legislature is in special session and the Adult Handicapped Fund is 
once again under siege.  This time it doesn't appear to be the 
legislature's fault, but rather, is at the request of the new VR 
Director, who is also in charge of this program.  TIME IS OF THE UTMOST 
IMPORTANT.  Please send the following message to the following people. 


THE MESSAGE: 


We have learned that Department of Education staff has asked that funds 
be taken from the Adult Handicapped Fund in order to address deficits in 
the VR and Blind Services Programs.   It is extremely unfair to adults 
with disabilities that one of the programs benefiting them should be 
compromised in order to benefit another.  The individuals who receive 
the benefits of the Adult Basic Education provided through the Adult 
Handicapped Fund are those who will likely never be able to be 
competitively employed, and therefore, not able to benefit from VR 
services.  In Miami-Dade, approximately 2,863 adults with disabilities 
are registered at 25+ agencies.  Each receives an average of 25-30 hours 
of educational services weekly.  While we recognize that there are many 
competing funding priorities, we urge you NOT to reduce funding for the 
DOE's Adult Handicapped Program. 


E-MAIL THE MESSAGE TO:

From: Mark  <mailto:markleycdf@terragon.com> & Marilyn Johnson 
To: Carol <mailto:hubcap@terragon.com>  ; Corky <mailto:corky1701@aol.com>  
Sent: Tuesday, May 07, 2002 4:54 PM
Subject: Can't speak english any longer!!

Tuesday, May 7, 2002 

Government Worker in U.S. Fired for Speaking English 


An employee of Miami-Dade County, harassed by Latino co-workers for being a white American, says she was fired for speaking English on the job. 


"I was referred to as the gringa, the Americana," Zita Wilensky told Miami's WSVN-TV. "Did they mean it in a polite way or a derogatory way? In some ways, at times, it was joking. But then it was like every single day, and you know what? I have a name." 


She was the only "Anglo" in the Domestic Violence Unit. All of her co-workers were Hispanic, and she says they liked to play tricks on her. 


"My boss presented me with an envelope one day when the anthrax was going around and told me: 'Come here; could you smell this? This just came in the mail.' Big joke in front of the whole department. Made me look like an idiot." 


A 16-year county employee, she has a personnel file full of letters of praise, but the racial discrimination began to take its toll. 


"Then Zita was told she had to speak Spanish in the office. She was given 60 days to learn. After 30 days her boss disguised her voice and called her," WSVN reported. 


Wilensky told the station: "So she called pretending to be someone who didn't speak English." 


"And when you could not communicate she fired you?" 


"Yes ... that's how it happened." 


According to the county, she was fired (merely) for transferring the call to the clerk's office. Wilensky says she transferred it because she wanted what she thought was a Spanish-speaking caller to talk to someone. Her boss claims she just requested that Wilensky learn Spanish, but a letter from the boss says Wilensky must speak Spanish, the TV station reported. 


The result: After her long service with the county, she was fired and replaced by a Hispanic. 


Now she is looking into whether an American can be fired for not speaking Spanish on the job. 


WSVN says that according to its legal expert, Howard Finkelstein: "The Florida Constitution says that English is the official language of the government. So you can't fire someone simply because they don't speak Spanish, and you can't fire them simply because they are Anglo. That's discrimination. That's illegal." 


Finkelstein added: "An employer cannot allow an employee to be subjected to racial slurs like 'gringo' or to be ridiculed or intimidated. ... That's called a hostile work environment, and that's illegal." 


If Wilensky sues the county, she has an excellent chance of winning, he said. 


The banana republic of Miami-Dade County, by the way, is the same government that failed to  <http://www.newsmax.com/showinside.shtml?a=2001/10/26/165850> fire three black firemen who refused to respond to emergency calls until an "offensive" American flag was removed from a fire truck.

From:	Jeb Bush
Sent:	Tuesday, May 7, 2002 8:10 PM
To:	Shirley Brown
Subject:	RE: SRBBA fup

-----Original Message-----
From: Judge Gregory P. Holder [mailto:holdergp@jud13.flcourts.org]
Sent: Tuesday, May 07, 2002 6:12 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Best wishes Governor


I gave an interview today with the ABC affiliate, pointing out that
government was never designed to function as either a father or mother
to a child.  Unfortunately, we have been thrust into this role due to
abuse, abandonment, or neglect by the father, mother, or other
relatives.  The system ultimately comes down to its lowest common
denominator; the human being with the responsibility to love and nurture
these children.  We must never lose sight of the fact that the system is
absolutely imperfect and although you, Kate Kearney and so many others
have done so much for Florida's children, we have both an imperfect
society, and an imperfect system.  While these tragedies must be
prevented, we will always have them as long as parents and relative
caregivers fail and refuse to fulfill their moral and legal
responsibilities.

Our thoughts and prayers are with you.  The Holder family loves you
dearly and appreciates your efforts.

greg

affirmation and a wonderful destination!  What more can we ask

May 7, 2002

The Honorable Jeb Bush
Governor, State of Florida
Capital Building

Dear Governor Bush:

I am writing regarding Allen L. Register, County Judge in Washington County.

I understand that Judge Register is being consider for Circuit Judge of the
14th Circuit.  I have known Allen Register my whole life and honestly feel
he is one of the last good men in the world.  We are first cousins (our
fathers were brothers) and through the years have kept in contact with each
other.  He has the qualities that more people should try to obtain.

As a father, he stands by and with his children.  He is very supportive in
their activities, social and academic.  His relationship with his children
and wife is one of mutual respect, open communication and a very comfortable
and safe atmosphere.  Which tends to put everyone around him in the same
frame. 

Through the years he has been the solid ground for his family, for his
parents and siblings.  During all the personal and professional events, good
and not so good, in his life I think that his strong Christian beliefs has
carried him, along with his light-hearted sense of humor, through those
times.

I believe that Judge Register would carried these same qualities into this
new position.

Sincerely,

Deborah L. (Register) Johnson

-----Original Message-----
From: Rebecca A Johnson [mailto:RAJ@vpha.health.ufl.edu]
Sent: Tuesday, May 07, 2002 2:49 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: fsga@fsiga.org
Subject: HB 319


e-mail
May 7, 2002
Governor Jeb Bush


RE:	HB 319

Governor Bush – I would urge you to sign HB 319 which 
essentially privatizes the work having been done for over a 
decade by the Florida Self-Insurance Guarantee Association in 
conjunction with the Department of Labor. 

This is a superb bill which further privatizes the role, scope and 
function of the Florida Self-Insurance Guarantee Association in 
relationship to paying Workers Compensation claims when 
companies in Florida enter bankruptcy.

The Florida Self-Insurance Program Board of Directors has an 
excellent track record in handling its assigned functions. 
Passage of this bill will decrease the number of state employees, 
increase the efficiency, cost less and thus would be a benefit to 
the business organizations of this state.

Thank you very much for considering this recommendation.

G.L. Schiebler, M.D.
Member, Board of Directors
Florida Self-Insurance Guarantee Association

cc:	Robert Williams, President – FSIGA
	Baxter Swing, Executive Vice President – FSIGA

Let's paws to chew on a trust law


Stephen Van Drake  
------------------------------------------------------------
   Things are looking up for cats Sugar and CeeCee Jr. and Marvin the dog.

   The top dog in their household, Gov. Jeb Bush, last week signed a bill
   that would allow Florida pet owners to set up trusts for pets.

   "This bill will allow man and woman's best friends to be taken care of
   if their masters pass on," Bush said.

   "There are a lot of orphaned animals," said Bobbie Ozer of the Animal
   Rescue League of the Palm Beaches in West Palm Beach. She said she
   strongly favors the new law.

   Florida's pet trust law takes effect Jan. 1. The state joins 17 other
   states with similar probate laws permitting pet owners to designate a
   trustee to spend the money in such a trust for the animal's care.

   "Many Floridians treat their furry friends like family," said Barbara
   Buxton of Aventura, who has a law degree in estate planning. "They
   deserve this."

   She said one of her clients, Bobbi Ford of Delray Beach ­ "proud mother
   of two golden retrievers" ­ set aside $10,000 for her dogs.

   "Chelsea and Patches are my babies," Ford said. "These are defenseless
   creatures who are totally dependent on us. I would hate to think that
   they wouldn't be taken care of after we're gone."

   An increasing number of people own pets, from exotic birds and reptiles
   to horses and, of course, cats and dogs. Buxton said she's thrilled that
   Bush signed the pet trust bill on April 23.

   She can now amend her own will to include care for her Shih Tzu, Daisey
   Sue Dumpling.

 Law demands accountability
   The new law recognizes pet trusts and makes trustees accountable to the
   court for money spent taking care of a decedent's animals. If the
   trustee doesn't want to serve or has died, the court can appoint a
   trustee "having an interest in the welfare of the animal."

   A probate judge can also remove a trustee. The new code sets out a
   method of distributing the remainder of the trust once the last of the
   animals dies.

   Before these formalized pet trusts, pet owners set up an "honorary
   trust," said David Westfall, Harvard University Law School probate
   professor. The trustee, however, could spend the money without any
   accountability, Westfall said.

   "I think the trend is with the Florida statute," he said.

   "The new pet trust law is practical and reasonable, a loving way to
   exit," Buxton said.

   Pets are generally known to help lower blood pressure, reduce mental
   depression and provide a host of other benefits to their owners, Buxton
   said. "It's a very responsible way to provide for a pet when they go."

   Some pets, such as cockatoos, which can live 80 years, will outlast
   their owners.

   Pet estate planning might well become a growth industry, Buxton noted.

 Third of homes have cats or dogs
   At least a third of all homes in the United States have a dog or a cat,
   according to a survey conducted last year by the American Pet Products
   Manufacturing Association of Greenwich, Conn.

   The association's survey concluded that more than 63 million U.S.
   households own pets and nearly 47 percent of these own more than one
   type of pet.

   The new Florida code doesn't discriminate. It refers to "animal." So,
   the Wellington polo horse owner could provide for the horse; the reptile
   lover, for a python, and so it goes.

   Pet trusts also open the door for inventive charitable giving.

   For example, Rep. Earl Blumenauer, D-Ore., last year introduced a bill
   currently lingering in the House Ways and Means Committee that would
   provide tax benefits to "charitable remainder pet trusts."

   In short, the remainder of the trust might pour over into a charity,
   such as the Animal Rescue League or other charities.

   The remainder would then be tax-deductible, said Bill Andrews, another
   Harvard law professor. His colleague Westfall agreed.

   "It would make a good development vehicle, say to prospective donors,
   after the pet dies."



Copyright(c) American City Business Journals Inc.  All rights reserved.

You can view this article on the web at:
http://southflorida.bizjournals.com/southflorida/stories/2002/05/06/story2.html

Dear Governor Bush,
My name is Theresa Danzey, and it the last name sounds familiar it is because my husband is Ron Danzey, School Board Member in Bay County.  I have a situation I would like to share with you concerning my son Andrew.
 
First of all, I agree and support testing like the HSCT and FCAT, however this is what has happened in my family.  Andrew is a LD student and was identified as such in and elementary school 10 years ago.  Andrew is about to complete High School and has done everything he was supposed to do.  He made A’s, B’s, C’s and one or two D’s through out his high school years. His attendance has been good and his classroom work has been good.  Our situation is that he has taken the HSCT for the 4th time.  He has passed the math portion, but has fell a few points from passing the language portion. (This is his LD area) I do not feel it is fair for a student who had accomplished everything that has been asked of him to not be allowed a graduation diploma. A certificate of completion does not amply provide or state his accomplishments.  There must be another option for All students who do not test well or have learning disabilities or just learn a different way.
 
This situation has really broken my heart, because I have watched him work hard for the last 4 years and now it apparent that it is all in vain because of ONE test given; instead of looking at the whole child.  Is there anything you can do to help my son?
 
I hope that you and others with our children at heart can take another look at options that will help my son and those like him.
 
Thank you so much for all you do and  for taking time to listen to my concern!
Theresa

Dear Governor Bush: 

I was pleased to see that you created a Blue Ribbon Panel of some of our finest citizens to review the child welfare department in Miami. I am sure that with their expertise and commitment that they will be effective. 

I wanted to let you know that I have served for the past three years as the Chairperson of the Florida Bar Commission on the Legal Needs of Children and that we have spent substantial time reviewing the needs of children who find themselves in our court system and in our foster care system. We produced an Interim Report last year and we are drafting our Final Report at this time. The Secretary of DCF served on our commission as did a wide variety of experts in child advocacy from around the state, including Representative Sandra Murman and Senator Burt Saunders.

I would be happy to send you our interim recommendations and our final recommendations which should be complete by the end of May.
