From:	Jeb Bush
Sent:	Tuesday, May 7, 2002 10:18 PM
To:	'RUSSELL.DAVE'
Subject:	RE: A concern

thanks Dave. 
 
Part of the problem is part of the solution. We opened the spicket with the Keyla bill that requires more people to call the hotline. the funnel has increased by law and the number of kids in the system is actually lower than 1998. I think this is a good thing but it creates more angst since more calls are being investigated. 
 
You and I must know that being a child welfare investigator is a really difficult job. You are asked to make judgements that a mom and dad should have already done. Sadly, wholesome family life is not always the norm in Florida. 
 
thanks to the Florida Legislature in the last three years, we have nearly doubled the funding for our child welfare system. Case loads have dropped, quality assurance funding and implementation is up, the technology project will begin to bear fruit, more kids are being adopted, more mental health and drug treatment funding are  going to parents who have lost their way, and perhaps most importantly, we are moving to a community based care model that gets DCF out of the direct business of caring for kids that are neglected and abused. I honestly think we are on the right track and I intend to use this tragic case as a means to accelerate our efforts to improve the system. 
 
Dave, should our review find that there is a systemic problem with our current system, I will take the necessary action. 

Jeb Bush

-----Original Message-----
From: CFLCC-Steele, William H MAJ ARCENT-KU [mailto:efsteelew@kuwait.army.mil]
Sent: Saturday, May 04, 2002 5:55 AM
To: RUSSELL.DAVE
Subject: A concern


Greetings and good morning Rep Russell.
 
You don't know me, but I am a registered voter in Dist 44.  In 1994, my family was almost destroyed by the DCFS (then known as HRS) because of false allegations that were made by incompetent and untrained case workers. When we dared to stand up to their gestapo tactics, HRS did EVERYTHING in their power to destroy us.  By the time HRS backed down, my family was torn apart and it cost us 70K.  All charges (which were based on hearsay and based on NO tangible evidence what so ever) were dropped to the dismay of the HRS case workers.  They appealed but to no avail. HRS continued to harass my family for months.  HRS never did apologize despicable behavior.  My wife and I went on to worked with SEN Steve Wise on getting new laws passed to prevent future HRS abuse.
 
As a commissioned officer with the U.S. Army (Military Police/CID), I am stationed away from my home in Florida, but I still keep on top of current events in my home town (Spring Hill) and home state.  I am a conscientious voter. Because of being stationed away from home, I can no longer be as active in helping families who are falsely and maliciously attached by DCFS as I once was.  I can however, communicate to my legislative representative and look to see that he/she is doing what is necessary to ensure that DCFS is doing their job responsibly to protect children and families alike.
 
 
Now, the purpose of this e-mail is to express a concern regarding a new license for DCFS to over react.
 
When I can get a free moment to catch up on Florida news, I can't help but notice that DCFS and their failures are once again in the lime light.  Most of the attention appears to be directed towards DCFS' continuing failures which are resulting the the "misplacement" and injury and death to children.  We both know that some of these unforgivable results are because DCFS continues to focus much energy and resources towards persecuting good wholesome families who stand up to DCFS gestapo tactics; families who have been attacked by DCFS based on pure hearsay and unsubstantiated speculations.
 
I can foresee that with all the new attention given DCFS failures resulting in death, injury and lost children, they will increase their gestapo tactics and cast a wide net - just so they can say "look at all the children we have taken into custody now Governor Bush.  Aren't we doing a great job now"  
 
I hope that the governor will take strong action to force DCFS to do its job responsibly and NOT to go after families unless there is clear articulated evidence that abuse and neglect exists - and not destroy families based on hearsay - which as you know is a common practice by DCFS.  I hope that the legislature will demand that DCFS does its job to protect BOTH children from dangerous situations AND families from false persecution by DCFS.
 
If only we could convince the legislature and the governor to take DCFS out of the criminal investigations business and put investigations of child abuse crimes in law enforcement hands.
 
Thank you for allowing this Florida  citizen the opportunity to express a concern.  
 
Thank you.

4.  You stalled me based on legal issues you said you had and I worked with Ken hart, at your direction, to solve these issues
5.  you deployed a solution on your own (good for you if it is good for the Lottery and the state and as long as it does not infringe on my patents and as long as it is legal)
 
I have invested time, money, and energy into this solution (IMARCS) and I took the time to educate you and your staff and in return you bypass me. I have no other option than to make sure that people who will take responsibility see this.  I want only the best for the Lottery and for the state. >From: literarychick28@netscape.net [mailto:literarychick28@netscape.net]
>Sent: Thursday, May 02, 2002 1:32 AM
>To: Jeb Bush
>Subject: re: school interview

>
>Hello Governor Bush,
>Thank you very much for agreeing to do this interview. Here is a list of
>questions that I had prepared about issues facing students as well as
>your experiences.
>
>-Why do you think that it is important to support the Florida Virtual
>School? IT HAS THE POTENTIAL OF HELPING TO REDEFINE EDUCATION. IT IS
>STUDENT CENTERED AND CAN BE USED IN SO MANY WAYS .... REMEDIATION,
>HONORS/AP CLASSES FOR STUDENTS WHO CAN'T ACCESS THEM, ETC.
>
>-Do you foresee other schools of a similar design popping up around the
>country? YES BUT IN OUR STATE IT IS MY HOPE THAT WE DON'T TRY TO
>REINVENT THE WHEEL AND CONTINUE TO SUPPORT FLORIDA VIRTUAL SCHOOL.
>
>-Do you think that online learning would have been beneficial when you
>were growing up or perhaps would have benefited your children? GOSH, I
>AM SO OLD I CAN REMEMBER BLACK AND WHITE TELEVISIONS! ON LINE LEARNING
>WOULD HAVE BEEN VERY USEFUL TO ME.
>
>-Do you think that the Virtual School will be able to issue diplomas to
>its students in the near future? I HOPE SO.
>
>-Many critics argue that FLVS is not an effective educational medium
>because of the lack of interaction among students and faculty. However,
>AP (Advanced Placement) scores among Virtual School students exceed the
>national average by nearly nine percent. What is your comment about this
>apparent contradiction? THE VIRTUAL SCHOOL IS NOT FOR EVERYONE. BUT IT
>IS A GOOD MEANS TO ACCELERATE LEARNING FOR KIDS THAT DON'T NEED AS MUCH
>ATTENTION.
>
>-There has been a considerable amount of media coverage on the recent
>cell phone controversies facing school districts across America. Some
>believe that students should be allowed to keep these devices on campus
>as long as they are not turned on, whereas others protest that such
>technologies would serve as nothing but a distraction. Where do you
>stand and why? I HAVE NOT FOLLOWED THE ISSUE BUT NOW i WILL!
>
>-The SWAT (Students Working Against Tobacco) program, which was founded
>under the Chiles administration, received a considerable budget cut in
>October, with a large portion of that money being redistributed to
>enhance road development. Do you think that it will be important to
>restore the funds for this program? THE TOBACCO PROGRAM IS DOING FINE.
>WE ARE SPENDING $39 MILLION DOLLARS. THAT WAS WHAT IS BEING SPENT LAST
>YEAR. THAT IS A LOT OF DOUGH!
>
>-If funding is not able to be replaced, what are some of the initiatives
>that can be taken to continue efforts to decrease youth smoking? TEEN
>SMOKING IS DOWN IN OUR STATE WHICH IS A GOOD THING.
>
>-Due to increased security after September 11, do you think that there
>has been a decrease in youth involvement in the government, such as the
>TeenPact program for Christian homeschoolers or the senate page program,
>in which Stephen York, a Florida Virtual School student, participates? I
>HAVE NOT NOTICED A DECLINE IN YOUTH INVOLVEMENT. IN FACT, I THINK THERE
>HAS BEEN MORE CIVIC INVOLVEMENT THAN BEFORE THAT I HOPE CAN BE
>SUSTAINED.
>
>-I am sure that you are aware of the teacher shortage facing the state
>of Florida. What would you say to high schoolers or college students to
>encourage them to pursue a career in the field of education? THE LAWS OF
>SUPPLY AND DEMAND APPLY TO THE TEACHING PROFESSION. THERE WILL BE GREAT
>OPPORTUNITIES IN TEACHING IN THE NEXT DECADE. TEACHING IS A VERY NOBLE
>PROFESSION!
>
>-What factors influenced your decision to attend the college that you
>did? I WENT TO HIGH SCHOOL IN THE NORTHEAST US AND WANTED TO GO BACK
>HOME SO I ATTENDED THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS. 
>
>-What is something that you now know that you wish you would have known
>while in school? I KNOW NOW NOT TO BE IN QUITE THE RUSH I WAS IN BACK
>THEN. I GRADUATED IN 2.5 YEARS.
>
>-Your mother seems to be a pretty amazing woman. What is the most
>important piece of advice that she gave you, and have you shared this
>with your own children? LOVE MY WIFE AND CHILDREN MORE THAN LIFE ITSELF.
>THAT IS EASY TO DO!
>
>-What advice would you give to the siblings of particularly high
>achievers? WORK HARD.
>
>-Growing up in a political family, when did you decide that this would
>be the area that you would go into? What other fields had you
>considered? I FIRST GOT INVOLVED IN POLITICS TO HELP MY DAD WHO I TRULY
>LOVE. I OVERCAME MY FEARS OF SPEAKING IN PUBLIC AND BEGAN TO UNDERSTAND
>THE JOYS OF SERVICE BY WATCHING MY DAD IN HIS PUBLIC SERVICE. IN 1993 I
>DECIDED TO MAKE THE LEAP. I HAD BEEN IN THE PRIVATE SECTOR UNTIL THEN.
>
>-Has it been difficult to maintain your own identity instead of just
>being one of “the Bush boys?” I STOPPED WORRYING ABOUT WHAT PEOPLE THINK
>A WHILE BACK AND NOW FOCUS ON HOW I CAN SERVE AND HELP OTHERS.
>
>-Integrity is an important quality for all of humanity, but especially
>those who have achieved celebrity status as political figures. What
>suggestions do you have for the next generation of voters who are
>exposed to negative campaigning and apparent lack of morality on the
>part of some elected officials? SAY WHAT YOU ARE GOING TO DO AND DO WHAT
>YOU SAID YOU WOULD DO. DON'T VEER FROM PRINCIPLE. BE HONEST WITH
>YOURSELF. SHOW HUMILITY. FIGHT HARD BUT FIGHT FAIR.
>
>-What do you think of such government based shows as NBC’S “The West
>Wing?” Do you feel that these give an accurate portrayal of political
>life? I DON'T WATCH WEST WING.
>
>-What is one of your stronger contributions that you would like to see
>communicated, but that you fear may be overshadowed by other platforms
>in the upcoming campaign? MOVING OUR STATE TOWARDS RISING STUDENT
>ACHIEVEMENT BEING THE MISSION AND CALLING OF ALL FLORIDIANS. 
>

>written.

>Thank you,

-----Original Message-----
From: Sandy Faulkner [mailto:sfaulk@tampabay.rr.com]
Sent: Wednesday, May 08, 2002 12:36 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Department of Children & Families


Dear Jeb,
 
I regret that I have to write you this e-mail at a time when you are already faced with mounting problems with the Department of Families and Children but a problem arrived on my doorstep unexpectedly and I can't just turn away.  
 
Over the weekend, Debbie brought a co-worker, Stefani home to join our family for a Sunday BBQ. Debbie had expressed concern for this girl because she had no parents and said her landlord wasn't very nice to her, so we decided to have her join us for a family day.   During the day, Stephani, who is 16,  told us about the exorbitant rent her landlord was charging her.  She explained that she pays over $600 per month rent for a room in the home of an employee (case worker) of the Department of Families & Children.  In addition,  the woman charges her extra for food, telephone and other incidentals, and gets angry when she has to pick Stefani up from work.   
 
If that wasn't bad enough, last night, the woman told the girl to "Pick up your sh#$ and get out!!"   Being 16, the girl the only person she knew she could call, a 19-year-old former foster sister to come get her.   She was picked up and spent the night with her foster sister.  To make matters even worse, the landlord/caseworker, reported the girl as a runaway today, and then had the girl's only means of communication, her cell phone (that Stephani pays for) shut off.
 
Before her phone was shut off, Stefani called Debbie  asking her what she should do.  Debbie handed the phone to me, and I have spent an entire day trying to find this girl some help.  To me, this is an inexcusable situation . . . certainly not as heinous as that of the missing 5-year-old, but certainly of major concern when those in charge of  protecting these kids are the ones taking advantage of them.
 
I have contacted a family court judge, the public defender's office, the state attorney and Gus Bilirakis's office and am awaiting replies.   When I spoke with the State Attorney's office I was told I needed to contact the girl's caseworker.   When I explained that the problem was with one of the case workers in the same office, they still insisted that I would have to talk with the case worker if there is a problem.  It seem to me, that calling the case worker who placed the girl with a co-worker who is charging this girl rent plus is liking asking the "wolf to watch the hen house!"  I was so baffled by the response, that I asked the person at the State Attorney's office if there was anyone who looked out for children in these situations and the answer I received was "I don't know.  You have to call the case worker."    
 
I'm sure there are all kinds of rules and regulations that I don't know and probably wouldn't understand.   But what I do know is that this "case" is not a number but a child, without any parents, who is working hard to maintain an 3.5 GPA in High School, works 30-40 hrs a week, and is being grossly taking advantage of by the very people who should be looking out for her.   I can't even explain how disgusted and frustrated I am.
 
I realize you can't get involved in all the individual cases all around the state, but considering the current scrutiny of this department, I wanted to share this situation since it seems to involve employees of the department using their positions in an improper way.
 
I will continue to work with the professionals locally until we can find a suitable solution for Stefani.  My only concern is that I am leaving on Monday for a trip to Washington D.C. with Debbie & Lisa. Although our main purpose of the trip is for Debbie to visit Georgetown University where she is seriously considering applying to the  School of Foreign Service, we plan to send a couple of extra days touring the city, since neither of the girls have ever visited before.  We planned the trip early so when Debbie returns she can begin her search for a summer job/internship or volunteer position with an agency or organization associated with International or Latin American Relations to further explore her possible career choice.   
 
Although I'm really excited and looking forward to taking Debbie & Lisa to Washington, I am very concerned with leaving Stefani.  I hope we can get her situation resolved before I leave on Monday, but I'm not very optimistic at this point.  
 
Regardless of what happens with the Department and Stefani's immediate situation, I have decided that I will continue to meet and work with Stefani and be an adult she can trust and count on.  She seems to be a remarkable young lady who has dreams and goals and appears to have the strength of character to overcome her difficult childhood to achieve them.  I only I hope I can help her see them come true.  
 
Thank you for listening.   
 
 
Sincerely,
 
Sandy Faulkner

Cc: 'laura.branker@myflorida.com'; 'laura.branker@myflorida.com'
Subject: Fw: Follow to meeting with the Governor on the DD Redesign


Did you get all theInfo you wanted?

The first 2 paragraghs in Shelly's email below summarize the strategy we

--------------------------
Sent from my BlackBerry Wireless Handheld (www.BlackBerry.net)


-----Original Message-----
From: Brantley, Michelle K. <brantlem@fdhc.state.fl.us>
To: Medows, Rhonda M.D. <medowsr@fdhc.state.fl.us>
Sent: Tue May 07 20:12:56 2002
Subject: Follow to meeting with the Governor on the DD Redesign

In response to our discussion, it is very important that we use some
strategy to balance flexibility and choice with budget parameters. If we
allow families maximum flexibility and choice with no budget parameters, we
will be in a program deficit again next year. Just as we experienced
significant resistance to managed care type arrangements (especially for the
disabled) it is difficult for most stakeholders to accept any type of
monetary limit. It is critical that the increased flexibility and choice are
tied to a budget based on individual needs especially when we try to
promulgate policies into administrative rule. This will require the
assessment tool and budget/rate analysis included in the RFP to be completed
first. The assessment tool, individual budgets based on level of need
(derived from the assessment) and standardized provider rates are the most
controversial because they are all linked to the bottom line; money. 

If all the good news is implemented first (flexibility, greater choice,
direct provider billing, reduced workload and paperwork for support
coordinators, fair and equitable rates) and then we try to phase in budget
parameters based on level of need, it will be extremely difficult to gain
any kind of stakeholder buy-in and phase 2 (not so good news) will be
challenged and protested in rule hearings.

As I mentioned earlier, it would be similar to handing everyone in the
consumer directed care program a Platinum American Express Card with no
limits instead of the monthly cash budget they work within now based on
their LTC needs. (Or worse, giving the CDC participant the credit card first
and then explaining limitations and credit card dept later).

 Another gross comparison would be handing a 16 yr old the keys to a new car
on his birthday and then announcing at the end of the month that he will
need to make car payments, buy car insurance and baby-sit his sister every
Friday night.

Unlike capitated arrangements, prior authorization or other more traditional
delivery models and cost containment methods, this model gives the consumer,
not the provider or the government, maximum choice and control over their
long term care needs.

Shelly Brantley
Bureau Chief
Medicaid Program Development
Telephone: (850)488-9347

-----Original Message-----
From: Bahrami, Kimberly [mailto:Kim.Bahrami@MyFlorida.com]
Sent: Friday, February 08, 2002 8:33 AM
To: Shanahan, Kathleen; Jeb Bush
Subject: RE: CIO Council Meeting


I had a fantastic, 2 hour strategy session with Accenture yesterday. We are developing the statewide business case for enterprise licenses.  We plan to lay out two or three innovative funding and integration options for an enterprise licensing solution to be used for licensing processes at 10 agencies.  As we work through the overall strategy, the initial focus will be on the convergence of the DBPR, DOH and AHCA Versa systems and business processes. I want to ensure that Dr. John, Dr. Medows and Secretary Binkley-Seyer clearly understand how we get from where we are today to the vision of enterprise licensing that we all share. The plan is to have this decision paper completed near the end of next week.
 
While the current Versa solution at DBPR is workable, there are a few technical shortcomings that Versa must address prior to or to extending this solution to DOH and AHCA.  Versa is a small company but a good one and they understand the potential benefits of ensuring that their product is "robust" and scalable.    Accenture and I agreed to work together to ensure that Versa places the appropriate priority and focus on the immediate resolution of these problems.  
 
Kim

-----Original Message-----
From: Sandy Faulkner [mailto:sfaulk@tampabay.rr.com]
Sent: Wednesday, May 08, 2002 12:36 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Department of Children & Families


Dear Jeb,
 
I regret that I have to write you this e-mail at a time when you are already faced with mounting problems with the Department of Families and Children but a problem arrived on my doorstep unexpectedly and I can't just turn away.  
 
Over the weekend, Debbie brought a co-worker, Stefani home to join our family for a Sunday BBQ. Debbie had expressed concern for this girl because she had no parents and said her landlord wasn't very nice to her, so we decided to have her join us for a family day.   During the day, Stephani, who is 16,  told us about the exorbitant rent her landlord was charging her.  She explained that she pays over $600 per month rent for a room in the home of an employee (case worker) of the Department of Families & Children.  In addition,  the woman charges her extra for food, telephone and other incidentals, and gets angry when she has to pick Stefani up from work.   
 
If that wasn't bad enough, last night, the woman told the girl to "Pick up your sh#$ and get out!!"   Being 16, the girl the only person she knew she could call, a 19-year-old former foster sister to come get her.   She was picked up and spent the night with her foster sister.  To make matters even worse, the landlord/caseworker, reported the girl as a runaway today, and then had the girl's only means of communication, her cell phone (that Stephani pays for) shut off.
 
Before her phone was shut off, Stefani called Debbie  asking her what she should do.  Debbie handed the phone to me, and I have spent an entire day trying to find this girl some help.  To me, this is an inexcusable situation . . . certainly not as heinous as that of the missing 5-year-old, but certainly of major concern when those in charge of  protecting these kids are the ones taking advantage of them.
 
I have contacted a family court judge, the public defender's office, the state attorney and Gus Bilirakis's office and am awaiting replies.   When I spoke with the State Attorney's office I was told I needed to contact the girl's caseworker.   When I explained that the problem was with one of the case workers in the same office, they still insisted that I would have to talk with the case worker if there is a problem.  It seem to me, that calling the case worker who placed the girl with a co-worker who is charging this girl rent plus is liking asking the "wolf to watch the hen house!"  I was so baffled by the response, that I asked the person at the State Attorney's office if there was anyone who looked out for children in these situations and the answer I received was "I don't know.  You have to call the case worker."    
 
I'm sure there are all kinds of rules and regulations that I don't know and probably wouldn't understand.   But what I do know is that this "case" is not a number but a child, without any parents, who is working hard to maintain an 3.5 GPA in High School, works 30-40 hrs a week, and is being grossly taking advantage of by the very people who should be looking out for her.   I can't even explain how disgusted and frustrated I am.
 
I realize you can't get involved in all the individual cases all around the state, but considering the current scrutiny of this department, I wanted to share this situation since it seems to involve employees of the department using their positions in an improper way.
 
I will continue to work with the professionals locally until we can find a suitable solution for Stefani.  My only concern is that I am leaving on Monday for a trip to Washington D.C. with Debbie & Lisa. Although our main purpose of the trip is for Debbie to visit Georgetown University where she is seriously considering applying to the  School of Foreign Service, we plan to send a couple of extra days touring the city, since neither of the girls have ever visited before.  We planned the trip early so when Debbie returns she can begin her search for a summer job/internship or volunteer position with an agency or organization associated with International or Latin American Relations to further explore her possible career choice.   
 
Although I'm really excited and looking forward to taking Debbie & Lisa to Washington, I am very concerned with leaving Stefani.  I hope we can get her situation resolved before I leave on Monday, but I'm not very optimistic at this point.  
 
Regardless of what happens with the Department and Stefani's immediate situation, I have decided that I will continue to meet and work with Stefani and be an adult she can trust and count on.  She seems to be a remarkable young lady who has dreams and goals and appears to have the strength of character to overcome her difficult childhood to achieve them.  I only I hope I can help her see them come true.  
 
Thank you for listening.   
 
 
Sincerely,
 
Sandy Faulkner

Park Service Plans Massive New Land Grabs! 

Republican Appointees in the National Park Service are hatching a new 
attack 
on private property rights! 

A May 1, 2002 article in the Portland, Oregon newspaper, the Oregonian, 
shows how the Park Service seems to be out of control in the Bush 
Administration.  FULL  ARTICLE PRINTED  BELOW. 

At a meeting of Park Service superintendents in Portland this week the land 
grabbers were setting their sights on your land and other lands between 
national parks across America.  The proposal uses soft words and invokes 
children and wildlife to hide the real agenda, a huge land grab of private 
and Federal land. 

The first thing that occurs when parks are created is that large areas are 
designated off-limits, roads are closed, campgrounds shut down, public 
services reduced and the public limited to using as little as 5% to 10% of 
the land area of the park to recreate. For example, 95% of the new Death 
Valley National Park is wilderness, closed to the public! 

A current proposal to force people to use busses in Yosemite is one 
example. 
If the Park Service gets its way,  the public won't be able to visit 
Yosemite unless they are willing to ride a bus and stuff all their camping 
equipment on a bus.  People do not leave their urban area to be forced into 
another urbanized area.   The public is going to support parks less if they 
can't go there. 

See article below - using a sea lion as an illustration with no barriers in 
the ocean is exactly what the superintendents really want with the park 
corridors -- no barriers.  That means the loss of private land, grazing, 
farming, forestry, recreation and many other multiple uses that take place 
adjacent to the parks.  It means local communities losing tax base and 
economic support for schools and roads, often used by park personnel. 

This new initiative has support from Park Service Director Fran Mainella, a 
liberal Democrat.  How did a liberal Democrat get appointed to a top job in 
a Republican Administration?????  Simple - her former boss was Jeb Bush, 
the 
Governor of Florida and the President's brother. 

Mainella has, as you might expect, appointed two liberal Democrats to help 
her to trash private property rights and restrict recreational access to 
the 
parks.  Here they are, the National Park Service's two deputy directors: 

Deputy Director Randy Jones is was brought in after serving as Park 
Superintendent in Rocky Mountain National Park in Colorado.  His claim to 
fame at Rocky Mountain was that he was opposed to any private land in the 
park and refused to set foot on private land if it was inside the park 
boundary.  He even attempted to prevent a 73 year old widow from repairing 
a 
bridge to her property, but was overruled by the Corps of Engineers. 
Jones's anti-private property stance is now guiding the Park Service. 

The other new Deputy Director is Don Murphy.  His claim to fame is 
spending the past four years running an outfit called Americans for 
Heritage 
and Recreation (AHR).  This was the umbrella group the ran the campaign 
to approve CARA, the Condemnation and Relocation Act, the infamous $47 
billion land acquisition trust fund!!!! 

Here is what Murphy thinks of private property rights.  This is the 
"Guiding 
Principles" from which he ran AHR: 

"AHR adamantly opposes any restrictions on the Land and Water Conservation 
Fund, especially those that limit acquisition, employ arbitrary geographic 
restrictions on the use of funds, require new authorizations, or prevent 
condemnation." 

Believe it or not, these are the liberal Democrats appointed by Interior 
Secretary Gale Norton to run the National Park Service.  Anti-private 
property rights, anti-recreation. 

The Park Service should be actually following the supposed Bush 
Administration agenda that they want to take care of the existing parks. 
It looks to us like the Park Service is spending more time on how it can 
expand the parks! 


ACTION ITEM: 

Call and e-mail your Congressman and both Senators.  Let them know you 
oppose more land acquisition funding and ask them to vote against HR 701, 
CARA, the Condemnation and Relocation Act, and S.990, the "Son of CARA" 
Land Grab. 

Urge them to question the funding for massive "wildlife" connecting 
corridors and additional expansion plans by the Park Service.   Wildlife is 
just being used an excuse 
for land use controls.  Tell them to force the Park Service to take care of 
what they already have, instead of expanding their empire. 

You may call any Congressman or Senator at the Capitol Switchboard -- (202) 
224-3121 or the temporary FREE NUMBER  (800) 648-3516. 


The Oregonian  -- Portland, Oregon - 

Park Leaders See Value In Networking 

05/01/02 by Michael Milstein 

Spectacular national parks such as Crater Lake and Mount Rainier may be 
icons all by themselves, but they will lose their value to people and 
wildlife if they become lone refuges all by themselves, said national park 
superintendents who gathered Tuesday in Portland. 

Park superintendents from around the West focused on a Bush administration 
goal of building "seamless networks" of parks around the country. It does 
not involve creating new parks as much as building connections among 
famous and lesser-known national parks, plus the state parks, playgrounds 
and inner-city parks that may be the first place many children enjoy the 
outdoors. 

Such connections may be as simple as attracting children from Portland's 
city park programs to Crater Lake to admire its pristine water and 
wildlife, or as elaborate as a parklike path for people to Rollerblade 
from Mount Rainier to Puget Sound. 

By building such connections, park managers will inevitably create 
corridors that also serve wildlife, they said. Without them, isolated 
national parks will become overcrowded final refuges for wildlife and an 
increasingly urban society trying to escape the development and sprawl 
that go with it. 

"That's the future of Mount Rainier if we don't save all that stuff from 
Mount Rainier to Puget Sound," said Jon Jarvis, superintendent of Mount 
Rainier National Park. "It becomes the last place wildlife has to go, but 
also the last place for recreation." 

The new initiative has support from National Park Service Director Fran 
Mainella and Interior Secretary Gale Norton, said Randy Jones, deputy 
director of the Park Service. They and park managers see it extending the 
reach of national parks to city residents who otherwise may lose touch 
with such natural places and the reasons for protecting them. 

"We have enjoyed tremendous support for the parks, but we have to make 
sure the parks remain essential to what is becoming our new and diverse 
constituency in this new century," said Chuck Lundy, superintendent of 
Crater Lake National Park. 

Studies in California have found that wildlife uses even tenuous links 
between park and forestland that involve crossing bridges over an 
interstate, said John Reynolds, regional director of the Park Service. A 
sea lion tagged at Point Reyes near San Francisco turned up in Russia this 
year, evidence of long-distance connections between wildlands, he said. 

The Bush administration has made national parks the core of its 
environmental strategy, vowing to repair the backlog of almost $1 billion 
worth of decaying buildings and potholed roads. 

But Liz Raisbeck of the National Parks and Conservation Association told 
superintendents Tuesday that her group is concerned "the pendulum may be 
swinging heavily" toward more intensive uses of parks that could damage 
them. She mentioned administration moves to compromise policies that could 
have banned snowmobiles and Jet Skis in parks. 

Donald Leal of the Political Economy Research Center, a free market think 
tank in Bozeman, Mont., said parks could control such uses by charging 
higher fees to account for the noise and pollution they may emit. 

"Don't send the idea that recreation is free -- it does have costs; it 
does have impacts," Leal said. "There is no mechanism in place that tells 
people who are using the parks, who are using the snowmobiles, that they 
have to bear some of the cost."

Sent:	Wednesday, May 8, 2002 1:46 PM
To:	Jeb Bush

Hi Jeb, 
Regarding your Blue Ribbon Panel to "investigate Rilya": 

While your Blue Ribbon Choices may sound "impressive" because of their "job categories", they are hardly familiar with law, procedures in Juvenile Dependency, and all the goings on in "The System".

Would be nice if you were more sincere. 

I could provide you with names of professionals with a much better familiarity and knowledge of the system, who would provide a more concrete investigation and suggestions for problems solving in the system, if impressive sounding individuals are what you want. 

Appointing the wrong people for such a task, is not a feather in your hat, but an acknowledgement that you have no serious intentions about these problems than winning your election..and to others who may not perceive it as such, that you yourself are ignorant of what goes on in the system. But we all know you are not. You have receive plenty of complaints. 
You were not concerned with these matters until the publicity, despite all the complaint letters you receive, and all the in person complaints you have received. 

Jeb, I know you can be a better man and political leader than that. 
But I gave up on you this year. Just like you are taking advantage of the "election year", we too were hoping to at least get a few good changes out of that same motive, but for good rather than votes. 

I am sure you will only do the minimum necessary to win in 2002. 

Sad it is, and a true pity for real American families, be they single parent or 2 parent homes. Too bad Sept 11 didn't bring out the real red, white and blue in you. 

Sheila Vives

From:	Lisa.Snell@reason.org
Sent:	Wednesday, May 8, 2002 4:29 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	College Market

Jeb,

I wanted to share this column by my colleague Mike Lynch, who is Reason magazine's national correspondent. He examines several recent reports on the cost and availability of college in the United States. As Mike explains, "in the higher ed market, there's something for everyone. Which is why the classrooms are full."  

Costly Education
By Mike Lynch <mailto:mwlynch@reason.com>

There's always something to worry about -- and for the government to spend more money on. 

The cost of college is never far down the list.

Back in January, the Lumina Foundation, which is spending a wad of cash kicked off from the student loan business, announced that Americans enjoy unequal access <http://www.luminafoundation.org/monographs/states/pdfs/Web.pdf> to higher education, since the wealthy can more easily afford to pay full freight. And last week the National Center for Public Policy in Higher Education delivered a study <http://www.highereducation.org/reports/losing_ground/ar3.shtml> that shows that the cost of public colleges and universities has gone up over the last 20 years. 

Yet if higher education is becoming unaffordable, someone has forgotten to tell students, who've increased <http://www.census.gov/prod/2002pubs/01statab/educ.pdf> from 8.6 million in 1970 to 14.5 million in 1998. Maybe this is because even as the sticker price of a college degree has increased, the returns to claiming one have shot up <http://www.acenet.edu/hena/facts_in_brief/1999/04_26_99_fib.cfm> as well. 

It's not as if governments have been neglecting the issue-college is clearly of great concern to middle and upper-middle class voters. In recent years, the federal and state governments have created and then liberalized the rules on tax-advantaged savings accounts, both Education IRAs <http://www.fool.com/money/allaboutiras/allaboutiras10.htm> and 529 plans <http://www.savingforcollege.com/>. And the average price of tuition, which appears strikingly high when quoted out of context, masks the tremendous diversity of the collection of institutions of higher learning, which include everything from inexpensive and extremely flexible junior colleges to extremely expensive elite liberal arts schools.

Indeed, one dares say that in the higher ed market, there's something for everyone. Which is why the classrooms are full.
 
Mike Lynch <mailto:mwlynch@reason.com> is Reason's national correspondent.


My hope is that someday "there will be something for everyone," in the K-12 education system.

Thank you for your continued support of Reason's education work.

Best,

Lisa

Lisa Snell
Director Education and Child Welfare Program
Reason Foundation
3415 S. Sepulveda Blvd. #400
Los Angeles, CA 90034
www.reason.org
www.RPPI.org
www.reason.com
310-391-2245


Reason Public Policy Institute is a think tank promoting choice, competition, and a dynamic market economy as the foundation for human dignity and progress.

From:	Pat Owens <stitchabq@earthlink.net>
Sent:	Wednesday, May 8, 2002 6:10 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	The Rilya Wilson Case

Copy of what I sent to the Clerk of Court in Miami today. The offer stands 
for you as well.  Pat

Hi,

Yesterday I attempted to call Judge Cindy Lederman's office to leave a 
message for either a call back at another time or establish an email 
link.  It must have been a very busy day as it took several attempts to get 
a ring and the ensuing conversation was quite rushed. That's understandable 
given the situation.

I would however like to offer my observations about this case. You see, 
almost two years ago my own family's travails with the Florida DCF ended in 
total failure with the death of my elderly invalid stepmother. I 
established contacts in that case as a representative of the extended 
family with DCF attempting to re-establish contact between my stepmother 
and the family when it was suddenly cut by a young unrelated caregiver. I 
quickly learned the ins and outs of dealing with the DCF both on a local 
and state level as the case eventually widened to involve no less than 
three counties (Volusia, Orange and Brevard) and a variety of law 
enforcement departments. I fought it as far as the Governor's office 
establishing a link there by both phone and email. You can imagine how I 
felt when I saw Rilya's case in the news. Even my friends commented on the 
similarities of Rilya's case to my battle. Some of the names I saw 
mentioned there were some of the same people that I dealt with. I 
understand them all too well.

I think that if someone there has the time to speak with me I could be of 
assistance in understanding the ramifications of  the actions by DCF. I 
could possibly save you some time and grief.  I'm willing to do this 
because I hate to see another family hurt by a system that causes otherwise 
good people to do hurtful things.

Did I just hint that I think the DCF is not all bad? Yes, I did. In a way 
they remind me of a cartoon character in the "Roger the Rabbit" movie, 
Jessica Rabbit. You might remember her catch phrase, "I'm not bad, I'm just 
drawn that way."  Well, a fair number of DCF employees are "not bad they're 
just totally overwhelmed."  Some times it takes someone who has enough 
distance in time and space with enough background in the subject to see 
more of what's really going on.  I think I might be just that person.

At any rate I only wanted to offer what assistance and insight that I might 
have to Judge Lederman. She looks and sounds like the kind of judge I wish 
I had met in Florida.  I put Rilya's picture on my computer screen to 
remind me to pray for her and her family.  I shall add all of you to that 
list as well.

Thank you.



Pat Owens

Stitched Together/Stitchers@ABQ Needlework
9800 Montgomery NE Ste 1A
Albuquerque, NM 87111
505-293-2221 Days/505-837-2554 Nights/505-235-8358 Cell/ 800-410-4514 Shop 
Toll Free

From:	JLRttag@cs.com
Sent:	Wednesday, May 8, 2002 8:37 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	FARM BILL GOES TO THE PRESIDENT

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE                                      CONTACT: 




May 8, 2002                                            Florida Farmers, Inc. 
                                                             J. Luis Rodriguez 800/895-2221 
                                                             Hugh MacMillan  850/224-9339 

FARM BILL GOES TO THE PRESIDENT 

FLORIDA FARMERS APPLAUD FOOD LABELING 


The U.S. Senate today approved the new Farm Bill. It now goes to the President who has indicated that he will sign it. The legislation includes a country-of-origin labeling requirement important to Florida growers and American consumers. The law calls for all imported fruits, vegetables, peanuts, meats and fish to be labeled with the country of origin on grocery store shelves. A similar law has been in force and appreciated by consumers in Florida since 1979.  Based on Florida’s experience, Senator Bob Graham and others have worked for a federal law, but each year the House of Representatives has blocked the measure.   

But earlier this year Congresswoman Mary Bono of California in a late night maneuver succeeded in passing a floor amendment to the Farm Bill. In 1998 she took up the cause of country-of-origin labeling that her late husband Sonny Bono had championed as a California congressman. The House vote on the Bono amendment was 296-121, thanks to a bipartisan group of consumer advocates, including most every woman in Congress. 

Florida Farmers, Inc. (FFI), an advocacy group of Florida winter vegetable growers, commended Senators Graham, Congresswoman Bono, Governor Jeb Bush and Florida Agriculture Commissioner Charles Bronson for their efforts in the last few days of the Farm Bill conference to keep country-of-origin labeling in the final Farm Bill report. FFI led a coalition of over 200 grassroots farm organizations, consumer and pubic interest groups across the nation to win this hard-fought issue. 

“The grassroots effort overcame the well-financed corporate food chain lobby to win the right to know and choose the place of origin of our food, “ said Paul DiMare of Homestead, Chairman of FFI.  “Country-of-origin labeling helps American consumers and those American farmers who provide food for American consumers.” 

“While much of the Farm Bill is oriented toward agribusiness sectors producing for export, Florida vegetable farmers are focused on providing a safe, quality product to the American consumer. In the present free trade environment, the national labeling law will help Florida winter vegetable farmers and all farmers of America compete with foreign products which may not meet the environmental and labor standards of U.S. growers,” according to J. Luis Rodriguez, a trade advisor to FFI who helped with the 1979 Florida effort and has advocated for national legislation for the past 20 years.

From: Sean Taylor [mailto:taylors@sso.org]
Sent: Wednesday, May 08, 2002 6:13 PM
To: Kathleen Shanahan; Brian Yablonski; Dave Still; David Rathke; Doug
Barr; Ernie Barnett; Frank Jimenez; Kathy Copeland; Leslie Palmer; Mike
Joyner; Mike Slayton
Cc: Nina Oviedo
Subject: Legislative action....


Legislative action for Wednesday May 8, 2002


Yucca Mountain - nuclear waste storage  (H.J.Res. 87)

Today the house voted 306 -117 in favor of H.J.Res. 87, which would
designate the site at Yucca Mountain, Nevada, for the development of a
repository for the disposal of high-level radioactive waste and spent
nuclear fuel, pursuant to the Nuclear Waste Policy Act of 1982.  Approval in
the Senate would allow the Department of Energy to submit a license
application to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

The Farm Bill - (H.R. 2646/S.1731)

Today the Senate passed the Farm Bill with a vote of 64 - 35.  The House
passed this bill on May 2, 2002, and the President is expected to sign this
bill before the end of the month.

That is a price the Lottery pays for using what is called a free service to conduct surveys and polls.  The Lottery added their own winning numbers email system through the FIRN network which is suppose to be an educational communication system.
 
The IMARCS system is used by several Lotteries, the Secretary of State, Associations, General Motors, Hotels and Resorts etc... and offers a suite of tools for direct marketing, forms processing, surveying, viral marketing, second chance to win systems, Lottery subscription services and more.
 
So, in closing, I am frustrated with my inability to close a deal with the Florida Lottery and that is my fault.  I am certain my email last night did not help my cause, but, I don't want to see this gambling site link exposed by someone else and it should go away quietly.  I have told the Lottery about this several times over the past year or so and have had no response.

Washington Post. I usually write long boring series about environmental
issues, and right now I'm working on one about Everglades restoration. I
was wondering if it would be possible to talk to you about it. I've spoken
to a bunch of your aides; David Struhs, Henry Dean, a slew of lower-ranking
people at the water district and other Florida agencies. But I'd love to
talk to you about your support for CERP, what you like about it, what (if
anything) concerns you about it, how (if at all) having two brothers in
charge of it matters, what you think about the criticism from enviros and
some federal people that the state has fought to avoid specific guarantees
for the environment, etc. I'd also like to ask you a bit about growth
management in Florida, especially in Southwest Florida, where it seems like
some of the same mistakes that led to CERP are being made all over again.

-----Original Message-----
From: Martha Pratt 
Sent: Wednesday, May 08, 2002 9:59 AM
Subject: FW: 4,300 school workers overpaid. Miami Herald 5/8/02


Posted on Wed, May. 08, 2002

4,300 school workers overpaid
Audit: Errors cost $2.1 million
BY SONJI JACOBS
sajacobs@herald.com

More than 4,300 Broward school employees -- including dozens who no longer
work for the district -- were overpaid a total of $2.1 million since July 1
because of persistent problems with a new payroll system, according to an
audit obtained by The Herald.

The problems also have left public school officials uncertain about how much
money remains in the district's coffers and may prevent them from completing
financial reports required by state and federal laws.

District officials say they are working on a plan to recover the money,
though some workers have stepped forward and admitted they were overpaid.
The plan would deduct the overpayments from paychecks and will be presented
to school board members later this month, officials said.

''Depending on the amount of overpayment, we're going to work on a payment
plan,'' said Schools Superintendent Frank Till. ``Employees don't have a
choice. We just have to be able to document the overpayment amount is
correct.''

The district has been plagued by a rash of problems since it began using the
$18 million computer payroll system on July 1.

Some employees were paid late, others weren't paid at all.

The April 4 Ernst & Young audit blames the $2.1 million in overpayments on
gaps between the actual dates of terminations, retirements and disabilities
and the time the information was logged in the computer system.

It also says many payroll and human resource personnel weren't properly
trained.

Patrick Reilly, the district's audit chief, said some of the overpayment
problems were more the result of human error than the new payroll system.

''Some employees who left the system weren't taken off payroll in a timely
way,'' Reilly said. ``That's a data entry problem, not necessarily a
software problem.''

While district officials are trying to resolve problems, the payroll
department estimates it will take about 90 minutes to explain the
overpayments and repayment schedules to each employee -- a total of 6,450
hours. The audit doesn't specify how much each employee was overpaid.

''If notices were sent to all affected employees,'' the district's response
and action plan states, ``we would be flooded with an unimaginable number of
phone calls and requests for appointments with employees to settle their
accounts.''

The memo goes on to state, ``It was suggested it might be more cost
effective to write off overpayments less than a certain amount.''

The audit also found the district has been unable to balance its key
accounts on a monthly basis for the last 10 months.

As a result, officials don't know how much money remains in the $1.4 billion
annual operating budget.

Without the reports, the district may miss deadlines for required financial
statements, according to the audit. The Annual Financial Report, for
example, is due to the Florida Department of Education in early September.
Tardy school districts can be sanctioned by the state, but DOE officials
often work with struggling districts to help them get their financial
reporting in, said Adam Shores, a state education department spokesman.

Without key accounting reports such as payroll register and labor
distribution, the district can't plan its payroll for the next fiscal year.

Those reports also help district officials generate crucial grant reports
for programs such as Title I, a federal program that pumps about $29 million
per year into the county's poorest schools. More than 52,000 Broward
students attend 83 schools that receive Title I dollars.

The district's payroll system has been mired in problems including late and
inaccurate paychecks since its implementation in July. Dozens of school bus
drivers staged a wildcat strike in November after they kept getting late
paychecks.

Teachers and other school district employees also complained about their
paystubs late last year. About 100 teachers staged a December protest at the
school district's main administrative building in Fort Lauderdale over the
problems.

John Ristow, Broward Teachers Union spokesman, said a few teachers are still
receiving late paychecks, but many more are having problems with
overpayments and automatic deductions. He said teachers still experiencing
problems are mostly new hires and those returning from leaves of absence.

''District staff does not seem very motivated to resolve these issues,''
Ristow said.

The audit report lists several ''lessons learned:'' Allowing adequate time
to transition to future new computer systems and making sure employees
understand them before the systems are put in place.

School Board member Lois Wexler said she was ''very upset'' about the
payroll problems. She said staff told her the district overpaid employees
between $300 and $400,000 during the 2000-01 school year before the new
payroll system was put in place.

''Now, in less than one year, it's over $2 million and that's definitely a
cause for alarm,'' Wexler said. ``Sometimes when the money is gone, it's
gone. I hope that's not the case here.''

-----Original Message-----
From: r s [mailto:rouxshep@hotmail.com]
Sent: Wednesday, May 08, 2002 11:19 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Circuit Judge, 14th Judicial Circuit


Dear Governor Bush:

It is with great pleasure and without reservation that I write this letter 
recommending you appoint Judge Allen Register to the position of Circuit 
Judge in the 14th Judicial Circuit.  I have had the pleasure of practicing 
under Judge Register as an prosecuting attorney assigned to County Court, 
Washington County since August of 2000.

I have found Judge Register to be intelligent, experienced, and well 
grounded.  Judge Register makes a conscientious effort to ensure that all 
parties are able to have their say in court.  He takes great pain to ensure 
that he understands the arguments, both legal and factual, in the cases that 
come before him.  Further, when issuing the opinion of the Court, Judge 
Register  is not afraid to take a stand and tell people why he is ruling the 
way he is ruling, even when it is not in their favor.

In conclusion, It is my sincere desire that you will give Judge Register 
your earnest consideration as a candidate for Circuit Judge.  Judge Register 
embodies the conservative ideology of those of us here Northwest Florida, 
and I feel if appointed he would be an asset to both you and the people of 
the 14th Judicial Circuit.

Very Truly Yours,
Rusty Shepard

-----Original Message-----
From: lb24fan [mailto:lb24fan@cfl.rr.com]
Sent: Wednesday, May 08, 2002 2:58 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Government Nanny Bill
Importance: High


 
Hello again, Jeb!
 
OK, here it is…The following content is still in the current Nanny Bill. As long as these parts are still there, I still adamantly oppose the Nanny Bill.
 
Can you please answer each of the questions below, and respond to the last reason regarding the costs of the program, and guarantee your answers?
 
 
1) S.B. 1844 mandates automatic referrals of high-risk newborns to the local Learning Gateway through the Office of Vital Statistics.
Who determines what is considered high risk? There is no parental consent required for this referral. What happens if the parent chooses not to follow up on this referral?
 
2) S.B. 1844 directs that screening processes be developed and tested to address social/emotional/behavioral indicators which could be a sign of future problems.
Will the Florida Department of Children and Families take the child away if the parent chooses to follow his own doctor's advice instead of the government's?
 
3) S.B. 1844 requires that an electronic data system be developed to track children who are screened, assessed, and referred for services.
Will mom and dad be able to remove the child from the government programs if the initial screening is done without parent's consent?
 
4) S.B. 1844 creates a huge, expensive bureaucracy, with the intent of expanding the program statewide.
The pilot project is $6 million the first year for only three counties---what will it cost taxpayers to fund this program for the whole state?
 
Thanks Jeb!
 
Lisa Butler :)
Orlando, FL
http://home.cfl.rr.com/jg24fans

-----Original Message-----
From: lb24fan [mailto:lb24fan@cfl.rr.com]

Hi Jeb!
 
Thanks for responding. I realize that the technology initiative bill that the Nanny Bill was attached to is good but the Nanny Bill needs to be detached from it before you sign it. I still stand by my firm belief that the current Nanny Bill will open up a whole new can of worms with regards to invasion of families’ privacy. Families have been doing just fine for thousands of years and this bill is completely intrusive and unnecessary, including a major drain on our tax dollars and we’re pretty fed up already that a third of our income is already going to many government agencies that we don’t care for and feel are unnecessary and where abuse is already occurring.
 
There are too many questions regarding the content of the current Nanny Bill:
 
1) S.B. 1844 mandates automatic referrals of high-risk newborns to
the local Learning Gateway through the Office of Vital Statistics.
Who determines what is considered high risk? There is no parental
consent required for this referral. What happens if the parent
chooses not to follow up on this referral?
 
2) S.B. 1844 directs that screening processes be developed and tested
to address social/emotional/behavioral indicators which could be a
sign of future problems. Will the Florida Department of Children and
Families take the child away if the parent chooses to follow his own
doctor's advice instead of the government's?
 
3) S.B. 1844 requires that an electronic data system be developed to
track children who are screened, assessed, and referred for services.
Will mom and dad be able to remove the child from the government
programs if the initial screening is done without parent's consent?
 
4) S.B. 1844 creates a huge, expensive bureaucracy, with the intent
of expanding the program statewide. The pilot project is $6 million
the first year for only three counties---what will it cost taxpayers
to fund this program for the whole state?
 
 
This really hits close to home with me, Jeb. I was just informed that one of my neighbors, also a friend, was falsely turned in to Social Services very recently and it has really messed with her head. It was one of our other neighbors, whose children play with my friend's kids, that called in the report. Because of the severity of the false accusations, a Social Services worker responded to the call within an hour and showed up at her house. He required her to "pee in a cup" because she was falsely accused of smoking marijuana. She was so humiliated. Unbeknownst to my friend, the same social worker ("a big black man" according to her kids) then went to her kids' school and interviewed and strip searched all three of her kids (the oldest is 9 or 10 years of age). THIS IS A NIGHTMARE FOR FAMILIES!!!
 
This is the closest I've come to knowing someone who's been through this and it really ticks me off that false accusations can be used to torment a decent family!! Her case is still open, pending a reverse investigation into the family who made the accusations. I told her to give my name as a character reference if needed...I feel so badly for her and her family! GOVERNMENT OFFICIALS SHOULD BE REQUIRED TO GET MUCH MORE INFORMATION BEFORE JUMPING TO STRIP SEARCHING CHILDREN AND MAKING PARENTS GIVE URINE SAMPLES!!!! This kind of business has a demoralizing impact on innocent children and their families!
 
I hope you now understand why I and so many others will continue to oppose this horrible legislation. I’m adamant about it enough that you’ll probably lose my vote in the upcoming election if you sign that Nanny Bill into law. It’s just too wide open for too many frightening repercussions to families who choose not to have the agency’s involvement.
 
I’ve supported you 100%+ and helped vote you into office, mainly because of your strong family values, which is what has made this country what it is today…the land of the free. I hope I will be able to do that again next election. I ask God to help you make the best decision for Florida families.
 
THANKS, Jeb! God Bless!
 
Lisa Butler :)
Hunter’s Creek, Orlando, FL

-----Original Message-----
From: lb24fan [mailto:lb24fan@cfl.rr.com]
Sent: Thursday, April 25, 2002 1:18 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Government Nanny Bill
Dear Governor Bush,
 
My family and I have been following the Government Nanny Bill and have just learned that Senate Majority leader John McKay slipped his Government Nanny Bill (formerly S.B. 88) into S.B. 1844 and that both the Senate and the House passed it today, not realizing that the Nanny Bill had been attached to S.B. 1844 at the last minute. Talk about DECEPTION!!! Apparently, Senator McKay will do anything to achieve his agenda and will stoop as low as possible in his efforts to deceive to make it happen. This man, and anyone like him, should be immediately removed from holding any public office where he represents American people!!
 
Here's what we know about the situation:
 
S.B. 1844 is now the vehicle to create a new government
program called Learning Gateway and will involve "developing
strategies for offering hospital visits or home visits by trained
staff to new mothers."
 
The purpose of Learning Gateway is to screen children from birth to
age 9 for "biological, environmental, and behavioral risks," and
"learning problems." Furthermore, Learning Gateway providers will
conduct "intake with families," conduct "needs/strength-based
assessments of families," and "make referrals for needed services"
and "developmental monitoring."
 
This will all be done in collaboration with the Florida Department of
Children and Family Services and numerous other big government
agencies and programs.
 
Some additional reasons why we oppose S.B. 1844:
 
1) S.B. 1844 mandates automatic referrals of high-risk newborns to
the local Learning Gateway through the Office of Vital Statistics.
Who determines what is considered high risk? There is no parental
consent required for this referral. What happens if the parent
chooses not to follow up on this referral?
 
2) S.B. 1844 directs that screening processes be developed and tested
to address social/emotional/behavioral indicators which could be a
sign of future problems. Will the Florida Department of Children and
Families take the child away if the parent chooses to follow his own
doctor's advice instead of the government's?
 
3) S.B. 1844 requires that an electronic data system be developed to
track children who are screened, assessed, and referred for services.
Will mom and dad be able to remove the child from the government
programs if the initial screening is done without parent's consent?
 
4) S.B. 1844 creates a huge, expensive bureaucracy, with the intent
of expanding the program statewide. The pilot project is $6 million
the first year for only three counties---what will it cost taxpayers
to fund this program for the whole state?
 
Governor Bush, PLEASE DO NOT SIGN THIS BILL!!! Please tell Senator John McKay to stop trampling on parental rights with intrusive, dangerous legislation that is completely anti-family in nature and opens the door for a wide range of government abuses, as well as being a major drain on taxpayers’ money. American people will NOT stand for this!!!!
 
Thanks Jeb…I hope you and your family are doing very well. And thanks for all you do for Florida residents!
 
Lisa Butler :)
Hunter’s Creek, Orlando, FL
 <http://home.cfl.rr.com/jg24fans> http://home.cfl.rr.com/jg24fans

is going on in this country and the world, that the national media focus is 
on Florida foster care.

one, but you need to get the facts out in front of these folks before the 
national media indicts you for one of Ponce De Leon's cabin boys being 
missing for over 500 years.........Rick

I believe the following is still considered confidential: 

Carlton and Lacasa have tentatively closed out everything except member projects, state employees pay, and proviso/implementing bill issues, as follows:

PECO: Senate position 

Medically needy: House/Senate position plus added money to phase in new spend down level 

nursing home reimbursement liability insurance: House position $11m 

capitalize risk pool: house position $6m 

mental health expansion: split difference at $9m 

legal needs of children: senate position, lawyers and all 

community based care lead agency funding: split difference $8m 

residential group care: senate position $17m 

TOPS: house position with some project adjustments (list not done yet) 

HR outsourcing: house position (yeah!!!!) 

rural and family lands: senate position $0 

lake jessup: house position $9m 

water projects: senate got many; house got $20m for south florida flooding 

DOI employees: Gallagher's position 


this needs to be added up -- plus the member projects not yet included, to see where our bottom line is... 

they are also spending more money on the legislature.

Notwithstanding the fact that Jeff Minder is CEO of Imarcs and that we

hyperlink

-----Original Message-----
From: Jeff Minder [mailto:JeffM@ImarcsGroup.com]
Sent: Tuesday, May 07, 2002 11:09 PM
To: King,Waymond; Jeb Bush
Subject: Business


Hi Waymond,
 
So, here is the outline I will be presenting to anyone who will listen:
 
1.  I tried to talk the Fl Lottery into using the Internet to increase
their sales.
2.  I am a CEO of a Tallahassee based company who is dedicated to the
growth of this region and this state and who has 6 other Lotteries as
clients
3.  I presented new ideas (patent pending) to the Lottery through demos
with you and David for the past 2 years
4.  You stalled me based on legal issues you said you had and I worked
with Ken hart, at your direction, to solve these issues
5.  you deployed a solution on your own (good for you if it is good for
the Lottery and the state and as long as it does not infringe on my
patents and as long as it is legal)
 
I have invested time, money, and energy into this solution (IMARCS) and
I took the time to educate you and your staff and in return you bypass
me.  I understand this approach and actually respect it...it creates
competition.  Up till now...however, I have supported you and David
consistently, that is over and we are now playing on a different field.
I went to your site today at www.fllottery.com , clicked on the bravenet
link (your survey and polling system) and was taken to an illegal
gambling site...endorsed, obviously, by the Florida Lottery since you
have it on your site. (the link actually exposes me, the lottery
consumer, to over 100 illegal gambling sites)
 
I want to be perfectly clear.  For close to a year I have told you that
your Lottery site has hyperlinks on your website that takes consumers to
www.gambling.com.  You have not responded to these emails or phone
calls...you have taken no measures to stop it and you have even expand
on it.  I have no other option than to make sure that people who will
take responsibility see this.  I want only the best for the Lottery and
for the state.  You have absolutely disregarded my consultation and
advice.  The federal wire act that is being redefined will charge the
State of Florida with a violation for exposing (and driving) consumers
to off-shore gambling sites.  If I didn't knpw better I would wonder if
these overseas gambling sites are paying you for this exposure.
 
Jeff Minder
CEO
ImarcsGroup.com
805 N. Gadsen St.
Tallahassee, Fl 32303
850.222.6772

PLEASE SEE COPY BELOW 

Subj: My school's Sept. 11 Memorial Garden 
Date: 5/3/02 9:26:52 PM Eastern Daylight Time 
From: Cheetahs41 
To: jeb@jeb.org 



Dear Governor Bush: 

My school is dedicating a memorial garden for the victims of September 11 on Friday, May 10, 2001, at 8:30 a.m.  I got to thinking and I thought it would be nice if I invited you to come.  Our art teacher, Mrs. Boni Meddock, designed it and the students and teachers participated in the making of it.  Each of us put a piece of glass into an American flag mosaic and our fifth graders made stepping stone mosaics.  Some students even competed by writing an essay or four verse poem about September 11, why we're proud of our country, or we could make up our own topic about the USA.  The winners, one person from each classroom, (I won for my class!) got to plant something in the memorial garden.  We also get to be at the dedication ceremony!  We're even trying to get people from television stations  to come too! 

I think that my school would appreciate it if you and Mrs. Bush could come.  I know this is short notice, but I thought I would invite you anyway.  If you need to reach Mrs. Meddock, her e-mail address is bmeddock@mail.volusia.k12.fl.us. Thanks for your time Governor Bush! Good luck in the election! 

Sincerely, 

Shayna Hart 
Fourth Grader at Forest Lake Elementary School 
1600 Doyle Rd. 
Deltona, FL 32725

From: J_Agwunobi@doh.state.fl.us [mailto:J_Agwunobi@doh.state.fl.us]
Sent: Thursday, May 09, 2002 12:53 AM
To: Bonita_Sorensen@doh.state.fl.us; Steven_Wiersma@doh.state.fl.us; Landis_Crockett@doh.state.fl.us; Jean_Malecki@doh.state.fl.us; David_Johnson@doh.state.fl.us; Sharon_Heber@doh.state.fl.us

I will respond on behalf of DOH but I need a few days to confer. 
No one is to authorize unless I say so. 

Please answer these questions for me. 
Am I correct in my assumption that that the building is currently under a formal indefinite public health quarantine? 
Was the quarantine signed by Jean Malecki? Did we seek a court order or did we use quarantine powers delegated by me? 
This study could potentially give us all valuable public health knowledge for the future? 
Can DOH be formally involved in the study and credited in some way(e.g. our labs, epi, environmental health etc.)? 
Is there a long term plan to clean and reoccupy? 
Who owns the building? 

Thank you for keeping me in the loop. 
John

Subject: Follow-up to phone call on AMI Building 


Marc - 
        Here is the information you asked me to send you and Steve Wiersma. 
It is lifted from a briefing document I had prepared for internal use.  By 
the way, all we are asking at this point is your agreement in principle to 
allow us to pursue this, conditional on your final approval after seeing a 
detailed protocol. 
        I hope this is helpful 
Regards, 
- Ed Kilbourne 
Edwin M. Kilbourne, MD 
Associate Administrator (Toxic Substances & Public Health) 
Agency for Toxic Substances & Disease Registry 
1600 Clifton Rd, MS - E28 
Atlanta, GA 30333 
Tel. +1-404-498-0004  eFAX +1-202-318-7668 
-------- 
Briefing Document v 1.1 
May 7, 2002 


Summary Description: Proposed Study of Anthrax Spore Dispersion 
 in the Indoor Environment of the AMI Building in Florida 
RATIONALE 
        Environmental sampling during the public health response to the 
anthrax attacks of 2001 was done principally with the aim of ascertaining 
the presence or absence of anthrax contamination.  Accordingly, samples were 
taken only where the suspicion of contamination was the highest. 
Laboratories analyzing these samples generally reported results as either 
positive or negative, indicating the presence or absence of anthrax but not 
the numbers of spores or colony forming units (CFU). 
        It is now clear that surface contamination persists in affected 
facilities and that resuspension of anthrax spores can occur, posing a 
potentially lethal health risk.  However, quantifying this risk is 
problematic, in part because of the very few quantitative data we have on 
anthrax contamination and the lack of systematic, representative sampling in 
contaminated facilities.  
        The study we propose is an important initial step to better 
characterize how the weaponized anthrax spores dispersed and became 
distributed in the environment. 

METHODS 
        We propose to travel a team of 40-hour Hazwopper-trained ATSDR, 
NIOSH, NCEH, NCID, and FBI staff to AMI during June 7-18, 2002. 
Investigators will enter the building first to get baseline air samples in 
the heavily contaminated mail room and the less contaminated photo library. 
Then surfaces will be sampled according to a pre-determined pattern and 
using a uniform technique.  (The exact method will be chosen based on 
sampling method sensitivity studies currently underway in the NCID 
microbiology laboratories.)  The samples will be quantified in the 
laboratory in terms of spores per square cm of surface.  Both floors and 
elevated surfaces (shelves & tabletops) will be sampled.  Deviation from a 
precise absolutely regular grid may occur in the hallways, where we expect 
foot traffic to have had a heavy influence on spore concentrations.  In 
areas where nearby samples show highly disparate values, a second stage of 
samples may be taken, involving a second series of  building entries during 
the study period.  In addition, air sampling will continue during the 
surface sampling activity, in order to detect any resuspension of spores 
that our activity generates.  
        We are currently securing permission for this activity.  Agencies 
contacted so far who are involved with the site have expressed agreement in 
principle, pending review of an expanded protocol 

ANTICIPATED FINDINGS 
*       Accurate graphical representation of interpolated spore 
concentrations 
*       Rate(s) of fall-off in spore concentrations as one travels away from 
heavy contamination 
*       An approximate representation of how corridor foot traffic affected 
spore distribution 
*       Approximate extent of surface contamination by the airborne route 
*       Estimate of airborne spore exposures resulting from disturbing 
settled spores 
*       Findings will also serve as an important point of comparison for 
further studies of airborne spread, which will likely use simulants 
(simulated spores). 

CONCLUSION 
        In combination with laboratory studies estimating the probability of 
illness with various doses of spores, this study and others like it will 
help estimate the likelihood of significant human exposure from residual 
surface spores following a primary anthrax contamination event.

greater participation of minority contractors, per One Florida, at the 
district, which is an ancillary, yet important, part of the overall plan to 
save the district 1 & 1/2 % to 3% saving in your O&M costs as we discussed.

Certainly would like to determine if this partnership approach can be as 
efficient in getting to the end game as would be a more traditional process.

Romerio Perkins

-----Original Message-----
From: Martha Pratt <martha@jeb.org>
Sent: Thu May 09 08:53:02 2002
Subject: 90-year-old man earns GED /AP

90-year-old man earns GED 
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. (AP) _ Harry Patrinelli feared if he didn't keep his mind sharp, he would end up in a rocking chair, one step from the grave. 
So the 90-year-old man went back to school to earn his GED and participated in a graduation ceremony Tuesday night at Daytona Beach Community College. 
Patrinelli actually graduated from high school back in 1930 in Massachusetts, and went to college to become an industrial engineer. He worked for a plastics factory that made pink flamingo yard decorations. 
But Patrinelli lost his diploma when he retired to Florida in 1974 and thought the $100 replacement fee was too expensive. He decided to go for a GED in 2000 because he needed a diploma to take a real estate course. 
Patrinelli took the classes for eight months, alongside classmates young enough to be his great-grandchildren. 
``It was crazy at first because some of the kids were out of this world, really,'' said Patrinelli, who complained that some students slept in class. 
He passed the test on his first attempt, almost a year ago. 
Patrinelli recently finished the real estate course, too, but has yet to pass the licensing exam. He was sidelined for a couple of months this spring after being injured in a car accident.

agricultural shipments.  When the ag. shipment is FOB the Fla. or U.S. port, 
our bank(s) cut a check and prepay the ag. producer.      We're focusing 
mainly on Florida agriculture.  Charlie Bronson and his people, and Bob 
Crawford, have been very helpful as we, in turn, can help producers.

private venture capital and Congressional  R & D appropriations funding (via 
DoD).  Bill Young and his people, and other Members of the Fla. Cong. 
Delegation being  very nonpartisan in their support.  

NorthrupGrumman coming next week to meet with us re: a sensing device which 
makes distinctions within and between naturally occuring radiation.  And can 
do so from a remote location, including thru a wall.  The other project is a 
blood based diagnostic bio marker for Traumatic Brain Injury.  A UF Brain

--------------
May 8, 11:05 PM

Schools spurn budget increase

$1.1 billion for education insufficient, DiPatri says

By Zenaida A. Gonzalez
FLORIDA TODAY

SATELLITE BEACH -- Brevard Public Schools Superintendent Richard DiPatri
and
14 other superintendents throughout Florida held simultaneous news
conferences Wednesday to say the $1.1 billion education budget state
legislators are expected to approve Friday, isn't nearly enough.

"We want to make it clear," DiPatri said. "This is not an attack on the
governor or legislators. . . . We're just trying to inform our community
so
they know that when they read the newspaper and see a 9.1 percent
increase
in the budget, it's really not a 9.1 percent. It's a 1.7 percent
increase."
Student growth, the reinstatement of budget cuts made this year and the
cost
of health care and insurance eat up most of the $1 billion, leaving$201
million to be divided among 67 districts, DiPatri said. That is about
1.7
percent.
Rep. Bob Allen, R-Merritt Island, disagreed and was irritated by the
school
district conferences.
"I get a little fed up with school boards meeting after every increase
and
saying it's not enough," Allen said. "They need to make the point to
their
constituents, we are giving the max we can get out of this budget,
unless
the citizens of Florida want us to raise taxes or stop delivering care
to
the poor and needy."
Allen also criticized Brevard for its climbing health care costs.
"That was a management decision. . . . It might have been a good choice
for
some health needs, but it costs more money."
The district and others in the care costs, which all districts have been
facing over the past three years. Private industry is facing a similar
climb.
Laurie Davie, a parent of students at Surfside Elementary School and
DeLaura
Middle School in Satellite Beach, said she was disappointed schools
would be
short-changed again.
"Health care is costing more everywhere, and if districts are expected
to
provide it, the state should give us an adequate amount to cover that
expense in addition to money for the classroom," Davie said.
Maggie Roller, a parent of a sixth-grader at Surfside, said she was
frustrated.
"I keep hearing (governor) Jeb on television saying that education is
our
No. 1 priority," Roller said. "I'd like to see him put the money where
his
mouth is."
She also took a shot at legislators.
"I understand what they're doing in Tallahassee," Roller said. "They
want to
get re-elected, and they aren't going to be elected if they raise
taxes."
DiPatri said it was unlikely that the legislators would change their
minds
at this point but wanted to let parents know that if no more money is
set
aside for education, the district could be laying off 50 teachers and
increasing class sizes. There's also a possibility other programs from
athletics to the arts could be reduced or eliminated.
Sally Davis, a teacher at Surfside, said she was worried.
"It's scary," Davis said. "Class size is really important to me because
it
impacts my daily work. The smaller the class size, the better I am able
to
get to each student and ensure they are learning what they need to know
to
succeed."

Florida Today reporter Paige St. John contributed to this report.


From:	Jeb Bush
Sent:	Thursday, May 9, 2002 1:09 PM
