-----Original Message-----
From: Tracey Rodney <poncho815@yahoo.com>
To: Jeb Bush <jeb@jeb.org>; peter colt <coltpeter@hotmail.com>
Sent: Thu May 09 10:29:48 2002
Subject: Proposed Changes to Redevelopment F.S. 163

May 9, 2002

Dear Governor Bush,

There is a bill awaiting your signature that I ask you,
quite simply, not to sign. I don’t know what the actual
bill number is but it makes sweeping changes to F.S.
Chapter 163, which deals with redevelopment and the
standards for a government finding of blight, the first
step in establishing the use of eminent domain to take an
individual’s private property. 

Government should do nothing that eases its ability to
invoke eminent domain…yet that is exactly what the
Legislature has done by removing a standard from the
existing legislation. With this new bill before you no
longer must an area be legally considered as being a menace
to public health, safety, morals or welfare in its present
condition or use. That criterion has been dropped for much
looser standards having to do with government statistics.
As I recall from both my undergrad and graduate college
statistic courses, depending upon how one frames the
question, statistics can be made to support just about
anything. Certainly such a fluid standard is less than
adequate when applied to private property rights.

It’s bad enough that there has been absolutely no oversight
or accountability for the 100+ redevelopment areas
throughout the state. It’s bad enough that under the
current law, the entire city of New Port Richey was
declared blighted, including the very wealthy waterfront
neighborhoods.

It’s bad enough that the existing statute doesn’t specify
certain established criteria, i.e. blight as an area in
which a substantial number of slum or deteriorating
structures exist. Minus any legal standard in F.S. 163 for
the term “substantial” the city of Daytona Beach, just last
summer, declared an area blighted claiming only 14% of the
structures substandard met the definition of “substantial”.
The dictionary defines substantial as being of considerable
size or amount, very large, a great deal. 14% means 86% was
standard, good or excellent. It’s obvious which of those
numbers better fits the dictionary definition, yet our
current law allowed this. The proposed revision before you
is even more flexible. Because of the vagueness of the
current law, 61 homeowners are now subject to eminent
domain for any project the city deems worthy, whether it’s
a parking lot for a motel, a Walgreen’s or a Publix. Would
you want to lose your home to a project like that?
Shouldn’t state government’s use of taking one’s property
reflect the U.S. Constitution’s – that of taking for a
public purpose? 

The Illinois Supreme Court recently struck down a local
authority’s taking of a recycling plant’s property to add
on to a racetrack’s parking lot. The court said the use of
eminent domain in economic development cases should be
closely scrutinized, “that using the power of government
for purely private purposes to allow one property owner to
avoid the open real-estate market, thus maximizing
corporate profits, is a misuse of the power entrusted by
the public.” Even Florida statute recognizes that the value
of a property is arrived at only when there is an exchange
between a willing buyer and a willing seller. Any “duress”
in the exchange devalues the property. And “negotiating”
under the threat of eminent domain definitely qualifies
as”duress” under the law.
    
Given that a person’s home is the largest single investment
for the greatest majority of our population, for government
to deny the individual the right to realize the most from
their investment is reprehensible. Yet our Republican
legislature has done just that.

And that is the worst part of the proposed changes in the
redevelopment statute. It is the Republican Florida
Legislature has done this! One of my basic understandings
of my own party is its stance on private property rights.
Rights that have been abused through several pieces of
Federal legislation, extreme environmental readings of the
law coming first to mind. Yet the Republican legislature
has passed a bill that deeply undercuts an individual’s
right to their own property by easing the restrictions
against government’s ability to take it.

Additionally, the legislature has done this in the face of
courts all across this country sending a strong message
concerning the clash of eminent domain and private property
that government has gone too far. Why? Because local
governments nationwide are using eminent domain, not to
take a person’s property for public use but for private
use. Local governments have become the tool for private
developers to avoid the open real estate market in
acquiring property for purely private, economic purposes.
In effect, local governments are picking and choosing
economic winners and losers. It’s not about economic
development. It’s about whose economic development and the
smaller property owner is losing out to the larger,
corporate property owner. Or the property owner with the
most expensive lobbyist.

I realize I am not part of any organized group, like
motorcyclists. Nor am I part of any business lobbying
effort, like billboard owners. But, considering your record
in these two areas, surely a person’s right to his/her
property counts as greatly as the motorcyclist’s right to
ride helmetless or the billboard owner’s right to realize
the value of his/her business investment.

I realize I am not a developer, the big business interests
that Republicans are always accused of being biased
towards. But I thought our concern was for a fair playing
field, with minimal government interference, allowing
business to thrive; not for setting up the field in such a
way that big business can actually steal from the small
businessperson. That’s what the changes to F.S. Chapter 163
will do. Rather than level the playing field these changes
will bulldoze the small property owner right off the field.

Think about it. One of the criteria for blighted conditions
currently, is a “diversity of ownership” in the defined
area. I think “diversity of ownership” is also known as
realizing a major part of the American Dream... that of a
person owning his/her own home. Did you know that a greater
percentage of people own their homes in America than in any
other country in the world! Did you know that Florida law
requires a 12-person jury for only two kinds of trail?
Murder and eminent domain. That of taking a person’s life
or taking a person’s property.

I told you what I was not. What I have been is an elected
municipal. I have voted to establish a redevelopment area
based on a survey showing the proposed area as having 48%
of its structures deteriorating, the highest crime stats in
the city, lack of curbs and sidewalks in the majority of
the area as well as substandard lot sizes given current
drainage, stormwater and setback criteria. I have voted to
invoke eminent domain against a holdout property owner for
a public parking garage and public areas along the beach.
These were not easy decisions, as I had 

concerns then over the current vagueness in the statutes.
But, compared to the greater picture, the situations were
extreme enough to warrant my support. I cannot imagine
decreasing those standards even more.

What I am is one small voice. A single citizen. And I am
begging you not to sign this bill. Please.

I recall several times when, after hearing public comment
on an issue, it would be the words of a single citizen that
made more sense than staff, consultants, experts and
professionals. Why? Because the single citizen, oftentimes,
was closer to feeling the possible effect of a proposed law
than everyone else involved in making that law. I pray that
is the case here. 

Thank you.

Sincerely, 
Tracey Remark
815 N. Oleander Ave.
Daytona Beach, Fl. 32118
386-248-2038




=====
As ever,
Tracey & Rodney
H(904)248-0100
Fax (904)248-2038
God bless

From:	Edward Ellegood <fsri-1@juno.com>
Sent:	Thursday, May 9, 2002 2:38 PM
To:	florida@space.com
Subject:	GRANTS AWARDED FOR FLORIDA SPACE RESEARCH/EDUCATION PROJECTS
Attachments:	Round-Five news release.doc

 
 
 
 GRANTS AWARDED FOR FLORIDA SPACE RESEARCH/EDUCATION PROJECTS

         CAPE CANAVERAL SPACEPORT (May 9, 2002) -- The NASA-sponsored Florida Space Grant Consortium (FSGC) at the University of Central Florida, and the Florida Space Research Institute (FSRI) today announced the selection of sixteen space research and education projects to receive over $360,000 in grant awards.  The grants will combine federal and state funds for projects supporting space-related commercial, military and NASA priorities in Florida.  

        “Our efforts to expand Florida’s academic involvement in space research and technology development are bearing fruit with the recent announcement of major new centers supported by NASA and the National Science Foundation,” said Florida Lt. Governor Frank Brogan.  “This latest round of state grant awards will add to the momentum we have established in Florida, and promote our vision for a statewide, multi-disciplinary aerospace research and education program.”  

        The approved research and education projects will involve 10 different universities and colleges, including Brevard Community College; Embry Riddle Aeronautical University; Florida A&M University; Florida Gulf Coast University; Florida Institute of Technology; Florida State University; Nova Southeastern University; University of Central Florida; University of Florida; and the University of Miami.  Other recipients include the Astronauts Memorial Foundation and the Hubbs Sea World Research Institute.  The projects cover a variety of topics, including spaceport technologies, satellite remote sensing, aerospace education and workforce training, and launch vehicle propulsion systems.  

        Also funded by FSGC under the same joint solicitation were eleven summer research projects for undergraduate students.  Through this program, students from the Florida Institute of Technology, Florida State University, University of Central Florida, and the University of Florida will each receive $3,000 to conduct space-related research projects in cooperation with faculty mentors.

        With this latest round of awards, the joint grant program has funded over $1.3 million since 2000 for university and community college space projects, many of them in partnership with industry.  A listing of the grant projects is attached.  A comprehensive listing of all projects supported since 2000 is posted on FSRI’s website at www.fsri.org/grants.html.

        FSRI is an institute established by Governor Jeb Bush and Florida’s Legislature to stimulate the state’s space industry diversification through academic support to space research and technology programs.  FSGC, hosted at the University of Central Florida, is part of a nationwide NASA-sponsored network of 52 academic consortia responsible for supporting space research and education projects.

#   #   #

From:	Hovanetz, Christy <HovaneC@mail.doe.state.fl.us>
Sent:	Thursday, May 9, 2002 3:20 PM
Subject:	Just Read, Florida! Update 5-9-02


We would like to thank those districts who attended the Reading First
pre-application workshop on May 8, 2002.  Please feel free to contact us at
the Just Read, Florida! Office; we look forward to working with you on this
new and exciting reading initiative!  

The University of Oregon has an outstanding website, "BIG IDEAS in Beginning
Reading" that we would like to share with you.  The content of the site
includes information on the five componenets; assessments, including DIBELS;
instruction, including the organizing principles and scientific learning
principles; and logistics.  The link is: http://reading.uoregon.edu/.

Florida's Reading First grant proposal to the United States Department of
Education is available on the Just Read, Florida! website at
www.myflorida.com.  Please keep in mind that the Reading First grant
application from Florida to USDE is a draft and content is subject to change
based on expert federal review panel input.  Also on the Just Read, Florida!
website is a copy of the DRAFT Reading Program Specifications and the DRAFT
Guidance for LEA applications to the state.  Pending federal approval of
Florida's state application, LEA applications will be made available.

We, at the Just Read, Florida! Office, will be providing a series of regular
updates to you regarding Governor Bush's Just Read, Florida! Reading
Initiative and the federal Reading First grants.  We encourage you to share
this information with others in your district.  If you would like
individuals added to this e-mail distribution list please have them reply to
this e-mail.

Just Read, Florida! Office
Florida Board of Education
325 West Gaines Street, Suite 1402
Tallahassee, Florida 32399
Phone: 850-921-9969
Fax: 850-487-7998

-----Original Message-----
From: Turbeville, Greg [mailto:Greg.Turbeville@LASPBS.STATE.FL.US] 
Sent: Thursday, May 09, 2002 3:35 PM
To: 'lb24fan@cfl.rr.com'
Subject: RE: Learning Gateway
 
 
 
The Governor forwarded your e-mail message to me, so that I may respond to your specific questions about parental involvement and the fiscal impact of the bill.
 
Thank you for your questions regarding the Learning Gateway bill.  As you may know, the bill is a priority of the Senate and was attached to the Centers of Excellence bill that the Governor proposed in his State of the State speech.  
 
As the Governor noted, the Senate’s proposal has been altered greatly in its latest version.  I have attached the Governor’s veto message from last year’s bill that the Governor vetoed.  I have also attached a copy of the bill that passed this year in order to provide some context for the changes that were made to accommodate the Governor’s concerns.  First, parental consent is required and guaranteed for initial contact and referrals.  Second, continued parental involvement is ensured in the bill as they are part of the steering committee, which will administer and approve the demonstration programs.  Finally, while the Legislature’s budget negotiations are ongoing, the level of funding for the program at this time is about $2.6 million, less than half of what was requested last year.
 
I know that the Governor appreciates your concerns on this issue.  If you have further questions, please let me know and I will attempt to answer them.  Thanks again.
 
Greg Turbeville
Policy Director
 
 
 
 
 
-----Original Message-----
From: lb24fan [mailto:lb24fan@cfl.rr.com]
Sent: Wednesday, May 08, 2002 2:58 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Government Nanny Bill
Importance: High
Hello again, Jeb!
 
OK, here it is…The following content is still in the current Nanny Bill. As long as these parts are still there, I still adamantly oppose the Nanny Bill.
 
Can you please answer each of the questions below, and respond to the last reason regarding the costs of the program, and guarantee your answers?
 
 
1) S.B. 1844 mandates automatic referrals of high-risk newborns to the local Learning Gateway through the Office of Vital Statistics.
Who determines what is considered high risk? There is no parental consent required for this referral. What happens if the parent chooses not to follow up on this referral?
 
2) S.B. 1844 directs that screening processes be developed and tested to address social/emotional/behavioral indicators which could be a sign of future problems.
Will the Florida Department of Children and Families take the child away if the parent chooses to follow his own doctor's advice instead of the government's?
 
3) S.B. 1844 requires that an electronic data system be developed to track children who are screened, assessed, and referred for services.
Will mom and dad be able to remove the child from the government programs if the initial screening is done without parent's consent?
 
4) S.B. 1844 creates a huge, expensive bureaucracy, with the intent of expanding the program statewide.
The pilot project is $6 million the first year for only three counties---what will it cost taxpayers to fund this program for the whole state?
 
Thanks Jeb!
 
Lisa Butler :)
Orlando, FL
http://home.cfl.rr.com/jg24fans

Hi Jeb!
 
Thanks for responding. I realize that the technology initiative bill that the Nanny Bill was attached to is good but the Nanny Bill needs to be detached from it before you sign it. I still stand by my firm belief that the current Nanny Bill will open up a whole new can of worms with regards to invasion of families’ privacy. Families have been doing just fine for thousands of years and this bill is completely intrusive and unnecessary, including a major drain on our tax dollars and we’re pretty fed up already that a third of our income is already going to many government agencies that we don’t care for and feel are unnecessary and where abuse is already occurring.
 
There are too many questions regarding the content of the current Nanny Bill:
 
1) S.B. 1844 mandates automatic referrals of high-risk newborns to
the local Learning Gateway through the Office of Vital Statistics.
Who determines what is considered high risk? There is no parental
consent required for this referral. What happens if the parent
chooses not to follow up on this referral?
 
2) S.B. 1844 directs that screening processes be developed and tested
to address social/emotional/behavioral indicators which could be a
sign of future problems. Will the Florida Department of Children and
Families take the child away if the parent chooses to follow his own
doctor's advice instead of the government's?
 
3) S.B. 1844 requires that an electronic data system be developed to
track children who are screened, assessed, and referred for services.
Will mom and dad be able to remove the child from the government
programs if the initial screening is done without parent's consent?
 
4) S.B. 1844 creates a huge, expensive bureaucracy, with the intent
of expanding the program statewide. The pilot project is $6 million
the first year for only three counties---what will it cost taxpayers
to fund this program for the whole state?
 
 
This really hits close to home with me, Jeb. I was just informed that one of my neighbors, also a friend, was falsely turned in to Social Services very recently and it has really messed with her head. It was one of our other neighbors, whose children play with my friend's kids, that called in the report. Because of the severity of the false accusations, a Social Services worker responded to the call within an hour and showed up at her house. He required her to "pee in a cup" because she was falsely accused of smoking marijuana. She was so humiliated. Unbeknownst to my friend, the same social worker ("a big black man" according to her kids) then went to her kids' school and interviewed and strip searched all three of her kids (the oldest is 9 or 10 years of age). THIS IS A NIGHTMARE FOR FAMILIES!!!
 
This is the closest I've come to knowing someone who's been through this and it really ticks me off that false accusations can be used to torment a decent family!! Her case is still open, pending a reverse investigation into the family who made the accusations. I told her to give my name as a character reference if needed...I feel so badly for her and her family! GOVERNMENT OFFICIALS SHOULD BE REQUIRED TO GET MUCH MORE INFORMATION BEFORE JUMPING TO STRIP SEARCHING CHILDREN AND MAKING PARENTS GIVE URINE SAMPLES!!!! This kind of business has a demoralizing impact on innocent children and their families!
 
I hope you now understand why I and so many others will continue to oppose this horrible legislation. I’m adamant about it enough that you’ll probably lose my vote in the upcoming election if you sign that Nanny Bill into law. It’s just too wide open for too many frightening repercussions to families who choose not to have the agency’s involvement.
 
I’ve supported you 100%+ and helped vote you into office, mainly because of your strong family values, which is what has made this country what it is today…the land of the free. I hope I will be able to do that again next election. I ask God to help you make the best decision for Florida families.
 
THANKS, Jeb! God Bless!
 
Lisa Butler :)

-----Original Message-----
From: lb24fan [mailto:lb24fan@cfl.rr.com]
Sent: Thursday, April 25, 2002 1:18 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Government Nanny Bill
Dear Governor Bush,
 
My family and I have been following the Government Nanny Bill and have just learned that Senate Majority leader John McKay slipped his Government Nanny Bill (formerly S.B. 88) into S.B. 1844 and that both the Senate and the House passed it today, not realizing that the Nanny Bill had been attached to S.B. 1844 at the last minute. Talk about DECEPTION!!! Apparently, Senator McKay will do anything to achieve his agenda and will stoop as low as possible in his efforts to deceive to make it happen. This man, and anyone like him, should be immediately removed from holding any public office where he represents American people!!
 
Here's what we know about the situation:
 
S.B. 1844 is now the vehicle to create a new government
program called Learning Gateway and will involve "developing
strategies for offering hospital visits or home visits by trained
staff to new mothers."
 
The purpose of Learning Gateway is to screen children from birth to
age 9 for "biological, environmental, and behavioral risks," and
"learning problems." Furthermore, Learning Gateway providers will
conduct "intake with families," conduct "needs/strength-based
assessments of families," and "make referrals for needed services"
and "developmental monitoring."
 
This will all be done in collaboration with the Florida Department of
Children and Family Services and numerous other big government
agencies and programs.
 
Some additional reasons why we oppose S.B. 1844:
 
1) S.B. 1844 mandates automatic referrals of high-risk newborns to
the local Learning Gateway through the Office of Vital Statistics.
Who determines what is considered high risk? There is no parental
consent required for this referral. What happens if the parent
chooses not to follow up on this referral?
 
2) S.B. 1844 directs that screening processes be developed and tested
to address social/emotional/behavioral indicators which could be a
sign of future problems. Will the Florida Department of Children and
Families take the child away if the parent chooses to follow his own
doctor's advice instead of the government's?
 
3) S.B. 1844 requires that an electronic data system be developed to
track children who are screened, assessed, and referred for services.
Will mom and dad be able to remove the child from the government
programs if the initial screening is done without parent's consent?
 
4) S.B. 1844 creates a huge, expensive bureaucracy, with the intent
of expanding the program statewide. The pilot project is $6 million
the first year for only three counties---what will it cost taxpayers
to fund this program for the whole state?
 
Governor Bush, PLEASE DO NOT SIGN THIS BILL!!! Please tell Senator John McKay to stop trampling on parental rights with intrusive, dangerous legislation that is completely anti-family in nature and opens the door for a wide range of government abuses, as well as being a major drain on taxpayers’ money. American people will NOT stand for this!!!!
 
Thanks Jeb…I hope you and your family are doing very well. And thanks for all you do for Florida residents!
 
Lisa Butler :)
Hunter’s Creek, Orlando, FL
 <http://home.cfl.rr.com/jg24fans> http://home.cfl.rr.com/jg24fans

-----Original Message-----
From: Fritz Steiger [mailto:fsteiger@ceoamerica.org]
Sent: Thursday, May 09, 2002 2:29 PM
To: Fritz S.. Steiger
Subject: Resignation Announcement 1



A Joint Announcement from:

Fritz S. Steiger
President & CEO
Children First America 
And 
Peter Flanigan
Chairman of the Board of Directors
Children First America

Thursday, May 9, 2002

Fritz S. Steiger

Today I announce that effective September 1, 2002, I will resign my position as President and CEO of Children First America.

It is with much excitement, enthusiasm, joy, and sadness that I make this news known to my staff, board, colleagues, supporters, and friends. This decision has been made in the best interest of my family after much discussion, consideration, and prayer with my wife, Martha. 


After spending the last twelve years in the school choice arena and the last twenty years in public and political affairs, the time has come for me to enter the private sector and pursue some entrepreneurial dreams that will allow me to spend more time with my family. 


In making this announcement, I would like to thank my excellent staff, dedicated board of directors, generous donors, and faithful friends, for the tremendous support they have given me over the years. Most importantly, I would like to thank God for allowing me the privilege to work with such wonderful people in helping to achieve equal educational opportunities for all children in the United States of America, a goal in which I know we will eventually prevail.

Please know that I will continue to be involved in a consulting capacity once we find a successor, as well as continuing to serve on the Board of Directors.


Thank you for your friendship and support. 
Peter Flanigan

Fritz Steiger, the President of Children First America, has informed the Board of Directors of his wish to resign as of September 1, 2002. 

No one has done more to further the cause of educational choice for all of America's children than Fritz Steiger. Under his leadership for more than a decade, Children First has grown to a nationwide organization, sponsoring private voucher programs throughout the country and leading the effort to provide publicly funded vouchers wherever the governmental climate is supportive. As a result of Children First America's efforts, over 100,000 children have been given the opportunity to attend schools that their parents think best for them through nearly 100 private voucher programs. 

Fortunately, Mr. Steiger will continue to help Children First by acting as a consultant and a member of its Board after September 1st. His experience and wisdom will help to maintain the momentum he has created in the school choice movement. 

Everyone connected with Children First - the Board, the Staff, and all its supporters - owe Fritz a debt of gratitude for his extraordinary leadership. His successor will find a high performance organization in place to carry on the work. While he will be sorely missed, all wish Fritz Godspeed and good luck in his new career.

-----Original Message-----

Subject: Marti Garlow-Lieb book

Governor --

I think we can help her, though a preface would be a little much.  What
about a letter along these lines:

***

I like big ideas, and "Resurrection of America!" is full of them.  Marti
Garlow-Lieb has a vision for revitalizing our communities by focusing on our
most precious resource -- our children -- and inspiring them to become civic
leaders of tomorrow.

But "Resurrection of America!" is not just theoretical.  Through her
fouiding of her H.E.M. Club Program in Pensacola, Marti has put a lot of her
ideas into practice, and the results and stories are well worth reading.  It
takes conviction to translate ideas into action that impacts a community,
and Marti's enourmous conviction and dedication are inspiring.

As America takes an extended look at itself following the tragic events of
September 11, we have discovered much to love about out country, and much we
can do to make it even better.  "Resurrection of America!" illustrates how
love and hard work can together change lives for the better.

****

Does this sound like a good way to go, sir?

-- Mark

 
Mark Busse
Chief Speechwriter

From:	Jeb Bush
Sent:	Thursday, May 9, 2002 6:02 PM

From: theresa.danzey@unitedvanlines.com <theresa.danzey@unitedvanlines.com>

Subject: RE: Graduation Diploma fup

Yes Sir he has more than enough credits for  college. I think he has 2 or 3 credits more than required. Also he was finally tested this past time like his IEP required in a room away from others with a teacher in there to help if needed. We thought this had been done in the other testing times. He also told us last night that several of his peers that have baseball scholarships won’t get their scholarships if they don’t have a graduation diploma. They will not accept a certificate of completion.  They have been advised to go to shaw(another school) and get their GED. The colleges will accept this. I’m really sorry to bother you with all this  but, these are good kids that have done everything ask of them. Just so you know my son Andrew goes to Bay High School. Thank you for answering back I know you are a very busy person.
Unless you have a child in this situation you don’t realize its happening or at least we didn’t.
Theresa

Whatever information you can give me would be greatly appreciated. 
 
Jeb Bush

-----Original Message-----
From: theresa.danzey@unitedvanlines.com [mailto:theresa.danzey@unitedvanlines.com]
Sent: Tuesday, May 07, 2002 4:06 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: ltgovftb@aol.com
Subject: Graduation Diploma
Dear Governor Bush,
My name is Theresa Danzey, and it the last name sounds familiar it is because my husband is Ron Danzey, School Board Member in Bay County.  I have a situation I would like to share with you concerning my son Andrew.
 
First of all, I agree and support testing like the HSCT and FCAT, however this is what has happened in my family.  Andrew is a LD student and was identified as such in and elementary school 10 years ago.  Andrew is about to complete High School and has done everything he was supposed to do.  He made A’s, B’s, C’s and one or two D’s through out his high school years. His attendance has been good and his classroom work has been good.  Our situation is that he has taken the HSCT for the 4th time.  He has passed the math portion, but has fell a few points from passing the language portion. (This is his LD area) I do not feel it is fair for a student who had accomplished everything that has been asked of him to not be allowed a graduation diploma. A certificate of completion does not amply provide or state his accomplishments.  There must be another option for All students who do not test well or have learning disabilities or just learn a different way.
 
This situation has really broken my heart, because I have watched him work hard for the last 4 years and now it apparent that it is all in vain because of ONE test given; instead of looking at the whole child.  Is there anything you can do to help my son?
 
I hope that you and others with our children at heart can take another look at options that will help my son and those like him.
 
Thank you so much for all you do and  for taking time to listen to my concern!
Theresa

The Investigators: Financial Dealings Of The United Teachers Of Dade
UTD President Angered By Questions
Updated: 12:58 p.m. EDT May 8, 2002

MIAMI --   <http://images.ibsys.com/2001/0510/765073.jpg> Closely guarded financial information about the United Teachers of Dade has been uncovered by the Channel 10 Investigators -- information about debt, loans and the home where UTD President Pat Tornillo lives. 

UNRUH: We've obtained UTD's 1999-2000 financial statements prepared by Grant Thornton accountants detailing the financial affairs of the state's largest teacher's union. We've also been tracking UTD's financial disclosure filings with the state of Florida and the financial picture painted by those documents appears to raise lots more questions than answers. A three-bedroom, three-bath home on Brickell Avenue is owned by the United Teachers of Dade. According to county property records, it's worth one million dollars. It's also the house that UTD president Pat Tornillo calls home -- something that surprised a number of union members. 


DR. SANRA MODEL, TEACHER AT KENWOOD ELEMENTARY: "No, I didn't know that." 


UNRUH: you had no idea? 


MODEL: "No ... I'm a union steward for Kenwood Elementary and I never knew that." 


UNRUH: In fact, no one would know it, just by looking at the financial statements we obtained which only states that some of the property the union owns is "...the building leased by a member of the executive board." 


TORNILLO: "It's an IRS lease. It's a continuing lease." 


UNRUH: Why don't you explain that to us. 


TORNILLO: "Why do I have to explain it you? Why do I have to explain it to Jilda Unruh." 


UTD boss Pat Tornillo, insisted his members know about his housing arrangements but recently refused to answer most questions about it. 


UNRUH: "What do you pay, Pat?" 


TORNILLO: "None of your business." 


UNRUH: Okay, fine. I thought it might be the business of your members. 


TORNILLO "No. But none of your business." 


UNRUH: In a March 19 letter UTD's chief financial officer did say "Mr. Tornillo leases this home from the UTD, and pays rent that is debited from his gross salary. He pays $2,700 monthly." 


But nowhere did that information show up on the union's most recent filing with the state Public Employee Relations Commission Or PERC. 


It lists Tornillo's salary as $225,429, plus an allowance of $17,700. 


In fact, UTD's filing with PERC Revealed some other interesting financial information. 


For example: six UTD employees receive an allowance that is actually bigger than their salary. 


And for the ten UTD employees whose salaries top $100,000 a year, each one also gets an additional $12,000 to $17,000 in allowance money. 


The PERC filing also shows that UTD made loans to 23 individuals between October 1, 2000 and September 30, 2001. 


All but two of those loans appear to be interest free. In fact, according to the union's 1999 to 2000 financials we obtained, the union listed $49,411 in employee loans that were "non-interest bearing." 


But according to UTD's CFO, Jim Angleton "interest was charged on all loans." Again he said, "that information is a mistake." 


Damaris Daugherty, founder of teacher's rights advocacy coalition or TRAC has been pushing the state to force UTD to have their filings comply with state statutes. 


DAUGHERTY: "The whole purpose of filing with PERC is to give members full disclosure so that they know where their money, not UTD's money, their money is going. And UTD has failed to do that." 


Tornillo, angered by our questions about some of UTD's finances, had just one thing to say before he walked away. 


TORNILLO: "We're going to challenge you from here on every time. Every time you open your mouth!" 


UNRUH: UTD insisted that all repayments of loans were through payroll deduction. The union also admitted that repayment of seven of those loans had been waived during the last reporting year due to hardship: among those claiming hardship are three UTD employees with salaries between $86,000 and $112,000. UTD says it no longer makes personal loans to employees.

From:	David Quaderer <Daveq@DeSotohq.com>
Sent:	Thursday, May 9, 2002 8:09 PM
To:	Coker, Travis
Cc:	Jeb Bush; Slater Bayliss; mckay.john.web@leg.state.fl.us; bennett.michael@leg.state.fl.us; jeb.bush@myflorida.com
Subject:	Re: HB 979

Dear Mr. Coker
 
Thank you for taking the time to reply to me.  You must get hundreds if not thousands of letters and e-mails,  I sincerely appreciate the personal response. 
 
Please pass on to the Governor my response as follows:
 
The premise that the "special district failed to seek the consent of its taxpayers" is bunk and here is why.
    1.  We held four public hearings on the issue.
        Two in the winter months and two in the summer months so our seasonal residents could be here. 
        One in the morning, one in the evening so everyone that wanted to had the opportunity to attend.
    2.  We mailed a newsletter (cost almost $5,000) to every resident of the district explaining our request and inviting residents to our public hearings.
    3. Besides the required legal advertisements, our board purchased regular ads in both local papers.
    4. Our Board adopted the draft language at yet another public hearing
    5. The local news papers (Bradenton Herald and Manatee Herald Tribune) reported on the public hearings.
    6. Our bill was subject to two public hearings before our local legislative delegation.
    7. There were numerous articles in our news papers about our proposed bill after it was filed.
 
By the words he used in the veto message the Governor's implication is that our board of Fire Commissioners are trying to sneak something by the tax payers.  Nothing could be further from the truth.  The public has been plugged in throughout the entire process as outlined above.
 
No one opposed this bill - It was supported unanimously by the 5 member locally elected board of fire commissioners. It was unanimously supported by our 5 member legislative delegation.  It passed the House and Senate without the first descending vote.  The Governor did not receive one e-mail,  letter, or phone call in opposition.  The only person who opposed this bill was the Governor.
 
Why would our Governor be opposed?  This must have been a bad bill, or something bad for our community.  No, the Governor vetoed this bill because we failed to follow his new rules.  Rules he only published in late February, well after the point we could have held a referendum, even if we wanted to.  It was the first week of March when I found out about them.
 
Did he veto it because our rates are excessive?  If he had asked, we would have shown that we have not adjusted our assessment caps since 1993, nearly 10 years.  Our impact fees have not changed in twenty years, since 1982.  Further research would have shown the Governor that our rates are well below most of the other fire districts in our county and way below our surrounding counties.  A quick glance at our audits, he would have seen we have been deficit spending for the last two years, reducing our reserves instead of raising assessments.  Did he veto it on any of these facts?  No, it was vetoed because we did not follow his new rules.
 
The fact is we were never asked the first question by the Governor or his staff.  We never had the opportunity to make our case.  The first clue we had that there was a problem was when a neighboring district had there codification language vetoed.  Then we started franticly calling and writing to no avail.
 
I believed our Governor supported local control and smaller and less intrusive government.  I also thought the Governor would support the fire department and us firefighters.  But actions speak louder than words,  I was wrong.  By his actions, he told us he knows what our fire department needs better than our locally elected officials.  So much for government closer to the people, Tallahassee knows best.
 
His creating these new rules with out any notice or input  just made government that much bigger and more intrusive.   We tried, we complied with all Statutes, House and Senate rules, and thought we had done everything we were required to do.  We were not trying to subvert the Governor or the taxpayers.  
 
We will jump through the new hoops he has setup again next year.  We will hold a referendum - at tax payers expense.  I just hope more hoops don't get setup after we jump through these.
 
As a result of the Governors veto,  we will institute a hiring freeze at our next Fire Commissioners meeting.  Hopefully we will make it through the next fiscal year without having to reduce our staffing or park any fire trucks.  We had hoped to increase our staffing to try to comply with the new 2-in 2-out firefighter safety standard recently mandated by the State Fire Marshal's Office (rule 4A-62),  instead we may have to declare a state of financial emergency.
 
Thank you for you continued support .
 
David R. Quaderer, Division Chief
Cedar Hammock Fire Rescue
Bradenton Florida
 
 
----- Original Message ----- 

From: Coker, Travis <mailto:Travis.Coker@LASPBS.STATE.FL.US>  
To: 'DaveQ@DeSotohq.com' 
Sent: Thursday, May 09, 2002 3:55 PM
Subject: HB 979



Dear Mr. Quaderer 

Thank you for your note to the Governor expressing your support for House Bill 979, relating to Cedar Hammock Fire Control District.  The Governor asked that I respond on his behalf.

The Governor’s office reviews all bills during the legislative process and in addition, local bills undergo an individual review process.  Given the diverse nature of issues addressed in local bills, the Governor has developed standard criteria by which to evaluate these bills.  The criteria generally provide that citizens impacted by revisions to the authority of the special district should be provided an opportunity for expressing their views by referendum.  Since this bill increases the maximum non-ad valorem assessment rates which may be levied and the special district failed to seek the consent of its taxpayers who could be significantly and adversely impacted by the changes, the Governor could not support this piece of legislation.

Again, thank you for taking the time to share your thoughts with Governor Bush. 

Sincerely, 



J. Travis Coker 
Public Safety Unit 
Office of Policy and Budget

-----Original Message-----
From: McDonough, Jim 
Sent: Wednesday, May 08, 2002 5:09 PM
To: Shanahan, Kathleen
Subject: RE: "Draft" letter of Recommendation: Chief, Nat'l Guard Bureau


Kathleen,

	Letter looks good; selection is right choice.  Only question is
whether to act.  This is big defense politics (your former boss can give you
the flavor of that).  That is not to say that our boss isn't into big
politics, but chances are he will not be seen as personally aware of the
choices and the implications.

	The reserves and the National Guard in particular are going through
a major conceptual --and therefore actual -- transformation.  So are the
regular forces (Army, Navy, Air Force, and Marines).  They and their
civilian bosses (the service chiefs, Department of Defense, others) pay
close attention to the decisions and why they were made, who recommended
what, and why they did so.  

	Bottom line.  I would tread lightly here.

							Jim

-----Original Message-----
From: Muniz, Katie [mailto:Katie.Muniz@MyFlorida.com]
Sent: Thursday, May 09, 2002 4:57 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: Shanahan, Kathleen; Branker, Laura
Subject: Has moved to the Wire


Boy Dies in Foster Care; Birth Mom Finds Out a Week Later
The Associated Press 
TAVARES, Fla. (AP) - The biological mother of a 23-month-old boy who
drowned
at a foster home wasn't told what happened by Department of Children &
Families workers until several days after the toddler's death. 
Austin Rogers died last Friday after spending two days in critical
condition
at Arnold Palmer Hospital for Children & Women in Orlando. He was found
limp
by his foster father in an aboveground pool. 
His biological mother, Bonnie Turner, 20, said she wasn't notified by
DCF
workers until Wednesday. Turner's parental rights were terminated in
April. 
"Legally, there was no obligation to tell her," said Janice Johnson, DCF
deputy district administrator. "Legally, everything is severed." 
But Turner, who lives with her mother in Tavares, said a final court
hearing
to terminate her rights was scheduled until May 14. She also said the
baby's
father, Jeremy Mills, 28, has not signed any paperwork. 
Austin was born with cerebral palsy and was put in foster care two days
later. 
Johnson said the drowning had been ruled an accident, but the Lake
County
Sheriff's Office said Wednesday the case is still under investigation. 
According to police and DCF reports, Austin's foster parents, Ysidoro
and
Tinnie Campos, lost track of the child for only a few moments May 1.
Ysidoro
Campos, 40, had been playing with five children in the front yard while
his
wife worked inside their Groveland home. 
"Two minutes, two minutes and we realized he was missing," Ysidoro
Campos
said. "Everybody was looking everywhere. None of the kids ever got in
the
pool without being supervised." 
Ysidoro Campos found the baby unconscious in the pool, according to
police
reports. Two children told police Austin was missing about three to five
minutes and that Campos started cardiopulmonary resuscitation when he
found
the toddler. 
Authorities said there was a chain-link fence around the pool and a gate
with a padlock on it but the gate wasn't padlocked on the day Austin was
found in the pool. Ysidoros Campos told authorities that one of the
older
children must have left the gate unlocked. 
A DCF counselor noted in Austin's files that the Campos were attentive
foster parents who kept a close watch on the children in their care. 
After the drowning, DCF officials removed two boys, ages 4 and 8, from
the
Campos' home. Tinnie Campos said the couple was supposed to have been in
court Wednesday for the adoption of two other children, ages 7 and 12.
They
have already adopted the two children's 11-year-old brother, and they
also
have two older children. 
DCF officials said the Camposes were being considered as potential
adoptive
parents to Austin. 
"God gave him to us, and I won't question why he took him," Ysidoro
Campos
said. "I have a hollow place in my heart." 
AP-ES-05-09-02 1541EDT

-----Original Message-----
From: Ilene Davis [mailto:ilenedavis@megabits.net]
Sent: Wednesday, May 08, 2002 2:43 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: sometimes you just have to start over


 
I've been reading about the problem with DCF.  We both know if you have a dishonest employee, you have a problem that can't be resolved til the truth is out. 
 
BUT MAYBE THE PROBLEM IS THE WHOLE CONCEPT OF FOSTER CARE.   When you have to pay families to take in children, can you really be sure caring and love are the motive.   
 
IT SEEMS TO ME THAT MAYBE A RADICAL SOLUTION IS NEEDED - namely stop the individual home placement and limit it to group homes.  This way you have easier supervision, you have better chance for accountability, and better oversight when more than one person (or family) is involved in the care.    
 
Of course, the better solution would be to start by preventing anyone on welfare from having a child using avaiable birth control methods.     And if they have a child while on welfare, take all children away and cut off benefits.   Use the money to feed the children in a group home, and let such an irresponsible person suffer the consequences of being self supporting.  BUT THAT WILL NOT HAPPEN IN MY LIFETIME................ so perhaps we can go back to something that helped create  a lot of valuable members of society..   (maybe look at the home in Titusville.  From what I've seen, it teaches responsiblbity and has had success with better school grades.      Its one of the few things done well in titusville.
 
ilene davis

-----Original Message-----
From: john.blanchard@verizon.com [mailto:john.blanchard@verizon.com]
Sent: Wednesday, May 08, 2002 12:25 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Insightful article in today's Wall Street


Governor Bush,

Perhaps you have already seen the following article in today's Wall Street
Journal, but I wanted to pass it along as it contains some tremendous
insight into several areas of critical importance.  The headline doesn't
tell the real story of the several trillion dollars that have been lost to
the nation's investing public, including many pension plans, as a result of
the regulatory approach of the past few years.  As the article points out,
the problems arose from many corners, not the least of which was the
approach taken by the FCC under Reed Hundt's administration.  The real
answer is to find a way through the regulatory maze to put the market to
work, creating real incentives for investment in new technology, and
thereby creating real jobs and real wealth for the citizens of the land.
There is a tremendous amount of information packed into this little
article, and I commend it to you.

John Blanchard


Date: 05/08/2002
Source:     Wall Street Journal
Keywords:
_____________________________________________________________

Business World: Telecom's Curse: Too Many Lobbyists

By Holman W. Jenkins Jr.


The Wall Street Journal via Dow Jones

  It hardly seems like a mere five years ago that WorldCom was plopping
into the
middle of the business world's consciousness with a $30 billion bid for
long-distance carrier MCI.

  Bernie Ebbers, he of the cowboy boots, was offering MCI shareholders
WorldCom
stock, then priced at a multiple of nearly 100. Investors at the time were
enthralled by the idea of the senile old phone companies being overrun by
the
Internet. His rival for MCI's affections, GTE's Charles Lee, was one of
those
old telephone guys but he had a different idea. He dared to offer a lower
price
for MCI but in Plain Old Cash.

  Mr. Ebbers won the battle but it's clear now who won the war. WorldCom
teeters
toward bankruptcy as its former chief licks his financial wounds on the
sidelines. Meanwhile, GTE went on to marry itself with Verizon, the
super-monopolist that dominates the Northeast and looks like one of the few
survivors of the spending frenzy of recent years.

  We won't weep for Mr. Ebbers, but such is the outcome when billions are
thrown
at opportunities designed by Washington rather than the market. Looking
back,
regulatory policy had become insane. Local Bells were being allowed to
merge
with Bells on the ground that, hey, they were already monopolies so what
difference did it make if they got bigger? Yet regulators stood fast
against a
sensible coalescence of the local and long-distance businesses to form a
single,
undifferentiated business called phone service.

  This was half the telecom meltdown right here. Out of every dollar paid
for
long distance, 93 cents goes to the overhead, billing and marketing costs
of
maintaining a separate long-distance industry. Any business built on such a
non
sequitur can't be long for the world. Long distance needed an orderly
burial,
but regulatory politics and telecom's lobbying wars got in the way.

  The other half of the disaster has its roots in Washington's regulatory
fumbling of broadband. Mike Armstrong has been working valiantly to dig
AT&T out
of the dying long-distance business by buying cable TV networks and
converting
them to two-way broadband. But it hasn't been a fun ride for AT&T
shareholders.
No sooner did he begin investing billions to build a digital pipe into
millions
of homes than competitors were demanding "open access" from regulators.
Now,
with this battle in remission, he finds himself fighting regulators and
rivals
over his attempt to merge his cable systems with those of Comcast.

  But the cable guys have hardly been innocents themselves, constantly
badgering
Congress and the FCC to hog-tie the Baby Bells' own broadband effort. State
legislators in Oklahoma finally got fed up and just deregulated
Southwestern
Bell's broadband business. In turn, the company announced plans last month
to
roll out service to 37 more towns.


  Sadly, not even Intel and a host of Silicon Valley worthies who recently
marched on Washington have managed to break a similar impasse there. They
just
keep bouncing off Ernest Hollings, the irascible Democrat who chairs a key
Senate panel and likes being the scourge of whatever big business his staff
points him at.

  History will want to know how we came to throw away $1 trillion of
bondholders' money while knocking $2 trillion off the collective wealth of
telecom shareholders in the 1990s. Here's how:

  Much of the wasted spending was actually predicated on a funny notion
embodied
in the '96 telecom law -- or at least the law as interpreted by Reed Hundt,
the
Al Gore protege who served as FCC chairman. His vision, dreamed up out of
the
whisperings of countless lobbyists, was that regulation should hold the
incumbent Bells in place while start-up competitors cherry picked their
businesses to death.

  This notion had a certain charm but was hardly necessary to keep the
world
moving forward. Wireless, satellite, cable and various other challengers
were
coming along anyway. Better that this investment had been made without
illusion
and without pathetic reliance on regulators, which turned out to be one of
the
worst gambles of all time. In the end the '96 act was successful mainly for
the
permanent gusher of campaign contributions it created.

  Mr. Armstrong at AT&T believes the '96 model can still work, and he's had
some
luck with state regulators lately. But a business plan built on expecting
the
Bells to cooperate in their own overthrow would seem a recipe for
frustration.
"Economics always wins out. Crazy, convoluted schemes never work," says one
telecom CEO.

  In comparison, WorldCom's Mr. Ebbers didn't seem to have any road map at
all
beyond continuing to make deals and grab telecom properties while telecom
was a
scarce resource.

  Hard to believe, but there was a moment when it seemed it might run out.
AOL
and other Internet hookup providers had gone to flat-rate, all-you-can eat
pricing. The standard three- to five-minute phone call the old system was
designed to handle had suddenly become a call that lasted all week.
Old-time
Bell engineers were worried the system would bog down under the surge in
demand.


  While it lasted, Mr. Ebbers was earning astronomical margins from
Internet
backbone. Indeed, even with all the lousy policy out of Washington, telecom
might still be levitating today if the courts had upheld Napster and
Hollywood
was busting a gut to offer a digital business model of its own.

  Too bad. Now the industry's biggest millstone is its own lobbying armies.
Telecom players need to do deals -- lots of them -- to clean up and
consolidate,
but trench warfare between the factions in Washington has made getting
anything
done almost impossible.

  We've got a wireless industry with too many players, a consumer
long-distance
industry that needs to be absorbed by the Bells, and needless regulatory
obstacles to broadband. The only way anything is going to get fixed is if
everyone puts down their battleaxes and agrees to let technological rather
than
regulatory competition drive the future.

DJWJviaNewsEdge

-----Original Message-----
From: Ron & Doris Garcia [mailto:gartiz@netzero.net]
Sent: Wednesday, May 08, 2002 6:13 PM
To: Cliett:Education:Gov; Cliett, Cheryl; Bush gov; Bush, Jeb; Jeb Bush; govenor Jeb Bush
Subject: Thank You for Just Read, Florida!


To the Honorable Governor Jeb Bush; 
Lt. Governor Frank T. Brogan; Commissioner of Education Charlie Crist; and the Secretary of Education Jim Horne;




I thank you for this year's Governor's Educators' Leadership Summit. Every facet of this year's summit evidenced yet again that the utmost priority of this administration has been and still is Education.

Over many years and in many ways, we Florida Educators have become complacent concerning what is truly important in education. We came to expect mediocrity from government and in turn have accepted mediocrity from education simply because it is labeled a "government institution". I am so thankful that the Florida Bush administration has laid down the gauntlet by saying, "No!" to complacency and saying, "Yes!"  to excellence in both government and education once more. 

The vision of "Just Read, Florida" raises the bar of expectations in Education back to where it should be. "Just Read, Florida!  reminds us all that the basic goal of education is to empower every child with the literacy skills to become productive citizens.  The concrete steps taken by this administration to positively impact education through unprecedented increased funding, support to classroom teachers, and solicitation of parental and community involvement are noted and applauded by those of us at the very heart and soul of education, the classroom teacher. 

As we near the end of this school term, I thought the timing of the Summit was most appropriate. This is the time of year teachers are called upon to assess their students' performance and issue grades that represent individual students' achievements. This brought to my mind the question ,"What grades would I give Jeb, if I had to assess his performance and the performance of his administration?" So, if you would indulge my "teacher imagination",  then these are the "grades" I believe you have earned. 

A+ in your Acceptance of all children and the refusal to leave any child behind. 

A+ in the Accountability for all school districts, administrators, teachers, parents, and students to measure the quality of learning taking place in our Florida Schools by means of  FCAT testing and a School Grading System.

 A+ for Achievement of all students reading on grade level by 2012. The "Just Read, Florida!" initiative boldly declares that putting reading first in Education is a "reasonable service" shared by every Florida parent, educator, and citizen. 

A+ for your Accessibility to all schools and educators through school visits, community dialogue, and events like, The Governor's Educators' Leadership Summit. 

Gentlemen, according to this Florida Educator, you have earned straight A's.

Thank you, again for the opportunity to be a part of a Summit focusing on the singular most important goal of Education, that of teaching all Florida children to just.....read.

Respectfully submitted,
 
Doris Ortiz Garcia
 
ESOL/Language Arts Teacher
Southwest Middle School
Orange County Public Schools
gartiz@netzero.net

 Martin Soin & Water Conservation District

Sir, 

I kayak on the Loxahatchee River and I spent the entire day paddling on it this past Sunday. I understand, today you are on the river in a canoe. What I wanted to bring to your attention is that the water level of the river has changed between the time I was there Sunday and when I was there early this morning. Though we have had no rain at all, the water level this morning was considerably higher. I assume this was done in preparation of your visit. I don't know if this has any effect on the reason for your visit today, but I just thought you should know, somehow, someone consciously must have caused the rise in water level. Maybe if you want to see the river the way it really is you should take a canoe trip with out first pre-announcing your intentions. Canoes and kayaks can be rented at the headwaters of the Loxahatchee seven days a week at Canoe Outfitters of Florida... Their phone number is... 1 888 272-1257

-----Original Message-----
From: Kathleen Gates [mailto:kgates@shadrach.net]
Sent: Wednesday, May 08, 2002 8:48 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Re: Hernando Today


Dear Governor Bush,
     Thank you!!!! In today's mail, at school, arrived a beautiful envelope from the White House. We are not telling Jacob what it is. I am having it professionally framed and presented to him at his 5th grade graduation at the end of May. He is an ESE student with behavior problems but like my custodian said to me today, "Mrs. Gates, who knows, this could turn him around!" We never give up on children. 
     I will check when the graduation date is. I know that you are booked for probably the next 10 years solid, but one never knows when an opening may occur. It would make a wonderful photo op for your "education" campaign. Our school is a success story. We were a "C" school and last year achieved an "A" status. We are titled a "Global School". Each year we highlight 4 different countries to learn about their cultures. We are also a Title 1 school. Many children have barely ventured outside of Brooksville.
     I teach 4th grade. Since our children are language deprived, I take them on field trips to enrich their spoken and written vocabulary, with the FCAT writing test in mind. If you haven't experienced, how can you write? SO! This year I have taken them to Tarpon Springs to see the inside of St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox Cathedral. They were awestruck by the 24 carat gold laden icons, stained glass windows and crystal chandeliers. We then took a boat ride and watched a diver don a traditional sponge diver's suit to retrieve sponges off the river's floor. Many of my students wrote later that they had never been on a boat.
   Just last month we took a trip to Ybor City. I hired two tour guides to accompany us on a bus and walking guided tour. They got to step on "Cuban" soil at the Jose Marti Park. We ordered 45 loaves of cuban bread from the Segunda Bakery to take back to our families and share our experiences around the dinner table that night. Some of the loaves were bigger than the children as they carried them to their buses after school. It was hysterical!
   Please tell your brother thanks a million. His letter will probably be cherished by this child for the rest of his life!
 
Sincerely,
 
Kathy GAtes
Brooksville Elementary School

     -----Original Message-----
     From: william weston [mailto:flaethic@worldnet.att.net]
     Sent: Wednesday, May 08, 2002 6:27 PM
     To: Jeb Bush
     Subject: Confidential

     Governor:  As you may recall, my wife is planning director for DCF in
     Broward. So, you can imagine that we spend a lot of time talking about
     the department as we did for the five years we were in Jacksonville
     where she also did planning for DCF in Duval.
     One of the results of our discussions was the establishment of a
     unique law school clinic at DCF sponsored by Florida Coastal. I had
     the privilege of serving as Associate Dean for Skills at Florida
     Coastal. The thought occurs to us that one way of addressing some of
     the issues of children at risk is to marshall of the law schools in
     Florida to establish a clinical program whereby law students work with
     DCF staff and lawyers to handle children in placement including doing
     some of the guardian at litem issues. This would have a three-fold
     value. First, it would train new lawyers to deal with public service
     issues for the future whether they enter government service or the
     private practice of law. Second, this would be an excellent service
     venue for students and third, this would fill a vital need. I don't
     have all of the answers and this might not be well received by our
     insular and turf-oriented law schools; but I think this could work.
     Florida Coastal had a good relationship with District Four and we had
     a number of students come through the clinic with a sense of what DCF
     does and how they can help. Perhaps if you think there is some value
     to this  you can consider it as part of any "solutions" for DCF and
     see if the Judge Kearney considers it valuable. Of course, if you or
     she need additional information or ideas related to this, I would be
     delighed to help. I know how hard DCF people work and Ellen and I
     appreciate your support of DCF which came through during today's video
     conference. I would hate to see us trash the department which does so
     much good because of a singular or limited problem. Please let me know
     what you think of the clinic idea. As always, my best wishes and
     support.

     bill weston

-----Original Message-----
From: Thorpe, Janet C. [mailto:ctjujt1@ocnjcc.org]
Sent: Wednesday, May 08, 2002 5:13 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Dependency


Dear Jeb-
I realize that you are up to your ears in alligators at this time, but I
just wanted you to know that it is possible to work through the morass
and backlog in the dependency area.

Judge Roche and I were well fought our first year or so on the bench
with the "changes" we were demanding.  Those "changes" were nothing less
than complying with the statutes enacted.  The results for Orange County
after less than 2 1/2 years of hard work and hundreds of dependency and
termination of parental rights trials is that over 4,000 children have
reached permanency. [translation-through adoption, long term relative
care or reunification, DCF is no longer involved in these children
lives]. Foster Care is down nearly 50%. Trials can be held in the
required 60 days.  Ancillary result- resources, both human and
financial, are now available for the children  under DCF's manageable
case load. imagine what could have been accomplished with all parties
pulling in the same direction.

The problem is solvable.  People need to be motivated towards
resolutions.

My thoughts and prayers are with you at this difficult time.

Sincerely,

Judge Janet C. Thorpe

PS.  Thanks for signing SB 618.  I'll definitely breathe easier after
next Friday's qualifying is over.

-----Original Message-----
From: Peggy Sapp [mailto:psapp@informedfamilies.org]
Sent: Wednesday, May 08, 2002 3:49 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Help Parents Help You!


I know your life is hectic and too many people make too many demands, and
requests but this could be a big help to you.

You had to cancel attending Informed Families' 20th Anniversary Joe's Stone
Crab Dinner on May 20th because of a White House Event.  I assumed that
event was in DC, when I read that it is a Cuban celebration in Miami, I see
a great opportunity for Republicans to reach out and be more inclusive.

In the last twenty years, Nancy Reagan's Parent Movement, The National
Family Partnership (NFP) and Informed Families have been the most successful
and cost effective
way to reduce casual drug use in America. By changing social norms and
enlisting large numbers of parents and schools to participate in our
programs, people become partners in the prevention process.  Unfortunately,
this is the Republican's best kept and little understood secret. 

You have a unique and wonderful opportunity to connect the dots for the
press, the public and the parents.  Republicans have been on the leading
edge of supporting
parents, kids, schools and reducing alcohol and drugs. Let's tell the public
about this ongoing work!

How?   By either stopping by the Joe's event anytime from
6:30-9:30 pm or coming by our building at 2490 Coral Way anytime that day to
see our new classrooms for parents and kids, funded by The Knight
Foundation, Bell South, etc.

Visiting Informed Families will generate interest and support at the local,
state,
and national level since NFP is headquartered at Informed Families and
I am the national president of the 67 affiliates nationwide.

A stop by/photo op would help Informed Families and NFP recruit more parents
to participate in prevention, which is certainly part of the President's
agenda.

I have just agreed to sit on NIDA's Advisory Council at the request of Tommy
Thompson's office to get the President's agenda of Faith Based Initiatives
and Prevention on NIDA's agenda.  As you know sitting on this Council and
trying to sway opinion in this direction is not going to be easy, pleasant,
or fun. A picture of you, Columba, and the President at the Joe's event or
at Informed Families' new classrooms would convey at least 1,000 words while
actually helping people understand how to participate in drug prevention.

So Jeb, that's it...please try not to miss this natural win/win opportunity!
Thanks for your consideration and help. Let me know what you think.

Peggy

-----Original Message-----
From: jgmeehan [mailto:jgmeehan@earthlink.net]

To: Jeb Bush
Subject: The Truth


Jeb - I have never sent you something like this before.  I tried to laugh at it but I couldn't.  If you wonder why education isn't working...this is just plain truth!  I'll tell you another story in the next day or so.  I'm just too tired tonight...and you probably are, too. - Gwen
 
FLUFF: A History of Teaching Arithmetic"

Teaching Arithmetic in 1950: A logger sells a truckload of lumber for $100.
His cost of production is 4/5 of the price. What is his profit?

Teaching Arithmetic in 1960: A logger sells a truckload of lumber for $100.
His cost of production is 4/5 of the price, or $80. What is his profit?

Teaching Arithmetic in 1970: A logger exchanges a set "L" of lumber for a
set "M" of money. The cardinality of set "M" is 100. Each element is worth
one dollar. Make 100 dots representing the elements of the set "M." The set
"C", the cost of production contains 20 fewer points than set "M." Represent
the set "C" as a subset of set "M" and answer the following question: What
is the cardinality of the set "P" of profits?

Teaching Arithmetic in 1980: A logger sells a truckload of lumber for $100.
His cost of production is $80 and his profit is $20. Your assignment:
Underline the number 20.

Teaching Arithmetic in 1990: By cutting down beautiful forest trees, the
logger makes $20. What do you think of this way of making a living? Topic
for class participation after answering the question: How did the forest
birds and squirrels feel as the logger cut down the trees? There are no
wrong answers.

Teaching Arithmetic in 2001: A logger sells a truckload of lumber for $100.
His cost of production is $120. How does Arthur Andersen determine that his
profit margin is $60?

~+~+~+~

-----Original Message-----
From: PRINGLE CLARENCE [mailto:pringleclan@msn.com]
Sent: Thursday, May 09, 2002 6:54 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: hvnsgate; nharris0
Subject: Let Joey Meyer Graduate with his classmates


 
Governor Bush and Mr. Charlie Crist,
*please forward to Mr. Crist as we didn't get his email, feel free to forward anywhere you feel might help. See you Friday at C.A.F.E., Joey will be there with us. :0) 
Self-Advocating 101 is right up his alley.

You know what is happening in St. Cloud Florida, just outside the Orlando area at the St. Cloud High School. 
 
The Principle of St. Cloud High School won't let Joey Meyer graduate with his classmates or participate in the graduation ceremony, because April 15, just weeks before graduation for Joey was to take place, the school is saying that he hasn't met all his required credit requirements. 
 
There are several agencies getting involved with this and it is making quiet a stir in the media and radio talk shows. Some thing's are being said of this student, because he has Down syndrome. The student council president sent a not so nice email to the radio station, which was read on the air and saying, something to the fact that the class doesn't really want him to participate in the graduation ceremonies, because; it would "compromise" the integrity of the whole graduating class. Much of the information contained in that email was more of administrative information and not student body privileged information. Students who have come to the home have expressed no poll or questionnaire was circulated therefore it is not the views of the entire senior class by far.
 
Senator Bill Nelson has just stepped in and offered to have Joey Meyer be included in their summer internship program; with or without his high school diploma! Another organization is also stepping in to give Joey is 'very own' graduation with full military escorts and a huge party and an honoree diploma in place of his high school diploma, set for Sunday May, 19th at 2 pm. These are all nice community supportive actions. 
 
As a parents of child(ren) who have been in the Florida school system since 1988, working through the ESE Department, IDEA and 504 for many, many years this concerns us greatly. We have not yet seen all of Joeys IEP's, Mrs. Meyers will fax them, she assures us she has been to most of the meetings and signed the plans which in deed state Joey is scheduled to graduate May 2002. Please help us understand why the iron door is shut on participation. Lee County has hit some real bumps in the road the past few years in the error of the school board and many exceptions and rules have been bent or changed to provide for the "best interest" of the education of children. One example being the fire code violations. Millions of dollars appeared and many provisions were aloud for the schools to move forward and get it right in time. They opened on time and remained open although they had not met their requirements. Please see what I am saying, there are waivers or provisions that can allow him to participate. Why is it that the state can get a waiver or make the rules bend when they are in need, here is a child with the weight of the world on his shoulders none of us could begin to imagine. You nor we can ever know what it is like to wake up every day knowing we are so different by no fault of our own, than a child with a disability. Every day it amazes us with the issues they face they laugh and bring joy to all of us around them. 
 
We just wanted to pass this information on to you, as it would seem you may be able to help or offer some suggestions on who, what or where to go for immediate action in helping us have Joey be involved in his classmates graduation ceremony with out entering the legal forum. 
 
We believe this could be turned into an awesome learning experience for the entire school body about children not the same as them and their need to be included and why. Time is of the essence because Graduation is scheduled for Monday, May 20th.
 
Enclosed are some Orlando Sentinel News articles to let you know about this situation. If you read the polls you will see the majority is behind us.
 
Please help, give us some advice on what more we can do...
 
A copy of this email is being sent to the Meyers, which you could send them some info too...but they are being flooded with well over 200 supportive emails an hour from all over the country at this point. We are helping the Meyers by being two of their many Advocates. Anything you can advise us on will be greatly appreciated.
 
Thank you.
 
Nancy Harris
PODS Angels Support Foundation, Inc.
nharris0@bellsouth.net
(954) 581-4165
Mary Pringle
Cape Coral PODS Angels Support Group
Pringleclan@msn.com
(941) 540-7897

tremendous. The High school is currently supporting approximately double the 
amount of students it was originally intended to house.

Personally, I feel the state needs to take a very close look at the entire 
school district leadership. From what the local newspapers say we have the 
highest dropout rate in the state and just recently of the ten counties that 
surround Polk, it is the only one which failed to come up with some sort of 
compensation package for its teachers. Polks teachers are not receiving one 
penny raise this year and as a matter of fact are actually making less than 
last year because of insurance increases passed on to the individual 
teachers. Where is the Polk County money going and where is the good 
management apparently present in the ten surrounding counties?? What is going 
on? Perhaps someone needs to take a look!

government, and businesses at the summit insures that Florida will be leading

'ole me" had an opportunity to meet with all the reading superstars in the 
state during my visit. What is even more amazing is that she managed to do 
this in the midst of planning the summit, an impeccably planned and executed 
tribute to Florida's great teachers. Finally, Governor Bush, thank you for

more to my dad who really thinks you are neat. Again, I am thrilled that I 
will be returning to Florida and particularly excited that it will be under 
your sincere and devoted leadership.

Sarah Seegers

This was in the local paper this morning. They all look good!!!!!   For what its worth.




District 1: Retired News Journal publisher Cliff Barnhart, former Commissioner Wilson Robertson and brokerage firm owner Eugene Franklin appear to be the leading choices.

District 2: Retired Vice Adm. Tim Wright, managing director of the University of West Florida's Institute for Human and Machine Cognition, and former state Rep. Lois Benson are strong contenders.

District 3: Pensacola City Council member Marie Young, a Democrat, and educator Ulysses Hughes, the Republican administrator of the Ruby J. Gainer Charter School, appear to be the favorites.

District 5: Janice Gilley, whom Bush called on to fill suspended Escambia County School Board member Vanette Webb's seat in 1999, is the presumed appointee.


Steve Luppert

excellent work, but did not find the position  very
challenging, and my qualifications were not fully
utilized. 

I finally decided to become qualified as a licensed
nursing home administrator, in order to contribute
more to the community, and therefore persued that
route the whole of last year while working at AHCA.
Now I am ready to sit for my board exam which will
qualify me as a nursing home administrator. 


Governor, I have seen you pushing for diversity,
and trying to give well deserved opportunities to
women and minorities. I am a minority, living in this
country for over 20 years, persued my university
degrees here and,  now I am ready to contribute my
knowledge and expertise for the betterment of our
community, but have not been given that opportunity
that fits my qualifications. I am completely well
versed in the rules and regulations that govern the
nursing home industry, and am very qualified to hold a
position in the policy making area of the nursing home
industry in the government.

-----Original Message-----
From: Nora Williams [mailto:namandawilliams@yahoo.com]
Sent: Friday, May 10, 2002 2:10 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: RE: I still don't know what to say



Hey, I reread that. It actually isn't what I'd hoped for, so let me ask it another way. 


You've said below that if you end up not agreeing with me that you will be kind enough to inform me before the announcement is made. I really do appreciate that and I know that this is your responsibility, not mine, and that I have handed off any rights in the matter by my resignation. I respect that and I trust you. 


That having been said, I would ask, if your considerations go in a different direction, that you allow me the opportunity to speak with you BEFORE a decision is made. One of the things I love about you is that you do stick to your path, once your research is finished and a decision is made. Please allow me to be part of informing that decision if you decide to pursue other directions. 


Man, I don't want to push you, Governor. But it would just about kill me to have someone appointed who disrespected the process and the work that meant so much to me. And I'm frankly having a hard enough time without staggering under that. So this is just a simple yes or no request to help me deal with the insomnia this is causing. Have your heart and your mind still open for reconsideration when you call me. That is genuinely all I ask for in recognition of my service in the position. 


Good night and take care, 


Nora
