-----Original Message-----
From: Nora Williams [mailto:namandawilliams@yahoo.com]
Sent: Thursday, May 09, 2002 1:19 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: CastilC@eog.state.fl.us
Subject: RE: I still don't know what to say



Governor, 


It is my great hope that you will see your way clear to appoint Mr. John Verdon as quickly as possible to replace me on the Monroe County Commission. John, 58, is a long-time Republican, and held public office in a small town for many years (5 terms, and served as Mayor). He has already submitted his Appointment materials to your office. As names come out of the woodwork, I have come to realize that I will carry a heavy burden indeed if my replacement is not someone who is responsible, smart, well-meaning, and with a kind-heart. I can tell you that, of the field that is emerging, John is the only candidate whose appointment will lighten that burden for me. Thank you so much for your willingness to consider my feelings in this. John will do you (and me) proud. 


Nora Williams 


P.S. If for any reason (and I can't imagine one), you find yourself unable to appoint Mr. Verdon, I would beg you to talk with me before you make an alternate appointment. There are two reasons for this: (1) I hope that you would never wish to replace me under these circumstances with someone who opposed my work while I held office and (2) I know that you care as much as I do about continuing our work with the state on water quality and other issues, priorities not shared by all of the emerging field, You may reach me at any time via cell phone at 305-393-1666 if you need to discuss. Wishing you all the best, as always, Nora. 


  Jeb Bush <jeb@jeb.org> wrote: 


Nora, you are the best. Monroe County has been so fortunate for your public service. The important thing is that you get well. Let me know if I can ever be of assistance. I will need to know who you think should replace you should I be the guy that has to replace you. god's blessings,
 

Jeb Bush

-----Original Message-----
From: Nora Williams [mailto:namandawilliams@yahoo.com]
Sent: Monday, May 06, 2002 8:17 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: I still don't know what to say



Governor,

This afternoon I announced in the press that, due to health issues, I will be stepping down from my County Commission post as of the 18th of this month. I have discussed it at some length with Colleen Castille, who has been a terrific comfort to me in a difficult time. I have had diabetes for over 34 years (jeepers, doesn't that make me sound OLD?), and, due to some complications with my insulin pump and resistance to insulin, I am having a tough time regaining blood sugar stability. It's going to take more work and more concentration than I can give it as a County Commissioner.

Please accept my heartfelt apology for not finishing my term. While I have no doubt that I am right to step down (and my mother has promised to smack me silly if I don't), I find today, having made the announcement, that it is nonetheless breaking my heart not to finish my term. And I have every hope and plan to get this problem under control and get back in fighting shape, so to speak. I thank you for all the support and kindness you have shown me over my years on the Commission and I hope you know how much I support you - and how much I think of you.

I will be wishing you all the best. 

Sincerely,

Nora Williams

P. S. After the Escambia County interlude, I feel like this is pretty small news on your front, and I do prefer my reason for leaving office by a long shot. Take care!

-----Original Message-----
From: eisinger [mailto:eisinger@hodg-podg.com]
Sent: Friday, May 10, 2002 8:15 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: j.d. alexander; ralph arza; dennis baxley; Susan Bucher; nancy detert; tom feeney; mark flanagan; betty holtzendorf; stan jordan; charlie justice; jack latvala; perry mcgriff; john mckay; david mealor; jerry melvin; les miller; joe pickens; curtis richardson; chris smith; dwight stansel; Donald Sullivan; dan webster; Tom Dwyer; susan lowe; pat lavelle; Mickey Nolen; Lisa Archer; Katie Kirk; Kathy J. Dolbow; Jonathan Levy; ira abrams; carmella nanton; Beth Thomas; Angelo Liquori; Charisse VanBiesen; tom sheehan; Tom Arth; bill cooley
Subject: turkeys


Dear Governor Bush:
 
I was disappointed to read in the Friday, May 11 Palm Beach Post that various legislators have succeeded in getting "line item turkeys" into the budget. It appears that for the fourteenth time in sixteen years, rates paid to Seagull Industries by the State for programs for mentally retarded and developmentally challenged adults will be frozen. So, taking large sums of money that could go to lots of non-profits who have been deprived of adequate funding over the years and giving it to a few organizations who have political clout is very simply VERY POOR PRIORITIZATION. I support your vetoing every one of the turkeys throughout Florida this year. If there are no funds in the budget for rate increases after all these years of freezes, there should not be one cent for a turkey. I have nothing against the turkey concept when there are funds for programs and services that have been doing good in their communities for many years. However, not this year! Thank you for your consideration in this matter.
 
 
Sincerely,
 
Fred Eisinger
Executive Director

Governor, I was initially opposed to abolishing the career service for
state
employees.  I am now convinced you are right.  The Senate amendments
last
session made it just as hard to get rid of "dead wood."  My wife is with
DOEA (need I say more) and is SES; I am career service with AHCA.  Our
hearts are with you, your wife and your daughter who is struggling with
one
of society's most difficult diseases.  I am a Victim Services
Practitioner
(Victim Advocate) volunteer with TPD and I know that no family,
including my
own, is immune from self-medication problems.  Four more years!  

Dennis LaRosa

(850) 922-2104 (Direct)

-----Original Message-----
From: Jeb Bush [mailto:jeb@jeb.org]
Sent: Monday, February 12, 2001 7:36 AM
To: larosad@fdhc.state.fl.us
Subject: 


Thank you for writing. First and foremost, I don't believe we should
abolish
the career civil service system. I agree with you that we should strive
to
improve it. What suggestions would you make?
I understand that there is confusion about our efforts. Part of that
confusion is my fault and part is being spread by folks who want no
changes
at all. That is why we are having town hall meetings, email exchanges,
meetings with workers all across the state. We are receiving many good
suggestions on how to improve the system to allow for state workers to
be
rewarded adequately for hard and effective work.
I really appreciate your taking the time to write.
Jeb Bush

Governor Bush:

I am a career service employee and believe that the system can be
improved,
not abolished. I am old enough to remember the patronage system prior to
1958 and the "bag" men who collected tribute from appointed employees on
pay
day. I am not even remotely suggesting that we would return to that day,
but
the patronage pressure would nonetheless be present. Every four years
the
patronage train arrived in Tallahassee and off loaded political
gadflies,
pork choppers and worse. Gov. Collins saw the necessity for a
professional
cadre of employees who retained institutional knowledge of government
and
overlapped the election of new governors, and now, the election of a new
political party... my party, I may add. Perhaps that cadre will shrink
without sacrificing initiative, loyalty and institutional knowledge.

There are premises that are not scientifically supported by the 100
business
leaders advocating this initiative. One, that the state will attract
better
employees, two, that the "team" concept will be engendered and three,
that a
leaner meaner government will be more efficient and cheaper to run. None
of
these concepts have a basis in the private sector, as I have spent most
of
my adult life just trying to make a payroll. The private sector is
revenue
driven; the public sector, service driven. The human resource theories
are
not coterminous. When revenue is low, people are laid off; when
management
is bad, the workers, not the management are let go. That is capitalism
and
the essence of American business, as cold as it may sound. Your office
is
looking to cut positions and then, only the least costly positions --
the
entry level jobs that lead up the ladder are the ones being cut. My
position
was cut in your current initiative, not because the position was not
needed,
but that it would impact the agency the least in terms of cost. Now, I
have
great leadership and was able to find a suitable position, but the
uncertainty of 6 months of waiting for the axe has a general negative
affect
on the people involved, their families and friends as well as the
over-all
morale of indirectly affected employees who say, "maybe I'm next." THIS
IS
JUST YEAR ONE.

I said earlier that career service could be improved. Its going to take
some
hard work and great cooperation. Governor, you are going to have to sit
down
with your employees, open the door to your office and let groups of
10-15 in
for 10 minutes at a time. You will get some truths. I have seen you
change
positions on other initiatives because you know and respect the power of
dissent. You are not going to see a ground swell of objection from
either
the public, the legislature or even the public employees themselves.
Only
those whose jobs on the line will dissent and in numbers too few to make
a
significant political impact. I have worked for and known many
Governors; my
wife has met and been pictured with all but you, sir, in her 32 years of
service to the State of Florida. Your office is the most important of
all.
If the troops do not truly feel the General supports them unequivocally,
not
merely by words, but by action, then the army flounders. Governor your
army
is floundering, not by your direct actions but by the uncertainty of the
process. I hear discussion that the current initiative is mean-spirited,
calculated to rid the state of poor employees -- the baby will also be
thrown out with the bath water. Your initiative will have little impact
on
the worst employees as the cream always comes to the top, the best are
over-worked as the worst are equally over-looked, not replaced. That is
human nature and applies to the private as well as public sectors.

Governor, I hear in the halls that you are losing the average state
employee's confidence, not the best and brightest and not the worst of
us. I
hear you are losing the rank and file, the employees that make this
state
go, the ones you want to reward with patronage bonus's instead of
across-the-board raises. Bonuses, promotions and raises are now based on
politics and friendships, not merit. There is nothing that can be
written
into law that will change that. Can you image not getting even a cost of
living increase because your supervisor doesn't think you merit it?

Government serves more people with a reduced workforce and yet each year
the
legislature passes new initiatives with less money for more work. Career
Service was created not to prevent government from doing its job but to
assure that it would have qualified technocrats to do the day-to-day
work
regardless of who was in office. That theory has not been lost, it has
just
been translated into 21st Century terms. Governor, please fix the career
service system without replacing it with a new and untested theory, a
theory
I may add , was tested until 1958 and left wanting.

My wife and I have over 40 years combined service in state government
and my
wife is in the drop program. Your changes will probably not affect us
directly so I speak for the 23 year olds that hope to make a career in
state
government. Give them job protection where it is warranted, a living
wage
and adequate benefits to retain them, training and experience to elevate
them, and leadership perceived to be in their best interests, to
motivate
them. Then you will have a lean government machine that will provide
good
public (not private) service at a reasonable cost to the taxpayers. Your
loyal employee.


b
From:	Craig M. Rappel, Esq, <cmr@rappellaw.com>
Sent:	Friday, May 10, 2002 11:30 AM
To:	'Cathy Kasriel'
Cc:	William_Marvin@dcf.state.fl.us; Jeb Bush; Betty Busbee (E-mail); grigass@fdhc.state.fl.us; sharpeb@fdhc.state.fl.us; meadowsr@fdhc.state.fl.us
Subject:	RE: Answer on Conditionality and the Florida SAC

Dear Ms. Kasriel:

	I am in receipt of the CMS response. On behalf of SAC, and our Chairperson,
Ms. Betty Busbee,  I thank you and Mr. Tomlinson for your prompt attention
to this matter. I also personally thank both you and Mr. Tomlinson as well
as Director Scully for CMS's support of the SAC mission. I am confident that
Governor Bush will be pleased to hear that state government, in this
instance being AHCA and SAC, were able to move forward in safeguarding
Florida's efforts to provide health and human services responsibly to the
beneficiaries of the Medicaid Program, because of CMS's endeavors.

	Again, for the record, it was General Counsel for the Dept. of Children &
Families ("DCF") who had opined to our SAC staff, who are DCF employees,
that SAC officials could never have access to Medicaid beneficiary
information, despite the Governor's signature on the bill passed by the
Florida Legislature in 2000 that intended to give SAC strong oversight
responsibility over the Medicaid Program, which caused me, as a healthcare
attorney, to seek out your assistance because I became concerned about
AHCA's ability to continue to cooperate with our state agency, as AHCA has
partnered with SAC in helping us advocate and protect Floridians with unique
needs.

	By way of this e-mail, SAC and I also thank AHCA Chief Medicaid Counsel,
Steven Grigass,  the State's Medicaid Program Director, Bob Sharpe, and of
course, AHCA Secretary Dr. Meadows for their continued assistance, kind
words, and support of the SAC mission.

Very Truly Yours,

The State of Florida
Florida Statewide Advocacy Council,
By: Hon. Craig M. Rappel, Esq.,
Vice Chair
Oak Point Professional Center
5070 Highway A1A, North, Suite 221
Vero Beach, Florida 32963-1216
772.231.7223 (Direct Line)
772.231.8824 (Telecopy)
cmr@rappellaw.com

The text and attachments, if any, are not confidential and the information
contained in this e-mail is subject to Chapter 119, Florida Statutes
("public records law"). The topic of the e-mail and attachments are in
furtherance of the duties specified in Section 402.164, et. seq., Florida
Statutes and are therefore official records of the State of Florida.

Any information obtained from this e-mail is for reference use only and does
not constitute the rendering of the official policy, or any legal,
financial, or other advice or official policy by the State of Florida, the
Florida Statewide Advocacy Council or the Florida Local Advocacy Councils.

When applicable, please use "Reply All" so that all participants that may
benefit from the subject of the e-mail text or attachments are notified in
accordance with the laws of the State of Florida.







-----Original Message-----
From: Cathy Kasriel [mailto:CKasriel@cms.hhs.gov]

Subject: Answer on Confidenality and the Florida SAC


Dear Mr. Rappell and Mr. Gringass,

I have attached the response I have received from CMS CO staff to the basic
issue on whether the Florida Statewide Advocacy Council (SAC)
and AHCA are required to have a data sharing agreement in light of our state
statutory authority to have access to all confidential information on
Medicaid beneficiaries as well as others.

let me know if you have additional questions.

-----Original Message-----
From: KIDNEYSTEW@aol.com [mailto:KIDNEYSTEW@aol.com]
Sent: Friday, May 10, 2002 10:57 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Insurance issue with All Children's Hospital


Dear Governor Bush,

In September,2001, I had a pancreas transplant in conjunction with Lifelink Transplant Institute (Tampa) and Tampa General Hospital due to complications from diabetes.  In 1994, I also had a kidney transplant due to the same reason.  I was referred for a pancreas transplant in order to slow or stop complications and to prolong my life.  My husband died unexpectedly the year before leaving me with a 4-year-old son adopted from the state.  Lifelink took full responsibility in obtaining approvals from both my primary insurance through All Children's (self-insured) and my secondary insurance (BCBS) prior to placing me on the transplant list.  The transplant has been a great success.  I've since been notified that my primary insurance has denied based on need for a second opinion.  Therefore, my secondary insurance has also denied.  At no time, prior to transplant was I notified by my employer, insurance company or Lifelink that there were any outstanding issues to address.  I've filed an appeal to All Children's regarding this matter but feel that if they were going to do the right thing that it would have happened by now.  I have been an employee in good standing for 9 years.  

In the past, I know you have been concerned about individual as well as state issues. I would appreciate any help you can give me regarding this looming financial matter.  This is affecting my health and well-being and that of my child.

Thank-you,

Suzanne Conrad
Kidneystew @aol.com
From:	Sue Rupe <SRupe@co.hernando.fl.us>
Sent:	Friday, May 10, 2002 1:09 PM
To:	Jeb Bush

communities

From:	Shiver, Steve (CMO) <manager@miamidade.gov>
Sent:	Friday, May 10, 2002 3:37 PM
Subject:	Miami-Dade County on the go...

Greetings, and I hope this email finds you well. Much has been going on in your county government over the last few weeks. We have overcome some technical difficulties with our email distribution list and I am glad to be able to send you this latest update via email. I am also very pleased at the response I am getting to our virtual open door policy. The emailed suggestions and concerns I am receiving from many of you really help to improve our organization - your government. Keep those emails coming....

This week, we released our second edition of the County Citizen: <http://www.miamidade.gov/countycitizen/> This publication, also produced in print for those without Internet access, is designed to publish the good works our 30,000 county employees do each and every day. We're good neighbors, doing good things for the community - our community and yours. I invite you to get to know us a bit better by reading the County Citizen. 

As part of our good citizenship, I encourage people to send us information about the things you may see in the community that need to be fixed. Through our Eyes at Miami-Dade program, I invite anyone to email us reports of things like downed stop signs or other potentially hazardous situations so that the county can proactively address these things. This is just part of working together to make our community as safe as possible for everyone. If you see something that's not right, please email your concern to eyes@miamidade.gov <mailto:eyes@miamidade.gov> .

 

Getting out of our offices and into the community is a big part of improving service to the public. The most recent addition to our fleet of mobile services, the Government on the Go bus, will be hitting the streets in the coming months, bringing county services right into your neighborhood. Staffed by Team Metro personnel, the bus will travel to places where people frequently gather such as, grocery stores, parks, shopping centers or special events. Services available include job information, voter registration, baby stroller permits, passports, dog license tags, Metropasses and tokens and Bike & Ride Permits. Eventually, the bus will offer services like Golden Passports (transportation for seniors), alarm registration, Homestead Exemption and more. Already, we are out in the community with two of our new Bookmobiles <http://www.mdpls.org/news/press/pr/41502bm_launch.htm> and the Mobile Animal Clinic <http://www.co.miami-dade.fl.us/animals/mac_schedule.htm>. And of course, we are available to the public 24 hours a day, 7 days a week via the Internet. Internet access is free to the public in all branches of our library system. It's all about getting closer to the people we serve, and making our services accessible and easy to use.

According to the Sloan Management Review "The rate at which organizations learn may become the only sustainable source of competitive advantage." While one may not associate the term 'competitive advantage' with the public sector, I firmly believe that governments must gain the same level of efficiency that drive private sector organizations to compete. We simply must be compelled to do more for the public with less resource. Along these lines, education in county government remains a top priority for me, and I am pleased to report continued progress in our partnership with Florida International University. Continuous learning is essential, and through these types of partnerships we are now offering educational opportunities for our employees ranging from high school equivalency, undergraduate and graduate programs, as well as certifications. More information on our training initiatives can be found online at: <http://www.co.miami-dade.fl.us/emprel/training.htm> 

It's just over a year now that I was given the opportunity to serve you as the Manager of Miami-Dade County. I believe that together we have made a good deal of progress and I look forward to working with you to overcome the challenges we face and embrace the opportunities we have to make this community the best ever. Again, please feel free to email or call any time.... 

Regards,
Steve Shiver
County Manager
"we're more than employees, we're neighbors"
305.375.1032 office
305.246.5409 home
manager@miamidade.gov <mailto:manager@miamidade.gov>

Please feel free to share this information with others you know, or ask them to subscribe to e-news at: <http://miamidade.gov/personalize.jsp>
To remove your name from this email list, please email: webmaster@miamidade.gov <mailto:webmaster@miamidade.gov>

-----Original Message-----
From: LccPraise@aol.com [mailto:LccPraise@aol.com]
Sent: Friday, May 10, 2002 3:53 PM
To: b.armstrong@advocacycenter.org; Dougt@drgglobal.com;
group@Tampabay.rr.com; tschmokel@apexmail.com; VScooterBug1@aol.com;
ladypd@juno.com; jeanne@accessibilitylifts.com;
jackhumburg@boleycenters.org; AlLinden@aol.com;

Cc: Jeb Bush; jeb@myflorida.com; alan.florez@myflorida.com;

janetkahn@netally.com; cilnf@nettally.com; cilj@southeast.net;
marciar@cilj.com; Michael@cascil.org; vmartin@self-reliance.org;
ehowe@cilorlando.org; sccil@billsouth.net; cilo2000@bellsouth.net;
cilb@cilbroward.org; andreaw@cilj.com
Subject: Please help on HB 1307


Please help us out. I need you to email Governor Bush's office: Jeb@jeb.org 
or Jeb@myflorida.com or give them a call at 850-488-7146.  Fax letters of 
organizational support on letterhead to: 850-921-9077. Ask them to Veto House 
Bill 1307:

We are looking for assurance that our Florida Statutes listing our more 
stringent accessibility laws were not changed, amended, altered, deleted
or defaulted to Federal Code in any way. We need to know that no one has 
changed the privileges and rights afforded to Floridians that we worked so 
hard for. Please veto HB 1307. 

May 9, 2002

Re: Request For Support of the Governor's Veto of HB 1307

Dear Colleague:

On May 2, six PVA members, including myself, met in the Governor's media room 
at the Tallahassee Statehouse to discuss Florida HB 1307, which is basically 
a good bill.  The problem is that it is a 52 page Florida Building Code bill, 
which contains four lines of language that would reduce accessibility into 
"places of public accommodation." It will accomplish this because less 
stringent Federal language from the Americans with Disabilities Act (The ADA) 
of 1990 was inserted into this bill in the form of an amendment.  Included in 
this meeting from the Governor's staff were:

* Alan Flores, Deputy Chief for Legislative Affairs (850-488-5000)
* Kevin Tang, Assistant General Counsel for Governor Bush (850-488-3494)
* Barbara Hoagland, Governor's Correspondence Liaison (850-487-1884)
* Julie Shaw, Executive Director, Administrator, Governor's ADA Working Group 
(850-487-3423)

* For the DCA: Jim Richmond, Assistant General Counsel (850-488-0410)

Shortly after this one + hour long discussion began, it became clear that 
neither Messrs. Flores nor Tang understood the concept of the Code of Federal 
Regulations 28 CFR Part 36.403 (f)(1) "20% Disproportionality" language, and 
they did not understand how introducing it into Florida statutes would 
negatively effect people with disabilities. They also heard our opposition to 
allowing private non-certified inspectors perform inspections on new 
construction. They listened, and I think we got through to them. Jim Richmond 
from the DCA supported our position. Now begs the question, what is the 
Governor going to do? We have requested an ASAP face-to-face meeting with the 
Governor on this issue.

This is the language we are opposed to:


SENATE AMENDMENT - - Bill No. CS for CS for SBA 2078

Amendment No. ___ Barcode 483402

18 the Accessibility Advisory Council. Notwithstanding any other

19 provision of this subsection, if an applicant for a waiver

20 demonstrates economic hardship in accordance with 28 C.F.R.

21 36.403(f)(1), a waiver shall be granted. The commission may - - -

^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

Note: The operative word in the above sentence is: "SHALL."

^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

Not only do we oppose this amendment, but we object to the manner that this 
amendment was slipped into the existing bill at the eleventh hour. The 
Amendment was introduced on March 13th, and the bill was signed by the House 
on the 20th and by the Senate on the 22nd. Persons with disabilities who will 
be affected by this amendment were not informed and were not given an 
opportunity to voice their opinions or opposition. This amendment should have 
been placed on the agenda of the Accessibility Advisory TAC (Technical 
Advisory Committee) of the Florida Building Commission. Advocates would have 
appreciated it if they had been notified in advance through the Governor's 
ADA Working Group. 

Chapter 28 of the US Code of Regulations (CFR) reads:

"28 C.F.R. 36.403(f)(1) Disproportionality. Alterations made to provide an 
accessible * path of travel to the altered area will be deemed 
disproportionate to the overall alteration where the cost exceeds 20% of the 
cost of the alteration to the primary function area."

( * Definition, Path of Travel: " - - - the continuous, unobstructed way of 
pedestrian passage by means of which the altered area may be approached, 
entered and exited and which connects the altered area with an exterior 
approach." Florida's Vertical Accessibility is part of the "Path of Travel.")

In other words, if this bill is signed, in the future, when building owners 
apply for waivers from vertical accessibility, if their cost of providing 
vertical accessibility to the altered portion of the building exceeds 20% of 
the cost of the alteration, the project is AUTOMATICALLY EXEMPTED (per the 
operative word, "shall") from providing vertical access to the newly altered 
area. 

This would effectively nullify our Florida vertical accessibility statute FS 
553.509, which states: 

"Florida State Statute 553.509: Vertical accessibility.--Nothing in sections 
553.501-553.513 or the guidelines shall be construed to relieve the owner of 
any building, structure, or facility governed by those sections from the duty 
to provide vertical accessibility to all levels above and below the 
occupiable grade level, regardless of whether the guidelines require an 
elevator to be installed in such building, structure, or facility - - -"

(The entire wording of this statute is included at the end of this 
communication.)

Under current Florida statutes, when a building owner makes alterations to an 
existing facility, the owner is obliged to include the costs of providing 
vertical accessibility. This means installing an elevator, ramp, wheelchair 
stairglide, or some other limited use lift device. He would also be required 
to make "Path of Travel" accessibility improvements. However, the system 
currently allows for a "Hardship Waiver." If providing vertical accessibility 
will cause an economic hardship, or if providing vertical accessibility is 
deemed by an architect or an engineer to be "technically infeasible," these 
are grounds for a hardship waiver to be granted. 

If the building owner appears before the Florida Building Commission and 
proves economic hardship, the waiver may be approved or deferred until some 
agreed-upon time in the future when the accessibility modification shall be 
completed. Or, if a hardship is not proven, the waiver may be denied. 

Example #1:
A building owner, under current statutes, is required to provide vertical 
accessibility when he performs a construction alteration. He applies for a 
building permit to do a $100,000 renovation. The owner estimates the costs of 
providing vertical accessibility at $30,000. He feels that this is too 
expensive and will be an economic hardship. If the owner does not meet one of 
the current statutory exemptions, the local code official is required to 
refer the owner to the Accessibility Advisory Committee of the Florida 
Building Commission to apply for a hardship waiver. 

Under the current Florida statutes, there is no 20% language. The seven 
member Accessibility Advisory Council, known as the "Waiver Board," will hear 
the applicant's petition for a waiver. The Board may grant or deny the 
request, based on the applicant's testimony. The Board may also grant a 
waiver for a limited period of time. This is something that is not done under 
the Federal regulation 28 CFR 36.

Example #2:
HB 1307 is signed by the Governor, and the same building owner applies for a 
building permit to do the same $100,000 renovation and gets referred to the 
Building Commission for a waiver. With the 20% language, in this example the 
maximum amount the owner would have to spend for both path of travel and 
vertical accessibility would be $20,000. 

Remember, the operative word in the amendment to HB 1307 is "SHALL. " If the 
cost exceeds 20%, a waiver SHALL be granted. 

In the second example, the owner applies for a waiver from providing vertical 
accessibility and attends his hearing at the monthly meeting of the Florida 
Building Commission's "Waiver Board." He presents estimates for $20,000 worth 
of accessibility work that will come under the "Path of Travel" guidelines. 
These costs are for Accessible Parking, Entrances, Bathrooms, etc.. He also 
has an estimate for an additional $30,000 for a lift device to provide 
vertical accessibility, for which he wants a waiver. 

In the second example, the owner is automatically granted his waiver to 
provide vertical accessibility in his facility because the $30,000 exceeds 
the 20% ceiling. In the first example, the waiver may be granted, denied, 
deferred to a future meeting, or conditionally granted. Quite a few 
applicants have received "conditional waivers" when they have agreed to 
achieve vertical accessibility in their facilities after an extended period 
of time. This allows them to accumulate the funds necessary to fund the 
alteration. If HB 1307 is signed, the Waiver Board will not be allowed to 
explore the possibility of a conditional waiver.

Under the 20% disproportionality, future applicants will have the opportunity 
to avoid providing vertical accessibility by spending more money than 
necessary on "Path of Travel" improvements. This will get them to the 20% 
ceiling, and thus, qualify them for their waiver. 

NOTE: Applicants who are refused a waiver by the seven member "Waiver Board" 
may reapply to the full 23 member Florida Building Commission. The Florida 
Building Commission hears waiver reviews within one day of the seven member 
"Waiver Board" hearing. Authorized by FS 553.74(1)(m), the Florida Building 
Commission includes: "One member of a Florida-based organization of persons 
with disabilities or a nationally chartered organization of persons with 
disabilities with chapters in this state." ( See the compete statute at the 
end of this communication.)

If the ADA language in the Federal 28 C. F. R. 36.403(f)(1) becomes the law 
of the land in Florida, we can expect to see fewer and fewer existing 
buildings become accessible in the future. When building owners make 
improvements to their property, they will have no incentive to try to include 
accessibility. To save money, they will take advantage of the "20% 
Disproportionality Exemption" afforded them in this amendment to HB 1307. 
Building owners will have an easy selection from two choices of options: 

1) Do I want to spend less money and not make my business accessible, or
2) Do I want to spend more money and make my place accessible.

To repeat what I mentioned earlier in this communication: This amendment 
would effectively nullify our Florida vertical accessibility statute FS 
553.509. The "Waiver Board" would be a rubber stamp for granting waivers from 
vertical accessibility. The insertion of the 28 CFR 36 20% language will 
clash and create a glich with our current FS 553.509: Vertical 
accessibility.--Nothing in sections 553.501-553.513 or the guidelines shall 
be construed to relieve the owner of any building, structure, or facility 
governed by those sections from the duty to provide vertical accessibility - 
- - . 

If the Governor signs HB 1307, he will be promoting INACCESSIBILITY in 
Florida. Additionally, there is a clause the Federal ADA that disallows a 
facility, or a state, 
to decrease existing accessibility. HB 1307 would achieve that undesirable 
affect in Florida and could trigger an investigation by the US Department of 
Justice. 

Here is another very important reason for vetoing this bill: This bill 
contains language that would lower the standards for building inspections 
around the state. This bill creates a class of new inspectors from the 
private sector who will not have to maintain or possess the same level of 
standards possessed by state-certified inspectors. This could lead to unsafe 
new structures because these inspectors may show loyalty to the person who 
hires and pays them and "overlook" items in favor of their employer.

I would very much appreciate any help or advice that you could give to us. We 
believe that the current "waiver process" is sufficient to satisfy the needs 
of both owners of buildings and persons with disabilities. Please help us 
protect the rights and privileges afforded to Floridians for which 
individuals with disabilities have worked so hard to obtain. We need to make 
every effort to ensure that the Governor will veto this devastating piece of 
legislation.

Please contact the Governors office and persuade him to veto this critical 
bill. Please call, write, email and/or fax your concerns about this bill.

Governor Jeb Bush
PL 05 The Capital
400 S. Monroe St.
Tallahassee, FL 32399-0001
Phone: (850) 488-4441
Fax: (850) 487-0801
Email: fl_governor@myflorida.com




Respectfully requested,

Ben Ritter
Government Relations Director
Florida Gulf Coast PVA chapter

David L. Bradbury
Government Relations Director

-----Original Message-----
From: Psychteach43@aol.com [mailto:Psychteach43@aol.com]
Sent: Friday, May 10, 2002 3:37 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Privacy for former law enforcement


Dear Sir:

In 1986 I spent a year serving the State of Florida as a Correctional 
Probation Officer  after which time I left the dept to attend law 
school....then I dropped out to become a teacher, my current occupation.  
After an examination of the statute, I see that probation officers are indeed 
classified as law enforcement officers and their addresses may NOT be 
released by the Dept of motor vehicles or their employers such as Miami-Dade 
County Public Schools unless the inquiry is made by a police agency.  This 
applies to all serving and FORMER officers.  

The reason I ask, sir, is that while I was a member of the dept I made 
several arrests and testified in serval more cases, and even received a death 
threat or two.  I'd like to verify that this shield law is still in effect 
and inquire as to how I can make the Dept of motor vehicles aware of my 
status (so they won't release sensitive info on me to just anybody) and that 
I might have something written on official letterhead to show my boss that he 
can't give my name and address info out to anybody either.
Jim Kononoff
1308 Genoa Street
Coral Gables, FL 33134-2339
(305) 448-9043

-----Original Message-----
From: Lisa Devitto [mailto:ldevitto@mindspring.com]
Sent: Friday, May 10, 2002 11:49 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Rilya: suggestion from Lisa DeVitto -- DCF should seek GAL and Attorney Ad Litem appointment for child


Dear Governor: 
This may have been considered, but I have a constructive suggestion -- it might be in the best interest of the child, and eliminate any appearance of conflict for DCF,  for DCF to seek appointment of both a Guardian ad litem and an attorney ad litem for Rilya.  I think it would be appropriate given that:   the status of Rilya's true next of kin are at issue; her mother's rights have been terminated; she is missing and may be dead, and there are legal issues pertaining to the openness of her files where it appears that DCF may have a conflict in decisionmaking, and other legal issues may arise.  
 
A guardian and attorney could relieve DCF of the appearance of any conflict and would protect the child's interests -- -- perhaps a former judge, or former prosecutor who has handled children's issues?    
 
Sincerely, 
 
Lisa K. DeVitto, Attorney at Law 
(Mrs. Ralph DeVitto)

From:	Jeb Bush
Sent:	Friday, May 10, 2002 4:52 PM
To:	Jonas Walton
Subject:	RE: Rilya Wilson

Jonas, you are right that family breakdown is the cause of the need for a government run child welfare system that can't replace loving wholesome families. I say that everytime I speak about this case. Your number on 25% of the children being out of wedlock is sadly low. The number is about 33%. 

Having said that, the negligence in handling this case is cause for concern and we have a responsibility to improve the system until their is a societal change that lessens the demands placed on government.

-----Original Message-----
From: Jonas Walton [mailto:jonas@insurer.com]
Sent: Friday, May 10, 2002 1:16 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Rilya Wilson


Hello Governor:

I think that you should be brave in terms of politics and public policy regarding Rilya Wilson and tell the truth. Little Ms. Wilson did not go missing because of your "failure to adequately fund social services" (although I do feel that you need to spend more money in that area as well as transportation and even more so in education ... if that isn't the role of government what is?) 

No, Rilya Wilson is missing solely because her guardian handed her to a stranger. Whatever her fate is, it was for all intents and purposes sealed when that was done, even had the police been called immediately (which they were not). You can make that statement clearly and without demonizing her guardian.

Why did Rilya Wilson go missing for so long? It is true that there was negligence in this case, but the true reason is because DFACS is overburdened. Why is DFACS overburdened? Again, not because of your "neglect" of social programs or "failed state bureaucracy, but because there are so many children in its care. Why are there so many children in its care? Because of family breakdown. Drugs, AIDS, crime/incarceration, unemployment, etc. compound the problem, as does poor educational systems. They should be referenced as causes contributing to the problem and be addressed.

But the primary cause of this overwhelming of state resources with hundreds of thousands of children is the culture of so many people having children for which they have no capacity of ever supporting, specifically teenage pregnancy, men who abandon their children and women having children out of wedlock. I would wager large sums of money that the vast majority of children under the care of DFACS and the state's many other noneducational social welfare programs (as well as those in the juvenile crime system) are products of this culture. 

In a state of 16 million people, there is no way DFACS can effectively do its job if 1/ 4 of children are born out of wedlock, and if 2/3rds or more are born out of wedlock in minority and urban communities. No government bureaucracy could ever be constructed to correct such massive personal failures. You must stand up and say that the reckless having of children (and engaging in the behavior that creates children) by selfish irresponsible people is not a lifestyle choice but a cancer on society, and it takes away resources spent vainly trying to deal with the problems that it creates from problems that are more tractable. Imagine how many more teachers that Florida could hire or how much more money could be spent on transportation projects if Florida did not have to spend billions to care for children created by absentee, irresponsible, and teen (and increasingly preteen) parents.

If you fail to show courage by taking on the real underlying root issues that led to this tragedy in public speeches and public policy, it would be a failure of leadership. You have to do it not because of politics but rather because no one else will. Thank you.

Jonas Walton
--

From:	Jeb Bush
Sent:	Friday, May 10, 2002 4:59 PM
To:	Brown Brewser (EOG) (E-mail)
Subject:	FW: North Broward Hospital District appointment fup

we need to respond and discuss.
 
Jeb Bush

-----Original Message-----
From: Judie S.Budnick [mailto:jbudnick@browardschools.com]
Sent: Friday, May 10, 2002 11:55 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: RE: North Broward Hospital District appointment


Jeb:
 
Thanks for asking for my input.  Before I begin to give the answers to your questions, I caution you not to read the responses believing that any monies we receive will not be appreciated. In fact, they will!   I am not one for looking a gift horse in the mouth!  However, the percentages being tossed around can be deceiving when disaggregated---that is what I will candidly relay to you.
 
1)       Overall Funding Increases:
I           If the State legislature adopts the budget as proposed, Broward County School District will receive a budget increase of     approximately $132M.  This is a 10% increase in overall funding from the mid-year cuts. If applied to the beginning of this school’s fiscal year, it amounts to an increase of 7%!  
 
 
2)       Growth Factor:
      There is a 4% increase in student growth anticipated.  It has been calculated into the 7% and/or 10% figures 
mentioned above.  Therefore, in reality, the school district will realize no more than 3% and/or 6% increase!  
 
 
3)       Insurance Premium Hit:
ALL school district will experience substantial increases in insurance costs next year.  Broward expects an 
increase of $20M!  
 
 
4)       Programs, adjustments and creative financing:
At the beginning of last year’s budget process, we cut 2 ½ % from each school site.  Principals where told not to cut 
from their staff but to look closely at the “fluff and stuff”.  Central administration (all departments) where cut by 10%.  At the mid-year cut, central admin put a freeze on hiring; we did not take any monies from classrooms.   In addition, we leveraged additional funds from a lease-purchase program for computer equipment, trucks and school buses. 
 
 
5)       Per Student Funding:
Indeed, we would receive a 6% increase per student, if the legislature adopts the proposed budget.  Once again, if the 
increase is calculated from the beginning of last year, that increase would only be a 3% increase per student. 
 
 
6)       TRUE BOTTOM LINE:
Calculating the proposed budget on the mid-year budget with the new insurance rates and growth factor = 1.5% increase
which would go directly to salary increases!  (It doesn’t even cover the cost of living increase!  :-( )
            Calculating the proposed budget on the beginning of the fiscal year with the new insurance rates and growth factor = 3% which would go directly to salary increases!  
            Broward is fortunate in that we made our cuts last year; therefore, this year will not be as draconian!  If we hadn’t, not only would we realize no TRUE increase, we would be further behind!  We are in better shape than a lot of other districts from what I am hearing.  
 
 
Once again, Jeb, this email is NOT covered with tears…just some blood and sweat!  (I loved that rock band of the 60’s!)  I caution your staff or the legislatures in approaching the proposed budget increase as “victorious” because in reality it truly is not.  I realize that without your persuasion we would not even be looking at a possible 1 ½% or 3% increase.  To that extent, I sincerely appreciate your efforts!
 
Good luck.  Contact me if you have other thoughts,  
 
Judie Budnick
 
      
 
 
 
 
-----Original Message-----
From: Jeb Bush [mailto:jeb@jeb.org]

Having Tim on the Board would bring a refreshing and innovative prospective on mutual opportunities.  His legal background would add still another dynamic.

Judie S. Budnick

Please note: Florida has a very broad public records law.
Most written communications to or from state officials
regarding state business are public records available to the
public and media upon request.   Your e-mail communications
may therefore be subject to public disclosure. 

-----Original Message-----
From: Ron Johnson [mailto:riverron@digitalusa.net]
Sent: Friday, May 10, 2002 4:22 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: Terry Sullivan; Chris McKendree
Subject: WHOA (Waterfront Home Owner's Assembly)


Governor Jeb Bush

Tallahassee, FL

Dear Governor Bush,

As secretary of the organization WHOA (Waterfront Home Owner's Assembly), I am writing you in reference to an e-mail you received from Stu Barnette concerning the treatment of invasive weed growth in Lake Rousseau. Stu Barnette is a respected member of our organization but the referenced letter represents Stu Barnette's personal views and does not reflect the sentiment of the association. Although it is true we are dissatisfied with the present situation and would like to have an alternate method of weed control, we have yet to be presented with a viable alternative. We have faith in the local representatives of the DEP and feel they are concerned and doing their best with the only method available. 

Our organization is dedicated to preserve, protect and perhaps restore, (if it is not already too late), one of the state's greatest treasures, the Withlacoochee River and Lake Rousseau. We feel that there must be some alternative to the self defeating methods we are now implementing. The spraying of these weeds is not very effective and produces a muck that settles to the bottom causing premature silting of this beautiful lake. It is in fact better than nothing, but we urge you to look into this problem, not from a local level, but encourage you to press any agency that you command into service. It is not just a local problem, but affects nearly every waterway in Florida. 

We are one of several organizations formed with similar goals. It is time for our officials to get on the band wagon and look for a solution to our deteriorating water resources. 

Respectfully, 

Sandra Clodwick, President and Ron Johnson, Secretary

WHOA (Waterfront Home Owner's Assembly)

Dear Governor: 
This may have been considered, but I have a constructive suggestion -- it might be in the best interest of the child, and eliminate any appearance of conflict for DCF,  for DCF to seek appointment of both a Guardian ad litem and an attorney ad litem for Rilya.  I think it would be appropriate given that:   the status of Rilya's true next of kin are at issue; her mother's rights have been terminated; she is missing and may be dead, and there are legal issues pertaining to the openness of her files where it appears that DCF may have a conflict in decisionmaking, and other legal issues may arise.  
 
A guardian and attorney could relieve DCF of the appearance of any conflict and would protect the child's interests -- -- perhaps a former judge, or former prosecutor who has handled children's issues?    
 
Sincerely, 
 
Lisa K. DeVitto, Attorney at Law

From:	Bill.Hendrich@cox.com
Sent:	Friday, May 10, 2002 5:13 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Cc:	waldemar.serrano@myflorida.com
Subject:	Spreading the message in Orlando

Dear Governor, 

This week at the initial Citizen Corps meeting held by Mayor Hood I had the opportunity to meet your Special Assistant, Waldemar Serrano.  In speaking with him I talked about the opportunity that you have to use AM580 WDBO as often as you wish to help Central Floridians understand the important issues facing the state.  The opportunity is more than just a news interview, rather I would suggest a four or five minute segment in morning drive with our host Jim Turner.  This way you can explain the issues as you want people to understand them, not just get a 5 to 10 second sound bite.  Prior to the election season heating up it seems to me that this is a great opportunity for you to lay out the issues that will affect the way people vote.

AM580 WDBO is the dominant News/Talk radio station in Central Florida and has been for many years.  Listeners to our station are active voters.  Mayor Hood,  Orange County Chairman Crotty, Congressman Ric Keller, Florida House Speaker Tom Feeney and other politicians understand this and take full advantage of WDBO to keep our community up to date on matters of importance.  It is a safe environment for a political figure to talk and be respected.  I encourage you to talk with any of them about how they work with WDBO. If you would like to call me and get a better understanding of what we can do I would love to explain it to you personally.  My direct line is 321-281-2013.

Governor, you are going to spend millions of dollars for 60 second commercials once the campaign really kicks in to get your message across.  So will many others.  There is a great opportunity now to clearly lay out the issues for a huge block of Central Florida voters.  And should you win re-election (sorry, I'll vote for you and think that you will win, but can't be completely presumptive about it) WDBO gives you a way to keep the issues alive and move voters to influence their Senators and Representatives on these issues.  

I hope that we get the opportunity to work together to help the State of Florida. 

Bill Hendrich 
Vice President/General Manager 
AM580 WDBO/K92FM

-----Original Message----- 
From: LccPraise@aol.com [mailto:LccPraise@aol.com] 
Sent: Friday, May 10, 2002 3:53 PM 
To: b.armstrong@advocacycenter.org; Dougt@drgglobal.com; 
group@Tampabay.rr.com; tschmokel@apexmail.com; VScooterBug1@aol.com; 
ladypd@juno.com; jeanne@accessibilitylifts.com; 
jackhumburg@boleycenters.org; AlLinden@aol.com; 
Cathy.White@dbpr.state.fl.us; pwolbert@tampabay.rr.com 
Cc: Jeb Bush; jeb@myflorida.com; alan.florez@myflorida.com; 
barbara.hoagland@myflorida.com; kevin.tang@myflorida.com; 
jim.richmond@dca.state.fl.us; Kelly@soflacil.org; SCILLORI@aol.com; 
eilfl@neosmart.com; cilnwf@cilnwf.org; william@cilncf.org; 
janetkahn@netally.com; cilnf@nettally.com; cilj@southeast.net; 
marciar@cilj.com; Michael@cascil.org; vmartin@self-reliance.org; 
ehowe@cilorlando.org; sccil@billsouth.net; cilo2000@bellsouth.net; 
cilb@cilbroward.org; andreaw@cilj.com 
Subject: Please help on HB 1307 


Please help us out. I need you to email Governor Bush's office: 
Jeb@jeb.org 
or Jeb@myflorida.com or give them a call at 850-488-7146.  Fax letters 
of 
organizational support on letterhead to: 850-921-9077. Ask them to Veto 
House 
Bill 1307: 

We are looking for assurance that our Florida Statutes listing our more 
stringent accessibility laws were not changed, amended, altered, deleted 
or defaulted to Federal Code in any way. We need to know that no one has 

changed the privileges and rights afforded to Floridians that we worked 
so 
hard for. Please veto HB 1307. 

May 9, 2002 

Re: Request For Support of the Governor's Veto of HB 1307 

Dear Colleague: 

On May 2, six PVA members, including myself, met in the Governor's media 
room 
at the Tallahassee Statehouse to discuss Florida HB 1307, which is 
basically 
a good bill.  The problem is that it is a 52 page Florida Building Code 
bill, 
which contains four lines of language that would reduce accessibility 
into 
"places of public accommodation." It will accomplish this because less 
stringent Federal language from the Americans with Disabilities Act (The 
ADA) 
of 1990 was inserted into this bill in the form of an amendment. 
Included in 
this meeting from the Governor's staff were: 

* Alan Flores, Deputy Chief for Legislative Affairs (850-488-5000) 
* Kevin Tang, Assistant General Counsel for Governor Bush (850-488-3494) 
* Barbara Hoagland, Governor's Correspondence Liaison (850-487-1884) 
* Julie Shaw, Executive Director, Administrator, Governor's ADA Working 
Group 
(850-487-3423) 

* For the DCA: Jim Richmond, Assistant General Counsel (850-488-0410) 

Shortly after this one + hour long discussion began, it became clear 
that 
neither Messrs. Flores nor Tang understood the concept of the Code of 
Federal 
Regulations 28 CFR Part 36.403 (f)(1) "20% Disproportionality" language, 
and 
they did not understand how introducing it into Florida statutes would 
negatively effect people with disabilities. They also heard our 
opposition to 
allowing private non-certified inspectors perform inspections on new 
construction. They listened, and I think we got through to them. Jim 
Richmond 
from the DCA supported our position. Now begs the question, what is the 
Governor going to do? We have requested an ASAP face-to-face meeting 
with the 
Governor on this issue. 

This is the language we are opposed to: 


SENATE AMENDMENT - - Bill No. CS for CS for SBA 2078 

Amendment No. ___ Barcode 483402 

18 the Accessibility Advisory Council. Notwithstanding any other 

19 provision of this subsection, if an applicant for a waiver 

20 demonstrates economic hardship in accordance with 28 C.F.R. 

21 36.403(f)(1), a waiver shall be granted. The commission may - - - 

^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ 
^^^^^^ 

^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ 

Note: The operative word in the above sentence is: "SHALL." 

^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ 
^^^^^^ 

^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ 

Not only do we oppose this amendment, but we object to the manner that 
this 
amendment was slipped into the existing bill at the eleventh hour. The 
Amendment was introduced on March 13th, and the bill was signed by the 
House 
on the 20th and by the Senate on the 22nd. Persons with disabilities who 
will 
be affected by this amendment were not informed and were not given an 
opportunity to voice their opinions or opposition. This amendment should 
have 
been placed on the agenda of the Accessibility Advisory TAC (Technical 
Advisory Committee) of the Florida Building Commission. Advocates would 
have 
appreciated it if they had been notified in advance through the 
Governor's 
ADA Working Group. 

Chapter 28 of the US Code of Regulations (CFR) reads: 

"28 C.F.R. 36.403(f)(1) Disproportionality. Alterations made to provide 
an 
accessible * path of travel to the altered area will be deemed 
disproportionate to the overall alteration where the cost exceeds 20% of 
the 
cost of the alteration to the primary function area." 

( * Definition, Path of Travel: " - - - the continuous, unobstructed way 
of 
pedestrian passage by means of which the altered area may be approached, 

entered and exited and which connects the altered area with an exterior 
approach." Florida's Vertical Accessibility is part of the "Path of 
Travel.") 

In other words, if this bill is signed, in the future, when building 
owners 
apply for waivers from vertical accessibility, if their cost of 
providing 
vertical accessibility to the altered portion of the building exceeds 
20% of 
the cost of the alteration, the project is AUTOMATICALLY EXEMPTED (per 
the 
operative word, "shall") from providing vertical access to the newly 
altered 
area. 

This would effectively nullify our Florida vertical accessibility 
statute FS 
553.509, which states: 

"Florida State Statute 553.509: Vertical accessibility.--Nothing in 
sections 
553.501-553.513 or the guidelines shall be construed to relieve the 
owner of 
any building, structure, or facility governed by those sections from the 
duty 
to provide vertical accessibility to all levels above and below the 
occupiable grade level, regardless of whether the guidelines require an 
elevator to be installed in such building, structure, or facility - - -" 

(The entire wording of this statute is included at the end of this 
communication.) 

Under current Florida statutes, when a building owner makes alterations 
to an 
existing facility, the owner is obliged to include the costs of 
providing 
vertical accessibility. This means installing an elevator, ramp, 
wheelchair 
stairglide, or some other limited use lift device. He would also be 
required 
to make "Path of Travel" accessibility improvements. However, the system 

currently allows for a "Hardship Waiver." If providing vertical 
accessibility 
will cause an economic hardship, or if providing vertical accessibility 
is 
deemed by an architect or an engineer to be "technically infeasible," 
these 
are grounds for a hardship waiver to be granted. 

If the building owner appears before the Florida Building Commission and 

proves economic hardship, the waiver may be approved or deferred until 
some 
agreed-upon time in the future when the accessibility modification shall 
be 
completed. Or, if a hardship is not proven, the waiver may be denied. 

Example #1: 
A building owner, under current statutes, is required to provide 
vertical 
accessibility when he performs a construction alteration. He applies for 
a 
building permit to do a $100,000 renovation. The owner estimates the 
costs of 
providing vertical accessibility at $30,000. He feels that this is too 
expensive and will be an economic hardship. If the owner does not meet 
one of 
the current statutory exemptions, the local code official is required to 

refer the owner to the Accessibility Advisory Committee of the Florida 
Building Commission to apply for a hardship waiver. 

Under the current Florida statutes, there is no 20% language. The seven 
member Accessibility Advisory Council, known as the "Waiver Board," will 
hear 
the applicant's petition for a waiver. The Board may grant or deny the 
request, based on the applicant's testimony. The Board may also grant a 
waiver for a limited period of time. This is something that is not done 
under 
the Federal regulation 28 CFR 36. 

Example #2: 
HB 1307 is signed by the Governor, and the same building owner applies 
for a 
building permit to do the same $100,000 renovation and gets referred to 
the 
Building Commission for a waiver. With the 20% language, in this example 
the 
maximum amount the owner would have to spend for both path of travel and 

vertical accessibility would be $20,000. 

Remember, the operative word in the amendment to HB 1307 is "SHALL. " If 
the 
cost exceeds 20%, a waiver SHALL be granted. 

In the second example, the owner applies for a waiver from providing 
vertical 
accessibility and attends his hearing at the monthly meeting of the 
Florida 
Building Commission's "Waiver Board." He presents estimates for $20,000 
worth 
of accessibility work that will come under the "Path of Travel" 
guidelines. 
These costs are for Accessible Parking, Entrances, Bathrooms, etc.. He 
also 
has an estimate for an additional $30,000 for a lift device to provide 
vertical accessibility, for which he wants a waiver. 

In the second example, the owner is automatically granted his waiver to 
provide vertical accessibility in his facility because the $30,000 
exceeds 
the 20% ceiling. In the first example, the waiver may be granted, 
denied, 
deferred to a future meeting, or conditionally granted. Quite a few 
applicants have received "conditional waivers" when they have agreed to 
achieve vertical accessibility in their facilities after an extended 
period 
of time. This allows them to accumulate the funds necessary to fund the 
alteration. If HB 1307 is signed, the Waiver Board will not be allowed 
to 
explore the possibility of a conditional waiver. 

Under the 20% disproportionality, future applicants will have the 
opportunity 
to avoid providing vertical accessibility by spending more money than 
necessary on "Path of Travel" improvements. This will get them to the 
20% 
ceiling, and thus, qualify them for their waiver. 

NOTE: Applicants who are refused a waiver by the seven member "Waiver 
Board" 
may reapply to the full 23 member Florida Building Commission. The 
Florida 
Building Commission hears waiver reviews within one day of the seven 
member 
"Waiver Board" hearing. Authorized by FS 553.74(1)(m), the Florida 
Building 
Commission includes: "One member of a Florida-based organization of 
persons 
with disabilities or a nationally chartered organization of persons with 

disabilities with chapters in this state." ( See the compete statute at 
the 
end of this communication.) 

If the ADA language in the Federal 28 C. F. R. 36.403(f)(1) becomes the 
law 
of the land in Florida, we can expect to see fewer and fewer existing 
buildings become accessible in the future. When building owners make 
improvements to their property, they will have no incentive to try to 
include 
accessibility. To save money, they will take advantage of the "20% 
Disproportionality Exemption" afforded them in this amendment to HB 
1307. 
Building owners will have an easy selection from two choices of options: 


1) Do I want to spend less money and not make my business accessible, or 
2) Do I want to spend more money and make my place accessible. 

To repeat what I mentioned earlier in this communication: This amendment 

would effectively nullify our Florida vertical accessibility statute FS 
553.509. The "Waiver Board" would be a rubber stamp for granting waivers 
from 
vertical accessibility. The insertion of the 28 CFR 36 20% language will 

clash and create a glich with our current FS 553.509: Vertical 
accessibility.--Nothing in sections 553.501-553.513 or the guidelines 
shall 
be construed to relieve the owner of any building, structure, or 
facility 
governed by those sections from the duty to provide vertical 
accessibility - 
- - . 

If the Governor signs HB 1307, he will be promoting INACCESSIBILITY in 
Florida. Additionally, there is a clause the Federal ADA that disallows 
a 
facility, or a state, 
to decrease existing accessibility. HB 1307 would achieve that 
undesirable 
affect in Florida and could trigger an investigation by the US 
Department of 
Justice. 

Here is another very important reason for vetoing this bill: This bill 
contains language that would lower the standards for building 
inspections 
around the state. This bill creates a class of new inspectors from the 
private sector who will not have to maintain or possess the same level 
of 
standards possessed by state-certified inspectors. This could lead to 
unsafe 
new structures because these inspectors may show loyalty to the person 
who 
hires and pays them and "overlook" items in favor of their employer. 

I would very much appreciate any help or advice that you could give to 
us. We 
believe that the current "waiver process" is sufficient to satisfy the 
needs 
of both owners of buildings and persons with disabilities. Please help 
us 
protect the rights and privileges afforded to Floridians for which 
individuals with disabilities have worked so hard to obtain. We need to 
make 
every effort to ensure that the Governor will veto this devastating 
piece of 
legislation. 

Please contact the Governors office and persuade him to veto this 
critical 
bill. Please call, write, email and/or fax your concerns about this 
bill. 

Governor Jeb Bush 
PL 05 The Capital 
400 S. Monroe St. 
Tallahassee, FL 32399-0001 
Phone: (850) 488-4441 
Fax: (850) 487-0801 
Email: fl_governor@myflorida.com 




Respectfully requested, 

Ben Ritter 
Government Relations Director 
Florida Gulf Coast PVA chapter 

David L. Bradbury 
Government Relations Director 
Paralyzed Veterans Association of Florida, Inc. 

Steve Sensakovic 
Government Relations Director 
Central Florida PVA chapter 



Angel Watson 
Accessibility Coordinator 
for Caring & Sharing Center for Independent Living, Inc. 
727-577-0065, fax 727-577-2932, 727-577-5034 TTY 
Toll Free: 1-877-778-2580, fax 877-779-2580 
M-F 11:30-2:30 (Thurs. off)

	  Latest  <http://cbs.marketwatch.com/tools/marketsummary/default.asp?siteid=mktw&dist=> Market Overview	   <http://cbs.marketwatch.com/1.gif> 	
5/10/2002 2:52:00 PM
Florida Economy Poised For Strong Recovery, According to Tony Villamil, Chairman of Gov. Bush Council of Economic Advisors 


CORAL GABLES, Fla., May 10, 2002 /PRNewswire via COMTEX/ -- The Florida economy has demonstrated significant resiliency and has started to recover from the twin externally produced shocks of a global recession and the terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001, according to former U.S. Under Secretary of Commerce for Economic Affairs, Tony Villamil. Mr. Villamil is currently chief executive officer of The Washington Economics Group, and chairman of Governor Jeb Bush Council of Economic Advisors.

Speaking to CEOs of top Florida corporations at the Annual Meeting of the Florida Council of 100 in Naples, the noted economist stressed that Florida's fundamentally sound economy is due primarily to a number of critical factors. Among these factors are:

*An improving business climate under Governor Jeb Bush, including tax
relief, streamlining of regulations and emphasis since 1999 on
educational system improvements, workforce development and investments
in "smart" infrastructure that link producers with the end-use
marketplace.

"There is a no-nonsense and pro-economic development Chief Executive in
Tallahassee.This creates growing confidence in the future of the
State," Villamil said to the Florida executives gathered at the
meeting.

*Florida has become increasingly diversified over the past years,
according to Villamil.The growth of a diversified economic base
includes the expansion of a wide range of knowledge-based services,
defense-related activities and high technology manufacturing, among
other "new economy" industries.

*A final critical factor in creating a large and more resilient Florida
economy is the birth of new economic regions of the State.The North
Florida region, Villamil stated, is expanding strongly, while Southwest
Florida shows growing economic muscle."In essence, we are not as
dependent on one or two economic regions of the State as in the past,"
Villamil reasoned.


In conclusion, according to the well-known economist, "Florida is poised to resume strong economic expansion as the U.S. and global economies recover from the recent recession."

The Washington Economics Group, Inc. (WEG) has been based in Coral Gables, Florida since 1993. WEG is an economic consulting firm, with a growing professional speaking and corporate training practice.

From:	Dana, Pam <pam.dana@myflorida.com>
Sent:	Friday, May 10, 2002 5:58 PM
To:	Jeb Bush; Shanahan, Kathleen; Jimenez, Frank; Yablonski, Brian; Brown, Brewser; Branker, Laura; Brogan, Frank
Subject:	OTTED update May 6-10
Attachments:	UpdateMay10-02.doc

From:	Dana, Pam <pam.dana@myflorida.com>
Sent:	Friday, May 10, 2002 6:06 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	RE: Tyndall AFB fup

We are OK.  I have been working with William all week long.  Good guy.  I
talked with Admiral Natter to share community concern (while unfounded) that
Navy training would impact AF training at Tyndall.  This is not the case and
the Admiral has scheduled a meeting w/ Gen Hodgkins (who was not part of
higher level planning and hence what created part of the problem) and
business/community leaders in June to discuss any outstanding
concerns/issues.  A similar meeting was held in Key West and all are pleased
with outcome.  General Hodgkins' boss in AF as well as AF Chief of Staff
have approved plan.  I also had Natter call Senator Graham and Cong Boyd to
discuss the training partnership between AF/Navy because some in the
community had filtered the information up to them--causing unnecessary
concern.

Since then, Boyd issued an editorial that, to my knowledge has not yet run,
but which affirms that Navy is there to partner not destroy.  I will forward
it to you for review in a minute.  I have seen a responding editorial which
Natter plans to submit which assures community that this is a good thing for
Tyndall, Air Force, Navy, Florida and that Navy training is not there to
impact.

-----Original Message-----
From: William Harrison [mailto:wharrison@wgharrison.com]
Sent: Friday, May 03, 2002 11:15 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Tyndall AFB


Hey! I'm concerned about the affect of the possible Vieques mission
relocation to Eglin. General Hodgekins indicated to me last week that
move would likely close Tyndall's primary mission of pilot training. The
Navy's proposal of conducting the training missions 3 times a year for 2
weeks each time would prevent Tyndall from training in the Gulf. Since
Eglin controls the Gulf range, they will prohibit Tyndall from using the
range during their training. It is my understanding that Tyndall uses
the range more than all other users combined. The training missions
would disrupt the Tyndall pilot training syllabus so that the pilots
could not complete their training within the schedule outlined by the
Air Force. 

I've talked with Brian Yablonski and Brett Doster about these concerns
and they can give you more details. At your convenience, it might be
useful for you to call General Hodgekins and cross-examine him about
what Vieques-to-Eglin will really mean to Bay County.   

I'm proud of you! William

Subject:	Fwd: VETO HB 1307

    FYI - a letter from another concerned citizen attached
    For people with disabilities, the amendment on the bill will lower the 
accessibility standards in existing buildings by 80%. We will not be able to 
access 1) goods and services or 2) the job market. When will the buildings 
get accessible? Who will hire us if there is no access to the 2nd floor?
    Please help us out. I need you to email Governor Bush's office: 
Jeb@jeb.org or Jeb@myflorida.com or give them a call at 850-488-7146.  Fax 
letters of organizational support on letterhead to: 850-921-9077. Tell them 
stories of places you could not use, services you were denied. This amendment 
will make a bad situation even worse! Tell them to Veto House Bill 1307:
We are looking for assurance that our Florida Statutes listing our more 
stringent accessibility laws were not changed, amended, altered, deleted
or defaulted to Federal Code in any way. We need to know that no one has 
changed the privileges and rights afforded to Floridians that we worked so 
hard for. Please veto HB 1307. 
    I've forwarded you another reason it is a bad bill, the Governor needs to 
hear from the people the bill will effect. Thank you so much for helping out.
Blessings,
Angel Watson
Accessibility Coordinator 
for Caring & Sharing Center for Independent Living, Inc.

************************************ SEE BELOW ******************** 


Hello Robert, 


I have been in communication with the State Attorney General's Office in reference to the corruption involving Timberlake Homeowner's Association. 


I am sending copies of my correspondence with you and Tay to Ronald W. Montford who is a regulatory specialist in the Consumer Affairs Division. I wanted to ask you if you would do the same? 


In particular, the letter that you sent to the Governor, etc. 


Would you please send a copy of the email to Mr. Montford that you sent to the Governor and all of the political legislative represenatives? 


I told Mr. Montford about your email and that there was apparently not one single response from it. Mr. Montford seemed surprised there was no response. 


In the latest, I spoke to Tay today by telephone. She is a single mother of 6 children and just had surgery for the removal of breast cancer. 


In our conversation she told me that her next door neighbor, yesterday, tried to commit sucide because of the pressure from the homeowners association in trying to take his home. 


Tay also told me that the population of her neighborhood consists mostly of  retirees. She said it is a very poor community. She said that there was 300 seperate properties that the Homeowners Association Attorney was foreclosing on and that 100 additional properties were being added to the list. The owner of the management company for the homeowners association is an attorney. He is the one that is conducting filing all of the documentation towards the foreclosures on the properties. 


The court date was extended until June 17, 2002. Tay said that in her research of the lawyer he has a long list of lawsuits that have been filed against him in the past. 


Here is Ronald W.Montford's email address... 


His email address is montfor@doacs.state.fl.us 


Thank you for your help and in advance for forwarding any helpful communication or information that you may have to Mr. Montford. 


Sharon Hirschfield

-----Original Message-----
From: Davis Charmaine-EOPR02 [mailto:EOPR02@motorola.com]
Sent: Friday, May 03, 2002 4:27 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Citrus Tree replacement program


Below is a copy of letter mailed today to Fla Dept. of Agriculture. I think it is very unfair that we are being punished for following water restrictions in our area last year.  Can anyone help us???

May 3, 2002


Florida Dept. of Agriculture
Consumer Services
PO Box 7456
Tallahassee, FL 32314-7456

We had our Citrus tree taken out in the year 2000. After several months we were sent a Shade Florida tree replacement Program card good for $100 tree/shrub replacement from Wal-Mart.  However, by that time, South Florida was in a severe drought and we were under strict water restrictions on watering plants/lawns which went on for several months.  So we did not purchase anything then.  When we tried to use the card we were told it had expired.  

I called the 888 phone number on back of card and spoke with a very nice individual today but she was unable to help me only stating that instructions from Tallahassee were to not extend any expired card dates.

I think this is very unfair in that if we had bought and planted a tree in place of our other one it would have died because we could not water it more then twice a week (our grass was so brown and dead in parts when the water restriction was finally lifted).If it would help, I can send you my card that was sent to me (# on bottom is 6002 8029 1215 8765) for a replacement card if you cannot lift expiration on the card I have.

Please can't you help us with this ??




Charmaine and William Davis
8857 NW 3rd Place
Coral Springs, FL 33071
