-----Original Message-----
From: JBuddBigAl@aol.com [mailto:JBuddBigAl@aol.com]
Sent: Sunday, March 03, 2002 8:59 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: castilc@ego.state.fl.us
Subject: USFWS v/s Citizens of Lee County

Dear Governor Bush:

In December (12/22/01), I wrote a letter to the USFWS  (Charles R. Danner) and copied you regarding the J.N."Ding" Darling National Wildlife Refuge expansion project and why I was opposed to such a venture. I received a response from your "Chief Cabinet Aide" (Colleen Castille) and I would like to thank you for that reply. Colleen stated, that your office has spoken with the USFWS representatives in regards to my letter, as well as other letters you received and that there was a follow up meeting scheduled for 1/14/2002 to continue your discussions.

Because of recent developments regarding this proposal here in Lee County, many concerned citizens (in affected areas) would like to hear the results of the 1/14/02 meeting and what your position is on this issue. It appears that the USFWS (J.N. "Ding" Darling) management staff will no longer discuss this proposal with the citizens of Lee County and have withdrawn a request to the BOCC (Lee County Board of Commissioners) to approve a resolution in support of the expansion, resulting in the cancellation of a public hearing which had been scheduled for March 12th. Its the opinion of many that the reason for USFWS pull-out was that there was too much opposition which was  backed up by a petition with thousands of signature.

This action by our own government has humiliated the citizens of Lee County and won't be forgotten. Can you imagine having people like this as your neighbors, but thats whats going to happen if this proposal goes through. 

I have attached a copy of my original letter to the USFWS in Atlanta for your reference. I am hopeful that you will take a few minute and review what is going on here and provide the citizens of Lee County and the Lee County Board of Commissioners with information regarding future action on this issue, because the citizens of Lee County have been hung out to dry by their own Federal government and are very upset. Thank you.

John "Al" Budd
3151 York Rd
St James City, Fl   33956

Attch: original letter of  12/22/01

12/22/2001

Mr. Charles R. Danner
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service
Division of Refuges
1875 Century Blvd
Atlanta, Ga.   30345

Dear Mr. Danner:

I have read the current "Draft Evironmental Assessment & Land Protection Plan for the Proposed Expansion of the J.N. "Ding" Darling National Wildlife Refuge Complex. Although the document is 104 pages, it is typical of government workmanship (like an IRS document) and is full of a lot of "gobbledygook" and meaningless data (waste of taxpayers dollars). 

I also attended the meeting that was held on Dec 5th, 2001 at St. James City, Fl on Pine Island. This meeting hall was "standing room only" with approximately 270 concerned citizens. During the public comment portion of the meeting, 40 of the 270 attendees stood up and gave their opinions/comments on the proposal. Consensus of opinion for the 40 speakers was that they opposed the expansion proposal and if the applause they received was any indication,
it looked as if much of the audience was in full agreement with the speakers.

A comment was made by a "Ding" Darling management  person, that the primary reason for this expansion is to further protect the bird population. 
Personally,I don't believe that the birds need further protection. We have an abundance of birds here on Pine Island. A recent article (12/16) in the Ft Myers News-Press confirmed this. The article stated that during a recent survey, the birdwatchers counted 10,000 more birds this year than last year. 

It really upsets me to see  our own government (USFWS) deceive the public like it has been doing, all over the country. How do you explain the escapades of the 2 USFWS officials in the State of Washington planting false evidence of Canadian lynx hair? It appeared that it was a very well planned hoax and the 2 perpetrators got their hand slapped and removed from the project. We just can't trust the USFWS with all their lies and deception. 

Your track record for integrity on the island (Pine Island/Matlacha) has a lot to be desired.

What I heard from a "Ding" Darling official at the meeting was what I viewed as the main reason for pushing this proposal through your so called process and it seemed to pertain to money. Apparently, there has been $6 million allocated to the "Ding" Darling Refuge for expansion, with promises of more money in the future. But unless "Ding" Darling management develops the acquisition boundries and gets them approved they will lose the allocation. 

It was also noted that the current manager of the "Ding" Darling Refuge is being transferred to Atlanta, Ga. Wow, wouldn't the approval of this proposal, be a nice feather in his cap if he could pull it off. 

The pathetic part of this fiasco is, I just finished reading a story in the Fort Myers News-Press, that last year in the State of Florida, 1.6 million people were living in poverty. Also, the number of people who were homeless on any given day last year was estimated at 65,597. Guess what? "Big Brother" wants to buy some more land in Florida so that they can rule our lives and have a nice place for the birds to build their nest where nobody will bother them.
How many tons of food can we buy for the homeless with $6 million. Isn't it pathetic to see a government take better care of its wildlife then it does its people. I'm having extreme difficulty trying to understand this scenario. 

Another incident that took place the night of the meeting in the Pine Island Church was that the manager of "Ding" Darling Refuge was informed by one of the attendees of a petition with 900 signatures against the expansion proposal. The response from the manager was that he wasn't running any popularity contest and he was going to do what he felt was right. 

Knowing a little something about management techniques, I can tell you this man would not last long in his job out  in the real world using that type of response to a customer or an employee.  I have a deep down feeling what is going to happen to this letter. I'm sure the USFWS will do what they want. But those responsible for the proposal can tell their superiors that the public was informed and involved.

Several other reasons why I'm opposed, is our loss of tax revenue, the imposing of 100 meter buffer zones around designated islands, fire protection, insurance rates, and impacts to aerial spraying for mosquitos, which is not allowed on Federal Refuge Land.

Bottomline, I really don't want the Federal government and all their ridiculous rules, regulations and restriction as a neighbor. We don't need you and neither do all the birds need you. If  they want to fly from island to island, let them do it, but stay out of their business, they don't need you people to act as their real estate agent. The residents of Matlacha/Pine Island are sick and tired of your harassment. Maybe your time would be better spent if you started screening your organization and weeding out those environmental terrorist such as those you had working on the Washington lynx project.

One final comment. In the Ft Myers News-Press on 12/18, a story ran about "Ding" Darling was having money problems and unless the Federal government bails them out they will be forced to cut back on staff and close on the weekends. My question is: If "Ding Darling Refuge is having financial 
difficulty right now, what is going to happen when they have 45,000 more acres to manage.   

I go on record as being opposed to any of the 3 Alternatives of the proposal. 
Thank you for the opportunity to comment on this proposal.

cc: Gale A. Norton  (Secretary of the Interior)


John "Al" Budd
3151 York Rd
St James City, Fl 33956

Subject: Flag bill not taken seriously by H.O.A. & their attorney in Jupiter


Dear Governor Bush,   

Thank you for emailing us in regards to the flag bill being passed on April 18.   I appreciate this bill S178 that you signed into law and so will many other people in the state Florida.  Hopefully every governor in the United States will follow in your steps and no other American will have go through what we went through with Homeowners Association and Courts.

We would appreciate Governor Bush if you could email us a copy of the amendment of the flag bill. With this bill in hand when we go to back to court, the judge and the attorney for the homeowners will concede to the law and the state ruling. 

Sincerely, 

George & Ann Andres

To: Jeb Bush
Subject: A situation in need of assistance


Please forward to whomever can help resolve this issue.
Adoption Subsidy for a child out of Dade county, Florida requested December 2000.
RE: Steven Lee Brettell
DOB: 02-20-97, born Dade County
Birth Mother: Beverly Susan Brettell, North Miami Beach
Parental rights are not severed on either parent (Father unknown), no contact from either parent with the child since placement on or about November 7, 1999. Birth Mother did attend the court hearing giving us placement.
 
On December 27, 2000 we sent a letter to the Miami, Florida Department of Children and Families Adoption Assistance Department to request adoption subsidy for a special needs child in our care. In the spring of 2000 Judge Sandy Karlan or the Miami Court, Circuit issued permanent custody for the purpose of adoption to us. We are requesting that the state process the subsidy paperwork as Steven is disabled and receiving SSI which qualifies him as IVE eligible. It is now a year and a half later and we still do not have any paperwork to sign to have this child secured in our home through adoption.
We spoke with Attorney Elizabeth Anon about this case early January 2000 prior to us getting custody through the courts. She was able to find limited information on this family.
On January 18th 2001, Graciela Fowler, called to state she received our request and would be gathering the necessary paperwork. She then called the biological grandparent from whom we took custody. They were involved in the initial investigation and were granted custody from the Department of Children and Families until it went in to Civil court under Judge Karlin. The Department had the initial call on the biological mother after Steven was released from the hospital at birth. The situation was unstable and several options were explored. The Department of Children and Families spoke with Kenneth and Nancy Brettell for possible placement and the grandparents. The final decision was the grandparents. Mrs. Fowler was having difficulty finding a case number to show the Departments involvement although the grandparents gave detailed descriptions of the meetings they attending as they were chosen for the placement. 
We received a letter in the mail from Mrs. Fowler dated January 22, 2001 stating she is working the case. We have faxed all of the necessary documentation well over a year and a half ago and nothing is completed for us to sign and move forward for final adoption. We are a family who was told this is the proper way to acquire adoption subsidy for situations such as ours from the local Department of Children and Families as well as the appeals office in Tallahassee. 
If any one can shine a light at the end of this tunnel, we would greatly appreciate the effort put forth. Steven will be starting public school in the fall, it would be wonderful to have this wrapped up to avoid name issues as he builds lasting friendships.
Thank you for your time, if you need any further information feel free to contact us. 
Clarence and Mary Pringle

Cape Coral, Florida  33904

She said that there was 300 seperate properties that the Homeowners Association Attorney was foreclosing on and that 100 additional properties were being added to the list. -----Original Message-----
From: Kirsty Edwards [mailto:vpadiva@hotmail.com]
Sent: Friday, May 10, 2002 7:18 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: FCAT and Orlando





Dear Governor Bush,
My name is Christine Edwards.  My parents have written to you many times 
regarding their concerns for my future.  However, I would like to share with 
you my concerns about my future. As of May 24, 2002, I will be a senior in 
the Visual and Performing Arts Theatre Magnet at Dr. Phillips High School in 
Orlando, Florida.  I am an honors student with learning disabilities.  I 
have dreamt of attending college to pursue my dreams and enhance my 
education since I was a little girl.  However, it doesn't look like I will 
have that  opportunity in the state of Florida.  I will not graduate next 
May with my diploma, nor my peers, nor the VPA seal that I have earned 
because, although I have taken the math section of the FCAT three times, I 
cannot pass it without the use of my accommodations.  I have been denied the 
use of those accommodations during that last 3 attempts.  Because of those 
denials, my anxiety has only gotten worse creating an even more stressful 
situation while taking the test.

I have never been allowed to use any of my Section 504 accommodations, 
including my right to test privately. The FCAT has sealed my fate and 
decided my future. I have a severe anxiety disorder known as Obsessive 
Compulsive Disorder and a learning disorder known as Non Verbal Learning 
Disorder that both severely impact my ability for recall.   Each time I have 
taken the math section of the FCAT without my accommodations and failed, my 
symptoms have become worse. I have panic attacks just thinking about the 
FCAT and my future without a college degree. I worry about not receiving my 
diploma and the impact that alone will have on my future.  Numerous times,I 
have made myself ill with worry.  There is no logical reason for me not to 
pass the FCAT, other than my disabilities. I have met the Sunshine State 
Standards required to graduate with a standard high school diploma, except 
for passing the FCAT. My math teachers from the last 3 years in high school 
are writing our Superintendent of Schools to ask him to request a waiver for 
me from the State of Florida's Department of Education, because my 
disabilities won't permit me to pass the FCAT math section. I can't benefit 
from the FCAT now, after 3 failed attempts, and the State won't benefit from 
my taking it. The State of Florida has all but guaranteed that I will never 
graduate with a standard diploma and I will be left behind, despite 
President Bush's Education initiative.

I need your help. Please help me. I need you to intervene on my behalf.  I 
need an FCAT math section waiver.  I want the future I am entitled to have.  
I have worked hard for almost 12 years to keep my grades high, I have put in 
many long hours studying and building bridges over my disabilities. I have 
been an exemplary student. Because I have such trouble taking tests due to 
the impact of my disability on my ability to recall, I won't be awarded any 
scholarships to help pay for any further education, even though I have met 
the criteria with community service, course work and grades. The fact is, I 
don't test well due to my disabilities and I am being punished by the State 
because of it.

I want to be a productive member of my community and my country. Without a 
high school diploma, I cannot have a college education, a dream or a future. 
  Without a college education, I am doomed to low paying jobs and no 
opportunities to further enhance my education or reach my goals.  I will be 
a child left behind. Please help me.

I found out today that you will be visiting my high school next Tuesday, May 
14, 2002 during 5th and 6th period.  I would love the opportunity to meet 
you in person and talk with you regarding my concerns not only for myself 
but for the future of all disabled students in the state of Florida. Thank 
you for taking the time to read my letter.

Sincerely,
Christine "Kirsty" Edwards
Student, Dr. Phillips High School
Visual and Performing Arts Theatre Magnet
Orlando, Florida

From:	JLRttag@cs.com
Sent:	Saturday, May 11, 2002 8:16 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Cc:	brian.yablonski@myflorida.com
Subject:	Giving Governor Bush Credit/ The Packer

Efforts pay off as farm bill goes to Bush’s desk By Tom Karst 
(May 10) WASHINGTON, D.C. — The 2002 farm bill is signed, sealed and delivered, but the issues raised in the bill and the produce industry’s coordinated approach to make its voice heard on Capitol Hill will be long remembered. 

Amid debate that characterized the farm bill as either an obscenely expensive move toward collective agriculture or a necessary safety net for struggling American farmers, the Senate passed the farm bill 64-35 and sent it to President Bush. He was expected to sign the bill early the week of May 12. 

The bill increases agricultural spending by nearly 80% over the cost of existing programs because of added subsidies to program crops, including rice, wheat, cotton, corn and soybeans. Expected to cost $190 billion over the next decade, it has been panned by global trading partners. One economist gives the farm bill a 20% chance of exceeding WTO limits on direct subsidies to farmers in its first year. 

LITTLE DIRECT AID 

Relative to the produce industry, issues like country-of-origin labeling, export assistance and increased federal purchases of fruits and vegetables were written into the bill and will continue to make headlines in coming years. 

The produce industry received little in direct aid, though apple growers did receive $94 million in direct market loss assistance. 

U.S. Apple Association president and chief executive officer Kraig Naasz said more than two dozen senators and 50 members of the House of Representatives voiced support for the inclusion of the apple aid in the final conference report. 

The country-of-origin labeling provision of the farm bill pleased domestic growers. 

In a news release, Florida Farmers Inc., an advocacy group of Florida winter vegetable growers, commended Sen. Bob Graham, D-Fla.; Rep. Mary Bono, R-Calif.; Florida Gov. Jeb Bush; and Florida Agriculture Commissioner Charles Bronson for their efforts to keep country-of-origin labeling in the final farm bill report. 

“The grass-roots effort overcame the well-financed corporate food chain lobby to win the right to know and choose the place of origin of our food,” said Paul DiMare, chairman of Florida Farmers and president of DiMare Homestead, Homestead, Fla. 

“Country-of-origin labeling helps American consumers and those American farmers who provide food for American consumers,” he said. 

UNITED FRONT 

Naasz said the overall effort from the produce industry on the farm bill was remarkable and unprecedented. 

“The work the produce industry did under the umbrella effort afforded by United to develop an agenda and top priority policy objectives and then to assemble the troops and presented a united front to Congress was critical to the success,” he said. 

He said the work on the farm bill provides a “template” for how work on the next big issue, which he said is the reauthorization of child nutrition programs. 

“In my view, the nutrition reauthorization act offers a far greater opportunity for the produce industry to promote the increased consumption of its produce and improve the economic condition of our overall industry,” he said.

-----Original Message-----
From: McFadden, Liza 
Sent: Friday, May 10, 2002 4:36 PM
To: Cliett, Cheryl; Cole, Cristal; Elizabeth Hirst (E-mail); Katherine

Cc: Shanahan, Kathleen
Subject: Update re: reading



For those of you not at the reading meeting, wanted to provide a quick
update and also share materials for your information/review.

I AM A READER KIT 
- We are holding bi-weekly conference calls with our partners on this
project.  The key items to date have been logistical:  setting up a
process
to disseminate smoothly.  Here is where we are:

- We have a coordinated team of partners from Fl Hospital Association
(FHA),
Dept of State, Scholastic, Florida Literacy Coalition, United Way, David
Lawrence's office, etc. who are involved in every-other-week conference
calls.  This week we approved two surveys:  one will go out from FHA to
the
hospitals regarding what hospitals are currently doing; best contact
persons; ways to collaborate etc.  A separate survey will go out from
United
Way for us to "Success by Six" and other similar programs to see how we
might work cooperatively with them etc.

- We have received bids from around the state on setting up a
Fulfillment
Center which would take in orders and then place the shipments to the
hospitals (this is fairly complicated process with the number of pieces
we
have in the packages and the fact that we will issue in 3 languages).
We
are working with a partner who we believe will make a 6 year commitment
to
ensuring that this project stays up and running.  Next week we begin
working
on timeline issues.

PHONE LINE STORY TIME
- Have met with PBS and completed budget; one-page overview of program;
are
working with partner we believe will be in place by next week to serve
as
PBS sponsor and buy books airing for mentors to also read with kids!;
planning to begin (as initially targeted) the program on July 1 and
would
use the well-known PBS character "Arthur" as the first reader.   Working
on:
who handles 800#'s; capacity issues; etc.

TEEN TRENDSETTERS
- Waiting on scheduling for date to kick off.  Have sent info out to all
principals, Monday Report, etc.  AAA has come one as partner and next
week
work with them on student scheduling etc.  Also working on more connects
to
get info on program direct to students.  Great article in Florida Trend
on
program.

PR PIECES:
- McDonald's tray liners - verbiage sent out previously.  See attachment
for
the picture we believe we would like to use for billboard and tray
liner.
Comments appreciated.  McDonald's piece needs to be finalized by Tues of
next week.
- Billboards - will have draft for your review on Monday
- Winn Dixie - draft for review mid- next week.

BUSINESS CHALLENGE
- World Class has really been getting out the word!  Terrific
partnerships
coming out of there.  Look for announcement we will do next week with LG
at
Bond Ele involving World Class and Bank of America on early reading for
kindergarten kids over the summer using Open Court.  If goes well, Bank
of
America may consider taking statewide.

More happening, but if you read this far - thanks!

All is well, and my wife Stephanie and I still live in Manalapan (in another home next to the one that you were in years ago) and still very happily married.

If you are in the area of Manalapan (or Palm Beach) Thursday, June 27th, Friday 28th or Saturday 29th, in the evening between 7-9 PM, I would like very much to see you at one of these three receptions to "say a few words."

I am a member of a physician's organization; AAPS (American Association of Physician Specialists) that upon my recommendation will be having there annual meeting at the Ritz Carlton Hotel in Manalapan this June (next month).

I know that it is short notice but the Opening Reception is Thurs. 27th, I will also be personally hosting a Florida Reception the 28th at our home in Manalapan and the Presidents Reception and Dinner is Sat 29th, at the Ritz. Any brief appearance at one of these functions would give you the opportunity to get additional physician supporters and make for some good public relations.

If your schedule is full and you cannot attend I understand, then a "brief letter" that I can read to the audience of over 300 physician leaders from across the country (100 or more doctors which are politically active and practice in Florida) and their guest or families, would be great!

You are a great Governor and a man that I personally truly admire, it would be terrific to see you again real soon.

You and your family have our families' complete and unwavering support. 
Please let me know if I could be of any additional help to you now and in the future.

I don't like to give gratuitous advice but in my not so humble opinion she is a failed agency head and an albatross around your neck. I know you are loyal but there are limits.  While it is true that agency was a cesspool to begin with and substantial improvements have been made in the organization and delivery of services through your programs, the heart of coddling ineptness and failure to supervise survives.  With each scandal that surfaces there, the same theme comes up again and again. Indifferent and shirking employees with supervisors who turn a blind eye rather than rock the boat. We see an agency head who just clucks her tongue, blames her own employees but does nothing to change the institutional attitude.  This latest personal scandal with her ex-husband presents a fine opportunity for her to simply resign citing the need to attend to personal matters. 

You need a kick ass agency head. I'd go in there and for the next six months have half of DCF, all the liberal newspapers and unions screaming bloody murder but at the end of that six months you'd have employees who knew their jobs and that they better work their rear ends off doing them or they would be history and supervisors who were expected to supervise and knew they'd get full backing if they did. 

So much for my soap box.  I'll see you Monday morning without it. 

Andy

----- Original Message ----- 
From: Nora Williams <mailto:namandawilliams@yahoo.com>  
To: tlrice@adelphia.net 
Sent: Saturday, May 11, 2002 9:28 AM
Subject: News I am late delivering to you


Terry,

I announced earlier this week that I will be stepping down from my County Commission seat as of May 18th. To make a long and difficult story short, a fairly serious squabble with my health insurance company over the replacement of a failed insulin pump left me without the device for a month and sent me into a serious physical tailspin from which I am having difficulty recovering. As my family and my doctor have told me, if I'll turn the same focus on getting better and returning to stability that I have to my job as a County Commissioner, I'll be fine. So that's what I'm going to be working on for the next few months.

Naturally, I'm both weirdly relieved and a little heartbroken right now. And the not feeling well part isn't exactly helping. But I did want you to know that I have always considered you the finest example of what government service can be, and it has been a tremendous honor to work with you on issues over the issues - and a source of great joy to me to consider you a friend.

All the best always

Nora

-----Original Message-----
From: Richard Snow [mailto:drsnow88@hotmail.com]
Sent: Saturday, May 11, 2002 2:58 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Stop the Blight


May 11, 2002

Dear Governor Bush:

A positive trend is sweeping the nation and we hope with you will decide to 
further its success.  Numerous citizens of small, mostly waterfront 
communities who have been living under the threat of eminent domain are 
relieved to learn that courts are stepping in to stop the abuse of this 
power.  When private property is taken from one citizen and handed over to 
another by the government, our nation becomes similar to a communist state. 
This disheartening abuse of governmental power has been running rampant and 
unchecked until relatively recently.

Unfortunately, the Florida Legislature just passed a bill that would
facilitate the abuse of the power of eminent domain by weakening the
criteria by which an area is declared "blighted."  Oftentimes Governor Bush, 
an area is declared blighted when it is not simply as a formality in order 
to allow a local government to work closely with real estate developers. The 
properties are promised as parking lots or other amenities needed by the 
developer to further "economic development" of an area.  I thought if I 
could briefly describe our situation to you, you would have a better 
understanding of the impact on human lives of the legislation that will soon 
appear before you for your endorsement or rejection.

After graduating in August 1999, my husband, a Florida native, and I chose 
Daytona Beach as our home.  We both teach at Embry-Riddle Aeronautical 
University.  We chose our 1924 home in an historic neighborhood after 
shopping in the area from Palm Coast to Ponce Inlet for an entire year.  Now 
our city officials have declared our neighborhood "blighted."  The blight 
study was completed by a single city staffer who drove around and conducted 
a "windshield survey."

A full 86% of the homes in this "Supplemental Blight Study" are in standard 
or better condition. When I spoke with the staffer and asked her how she 
decided where to draw her red line which encompassed our house and 
approximately 60 of our neighbors' homes, she replied that the "depth is 
generally what developers need."  I ask you Governor Bush, how the needs of 
a developer constitute blighted conditions in my neighborhood!

Please do not sign this bill into law when it comes before you! My husband 
and I worked 10 years to attain our Ph.D.s and we chose to live by the sea. 
Our Daytona Beach City government has no right to abuse the power of eminent 
domain to take our home to hand over to a private real estate developer.  If 
"economic development" is the only explanation needed by officials to abuse 
this power, absolutely no home is safe.  Any resident's home could be taken 
and the area could become another theme park or the like to raise the local 
tax base.  The eminent domain power was created to better communities by 
either ridding a community of slum-like conditions, or to seize private 
property for a sound PUBLIC purpose.

Please take a stand against the state legislature by opposing the
facilitation of government infringement on private property rights!

Feel free to write or call with any questions or comments.

Sincere thanks for your consideration,
Drs. Mary and Rich Snow
628 Vermont Ave
Daytona Beach, FL 32118
386 226 8514

From:	Kathleen Kearney <Kathleen_Kearney@dcf.state.fl.us>
Sent:	Saturday, May 11, 2002 7:04 PM
To:	lcrawfo2@tampabay.rr.com
Subject:	Re: Family Continuity Programs (FCP)


Dear Lauri,

Thank you so much for sending me this e-mail.  My heart breaks for the
wonderful case workers like you that get up every morning and give it their
all for Florida's children.  Your voice is the one that must be heard and
believed -- not those that call themselves "advocates" and do nothing to
help repair a system that is beyond broken.  The description of your
average day at Family Continuity is an eye-opener.  I've been lobbying
Congress for three years to change the federal requirements (e.g. the IV-E
time logs you mention for one) to make it easier on the workers in the
field.  I hope that you will let me use your e-mail as an example of the
true impact of this on families.  Community-based care was designed to free
up workers to spend time with families, not bog them down in paperwork.

I hope that the St. Pete Times will print your e-mail.  Your passion for
the profession is an inspiration in these challenging times.  Thank you for
your work on behalf of the children of Pasco and Pinellas counties.  They
are lucky to have a person like you in their corner.

Lauri Crawford

one year, have in my past been a  probation/parole officer for the state of
florida, the state of massachusetts, a foster mother for extremely

Lauri Crawford


~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

5/11/02

To tell the complete story, one must hear the 'other side'.  I sincerely
hope you find the means to publish this as well.

Dear Curtis and Howard,

I'm writing you because I'm an employee of Family Continuity Programs (FCP)
and read your articles in the St. Pete Times.  I'm a case manager who
supervises nearly 40 children.  So you'll understand exactly what this
means let me explain....  One child is actually part of a woven dynamic
that may involve his biological parents, step parents, paramours if his
parents are living with a partner, a relative placement/non-relative
placement or licensed foster family if he's removed.  Thus, this ONE
child's supervision is actually equivalent to supervising 7 people,
providing both parents are divorced, each have another partner, and the
child's been removed, which is often the case.  Thus, 'one' child does NOT
mean 'one' child under my supervision...it means supervising the whole
family dynamic.  Additionally, 40 children does not mean 40 families.  For
example, I could have 20 families, each with 2 children, and that would
equal the 40 children I'm supervising while having 20 cases (families).

With every child comes enormous paperwork - on ALL parties involved with
this ONE child.  There's the case plan we write after reviewing the file,
there's the hearing to file said case plan which we must attend, there's
the additional referrals we hand-write and explain to all parties involved
so they'll clearly understand the case plan they're required to complete,
there's the initial judicial review we write at 90 days which is
approximately 15 pages long (this is a status update to the court regarding
the family's progress and requires us to be at the court hearing), there's
the referral packets we put together for this family (between  5-20  pages
upon completion) that is a requirement of most programs,  there's the
endless phone calls to all providers requesting proof, or lack thereof, of
attendance of these programs we have referred the family to, there's the
endless phone calls to and from the families and FCP attorneys regarding
other problems we must address,  there's the continual ongoing diligent
searches we must complete for absent parents, there's the supervised
visitations we must arrange and supervise if court ordered, there's the
transportation we must provide to assist this family if they don't own a
car or can't take the bus, there's the multiple staffings we must arrange
to evaluate and re-evaluate permanency goals, there's the required
one-time-per-week home visit if this family is determined 'high risk', or,
the required every-other-week home visit if this family is determined
'medium risk', or, the required one home visit per month if this family is
determined 'low risk' which requires a 5 page packet that must be filled
out at every monthly home visit,  there's the paperwork we must do if this
family is in need of financial assistance, there's the continual 6 month
judicial review we must write for this family until the case is closed and
attend the hearing, there's the updated case plan we must re-write and file
when it expires (between 12-18 months), and there's the chronology notes we
must write every time we so much as speak to this family, and the list goes
on and on.  And this is for ONE family only.

Multiply this by 20 families, and I think you get the picture of our
workload.  Of course there's the children that come in through ICPC (out of
state/interstate compact) that require a written home study,  supervision
and monthly home visits if approved, and referrals (their state does the
required legal paperwork - we only report quarterly), and there's the
courtesy supervision cases from other counties that we do the same.  Out of
approximately 20 families, I maybe have 3 of these kinds of cases.

Simultaneously, I have other cases who's children have run-away and I'm
forced to stop what I'm doing to write a pick-up order, simultaneously I'm
getting calls from other families who are in the midst of a break down I
must tend to, simultaneously I'm getting calls from foster families who
want children out NOW, thus, I'm running out to pick up said child while
arranging alternate placement with our placement coordinator,
simultaneously I'm getting a call from the JAC Center stating they've
picked up my runaway and I must get this child within so many hours and
either return said child to his placement or have a shelter hearing first
thing in the morning to change placement, simultaneously I have 2
arraignments in the morning and 4 Judicial Reviews in the afternoon I must
attend, simultaneously I have 2 permanency staffings scheduled in between
my court times, simultaneously I'm still trying to find placement for this
child since the morning, to no avail, and in between all, I'm writing this
all down because I can't do ANYTHING without chrono notes for the files.
It's now 8P and after getting breakfast, lunch, and dinner for this child,
I'm still at the office awaiting placement for him and could be here until
10P at this rate, and it's only Monday...

This does not include the daily time logs we're required to do in no less
than 15 minute increments (this is a report of EVERYTHING we've done to
account for our time - every day of every week).  This does not include the
tracking logs we're required to do every Monday.  This does not include the
'unannounced' minimum monthly home visits we must do - which means we have
to work after 6P when the children get home from their required day care
programs. This does not include the one week of 'on-call' we're required to
do from 5P to 8A every 3-4 months.  This does not include the continual
meetings and trainings we must attend to either get our certifications or
maintain them.

My caseload is supposed to be no more than 20 children; it's now at 36 and
climbing all the time.  Why?  We do all of the above for an approximate
salary of $27,000 per year working 50+ hours per week, so the burnout and
turnover rate is enormous.  We do home visits at night by ourselves, we
transport children by ourselves at all hours of the day and night putting
ourselves at risk for the obvious, and we're not equipped with cell phones
in the field - which would not only increase our safety, but make us more
available to our families when needed.   When families say we don't care,
that we don't tend to their emergencies in a timely manner, let me say
this...what an emergency is to a family, and what an emergency is to a case
manager, are two completely different entities. When a family calls and
says, "This is an emergency, Susie won't go to school..." and on the other
line I have a mother telling me her paramour beat her last night and abused
the children, it's obvious which 'emergency' a case manager will tend to
first - EVERYTHING ELSE must be put on hold - including Susie. The
responsibilities to our families and children is incredible, and add the
mounds of paperwork that is a required priority...and you wonder, who would
even consider this job....

Well, let me tell you....

We are case managers who love children dearly and feel a need to save them
from one more day of trauma.  We work for a wonderful organization called
FCP who understands our plight and supports us emotionally.   Like you, we
are mothers, fathers, sons and daughters.  We do our job the best we can,
with the limited resources we have, in the face of overwhelming adversity,
because we genuinely care.   When we hear in the media we don't have a
conscience, I'm sorry, I tend to take that personally.  It's not the case
managers you should be pointing your finger at, it's the system we work
under that needs reform.  All I ask is you walk in our shoes for one
week...just one week...and I'm sure you'll never point your finger again -
not at us anyway.

Lauri Crawford
FCP Case Manager

Hi Berthy,  I got your message asking for details on our budget and how
we are faring.  Here is the breakdown.  All of our budget requests were
matched by the Governor, House and Senate with the exception of the
Clearinghouse (CH) on Disability Information.
 
CH - House: Item #422 = 1 FTE included in a total allocation of $123,158
CH - Senate: Item #741 = 1 FTE included in total allocation of $234,817
CH - Governor = 1 FTE and expenses totaling $250,000
 
The FTE with salaries and benefits costs $48,372.

Hola Jeb:

In the multitude of issues that you have to deal with, this is a minute
one, but I feel responsible to give you my perspective in the conflict
situation related to the accessibility code conflict on the ADAWG.

The technical aspect of the accessibility code issue is a complex matter
which I do not understand very much.  Angel WATS, and JR Harding seem to
be the board members with greatest knowledge on the issue, and they were
in disagreement.  Julie Shaw, is also knowledgeable about the issue, so
the disagreement on this issue may not have anything to do with a
personality conflict between Julia and Angel.  I do want to share with
you that there is a clear personality conflict between Angel and Julie,
which is less apparent now that Angel is not the chair, but still very
obvious.  I privately addressed the issue with Julie during our last
meeting, as I do not think it portraits a good image to the public.  I
think she heard me, and I hope that she deals with the issue.  My
impressions of Julie, is that she is a strong advocate, and very
knowledgeable across disability issues, but she can sometimes appear to
be rough.

Carinos

On Sat, 11 May 2002 15:54:03 -0400 "Shaw, Julie" <ShawJ@dms.state.fl.us>
writes:
Wow do I feel attacked.  It appears you are basing your response on an
opinion Doug told you or you are taking this personally.  I  have already
notified all people involved about the ADAWG decision and the content of
the
letter to come, in fact that evening of the vote, again the next day,
Friday
afternoon and in subsequent meetings in Tallahassee which have been
numerous.  
 
What you don't seem to understand is that the Governor will determine his
position on the issue.  I have no stance in my current role.  I can only
share what the intent at that time was.  The letter would have gone
earlier
if the bill was not delayed by the Senate.  I am watching it very
closely.
The letter will be in the Governor's Office before he receives the bill. 
It
will be included.  The Governor makes no comments to emails or
correspondence on pending legislation until his decision is made.  The
process to have a decision doesn't even begin until the bill hits the
Governor's Office.  Everything is collected, organized and a report
written
reflecting all views, issues, etc.  Then he makes the decision and no one
else.
 
I can only apologize for my email workload.  I currently have 578 emails
in
my system and over 100 not opened.  I am not the entry point for
Governor's
communication.  I forwarded the initial emails on the subject to board
members.  I had several complaints about them.  But from what I can tell,
all of the letters have been collected by OPB and there was a coordinated
effort to do that.  I try to process as many emails as possible daily,
skim
titles and content if necessary and handle the priorities first.  Based
on
the delay of the bill - it is still in the Senate - it was not a priority
compared to other items pending.  The Governor has up to 15 days once his
office receives the bill to make a decision.
 
No members advised me the Clarification Statement was confusing.  You
kept
saying it was to other members but no one spoke up or asked for
assistance
during the break when the questions were being composed.  If there was
confusion I believe it is because the code is a very technical issue and
if
you do not work with it daily or frequently it is impossible to
understand.
 
 
I don't have a position until the Governor's decision is made. ADAWG's
board
has a position which has been clearly communicated.  Individuals may have
a
position and some associations do.  
 
I am no longer a private sector employee.  My interest 100% was to
protect
the access code  and the interests of people with disabilities as much as
possible in my role overseeing all 3 programs for the Governor and as an
advocate for compliance with the ADA or a better standard.  That agenda
has
never changed.  Just because I am in a different role compared to a
private
lobbyist does not mean my understanding of the code, needs of people with
disabilities, commitment etc. has changed.  
 
We have a difference of opinion about how much damage, if any, the
amendment
could do to the access code if passed into law.  But we aren't the only
ones.  And I believe that can be considered the good or the bad things
about
making laws.
 
Your expertise on building codes has never been doubted.  The issue is
you
take positions on certain items not everyone agrees with.  And just
because
there is a disagreement does not mean the other opinion has an ulterior
motive or change in agenda.  To say that this is not a priority of the
ADAWG
Office or the Governor's is a statement not based on fact.  The
Governor's
commitment to people with disabilities and this office is clearly seen
time
and time again in the agendas pursued and changes made.  Once again,
there
has been NO decision or position determined by the Governor to date.   
 
Your motions to not ask the Governor's Office to consult with me on
issues
in the future, I believe is a reflection of you personalizing this
difference of opinion.  I apologize if I am misinterpreting you actions
differently.

From:	Naamonlewis@cs.com
Sent:	Sunday, May 12, 2002 1:42 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	RE: CS/SB160 (Waserman-Schultz)

Governor Jeb Bush
The Capitol
400 South Monroe St.
Tallahassee, Fl  32399-0001

Dear Gov. Bush:

On behalf of the patrons of the dog tracks and poker rooms in Florida, I 
would like to encourage you to Support Senate Bill 160.

Greyhounds are dogs that must run.it is their nature and they enjoy it.  
Greyhounds have very sweet dispositions and make wonderful pets when their 
careers are over.  It is with this  Bill 160  that more greyhounds will be 
adopted.  Through the Support of this legislation, the greyhounds adoption 
program will be mandatory at ALL DOG TRACKS.

As it is now  more animals are killed in just one humane society shelter than 
all the greyhounds in the United States.  For this reason alone yhou should 
SUPPORT  BILL 160.

The poker rooms at the tracks have numerous employees that will be unemployed 
if the card rooms close.  Increasing the stakes of the poker games will not 
only bring in more people, but also more REVENUE TO THE STATE OF FLORIDA.  We 
have to many $'s passing through FLordia and going out  to SEA, that we don't 
benefit from.

By forcing the Poker Rooms to support the Greyhounds, this will benefit the 
greyhound adoption program and save jobs.

PLEASE SUPPORT BILL 160

From:	Pat Owens <stitchabq@earthlink.net>
Sent:	Sunday, May 12, 2002 6:41 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Before you.....

Hi,

I was just sitting here studying the picture of little Rilya Wilson on my 
computer screen considering the situation and thought of a few things. I 
offer them as suggestions as what I would do if  I could....

1. Go back to the beginning. Identify Rilya Wilson from the date of her 
birth. Establish paternity.

2. Reestablish the time line of the disappearance. Who was where when. And 
don't take anyone's word for anything.  Court admissible proof only.

3. Call "all in free" in the DCF.  Shake out who is where and for how 
long.  Once you know what else has happened you will know more about where 
in the system you should look.  Nothing like a little spring housecleaning 
to clean out those cobwebs and show you where the spiders live. And a few 
pet spiders can be very helpful at times.

You have a lot of good people in the DCF  who are simply overwhelmed and 
out classed by those who would do them in. In bringing in a reformer to 
clean up the system you were seen to blame them and not the system.  And 
Kathleen Kearney's reputation preceded her. Very few people in this world 
will openly say "I don't understand" or "I'm lost help me" to someone 
brought in for the express purpose of reforming a department. To avoid 
saying anything that would even hint incompetence, they stonewalled her or 
told her what they think she wanted to hear. Nothing changed! I saw it by 
running the exact same letter by various people in the system from top to 
bottom and getting to see what they said to me and to others in return. It 
was very illuminating. They will bad mouth one of their own or shuffle 
departments to cover up their own confusion. They will even sacrifice one 
of their own on the altar of self preservation. They're completely normal 
in an abnormal system. Once they see you understand that, they will be much 
more open with you and you will be on the way to solving the overall 
problem not just the case at hand. Do nothing and it will happen again and 
again and again.

Do I think Rilya is lost in the system? Not really. I'm still waiting to 
hear who Rilya really is.  Okay, if you accept the notion we know who Rilya 
really is and who her family is, do I think someone from the DCF came and 
took Rilya away some nefarious purpose? No. Someone took her away but I 
doubt strongly it was the DCF. My best guess based on limited access to 
information would be that she was sold off to the drug trade as a mule. Who 
did? You have to figure that one out.

Here's a wild suggestion as to how to get a hint on how to solve the case. 
A new tv show based in Miami is just about the surest thing in television. 
It's called CSI-Miami. Every episode is a mystery to be solved by evidence. 
The writers think up elaborate schemes to solve every day. Give them a shot 
at the evidence so far and ask the writers to write you an ending.  Want 
the phone number for the production office of the series? I have it.

Just my musings on a lazy Sunday afternoon.




Pat Owens

Stitched Together/Stitchers@ABQ Needlework
9800 Montgomery NE Ste 1A
Albuquerque, NM 87111
505-293-2221

-----Original Message-----
From: Brewser [mailto:brewserbrown@hotmail.com]
Sent: Sunday, May 12, 2002 6:33 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Contents of http://www.pensacolanewsjournal.com/news/051202/Local/ST003.shtml



PUBLISHED SUNDAY, MAY 12, 2002


Commission stand-ins get early kudos


Array of experience, diversity seen as pluses for interim county leaders


Bios and Q&As

 <mailto:ginnygraybiel@pensacolanewsjournal.com> Ginny Graybiel
@PensacolaNewsJournal.com

A retired newspaper publisher who golfs with many of Pensacola's older and well-regarded leaders.

A longtime legislative aide with a knack for helping people and scrutinizing budgets.

A retired educator who calls people "darlin"' and is a popular member of the Pensacola City Council.

A retired vice admiral who works in Pensacola's most elite academic and research circles.

Cliff Barnhart, Janice Gilley, Marie Young and Tim Wright will be sworn in this week as Escambia County commissioners.

Gov. Jeb Bush selected them from 158 applicants to fill in for indicted and suspended commissioners W.D. Childers, Terry Smith, Willie Junior and Mike Bass. They've all promised to act as `'caretakers" until the indictees' charges are resolved or another election comes along, and they've agreed not to seek election on their own.

After months of turmoil capped off by the indictments of every commissioner except Tom Banjanin, a number of board watchers are looking at the appointees as opportunity knocking.

"It's a great group," said former state Rep. Buzz Ritchie. "In terms of their involvement with the community, they are certainly well qualified, and they're all good people."

They're also a diverse group.

Barnhart, Gilley and Wright are Republicans; Young is a Democrat.

Young is only the second black member of the board. Junior, who served for 19 years, was the first.

Young and Gilley are the second and third women members. The pioneer, Muriel Wagner, represented District 4 from 1985 to 1989 but lost her re-election bid.

Frank Montenes, who attends most commission meetings and is a leading advocate of a switch to charter government, likes the fact the appointees come from different backgrounds.

"If you look at their credentials, they're pretty well-balanced," he said. "The best way to sum it up is that these are people who are in touch with reality and in touch with the grass roots. They're going to allow the community to rally around them and heal and cooperate."


Business experience


Barnhart, 80, the District 1 appointee, has a lot of support among Pensacola's business community as well as among affluent retirees as Childers' replacement.

Pensacola businessman Eric Nickelsen, one of Bush's top local advisers, said Barnhart fits the bill perfectly for temporary commissioner.

"He's a retired CEO," he said. "He certainly has the knowledge. He's respected. He's a consensus- builder type of personality. We needed someone with the leadership abilities and the time."

Pensacola lawyer M.J. Menge, a longtime community activist, said any concerns about Barnhart keeping up because of his age are misplaced.

"I play golf with him, and he surely doesn't act like he's 80 years of age," Menge said. "He stays up with what's going on and is very interested in the community."

Barnhart, who spent his working life in journalism, moved to Pensacola in 1978 as publisher of the News Journal and remained here after retirement in 1984.

Barnhart's son, Scott, also has Republican political connections that may have helped his father.

The younger Barnhart worked as an aide to former U.S. Sen. Connie Mack, the Republican from Florida, and now works as a lobbyist in Washington, D.C.

Former District 1 Commissioner Wilson Robertson was the other top contender for the seat.

Robertson did not seek re-election in 2000 because of his wife's poor health. But she is better, and he was willing to bring his experience back to the temporary slot.

But Nickelsen and Menge, a Democrat with many contacts among Bush's advisers, said the governor made it clear early that he was not going to pick a former commissioner.

"The local advisers told the governor that Wilson Robertson was just as acceptable, but they also said they were fully supportive of Cliff Barnhart," Menge said.

Nickelsen said Bush also received several e-mails from local residents who felt that Robertson, while he has never been associated with scandal or wrongdoing, represents the commission's old guard.

"I'm glad they didn't go with Wilson," said Ann Sanborn, who attends most commission meetings. "He's a nice guy, but it's more of the same."

State Rep. Jerry Maygarden said that Eugene Franklin, owner of Franklin Mortgage & Investment Co., also got a serious look. In 1998, the Pensacola Area Chamber of Commerce honored his firm as the Minority Business of the Year.

"The governor wanted diversity," Maygarden said. "So all of the African-American candidates were looked at carefully. The recommendations concerned his work in the Chamber of Commerce and his personal business background."


Military and education


Wright, who rose to vice admiral during his Navy career, was an early favorite for the District 2 slot held by Bass.

He retired as chief of the Naval Education and Training Command at Pensacola Naval Air Station in 1996 and immediately made himself a big part of the civilian world.

He is associate director of the University of West Florida Institute of Human and Machine Cognition, the cutting-edge research center that studies improving human performance through computer applicatios.

Republican leaders have called upon Wright before for short-term projects:

Last year, Escambia School Superintendent Jim Paul selected him as chairman of a 10-member panel to study school closures and consolidations. Although the committee recommended cuts that would have freed $2 million for teacher raises, the School Board bypassed most of its recommendations.

In 1997, then-U.S. Rep. Joe Scarborough appointed Wright to a commission to study TRICARE, the military's managed health-care program.

Last year, Wright was one of 46 applicants for the University of West Florida's board of trustees. Bush did not select him for that position.

"Admiral Wright truly is a leader," said Menge, who was chairman of the Chamber of Commerce's armed services committee when the admiral was at the Naval Air Station. "He has a personality that commands respect. He's got good judgment. I've also found him to be very receptive to different ideas."

Menge has no doubt Wright will shed his admiral's stars in a district that is rich with military retirees who have listened to admirals all their lives.

"I think the citizens are going to put aside his former position and see how he deals with issues that come before the county today," he said.

Former state Rep. Lois Benson, who chaired the TRICARE commission, also was a contender for the District 2 site. But she was hurt by the fact that she has lost races for Congress, the state Senate and Pensacola mayor.

"The governor just decided he wasn't going to put someone in office the voters had rejected before," Nickelsen said.

State Rep. Jerry Maygarden said Roger MacDonald, the retired owner of Manpower temporary services, also was considered.

"He had all the right business experience and skill," he said.


Crossing party lines


In choosing Young to replace Junior in the majority-Democratic District 3, Bush elected to cross party lines.

Republican Ulysses Hughes, a well-regarded educator, was another top contender.

He is administrator of the Ruby Gainer Charter School, a cause dear to Bush's heart. He also served 31 years in the Escambia School District before retiring as assistant superintendent in 1991.

He also was on the steering committee that helped elect Superintendent Paul. Later, Paul drew criticism from some Republican quarters by selecting Democrat Norm Ross as his assistant superintendent rather than bringing back Hughes.

It was Nickelsen who asked Young to apply for the commission slot.

Comfortable on the City Council, the thought had not occurred to her.

She had planned to run next November for a final, two-year term on the City Council. But, since her County Commission stint most likely will expire in 2004, it also fit in with her plans.

"I had time to pray over it and talk it through with my husband," she said.

She agreed to apply. But when Bush actually tapped her, she was surprised.

"He's smart to put a Democrat in," she said. "I thought he was on the other side of the fence, but I have a lot of confidence in him now."

Katie Holmes, secretary of the Northwest Florida Young Democrats, said Young's selection is a relief.

"Our biggest concern was making sure District 3 was dealt with fairly," she said. "And the only fair thing in that district would be to appoint a Democrat."

Nickelsen said Young's selection should not have been a surprise, even though Hughes also is well-qualified.

"That district has elected a Democrat for 16 years," he said. "The governor wanted to pick people who are reflective of the district. He wasn't going to ram down his choices."

Nickelsen also said Young's reputation is impeccable.

"She personifies Christianity," he said. "She's steadfast in what she believes."

Mike Wiggins, who serves on the City Council with Young, called her "a magnificent lady and a superb public servant."

Her strength, he said, is building bridges.

"She's a peacemaker," he said. "I think she has the ability to effect a compromise when many think a compromise is not possible. Everyone walks away feeling good."

Maygarden said Bush was well aware of Young's talents in that regard.

"She has demonstrated to the community that she's a coalition builder," Maygarden said. "She's not on the fringe anywhere. She's got a lot of talent that's under the surface. I don't think she gets enough credit."


Political bridge-builder


In District 5, there was no contest over Gilley's selection to replace Smith.

Gilley has been an aide to Maygarden for seven years, currently working as staff director of the House Majority Office.

In 1999, when Escambia School Board member Vanette Webb was charged with breaking the public records law and suspended, Bush appointed Gilley to fill her spot. She served five months.

Maygarden said Bush didn't know Gilley well when he appointed her to the School Board but was comfortable she would do a good job.

"She really did do a good job, and I think that elevated her in the governor's eyes a whole lot," Maygarden said. "He would have been hard-pressed not to pick her again."

Nickelsen agreed.

"Why not go back to the well?" he said.

Maygarden can't say enough positive things about Gilley, particularly in her desire to help people.

"Aside from having a very outgoing, warm and cordial personality, she's the epitome of Will Rogers: She never met a stranger," he said. "She's very sincere in her effort to be helpful and supportive to constituents."

Gilley, like Young, also has a reputation as an easy-to-work- with bridge-builder.

"Janice is very good at making everybody get along," said Republican activist Jeanne Godwin, another local adviser to Bush. "She does not have an ego that gets in the way. She's fair and objective, and she builds a cohesive, unified feeling in a group."

The fact that Bush selected two women for the board also draws praise.

"Hooray," said Ellen Roston, president of the League of Women Voters of the Pensacola Bay Area.

The two women's political backgrounds are an extra bonus.

"It's nice that Marie Young has had experience with the City Council and the same with Janice Gilley with the Legislature," Roston said. "I like to see people coming in with some experience."

Nickelsen said the thing that the new appointees have in common is a willingness to serve community interests above their own.

"There's honesty and integrity among all of them," he said, "and that's certainly what we're looking for."

From:	Michele Williams <fape4kids@netzero.net>
Sent:	Sunday, May 12, 2002 9:07 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Chistine (Kirsty) Edwards

Governor Bush,
 
I am writing to you on behalf of a learning disabled student whose family are my clients.  I first became an education consultant/advocate because it was so difficult to get an appropriate education for my own disabled children that I knew average parents could never make it through our education system.  After 13 years' experience at it, I know that even outstanding, highly educated parents often can't use the system as it is designed to be used.  Kirsty's family is the perfect example.
 
Kirsty Edwards is a learning disabled student who is consistently an A-B student in the honors curriculum at the Visual and Performing Arts Theatre Magnet at Dr. Phillips High School in 
Orlando, Florida.  Despite everything her parents have done, despite all my efforts in her behalf, the Department of Education of the State of Florida itself stands in the way of Kirsty getting the diploma she is working so hard to earn.  
 
Florida's Department of Education in its wisdom put together a list of "acceptable" accommodations for standardized testing that is so limited that many students may not be able to have the accommodations they need to pass the HSCT or FCAT.  DOE insists that only one or two students have requested to have accommodations not on that list.  I maintain that is because parents are not educated by Florida's schools to know they SHOULD request accommodations during testing, much less accommodations other than what are on the list.  I also believe that to use any such list is discriminatory, since no list can contain all the possible variations of accommodations a student might require for appropriate testing.  Denying a student any accommodation he/she needs to have equal opportunity to show on a test what he/she has learned is discriminatory, and Florida is doing it consistently with HSCT and FCAT testing.
 
It is only after months of effort that we discovered the procedure for getting a waiver to the FCAT, and even with Kirsty's history, we can not be certain she will be given the waiver.  Only one thing is certain.  If she is not given the waiver, Kirsty's future in Florida is the same as any dropout who does not know a third of what she knows and has never applied himself/herself to any study endeavor.  
 
There is a bill before the legislature now to allow standardized testing to be given with any/all accommodations listed on the students' IEPs.  That bill is far less discriminatory than what exists now, because what exists now is pure discrimination and nothing less.  I do not recall at this moment if the bill would allow accommodations listed on disabled students Section 504 Accommodation Plans, but if it does not, it must be amended to do so.  
 
Given that the State already has a contingent of people who realize the discriminatory nature of the FCAT accommodations list and are seeking to change our procedures to something more ethical and legal, it would not be inappropriate for you to use your gubernatorial discretion to request an exemption from the FCAT for any disabled students who require accommodations currently not appearing on that list if the students' academic records show the students obviously meet all other requirements for a diploma.  Surely you must be able to appoint a small committee of people to examine academic records and conduct quick interviews of school staff to determine whether disabled students who can't pass the HSCT/FCAT are otherwise fully qualified to hold Florida diplomas so these students could be exempted from the HSCT/FCAT process. Would you check to see if you can use your authority in that way for these students until more appropriate accommodations are available to them?  
 
You call yourself the Education Governor.  Quite frankly, I think it would be embarrassing to have to explain how you are our "Education Governor" if you could not move DOE's heaven and earth to allow qualified students to have the diplomas they have earned.  There simply must be something you can do, since denying good students diplomas would be a blemish on the honor of our State.  I believe this denial could also open the State to possible lawsuits alleging discrimination against disabled students.  Since the list is clearly discriminatory and no one disagrees with that, it defies reason to understand why it has not been replaced with non-discriminatory procedures, and such adherence to obvious discriminatory procedures practically begs for lawsuits.  I do my best to find alternative strategies for parents to use, but in this case....we really need you to use your Education-ness in our students' behalf.
 
Kirsty Edwards has requested to meet with you when you visit her school on May 14.  I am requesting that when you speak with her, if only for 5 minutes, please let her know whether you have the power to intervene for her and other students in her situation, and let her know what you or someone else can do to help.  
 
I will appreciate anything you can do to help Kirsty and other disabled students like her.  
 
Sincerely,
 
Michele Williams
Education Consultant/Advocate
"The success of a child is the true measure of the adults who surround him."

From: frankh [mailto:frankh@mymailstation.com]
Sent: Saturday, May 11, 2002 1:50 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: (draft only) ACSI/UCG Teacher of the Year Award 


Jeb, this is a draft only, it is really worth the read.  This is what I
want you to joint announce with ACSI.  It is good for Florida education
(ACSI now has 350 schools in Florida).  Tentatively, will you consider a
joint announcement of this PILOT program with ACSI sometime the end of
May?  See below: frank
Dear Administrator,                    May 2002
The Florida Region is pleased to announce the ACSI/United Christian
Giving (UCG) Teacher of the Year Program which will begin this coming
fall.  The program will recognize, honor and award three teachers from
our region for their contributions to Christian education and their
Godly impact on the lives of students and parents.
ACSI has always had the goal of equipping teachers and schools to
minister more effectively for the Lord.  We believe this program will
allow us to honor fine Christian educators in our state and will serve
as an encouragement to other teachers.  These Teacher of the Year
winners will be asked to represent Christian edcuation no only at their
own school but also as an ambassador for the Lord throughout the region.
We are asking each school administrator to review the staff of their
school and nominate those teachers who best exemplify the Lord Jesus
Christ and solid Christian philosophy of education. These teachers will
then fill out the application form and attach the other required
documentation (Administrative Questionaire, support letters, school
recommendation letter and videotape).  These materials should be sent to
the Florida regional office by September 3, 2002, where they will be
reviewed by a selection committee.  The committee will then select three
teachers (one each from the early education, elementary and secondary
levels) as the ACSI/UCG Florida Teacher of the Year.  The awards wil be
presented at the Florida Teachers Convention on November 25-26, 2002 in
Orlando.
We are especially thankful for the support of United Christian Giving, a
non-profit foundation in the Ft Myers area.  United Christian Giving is
made up of Christian business men and women who are supportive of
numerous ministry opportunities.  The foundation has pledged to give
each Teacher of the Year a $2,500. cash gift along with a $1,000. cash
gift to that teacher's school.
We look forward to your participation in this program.  If you have any
questions, please feel free to contact us.  May the Lord bless you as
you faithfully serve Him.
In His Service,
David M. Ray
Florida Regional Director (ACSI)

-----Original Message-----
From: David Farrar [mailto:farrardm@bellsouth.net]
Sent: Thursday, May 09, 2002 10:32 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Incase you missed my last message


Governor,

 

You wanted to know my suggestion on how I would deal with the issue of the single-insured in the new Healthcare Plan.

 I will try to be brief.  But since this is not my area of expertise, I may be a trifle long...please bear with me.

 

I have briefly scanned through SB 46-I Health Care bill, mainly the "clean claim" section, the pilot health flex plan and the single insured provision.  

 

Since I view the primary reason for higher medical premiums almost exclusively on uncontrolled medical costs, forcing carriers to pay medical providers before a clean claim will simply allow the medical industry to gouge the consumer even more.  The clean claim proviso will make it even harder for carriers to hold down medical costs, or even develop an incentive to do so.

 

Governor, I am a court reporter. All I do all day long is take EUOs (examination under oaths) and IMEs (independent medical examination) testimony. Under our present structure there is no incentive for medical providers to cut costs. And as long as the insurance industry can simply go to the state and raise premiums to meet rising costs, they will not play their natural and vital role in reducing costs -- that leaves the consumer virtually powerless and defenseless. We should be passing laws that strengthen the insurance carrier's hands in making sure these medical costs are reasonable, necessary and affordable.  The mere fact that insurance carriers are not asking the Legislature for more tools to address rising medical costs tells me the direction of this bill is headed in the wrong direction.

 

The health flex pilot plan is designed to help provide medical coverage for the uninsured whose family gross income equals to or less than 200 percent of the federal poverty level, about $30,000 per year. I make around $60,000 a year, gross. I pay about $800 per month in medical coverage for my wife, daughter and myself. This amount is due to go up to $890 next year. I will not be able to afford 150 percent increase on this amount. I also will not qualify for your health flex plan at present, neither will a lot of other one-life groups. There is at present no safety net for us. The health flex plan must be far more developed to insure that no one is singled out to carry an unfair burden or be left behind.

 

That leaves me with the single insured issue. I have nothing against joining a larger consumer group if the transition is seamless and harmless. I see nothing in this bill that assures me that bringing one-lifers into a larger consumer pool will be a simple matter of paperwork. I have paid into my present medical coverage for the past 15 years with very little medical expense. At my age, I am not a very good prospect to a new insurance carrier and would be an enticing target to jettison by my insurance carrier if given half a chance. The law must ensure the pooling of one-life groups is carried out in a transparent and professional manner.

 

Yes, Governor, there are good provisions in this bill, and insurance reform is needed. But this bill is premature in its design and puts people at risk needlessly. 

 

I know you will do your best to do what is right, as you have done before. But no irreversible harm will come from putting this reform bill off another year so adequate provisions can be made to protect all the people.

 

ex animo

 

davidfarrar

From:	Nina Oviedo <oviedon@sso.org>

Team---------We feel that Nelson's efforts are clearly political.  We talked
to his staff almost daily last week and no one mentioned the e-mail letter;

telling Graham about amendments. We also have left a message for our WH
contacts.

We spoke w/ USTR contacts this morning.  A deal has been cut and Daschle and
Lott will be opposing all amendments.  USTR anticipates heavy debate Wed and
Thurs w/ hopes of a vote on Thursday.

We also spoke with Andy LaVigne who understands the current situation and
told us that he has talked to Graham and Nelson's staff and said, "If the
deal is cut, offer the amendment, talk about it, and withdraw it."  Andy
takes the view that if we push too hard, we/citrus will hurt ourselves in
future negotiations.

As soon as we have a few more pieces...we will call...to talk about whether
we respond in writing.  At this time, we feel that by responding we escalate
the political rhetoric.

Melissa is currently working on the Bacardi letter and we'll have that to
you later today for review.  Nina.



-----Original Message-----
From: Yablonski, Brian [mailto:Brian.Yablonski@MyFlorida.com]
Sent: Friday, May 10, 2002 5:57 PM
To: Dana, Pam; Oviedo, Nina; Jimenez, Frank
Cc: Shanahan, Kathleen; 'jeb@jeb.org'
Subject: RE: Trade legislation

Nina, can you call Andy/Jennifer and find out what gives -- this is clearly
the broader amendment -- did Citrus just ignore our counsel? any
expectations subsequent to our conversations from last week?

Daschle and the White House have a deal -- so amendment just appears to be
going through the motions.

Option 1:  Do a letter back to the senators indicating support for tpa and
support for a narrower amendment that applies to citrus, reiterate that we
have contacted multiple parties on the issue, including grassley, and that
we will be involved in trade negotiations and looking out for florida's
interests.
Finally, expose Nelson in letter for his true intentions.

Option 2: Ignore the letter -- it is political and nothing else.  If asked
by reporters, we can state the above.



-----Original Message-----
From: Dana, Pam
