-----Original Message-----
From: Bill_Nelson@billnelson.senate.gov
[mailto:Bill_Nelson@billnelson.senate.gov]
Sent: Wednesday, May 08, 2002 7:48 PM
To: jeb.bush@myflorida.com
Subject: Trade legislation


Dear Governor Bush:

We are writing to seek your partnership in a matter of vital importance to
the Florida citrus industry.  We are contacting you by e-mail because our
efforts to reach you by telephone late last week were unsuccessful.

In preparation for the Senate's final consideration of the Trade Promotion
Authority bill, we drafted an amendment that would help ensure the Florida
citrus industry is afforded fair treatment in future trade agreements.  In
essence, our amendment would prevent any negotiated reduction in the tariff
on
Brazilian frozen concentrated orange juice from taking effect until the
Brazilian citrus industry ceases its unfair trade practices, specifically
dumping.

In crafting this amendment, we have consulted closely with Florida Citrus
Mutual, the Florida Department of Citrus and the Florida Department of
Agriculture and Consumer Services, and we are assured this language has
their
consensus support.  They and we agree our chances of success are maximized
by an
amendment that is broad enough to attract support from similarly situated
industries - and Senators from affected states.  That is why our amendment
would
benefit several other industries subject to unfair foreign competition, and
not
just the citrus industry.  The amendment is attached below for your review.

In response to our calls to you, we received a memo from your staff
informing us of your office's activities in support of the citrus industry.
The
memo indicates that, while your staff has had recent discussions with their
counterparts in the Administration and in Congress, your last conversations
with
Administration officials were in February.

Now, with the bill on the Senate floor, we have spoken to dozens of our
colleagues, as well to numerous senior Administration officials, on behalf
of
this crucial amendment. We have no doubt that you are an influential voice
with
this Administration and invite you to join our efforts to help Florida's
citrus
growers by seeking the support of the White House for the amendment.  A
signal
from the White House that this amendment has its support could deliver
enough
Republican Senators' votes to ensure its passage.

Furthermore, we urge that you personally contact Senator Charles Grassley,
the
Ranking Republican on the Senate Finance Committee, to request specifically
that
he support our amendment to the Trade Promotion Authority bill.  Senator
Grassley can be reached at (202) 224-3744.

Please call us at your first available opportunity to discuss our
cooperative
efforts and strategy to help our citrus growers.  For Senator Graham, call
(202)
224-3041, or for Senator Nelson, call (202) 224-5274.

Sincerely,


Bob Graham                              Bill Nelson






To extend trade authorities procedures with respect to
reciprocal trade agreements.

Referred to the Committee on ______ and ordered to be printed
Ordered to lie on the table and to be printed

AMENDMENTS intended to be proposed by Mr. NELSON of
Florida, for himself and Mr. GRAHAM of Florida

Viz:
At the end of section 3(a), insert the following new paragraph:

(8) PRODUCTS SUBJECT TO ANTIDUMPING AND COUNTERVAILING DUTY
ORDERS.-Paragraph
(1)(A) shall not apply to a product that is the subject of an antidumping or
countervailing duty order at the time of the agreement referred to in
paragraph
(1), unless the agreement provides that as a term, condition, or
qualification
of the tariff concession, the tariff reduction will not be implemented
before
the date that is 1 year after the date of the termination or revocation of
such
antidumping or countervailing duty order with respect to all exporters of
such
product.

At the end of section 3(b), insert the following new paragraph:

(4) PRODUCTS SUBJECT TO ANTIDUMPING AND COUNTERVAILING DUTY
ORDERS.-Paragraph
(1) shall not apply to a product that is the subject of an antidumping or
countervailing duty order at the time of the agreement referred to in
paragraph
(1), unless the agreement provides that as a term, condition, or
qualification
of the tariff concession, the tariff reduction will not be implemented
before
the date that is 1 year after the date of termination or revocation of such
antidumping or countervailing duty order with respect to all exporters of
such
product.

From:	dbrice4@bellsouth.net
Sent:	Monday, May 13, 2002 12:13 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	cs/sb160

Governor Bush,
   I urge you to allow passage of CS/SB160. This bill will secure more protection for the racing greyhounds in Florida. I currently work at Daytona Beach Kennel Club which has an addoption service for retired dogs. All dogs that are retired from this facility go through the adoption process. This bill would make this required at all tracks. 
  This bill would also allow increased stakes at the poker games attached to these tracks. These increased stakes would not create "high stakes" poker in any sense of the meaning of high stakes. However it would make a much more enjotable game for our customers. This in turn would increase the taxes collected by the state which could be put to good use educating our children along with the state operated lottery.
  Not allowing this bill to pass would certainly lead to higher unemolyment as track workers are laid off or terminated due to lack of support. Please lets not add to the States reputation where turtles are protected and children are lost and forgotten. Lets do all we can to better educate our children and keep their parents employed. This bill will help accomplish this in a small way. If we all work together maybe we can find other ways as well. 
 Thank You,
Don Brice, 313 N. Greenway Dr. Port Orange, Fl 32127
ph, 386 760 3046

-----Original Message-----
From: EMART51@aol.com <EMART51@aol.com>
To: Jeb Bush <jeb@jeb.org>
Sent: Mon May 13 11:12:13 2002
Subject: Blue ribbon panel

Honorable Governor: 
Sometimes the best efforts and well intended projects fail due to the fact that the people designated to inquire, evaluate and possibly make recommendations on a very sensitive issue, as the one in question may be the best on paper. 
However, these people are so detached from reality that their learning on issues of children's needs, mostly needy children from ghetto homes, whose head of family is a female resulting from a broken home or some socially related problem, comes from books and reports that are or have been on file for quite some time without any action by anyone. 
I believe that for such a panel to succeed it needs participation and input from one or two persons at the grass roots levels, who can talk about reality and apply factual information, not that which has been produced to satisfy the system, to the final report in order for it to satisfy the needs that years of decay and carelessness have developed. 
These grandiose persons are very much detached from the levels from which the children in question turn into victimes of a system that has not worked for decades. 
Back when I was a police officer in New York City they had what was known as the Bureau of Child Welfare.  It was a bust.  When we ran into an incident involving such children, most of the time we had to carry the ball all the way through.  They were not qualified, inept, insensitive to the needs of such children, not well trained and undermanned. Their only reason for beding there ws to get a check, fringe benefits and a pension down the road. 
They, as well as here, falsified reports, filed fradulent vouchers, and mostly were afraid to enter certain neighborhoods in order to perform at expected levels. 
Florida is no different. Take case workers from certain areas and have them tailed for a few weeks and then check the reports filed and you will learn that the above is true. 
High society people are not in tune with the happenings and their final analysis is accepted and put to work and ends up failing again and again. 
I know you never get to read this messages.  That is a shame.  There are more average people with better ideas on how to handle matters of such sensitivity that are never heard for the assignments always go to elitist individuals who have never been nor will ever be in the pit with the alligators. 
Have a good one and good luck. 
Ed Martinez

-----Original Message-----
From: Ken Armstrong [mailto:ken@uwbb.org]

Subject: $17,000


Jeb, thanks again for your generous gift of your time and the mansion.  
One quick deal:  for a handful of years the state budget has included
the
$17,000 necessary for DMS to hire a part-time OPS employee to staff and
support the Statewide FSECC Steering Committee.  This year, the
committee
has outsourced that job (with encouragement from DMS) to us.  The Senate
had
the $17,000 in their budget.  The House didn't.  It has come and gone
and
then come and gone.  I'm not sure where things are right now.  Colleen
is
working on making sure the $17,000 DOES happen.  She is obviously part
of
the Steering Committee that voted unanimously for the $17,000 to be
included
in the state's budget.  Otherwise, it will have to come from employees'
gifts (or United Way budgets).  Colleen and I spoke today, and we
figured I
ought to just send you a quick email underlining how important it
is--and
thanking you and her for putting in a good word for its inclusion.  Of
course it's not very much money--but it would hit some United Way
budgets
pretty hard.  AND it pays for the actual work that the Steering
Committee
does in setting up the campaign.  That's the reason the committee (and
Colleen) feel that it should be in the state budget again as it has been
ever since you became Governor.  Thanks for putting in a good word
wherever
it would help.  Ken

-----Original Message-----
From: Yablonski, Brian <Brian.Yablonski@MyFlorida.com>
To: Jeb Bush <jeb@jeb.org>
CC: Hansen, Michael <Michael.Hansen@LASPBS.STATE.FL.US>
Sent: Mon May 13 10:49:53 2002
Subject: RE: Child Welfare Info

Spoke with executive director of Health Families
 
Here's the news -- in 1997 Healthy Families was in 6 counties with ZERO state funding.  
 
In 1998/99 it jumped to 10m in state funding and serving 1890 families -- this was a direct result of our child welfare initiative and call to expand.  In years following, program expanded futher with a recurring base of 22.2m.  
 
This has enabled the program to serve 6,100 families in 99/00, 10,022 families in 00/01, and 11,000 families this year -- base is still 22.2m.  
 
What has changed is non-recurring $$ that they used to supplement base -- the non recurring, which is lower this upcoming year means that they will probably not get up to 11,000 families this upcoming year -- BUT NO FAMILIES that are currently receiving services will be cut, just they will not have as many families coming on line -- Healthy Families is just trying to more prudently spend its non-recurring so that they do not over extend with one time money -- next year, they will seek more recurring.

-----Original Message-----
From: Pauline Chusid [mailto:pchusid@earthlink.net]
Sent: Monday, April 29, 2002 10:54 PM
To: Jeb Bush; knapp@fdhc.state.fl.us; 4hand@cyberagenct.net
Cc: Ken kiehl
Subject: Resignation from District 8 MCOC


My Chair, Dr. Ken Kiehl, has asked that I forward this letter to you.
Sincerely yours, Pauline Chusid, MD, FACP, MBA

        25 April 2002

Ken Kiehl, M.D., Chairman,
District 8 Managed Care Ombudsman Committee
1430 Hillview Drive
Sarasota, FL 34239

Dear Ken:
 After much soul searching, I have decided to resign from the District 8
Managed Care Ombudsman Committee.  I am resigning because I have come to
believe that the Ombudsman Committee actually shields Governor Jeb Bush
from the critical attention his administration deserves for its managed
care policies and performance.
 He has failed to make any real effort to protect Florida citizens from
managed care company abuses, and uses our committee to deflect
criticism.  If we on the committee manage to help someone get his or her
health care needs covered, it is all well and good.  But our committee
has discovered a pattern of bad faith abuses by two large managed care
organizations, and ACHA has failed to act.  So some policyholders have
had their care needlessly delayed or denied, despite our efforts.
 I see this pattern of non action by the Bush administration as enabling
the systemic abuses to continue.  As other managed care organizations
learn that the bad faith abuses are permitted to continue without
sanction, then they, too, will cease to cooperate with our committee.
 But as long as our committee exists, Governor Jeb Bush can point to us
and pretend he is working to protect Florida's citizens.  It is a sham.
He failed to respond to two emails I sent to him on this subject.
 Therefore, I am resigning from the District 8 Managed Care Ombudsman
Committee effective immediately.  I am glad I have been able to help a
handful of people.  I am grateful that being on this committee has
allowed me to meet several caring and committed fellow committee
members.  Maybe in the future we will be able to work together again, on
a project with more chance of success.
 Thank you for you attention and your efforts.


        Sincerely,


        Pauline Chusid, M.D., F.A.C.P.
CC: Kurt A. Streyffeler
 Linda Brown, ARNP,  Craig Barcomb, D.C.
 Barbara Corbett,   Nancy Perez
 Gwen Kolegue,   Phyllis Cobb



From:	Yablonski, Brian <Brian.Yablonski@MyFlorida.com>
Sent:	Monday, May 13, 2002 12:46 PM
To:	Jeb Bush; Turbeville, Greg; Shanahan, Kathleen
Subject:	RE: Dog bill (card room bill; adoption bill)

The question in my mind is whether this is "maintenance of a product" or "improving a product" -- by making it more attractive, more lucrative, are we encouraging the behavior.   From what i know about this bill, it will make it more attractive, more lucrative and encourage that particular behavior, so in that sense i think it is improving the product.  as such, i do believe it is an expansion of gaming taking us ever closer, bit by bit, inch by inch to full scale level 3 casino gaming. 
 
rationalizing this bill is fine, but in the end it creates more loopholes that lead to more bills that will force us to do more rationalization.   
 
and yes, we inherited legalized forms of gaming, but it is not necessarily our job to keep them on life support, or revise them every few years to keep them lucrative.  

-----Original Message-----
From: Jeb Bush [mailto:jeb@jeb.org]
Sent: Friday, May 10, 2002 8:53 PM
To: Turbeville, Greg (E-mail); Brian Yablonski (EOG) (E-mail); Kathleen Shanahan (E-mail 2)
Subject: FW: Dog bill (card room bill; adoption bill)


your thoughts on this thesis?
 

Jeb Bush

-----Original Message-----
From: John Thrasher [mailto:JThrasher@SmithHulsey.com]
Sent: Thursday, May 09, 2002 11:27 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Dog bill (card room bill; adoption bill)



Governor: 

Thanks for lunch the other day.  I really enjoyed our conversation.  I also appreciate your taking my call later that day.

I have been thinking about the above-referenced legislation and understand that you will get it next week.  I know that at least one of the issues that you and your staff will deliberate on is whether or not this bill constitutes an expansion of gambling.  I wanted to give you one last thought on that from my perspective as to why I believe the bill does not constitute an expansion of gambling.

The expansion of gambling took place when the original card room legislation was enacted--not within this bill.  This previous legislation added card rooms as another product that could be offered by the pari-mutuel operators.  The Legislature has now determined that that product is faulty, does not work properly, and needs to be adjusted.  The bill adjusts the operational aspects of the product and allows it to function as intended by the original legislation.  You inherited this and other forms of gaming that are legal.  You can choose to pursue a course of repealing the legislation authorizing this and other gaming, or you can take steps to make currently authorized activity work as intended without expanding the offerings.  To adopt a position that maintenance of a specific existing product constitutes expanding that product, in my opinion does not seem to be an appropriate policy position.  This policy position would seem particularly troublesome when you look at other legal gaming products such as the lottery, which also existed before your term and whose operations have been allowed to be adjusted in a similar fashion to what this legislation proposes. 

In summary, I believe this bill is not an expansion but a necessary adjustment to an existing product.  I hope this helps.  Let me know if I can do anything else.  

Thanks for your friendship. 

JET

Thanks for sharing this email.  I was impressed with Dan when I met him last year.  It's basically the "girl-scout cookie" model of social service - the social service provider has a business that helps fund the provision of services (just like the sale of girl scout cookies funds the operations of the girls scouts). 

Governor, when the time comes, I am interested in helping you identify some outside-the-box thinking, change-agent champions to recruit who can continue in the all-too-important effort to continuously challenge the status quo and resist the siren songs of the bureaucratic blob.

-----Original Message-----
From: Kirsty Edwards [mailto:vpadiva@hotmail.com]
Sent: Friday, May 10, 2002 7:18 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: FCAT and Orlando





Dear Governor Bush,
My name is Christine Edwards.  My parents have written to you many times

regarding their concerns for my future.  However, I would like to share
with 
you my concerns about my future. As of May 24, 2002, I will be a senior
in 
the Visual and Performing Arts Theatre Magnet at Dr. Phillips High
School in 
Orlando, Florida.  I am an honors student with learning disabilities.  I

have dreamt of attending college to pursue my dreams and enhance my 
education since I was a little girl.  However, it doesn't look like I
will 
have that  opportunity in the state of Florida.  I will not graduate
next 
May with my diploma, nor my peers, nor the VPA seal that I have earned 
because, although I have taken the math section of the FCAT three times,
I 
cannot pass it without the use of my accommodations.  I have been denied
the 
use of those accommodations during that last 3 attempts.  Because of
those 
denials, my anxiety has only gotten worse creating an even more
stressful 
situation while taking the test.

I have never been allowed to use any of my Section 504 accommodations, 
including my right to test privately. The FCAT has sealed my fate and 
decided my future. I have a severe anxiety disorder known as Obsessive 
Compulsive Disorder and a learning disorder known as Non Verbal Learning

Disorder that both severely impact my ability for recall.   Each time I
have 
taken the math section of the FCAT without my accommodations and failed,
my 
symptoms have become worse. I have panic attacks just thinking about the

FCAT and my future without a college degree. I worry about not receiving
my 
diploma and the impact that alone will have on my future.  Numerous
times,I 
have made myself ill with worry.  There is no logical reason for me not
to 
pass the FCAT, other than my disabilities. I have met the Sunshine State

Standards required to graduate with a standard high school diploma,
except 
for passing the FCAT. My math teachers from the last 3 years in high
school 
are writing our Superintendent of Schools to ask him to request a waiver
for 
me from the State of Florida's Department of Education, because my 
disabilities won't permit me to pass the FCAT math section. I can't
benefit 
from the FCAT now, after 3 failed attempts, and the State won't benefit
from 
my taking it. The State of Florida has all but guaranteed that I will
never 
graduate with a standard diploma and I will be left behind, despite 
President Bush's Education initiative.

I need your help. Please help me. I need you to intervene on my behalf.
I 
need an FCAT math section waiver.  I want the future I am entitled to
have.  
I have worked hard for almost 12 years to keep my grades high, I have
put in 
many long hours studying and building bridges over my disabilities. I
have 
been an exemplary student. Because I have such trouble taking tests due
to 
the impact of my disability on my ability to recall, I won't be awarded
any 
scholarships to help pay for any further education, even though I have
met 
the criteria with community service, course work and grades. The fact
is, I 
don't test well due to my disabilities and I am being punished by the
State 
because of it.

I want to be a productive member of my community and my country. Without
a 
high school diploma, I cannot have a college education, a dream or a
future. 
  Without a college education, I am doomed to low paying jobs and no 
opportunities to further enhance my education or reach my goals.  I will
be 
a child left behind. Please help me.

I found out today that you will be visiting my high school next Tuesday,
May 
14, 2002 during 5th and 6th period.  I would love the opportunity to
meet 
you in person and talk with you regarding my concerns not only for
myself 
but for the future of all disabled students in the state of Florida.
Thank 
you for taking the time to read my letter.

Sincerely,
Christine "Kirsty" Edwards
Student, Dr. Phillips High School
Visual and Performing Arts Theatre Magnet
Orlando, Florida

-----Original Message-----
From: William Harrison [mailto:wharrison@wgharrison.com]

Subject: Vieques article from Saturday's Panama City News Herald


Saturday, May 11, 2002

Vieques move no bomb for Tyndall, says Boyd
"ON THE SAME PAGE": Congressman feels details have been worked out to keep
base's mission safe.

KENDALL MIDDLEMAS
The News Herald 
News that a portion of the U.S. Navy's training mission on Vieques Island,
Puerto Rico, might be reassigned to Eglin Air Force Base generally has been
regarded as a potential boon for Northwest Florida's military installations.

But U.S. Rep. Allen Boyd, D-Monticello, wants to be sure that the training,
which includes bombing exercises and aerial combat training, would not
interfere with Tyndall Air Force Base's use of the airspace known as the
Gulf Range Complex. 
Boyd said that a meeting earlier this week with Adm. Robert Natter,
commander of the Navy's Atlantic Fleet, "allayed a lot of the anxiety" he
had about a possible threat to Tyndall's mission. 
"I think that everybody's on the same page," Boyd said. "I'm very encouraged
that this thing's going to work out." 
Eglin handles scheduling in the Gulf Range airspace, but Tyndall is its
primary user. Tyndall's F-15 pilots spend 245 days a year training in the
Gulf Range. That accounts for about 90 percent of the airspace scheduling
capacity, Boyd said. 
"The unrestricted use and access to the Gulf Range airspace complex is
critical to Tyndall's ability to accomplish its mission," said Capt. Chris
Karns, chief public affairs officer for the 325th Fighter Wing at Tyndall.
"The Gulf Range complex is a national defense treasure critical to training
our pilots and ensuring they have the knowledge, skills and experience to
fight and win America's wars. We need to ensure to the maximum extent
possible that the objectives of all potential Department of Defense users
are able to be met, and at the same time make sure current missions are not
negatively impacted." 
Boyd said his meeting with Natter was a "very positive conversation," and he
is now comfortable that any plans to reassign the Vieques mission to Eglin
will take Tyndall's needs into account. 
"Adm. Natter and the Navy have got a clear understanding of what we're
trying to do," he said. 
U.S. Rep. Jeff Miller, R-Chumuckla, has been a proponent of bringing the
Vieques mission to Eglin, which falls within his 1st Congressional District.

While there is "a strong consideration for some participation in the
Panhandle," Miller said Eglin likely would assume only a portion of the
mission, thereby decreasing the chances for interference with Tyndall's
training schedule. Bases in other parts of Florida and up the East Coast
likely will absorb some of the Vieques mission, Miller said. 
"There is no plan to move all the Vieques mission to the gulf," he said. 
And, Miller said, plans are only in their earliest stage. As they progress,
issues like shared airspace will be discussed, he said. 
"There is still a large amount of dialogue and planning that needs to be put
into place," Miller said. "I feel those issues will have to be addressed and
resolved as this proposal moves forward." 
Miller said he supports the relocation of the Vieques training to the
Panhandle because he believes it would be an asset to existing bases and
missions. 
"The idea is to strengthen the military installations in West Florida, not
weaken them," he said. "My desire is to strengthen the military bases
throughout the Panhandle." 
Larry Dantzler, president of the Bay Defense Alliance, said the Navy
received a warm reception from Eglin when it raised the possibility of
conducting some of the Vieques training there. 
"Only now have they realized the involvement of Tyndall in the area," he
said. "Tyndall's missions had not really been considered." 
Boyd said the protection of Tyndall's access to the Gulf Range is especially
critical as another round of base closures approaches. If Tyndall's pilots
cannot stick to the strict schedule required to graduate them to
fighter-pilot status, the base might be an easier target. 
"That's why we have to keep our shoulder to the wheel on this," he said. 
But Boyd agreed with Miller that if properly planned, the relocation of some
of the Vieques mission to Northwest Florida could be an asset when area
bases come under scrutiny in 2005. 
"If we get this done right it will be another feather in our cap," he said. 
The writer can be contacted at kmiddlemas@pcnh.com
<<mailto:kmiddlemas@pcnh.com>>

From:	Muniz, Katie <Katie.Muniz@MyFlorida.com>
Sent:	Monday, May 13, 2002 5:21 PM
Subject:	And You Thought We Had Problems--CALIFORNIA

Thought this might be of interest as you write your budget stories for the
day.

Katie Muniz, Governor's Communication Director


> New York Times
> May 12, 2002
> California Officials Face Unprecedented Budget Gap
> By JAMES STERNGOLD
> LOS ANGELES, May 11 - The fury of last year's dot-com bust may be fading
> from memory, but its effects are proving far more severe than anyone had
> predicted even a few months ago, state officials and economists say. 
> Gov. Gray Davis and state finance officials are to release updated figures
> for the state budget on Tuesday, and economists are predicting that they
> will show a potentially catastrophic deficit of $20 billion to $25 billion
> for the current fiscal year, which ends June 30, and the next.
> The shortfall could well force the state and local governments to slash an
> array of services, including police protection and mental health, state
> and local officials say. The California Legislature is expected to spend
> most of the summer in a brutal political battle over who will have to
> sacrifice the most. 
> Nearly every state has budget problems, but California's potential deficit
> is larger than the entire budgets of most states. California's general
> budget is about $80 billion.
> State finance officials began expecting a problem months ago, given the
> downturns in the technology industry and the stock market. In January they
> predicted a shortfall of $12.5 billion. Now, with most tax returns
> tallied, the figures have mushroomed. The principal cause, the officials
> say, is not the overall economic malaise, or even the terrorist attacks,
> but plunging tax revenues from stock options and other capital gains,
> which evaporated when the dot-com bubble burst last year. 
> The total income reported by California taxpayers from stock options and
> capital gains rocketed to roughly $200 billion in 2000 from $25 billion in
> 1994, state officials say. Then last year it fell to less than $70
> billion, a decline that will reduce state tax revenues this fiscal year by
> $11 billion to $15 billion. 
> "Everyone was taken by surprise," said Kathleen Connell, the state
> controller, who has been forced to prepare an extraordinary $7.5 billion
> short-term bond offering next month to close the state's financial gap.
> "The diminished revenue was startling. And we don't see this as a
> single-year problem."
> In recent weeks, local governments and their lobbyists in Sacramento have
> been scrambling to find ways to protect basic services and prevent the
> state from forcing the localities to absorb the brunt of coming budget
> reductions.
> Making matters worse, the problem has surfaced in an election year, when
> the governor and the Legislature will be particularly reluctant to make
> painful budget cuts or to raise taxes. Those constraints have put many
> officials in the awkward position of both playing down the severity of the
> problem and stressing that it will require extraordinary measures to fix.
> "It's not a crisis," said Tim Gage, director of the Department of Finance.
> "It's a significant challenge. No one really saw what the magnitude of
> that drop was going to be. The problem is to close the gap with the least
> damage, to cushion the otherwise devastating impact if we just made the
> cuts directly to programs."
> Local governments are particularly vulnerable because they have two basic
> sources of income, local taxes and tax revenues passed down from the
> state, and many localities expect to be hit on both fronts.
> For example, Santa Clara County, which includes Silicon Valley, faces an
> $85 million budget gap because of plummeting revenues from things like
> property transfer taxes, sales taxes and vehicle license fees. 
> Unemployment has gone to 7.7 percent from less than 1 percent two years
> ago, and now the government is preparing for potentially steep reductions
> in the money it receives from the state, which accounts for 43 percent of
> its annual revenues. 
> "I've been doing this for 26 years, and I've never seen anything like this
> in terms of how quickly things have turned," said Richard Wittenberg, the
> county executive. "It's been a free fall, and we haven't had much time to
> prepare." 
> He said services like health care, a program providing health insurance
> for children and welfare programs were likely to face cuts. 
> Richard Averett, finance director for the tiny city of San Carlos, south
> of San Francisco, said he was preparing for cuts in recreation, senior
> programs, the library system and police protection. 
> Even rural counties are expecting the worst. Fresno County, for instance,
> in the San Joaquin Valley, is concerned about potential cuts in state fire
> protection in its forests. Los Angeles County, which has nearly 10 million
> people, is particularly concerned about potential cuts in the money it
> receives for its extensive health programs, which focus on the burgeoning
> immigrant community. 
> Butte County, in Northern California, is one of the poorest in the state
> and has been on the verge of bankruptcy for years. Officials there worry
> about even modest cuts. 
> "We're in no position to bail anyone out," said Paul McIntosh, the chief
> administrator for Butte County. "We're just hoping we'll have some
> flexibility in how we can deal with this because we don't have anywhere
> else to dig."
> The only time the state came close to this situation was in the early
> 1990's, when there were rampant layoffs in the aerospace industry. The
> revenue shortfall reached $14 billion in fiscal 1991, a gap that was
> closed, in large measure, by taking money away from local governments.
> The problems are a reminder of just how unusual the 1990's were in
> California. While poor and working class immigrants flooded into the
> state, the wealthiest residents simply grew wealthier, laying the
> groundwork for the current problem.
> The top 5 percent of taxpayers accounted for 22 percent of total personal
> income in California in 1980. By 2000, the top 5 percent of taxpayers -
> with gross incomes of $150,000 or more - accounted for 42 percent of total
> personal income. 
> When the stock options and portfolios of that tiny slice of the population
> collapsed, so did the state budget. 
> State officials are not in the business of making stock market forecasts,
> but they are working hard on their economic predictions and they expect
> little relief soon. 
> "If there is no real economic growth until the end of the fourth quarter,
> there will be no revenue growth to help out on next year's budget," said
> Ms. Connell, the state controller. "We could be dealing with this for
> three or four years."
From:	ALLEN.BOB <ALLEN.BOB@leg.state.fl.us>
Sent:	Monday, May 13, 2002 5:32 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Thank you for writing to my office.

Sometimes on issues of great public interest, it is not uncommon for legislators to receive thousands of e-mails. 

I personally read every e-mail message that is sent to me, but sometimes it takes awhile to get through them all. Also, due to the time required to remain current on the hundreds of bills and related issues, it is occasionally impossible to personally respond to them all.

Thank you for allowing me the privilege of serving you in the Florida House of Representatives. 

Bob Allen 
Representative 
District 32

-----Original Message-----
From: Marisa Feito [mailto:gmcc03@bellsouth.net]

Cc: Bill Cullom (Bill Cullom); Tony Villamil (Tony Villamil);

Subject: RE: INS anecdotal - 30 day visas


Hi Pam -- as you know there are a lot of issues such as the 30 days
visas impacting Florida's int'l trade and commerce right now.  We are
putting together an inventory of such issues to present to our Executive
Committee next week. When the document is ready, I will be happy to send
you a copy along with a letter sent to INS re: 30 days visas. We are
trying to do as much as we can to mitigate the impact that these new
rules can have on our economy by communicating with the Gov't and with
the public. However, we may have to live with some of them -- at least
for the time being. The Chamber is very proactive and we keep an open
line of communication with INS. We meet monthly with them and we have an
excellent working relationship. I believe that more public awareness and
education is needed so foreign tourists and businessmen are not driven
away.  I can do some of this through our website, missions and seminars
but more will be needed. We know that you are working hard on all these
issues and we want to thank you and the governor for your outstanding
support and leadership.

Dear Pam,

I pass this information along to you as "anecdotal" -- I don't know how
representative it is of a broader segment of travelers from Latin
America.

A colleague here in Miami has a friend in Latin America who is planning
to
take a two month vacation.  He would normally come to the US.  When
asked if
he would be coming through Miami, he said no, he just didn't need all
the
aggravation of trying to travel to Miami  - the Patriot Act, the INS,
etc.

He is not planning to travel to the United States at all, -- he will be
going to Spain and London.

Thanks,

CLARIFICATION RE Sarasota County tax - this changes the tax issues for
school construction back to 18 of 28 or 64% passing, but in any event it is
a tax for schools.
____________________________________________________________________________
_________________
YES, Sarasota did in fact pass a local ad valorem tax for operating purposes
for four years.  The additional tax is estimated to raise $100 million over
the 4 year period ($25 million yearly).

There are not bonds to be sold, nor is it a half-cent sales surtax.  It is
strictly an additional ad valorem tax for four years to support operations,
etc.  The vote passed district wide by a 2 to 1 margin.  

Since this is not a capital outlay issue, I will not include the information
in my capital outlay sheets.

If I can be of further assistance, please call me at 921-8699.

Trust this answers Brewsers question.

Again thanks for all you both do for the citizens of Florida.

My regards,
Spessard

From:	Doug Belden <tax@tampabay.rr.com>
Sent:	Monday, May 13, 2002 10:48 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Town Hall Meeting

Dear Governor Bush,
 
It was a pleasure seeing you several weeks ago at the ceremonial signing of the Fish and Wildlife bill. That was a winner for all involved parties. I received many accolades from the public on the Tampa Tribune coverage of the signing.
 
I would strongly encourage you to consider a town hall meeting here in Tampa. As you recall, I suggested this to you six months ago. Now with your campaign underway and the finish of the legislative session the timing would be excellent. I proposed to you that I would moderate a town hall meeting comprised of the most diversified group ever assembled in Hillsborough County. This would not be a speech, or a press conference but a progressive and positive forum in which citizens would speak to you on issues relevant to Hillsborough County. You would then make a closing statement.
 
I had lunch with Mr. Steve Weaver, publisher of the Tampa Tribune last week. In fact it was the same day you were to meet him in Tampa. He is very positive about this proposal and would lend great support. I also had the opportunity to attend a baseball game Friday night with Mr. Paul Tash, President of the St. Petersburg Times. He would also support such an endeavor.
 
I have and will always be a strong supporter of yours and I think you are off to a strong campaign start. Your many accomplishments in your first term speak for themselves.
 
Please give some thought to my suggestion, and let me know if you wish to pursue it. I believe it would be great for you and Hillsborough County.
 
Hope all is well with you and your family.
Kindest regards,
Doug Belden

From:	Marstiller, Simone <Simone.Marstiller@MyFlorida.com>
Sent:	Monday, May 13, 2002 6:43 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Cc:	Shanahan, Kathleen; Branker, Laura; Muniz, Katie; Canady, Charles T.
Subject:	3rd DCA ruling in Rilya's sister's case

Importance:	High

The 3rd DCA this afternoon denied DCF's petition to prohibit Judge Lederman
from holding a shelter hearing to determine whether DCF appropriately
removed Rodericka Wilson, Rilya's younger sister, from the home of Pamela
Graham/Geralyn Graham.  The shelter hearing is expected to go forward
tomorrow--what time, we don't know yet.

The appellate court's order simply denies DCF's efforts at this juncture in
the proceedings but leaves the door open for DCF to appeal any order Judge
Lederman may enter.  The 3d DCA did not in any way speak to the merits of
DCF's position that the lower court lacks statutory authority to approve or
disapprove DCF's changing a child's residence/caregiver if it sees fit to do
so.

From:	Shanahan, Kathleen <Kathleen.Shanahan@MyFlorida.com>
Sent:	Monday, May 13, 2002 7:00 PM
To:	Sartin, Sandy; Shanahan, Kathleen; Arduin, Donna; Branker, Laura

-----Original Message-----
From: Sartin, Sandy [mailto:Sandy.Sartin@LASPBS.STATE.FL.US]
Sent: Monday, May 13, 2002 9:04 AM
To: Shanahan, Kathleen; Arduin, Donna
Cc: Turbeville, Greg; Yablonski, Brian; 'jeb@jeb.org'
Subject: RE: When is exact date of final quarterly release of funds to agencies for before end of fiscal year?


Just to provide a little more information on this topic - we have received and approved numerous budget amendments from many state agencies for additional releases of funds over and above the amounts we've been releasing monthly.  We have not denied any of the requests.  There have been a few times we've changed a requested amount but only with the concurrence of the agency when we were able to show them that the records show there was actually not a need for the additional release.
 
In addition to the June 18 release I mentioned earlier as the final one for the fiscal year, there will be another partial release on May 21.

FYI,
This is what the Sec. Mineta was going to announce on his trip to Florida
that was canceled.



 Monday, May 13, 2002

 ISSN 1521-1495

                                                           News
                                                           News



 Transportation Journal
 $11.4 Million Infrastructure Grants Awarded to Orlando
 International Airport



               Transportation Secretary Norman Y. Mineta May 10 announced
               $11.4 million in federal grants for Orlando International
               Airport. A total of $6.4 million will be used to continue
               construction of the North Crossfield Taxiway.


               In addition, $5 million in federal funds are to be used to
               continue construction of a fourth runway at the airport. The
               Greater Orlando Aviation Authority is in the midst of a $1.2
               billion expansion program including a new air traffic
               control tower, a fourth runway, taxiways and other
               facilities that when completed will double the airport's
               capacity.

-----Original Message-----
From: Michael Bier <islamike@terranova.net>
To: Jeb Bush <jeb@jeb.org>
Sent: Mon May 13 21:36:44 2002
Subject: Monroe County Commission Appointment

Dear Governor Bush,
 
It has recently come to my attention that you will be appointing a new Monroe County Commissioner to fill the vacating seat of Commissioner Nora Williams.  Further, that the name of Keith Douglass has been submitted to you as a possible choice to fill this unexpired term for the next four to five months.  I would like to submit this recommendation for Keith Douglass, as a way to help assist you in making that decision, and why in my opinion I think he would be the perfect person to appoint to this position.
 
I am a practicing architect in the Islamorada area for the last 18 years, having moved to the Florida Keys after living in Miami for the prior 25 years.  I have been quite active in the Florida Keys, especially Monroe County government, having served on the Monroe County Planning Commission and also having been the Chairman of the Monroe County Land Authority's Advisory Committee.  Currently, I'm still serving on two Monroe County committees.
 
Because of the relatively short term to be filled until the Fall elections, I believe we need to find someone who is well acquainted with the many complex issues still facing Monroe County government.  During this period will also be the difficult task of addressing the county's budget for the year 2003.  Trying to teach a "new" person how to be a commissioner & the myriad details before them during this short time frame, would leave that individual at an extreme disadvantage, and thusly the general public as well.  Attempting to grasp the many issues would be a very difficult at best, to be in any way effective during this period.  Keith Douglass was Nora Williams immediate predecessor on the Monroe County Commission and is very familiar with the issues currently being addressed.  In addition, Mr. Douglass, as a former commissioner, has gone through the budget approval process four times in the past and understands the intricacies involved in that process.  Knowing Keith Douglass for almost all of the approximately 12 years he has resided in the Florida Keys, I can't think of a more community minded individual who would be willing to step in and help his community, without being self-serving, and has the qualifications to lend serious, immediate impute during this short, but very important period.
 
I hope that in the best "short term" interests of Monroe County, you will very seriously consider Keith Douglass for this position.
 
Thank you.
 
 
Michael Jason Bier, A.I.A. - Architect
110 Bayview Drive
Islamorada, FL  33036
(305)  664-8258
islamike@terranova.net

-----Original Message-----
From: Marketing Edge <info@marketingedgeonline.com>
To: Jeb Bush <jeb@jeb.org>
Sent: Mon May 13 21:41:53 2002
Subject: COmmunity colleges and BS degrees

Hello-
 
I don't know if you are closely following the Community College
Baccaclaureate Degree issue as I am sure you have many other things on
your plate. 
 
May I share with you my concern over the e-mail I received regarding
Secretary of Education Jim Horne's recommendations in regards to
community colleges offering baccalaureate degrees? I am concerned that
by extending funding for community colleges to offer baccalaureate
degrees just because they apply,  might undermine the vision your have
of the new education governance structure, still being formed.    I also
would like to suggest that based on current research, the teacher
shortage problem we have is not solely due to lack of teacher degree
programs.  Research would suggest that we have more than enough
qualified teachers in Florida, they choose not to work in their chosen
profession due to other circumstances.  Therefore, offering more degree
programs to generate more teachers might not be the answer.  It is a
complicated issue just as nursing is a complicated issue.  
 
I also am concerned about community colleges losing the focus of their
primary missions and of creating a tiered degree program ie: BS degrees
that don't articulate completely to 4 year institutions for master
degrees etc.
 
We have such a great opportunity to create a new education governance
structure based on your vision, it will take time to research best
practices and pull the best of the "best practices" together to
re-structure our current system into one that is student focused and
seamless.  
 
I would be interested in your comments if you have seen the memo from
Secretary Horne.
 
 
I'm glad you had a nice day on Sunday.
 
Regards,
Diane 

Diane Leone
President
Marketing Edge, Inc.
Diane Leone Interiors
405 Old Quarry Road
St. Augustine, Florida 32080
904-823-1998
Synergy@MarketingEdgeOnline.com

Honorable Governor Bush.   Ron levy here, former mayor and elected offfical
from Islamorada.  We met a few months ago in your office when i had the
courage to ask you (not you,you -- but you,the State) for a 30 million
principal deferred loan for wastewater.  It was a great pleasure.  And while
it didn't work out, thanks so much for you attention to the issue.

I'm writing now to ask your strong consideration for appointing John Verdon
for Nora Williams seat.  I ask this first because of Mr. Verdon's
experience.  He has elected official experience as a moyor in Michigan ( i
think elected 4 times ).  He has worked very diligently on Islamorada's
Wastewater committiee.  He listens to all sides of issues and then makes
thoughtful decisions which he can clearly articulate.    Another reason is
that John is a resident of Islamorada.  and while technically Nora's
district goes down into Marathon, Marathon is already represented by George
Nugent, who has interests in Marathon.  The other names I have heard
considered for this seat live in Marathon, and have little connection to the
great majority of Nora's district.  I believe this seat has always in recent
history been occupied by a Islamorada resident.  A third reason is that Mr
Verdon is independent of any old MonCo politics and would work for the  good
of all the citizens of the Keys.

Thanks for your time on this mattter, and all your work for the State of
Florida.  I really enjoyed ( and miss)  my years of  public service for
Islamorada -- if I can be of any further help, please let me know.
Sincerely, Ron Levy

-----Original Message-----
From: Papa Joe [mailto:papajoe@papajoesmarina.com]
Sent: Monday, May 13, 2002 10:43 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: touting Keith Douglass


5/13/2002

To: the Honorable Governor Jeb Bush

From: Councilman Bob Johnson
          Islamorada, Village Of Islands


Hello Governor Bush,

It is my understanding you are currently considering appointing a
temporary replacement for the recently-vacated commission seat in Monroe
County. I would like to suggest that you consider former Monroe County
Commissioner Keith Douglass, one of the most respected and capable
individuals in the Upper Keys.

Since his term as county commissioner, Douglass has become the ultimate
diplomat, while relating well to both business and residential occupants
in the Florida Keys. His people skills are outstanding and most recently
he was chosen to moderate a local political debate in the Islamorada
election. Also, Douglass is a member of the Marathon Rotary, is an
Islamorada resident and often works in Key Largo, a combination which
has provided him with a working understanding of both the social and
political dynamics of the entire Upper Keys.

A loyal Republican, Douglas is warm, friendly and outgoing. But most
importantly, Douglass is a communicator, inherently able to mediate
disputes or address difficult issues, almost always producing positive
results. Again, he is one of the most respected people in the Upper
Keys.

Thank you for considering these words and best of luck to you and yours
in these most difficult economic and political times. By the way, I
think you're doing a great job.


Councilman Bob Johnson,
Islamorada, Florida Keys
office (305) 664-5005
home (305) 664-8508
bobj@papajoesmarina.com

-----Original Message-----
From: Moms99am@aol.com [mailto:Moms99am@aol.com]
Sent: Monday, May 13, 2002 3:46 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: Moms99am@aol.com
Subject: Victims rights


Dear  Governor Bush , 
I am  writing  you  because  I  was  told  you  are  the  person  to  talk  to  concerning  laws .  You  see  I  am  very  concerned  that  criminals  have  way  more  rights  then  there  victims  and  I  don't  feel  that  is  right . I  am  hoping  you could  clear  something  up  for  me .  What  I  would  like  to  know  is  if  it  is  true  that  law  enforcement  cannot  question  a  person  that may  be  involved  in  a  serious  crime  such  as  murder   if  they  say  they  have  a  attorney ?  Can  they  not question  them  in  the  presence  of  their  attorney .  The reason  I  am  asking  is  because  A  friend  of  mine  was  shot  and  killed  and  her  husband  was  the  only  one  with  her  when  this  happened  and  we  have  reason  to  beleive  he  may  have  been  involved  with  her  death .  This  happened  January  of  99 and  her death  was  ruled  a  suicide  and  the  case  was  closed until  Febuary  of  2001 .  The  case  was  reopened  because  of  too  many  Descrepencies  in  the  case  .  You  see  there  is  evidence  that  this  man  may  have  been  involved  and  he  told  so  many  lies  to  several  different  people  including  law  en forcement  and  to  this  day  has  never  been  questioned  .  He  was  not  even  questioned  the  night  it  happened  .  He  was  asked  later  to  take  a  polygraph  test  but  he  refused  and  said  his  attorney  told  him  not  to  take  one  or  answer  any  questions .  I  can't  understand  how  a  person  who  we  are  positive  has  no  lawyer  can  not  ever  be  questioned  on  any  of  his  lies  just  because  he  claims  to  have  an  attorney .  Is  this  really  the  way  the  law  works  because  if  it  is  it  should  be  changed .  There  are  too  many  people  getting  away  with  murder  because  of  this  law  and  it  is  not  right  because  anybody  can  say  they  have  an  attorney  just  to  get  out  of  being  questioned  and  if  they  are  guilty  then  they  get  away  with  it  with  no  questions  asked .  It's  like  telling  people  it's  ok  to  murder  as  long  as  you  say  you  have  an  attorney .  Please  help  me  understand  this  because  a  young  boy  has  lost  his  mother  and  the  only  chance  we  have  of  ever  finding  out  what  happened  to  his  mother  is  by  law  enforcement  questioning  her  husband  because  he  is  the  only  other  living  person  who  knows  what  happened .  This  law  gives  criminals  too  many  rights  and  their  victims  have  none .  What  can  we  do  to  change  this  law ?  If  a  person  say's  they  have  an  attorney  then  they  should  at  least  half  to  prove  they  have  one  and  still  they  should  be  able  to  be  questioned  with  their  attorney  present  .  Can  you  please  clear  this  matter  up  for  me ? 

I  know  you  are very  busy  and  I  do  Thank  you  for  your  time . 

                                      Sincerely  Joy  Stearns

Please note: Florida has a very broad public records law.
Most written communications to or from state officials

-----Original Message-----
From: STRAHL, Stuart [mailto:sstrahl@Audubon.org]
Sent: Monday, May 13, 2002 4:37 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Bald Eagle Opportunities



Governor: 

For over 20 years, Audubon's Center for Birds of Prey in Maitland has been a national leader on rehabilitating injured and sick Bald Eagles, and releasing them back into the wild.  In addition, our 200 Eaglewatch volunteers around the State work with agencies and landowners to conserve and protect this important species and its nesting sites.  You may have seen the "Eaglecam" live video we set up each year in conjunction with the Orlando Sentinel...real-time footage from active eagle nest.

This year, we will reach another milestone: Audubon plans to release our 250th eagle back into the wild, and we would very much like you to do the honors releasing the bird.  

Are you interested?  It's quite an experience...and you'd enjoy it! 

As ever, 

Stuart

Subject:	 Support Bill 160





> May 11, 2002
> Governor Jeb Bush
> The Capitol
> 400 South Monroe St.
> Tallahassee, Florida 32399-0001
> Jeb@jeb.org
> 
> Re:  CS/ SB160  (Wasserman-Schultz)
> 
> Dear Gov. Bush,
> 
> On behalf of the patrons of the dog tracks and poker 
> rooms in Florida, I would like to encourage you to 
> SUPPORT the Senate Bill 160.
> 
> Greyhounds are dogs that must run - it is their nature- 
> and they enjoy it.  Greyhounds have very sweet 
> dispositions and make wonderful pets when their careers 
> are over.  It is with this BILL 160 that more greyhounds 
> will be adopted.  Through the SUPPORT of this 
> legislation, the greyhounds adoption program will be 
> mandatory at all dog tracks.  
> 
> As it is now, more animals are killed in just one humane 
> society shelter than all the greyhounds in the United 
> States.  For this reason alone you should SUPPORT BILL 
> 160.
> 
> The poker rooms at the tracks have numerous employees 
> that will be unemployed if the card rooms close.  
> Increasing the stakes of the poker games will not only 
> bring in more people, but also more revenue to the state 
> of Florida, rather than out to sea.  
> 
> By forcing the poker rooms to support the greyhounds, 
> this will benefit the greyhound adoption program and 
> thereby save jobs as well as many more animals.
> 
> Please SUPPORT BILL 160.
> 
> 
> Sincerely,
> 
> Marcia A. Choquette
    Casselberry, Fl.

From:	Argyle Area Civic Council <ArgyleACC@netzero.net>
Sent:	Tuesday, May 14, 2002 8:00 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Argyle Forest News 05-13-2002 : Argyle Area Civic Council Meeting , Thursday, May 16, 2002 at 7:30pm at Kirkwood Presbyterian Church.

To: Jeb Bush
.     jeb@jeb.org

Dear Governor Bush,  

Here is a MEETING REMINDER:  May 13, 2002.   This is being sent to over 500 people in the Argyle Forest Area, Neighboring Clay County and Civic Minded People in Jacksonville, FL.

Included in this email:
1.  Agenda for the Thursday, May 16, 2002 AACC meeting.  

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

The Next meeting of the Argyle Area Civic Council will be on Thursday, May 16th, 2002 at 7:30 pm at Kirkwood Presbyterian Church at the corner of Argyle Forest Boulevard and Shindler Road.  All Chairs are encourages to be prepared and ready with good report of status and needs.

Here is the Agenda for that meeting:   Minutes will be posted on the web site approximately one week after the meeting.

1. Approval of the the minutes from the Thursday, April 18, 2002 AACC meeting.
. Full Minutes Posted at -> http://www.neighborhoodlink.com/jacksonville/genpage.html?nid=[REDACTED]&nneighid=[REDACTED]&nsupercity=[REDACTED]
Summary of the Thursday, April 18, 2002 meeting 
· Henry Mooneyhan reviewed the reasons for establishing an AACC Literacy Campaign. 
· Senator Steve Wise commented on the Literacy Campaign, and expressed his gratitude that the AACC was undertaking such an important project. 
· Dan Hoard reported on Business Development. 
· Clay County Chairman, Pat McGovern’s message regarding the Cleveland Avenue Extension. 
· Comments on construction that will be going on simultaneously at Collins and Blanding, I-295 and Blanding, and Argyle Forest Boulevard and Blanding. 
· Opposition to the Wells Road Extension. 
· Call for the AACC to conduct a Transportation Symposium. 
· Voter Participation Committee set. 
· Letter to Mayor Delaney regarding contractors ignoring construction requirements for silt fences near the protected Ortega Swamp. 
· Noise abatement for AFB widening. 

2. Congratulations to Committee Chair Ken Bible for getting approval from all parties to place a newly defined mini-substation in the Argyle Commerce Center. 
3.By Lars Jettman < LJettma@AOL.com >, Transportation Chair, a Report on Apr 16, 2002 Jacksonville Transportation Authority Public Hearing for Argyle Forest Blvd. Improvements (Widening & Scheduling) 
Introduction of Aage Schroeder, FDOT District Secretary, who will listen to and participate in our discussion of the Wells Road Connector across the Ortega Swamp and the Collins Road @ I-295 Interchange ideas. 
You need to be present to voice your concerns or forever hold your peace. 

4. Phase II Report from Henry Mooneyham < HMooneyhan@aol.com > and staff on Literacy Committee. 

5. Report on the Argyle Stalker case by Bill Lewis 

6. Could the land set aside for schools be donated to a charter or private school which could be up and running much faster than the public schools seem to be able to move?  Is a charter or private school the answer to the Cheswick Oaks Elementary need? 

7. Voter Registration Drive. A Chair will be selected at this meeting. You need to be there if you are interested. 

8. Reminder about City Grants for neighborhoods due dates. 

9. By Jim Doughfman, Rec Chair < Respman1@bellsouth.net >, a report on skateboard park and others. 

10. Request for Chair Person of: 
a. Bumper Sticker campaign. 
b. Schools liaison 
c. Landscaping 
d. Tutor recruitment & training for literacy campaign 
e. Meetings Speaker committee f. Community Center project 
g. Senior Center project 
h. Nominations/Future Leaders Committee 

If you want to be involved in one of the above committees, email that Chairperson or come to the meeting on Thursday, May 16, 2002.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

From:	Mathis, Linda <MathisL@dms.state.fl.us>
Sent:	Tuesday, May 14, 2002 8:50 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	RE: WE Need Action not Panels

I'm glad to here that the panel is separate from the criminal case.  The
media has exaggerated the story again, and of course the democrats are
playing politics with it too.  I appologize for the misunderstanding.  They
already are saying the the AMW show has brought in no leads but it hasn't
had time to yet so I suggest keeping it front and center because someone
somewhere will know something that can help arrest the culprits.  

I'm glad I'm not a social worker with the DCF because its a hard job with
not enough pay and the qualifications are too low for people who are
supposed to have expertise in that field.  I feel the qualifications should
be an MSW with specialization in child welfare or child development.  I do
not feel that a BS in business or other non-related fields qualifies a
person to do that job.  when a person is qualified and has the expertise
they should also be paid better.  Having a case load of 500 or 1000 kids is
way too high and does not allow for good case management.  The majority of
the workers do a good job, based on their training and knowledge, I know
that.  However, falsification of records can not be tolerated from anyone in
any state job and I am a state employee to so it applies to me as well as
anyone else.  People are terminated from jobs for falsification of documents
or records on a regular basis.   I'm glad the legislature and you have
agreed to strengthen those laws.  I fear that something terrible has
happened to that child and until we know what the truth is, the whole system
wil continue to be under scrutiny no matter who the governor happens to be.
Unfortunately, the caregivers of the child are not exactly clean either and
they should also be subjected to investigation as well as the state
employees involved. Someone is hiding something that's for sure.  

I think a procedure should be put in place so that whenever a child is
removed from a foster home or caregivers home, a written noterized document
should be given to the caregiver so that the new location of that child and
the reason for the move is recorded so that this can not happen again.  All
parties should sign and noterize the document so that their identities can
be verified before the transfer is made.  A computer check of drivers
licenses should also be done when a kid is transferred from a home or is
removed by a case worker or other state employee. periodically, the document
format and appearance should be changed so that no one could duplicate it
and inflitrate the system.  The location of the child should also be put in
that noterized document with new addresses, phone numbers, and contact
persons for that new placement or evaluation site.  Then, it would be less
likely that a person would be able to kidnap a hchild away from a home. This
may take more time but we can't have this happen again, no matter what. All
adults in this state are obligated to care for children and I know that you
will continue to make sure this happens.
Linda Mathis Tallahassee

Their report will be completed in several weeks. Thank you.

Jeb Bush

-----Original Message-----
From: Sharon Blair <jblair02@tampabay.rr.com>
To: McDonough, Jim <jim.mcdonough@myflorida.com>
CC: Jeb Bush <jeb@jeb.org>
Sent: Tue May 14 08:17:55 2002
Subject: FROM: SHARON BLAIR

May 14, 2002
 
cc: Gov. Jeb Bush
 
Jim,
 
 I read in today's St. Petersburg Times  (Pg.5-A) the Legislature rejected building a database to track people abusing prescriptions such as OxyContin, codeine and opiates. 
I support this database to protect and ensure a monitoring system for those who have addiction issues and abuse prescriptions. 
I want to let you and Gov. Bush know I am one voice of thousands whose family has been affected by substance abuse. (my daughter, Jennifer)  I wish the Legislature could sit down face to face with me, someone who has been through the war....the war of addiction, and hear me when I say we are facing challenges in our state and in our country and that traditional methods are not working to treat the ever growing problem of abusing drugs (prescription or other).  If an opiate addict cannot get heroin, they will doctor shop from one doctor to another to get the opiate based prescription they are craving.  Currently, we have no way of monitoring who these individuals are.  Therefore their addiction escalates, creating a bigger problem. 
I pray there is a seat waiting for me because I will sit between you and Gov. Bush and say what needs to be heard regarding this issue.  I believe a frank, open, honest look at this can result in positive changes to help those who need it. 
Discussion + Negotiation = Positive change for all.
 
Sincerely,
 
Sharon Blair
7364  118th Drive
Largo,  FL. 33773

-----Original Message-----
From: Arduin, Donna <Donna.Arduin@LASPBS.STATE.FL.US>
To: Jeb Bush <jeb@jeb.org>
CC: Shanahan, Kathleen <Kathleen.Shanahan@MyFlorida.com>; Dempsey, Hayden <hayden.dempsey@myflorida.com>; Woodring, Daniel <WoodriD@eog.state.fl.us>
Sent: Tue May 14 09:50:12 2002
Subject: FW: Amount of time needed for first round budget review with Governor Bush

Governor, I want to make sure you know what we are doing to help you review the budget. 

I hope you received the notebook we sent to you Friday. It contains a good review of what is in the budget. If you have any questions, I am always available by phone.

This Friday, we will send you an overview of member projects and other interesting spending items. We should have a brief discussion, so that I can explain what we have done. I will go through it with Kathleen as well. Hayden will get this list so that he can review. We will then need direction on the next step. 

We are giving Daniel items that require legal review. 

We will also provide an outlook for the 2004 budget...don' worry, we have a plan :) 




 -----Original Message----- 
From:   Arduin, Donna  
Sent:   Friday, May 10, 2002 3:42 PM 
To:     Wainwright, Tara 
Cc:     Hampton, Betty; Goins, Vickie; Shanahan, Kathleen 
Subject:        RE: Amount of time needed for first round budget review with Governor Bush 

I understand you are having a difficult time trying to find time to review the budget . Please let me know if we can not get time before the end of the month, so we can plan to have the Governor review the budget without meeting with us. We need to be done (sign the budget) by the first week in June so that we can go through our "start-up" process, which allows agencies to spend money on July 1. Unfortunately, the start-up process takes a month.

	Transportation & Economic

From: Bill Morgan <morganb@mindspring.com>
To: Jeb Bush <jeb@jeb.org>
Sent: Tue May 14 10:09:14 2002
Subject: Re: Republican rebuked for flier in primary

I am representing Voyager, a literacy curriculum for the state and local
levels.
This organization is based in Dallas and co-founded by Adm Thomas Haywood
former Chief of Naval Operations(ret). They are committed to literacy.
Following two years of research and a year of field-testing, Voyager began a
national rollout in September of 1997. In less than three years, Voyager's
research-based learning systems were operating in more than 1,000 of the
nation´s largest school districts across forty-five states, making Voyager
the largest provider of extended-time reading intervention and
adventure-based programs in America´s public schools.
http://voyagerlearning.com/index.jsp
To whom in the state should I contact in order to discuss our offering.
Thank you
Bill Morgan
407-523-7887

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Florida Governor [mailto:jeb.bush@myflorida.com]
> Sent: Wednesday, September 06, 2000 12:30 PM
> To: sally@jeb.org
> Subject: FW: Republican rebuked for flier in primary
> Importance: High
>
>
> political.
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Bill Morgan [mailto:morganb@mindspring.com]
> Sent: Sunday, September 03, 2000 11:40 PM
> To: jeb@myflorida.com
> Subject: Republican rebuked for flier in primary
> Importance: High
>
>
> My name is Bill Morgan.
> I am a Florida resident currently living in the Orlando area.
> I moved to Broward County just after Lawton Chiles was elected to the
> Governor's office.
> In a discussion of local politics with friends there the Governor's race
> came up.
> My friend related to me that the election had been tight and was decided,
by
> the narrowest of margins, right in Broward County.
> I may be oversimplifying it a bit, but it went something like this.
> Subsequent to the election it was learned that by use of false statements
> through phone banks Chiles's organization had been effective in swinging
> just enough of the elderly vote to carry the election.
> My friend was incensed that you had been possibly lost the election due to
> false campaigning. Since she and her husband-to-be had both helped in your
> campaign's effort.
> Her story and my later analysis led me to vote for you in this last
> Governor's race.
> The attached article is related to the topic of false campaign practices,
in
> order to try and make gains at the last moment a candidate for state house
> has resorted to similar tactics as those you were subjected too.
> Except this time it is in the Republican primary for district 91 of the
> state house.
> One change since Chiles election was the formation of a Fair Campaign
> Practices Committee in Broward County to deal with any similar future
> situations.
> They met in session from 5:30 till 8:30 on a Friday night before a holiday
> weekend to deal with the issue at hand. And thought there was enough merit
> to issue the attached rebuke. In a local race mind you.
> My friend that I mentioned earlier in this e-mail was Lynn Spinella
Pagans.
> I thought you might like to know.
> Her web site is:
> www.spinellapagans.com <http://www.spinellapagans.com>
>
> Respectfully,
> Bill Morgan

>   <http://www.sun-sentinel.com/bot/sectionheads/BOTimages/transp.gif>
>   <http://www.sun-sentinel.com/bot/sectionheads/BOTimages/transp.gif>
> Republican rebuked for flier in primary
>
> By DAVID FLESHLER
> Web-posted: 1:24 a.m. Sep. 2, 2000
>
> A new committee that monitors political campaigns issued its first public
> rebuke of a candidate on Friday, voting to criticize state House candidate
> Connie H. Mack for allegedly distorting his opponent's record on
education.
>    Just four days before the primary, the Fair Campaign Practices
Committee
> of Broward voted 7-3 to criticize Mack for "distortion and
misrepresentation
> of facts" concerning Lynn Spinella Pagans' position on Gov. Jeb Bush's
> school vouchers plan.
>    In a campaign flier, the Mack campaign wrote of Spinella Pagans:
>     "Losing badly in the polls, she is running a viciously negative
campaign
> against Connie Mack. Now, she's even gone so far as to attack Gov. Jeb
> Bush's A-Plus Education Plan (Palm Beach Post, 8/18/00). That's right: Ms.
> Spinella Pagans is attacking a program that will encourage children to
learn
> more, read earlier and receive the skills, training and support they need
> for the future. She's raising money from the most liberal elements of the
> Democratic Party -- people who want to defeat George W. Bush."
>    Spinella Pagans, competing in the Republican primary to represent House
> District 91, filed a complaint with the committee. She said she strongly
> supports the governor's education plan and has said so publicly many
times.
> She said she is a conservative Republican with no ties to left-wing
> Democrats.
>    The newspaper article mentioned in the flier quoted her saying that the
> education plan would be a "cold splash of water." By that, she said, she
> meant it would shake up the education system in a positive way.
>     In a statement issued after the decision, the Mack campaign took
nothing
> back. The statement said that Spinella Pagans had gotten a "sharp rebuke"
> from the committee and it said she had "clearly criticized" Bush's plan.
>     The committee tossed her complaint on ties to the Democrats, since she
> had allowed Democratic County Commissioner Lori Parrish to be host to a
> fund-raiser for her.
>    The 91st House district runs along the Intracoastal Waterway from Fort
> Lauderdale to Boca Raton.
>    The campaign practices group consists of 16 representatives of
> organizations such as the Broward Bar Association, the Broward Chamber of
> Commerce and the League of Women Voters. It is intended to investigate
> charges that candidates lied, appealed to ethnic or racial prejudice or
> spread innuendo about a candidate's personal life. The committee has no
> authority beyond the power to publicize unethical campaign practices.
>    Because the committee is venturing into local politics, there was a
fair
> amount of agonizing over whether to issue a rebuke.
>     David Fleshler can be reached at dfleshler@sun-sentinel.com or
> 954-356-4535.
>

-----Original Message-----
From: Floyd Ford <papajo@perry.gulfnet.com>

Sent: Tue May 14 10:26:00 2002
Subject: [Fwd: status of Funding for TCW&SD Water Treatment]

Dear Governor Bush,

This attached email summarizes the funding status for the waster water
treatment facility on the Coastline of Taylor County. We appreciate all
the support you and your staff have provided. We eagerly await the
decision by EDA officials on our grant request for $1,000,000!

Floyd Ford
Project Manager.

-----Original Message-----
From: Bill Morgan <morganb@mindspring.com>
To: Jeb Bush <jeb@jeb.org>
Sent: Tue May 14 10:09:14 2002
Subject: Re: Republican rebuked for flier in primary

I am representing Voyager, a literacy curriculum for the state and local
levels.
This organization is based in Dallas and co-founded by Adm Thomas
Haywood
former Chief of Naval Operations(ret). They are committed to literacy.
Following two years of research and a year of field-testing, Voyager
began a
national rollout in September of 1997. In less than three years,
Voyager's
research-based learning systems were operating in more than 1,000 of the
nation´s largest school districts across forty-five states, making
Voyager
the largest provider of extended-time reading intervention and
adventure-based programs in America´s public schools.
http://voyagerlearning.com/index.jsp
To whom in the state should I contact in order to discuss our offering.
Thank you
Bill Morgan
407-523-7887
----- Original Message -----
From: "Jeb Bush" <jeb@jeb.org>
To: <morganb@mindspring.com>
Sent: Wednesday, September 06, 2000 5:15 PM
Subject: FW: Republican rebuked for flier in primary


> Thank you for writing. I appreciate your interest in clean
campaigning.
>
> Jeb Bush
>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Florida Governor [mailto:jeb.bush@myflorida.com]
> Sent: Wednesday, September 06, 2000 12:30 PM
> To: sally@jeb.org
> Subject: FW: Republican rebuked for flier in primary
> Importance: High
>
>
> political.
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Bill Morgan [mailto:morganb@mindspring.com]
> Sent: Sunday, September 03, 2000 11:40 PM
> To: jeb@myflorida.com
> Subject: Republican rebuked for flier in primary
> Importance: High
>
>
> My name is Bill Morgan.
> I am a Florida resident currently living in the Orlando area.
> I moved to Broward County just after Lawton Chiles was elected to the
> Governor's office.
> In a discussion of local politics with friends there the Governor's
race
> came up.
> My friend related to me that the election had been tight and was
decided,
by
> the narrowest of margins, right in Broward County.
> I may be oversimplifying it a bit, but it went something like this.
> Subsequent to the election it was learned that by use of false
statements
> through phone banks Chiles's organization had been effective in
swinging
> just enough of the elderly vote to carry the election.
> My friend was incensed that you had been possibly lost the election
due to
> false campaigning. Since she and her husband-to-be had both helped in
your
> campaign's effort.
> Her story and my later analysis led me to vote for you in this last
> Governor's race.
> The attached article is related to the topic of false campaign
practices,
in
> order to try and make gains at the last moment a candidate for state
house
> has resorted to similar tactics as those you were subjected too.
> Except this time it is in the Republican primary for district 91 of
the
> state house.
> One change since Chiles election was the formation of a Fair Campaign
> Practices Committee in Broward County to deal with any similar future
> situations.
> They met in session from 5:30 till 8:30 on a Friday night before a
holiday
> weekend to deal with the issue at hand. And thought there was enough
merit
> to issue the attached rebuke. In a local race mind you.
> My friend that I mentioned earlier in this e-mail was Lynn Spinella
Pagans.
> I thought you might like to know.
> Her web site is:
> www.spinellapagans.com <http://www.spinellapagans.com>
>
> Respectfully,
> Bill Morgan

>
>   <http://www.sun-sentinel.com/bot/sectionheads/BOTimages/transp.gif>
>   <http://www.sun-sentinel.com/bot/sectionheads/BOTimages/transp.gif>
> Republican rebuked for flier in primary
>
> By DAVID FLESHLER
> Web-posted: 1:24 a.m. Sep. 2, 2000
>
> A new committee that monitors political campaigns issued its first
public
> rebuke of a candidate on Friday, voting to criticize state House
candidate
> Connie H. Mack for allegedly distorting his opponent's record on
education.
>    Just four days before the primary, the Fair Campaign Practices
Committee
> of Broward voted 7-3 to criticize Mack for "distortion and
misrepresentation
> of facts" concerning Lynn Spinella Pagans' position on Gov. Jeb Bush's
> school vouchers plan.
>    In a campaign flier, the Mack campaign wrote of Spinella Pagans:
>     "Losing badly in the polls, she is running a viciously negative
campaign
> against Connie Mack. Now, she's even gone so far as to attack Gov. Jeb
> Bush's A-Plus Education Plan (Palm Beach Post, 8/18/00). That's right:
Ms.
> Spinella Pagans is attacking a program that will encourage children to
learn
> more, read earlier and receive the skills, training and support they
need
> for the future. She's raising money from the most liberal elements of
the
> Democratic Party -- people who want to defeat George W. Bush."
>    Spinella Pagans, competing in the Republican primary to represent
House
> District 91, filed a complaint with the committee. She said she
strongly
> supports the governor's education plan and has said so publicly many
times.
> She said she is a conservative Republican with no ties to left-wing
> Democrats.
>    The newspaper article mentioned in the flier quoted her saying that
the
> education plan would be a "cold splash of water." By that, she said,
she
> meant it would shake up the education system in a positive way.
>     In a statement issued after the decision, the Mack campaign took
nothing
> back. The statement said that Spinella Pagans had gotten a "sharp
rebuke"
> from the committee and it said she had "clearly criticized" Bush's
plan.
>     The committee tossed her complaint on ties to the Democrats, since
she
> had allowed Democratic County Commissioner Lori Parrish to be host to
a
> fund-raiser for her.
>    The 91st House district runs along the Intracoastal Waterway from
Fort
> Lauderdale to Boca Raton.
>    The campaign practices group consists of 16 representatives of
> organizations such as the Broward Bar Association, the Broward Chamber
of
> Commerce and the League of Women Voters. It is intended to investigate
> charges that candidates lied, appealed to ethnic or racial prejudice
or
> spread innuendo about a candidate's personal life. The committee has
no
> authority beyond the power to publicize unethical campaign practices.
>    Because the committee is venturing into local politics, there was a
fair
> amount of agonizing over whether to issue a rebuke.
>     David Fleshler can be reached at dfleshler@sun-sentinel.com or
> 954-356-4535.
>
