MEDIA ADVISORY

Florida Board of Education

May 14, 2002

 
Bill Edmonds
Florida Board of Education
(850) 201-7130
 <mailto:bill.edmonds@flboe.org> bill.edmonds@flboe.org
 

Chancellor Candidate Review Team to hold conference call


The team named to guide the search for candidates for Chancellor of the Division of Community Colleges will hold a conference call on Friday, May 17, to discuss the process of selecting prospective nominees.

 
The Candidate Review Team’s call will commence at 2 p.m. EDT.
 
Members of the media may listen to the call. To dial in, call (877) 633-8285, 

and press 1. Enter the meeting ID number – 32426 – and press the # key. Speak your name and that of your newspaper or station and press # to end the recording. Follow the voice prompts to join the call.

 
Please put your phone on mute or take other steps to ensure you do not disrupt the conference call. Please do not call via a cell phone, as cellular calls create interference with the conference-call equipment. If you experience technical difficulties, call (703) 739-4774.
 
The Candidate Review Team was appointed by Education Secretary Jim Horne, in consultation with members of the Florida Board of Education, to conduct a search for qualified candidates. The review team will provide a list of candidates for Chancellor of the Division of Community Colleges, and Secretary Horne will draw from that list when he recommends a nominee to the Florida Board of Education.

Dear members and friends, 
 
How many of you read this story in your local newspaper courtesy of staff writer Carl Hiaasen of the Miami Herald? 
 
Did it make you wonder why it's so difficult for consumer advocates to insist that Full Disclosure not Caveat Emptor must become the "Buy Words" in the 'Sunshine State?' 
 
Did it make you wonder if your rights as a homeowner and taxpayer are being protected at the state and federal levels of government? 
 
Did you conjure up thoughts that the 'good ole boy' network is alive and well in Florida while the tenacles have a far reaching effect?

Posted on Sun, May. 12, 2002
  <http://www.miami.com/images/component/topstory_fromthe_txt.gif>  story:PUB_DESC <http://www.miami.com/images/logos/site/miami/miamiherald/archives_title.gif> 	  <http://www.miami.com/images/common/spacer.gif> 	
  <http://www.miami.com/images/common/spacer.gif> 	

CARL HIAASEN
The high cost of changing Panhandle's name


If the St. Joe Co. has its way, Florida's historic Panhandle soon will be known as Florida's ``Great Northwest.''

....The company wants to lure thousands of baby boomers to North Florida, where it is planning no less than 20 major projects.

....St. Joe bought Arvida and launched big-time into real-estate development. With almost a million acres, including 39 miles of coast, St. Joe is Florida's largest landholder.

Its ambition is to populate the quiet Panhandle with smitten vacationers-turned-home buyers. .....If the good folks of Bay, Walton, Franklin and Gulf counties think that St. Joe has only their best interests at heart, they are sadly deluded.

...The Gulf County Commission rolled over like a fat hound...(for St. Joe),,,,,,,,, and said sure, let's move the road. Irate residents never got to vote on the matter.

But that's nothing compared to the Bay County airport boondoggle... And who would pay for St. Joe's airport? ...About 80 percent of the $200 million-plus construction cost would come from....your pocket and mine.

The Bush brothers, George W. and Jeb, love this idea. So does the Florida Legislature, which is always keen to help out struggling multibillion-dollar corporations.

...the state has committed about $10 million...President Bush....and the feds quickly kicked in $2 million to get the ball rolling.

If St. Joe pulls this off, even its critics would have to marvel. What a feat for a private company....to advance its own agenda. 

...the folks in those strapped rural counties of Florida's ''great northwest'' don't stand much of a chance in deciding their own future. That's bad enough.

What's worse is how St. Joe is relying on every other Floridian to subsidize and enrich its real-estate juggernaut with new beachfront, new highways, a new airport.

It's the ultimate corporate panhandle in a place that could not be more aptly named.

Naturally, St. Joe wants to call it something else.

From: lakeith Amir-Sharif [mailto:amirsharif1@hotmail.com]

Subject: Sharif/Officials Responses To May 8th 1997 Beating at Charlotte Corr. Inst.



On May 08th, 1997, while handcuffed behind my back,  I was brutally beaten and stomped by guards employed by the Florida Dept. Of Corrections ( FDOC ) at Charlotte Corr. Inst. in Punta Gorda, Florida. The FDOC and other agencies with knowledge of the beating, and a responsibility of investigating the same,contend that nothing happen. That the guards and the FDOC followed "procedures", and that none of the investigations (by the Florida Dept. Of Law Enforcement(FDLE), Charlotte County State Attorneys, FBI, U.S. Dept. Of Justice Civil Rights Division) uncovered any wrongdoing on the part of my attackers or the FDOC, that would constitute a crime under either state or federal law. How they arrived at their questionable conclusions is something you can ask yourself after reviewing the attached documents and those that will follow.
 
Did the FDOC and the other agencies have a unspoken interest to collaborate and conceal my beating and other violence by guards that did and continues to result in the death of prisoners under FDOC control; such as John Allen Edwards who was sadistically murdered by 10 guards at the same prison nearly 60-days after I was beaten. (It should be noted that five of the guards who were federally indicted in the murder of Edwards, were the same guards whom I'd sought, but was denied protection from, by the prison and FDOC administrators in Tallahassee, prior to and after I was brutally beaten.)
 
Attached:
 
1. Feb. 12, 1998, Public Records Request from attorney Peter M. Siegel, to Charlotte County State Attorney Joseph P. D'Alessandro for copy of FDOC investigation #97-51292.
 
2. May 01, 1998, letter from Richard W. Roberts,Chief, Criminal Section of U.S. Dept. of Justice Civil Rights Division.
 
3. May 19, 1998, letter from attorney Peter M. Siegel.
 
4. May 27, 1998, letter from Melaine High Tuttle, Charlotte County Asst. State Attorney office.
 
5. Sept. 08, 1998, letter from Robert C. Howell, Investigator for Charlotte County State Attorney Office.
 
6. May 05, 1998, letter from Ebony Philmore, FDOC Correspondence Control officer.
 
7. Unasked/Unanswered Questions.
 
8. Pictures after beating.
 
 
 
 
"How can prisoners be expected to reenter society with a commitment to lawful behavior when all around them during their incarceration they are exposed to wide-scale violence and corruption by the very officials whom should be setting positive examples for the prisoner to emulate"?
 
 
Sharif

-----Original Message-----
From: Kevin Neal [mailto:KNeal@PSC.STATE.FL.US]
Sent: Tuesday, May 14, 2002 11:56 AM
To: Brian Yablonski (E-mail)
Subject: AP-Court rules to keep phone lines open


Court rules to keep phone lines open
By Gina Holland
THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

WASHINGTON - The Supreme Court on Monday upheld a key part of the
government's effort to give Americans choices for local telephone service.

The ruling keeps costs low for companies that want to get into a market and
could eventually lead to cheaper service for consumers.

Congress approved a plan to open up the $110 billion local telephone service
market to competition in 1996. Since then, companies ordered to make lines
available to upstart competitors have been contesting the details in court,
and many people still have no options.

Justices affirmed the way the government requires companies that were part
of the old Bell system to lease their lines. They also ruled that regulators
could require the former Bells to make more network connections available to
competitors.

The loser in the case was a conglomeration of former Bells, including
Verizon Communications, which wanted to be able to charge other telephone
companies higher fees to use their lines. Verizon contested the fee system
set up by federal regulators, arguing that it cannot recover it own
construction costs.

Consumer advocates had said if the pricing rules were overturned,
competition efforts would stall. So far, less than 10 percent of the old
Bell system is being leased by rival companies for residential service, they
said.

"This preserves a glimmer of hope for the development of local telephone
competition," said Gene Kimmelman, of the Consumers Union.

Federal Communications Commission Chairman Michael Powell said the ruling
"brings much-needed additional certainty to the legal landscape" and should
help the commission speed up changes.

Bob Bishop, Verizon spokesman, said the system has not worked and the FCC
should now consider other options.

BellSouth Inc. said in a statement that the "decision maintains an
unfortunate status quo: BellSouth must continue to provide pieces of its
network to competitors at below-cost prices. This status quo discourages
investment by both us and our competitors, resulting in poorer choices for
customers."

The decision in the complicated case has been the slowest of this term.
Justices heard arguments six months ago. Justice Stephen Breyer, joined in
part by Justice Antonin Scalia, said in a dissent that regulators were given
too much authority to order phone companies to make changes for competitors.
Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, who has stock in AT&T and WorldCom, did not
participate in the case.

-----Original Message-----
From: Schreiber, Jr., Charles J. [mailto:cjschreiber@batemanharden.com]
Sent: Tuesday, May 14, 2002 9:34 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Just wanted to make certain your Honor's staff had this one on their radar screen:




Lapides v. Bd. of Regents of the Univ. Sys. of Georgia

Decided: 05/13/02

No. 01-298

Full Text:  <http://laws.findlaw.com/us/000/01-298.html> http://laws.findlaw.com/us/000/01-298.html

ELEVENTH AMENDMENT (State's Removal of Lawsuit From State Court to Federal Court Waives Eleventh Amendment Immunity)

The United States Supreme Court held unanimously (opinion by Breyer) that a state's removal of a lawsuit from state court to federal court is a form of voluntary invocation of a federal court's jurisdiction sufficient to waive the state's Eleventh Amendment immunity.

Paul Lapides, a professor in the Georgia state university system, filed suit against the Board of Regents of the University Systems of Georgia (Georgia) in a Georgia state court alleging that university officials placed allegations of sexual harassment in his personnel files. He alleged this violated Georgia and federal law. Georgia voluntarily joined in removing the case to Federal District Court. While the District Court ruled the doctrine of qualified immunity barred the federal law claim, it ruled Georgia had waived its Eleventh Amendment immunity by removing the state-law case from state to federal court. The Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit reversed, stating that state law was unclear as to whether the state's attorney general possessed the legal authority to waive the state's Eleventh Amendment immunity, thus allowing Georgia to retain the legal right to assert its immunity, even after removal. The United States Supreme Court reversed, upholding the general principle that where a state voluntarily becomes a party to a cause and submits its rights for judicial determination, it cannot escape the result of its own voluntary act by invoking Eleventh Amendment immunity. The Court recognized Georgia was brought involuntarily into the case as a defendant in the state-court proceedings, but held Georgia's voluntary removal to federal court invoked the federal court's jurisdiction. [Summarized by Kimberly Larson]

 

UNITED STATES SUPREME COURT NEWS

Wanted to make sure you saw this...great for Florida



Tuesday, May 14, 2002

Last modified at 11:04 p.m. on Monday, May 13, 2002
Jacksonville lawyer tapped to manage FEMA
By Jessie-Lynne Kerr
Times-Union staff writer
Jacksonville lawyer Reynold N. Hoover, an aviation counterterrorism and
security expert, is the new chief of staff for the Federal Emergency
Management Agency in Washington, it was announced yesterday by FEMA Director
Joe Allbaugh.
Hoover, whose wife, Lucy, is an FBI agent in Jacksonville, resigned his
position with the Smith, Hulsey & Busey law firm to return to work for the
federal government. He previously served as a special agent for the Bureau
of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms for 17 years before joining the law firm
nearly three years ago.
While with ATF, Hoover's responsibilities included developing explosives
countermeasures and counterterrorism training programs for the aviation
community.
"Reynold brings excellent management experience to FEMA as well as valuable
knowledge of counterterrorism strategy," Allbaugh said. "His leadership will
be an important asset as FEMA implements President Bush's agenda for a
better-prepared nation."
As chief of staff, Hoover, 40, will be responsible for the daily operations
of the agency and for executing the priorities and policies set by Allbaugh.

FEMA programs include disaster response and recovery, hazard mitigation,
training, preparedness exercises, insurance and fire prevention.
Headquartered in Washington, FEMA has 10 regional offices with a permanent
staff of 2,600, a temporary staff of 4,000 and a $6.4 billion annual budget.

As an associate at the Smith, Hulsey & Busey law firm, Hoover worked in
commercial litigation, said Lanny Russell, a partner.
"He got significantly involved in our firm's representation of the Bush
presidential campaign," Russell said. Hoover was the attorney for the Duval
County Republican Party during the presidential election recount.
Long considered an explosives expert, he took a leave of absence from the
firm this year to supervise security at the Salt Lake City Olympics, Russell
added.
"He's a good guy with a lot of talent and energy," Russell said. "Reynold is
talented in his organizational skills, is detail-oriented and focused."
While working with the law firm, Russell added, Hoover did some work for a
congressional committee preparing legislation concerning the licensing of
those who work with explosives and testified as an expert witness in
explosives.
Hoover graduated from the U.S. Military Academy at West Point in 1983.
He served in the Army and Army National Guard for nearly 20 years and was
awarded the Bronze Star for service in Operation Desert Storm.


From:	Nora Williams <namandawilliams@yahoo.com>

Governor,

In this my last week as a County Commissioner, I planned to attend my last meeting tomorrow and make a graceful exit, with thanks to you for the pleasure it was to serve the State under your leadership.

It being me, however, I managed to swoon in the bathroom over the weekend and break my ribs. Apparently, the job has aged me more than I realized (-;. In short, I'm in a great deal of pain, pretty much immobilized, and fairly certain that graceful is not on my list of options. 

So I'll be delivering a statement this aftenroon to be read on my behalf. I WILL laugh about this in years to come but, just for your own safety, when next we're at a public function, be careful never to ask me to dance. 

Nora Williams

WHoa Nelly!!!!!!

>  -----Original Message-----
> From: 	Brown, Brewser  
> Sent:	Tuesday, May 14, 2002 1:54 PM
> To:	'jeb@jeb.org'; Brogan, Frank; Muniz, Katie; McDougal, Kim;
> Turbeville, Greg
> Subject:	USA Today editorial
> 
>   
>  
>   
>   
>  
> 05/13/2002 - Updated 09:21 PM ET  
>   
>  
>  
>  
>  
> Pay teachers their worth
> 
> An annual headache for Jim Warford, the superintendent of schools in
> Marion County, Fla., is finding teachers for the advanced math and science
> courses many competitive colleges demand. This year, one high school
> offered Advanced Placement physics only after school, taught by a retired
> teacher.
> 
> The problem is pay. The most Warford can offer is $30,549 - for 10-year
> veterans.
> 
> In part, that's because all teachers are paid alike regardless of the
> supply and demand for their specialty and whether they do a good job. One
> solution is to treat teachers like other professionals. Top performers
> could get fatter paychecks, and higher salaries could be used to attract
> candidates for hard-to-fill jobs.
> 
> Outside of teaching, many employees are familiar with merit pay and
> salaries set by market forces. But the concept is anathema to the National
> Education Association (NEA), the nation's largest teachers union. Teachers
> do equally valuable work, it argues. They deserve equal pay.
> 
> Breaking out of that mind-set could produce dramatic improvements in
> teacher quality, according to an upcoming report from the Progressive
> Policy Institute, a centrist Democrat think tank. The report, to be
> released this month, advocates realigning the ways that schools divvy up
> the $109 billion spent annually paying teachers.
> 
> Currently, nearly all districts decide teacher salaries on just two
> criteria: experience and advanced degrees. But there's little evidence
> that either ensures high quality.
> 
> While experience can be important, some 20-year veterans are less
> effective than new teachers. The link between advanced degrees and teacher
> quality is even weaker.
> 
> The report suggests that paying teachers based on need, knowledge and
> skills could improve quality. Here are some options:
> 
> Give higher salaries to teachers stepping into hard-to-fill specialties
> such as math, science and special education.
> 
> Pay higher salaries to teachers in hard-to-staff schools in urban and
> rural areas. In urban school districts, about half the new teachers leave
> within the first five years.
> 
> Raise salaries for teachers who take on a school's most difficult
> challenges.
> 
> Pay more for teachers who demonstrate superior knowledge and skills, or
> link salaries and bonuses to student learning. Outside evaluators or
> student test data could measure learning.
> 
> By increasing pay for hard-to-fill specialties, schools could conduct an
> easy test of the concept. Yet the NEA insists on fighting the reform. It
> says that paying math teachers extra could trigger shortages.
> 
> If so, the marketplace could correct the problem without the union's
> interference. Teacher quality won't improve until schools stop paying
> teachers alike and start paying them what they're worth. 
>  
>  
>

Laura: this is the article Dr. Medows was sending you.
State health care administrator tours Immokalee medical center 
Tuesday, May 14, 2002 
By LIZ FREEMAN, epfreeman@naplesnews.com <mailto:epfreeman@naplesnews.com> 
The secretary of the state Agency for Health Care Administration strolled
the halls of the Marion E. Fether Medical Center in Immokalee on Monday,
getting a quick immersion in how the primary-care clinic is a life link to
the farmworker community. 
"It's gorgeous," Secretary Rhonda Medows said. "It's amazing. I wish I could
model it for other places." 
 <<...OLE_Obj...>> 	 <<...OLE_Obj...>>   <<...OLE_Obj...>>  Dr. Jerry
Williamson speaks with Rhonda Medows, the secretary of the state Agency for
Health Care Administration, during a tour of the Marion E. Fether Clinic in
Immokalee on Monday. Dan Wagner <mailto:dtwagner@naplesnews.com>/Staff	
Medows, who since August has been at the helm of the agency that oversees
the bulk of the state's health-care industry, came to Southwest Florida for
the first time to meet with some health-care providers and agency staff in
field offices. 
The visit is part of a statewide tour she's making of health-care entities
that receive state Medicaid funding, to see how well the programs are
performing. She made earlier visits to health-care centers in Jacksonville,
Pensacola, Tampa/St. Petersburg and Miami. 
The Marion E. Fether clinic is run by the private, nonprofit Collier Health
Services Inc. (CHSI), and it provides a full range of basic medical care,
including dental care, to a largely indigent and culturally diverse
community. 
The clinic had 120,000 patient visits last year, of which about 25 percent
of the patients are on Medicaid. Budget figures for the Immokalee clinic
alone weren't immediately available, but CHSI's total budget last year is
$12 million, of which $3.9 million is Medicaid funding, CHSI administrator
Richard Akin said. 
Medows' tour was given by Dr. Jerry Williamson, CHSI's medical director, who
talked about how the clinic has evolved since it opened in 1993 and how
there are eight interpreters on hand to provide language translation between
the medical staff and patients, many of whom migrated to Immokalee from
Mexico, Haiti, Guatemala and elsewhere. 
"Half the problem is getting people to understand what you want them to do,"
Medows said about language barriers between patients and medical
professionals. 
Medows was asked about a new program - generically known as an
intergovernmental loan program - being developed out of this year's
legislative session that would provide more funding for primary-care
services. By offering local money, communities can tap matching state
Medicaid money and be eligible for federal money. The program will require
the pooled money to be allocated to a local hospital, which then funnels it
to a primary-care clinic that's designated to receive federal dollars. CHSI
has that designation. 
The program is being considered by the county's Health and Human Services
Committee to address the indigent-care problem, but no word has come down
from Tallahassee yet whether funding was allocated in the new state budget. 
Medows said she wasn't familiar with the program and couldn't comment.

From:	dottie ann <dottyan1@bellsouth.net>
Sent:	Tuesday, May 14, 2002 2:38 PM
To:	leo; kim; joyce; jennifer; Jeb Bush; jaime; inda; debbie; david2; cindy; carol jean; bev
Cc:	rush@eibnet.com; NADFINE
Subject:	Fw: Weldon Statement: VA Health Care: Structural Problems, Superficial Solutions?

 
----- Original Message ----- 
From: Groover, Pamela <mailto:Pamela.Groover@mail.house.gov>  
Sent: Tuesday, May 14, 2002 2:14 PM
Subject: Weldon Statement: VA Health Care: Structural Problems, Superficial Solutions?


FROM THE OFFICE OF REP. DAVE WELDON, M.D. 
For Immediate Release: May 14, 2002 
Contact: Pamela Groover at 202-225-3671 Statement by Rep. Dave Weldon, M.D. (FL-15) Subcommittee on National Security, Veterans Affairs, and International Relations 

I appreciate the Chairman for calling this hearing today, I am pleased to see Dr. Bob Roswell is his new position here before us today.  I have had the pleasure of working with you over the past few years while you served as VISN 8 Director in Florida. While Dr. Roswell presided over VISN 8 we saw the funding for VISN 8 increase by about 40%; however, we also saw the number of veterans seeking service in VISN 8 increase by 40%.  This is a critical point.  Because as we look at the impact of VERA, we must also consider the dramatic increases in utilization of the VA that we have seen in places like Florida.  While VERA has made funding a little more equitable, those of us representing growth states still see significant funding problems and believe that much more progress needs to be made.  While the Chairman and I come from very different regions of the country and come at VERA from a different perspective, I believe that we share a common goal of working toward best serving the veterans who have given of themselves to defend our liberties. Just yesterday I received the following message from one of those veterans who happens to live in Florida.  My constituent wrote: "Veterans health care at Viera [outpatient clinic] claims they can't accept any more veterans.  I am a disabled veteran from World War II.  The steel company I worked for went out of business.  I lost my hospitalization, and need protection from the high cost of medicine. I am 80 years of age and back in 1943/44 I flew 69 missions over Europe as tail gunner and I have the Purple Heart. I was also promised health care if I ever needed it." Another constituent told me he has "been enrolled with the VA clinic at Viera for well over one-year.  I am a 'category 5' nearly poverty level income... I am told they are not making any more appointments and haven't for over one year...  They do not know when the situation will change.  What good is a VA clinic if they won't make any new appointments?  My income in 2001 was $22,000 and my medical bills were over $9,000." Let me play for you the recorded message that veterans in my Congressional District in Florida get when they call the local medical VA clinic to enroll or get an appointment. (Transcript below) You have reached the Brevard VA outpatient clinic enrollment eligibility office.  We are either on the phone or assisting another veteran at this time. If you are calling about the status of your application, our clinic has reached full capacity and we cannot take any new patients. If you have submitted an application after January 1st 2002, your name will automatically be placed on our waiting list, and you will receive a letter when we can start taking new patients again.  We do not anticipate that happening this year so please do not call us to ask where you are on the list or how long it will be before we contact you by letter. If you wish to be placed on the waiting list, plea leave your name, full social security number and telephone number and we will return your call within 72 hours.  Thank you for calling and have a great day. Clearly, we do not have enough resources in Florida to meet the needs of the thousands of veterans like these, who are waiting to enroll or simply waiting for an appointment to see a provider.  I also know about this shortage first hand, as I volunteer my medical services at the Viera clinic on a monthly basis.  I see it first hand every month as I see patients. In contrast to this shortage in Florida, I was troubled when I came across the following letter from the Bronx, NY, VA Medical Center inviting all veterans to come by for a free annual exam.  The letter reads: Dear Veteran: On behalf of the [VA] may we extend our best wished to you on your Birthday. As part of our reorganization the VA Medical Centers are expanding to make our facilities more friendly and accessible to all our veterans.  At present, we have a program whereby all veterans may receive a yearly physical examination free.  Thereby offering one and all the opportunity to see for themselves, at no expense, the quality services offered by our team of expert medical clinicians.  Also, Veterans scheduling a free physical exam will also receive a free eye exam and glasses at General Vision Opticians (convenient locations). If you are interested in arranging for an appointment, please call....We will arrange for an appointment, at your convenience, as soon as possible..." Meanwhile, back in Florida, A 78-year-old veteran wrote me earlier this year stating: "I have a service-connected hearing disability and need hearing aids desperately.... However, due to the critical shortage of doctors, it will be more than one year before I will be assigned to a doctor....' In Florida the VA says we don't have enough money - give us a call next year. In New England the VA sends out a birthday letter inviting the veteran to come in for a yearly physical, hearing and eye exam.  How is this possible?  Clearly, VERA needs to be updated to better reflect the needs of veterans across the nation.  We have a good start, but he inequity is far too large.  We have a lag time in allocation of VA dollars that is about a year and a half behind.  With the type of growth rates we are seeing in Florida we cannot allow this to keep happening.  In Florida we have over FORTY-TWO THOUSAND veterans on a waiting list to see a primary care provider.  They cannot even get in the door.  The waiting list in Central Florida alone has grown from 12,000 to 16,000 in just the last two months.  We have thousands more who are on a waiting list just to get enrolled in VA care. Our veterans deserve better. I thank the chairman for holding this hearing and I look forward to his working with me to address these important matters. 

###

From: Kevin Neal [mailto:KNeal@PSC.STATE.FL.US]

Subject: Dallas Morning News-Bells' rivals bypass residences to focus on
b usinesses 


Bells' rivals bypass residences to focus on businesses 
05/12/2002 

By VIKAS BAJAJ / The Dallas Morning News 

The local phone bill is proving too cheap to pick a fight over. 

Few challengers are bothering to battle Southwestern Bell for Jane Consumer.
She's already getting a sweet deal from the monopoly: She's only charged a
portion of what phone service costs. 

The rest of the tab is footed by long-distance callers and businesses, some
regulators and industry officials say. 

Six years after Congress declared the local phone bout open, many Bell
rivals are lobbing sales pitches mainly to businesses. Only 5.5 percent of
homes and small companies are served by the challengers, compared with 9
percent for all phone lines. 

"As long as you have a subsidy, you are trying to make water run uphill,"
said Dr. Alfred Kahn, an adjunct economics professor at Cornell University. 

But untangling the phone subsidy web is controversial. Southwestern Bell and
the three other Baby Bell monopolies would like to raise basic rates to
encourage competition. In return, consumers are promised lower long-distance
rates and businesses lower local phone bills. 

The Florida Legislature recently authorized an increase in basic rates, but
many other states have roundly rejected rate hikes. 

"The system is ugly, not at all effective and it does discourage
competition," said Robert C. Atkinson, director of policy research at
Columbia University's Institute for Tele-Information. "But the reality is
... legal, regulatory processes tend to move slowly." 

Subsidies are a legacy of a 1919 deal struck by AT&T's then-chairman
Theodore Vail and President Woodrow Wilson. The company won a monopoly in
exchange for regulation. 

Low local rates, about $11 in Dallas today, have helped bring phones to the
masses. Today, 95 percent of American homes have phones. 

"There is a real benefit of having the country interlinked, and so in the
early stage we subsidized getting people linked," said Dr. Kahn, who has
testified on behalf of Verizon Communications Inc., the nation's biggest
local phone company. 

Some legislators and consumer advocates, who oppose rate increases, agree
that subsidies played a key role in the past but contend that their effect
today is overstated. Rivals such as MCI and AT&T are raising a sustained
attack on the Bells on the home front, they say. 

"It is remedied now," said Texas House Rep. Steve Wolens, D-Dallas. "The
Legislature has exercised a thoughtful judgment on what basis telephone
services should be regulated and deregulated, and ... permitted deregulation
in areas that are not essential." 

Bell rivals say it's only natural that businesses would benefit from
competition before consumers because businesses use more phone and data
links. But as challengers master the game, they're warming up to consumers
as well. 

At what price? 


The issue's contentiousness and complexity is highlighted by experts'
inability to agree on just how much of the local phone bill remains
subsidized. 
SBC Communications Inc., Southwestern Bell's corporate parent, couldn't
quantify how much its local rates are subsidized. 

Economists and policy-makers answer many thorny questions when setting
rates: What does basic local service cost in relation to Caller ID or voice
mail? What's an appropriate subsidized price in rural areas where people
live farther apart? 

The interplay of different rates has been fine-tuned by regulators over
decades to achieve certain economic and political goals, said Brad Ramsey,
general counsel of National Association of Regulatory Utility Commissioners.


"Business rates do typically subsidize residential rates in most
jurisdictions, and urban people subsidize rural rates," he said. "There are
a lot of different mechanisms. It's not just explicit [subsidy] funds. It's
also rate differences and geographical rate averaging." 

But if costs were tabulated differently, basic residential phone service
wouldn't seem cheap, said Janee Briesemeister, a Consumers Union policy
analyst in Austin. 

For example, modern telephone switching equipment has technology built in
for features such as Caller ID, she said. But much of the machines' cost is
assigned to local phone service. 

"If you look at all services and allocate the cost fairly, local service is
not provided below cost," Ms. Briesemeister said. "You don't need a fancy
switch to make plain old telephone service." 

But some regulators say it is clear that businesses, on average, pay twice
as much as consumers for a telephone line. This has encouraged Bell
competitors to target companies, not homes, said Brett Perlman, a Texas
Public Utility Commissioner. 

"It's the Jesse James school of competition: People go where the money is,"
he said. 

How close is too far 


Subsidies are also funneled from long-distance rates to local phone service.

AT&T and others pay Southwestern Bell access charges for each minute the
local network is used for a long-distance call. The fees come in two
flavors: interstate and in-state. 

"The idea was that people who use long-distance paid more in order for local
rates to stay low," said Judy Walsh, SBC's senior vice president of state
regulatory compliance and policy. 

The interstate charge is about 1 cent a minute. In exchange for reducing the
rate in the late 1990s, the Federal Communications Commission let the Baby
Bells levy a $5 monthly fee on local phone bills. 

Southwestern Bell's in-state fee in Texas is 5.7 cents a minute. 

(The PUC wants to lower the charges, but SBC has sued to block it, saying
only the Legislature can do so.) 

High in-state charges mean Dallas residents often pay more to call Austin
than New York. 

In some other states, keeping local rates low has other peculiar
consequences. 

In New Jersey, regulators have kept local calling areas small so basic rates
can be as low as $8 a month, said Mr. Atkinson, a Garden State resident. 

"Any call of any distance here is a long-distance call," he said. 

Profit centers 


Those examples are worrisome, but they don't present the full picture, some
policy-makers and industry officials say. 
In Texas, Southwestern Bell has been able to set the rates on features such
as Caller ID and three-way calling since 1999. The company has doubled or
tripled the price on some features. 

Allowing those fees to climb has eliminated the need to raise basic prices,
Mr. Wolens said. 

"The killer profit center for them is Caller ID," he said. "It's just
enormous profit. The cost of that is next to nothing." 

Local phone companies can't afford to lose money on consumers, even with
higher business rates, said Royce Holland, chairman and chief executive of
Dallas-based Allegiance Telecom Inc. 

"In urban areas, most lines are profitable," Mr. Holland said. "When you get
access charges, Caller ID, call waiting, that really fattens [profit]
margins." 

Those fees have made it possible for competitors to break into the local
phone market, said Billy Jack Gregg, a board member at the National
Regulatory Research Institute at Ohio State University. 

For instance, MCI's new Neighborhood package includes local service, several
phone features and unlimited long-distance for $50 to $60. 

"The market itself will ferret out subsidies if they indeed exist," Mr.
Gregg said. 

But Caller ID and other features don't nullify subsidies because many people
aren't buying, said Ms. Walsh, a former Texas PUC commissioner. 

Rivals can skim away businesses and affluent consumers who buy many
features. But that leaves SBC to serve everyone else, she said. 

"Every time a customer is taken away [from us] ... their vertical features
and access charges go, too," Ms. Walsh said. "We have a bigger percentage of
customers that need a subsidy." 

SBC says rivals have another key advantage: They can lease its telephone
wires and equipment at low wholesale rates set by regulators. Some states,
including Texas, are considering further reducing those prices, on average
about $21 per line here. 

"Lowering the [wholesale] ... prices is a real danger and threat to the
whole economic structure of the industry," Ms. Walsh said. 

Adjusting rates 


The Supreme Court is reviewing a Baby Bell challenge to the method
regulators use to calculate wholesale prices. A decision is expected soon. 
But rivals say lower wholesale rates are justified because newer telephone
technologies are more efficient. 

"The [wholesale] rates in Texas are relatively low, but ... other SBC states
have set prices significantly lower," said Neal Larsen, WorldCom Inc.'s
director of public policy in Austin. "We are making money in Dallas and
Houston, not a whole lot, but it's at least profitable ... We don't need to
raise local rates to do that." 

Mr. Atkinson, the Columbia scholar and a former FCC official, proposes a
food stamps approach to telephone subsidies. People who can't pay full
freight would receive discount vouchers. The money would come from a fund
financed by all phone users. 

Current universal service funds already help rural and low-income urban
users, but the subsidy is given to local phone companies, not customers. 

"Some people's bill will go up and others will drop," Mr. Atkinson said.
"It's ridiculous to subsidize one of your oil millionaires. But by the same
token, it's absolutely necessary to subsidize rural farmers." 

SBC says regulators should let the market set local phone rates because
competitors will keep local phone companies in check. 

"If policy-makers would allow some pricing freedom, then residential prices
would be raised to the point where competition would come in and find it
valuable to serve those customers," Ms. Walsh said. 

'Do no harm' 


But it's counterproductive to raise rates to encourage competition, said Mr.
Gregg, who is also director of West Virginia Public Service Commission's
consumer advocate division. 
"It's akin to destroying the village in order to save it," he said. "We want
to raise rates to induce competition to [then] lower rates. But we already
have low rates. My maxim is to first do no harm." 

Regulators are terrified at the prospect of people giving up phone service
if basic prices rise. 

"You don't want to be in a situation where our telephone penetration is
going down," FCC Commissioner Kevin J. Martin said. 

Despite stiff opposition, some governments have taken a stab at subsidies. 

In Florida, Gov. Jeb Bush recently signed a bill that would raise local
rates by $3 to $8 in return for lower long-distance access charges. 

But a Kansas measure that would free SBC from most rate regulation by 2005
has foundered. Lawmakers there have said there isn't enough competition to
keep the company honest once it's unleashed. 

Legislators and regulators expect SBC to push for more freedom in Texas
during next year's legislative session. 

"The Legislature is going to have to take up that issue," Mr. Perlman said.
"Basic, local rates are frozen through 2005, and that issue will come up, if
not this session, then the next session." 

E-mail vbajaj@dallasnews.com

From:	Jimenez, Frank <Frank.Jimenez@MyFlorida.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, May 14, 2002 3:07 PM

-----Original Message-----
From: Kalb, Eileen [mailto:Eileen.Kalb@LASPBS.STATE.FL.US]
Sent: Tuesday, May 14, 2002 2:53 PM
To: Sartin, Sandy; Branker, Laura; Jimenez, Frank; Muniz, Katie; Yablonski, Brian
Subject: Preliminary General Revenue Report



You will be receiving this report on a monthly basis, as requested by Don Langston.

The attached is a preliminary gauge of general revenue that is expected to be collected for the month of April based on current collection information. These data will change once the Department of Revenue completes processing the receipts for this month.

 The attached report shows that General Revenue collections for April exceeded estimate by just over $132 million, more than offsetting the March shortfall of $80 million.  The April number brings year-to-date collections to $52 million over estimate.  A closer examination reveals that, on a year-to-date basis, most of the individual revenue sources, including sales tax, are very close to the projections made in early March.  The exception is corporate income tax, which is over estimate by $85 million.  

 While the April numbers are certainly positive it is important to put them in perspective. Note that sales tax collections increased only about 2.5% over April of last year.  For Florida, this is very modest growth and is indicative that there is still some lingering weakness in the economy.  Also, even with April's results, corporate income tax year-to-date is 7% below the same period last year.  The point is, that the worst is behind us, but we have yet to achieve the kind of revenue growth associated with a full-blown economic expansion.  The prospects are very good, though.  Generally, the economy is progressing as expected.  There is solid economic evidence that a modest recovery is under way.  Since last February, when the official economic forecast was adopted, the national economic outlook has improved marginally.  It would not be surprising to see further gains relative to estimate in coming months, though it is still too early to tell if April was an aberration or a sign of things to come.

From:	Jimenez, Frank <Frank.Jimenez@MyFlorida.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, May 14, 2002 6:51 PM
To:	Steele, Leslie; Grant, Wendy
Cc:	Yablonski, Brian; Jeb Bush; Shanahan, Kathleen; Muniz, Katie; Hirst, Elizabeth; Winn, John; McDougal, Kim; Muniz, Carlos; Canady, Charles T.
Subject:	RE: U-M law school affirmative action victory sets stage for Supreme Court appeal

This ruling about the Univ. of Michigan law school has made national news
today.  The key points to remember are (1) this was a sharply divided 5-4
decision by the 6th Circuit today, (2) the 5th Circuit (TX, LA, MS) and the
11th Circuit (FL, GA, AL) have issued contrary opinions, (3) because the
11th Circuit governs Florida, we would have had no choice but to comply with
its decision requiring race-neutrality had One Florida not already been in
effect, (4) this is headed to the Supreme Court, so it's far from over, and
(5) isn't it far superior to achieve diversity in a way that is safe from
the vagaries and shifting tides of judicial opinions and ballot initiatives?

-----Original Message-----
From: Steele, Leslie 
Sent: Tuesday, May 14, 2002 6:43 PM
To: Grant, Wendy; PRESS OFFICE
Cc: Jimenez, Frank; Yablonski, Brian; 'jeb@jeb.org'
Subject: U-M law school affirmative action victory sets stage for
Supreme Court appeal


  FYI
A key factor in the university's victory was that the 6th Circuit found UM's
law school admissions policy agrees with a 1978 Supreme Court decision in
the Bakke case. Justic Lewis s Powell said in his opinion that a racially
diverse student body is a compelling governmental interest, justifying the
use of race, said Robert Sedler, Wayne State University law professor.

 
 http://www.freep.com/news/latestnews/pm9211_20020514.htm

-----Original Message-----
From: Michael Heekin [mailto:heekin@mindspring.com]
Sent: Tuesday, May 14, 2002 11:06 AM
To: Stephen MacNamara
Subject: I've been thinking ...
 
Steve,
 
Some time ago, you mentioned that the State Technology Office was having troubles after its director got into legal troubles.  I just saw a piece about the STO on the Internet, and unfortunately, it looks like things still are not on a firm footing.
 
As you know, since I co-founded and later left WebMD, I’ve been living the good life in Atlanta, but the Boy Scout in me still wants to do something to make a difference.  I wonder if I could be helpful at the STO on an interim basis, say for the next six months, to put things in order there and implement Jeb’s vision for how that operation should be run.  I think he’s on the right track in wanting to capture economies of scale, coordinate and rationalize the disparate elements of the state’s IT infrastructure and leverage the Internet to increase citizen access and efficiencies in government operations.  (As we used to say back at WebMD, “I’ve drunk the Kool Aid.”)  But he needs someone there who can make it happen.
 
During my time at WebMD, I planned and managed key strategic relationships with many of  the key players in the technology industry and raised over $1 billion in private strategic investments.  I modestly think my experiences could be very helpful in structuring an office that looks and runs like a private technology company.  
 
If Jeb had someone over there on an interim basis, he could take his time finding the right person for a permanent appointment, in a less politically charged situation.  (By the way, you may recall that I’ve also had experience handling sensitive Tallahassee situations efficiently and with “minimum wake.”)
 
If you think this is not totally crazy, let me know.  I could run down to Tallahassee some time and talk about it with whomever you think would be appropriate.
 
Michael
 
PS:  I'd work for a buck a year, if that's legal.

-----Original Message-----
From: STRAHL, Stuart [mailto:sstrahl@Audubon.org]
Sent: Monday, May 13, 2002 4:37 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Bald Eagle Opportunities



Governor: 

For over 20 years, Audubon's Center for Birds of Prey in Maitland has been a national leader on rehabilitating injured and sick Bald Eagles, and releasing them back into the wild.  In addition, our 200 Eaglewatch volunteers around the State work with agencies and landowners to conserve and protect this important species and its nesting sites.  You may have seen the "Eaglecam" live video we set up each year in conjunction with the Orlando Sentinel...real-time footage from active eagle nest.

This year, we will reach another milestone: Audubon plans to release our 250th eagle back into the wild, and we would very much like you to do the honors releasing the bird.  

Are you interested?  It's quite an experience...and you'd enjoy it! 

As ever, 

Stuart

From:	Branker, Laura <Laura.Branker@MyFlorida.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, May 14, 2002 8:48 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	RE: Medicare/Medicaid policy Re. Custom Wheelchairs

More info from AHCA staff... 

this little boy, Collin, now has his customized wheelchair.  His parents
brought him from Jacksonville to Tallahassee and participated in a telephone
conference call with providers.  After hearing concerns re: recently
implemented Medicaid policies for prior authorization and pricing, Bob's
decision was to suspend current policy and reinstate pre-January policy.
Providers and the family seemed very grateful.

We also asked the Area Offices to compile lists of any pending requests and
move them quickly through the system.

-----Original Message-----
From: Branker, Laura <Laura.Branker@MyFlorida.com>
To: Jeb Bush <jeb@jeb.org>
Sent: Tue May 14 20:38:39 2002
Subject: RE: Medicare/Medicaid policy Re. Custom Wheelchairs

This response will go to the writers -- 
 
Thank you for your e-mail about the Medicaid policy on paying for custom
wheelchairs. I certainly understand your concern.

I am happy to tell you that the policy that went into effect in January
has been suspended, and Medicaid has reinstated its old policies.
Representatives from Medicaid, Children's Medical Services, major
wheelchair providers and affected families participated in a conference
call to discuss the issues. People are now at work throughout the state
to collect all the pending requests for customized wheelchairs and are
working to get them processed.

If you have additional questions, you may want to get in touch with the
Medicaid office in your area.

-----Original Message-----
From: Jeb Bush [mailto:jeb@jeb.org]

-----Original Message-----
From: Pbcfcc9@aol.com [mailto:Pbcfcc9@aol.com]
Sent: Tuesday, April 16, 2002 8:08 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Medicare/Medicaid policy Re. Custom Wheelchairs


Dear Governor Bush,

     I was copied today on a letter sent to you by Charles Ruckstuhl.
Mr. Ruckstuhl speaks to the issue of rules enacted by Medicaid in
January that mirror policies of the Medicare System.  Providers have
been refusing to take orders of highly customized wheelchairs needed for
individuals with severe physical and motor disabilities since the
Supreme Court ordered Medicaid and Medicare to pay for these chairs.
Our family member, Cynthia Norris, has been trying to replace her old
and worn chair for almost three years.  Say the word "Medicare," and you
are turned away at the door.  DME providers can not afford to sell
highly customized chairs for the prices allowed, nor would they
substitute parts that do not meet the consumers unique needs. this is
NOT an issue of greedy providers, but one of providing a service at a
fair price.   Now, Medicaid apparently has instituted similar pricing
guidelines, and effectively is preventing children as well as adults
from getting the customized chairs they need.
     Mr. Ruckstuhl outlines the problems quite clearly in his posts to
you.  I hope you will intervene on behalf of those individuals who are
unable to access the community or enjoy their lives without the
customized wheelchairs they need.  You have continued to be supportive
of persons with disabilities, and they are counting on you once again.
     Thank you in advance for anything you can do.
Priscilla L. Sherman
Family Care Council, District Nine
and Care provider for three severely disabled adults. 


From:	Mattingly, Rebecca <Rebecca.Mattingly@MyFlorida.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, May 14, 2002 8:49 PM
To:	Dana, Pam; Shanahan, Kathleen; Sircy, Crystal; Steve  Mayberry
Cc:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	UPDATE: "CSI Miami"

Crystal Sircy at Enterprise and I are supposed to talk tomorrow.  Basically,
here's what I know so far:

The gap number that Exec. Producer Sam Strangis gave me was $2.5 Million at
a minimum, based largely on the cost of relocating above-the-line creative
staff, writers and producers et al, which are full time employees. I need to
get as firm a number as possible on FTE's because I don't think that CBS has
factored this in.  These above-the-line employees, along with the other full
time below-the-line production personnel who would be hired on an ongoing
basis might make them available for QTI.  Although Kevin Berg, CBS' Sr. VP
of Production, said that cost could be even higher, to perhaps as much as $4
million. I have a stronger belief in Sam's number - he's the day-to-day
budget exec. who has been working in the trenches w/us.

CBS is unwilling to pay that much more for the series - so if we were to try
to make up the difference, it would have to be the whole number. Miami-Dade
has indicated that they could come up with about $1M - but not $2.5M plus.

-----Original Message-----
From: Mattingly, Rebecca [mailto:Rebecca.Mattingly@MyFlorida.com]
Sent: Monday, May 13, 2002 9:06 AM
To: Dana, Pamella; Shanahan, Kathleen
Cc: 'jeb@jeb.org'
Subject: We Might Lose the "CSI Miami" Series
Importance: High


Pam/Kathleen:

CBS has decided to take the new Miami spin-off of the hit TV series, "CSI"
BACK TO LOS ANGELES, due to financial reasons.  During a meeting last week
with CBS, they are leaning heavily on shooting the exteriors and aerial
shots here, but doing the rest on a stage in LA.

I've worked with the local film offices in Miami, Miami Beach, the County,
Beacon Council etc. on finding them eligible incentives, since they will be

Building a new studio in an urban core (eligible for Urban Job Tax Credit
Prog. & local Cmmty Block Dev. Grant)
Hiring full time employees (min. 200 - might be eligible for QTI due to pay
rates)
Motion Picture Sales Tax Exemption

Everything that is available for me to use in terms of economic development
incentives is on the table.  This show will produce a $40 million eco impact
ANNUALLY.  We cannot let this one get away.  If I find out the number that
they need to reach in order to stay in Florida, I would very much like to
explore using some of the Closing Fund.  What do I have to do make this
happen?

I'm in Ft. Myers today and tomorrow dealing with the Denzel feature.  I can
call you.  Will be checking email regularly.

FYI - fall TV schedules will be formally announced on Wednesday.
AARRRGGHHH!!!!

RDM

-----Original Message-----
From: Joe Catrambone <jcat@goodnature.org>
To: Jeb Bush <jeb@jeb.org>
CC: Frank Brogan (E-mail) <frank.brogan@myflorida.com>
Sent: Tue May 14 08:36:05 2002
Subject: Health Care Insurance

Dear Governor,
Congratulations on your efforts to increase spending for education in the
02-03 budget. My condolences to you and the Lt. Governor for the
consternation Senate President McKay & Speaker Feeney caused throughout the
session. Quite frankly, in my opinion it was politics at its WORST! SB-46E,
while not totally supported by the Florida Chamber and local chambers around
the state is a step in the right direction, it will pave the way for even
more needed reform in the 2003 Session. I believe Rep. Farkas and Senator
Jim King will continue their quest for reform. This issue has been plaguing
small business in our state for several years and again in my opinion SB-46E
is the most significant piece of legislation for small business that came
out of the session. There is much more to be done, not only in Florida but
nationally. I believe we can be the leaders in the country to begin much
needed reform in that industry.

I would like to suggest the Governor appoint a Blue Ribbon Panel, to travel
the state, meet with small business owners and others affect by the rising
cost of Health Insurance and Health Care. The panel should be void of any
one in the medical or insurance professions. Of course I would very much
like to be part of that panel if you were to see fit to appoint me. I have
been involved with the Florida Chamber & FACP (Florida Association of
Chamber Professional) for several  years in attempting to affect change in
the industry. The findings of this panel would be helpful in introducing
legislation in the 2003 session.

I look forward to your reply.

Sincerely,

Joe Catrambone, President/CEO
Stuart/Martin County Chamber of Commerce

2:45 EST Monday

Dear Bob,

Today I received a call from Beatrice Pruitt who is the Secretary to Mr.
Ross Fleetwood.

She had a telephone number for me to give to Tay in reference to legal
representation. She stated that one of "their attorneys" had given her the
telphone number for Tay.

She and I spoke about the comment that Mr. Fleetwood had made about this
problem being one that has erupted due to the Legislature deciding not to
address the State of Florida's regulation of Townhome
Properties...again she mentioned "not being within their jurisdiction".

She said that their office had determined this is a legal problem that Tay
should seek legal help or advice for.

I stated to Ms. Pruitt that I am a "FRIEND" of Tay's and that she does not
have long distance service, that Tay recently had surgery and is a single
mom of six children which is why I made the calls to Mr. Fleetwood. I asked
her to please tell him this. She said they know I am a friend.

When Ms. Pruitt and I hung up, immediately I called Tay and we did a three
way call to the telphone number that Mr. Fleetwood's Office had given that
305-232-9680. She had indicated this is the Dade County Legal Services which
it turned out to be.

Because Tay is located in Miami it turned out to be the wrong office.
We were given another telephone number and called another office. That
telephone number is 305-576-080 Ext. O

Ms. Pruitt also said she is receiving "a package" and I think she meant from
Legal Services. She wanted an address where to forward it to. I told her I
do not know Tays specific address, only her telphone number.
I gave her my address and told her I would forward it to Tay when in
receipt.

Then Tay and I called the second number this is the results:

Because it was a three way call the volume of hearing was so reduced that we
had to end the three way call.
Tay then called that number directly herself since it was in Miami. When she
did they took her name and telephone number and told her they would contact
her in three days. And that was the end of it!

Here is another most likely problem with contacting the Dade County Legal
Services Dept. When Tay contacted a Department by the same name some time
previously, she was told that she could not be
represented by them because there is a confict of interest. The Universal
Truth Center (the church that Dade county was supposively planning to donate
a large number of foreclosures after they occur to) has an office of Dade
County within it!!!!!!!!!!!

Legal Services already represents THE UNIVERSAL TRUTH CENTER, according to
Tay...therefore that is where the conflict of interest arises. Tay believes
these are probally the same people.

So here we are on this bright and sunny day in beautiful Florida..Tay is
scheduled to go to court again on June 17...this situation has not been
improved one ounce for Tay nor the people of Timerlake (Miramar
Gardens)...time is being eaten away and no resolution...

Is it possible to email the Governor again and ask for him to appoint a
State Attorney to investigate this matter? Or to ask him for advice? Surely
he has someone that "WILL" do the job.

From:	McFadden, Liza <Liza.Mcfadden@MyFlorida.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, May 15, 2002 12:02 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Cc:	Z. Kramer Lesa (E-mail)
Subject:	Gov Family Literacy recommended award winners
Attachments:	Gov recommend list 1.xls; 3rd level no with money.xls; reviewers 2003.doc; McFadden, Liza.vcf

 <<Gov recommend list 1.xls>> Governor, our Family Literacy review team has
met and recommended the following programs be funded for our second year of
statewide funding.   There were initially about 100 applicants which our
office and the Florida Literacy Coalition reviewed and screened.  Of these
approximately 30 were forwarded to the review team which selected the 15
attached for funding.  They represent a good geographical mix from around
the state and include community-based organizations, schools, a library and
a university partnership.

You may note that these projects total about $715,000.  Although this is
about $235,000 less than was funded last year, the team as a whole felt that
it was more important to fund quality programs that they felt had a good
chance for a strong start-up and continuation after one year of funding.
They took the research results from this year's first statewide start-up
very seriously (what works) and felt that it was better to fund programs
that would serve as models for DOE and other education funders than to fund
programs that would only last one year and have no long term results for the
families in these areas of great need.

Below please find the remainder of the top 30 or so that were not
recommended for funding, but with their scores and comments on why the
decision to not fund was made.   A list of the reviewers (not including me
or Lesa Kramer from FLC, but we did read all 100!) is attached.

Please let me know if you are in agreement with recommendations or have
recommended considerations of any kind.  When decisions are final, we will
invite the grantees to a June 18th event at the mansion to announce the
winners.  We will also use this event to update the state on the status of
the other parent pieces announced in Naples (I am a Reader kit).

LIZA

 <<3rd level no with money.xls>> 
 <<reviewers 2003.doc>> 

Liza McFadden
Executive Director, Gov's Mentoring/Family Literacy Initiative
Executive Office of the Governor
909 The Capitol
Tallahassee, Fl 32399
850-410-0696
www.flamentoring.org

(Embedded image moved to file: pic11422.jpg)EMBARGOED FOR RELEASE UNTIL
                                                     WEDNESDAY, MAY 8,

Page








                              It's Official:
           Minnesota Once Again is America's Most Livable State
                 Mississippi Repeats its Last Place Finish
|------------------------------------------------------------|
|          Read the Press Release Below or Click on          |
|                                                            |
|                                                            |
|             These Links for More Information:              |
|                                                            |
|                                                            |
| (Embedded image moved to file: pic11247.jpg)Click Here for |
|         the Complete 2002 State Awards Publication         |
|                                                            |
|                                                            |
|               | 2002 Rankings | 43 Factors |               |
|                                                            |
|                                                            |
|  Methodology | Most Livable State Rankings 1991 to 2002 |  |
|                                                            |
|                                                            |
|             About Morgan Quitno | MQ Home Page             |
|------------------------------------------------------------|







LAWRENCE, KS. Minnesota has done it again. For a record sixth year in a
row, the North Star State is the nation's Most Livable State. Morgan
Quitno
Press, a Lawrence, Kansas-based publishing and research company today
announced the findings of its 12th annual award. Also making a repeat
appearance in the award spotlight ? but at the opposite end of the scale
?
is Mississippi, which ranks #50 for the fourth consecutive year.


"Our award is nothing if not consistent," said Scott Morgan, President
of
Morgan Quitno Press. "But Minnesota seems to have what it takes to keep
the
other 49 states at bay. The state performs consistently well in many
areas.
Minnesota has a low teen birth rate, a high homeownership rate, a very
good
high school graduation rate and high spending for the arts. The only
category that Minnesota ranks poorly in is average daily mean
temperature."


For the last twelve years, Morgan Quitno Press has issued its Livable
State
Award. Based on 43 factors selected from updated editions of its annual
reference book, State Rankings, the Most Livable State Award recognizes
a
state for its high quality of life. The 2002 edition of State Rankings,
which compares states in more than 550 categories, was published in
April.


"We issue the award every year because it tells an interesting story
about
life and government in the 50 United States," said Morgan. Our award is
not
a measurement of which state is most fun or the best place for everyone
to
live. It is based on statistical indicators that reflect the kind of
lifestyle that most Americans agree is positive ? affordable housing,
safe
streets, good employment opportunities, a strong education system and a
healthy state economy."


Rounding out the top five spots with Minnesota are (in descending order)
Iowa, New Hampshire, Virginia and Massachusetts. Bringing up the
opposite
end of the scale with Mississippi are Louisiana in 49th, Alabama in
48th,
Arkansas in 47th and New Mexico in 46th place.


The Most Livable State Award is one of four designations announced
annually
by Morgan Quitno Press in conjunction with the publication of its annual
reference books. These other annual announcements name the nation's
Safest
City and Metro Area, the Healthiest State and the Most Dangerous State.


Additional information about 2002's Most Livable State Award is
available
through the Morgan Quitno website at www.statestats.com. For further
inquiries, please contact Morgan Quitno Press at (785) 841-3534.


                                   #####





(Back to Top)


Morgan Quitno Press Home Page

Thanks,
Joe I Rasco

From:	Hansen, Michael <Michael.Hansen@LASPBS.STATE.FL.US>
Sent:	Wednesday, May 15, 2002 9:07 AM
To:	'sidbarret@hotmail.com'
Cc:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Medicaid Wheelchairs

Dear Mr. Coffay: 

Thank you for your e-mail to Governor Bush about Medicaid policy on paying for wheelchairs.  The Governor has asked that I respond on his behalf. I certainly understand your concern.

I am happy to tell you that the policy that went into effect in January has been suspended, and Medicaid has reinstated its old policies.  Representatives from Medicaid, Children's Medical Services, major wheelchair providers and affected families participated in a conference call to discuss the issues. People are now at work throughout the state to collect all the pending requests for customized wheelchairs and are working to get them processed.

If you have additional questions, you may want to get in touch with the Medicaid office in your area. 

Mike Hansen 
Health and Human Services Policy Coordinator 
Governor's Office of Policy and Budget 
850-488-7734

have
the first lunch (some time this year) serve as a luncheon/kick-off

attract 200-500 persons at each luncheon.

before December). The message would allow you to highlight your
commitment
to education as a UNCF partner.

Mr. Tyson was excited about UNCF becoming a partner with the Governor's
Black History Month Celebration and would like to announce (at the
inaugural
luncheon) the partnership and a 4 year-scholarship commitment.

UNCF understands you have a demanding schedule and they are willing to
work
around your schedule to accommodate dates/locations.

becoming
the state's honorary chairman. 

Leslie and I would work closely with UNCF to maximize your time. Please
let
us know how to proceed.

MEDICAID/MEDICARE/Rx

Judge Dismisses Medicaid Lawsuit
Source: Associated Press 

By KELLY WIESE Associated Press Writer LITTLE ROCK, Ark. (AP) _ A federal
judge has dismissed a lawsuit filed by hospital associations trying to stop
the government from killing a Medicaid provision that allowed some states to
draw extra federal funds through an accounting gimmick. 
http://cnniw.yellowbrix.com/pages/cnniw/Story.nsp?story_id=29885031&ID=cnniw
&scategory=Healthcare%3AMedicaid%2FMedicare&

AHA, NAPH decry judge's UPL ruling; response brewing in Congress 
The heads of AHA and the National Association of Public Hospitals and Health
Systems today expressed disappointment and dismay at a federal judge's
decision against blocking a Department of Health and Human Services
regulation eliminating the Medicaid 150% upper payment limit for public
hospitals. Meanwhile, Sen. Paul Wellstone, D-MN, and Rep. Eliot Engel, D-NY,
were poised late today to introduce a "resolution of disapproval" about the
rule in their respective houses. Passage of the resolution -- which requires
both houses' approval and the president's signature -- would block the rule
from taking effect. The effort on Capitol Hill follows a ruling late Monday
by U.S. District Judge Thomas Eisele of the U.S. District Court for the
Eastern District of Arkansas. Eisele granted HHS' motion for summary
judgment in a suit filed by AHA, NAPH and several other national and state
hospital associations and individual hospitals challenging the rule. AHA
calculates that an earlier delay in the rule brought about by the suit saved
affected hospitals almost $300 million in cuts.
Texas Struggles to Raise Revenue for Medicaid; Fares Better than Many States
Source: Knight Ridder/Tribune Business News 

May 14--WASHINGTON-State governments are getting squeezed. 
Costs for Medicaid, the health program for the poor, are soaring. And the
bills for doctors, hospitals and prescription drugs are hitting state
coffers at a time when tax revenues have plummeted because of the slow
economy. 
http://cnniw.yellowbrix.com/pages/cnniw/Story.nsp?story_id=29878915&ID=cnniw
&scategory=Healthcare&

House prescription drug bill under fire for proposed provider cutbacks 
By JANELLE CARTER, Associated Press Writer 
WASHINGTON - Legislation that would give Medicare clients a prescription
drug benefit is under fire from hospitals and other health-care providers
angry about payment changes included in the measure.
The outcry has several Republican lawmakers to worrying about the bill and
has sparked an internal debate among House Republican leaders, who don't
want to force members to make a politically difficult vote in an election
year.
http://story.news.yahoo.com/news?tmpl=story&u=/ap/20020514/ap_to_po/congress

Ms. Aponte:
 
Sister Margaret Johnson has suggested that I contact you for a recommendation to Govenor Jeb Bush for me to become a member of the Board of Commissioners of the South Broward Hospital District.  The position requires its members to be active in community service and familiar with health care in South Florida.  For a number of years I have been active in our community serving as a volunteer and board member for various organizations as you can see on the attached CV and biography.  I have spent much time at the Schott Center, as a nurse with the group home staff, in the gardens, and in chapel events with Sr. Margaret.  I have taken sign language classes and am beginning to be able to communicate with the staff and members at Schott.  I am also a nurse, nurse educator, and nurse administrator.  In these days of nursing shortages and our troubled health care system it is important that a nurse be represented on health care boards.  You may even have encountered difficulties with the health care system with your family.  In this position I could represent the needs of the deaf, and physically, emotionally, and developmentally disabled.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 
Bush torn over Everglades bill 

Should he sign or veto the crucial funding measure - which also restricts 
challenges to development projects on environmental grounds? 

By JULIE HAUSERMAN, Times Staff Writer 
© St. Petersburg Times 
published May 15, 2002 

http://www.sptimes.com/2002/05/15/State/Bush_torn_over_Evergl.shtml 


TALLAHASSEE -- On the one hand, Gov. Jeb Bush wants to sign a bill this week 
that would pay for a billion-dollar public works project in the Everglades. 

On the other, he's hearing from thousands of environmentalists, including a 
new Florida group called Republicans for Environmental Protection, who want 
him to veto it. They say it is tainted by an amendment that favors 
developers and limits an ordinary citizen's right to challenge damaging 
projects all over the state. 

Bush has until Thursday to decide whether to veto the bill or sign it into 
law. 

"But for this, I could tell you automatically that I would sign the bill 
into law," Bush said last week. 

With e-mails pouring into his office urging a veto, Bush asked his staff for 
a list of development permits challenged under current law. 

"There's a lot of varying opinions on what this impact is," Bush said. 

Environmentalists aren't the only ones opposing the change in so-called 
citizen standing. Attorney General Bob Butterworth opposes the bill, and so 
do six of the seven candidates running for attorney general. Only Republican 
candidate Tom Warner supports the bill because he says the Everglades 
portion is too important. 

At issue is the 1971 Environmental Protection Act. Lawmakers gave ordinary 
citizens the right to challenge developers and state agencies. The theory is 
that all citizens can file a challenge, even if the project is miles away, 
because everyone has a stake in protecting Florida's environment. 

The measure sitting on Bush's desk would change that. A provision added by 
incoming Senate President Jim King, R-Jacksonville, would allow only people 
who can prove they are personally affected by a project to file a challenge. 
So, for example, a concerned citizen in Tampa who wants to stop a project in 
the Everglades wouldn't have the legal standing to challenge it. 

"It generally just improves the business climate by eliminating an 
artificial means of harassment and delay," said Frank Matthews, a 
development attorney and Tallahassee lobbyist who supports the change. "It 
addresses the gadfly, the individual who has no interest in a permit, from 
being able to sue anybody in the state to be an obstructionist." 

Environmentalists say frivolous suits are a myth. They say it takes money 
and nerve to challenge development, especially in small counties where one 
industry dominates. 

"We know that people who challenge developments take a big risk," said John 
Whitescarver of Hobe Sound, president of the Florida chapter of Republicans 
for the Environment. 

The bill also affects environmental and homeowner groups all over Florida. 
It says in order to file a challenge, a group must have at least 25 members 
in the affected area, and it has to have been a Florida corporation for a 
year. 

That worries people like Bobby C. Billie, an American Indian who is not part 
of the government-recognized Seminole Tribe of Florida. Billie, who lives in 
South Florida, is spiritual leader of an offshoot group, the Independent 
Seminole Nation, which eschews life on organized Indian reservations. 

Billie has made it his life's work to protect Indian burial grounds all over 
the state. 

Under the bill, Billie says he would have no legal standing to challenge 
development outside his home county. And he certainly doesn't have 25 
members in every county to file a challenge as an organized group. 

Three years ago, Billie objected to a development near ancient burial 
grounds along Marshall Creek in Jacksonville. The developer was a 
constituent of King's. King says someone in South Florida shouldn't be able 
to challenge a development in Jacksonville. So King tacked the 
legal-standing language onto the Everglades bill. 

Under the bill, ordinary homeowners associations also could face a tough 
legal fight. To challenge a project, a group must be incorporated 
specifically to protect "the environment, fish and wildlife resources, and 
the protection of air and water quality." Homeowner groups don't qualify. 
And most groups come together to fight a specific project, so they likely 
would not meet the requirement that the group be in place a year ahead of 
time. 

"Most of the big environmental cases in Florida could not have been brought" 
under the bill's new definitions of legal standing, said David Guest, an 
attorney for Earthjustice, a nonprofit environmental law firm. 

One case he cites: In the late 1990s, a new group organized as the 
Environmental Confederation of Southwest Florida to oppose a phosphate mine 
in De Soto County because it would harm the region's groundwater. The group 
wouldn't have had standing under the bill because it didn't have 25 members 
and wasn't incorporated when it filed the legal challenge. 

"We won the case," Guest said. "We caught them red-handed on their 
misstatements of what the impacts were. The environmental impacts were much 
worse. The dramatic impacts from that mine would be taking place right now."
