-----Original Message-----
From: govnews-owner@elist.myflorida.com [mailto:govnews-owner@elist.myflorida.com]On Behalf Of Governor Jeb Bush
Sent: Saturday, May 11, 2002 2:36 PM
To: jeb.bush@myflorida.com
Subject: IN THE NEWS....Friday, May 10, 2002


For those E-Newsletter recipients who have Adobe Acrobat reader, Governor Bush's e-newsletter is available in .PDF format by clicking here www.myflorida.com/myflorida/governorsoffice/pdfs/govnews0 <http://www.myflorida.com/myflorida/governorsoffice/pdfs/govnews051002.pdf> 51002.pdf .

The text version of the e-newsletter is below for those who do not have Adobe Acrobat reader.


Message from the Governor

This week I continued to focus on the Rilya Wilson case:  finding out what happened and taking measures to ensure it does not happen again.  The children under the supervision of the state often come to us with harrowing life experiences - truly these children are among the most vulnerable in our society - and we must show compassion as we care for them.

But while government cannot make up for all of society's ills, or completely make up for a lack of parental love and support, we can and must do the best job we can.  I remain proud of our record on child welfare, which has included a doubling of funding for child welfare services over the past four years, more child abuse investigations, and innovative programs such as community-based care to address endemic social problems in new ways.

 

Nevertheless, the Rilya Wilson case tragically illustrates that we still have a long way to go.  That's why this week I appointed a Blue Ribbon Panel on Child Protection to determine what went wrong and what we can do to prevent any more such cases.  Their report is due to me on an accelerated schedule so we can take needed action quickly.  I have also ordered all district administrators from the Department of Children and Families to confirm that every child in state custody is safe and where they are supposed to be.

 

I also applaud two measures the Legislature has taken this week to improve the system.  First, those who falsify child welfare records will now face stiff criminal penalties.  Second, the House and the Senate have come to agreement on the state's guardian ad-litem program, providing a $7.5 million increase in funding this year.  Caring, committed volunteers make up this program, which serves as a safeguard for children who have been placed in the state's care and are awaiting placement in a permanent home.  

 

Also this week I attended the Fallen Officers Memorial Service in Tallahassee to honor those Florida law enforcement officers who gave their lives in the line of duty.  I hosted an Educators' Summit in Tampa that focused on our "Just Read, Florida!" initiative.  I also highlighted the early success of our "Florida:  A Healthy State" program at Jackson Memorial Hospital in Miami, congratulated Homestead Senior High on being one of three schools nationwide given an Inspiration Award from the College Board, and thanked the Council of 100 in Naples for their continued leadership in fostering economic opportunity across our state.

 

Please continue to pray for the return of Rilya Wilson to safety, and for all children in our state whose unfortunate home environments necessitate government intervention and supervision.

 

Sincerely, Jeb Bush

 

 

JUST READ, FLORIDA!

 

Governor Jeb Bush spoke to teachers Monday about the Just Read, Florida! initiative at the Second Annual Governor's Educators' Leadership Summit.  The Just Read, Florida! initiative is an effort to create a comprehensive and coordinated reading strategy aimed at helping every student become a successful and independent reader.  The two-day summit brought together K-20 educators recognized for their outstanding contributions in reading to Florida's students, schools and communities.  The summit featured sessions conducted by some of Florida's own reading experts: Dr. Joe Torgesen, Director, Florida Center for Reading Research, Florida State University; Dr. Maria Elena Arguellas, School of Education Research, University of Miami; Dr. Holly Lane, Department of Special Education, University of Florida; and Dr. Mary Little, Project CENTRAL, University of Central Florida.  Topics ranged from the latest research on reading, the use of data to inform instruction, and success stories from Florida elementary, middle and high schools.  Also at the Education Summit, Citigroup announced a gift of $125,000 as the founding partner of the Consortium of Education's Teachers are Heroes program.  Teachers are Heroes will provide mini-grants to teachers to work with mentor teachers on a broad array of curriculum projects.  

 

For more information on the Just Read, Florida! initiative visit the Just Read, Florida! website at 

 <http://www.myflorida.com/> www.myflorida.com.

 


 


ON THE ROAD WITH FLORIDA'S FIRST LADY


 

First Lady Columba Bush and Florida's Office of Drug Control Director Jim McDonough hosted the launch of a new education teen television show "Choices" at Palm Beach Garden High School Thursday.  The "Choices" program will follow the lives of a teen-age cast as they struggle through the turbulence and frustration of the teen-age years.  The interactive series is being distributed to middle and senior high schools throughout Florida.  The First Lady and Director McDonough were joined by the cast of "Choices," parents, students, faculty and staff of Palm Beach Garden High, Charles Stiles, partnership chairman and Nat Harrington of the Palm Beach County School District.  On Friday, First Lady and  Director Jim McDonough visited the Key West Housing Authority's, Campus South, Drug Free Kids and Safeport drug prevention programs in Key West.  The Key West Housing Authority was first established in 1938.  In addition to managing public housing units and Section 8 housing, the Key West Housing Authority has developed and currently manages special programs that benefit the housing residents.  Campus South, Drug Free Kids and Safeport represent just three prevention, education and treatment program initiatives located in public housing communities.  Protecting youth from substance abuse is one of the four major goals identified in Governor Jeb Bush's Drug Control strategy.  The early indications are that the administration's efforts at prevention are working.  Since becoming Florida's First Lady, Mrs. Bush has traveled with Director McDonough throughout the state speaking with youth about the dangers of substance abuse.  Two of her top priorities are to reduce substance abuse among Florida's youth and to get them involved in the arts.  In collaboration with Arts for a Complete Education / Florida Alliance for Arts Education (ACE/FAAE), the First Lady visits at least two school art programs a month.  She also awards 24 art scholarships for $1,000 each to students in visual arts, music, dance and theatre a year.  For more information on the First Lady, please visit www.myflorida.com <http://www.myflorida.com/> .

GOVERNOR'S POINTS OF LIGHT AWARD


 

Over the last 11 years Albert and Barbara Davis have prepared and shipped approximately 17,000 loaves of banana bread to service members in the Middle East.  "We heard that due to the heat, bananas were not readily available to service members," said Mrs. Davis.  "We thought that this bread, containing as many bananas and nuts as possible and very few preservatives, would be a good substitute to provide potassium and vitamins to our troops."  Mr. and Mrs. Davis use their own funds to purchase the ingredients and bake each loaf in their home, at the rate of seven loaves per hour.  Albert Davis served over 26 years in the Navy and fought in three wars.  "I feel this is a small payback for the many times my life was saved in combat," said Mr. Davis.  "I want the troops to feel that someone back home cares and is thinking about them."  "All aspects are considered in preparing the banana bread," said friend Tonya Mendoza.  "From the selection of ingredients to storage and delivery, Mr. and Mrs. Davis provide service members who are away from home with a welcome addition to their standard military meals."  Albert and Barbara Davis are this week's Points of Light Award winners.  Congratulations! 


 


Want to nominate an outstanding volunteer in your community?  Simply visit  <http://www.myflorida.com/> www.myflorida.com to download a nomination form. 


 


From:	Ldgaeg@aol.com

Subject:	Re: Rilya

Dear Gov Jeb: 

Yes, I understand DCF can't fire someone who has already resigned, but, and I realize it would be a judgment call, I tend to lean to firing someone for a record of poor job performance rather than allowing that someone the option to resign.  Nevertheless, I'm not privy to this situation, and perhaps the "eye on the ball" decision was to get someone out of a job as quickly and inexpensively as possible.   

Anyway, one other thought I have to break the cycle of these poor children continually being churned through the welfare system by these derelict, self-absorbed, non-caring parents is similar to the "3-strike" law.  After birthing 2 children who become wards of the State, at the time of the 3rd child born by one of these "mothers", her tubes should be tied right there on the spot so that no more future children will see such suffering.  I'd like the fornicating "father" to have a vasectomy.  But, realistically I have not figured a way in  to know who the "father" is or how to find him if he did not voluntarily identify himself, which he probably would not do.  It may seem extreme to some, but something needs to happen to break these vicious downward cycles of generational welfare children.  And I really do think the neglect and abuse the children endure is criminal and when at least 2 children have been dumped into welfare, the "parents" don't deserve any more chances after the 3rd baby.  Anyway..... 

Regards, Lorraine Grigsby

Governor,
 
After your call this morning Melissa and I spoke with Crystal Williams, of the INS Office of Policy and Planning.  This is the office responsible for the regulation.  We have worked with her in the past on this particular issue.
 
Crystal reported that the INS received over 7,000 letters and comments on the regulations.  Many letters were products of letter writing campaigns but there are several hundred “serious” letters and comments.  She does not see “fast action” on the publication of the final regulations.  It will take INS some time to get through the comments.
 
The State Department also wrote comments for the INS----we have called for a copy.
 
We are checking with the Congressional Committees to see what they might have in mind and are following up with our prior Hill contacts and other state offices. From: Michele Williams <mailto:fape4kids@netzero.net>

Sent: Tuesday, May 14, 2002 11:17 AM
Subject: Getting Rid of FCAT Accommodations List


Folks,
 
Today a client of mine is meeting with Gov. Bush.  Not a parent.  The student.  She is a gifted LD student who has anxiety disorder and panic attacks, she is obsessive-compulsive, and although she is an A-B student and has been in magnet schools since 3rd grade, she can't pass the FCAT because she can't have the accommodations she needs to pass--and under current rules she won't receive a diploma.  She is a student capable of going through college and beyond, capable of becoming anything she wants to be.
 
I've been helping her family for nearly a year now trying to find ways to do what is appropriate in this case, and when we finally found an alternative, it is so obscure that nobody really knows how it should be done.  So I asked the student to write to Gov. Bush, knowing she could, knowing that sometimes students can make a case their parents can't.  We thought it would be just an exchange of letters between the student and, ultimately, an aide appointed to handle the case.  No, it didn't work that way.  Bush is in a town meeting at her school today and wil spend 20 minutes with her himself!  This is a beautiful, articulate and eloquent student who will leave him simply astonished that she will not be able to get a diploma in Florida.
 
If things go well, this student is going to ask Bush if he can't use his executive powers to request a "stay of execution" and an emergency creation of an alternative until the bill that will free us to use all IEP and 504 accommodations on standardized testing is passed.  
 
Please use all your influence with God to ask that Bush and this student can become the focal point for a change Florida's disabled students need very much.  Virtual flowers, hugs, kisses to both feet, etc., in advance for your help!
 
Michele Williams
Education Consultant/Advocate

From:	Yablonski, Brian <Brian.Yablonski@MyFlorida.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, May 15, 2002 7:13 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	RE: Construction Industry - Economic Impact fup

Governor, Ms. Smith's issue is still unresolved, primarily b/c the state
funding that was to be matched with the federal dollars to begin the
construction was eliminated from the budget during the budget reductions
last fall.  In this most recent session, the Legislature did not restore
this reduction.  So even though this is a good match ratio with the feds,
the funding was still not allocated by the state to allow construction to
proceed.

Brian

thank you Rebecca. I will look into both items. 

Jeb Bush

Please note: Florida has a very broad public records law.
Most written communications to or from state officials
regarding state business are public records available to the
public and media upon request.   Your e-mail communications
may therefore be subject to public disclosure. 



-----Original Message-----
From: Rebecca Smith [mailto:rebecca@admorgan.com]
Sent: Friday, May 03, 2002 1:52 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Construction Industry - Economic Impact


Dear Governor:

I was attending the "heroes luncheon" this afternoon in Tampa when you
addressed the room.  It was a moving tribute to all of the men and women
who
serve our Country.  You would have been very proud of our State as Gen.
Franks represented our local community and our Country with such
eloquence.
Your comments were heard by 5,000 who attended today's event.

I was also reminded to follow up with you on the issues we have
discussed
previously.

I have had the opportunity to speak with you in person about the issue
related to the construction industry.  Specifically, our company, The
A.D.
Morgan Corporation, with offices in Tampa and Melbourne have had two of
our
Construction Contracts for Dept of Juvenile Justice put on indefinite
hold
($15 million).  As you will recall, these are 90% Federally funded with
the
money available to spend now.  The Juvenile Justice project in
Seffner($7.3
million)  has been ready  to break ground since December of 2001.  The
project was stopped two weeks prior to our notice to proceed.

This has been quite a challenge for our company and to date, we have not
been successful in  replacing that revenue for the year 2002.
Additionally,
we are currently contracted for work at the Lowell Correctional
Institution,
(Ocala)  with a need for budget approval for our contract to be
continued.
My understanding is that the budget request from DOC does not have much
support at this time.

While my first concern is my company, I want to take the opportunity to
once
again make certain that you are aware that your directive to "boost the
economy through construction is NOT what is being funded".  Small
business
comprises the heartbeat of our state.  As a small business employer of
50
people, responsible for their families, I must tell you that without
construction project funding for state projects, we will take a huge
loss as
well as loose employees.  Our annual revenue is appx $50 million, we are
in
our 14th year of business, this is our worst year yet.

With all that you are responsible for, please check to make certain that
construction funding is getting the attention you intended.  We need
your
help.  Please let me know who I should speak with regarding funding for
the
contracts we currently hold.

Sincerely and
with my full support,

Rebecca Smith, President
The A.D. Morgan Corporation

PS  I was having dinner with Congressman Sonny Montgomery on my recent
trip
to Washington.  He asked about you and sends his best.  He also,
encouraged
me to make certain to follow up and let you know what was happening with
our
contracts.

Thanks again for your attention.  See you in Tampa on your next visit if
not
the Republican Victory Committee Dinner.

Dear Dean,
Thank you for your comments and your support.  This is such a difficult
time for all of us who work in the social services.  It is my fervent hope
that this tragic event will help all of us to learn how to better do our
jobs, and to let the public know of the challenges we face.  Hopefully, it
will bring about the positive result of infusing a sense of passion and
commitment in all Floridians that reaches the level of Governor Bush's --
we can and must do better.  Your kind words mean a lot to me and my family.
Judge Kearney

http://eww.dcf.state.fl.us/

             A Message from Secretary Kearney to DCF Employees

 As most of you know if you have been watching the news, our Department is
 receiving an enormous amount of scrutiny from the public, the legislature
 and the media over Rilya Wilson, a 5-year-old girl from Miami, who was in
 our care and has disappeared.

 I know you share my grave concern for Rilya and my fervent hope that we
 will find her alive and well.  Right now, we are in Miami making sure we
 are doing everything possible to help law enforcement officials find Rilya
 and to support all of you in making sure that every child in the care of
 the Department is safe.

 Unfortunately, in the news, we hear nothing about the hundreds of
 thousands of the lives saved and those made better by your work.  Last
 year, you took 390,365 calls to our abuse hotline; you investigated
 176,625 child abuse or neglect cases; you protected more than 44,000
 children from further abuse or neglect; and you found permanent loving
 homes for 2,008 of our foster children.

 I deeply regret that the unscrupulous actions of a few employees have cast
 a shadow on the entire agency and that this situation has made it even
 more difficult for each of you to get your job done.  I know how concerned
 you are every day with the safety and well being of all of the children we
 protect and families we serve.

 There are many other people who also understand your work and dedication.
 Governor Bush has given us his full support and has proved over and over
 that he understands the enormous demands of our work on behalf of
 Florida's most vulnerable citizens.

 In closing, I want to share with you a few excerpts from a lengthy letter
 of support we recently received:

      After reading Sunday's "Sun-Sentinel" front-page story criticizing
      DCF, I felt that I had to write you, not to join the criticism, but
      to give you and the Florida DCF staff some support.  I know what your
      jobs and careers are like.  I gave thirty-one years of my life to the
      system in Ohio.  When I retired in 1998 I was the Assistant Director
      of the Hamilton County (Cincinnati) Department of human Services and
      had responsibility for the Children's services, Child Support and
      income Maintenance Divisions of the Department.

      I know what a heart breaking experience it is to have a child death
      occur while that child is in the care of the child welfare system.  I
      know how social workers feel when they read in the newspapers how
      incompetent they are because one of their peers had a child in
      his/her caseload die.  I know how angry they feel when they believe
      that a peer was negligent on the job and could have contributed to
      the harm or death of a child.  I know how angry they feel when they
      believe that a peer was negligent on the job and did everything he or
      she could have to help a family, but still a child died.

      For some reason, everyone not employed in the field of child welfare,
      is an expert in the field.  Those of us who choose to work in the
      field of child welfare seem to be the least expert in the field, at
      least according to the media and the general public.  Those of us who
      have worked in the field know how badly it hurts to receive such
      criticism at the time of a tragedy such as a child death.  We rarely
      know how it feels to receive sympathy or empathy when such a tragedy
      occurs.  Even more rare is to know how it feels to receive praise for
      the good work we have done.

      Please accept my support and gratitude for the good work you and your
      staff across the state of Florida do to help children and families.
      Please tell your exceptional, caring social workers, supervisors,
      managers and administrators that a great job they do day in and day
      out and how much they matter to the children and families they serve.
      Please let them know that there are people who know what they do
      everyday and that we appreciate what they do and what they feel each
      and every day of the week for the children and families with whom
      they work.  Please tell your competent staff members that they are
      valued and that they need to be strong to overcome the negative media
      attention.  The children and families they each serve need them in
      their lives.  Things will not get better for the children if the
      good, caring workers are no longer employed by DCF.

      (Letter from Linda Simonds, Delray Beach, Fla.)

I am tremendously proud of you and the difficult work you perform so
competently on a routine basis.  In this time of crisis, let us affirm and
uphold each other in continuing to serve the most vulnerable Floridians to
the very best of our abilities.


Sarah B Robinson
Department of Children & Families
Communications Office
1317 Winewood Blvd, Bldg. 1, Suite 206
Tallahassee, FL 32399-0700
(Ph: 850-488-4550; Suncom: 278-4550; Fx: 487-0800)

-----Original Message-----
From: Chris Card <ccard@HillsboroughKids.org>
To: Jeb Bush <jeb@jeb.org>
CC: charla.sasser@myflorida.com <charla.sasser@myflorida.com>; Slater Bayliss <slater@jeb.org>; elizabeth.hurst@myflorida.com <elizabeth.hurst@myflorida.com>; Kimberly.dale@myflorida.com <Kimberly.dale@myflorida.com>
Sent: Wed May 15 19:47:17 2002
Subject: List For Tomorrow's visit

Governor,
 
We are all very excited and pleased that you are coming to see us.  I do want you to know that we have had a pilot group of 4 teams (2 care managers and one care team coordinator) working since January and have just transferred the first third (1,500 children) of the caseload from DCF to HKI on May 6th.  You will be coming to a temporary office location that we are using while the permanent location is getting renovated.
 
Once you arrive we will have a number of our community partners and leaders there to greet you.  Then we will go into our conference room with the core of our frontline staff that are listed below.  A number of these folks are transfers from DCF to us and will be able to tell you the difference, although we are still really new.
 
Our staff and DCF locally have been working very hard on this transition, it is very difficult but we are very energized and enthusiastic.  We will finish transitioning the rest of the caseload in a couple of more steps by November.
 
Carl and I will ride with you from the High School to our center.
 
See you tomorrow!!
 
Chris 
 
Here is the list of people in the room.
 
Bea Moran, Care Team Coordinator, Children’s Home Society of Florida
John Abidir, Care Manager, Children’s Home Society of Florida
Ann Zimmerman, Care Manage, Children’s Home Society of Florida
 
Justine Massey, Care Team Coordinator, Northside Mental Health Center

Please note: Florida has a very broad public records law.

-----Original Message-----

-----Original Message-----
From: Padron, Eduardo [mailto:epadron@mdcc.edu]
Sent: Thursday, May 09, 2002 2:57 PM
To: 'ccastillo@codina.com'
Subject: Email to Armando Codina -- President Bush's Visit to Miami - For your consideration!
Importance: High



Dear Armando: 

As you may be aware, President Bush will be visiting Miami on May 20th  to commemorate Cuba's Independence with the tens of thousands of proud Cuban-Americans here in our community; this is a wonderful gesture on the President's part. I'd like to enlist your support and capacity for influencing those in the White House in a suggestion that I feel our President and the Miami community would greatly appreciate and embrace.  You'll no doubt agree that visits to Miami by high officials are known to include a taste of cafecito and the "Viva Cuba Libre" theme - very typical, predictable and often jeered at by the media in that regard.  

Therefore, I'd like you to help me suggest  to the White House that the President use part of his valuable time that day emphasizing the accomplishments of Cuban-Americans and what they've been able to achieve under a system of freedom and democracy.  The President could visit Miami -Dade Community  College  in the heart of Little Havana,  where thousands of Cuban-Americans through hard work and sacrifice are commendably getting the necessary training to be able to join the ranks of working Americans.  This is also the place from which thousands of leading Cuban-American professionals have emerged. The President would be able to witness and speak first hand about the way in which Cubans and other immigrants have equipped themselves, through education and tranining, and are contributing in a worthwhile way to the welfare of our nation.  I truly feel that the President would welcome the opportunity to experience this wonderful example of how "America - the Free"  has given Cuban-Americans the opportunity to be able to do their part toward  becoming productive, contributing Americans.  


Armando, let me know what you think! M-DCC is the higher education institution that enrolls the highest numbers of Hispanics (of any U.S. College or university) and awards the highest number of Associate's degrees.  We are ready to roll out the Red Carpet for our President, and I know you're in a position to talk to the right people to help make this happen!!!

	I look forward to hearing from you.  Thank you. 
  
Sincerely, 
  
Eduardo

-----Original Message-----
From: Anne & Chuck Edwards [mailto:aedward1@cfl.rr.com]
Sent: Tuesday, May 14, 2002 9:59 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: thank you


 
Dear Governor Bush,
Thank you for taking time to meet with Kirsty today.  What a wonderful experience it was for her to be able to share her concerns for her future with you.  
  
You asked a very logical question regarding how many memory aids she might need for a test like the FCAT. After some thought, our answer would have to be that disabled students should have the right to use any and all accommodations during the FCAT that are written on their IEP's or 504 plans.  Unfortunately, Kirsty's disorder is not logical and it is difficult to answer such a question in logical terms because it follows no pattern...there is no rhyme or reason to her anxiety/panic attacks.  She can't predict when an anxiety/panic attack might occur therefore, she must always be prepared.   She makes her own memory aids for every test; that is how she studies. Access to recall during an anxiety/ panic attack is a memory issue which is the reason why we pursued the memory aid as an accommodation because it is appropriate to her individualized needs.  The color coded memory aids were her own concoction to help her  build bridges over her individual disabilities.  Each color serves to access a memory file and relieve anxiety/panic when needed. When she doesn't need them, she doesn't use them.
 
There were years when Kirsty couldn't complete ANY tests due to her disability.  She'd turn in blank tests and then have to suffer the ridicule that followed. Her self -esteem was as low as her grades. Conference after conference, we were told Kirsty isn't studying enough to pass the tests. Year after year, she worked in class and made A's, only to end up with a C's or lower because she failed the tests or the finals.  
 
We are enormously proud of Kirsty and her sheer determination and all she has been able to accomplish; from the little girl whom we were told was borderline retarded to the well spoken young lady she is today.  Many people have tried to encourage Kirsty to give up and quit school, get her GED and get on with her life. She believes she has proven through her grades that she has earned the standard diploma, her VPA seal, and the right to walk with her peers in a cap and gown. There is no single test that is indicative of her knowledge or intelligence. 
 
Thank you again for keeping your commitment to meet with her today. You created an opportunity of a lifetime; one she'll never forget and one we are appreciative of having been a part.  We hope that Kirsty was able to offer you a glimpse into her unique world.
 
Sincerely,
Chuck and Anne Edwards

-----Original Message-----
From: Morales, Jimmy (DIST7) [mailto:CMOR1@miamidade.gov]
Sent: Friday, April 19, 2002 12:35 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: 20 de mayo


Governor,

Greetings from Miami-Dade County.  I did not get up to Tallahassee this
session, but I hope it went fine from your perspective.  I also hope
this
e-mail finds you and your family well.

I am writing to invite you to an event I am hosting on May 20th.  As you
are
very well aware, this May 20 is the 100th anniversary of Cuban
statehood.  I
suspect you will be in Miami for some of those events.  It is also the
100th
anniversary of the raising of the Cuban flag over Cuba.  General Emilio
Nunez raised the flag on that day.  His grandson, Ricardo Nunez
Portuondo (I
believe you know him and his family well) is on my Commission staff and
I am
honoring his family and that special event.  As you may know, Ricardo
was
the first Cuban-American to receive a Presidential Appointment (by Pres.
Ford to run the Cuban Refugee Program) and has been quite a community
leader. 

His grandson, therefore the great-great grandson of General Nunez, will
hoist the flag to commemorate the 100th anniversary.  It will take place
at
Noon, which was when the original flag was hoisted.  The event takes
place
on Cuban Memorial Boulevard, which is at the intersection of S.W. 8th
Street
and 13th Avenue.  Many Cuban exile organizations have been invited.

I would be quite honored if you would be in attendance.  I am sure that
you
have a busy schedule, but I think this will be a special event,
particularly
with the role played by such a prominent family in the history of Cuba
and
the Cuban exile.  I have also heard a rumor that your brother and our
President might be in town that day.  He is certainly welcome to attend
and
I would certainly arrange the event in such a way so as to accommodate
either you or your brother.  Please let me know.

In the meantime, all my best wishes!


Jimmy Morales
305-375-5680
district7@miamidade.gov

-----Original Message-----
From: Stephen R. Wise [mailto:srwise@attbi.com]
Sent: Wednesday, May 15, 2002 3:22 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: HB 295


Governor:
 
HB 295 is the personal attendant care bill to get quadriplegics ages 18-55 out of nursing homes and into the work force... This is a big deal in the disabled community.  The funding for the program is from uncollected sales taxes that have not been remitted to the State.  The pilot program has been operating in Jacksonville for many years and we would like for you to consider coming to Jacksonville to sign the bill.  The collection of the funds will be from the States Attorney Office.
 
You will be a big hit on this bill with the disabled community that ususally votes Democratic... Let me know what I can do for you... I only wish we had more real Republicans in the Senate.
 
Have a great day.
 
Steve

----- Original Message ----- 
From: Butch@handnhand.org 
To: Dianne <mailto:toodle@redmule.net>  ; Haynes, Nancy <mailto:HaynesN@citrus.k12.fl.us>  ; Tracy Sumner <mailto:tracy.sumner@awi.state.fl.us>  ; Barbara Mainster <mailto:barbara@rcma.org>  ; Colleen  <mailto:cgallag@4corlando.org> Gallagher ; Danny  <mailto:dueled@aol.com> Morris ; Debby Russo <mailto:debby_russo@dcf.state.fl.us>  ; Dorothy Dukes <mailto:ddukes@4corlando.org>  ; Eddie Rivera <mailto:eduardo_rivera@dcf.state.fl.us>  ; Ellen McKinley <mailto:kids@cdealliance.org>  ; Gabriela DiTota <mailto:jbj3115@aol.com>  ; Ginger Tate (recording sec <mailto:ginger.tate@myflorida.com>  ; Ivonne  <mailto:ianton@familycentral.org> Anton ; Kathy  <mailto:khaight@owccs.org> Haight ; Kathy Snyder <mailto:ccdir@wesleyhouse.org>  ; Kayce Morton <mailto:kmorton@unr2.net>  ; Marina Harkness <mailto:marina.harkness@sdhc.k12.fl.us>  ; Mark  <mailto:mgrohman@bellsouth.net> Grohman ; Martha Fletcher <mailto:fletcherm@mail.leon.k12.fl.us>  ; Maxine McConnell <mailto:maxine.mcconnell@awi.state.fl.us>  ; Molly  <mailto:molly.jones@myflorida.com> Jones ; Pat Desmond <mailto:pdesmond@title1tech.org>  ; Pat  <mailto:pat.shuler@awi.state.fl.us> Shuler ; Prudence Pate <mailto:pate_pl@popmail.firn.edu>  ; Rod Kendig <mailto:rlk@bdi-ae.com>  ; Sooni Raymaker <mailto:mindy.raymaker@awi.state.fl.us>  ; Thelma Griffith <mailto:tgriffith@cdsi.org>  ; Winston  <mailto:wcroft@jwbpinellas.org> Croft 
Sent: Wednesday, May 15, 2002 3:34 PM
Subject: RE: Citrus County Pre-K Program

Dear Mrs.. Bailey,
 
I have no idea who you have spoken with however, I can tell you they have misled you if they have told you what you describe in your e-mail. I will explain where we are with rules in just a moment but, I first want to thank you for your concerns for your children and those children you have welcomed into your family. People like yourself are blessed with a gift of caring and a willingness to reach out to those less fortunate and I am grateful for your effort and wish you continued blessing in your life.
 More to the point of your concern, First let me point out no rules have been proposed ,our work group is working to developed rules, which coalitions  will follow in order to comply with the School Readiness Act.
Currently, we are discussing the eligibility requirements under the School Readiness Act which governs all school readiness programs. School based readiness programs have replaced the pre-kindergarten program formerly controlled by the local school district. Local coalition made up of local community leaders have responsibility to design and implement school readiness programs that match the needs of your local community. These programs are required by statute to offer a variety of choices and settings for parents to choose. School based ,Private based,and Faith based providers all of whom must conduct developmentally appropriately programs should be available for parental choice.
The School Readiness Act in the intent section clearly point out that  these programs " be developmentally appropriate,researched based,involve parents as the Childs first teacher,serve as preventive measures for children at risk of future school failure,enhance the educational readiness of eligible children and support family education". The Act further states that "school readiness programs be operated on a full-day, year round basis to the maximum extent possible to enable parents to work and become financially self-sufficient.
Clearly the Legislature has pointed out two of the purposes of readiness are to help "at risk" children with preparedness for school and to help families become self sufficient. The statute also points out nothing in this act is intended to:"Relieve parents or guardians of their own obligations to ready their children for school or create any obligation to provide publicly funded school readiness programs or services beyond those authorized by the Legislature".
Children with disabilities ( speech impediments) are one of the eligible groups who are prioritized for school readiness programs which means your son will likely qualify for school readiness in your community.
Your e-mail is not specific as to whether your school district will be participating in the readiness programs. Hopefully. if your school district will participate , you will have the choice of setting and location at a school based site, for your son.
Another part of the readiness programs are the qualitative out reach programs to work with stay at home parents to assist them with their responsibility to prepare their children for school . I would suggest you attend your local coalition meetings and learn more about the unique programs that are being developed by your coalition for your community.
Finally, as to your concern about the work issue our discussions have revolved around how to best use the limited resources we have to serve Florida's children. None of us want to usurp the responsibility of parents to prepare their children for school and we  want to help as many families as possible to be come self sufficient . With that in mind we have discussed setting a priority for two income families falling below the 150% level, with the knowledge that a stay at home parent could engage in the preparedness of their children more readily than a family where both parents work.
From the tone of your e-mail I believe you have been misled by those who have an agenda other than school readiness, which I regret. Change is difficult and when we are trying to change ingrained institutional practices a considerable amount of turf protection and effort is expended by those who desire to maintain the status quo.
Please accept my best wishes for the future of your children and your self . Should you wish to discuss this issue further or any other readiness aspect, please feel free to call me a 407-859 -6635.
 
All the best, Butch
 
 
 
 
 A[Butch@handnhand.or -----Original Message-----
From: Dianne [mailto:toodle@redmule.net]
Sent: Wednesday, May 15, 2002 1:11 PM
To: Haynes, Nancy; Tracy Sumner; Barbara Mainster; Butch Cronon; Colleen Gallagher; Danny Morris; Debby Russo; Dorothy Dukes; Eddie Rivera; Ellen McKinley; Gabriela DiTota; Ginger Tate (recording sec; Ivonne Anton; Kathy Haight; Kathy Snyder; Kayce Morton; Marina Harkness; Mark Grohman; Martha Fletcher; Maxine McConnell; Molly Jones; Pat Desmond; Pat Shuler; Prudence Pate; Rod Kendig; Sooni Raymaker; Thelma Griffith; Winston Croft
Subject: Citrus County Pre-K Program



 
5/15/2002
 
To:  Rule Development Workgroup
       Board Members, Advisory Panel and Staff
 
From:  Dianne Bailey 
            920 E. Harvard St.
            Inverness, Florida 34452
            352-860-2517
 
Dear Sir or Madam,
 
Thank you for taking the time to read my email. I have never felt the need to write to any government office or elected official before but because of the information that I received recently I fell compelled to speak for my son.
First a little background on myself. I am a former foster parent who has adopted two beautiful children from the state of Florida. My daughter, age 5, is just finishing her first wonderful year of pre-k. My son, age 4, has been talking about going to pre-k for the past year and so looking forward to it. He has a speech impediment and I was calling the school ESE supervisor to find out when he was to be evaluated by the speech therapist and she informed me that the Rule Development Workgroup has advised Childhood Development Services of Citrus County that they have just passed a new rule that the children, in order to be qualified to be in the pre-k program must have two working parents. Both parents must be employed and work at least 20 hours a week. Then I was told that my son does not qualify now and will not be able to attend school.
I am shocked beyond belief that the members of the Rule Development Workgroup and other members of legislature in our fine state are so non-family oriented. If I were to get a job to meet these new requirements I would have to put my children in a daycare. I have no one who can watch them. I can not believe that the members of the coalition would rather see a child go to a care giver than to their home where a loving parent is there for them. Being a former foster parent and also talking to the Citrus County Foster Parent Supervisor, I know that the Department of Children and Families strongly supports a stay at home parent. 
Please, listen to my words. I am so determined to reverse this terrible decision that I have already written a similar letter to Mr. and Mrs. Jeb Bush, Frank Brogen, and anyone else who will listen to my words. Who will see the injustice being done to me and to my son. We are all so interested in bringing back family values and to improving education. Parents at home for their children is the best thing and it has been proven. I feel that I and my son are being punished for me being a stay at home mother and that the coalition has lost sight of these values.
 I am very active in my daughters school and the programs that are offered for parents to participate in. Just recently I attended a "Tea Party for Mothers Day" at my daughters school. There were only one third of the mothers there and the children were so sad that their mothers were not able to attend to see them. I was so happy that I was able to attend and brought my son along. I felt so proud of my daughter and her accomplishments and felt an overwhelming sense of sadness for my son who will not be able to have this wonderful opportunity because of this new ruling. 
My priorities are straight. My children come first. It seems to me that the Rule Development Workgroup have lost sight of their priorities in putting education and children's needs first. My daughter has benefited tremendously from this program. My son will too if given the chance.  This is not  a glorified babysitting program. 
We do qualify for the program financially and if the job stipulation is enforced we will no longer qualify because we will be over income. I feel like we are caught between a rock and a hard place. 
I know that there are many parents in the same situation that I am in. I hope to start speaking to them soon and we will all join our voices together to let you all know that a wrong decision has been made. I am planning to attend the meeting on June 5, 2002 and I hope to speak not only for myself but for all the the parents and children that will not have this first step in a life time of education that will shape a child's future and allow them to reach untold heights if this decision is not reversed.
Sincerely,
Dianne Bailey

-----Original Message-----
From: Eduardo Stern [mailto:es@landstarhomes.com]
Sent: Wednesday, May 15, 2002 4:44 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: School Safety Program


 
 
Dear Mr. Governor, 
 
As you may know, for the past ten (10) years I have been extensively involved, as a community service , in programs that help address various issues facing our school age kids.  Issues such as school violence, drug abuse, suicide, bullying/harassment, among others, have been statistically proven to be a deterrent to safe schools and effective learning.  Obviously, the Columbine type tragedies that have become a part of our children’s everyday reality are yet greater examples of deterrents to education.
 
Given your well-known commitment to education and children, I thought you would best appreciate my excitement about having identified a school safety program, designed and brought to my attention by a recently retired top executive of The Wackenhut Corporation, that is modeled after the recommendations from studies conducted by many of our nation’s law enforcement agencies.  
 
The program, to be administered by a for-profit company, consists of a national centralized system for the collection of intelligence regarding our nation’s schools and their respective students, teachers, and administration.  This intelligence is immediately disseminated to the proper authorities for appropriate action.  The main objective of the program is to act as a proactive measure to thwart activities that threaten the safety of those affiliated with a given school, using a national hotline, sophisticated proprietary software (designed by IBM), and highly trained and qualified personnel from professionals fields including law enforcement, intelligence, crisis negotiation, psychology, sociology, and education. 
 
Additionally, I am particularly proud that the company’s plans include locating its national headquarters in Palm Beach County, Florida, and will initially employ over 300 people.
 
I would very much appreciate the opportunity to meet with you in order to better inform you about the program, and how it is right in-line with your education platform.  I am confident that once you learn more about its mechanics you will agree that this innovative approach will provide a very effective means of addressing most of the problem issues facing our schools and youth today.  
 
Please contact me at your earliest convenience through my office (305) 461-2440 extension 115, or e-mail address ( es@landstarhomes.com), if you are interested in learning more about this program.   As always, I would very much welcome the opportunity to meet with you in Tallahassee, or any other location of your choosing.   
 
Warmest personal regards from your friend,
Eduardo Stern

-----Original Message-----
From: Growney Matt-AMG023 [mailto:Matthew.Growney@motorola.com]
Sent: Wednesday, May 15, 2002 5:03 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: 'mgarcia@evn.org'
Subject: Emerging Venture Network


Greetings Governor Bush. Thank you for the recent note and support through
Brett Doster. On a similar front, I have been working with a group that
identifies and prepares minority entrepreneurs for receiving equity funding
and then connects them with venture capitalists.  The Emerging Venture
Network (EVN) is a not-for-profit organization that has had a high success
rate in assisting high-growth minority entrepreneurs. Six of the 15
companies they presented to investors last November have already received
funding. 

Florida's commitment to investing state pension funds in venture capital
funds may signal a strong commitment to creating high-growth businesses, and
thus jobs, in the State of Florida.   The other half of the equation is
identifying and developing businesses that have the potential to be venture
backed.  EVN's success, coupled with industry statistics, suggests that
investors have not sufficiently tapped into minority deals.  In today's
market, minority firms garner 2-3% of venture capital dollars despite being
one of the fastest growing business sectors.  As home to the US' 3rd largest
metro area for minority business - Miami -- and a diverse population
statewide, Florida can build a competitive advantage by tapping into venture
deals that may otherwise go unidentified. I think we briefly discussed
Florida's need to either build an angel investor network or find strong
catalysts to support budding entrepreneurs. EVN coordinates both. 

I would like to recommend EVN as a resource to the state and ask you to
identify a person in the Governor's office with whom they should work to
coordinate further exposure to any young Florida entrepreneurial community.
Through this email, I would also like to introduce you to Michelle Garcia,
one of EVN's co-founders who runs the Miami office. Please let us know any
proper course of action EVN can take with your administration to come online
throughout the State of Florida. Please let either of us know if you have
any questions.

Again thank you for taking the time and I wish you continued success.
Regards,

matthew i. growney

Managing Director
Motorola V E N T U R E S
210 Broadway- 4th Fl.
Cambridge, MA.  02139
P: 617-252-9655
www.motorola.com

May 15, 2002

To Whom It May Concern:

This serves as a letter of reference for Carrie Dunn, who has been our
daughter's kindergarten teacher for the last school year.  We wanted to take
this step in an effort to assist her in any future vocational opportunities
as they may emerge.  It is our honor to recommend Mrs. Dunn. While we have
only known Carrie Dunn since August 2001, we have been very impressed with
both her skills as an academic instructor and with her professionalism and
demeanor as a role model and mentor to her large class of students.  She has
demonstrated outstanding talents in both the administrative/managerial
aspects of her role as well as the academic instruction responsibilities.
Carrie has an excellent reputation among the fellow parents as a superb
kindergarten teacher at Pride Elementary School. 

Revealing of her abilities, Carrie has consistently taken the initiative to
significantly expand and augment the core academic program, especially as
individual student scenarios might dictate.  She works very diligently to
assist those students that might require additional attention or assistance,
and she also enhances the scope of learning for those students who may be
learning at an accelerated level.  We have been very pleased with our
daughter, Brianna's, personal growth and development on many fronts over the
last school year.  The academic transition has been truly astounding.
Brianna is now reading and comprehending at a second-grade level.  She is
able to read and navigate alone on children's websites online. Brianna can
read nearly every storybook that we have ever purchased for her to her
younger sister.  She is also able to write in sentence and paragraph form
with very few errors in structure or spelling.  We could not be more
pleased.

Carrie Dunn has also demonstrated tremendous skill at navigating through the
disciplinary and other issues that sometimes arise in such a diverse mix of
students and parents.  She maintains a well structured yet nurturing
environment for her classroom of 30+ students.  Carrie Dunn has
distinguished herself as a superb teacher in our opinion.  We have actively
participated in most school functions, both during and outside school hours.
We have had tremendous exposure to her leadership and academic skills, even
with the younger siblings of her students. Her competence, compassion and
ethics as an instructor of young children are exemplary.  In providing a
broad spectrum of support, care giving and instruction, Carrie has more than
proven her ability to lead a large and complex classroom environment. 

Carrie Dunn's commitment to education and teaching is highlighted by the
success of her students at Pride Elementary.  We are deeply impressed by
Carrie's efforts above-and-beyond the "call of duty" and recommend her
unhesitatingly for any similar role. I am confident that in the future she
would provide the same high level of service and commitment.  If you have
any questions or wish to speak further about Carrie Dunn, please feel free
to contact us directly at 813.220.5462.

Sincerely,

Sonja and Kevin Ward

Dear Jeb
I want to wish you all the luck in the world as you seek re-election.
May I also strongly urge the abandonment of the proposal that the INS is
floating around, to restrict foreign visitors to 30 days per year in the
US. Florida of course, would be particularly hard hit and in my opinion, it
would not achieve any of its desired objectives. Once someone enters the US
for even one day, they can dissapear if they so choose. Even a thirty day
period would make it nearly impossible to find such a person. Additionally,
the potential that troublemakers are US citizens negates this initiative.
So many have dual citizenships.
something has to be done to ensure better security, but that could be said
for the rest of the world as well. This knee jerk reaction makes absolutely
no sense and of course harms the innocents.
Still looking forward to a golf game with you and Ed one of these days.
Best regards, Bill Shenkman

From:	PBrid45808@aol.com
Sent:	Wednesday, May 15, 2002 11:39 PM
To:	Kathleen_Kearney@dcf.state.fl.us
Cc:	Bob_Morin@dcf.state.fl.us; Cheryl_Mundy@dcf.state.fl.us; Helen_Tasker@dcf.state.fl.us; Jeb Bush
Subject:	We Support You!

Dear Secretary Kearney: 

      Please be aware that we families and consumers of DCF services here in District 7 support you and the DCF administrators, staff and workers who are dedicated to the well-being of our developmentally disabled population.  As a nurse, I can certainly sympathize, and possibly empathize, with you in the Miami situation.  The medical profession often faces many tragic situations and must deal with media scrutiny and "bad press."   
      We appreciate that the Department of Children and Families has a very broad scope of services under its wings.  It is difficult for one agency to handle all those critical issues involved with our children and families.  We are grateful that there are so many willing to devote their careers to helping the less fortunate in this state.  It is not easy and often under-appreciated.  Much progress had been made over the last three or more years.  We have seen it.  For instance, there is more open communication and more family and consumer involvement in the programs.  We pray that the wonderful progress that has been made will continue. 
      Thank you for your leadership and God Bless You! 

Sincerely, 

Phyllis A. Bridges 
Parent, Advocate, FCC, District 7
From:	russell bjorkman <russellbjorkman@yahoo.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, May 15, 2002 11:45 PM
To:	Colleen Castille
Cc:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	DC Calculations
Attachments:	RE: 

Colleen:

# 1.
The calculations that are being used by the FSBA
appear to me to be short changing the participants by
29%.

The Present Value of Accumulated Benefits(PVAB)
calculation for each individual should be
representative of their accrued value to date -
period.  

The summation of each individual's PVAB should equal
the same amount that is being used for the DB plan.

According to my questions and Francis's answers, this
is not the case. 


# 2.
The FRS DB/DC web-site decision tutorial pages should
prominately provide descriptions of the components
that drive the PV - CASH OUT number. 2 of the FSBA
estimated numbers that make the biggest difference in
the CASH OUT calculations  are the earnings assumption
and and salary growth rate.  

The salary growth rate that is being used is 5%-10%
per year and is age dependent.  This is a very high
salary growth rate. 

I think that many people would be interested in
applying their own forecast in this area.  A lower
forward looking salary assumption would reduce the
amount of the future DB benefit.  This would change
the DB DC comparison. This would not change the Cash
OUT amount(depending on the answers to my #1 above),
but the individual's comparison of their DB payment to
a potential DC accumulation would be significantly
different.


This is one more unfortunate chapter in a book that
has been made far more expensive and difficult than is
necessary.

Regards,

Russell



Note: forwarded message attached.

From: Genevieve Jones [mailto:ghugginsjones@hotmail.com]
Sent: Wednesday, May 15, 2002 11:46 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Charles Huggins



 To Whom It May Concern:

 

            RE:  Charles Wesley Huggins, Jr. H05888

 

            I just received a call from my nephew, Chuck.  He has received a letter from Janet Keels’ office stating that the parole board has recommended that his request for waiver be denied.  I hope that this is not an indication of the thoughts of the whole board.  He has a good record and has tried very hard to do what he needs to do to steer clear of the drugs that are available in prison.  He is now working at the Fire College in Ocala and doing quite well.  I keep hearing that the prisons are overcrowded and the state is trying to come up with a way to release inmates that are not a threat to society and that have a good record.  I believe that my nephew is definitely an excellent candidate for that consideration. 

I don’t mean to beat a dead horse but the recent affair of a certain ball player really saddens me.  He has finally been put in prison for a very minimal time and yet not for the original crimes but for breaking parole, what a message that has sent to the rest of the world.  If you have money or a big name, you can do most anything and get a slap on the hand.  All my family and I are asking is that you grant my nephew the same courtesy.  No we don’t have a big name or any money, but we love him and want him home.  He has definitely matured in the 3 years he has been locked up and I believe that he can go out into the world and walk away from the temptations of drugs and alcohol.  He is a very bright young man who made some very stupid choices and he knows that now.  Please give him the opportunity to become a self-supporting, honest, law abiding citizen.  

If you don’t grant this, then if I understand what I have read, he will have to wait an additional two years before he can apply again.  I certainly hope that is not an avenue we are going to have to go down.  The middle class people of our society deserve the same considerations as the richer portion of society.  Please consider prayerfully before you make your decision.  

 

                                                                        Sincerely, 

                                                                        Genevieve Jones

                                                                        813-719-2812 

PS - I know you will be in Hillsborough County campaigning for equal education for everyone.  I wholeheartedly agree with that and I hope you have the same attitude about Chuck.

-----Original Message-----
From: Growney Matt-AMG023 [mailto:Matthew.Growney@motorola.com]
Sent: Wednesday, May 15, 2002 5:03 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: 'mgarcia@evn.org'
Subject: Emerging Venture Network


Greetings Governor Bush. Thank you for the recent note and support
through
Brett Doster. On a similar front, I have been working with a group that
identifies and prepares minority entrepreneurs for receiving equity
funding
and then connects them with venture capitalists.  The Emerging Venture
Network (EVN) is a not-for-profit organization that has had a high
success
rate in assisting high-growth minority entrepreneurs. Six of the 15
companies they presented to investors last November have already
received
funding. 

Florida's commitment to investing state pension funds in venture capital
funds may signal a strong commitment to creating high-growth businesses,
and
thus jobs, in the State of Florida.   The other half of the equation is
identifying and developing businesses that have the potential to be
venture
backed.  EVN's success, coupled with industry statistics, suggests that
investors have not sufficiently tapped into minority deals.  In today's
market, minority firms garner 2-3% of venture capital dollars despite
being
one of the fastest growing business sectors.  As home to the US' 3rd
largest
metro area for minority business - Miami -- and a diverse population
statewide, Florida can build a competitive advantage by tapping into
venture
deals that may otherwise go unidentified. I think we briefly discussed
Florida's need to either build an angel investor network or find strong
catalysts to support budding entrepreneurs. EVN coordinates both. 

I would like to recommend EVN as a resource to the state and ask you to
identify a person in the Governor's office with whom they should work to
coordinate further exposure to any young Florida entrepreneurial
community.
Through this email, I would also like to introduce you to Michelle
Garcia,
one of EVN's co-founders who runs the Miami office. Please let us know
any
proper course of action EVN can take with your administration to come
online
throughout the State of Florida. Please let either of us know if you
have
any questions.

Again thank you for taking the time and I wish you continued success.
Regards,

matthew i. growney

Managing Director
Motorola V E N T U R E S
210 Broadway- 4th Fl.
Cambridge, MA.  02139
P: 617-252-9655
www.motorola.com

Subject: Re: ESY 2002
 
Thank you Gary!!  What a mess!!  At this point we are not sure that it will be safe for Lucy to attend the proposed ESY services.  It's a shame for those that do not have a back up system, but what I see happening is that the state is going to end paying more out of Waiver funds, and even though they are mandated by IDEA, the school system is going to be off the hook.  Most parents, teachers, aides, bus drivers do not know at this point in they have a program, a job, and if they do where, and if the services are in place. I understand that our district will be sending a letter to all those that qualified for ESY services asking if they are still planning to attend.  It's fair to assumed that many will say NO because the services are not considered appropriate. In our case, we can not allow for Lucy to be DUMPED in a new setting (middle school) without competent staff that can ensure her an appropriate and safe program. Not only is it going to be a segregated setting, but Lucy is 20 years old, and should not be attending a Middle School.   Do you think that we should file a formal complain with the state DOE?  IDEA is vague on this area, and I am not sure what to do.  I have been trying to avoid to litigate, but I wonder if we are being force to use that avenue,
 
Berthy

On Wed, 15 May 2002 11:36:47 -0400 "Carole Zangari" <zangaric@nova.edu> writes:

Hi Jill,
 
Very nice to hear from you. We have no 'regular' program set up that would be appropriate for Lucy, but she is welcome to return as a volunteer with our WorkAble Solutions project the way she did last year. It was wonderful having her and we certainly would welcome her back. We were able to customize a series of activities for her last year that seemed to work out fairly well.
 
In terms of logistics, Lucy would have to come with her aide, of course, and the same set of equipment and materials. We also need a name stamp for her, which I mentioned to Robin at the IEP. She needs to bring the following at each visit:
Big Mac
Step by Step
Spin Art
Trigger Sound
Switch adapted tape player
Power Link
Name Stamp
Lunch
 
She can come 1-2 days a week starting the week of June 24th (we have camp the week before). Tuesdays and Thursdays would be best. The 5 days/week in weeks 1 and 5 would not be the best set up for us. Last year the times were 10-1, if I remember correctly, but we have some flexibility there.
 
I will need to have the family fill out a case history form since we are making this a bit more formal. Berthy, can you give me an address where I can have those forms sent? Also, I will need to see her for speech tx a few times while she is with us as this is part of our WorkAble Solutions model. I would work on collaboration with her aide in developing a program for her to do while she is with us, and then monitor it, retraining as needed. This would need to be included in her Medicaid POC, I believe, if that is to be the funding source for her therapy.
 
Let me know ASAP if this is workable so that I can make the appropriate arrangements on this end. There is a bit more competition for slots and I need to act quickly to save one for Lucy.
 
Regards,
Carole

From:	Yablonski, Brian <Brian.Yablonski@MyFlorida.com>
Sent:	Thursday, May 16, 2002 2:50 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	RE: Incase you missed my last message

Governor, Mike and I discussed . . . . Here are Mike's thoughts -- I would only add that ideally, in the years ahead, Health Flex would be expanded to include populations such as David's -- part of the problem, as Mike notes, is the high cost of insurance due to mandates and regulation.  Health Flex should be the norm, not the exception:
 
Health flex may not directly help him, but it will potentially help tens of thousands of other low income uninsured in Florida.  And there is a provision in the bill which allows for limited benefit policies for all small groups (the modified Farkas language) which he could take advantage of..
 
In terms of insurance carriers having not demonstrating any interest in keeping insurance costs low, he is way off base.  The insurance industry and HMO industry have offer dozens of proposals to keep costs low, and most of their time is spent fighting off special interests who want to add mandated benefits and coverages which increase costs.  He is also not aware of the role that the insurance commissioner plays in holding down rate increases through approval of all rate increases.
 
In terms of the groups of one issue, the reform is not meant to help him, but rather to help groups of 2 - 50 whose costs are being driven up as a result of the high cost of including groups of one.  Groups of  one are gaming the system and shifting their costs to other small groups.  Ideally, groups of one should be in the individual market where there is no community rating.  But since we have no high risk pool, we added them into the small group market if they can prove they are self employed.

-----Original Message-----
From: David Farrar [mailto:farrardm@bellsouth.net]
Sent: Thursday, May 09, 2002 10:32 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Incase you missed my last message


Governor,

 

You wanted to know my suggestion on how I would deal with the issue of the single-insured in the new Healthcare Plan.

 I will try to be brief.  But since this is not my area of expertise, I may be a trifle long...please bear with me.

 

I have briefly scanned through SB 46-I Health Care bill, mainly the "clean claim" section, the pilot health flex plan and the single insured provision.  

 

Since I view the primary reason for higher medical premiums almost exclusively on uncontrolled medical costs, forcing carriers to pay medical providers before a clean claim will simply allow the medical industry to gouge the consumer even more.  The clean claim proviso will make it even harder for carriers to hold down medical costs, or even develop an incentive to do so.

 

Governor, I am a court reporter. All I do all day long is take EUOs (examination under oaths) and IMEs (independent medical examination) testimony. Under our present structure there is no incentive for medical providers to cut costs. And as long as the insurance industry can simply go to the state and raise premiums to meet rising costs, they will not play their natural and vital role in reducing costs -- that leaves the consumer virtually powerless and defenseless. We should be passing laws that strengthen the insurance carrier's hands in making sure these medical costs are reasonable, necessary and affordable.  The mere fact that insurance carriers are not asking the Legislature for more tools to address rising medical costs tells me the direction of this bill is headed in the wrong direction.

 

The health flex pilot plan is designed to help provide medical coverage for the uninsured whose family gross income equals to or less than 200 percent of the federal poverty level, about $30,000 per year. I make around $60,000 a year, gross. I pay about $800 per month in medical coverage for my wife, daughter and myself. This amount is due to go up to $890 next year. I will not be able to afford 150 percent increase on this amount. I also will not qualify for your health flex plan at present, neither will a lot of other one-life groups. There is at present no safety net for us. The health flex plan must be far more developed to insure that no one is singled out to carry an unfair burden or be left behind.

 

That leaves me with the single insured issue. I have nothing against joining a larger consumer group if the transition is seamless and harmless. I see nothing in this bill that assures me that bringing one-lifers into a larger consumer pool will be a simple matter of paperwork. I have paid into my present medical coverage for the past 15 years with very little medical expense. At my age, I am not a very good prospect to a new insurance carrier and would be an enticing target to jettison by my insurance carrier if given half a chance. The law must ensure the pooling of one-life groups is carried out in a transparent and professional manner.

 

Yes, Governor, there are good provisions in this bill, and insurance reform is needed. But this bill is premature in its design and puts people at risk needlessly. 

 

I know you will do your best to do what is right, as you have done before. But no irreversible harm will come from putting this reform bill off another year so adequate provisions can be made to protect all the people.

 

ex animo

 

davidfarrar
