From:	Lisa.Snell@reason.org
Sent:	Thursday, May 16, 2002 3:47 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	High School Blues in California

Jeb,

As if high school students in California do not have enough problems, a controversial new policy affecting eight California high schools asks seniors who wish to walk in graduation ceremonies to first submit a plan and documentation proving they're going to college, a trade school, or the military. 

Fox News takes up the story today here:
<http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,52875,00.html>

Reason Editor Nick Gillespie takes Los Angeles Unified's General Counsel Harold Kwalwasser to task for this adolescent injustice on CNN's American Morning with Paula Zahn. Here's a sample:  "You know, well, first off, I want to congratulate the Los Angeles unified school district on creating a new reason for kids to resent high school and administrators. If this planning was such an obvious good idea, then make it a requirement of graduation, but don't let people go through what the state approves and what L.A. approves as necessary to graduate from high school, and then deny them the right to graduate in front of their friends as parent."

And in a perfect soundbite moment Nick ends the interview with an argument for school choice:  "Jack, if I may add, the real question here really is educational choice, and is matching parents and students to school that have curricula and programs that they want, and until we address that basic issue, and this is one of the reasons why in Los Angeles, where people are very fearful of sending their kids to the schools."

Read the transcript below:



SHOW: AMERICAN MORNING WITH PAULA ZAHN 07:00 

May 9, 2002 Thursday 

Transcript # 050905CN.V74 

SECTION: News; Domestic 

LENGTH: 1526 words 

HEADLINE: Some Students in San Fernando Valley Won't be Donning Caps and Gowns Because They 'Failed to Develop Acceptable Plan for Future' 

GUESTS: Nick Gillespie, Harold Kwalwasser 

BYLINE: Jack Cafferty 

HIGHLIGHT: 
This summer, some students in California's San Fernando Valley will not be donning caps and gowns with their classmates because they failed to develop an acceptable plan for their future. 

BODY: 
THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOT BE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED. 

JACK CAFFERTY, CNN ANCHOR: This time of year, high school seniors all across the country counting the days until graduation. It's often said at the annual pomp-and-circumstance ceremony that graduation is not the end of anything, rather it's the beginning. 

This summer, some students in California's San Fernando Valley will not be donning caps and gowns with their classmates because they failed to develop an acceptable plan for their future. There is a new school policy out there that says only student who have committed to postgraduate training in college, trade school or the military, will be allowed to participate in graduation ceremonies. They'll still get the diploma, but they won't participate in the graduation ceremony. As you might imagine, there is a hew and cry coming from this idea. 

Joining us from Los Angeles to talk about it is Harold Kwalwasser, who's general counsel for the Los Angeles unified school district, and from Washington D.C., Nick Gillespie, who's editor in chief of "Reason" magazine. 

Gentlemen, welcome. It's nice to you have with us. 

Harold, let me begin with you. The minute we began teasing this story we starting getting e-mails saying something to the effect, how dare the schools demand that students lay out some sort of plan for the future in order to be allowed to participate in their graduation if they met all the requirements to, in fact, graduate from high school. It sounds a bit Draconian. Tell me how it works. 

HAROLD KWALWASSER, GENERAL COUNSEL, L.A. UNITED SCHOOL DIST.: First of all, it is a great success, and I want to emphasize that in the beginning, because what we tried to do here is encourage think about after school, and that means not just those going college, but those who are going to go on and get a job afterward. We don't want them in dead-end jobs. We don't want them really just falling off the edge of the earth. We want these children to understand there is more out there to life, and you don't have to go to college to get it. You can have a plan for life where you can find advancement through vocational education, through apprenticeships, through the military, and we want them merely e think about these things and plan for them. 

CAFFERTY: What about kids... 

KWALWASSER: Now the thing I think I must take exception to, is it's not clear to me at the end of the day we're going to have anybody that's denied the right to participate in the graduation ceremony. As of May 1st, we had approximately 95 percent of our kids in local district C, the San Fernando Valley, who have in fact completed their plans. We have an expectation that virtually everybody will have completed the plans by graduation time. 

CAFFERTY: What about a kid that doesn't know what he wants to do, or what about a kid who doesn't have the money to go to college, who says, hey, I have to work in one of those so-called dead-end jobs in a couple of years to save up some money, and then I'll decide whether I want to go to college or not? 

Are there exceptions to this rule? Can a kid still participate if he doesn't fall into one of the three defined category, college, vocational, trade school or the military? 

KWALWASSER: Oh, sure. This is not about trying to force kids not to work or to penalize kids if they do work. This is to say to kids who are going to go off to work, well, let's think about your future and how you're going to advance from the entry-level job you get when you finish high school to something better thereafter. Remember, what we're trying to do is to get kids to plan for the future. 

CAFFERTY: Fair enough. 

KWALWASSER: That's what they have to do. It's merely to participate in thinking about their future, and in raising their expectations, and in having high expectations of them. 

CAFFERTY: Nick Gillepsie, let me switch... 

KWALWASSER: So once they participate in the plan, that's sufficient. 

CAFFERTY: Let's me switch to this to Nick Gillespie. And let me put up some statistics, Nick, that appear this is more than a good idea. These are statistics from the district C that's involved in this program, enrollment at University of California schools up 10 percent overall, an 8 percent increase for white students, for Latino students up 31 percent, for African-American students up 150 percent. The numbers seem to suggest that something's working. What's your reaction? 

NICK GILLESPIE, EDITOR-IN-CHIEF, "REASON: MAGAZINE: You know, well, first off, I want to congratulate the Los Angeles unified school district on creating a new reason for kids to resent high school and administrators. If this planning was such an obvious good idea, then make it a requirement of graduation, but don't let people go through what the state approves and what L.A. approves as necessary to graduate from high school, and then deny them the right to graduate in front of their friends as parent. 

"The Los Angeles Times" yesterday reporting the story made it clear many students won't be involved in graduation because of this, and also, you know, that there is a lot of resentment. Whatever the intentions of the plan, it's invidious. It creates two sets of graduates, one who gets to march in front of graduates and pick up their diploma, and the other ones that go on merely to work, which I thought was the great American value. 

I think it's intrusive. It inserts the school in a conversation that really most properly takes place between parents and children, in large degree, and I think it's largely ineffective for the reason that counsel was saying, in that anybody can do it. This a piece of paper, and I'm not sure that it's really focusing anybody's attention. 

CAFFERTY: What about those criticisms, Mr. Kwalwasser? 

KWALWASSER: I think they're wrong up and down the line. Let me start with a few key points. First of all, I don't think that there are going to very many kids not participating in high school graduation ceremonies. 

CAFFERTY: But why shouldn't they all be able to participate I guess is the question? If they completed the curriculum for 12 years in the public school system, why is it up to some bureaucrat to come along, and say your plan for the next part of the life isn't satisfactory for me, and therefore, you can't stand up in front of your family and friends and get your diploma? 

GILLESPIE: If I may say, it will force them to lie about something. Say, you're the son of an immigrant... 

KWALWASSER: I think that's all high speculation that doesn't mirror reality. 

GILLESPIE: No, no, well, wait. Let me just say, this is what you're saying, so the son of an immigrant who is going to work in his parent's business after school and not go on for education, what you're saying is, and not going out to the military or vocational training, what you're saying to that person is that we value your hard work and your effort in those kinds of stores less than if you say you're going on to the military. If you want to put people through an exercise... 

KWALWASSER: That hypothetical doesn't wash. 

CAFFERTY: All right, we'll give you the last word here, but it's got to be brief. We're going lose the satellite. Last word on this, and why those people that Nick is talking about shouldn't feel a bit disenfranchised by a regulation such as this. 

KWALWASSER: First of all, those kids will still graduate. The fact that you go on to work in your parents store isn't the issue, so long as you think about how you're going to advance yourself forward after you start working in your parent's store, you satisfied all the requirements here. All we're trying to do is work with these kids to plan their future. 

You know, so often, public schools are criticized for not caring about what happens to their kids. Here we have a commitment to care and to help them think through their future. If they work in their parents store but think about their future, they got it made, and they graduate in the ceremony along with everybody else. 

CAFFERTY: Good. 

GILLESPIE: Jack, if I may add, the real question here really is educational choice, and is matching parents and students to school that have curricula and programs that they want, and until we address that basic issue, and this is one of the reasons why in Los Angeles, where people are very fearful of sending their kids to the schools. 

CAFFERTY: All right. Gentlemen, I have got to stop it there. I appreciate your talking with us. We'll follow up on the story and keep track of parental reaction and student reaction out there. Nick Gillespie, from Washington, editor-in-chief of "Reason" magazine, thanks, Nick. Harold Kwalwasser, who's general counsel of the Los Angeles unified district, joining us from California. Thanks for being with us on AMERICAN MORNING. 

KWALWASSER: Thank you. Come see one of our graduations from district C. 

CAFFERTY: All right, good. TO ORDER A VIDEO OF THIS TRANSCRIPT, PLEASE CALL 800-CNN-NEWS OR USE OUR SECURE ONLINE ORDER FORM LOCATED AT www.fdch.com <http://www.fdch.com/> 



Thanks for your continued support of Reason's education program.

best,

Lisa

____________________________________________

3415 S. Sepulveda Blvd. #400
Los Angeles, CA 90034

> 		From: 	Hosay, Robert  
> 		Sent:	Wednesday, May 15, 2002 5:43 PM
> 		To:	Henderson, Cynthia
> 		Cc:	Brown, Monesia; Dominguez, Melissa
> 		Subject:	Fingerprint bid FYI
> 
> 		We released the finger print ITB that you and I discussed
> last week. This is the first ITB to be released with the new bonus point
> system for minorities and Florida businesses. The language is a follows:
> 
> 		1.06 Basis for Award:  The Department intends to make
> statewide multiple awards to one or more (not to exceed four) responsive
> bidders as scored in accordance with this section, based upon the highest
> total net score. If more than one bidder offers the same Manufacturer's
> brand product (make & model), only the highest scored bid will be eligible
> for award for that brand.  "Optional Items" will only be awarded to those
> Contractors that are being awarded the "Equipment" as listed on the Price
> Sheet, attachment herein.
> 
> 		Prices bid shall include all costs including delivery,
> installation, training and preparing the Live Capture Fingerprint Stations
> for operational use.
> 
> 		To be eligible for an award, a bidder must satisfy the
> technical specifications and be within 20 points of the highest-scored
> bid.  Bids will be scored as follows, with price being the controlling
> criterion.  The bidder submitting the lowest price will receive the
> maximum number of points (100), and others will be awarded points
> according to this formula:  (N / X) * C = Z, where
> 
> 			N = lowest price bid
> 			X = bidder's price
> 			C = total number of points
> 			Z = points awarded
> 
> 		A maximum of ten bonus points will be awarded as follows:  A
> bidder may receive points on more than one basis, but the total shall not
> exceed ten points.  A bidder shall submit with its bid conclusive proof
> that it qualifies for bonus points.
> 
> 		10 points - Bidder is a Florida-certified WMBE (submit copy
> of certification from the Florida Office of Supplier Diversity)
> 
> 		8 points - Bidder is a WMBE certified by another state of
> the federal government (submit copy of certification from the other state
> or the federal government)
> 
> 		6 points - Bidder is incorporated in, or has its principal
> place of business in, Florida (submit proof from the Florida Secretary of
> State, Division of Corporations, or certification from company officer)
> 
> 		Delivery shall be within 30 days after receipt of Purchase
> Order or may be more than 30 days if directed by Eligible Users in
> writing.
> 
> 		The Department reserves the right to reject pricing that is
> greater than pricing offered to other potential Customers (e.g., city,
> county, university, or federal contracts).  The Department reserves the
> right to accept or reject any and all bids, or separable portions, and to
> waive any minor irregularity, technicality, or omission if the Department
> determines that doing so will serve the State's best interest. 
>

From:	Jkreimer@aol.com
Sent:	Thursday, May 16, 2002 4:15 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Cc:	mavis.knight@myflorida.com
Subject:	The 9/21/00 e-mail

Dear Governor, In case your computer no longer has my message of September 
21, 2000 on it, I decided to send the letter of that date that I mentioned in 
the first e-mail I sent to you, today,by retyping it. Cambridge Medical 
Centers Inc. is a typing mistake - it is Cambridge Medical Holdings Inc. Of 
course, this is the old Board, with Bill Scherer in control. Please pay 
special attention to the underlined part of paragraph 2 - it shows that Bill 
Scherer was knowingly lending money to defunct corporations (incidentally, it 
is also against the law for a body such as the District,  non-profit too, to 
lend money to a for-profit corporation, which Scherer had to know.) I am so 
disgusted that the present Board is split, with Scherer advocating keeping 
the clinic at Deerfield open, when the Board knows that it has failed so 
badly that they have had to pour about $2,000,000 into it. There is no 
reasonable rationale for doing this in the face of the residents holding a 
rally against it, except for Scherer to win Trinchi's four votes to stay on 
as attorney to the Board, for the political benefit of Trinchi, to conceal 
that the residents would be committed to paying the mortgage on the new 5000 
square foot clubhouse built to replace the one Trinchi gave to Cambridge for 
the clinic. I hope you realize that these e-mails are coming to you because 
of my interest in doing the right thing. Sincerely, Jane Kreimer 

Subj:  The Honorable Paul Sallarulo and The Honorable Emmett McTigue, etc.

Dear Governor Bush,

For me, the Cambridge mess is the last straw in a long line of last straws. 

The Board is going to tell you that they had no idea what was going on, 
especially when they voted for Cambridge Medical Center Inc. No excuse is 
acceptable. They should have done what Paul Sallarulo did at his first Board 
meeting. He refused to vote because they delivered the information he needed 
to read in order to make a decision at about 5 o'clock the day before, on 
Tuesday. Then he ordered the president and ceo to deliver whatever he needed 
to make a decision, on the Friday before the monthly Wednesday meeting, and 
said that otherwise he wasn't voting. I told the other Board members that 
there was no excuse for their not having done the same thing a long time ago.

The Board, in the person of Dr. Rosalyn Carter (Ph.D) was quoted recently in 
one of the newspapers as having said that they had no idea that Bill Scherer 
wrote a second contract for Barry Chapnick and Trinchi on April 1st or 1999, 
after the clinic failed to open at all on March 1 of 1999 under the terms of 
the first contract of October 1st, 1998. Without first going back to the 
Board for permission to write a second contract, Bill Scherer changed the 
terms, and gave Cambridge at Margate a 9 1/2% loan, which was way under what 
the Board had agreed to. I informed the Board of this at the June 1999 
meeting, the same meeting where I read all of the Cambridge corporations to 
them that I had pulled from the internet from the Division of Corporations, 
all of which read "dissolved for failure to file annual report" except one, 
which read "active". When I called to double check that one, the Department 
told me that they were "active but not current", which meant they had not 
paid their fee or filed before May 1 of that year. In August, they were 
dissolved for failure to file the annual report. Not one Board member did 
anything about it, and they let it ride for more than a year. The clinic at 
Deerfield beach, Century Village, was also failing.

The District does not have to lose that $500,000 loan (or the loss that 
followed). They don't have to file an expensive lawsuit to get that money 
back. They can go against Bill Scherer's  and Buchanan and Ingersoll's e and 
o insurance (Buchanan and Ingersoll closed the loan for Scherer), as well as 
the bond that the District paid for Trinchi when he was appointed to the 
District in the first place. I think it is fair to say that Scherer and 
Trinchi are in BIG trouble. It just doesn't pay to lie to the public and 
cheat the taxpayers. I hope you do not intend to protect Bill Scherer because 
he raised so much money for you and especially for your brother now.

Quite frankly, and sadly, I don't think that Trinchi knows what the truth is 
anymore. He said at the last Board meeting that he didn't know the law firm 
Greenberg and Traurer - had never heard of them, when Moskowitz (who 
definitely should be bounced off that Board) recommended them to write a 
letter to Bob Butterworth asking if it was legal to lend the half million in 
the first place. Truth: Trinchi was standing next to the attorneys for 
Century Village and Greenberg and Traurer at a City Commission meeting in 
Deerfield when Greenberg and Traurer were chosen to handle the current bond 
issue for Deerfield Beach - which choice never would have been made without 
Trinchi's approval.

Contrary to Trinchi's insisting that the residents at Century Village want a 
clinic, they held a huge rally against it before the clinic was put in by 
Trinchi. That is why Trinchi by-passed a vote on it, and just went ahead and 
announced that it was an accomplished fact.

As I told Arlene DiBenigno, when the District is failing financially two 
years in a row, which it is, you are supposed to take it over, and appoint a 
new Board. I would say the $12,000,000 last year and $7,000,000 this year in 
arrears, qualifies for such action. I feel very strongly that when one is 
appointed to the Board, one owes the Governor who appointed you absolute 
loyalty. This is why I have so little respect for Trinchi, Carter, Weaver and 
Moskowitz. Dead or alive, they owe Lawton Chiles that loyalty, and instead, 
in my opinion they have disgraced him, as well as themselves. In my opinion, 
Cora Braynan has done the same thing to you, by aligning herself with them 
and everything they do. Emmett McTigue stands alone from those other 
appointees as a pillar of integrity, intelligence and common sense, and 
should remain on the Board, as should Paul Sallarulo.

A fine kettle of fish! I don't know you at all. You have some tough choices 
to make. I just hope that you have the character and integrity to make the 
right ones.

Sincerely,  Jane Kreimer

The confidentiality of Internet e-mail cannot be guaranteed. Information
you send us
over Internet e-mail could be viewed by persons other than the intended
recipients.
Therefore, you should not include your account numbers, credit card
numbers,
passwords, home address or other private information in your e-mail
messages.
Also, we will not accept buy or sell orders or cancels, address changes,
funds
transfer requests or other instructions normally requiring your signature
by e-mail.

All market prices, data and other information in this communication are not
warranted
as to completeness or accuracy and may be subject to change. This
communication
is not an official record of your account and should not be relied upon for
information
regarding your account. Please refer to your Trade Confirmation and Client
Statement
which are the official records of your account. If there are any
discrepancies between
this transmission and your Trade Confirmation and Client Statement, you
should rely
on the Trade Confirmation and Client Statement and contact your local
branch
manager with any questions.

This information is being sent to you for your information or at your
request. If you do
not wish to receive any further information about our products or services,
please

From:    seeamericafirst@adelphia.net (See America First)

Sandy, I thought of you when I read an article in the Boston Sunday Globe about the revival of civics education for school children and the benefits such as increased voter participation more community involvement.  It states that Bush's advisors are trying to come up with a plan such a federal incentives for states that adopt civics education. I thought that Gov. Bush might be interested in hearing about See America First...especially if participation could result in better citizens AND federal incentives.
 
Just to give you few updates..we will soon be a Foundation under National Heritage Foundation, we are also forming a strategic alliance with yourhomework.com.  The best part of that is we will have a full page on their website devoted to our Fostering Awareness program.  We have endorsement letters from the State of Massachusetts and would love to replicate this program for the benefit of kids in foster care in Florida.  Our first Fostering Awareness program is scheduled for July and then is expected to run on a monthly basis.
 
Jack has taken on a project that is close to my heart and I had to put on the back burner due to "not enough hours in the day"...This other program we are developing is for kids that are "aged out" of foster care and have been accepted to community college...but can't attend because they have no housing and no family!  Can you imagine...these kids are supported through their teen years and then they just fall off when they are 18 because their is no affordable housing?  So Jack is looking into a program where we will buy multiple family dwellings in communities surrounding community colleges and offer housing to these kids.  The State Outreach Workers supervise the kids and the State pays for their living expenses.  The kids are incentivized to do well and stay in school because they have about 200 applicants waiting for their spot.   It is a great investment in these kids....
 
Ok...didn't mean to get into all of that...Bottom line is we would love contact with anyone in the Bush Administration that could assist us in becoming part of the plan for civics education.. I would love for Gov. Bush Bush to also be aware of what we are planning to accomplish with See America First and Fostering Awareness.  The website has been updated and gives a bit better picture of what we are doing...
 
Talk to you soon!
 
Janet

----- Forwarded by Kathleen Kearney/D20/DCF on 05/16/02 10:32 AM -----
                                                                                            
                    Larry                                                                   
                    Pintacuda            To:     jeb@jeb.org                                
                                         cc:     Kathleen Kearney/D20/DCF@DCF,              
                    05/16/02 09:55        laura.branker@myflorida.com, Mike                 
                    AM                    Watkins/D20/DCF@DCF                               
                                         Subject:     Update on Pinellas County Foster      
                                          Child                                             
                                                                                            



This email is from Mike Watkins at the request of Laura Branker.

* Stefani continues to be under the case management of Family Continuity
Program.

* Stefani's placement with Paula Kaminski (19 year old friend) was approved
on May 9th by Family Continuity.

* On Tuesday night May 14th, Family Continuity filed a motion to "pick-up"
Stefani due to her threats of running away.  Stefani made these threats
after being presented with a plan to place her into a residential group
care setting (SB1214) in order for her to be successfully transitioned into
independent living.

* On May 15th, Stefani requested and was granted a hearing before Judge
Sullivan to be declared an adult.  Judge Sullivan deferred his ruling on
Stefani's request and  scheduled a hearing for June 12, 2002.   He also
approved continued placement with Paula Kaminski and ordered Stefani to
complete her last 3 weeks of school at Tarpon Springs High School where she
is currently a junior.  The judge agreed that a residential group care
placement should be pursued for Stefani as long as she remains at Tarpon
Springs High School.

* The school reports that Stefani is "progressing and is on target".

* Stefani will be 17 years old next month.

----- Original Message ----- 
From: Governor Jeb  <mailto:jeb.bush@myflorida.com> Bush 
To: jeb.bush@myflorida.com 
Sent: Wednesday, May 15, 2002 5:10 PM
Subject: GOVERNOR BUSH'S SIGNING OF CS/SB 520


MEMORANDUM


 

 

FROM:    THE EXECUTIVE OFFICE OF THE GOVERNOR

 


DATE:     WEDNESDAY, MAY 15, 2002


 

RE:          GOVERNOR BUSH'S SIGNING OF CS/SB 520

 

Florida's driver licenses and identification cards will be more secure because of a bill that Gov. Jeb Bush signed into law today.  The bill (CS/SB 520) establishes penalties for knowingly selling, manufacturing, or delivering - or offering to sell, manufacture or deliver - any "blank, forged, stolen, fictitious, counterfeit, or unlawfully issued" driver license or identification card.

 

The bill also codifies changes made in response to Executive Order 2001-300, which Governor Bush signed on October 11, 2001 in response to the September 11th terrorist attacks.  These changes include a provision that the Florida driver licenses and identification cards of non-U.S. citizens whose stay in Florida is temporary will generally expire when their U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service documents expire.

 

The new law does not affect the 1999 statute requiring all applicants for a Florida driver license or identification card to provide documentary proof of their legal presence in the United States when such proof has not been previously established.

 

However, the Department of Highway Safety and Motor Vehicles, in concert with the Governor, has initiated an outreach program to address the concerns of non-U.S. citizens.  Informative brochures in English, Spanish, and Haitian Creole have been prepared. They offer details concerning the documents required to obtain a license or ID card.  Acceptable documents include those indicating that license applicants have submitted information to the INS and are awaiting a determination of their status.  Such applicants may be entitled to a two-year license.  

 

 The department also has hired a Miami-based liaison to Florida's Hispanic community. One of his goals is to dispel misunderstandings.  For instance, driver license examiners do not seize and keep valid immigration documents, nor do they summon the INS for the purpose of arresting non-U.S. citizens. Rather, the examiners briefly take custody of the documents for the purpose of making copies, after which the documents are returned.

 

Governor Bush's statement on the signing of CS/SB 520 is attached for your information.

 

Thank you.

 

May 15, 2002

 

 

The Honorable Katherine Harris

Secretary of State

PL 02, The Capitol

Tallahassee, Florida 32399

 

Dear Secretary Harris:

 

I hereby transmit to you, with my signature, Committee Substitute for Senate Bill 520, setting forth requirements to obtain a Florida driver's license or identification card and prohibiting the manufacturing or sale of fake or stolen driver's licenses or identification cards.

 

Committee Substitute for Senate Bill 520 continues important efforts to clearly identify the documents individuals can use to obtain a driver's license or identification card and the length of time the license will be valid.  This legislation, in fact, adds to the existing list of acceptable documents in an effort to protect those individuals that have come to Florida for legitimate purposes.

 

This legislation also contains provisions which will close a loophole in current law and make it illegal for anyone to knowingly manufacture, sell or deliver a fake or stolen driver's license or identification card, another important step toward ensuring the citizens of this state and nation are protected.

 

A driver's license is much more than merely a means to individual travel.  Driver's licenses are accepted across the United States as a primary form of identification and a passport to many of the things that make up our modern lifestyle - major purchases, automobile rentals and apartment rentals.

 

The tragic events of September 11, 2001, and the ensuing investigations into the backgrounds of the individuals involved in the terrorist attacks underscored the need to continually review and adapt Florida laws concerning the type of documents used to obtain a driver's license or identification card and the length of time a license should be made available to certain non-citizens of Florida. 

 

Immediately after the September 11 attacks, I appointed a taskforce to review security issues in this state.  The Taskforce on Domestic Security, led by Commissioner Tim Moore, Director of the Florida Department of Law Enforcement (FDLE), made the following recommendations concerning Florida's licenses and identification cards:

 

*	Implement measures to eliminate the inadvertent issuance of fraudulent driver's licenses.  


*	Enhance the driver's license issuance process to ensure reliability and validation of identity. 


*	Acquire equipment for driver's license issuance to create a record of companion documents used to establish identity.  


*	Provide a high level of identity security and enhance the forensics aspects of investigative activities through use of layered biometrics technology, such as facial recognition, fingerprint and iris scanning. 

Unfortunately, some misunderstandings have arisen concerning the impact this legislation will have on Florida's immigrant community.  Some say this bill ties legal presence to licensure eligibility for the first time.  This is not true.  For several years now, Florida law has required legal presence in the United States.  Since 1999, Florida law has named the specific documents that must be presented when applying for a driver's license or identification card for the first time -- a certified copy of a United States birth certificate, a valid United States passport, an alien registration receipt card (green card), an employment authorization card issued by the United States Department of Justice, or proof of nonimmigrant classification provided by the United States Department of Justice.  Additional requirements went into effect in December 2001, to implement the recommendations of the Taskforce on Domestic Security.  These requirements limited the time a driver's license is valid to coincide with the expiration of INS documentation.

 

I believe this bill establishes reasonable and necessary requirements for issuing licenses and identification cards in this state.  I am committed to ensuring that those in Florida's immigrant community are fully informed about the new requirements so that this law does not place an undue hardship on individuals seeking proper identification.  The Department of Highway Safety and Motor Vehicles has conducted a number of document verification seminars and trained 480 managers and driver's license examiners to be able to carry out the new requirements in a courteous, respectful and professional manner.  To strengthen our ongoing outreach efforts, the department has employed a coordinator who will serve as the state's Hispanic and immigrant community liaison on this issue.  

 

Florida has a rich and diverse culture.  It is a strength more critical to our common future than even our healthy climate and world-famous beaches.  People of all nationalities come to Florida for the beauty, but they stay because of the richness of our culture and the opportunity Floridians share to build a future together.  As you know, my family reflects the ethnic diversity we all cherish, so I understand the great sensitivity that many Floridians share about issues relating to documentation.

 

The strong justifications for this bill notwithstanding, I am aware of the possibility that this bill may have unintended consequences for individuals who have had licenses for many years but may be unable to renew them under this law.  I encourage the Legislature and the department to monitor this new law and consider the possibility of follow-up legislation next session.  Although Senate Bill 520 allows the granting of license privileges to individuals who have residency applications pending before the INS, further legislation may be needed to resolve unintended problems arising from this bill.  

 

Although I am sensitive to the concerns raised about this legislation, I fully believe these measures are appropriate and necessary.  I am confident that the Department of Highway Safety and Motor Vehicles will make it a priority to work with Florida's communities on the new requirements contained in this legislation.  

 

For the reasons set forth above, I hereby sign Committee Substitute for Senate Bill 520.

 

                        Sincerely,

                        Jeb Bush

 Wednesday, May 15, 2002 

Last modified at 9:37 p.m. on Tuesday, May 14, 2002
LEGISLATURE: Well done





Monday, the Florida Legislature wrapped up its work for the year. It was an 
impressive showing.

Lawmakers had their work cut out for them. A mild recession had caused a 
budget setback earlier. The realignment of legislative and congressional 
seats that is required every 10 years was due.

Even though Republicans control both houses, Senate President John McKay set 
off on his own course this year, determined to totally revamp the state's tax 
structure and build in huge revenue increases for the future. When his plan 
did not fly, McKay impeded other legislation until he got a sop for his 
wounded feelings. It took leadership by Gov. Jeb Bush, incoming Senate 
President Jim King and House Speaker Tom Feeney to restore order, although 
McKay got in the last shot by killing the tax holiday for shoppers next year.

Still, the Legislature managed to do redistricting in record time, with 
fairly drawn boundaries for the most part.

It also was able to enact a $50.4 billion budget for the coming year that 
included $262 million in temporary tax relief for business to help stimulate 
the state's economic activity.

Since 1998, Bush and the Legislature have enacted $6 billion in tax relief, 
rolling back the tax increases of the previous eight years. Taxes have been 
reduced as a percent of personal income from 6.4 percent in 1998-99 to less 
than 6 percent in 2002-03.

One of the major accomplishments was a human resources outsourcing proposal 
that will produce an estimated $173 million savings by providing private 
sector contracts for personnel services. 

Providing prescription drug coverage for Medicaid-eligible elderly residents 
of the state, funding for the governor's statewide reading initiative and 
legislation to preserve the state's environment by providing guidelines for 
managing growth were among other accomplish- ments.

In addition, the Legislature finished restructuring the Cabinet, revamped the 
entire education code and increased school funding by 6 percent.

Even chronic complainers will have difficulty faulting the Legislature for 
its work this year under difficult conditions.

Most written communications to or from state officials
regarding state business are public records available to the
public and media upon request.   Your e-mail communications
may therefore be subject to public disclosure. 
-----Original Message-----
From: Garrett, Allen [mailto:allen.garrett@scantibodies.com]
Sent: Wednesday, May 15, 2002 10:09 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: TCantor; Van Duzer, John; Sharp, Janet; Baker, Donald
Subject: Self-Referring Dialysis Chains


Dear Governor Bush
 
I am president and CEO of the largest privately held Biotech Company in San Diego, California, Scantibodies Clinical Laboratory.  We have 385 employees and manufacture First Response, the nation's leading over the counter pregnancy test.  We have also discovered a new hormone which is the inhibitor of PTH.  PTH is a critical measurement for the lives of renal dialysis patients.
 
We perform routine dialysis blood testing in Florida and we are licensed to do this testing for dialysis patients in Florida.  We are the only lab that offers the testing of both PTH and its inhibitor.  This testing of dialysis patients helps them to avoid being unnecessarily treated with vitamin D.  This treatment not only doubles the cost to Florida Medicaid unnecessarily, but more importantly, leads Florida dialysis patients to develop the key life threatening disease that cripples their lives, soft tissue calcification.
 
Our Florida sales force has been blocked continually from being able to offer these tests in Florida by the large dialysis chains of Fresenius, Gambro and Davita.  Medical Directors at these dialysis units have been threatened with a decrease in finances paid to them if they allow blood samples (which have been requested by nephrologists treating Florida dialysis patients) to be sent to labs other than Fresenius, Gambro and Davita.  I would like to share more details with you if you would find it useful.
 
For the sake of the Florida dialysis patients and the nephrologists in Florida I urge you to break the power of self serving dialysis chains by passing the bill that would bar them from controlling the stream of blood samples to their own labs by voting to pass the bill approved by the Senate and House of Representatives.
 
Thank you,
 
Tom Cantor
President 
Scantibodies Laboratory
 
Allen Garrett
allen.garrett@scantibodies.com
Scantibodies Laboratory Inc.
9336 Abraham Way
Santee, CA 92071
(619) 258-9300 x 461
(619) 200-4067 cell
(619) 258-9366 fax
www.scantibodies.com

-----Original Message-----
From: CDEAlliance [mailto:kids@cdealliance.org]
Sent: Wednesday, May 15, 2002 10:16 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Fw: School Readiness


Dear Gov. Bush,
 
In case Katherine failed to forward Butch Cronon's response to Dr. Rodger's letter to you, I am sending it.  As chair of the rules committee, I would like confirmation that we are indeed proceeding in the direction of the statue.  Judge Carney appeared before the Partnership Board recently and carefully explained that to continue to draw down federal funds, we should be very careful to prioritize working families.  
 
In the proposed rule, we have defined "Working Family" as :
20 (a)  A single parent family in which the parent with whom the child resides is employed a minimum of 20 hours per week.
 
(b)  A two parent family in which both parents with whom the child resides ar employed a minimum of 20 hours per week.
 
(c)  A family with whom the child resides and in which parental work requirements are not met due to disability, as determined and documented by a physician licensed under Chapters 458 or 459, Florida Statues.  Eligible educational activities, as defined herein, may be substituted for required hours of employment on an hourly basis.
 
Under "Eligibility", we have stated:
xxA-1.004  Eligibility for children in working families whose income does not exceed 150 percent of the federal poverty level.
    Within the eligibility category established by S. 411.01(6)(a)(3);Florida Statues,
 
        (1)  "Working families," as defined by rule will be given priority for children in this eligibility category.  
 
        (2)  Coalitions may use "other funds," as defined by rule, whose children are determined to be at hgih risk of school failure, to the greatest extent possible.  Eligivility under this provision does not eliminate the requirement that family income not exceed 150 percent of the federal poverty level.
 
The word "priority" is the key word here.  Nothing prohibits them from serving other children once they have served single parent families with one parent working, two parent homes where both are working, and families who are disabled.
 
Because I was present at the conference that Dr. Nanette Rodgers presided over this spring, I humbly suggest you may want to send her a reply instead of the Partnership Board.  I guess it is in keeping with the principle of "doing good to those who wrongfully hurt you" that prompts me to suggest this.  Dr. Rodgers perpetuated your letter of regrets (of your inavailability to attend her conference) to be read with slur and sarcasim, to which an audience of about 500 booed you.  I know you would like to see her turn her opinion around, if at all possible. 
 
This may give you an opportunity to open the door of caring about her needs, by explaining the above statues and principles upon which we are trying to write rule.  In the meantime, if we have misinterpreted, please let us know.  Our next rules meeting is Monday, May 20.  I have a lot of work to do in very litte time if we are not proceeding down the right path.  Thank you for your kind attention to this matter.  
 
Sincerely,
Ellen McKinley 
 
 
----- Original Message ----- 
From: Butch@handnhand.org 
To: Kamiya, Katherine <mailto:Katherine.Kamiya@MyFlorida.com>  ; kids@cdealliance.org ; RodneyLeeK@aol.com ; jfkirtley@fcpinestors.com 
Cc: Jones, Molly <mailto:Molly.Jones@MyFlorida.com>  ; kmorton@unr2.net 
Sent: Tuesday, May 14, 2002 10:15 AM
Subject: RE: School Readiness

Katherine, I would hope you, as Executive Director ,will respond to the E-mail from Dr. Rodgers outlining the statutorily mandated parameters in s.411.01. The Legislature in the "Intent" section defines the precepts for readiness, s.411.01(2)a..." It is the intent of the Legislature that such programs be developmentally appropriate,research-based, Involve parents as their child's first teacher, serve as a preventive measure for children at risk of school failure"....
 
s.411.01(2)b...."It is the intent of the Legislature that school readiness programs be operated on a full-day, year round basis to the maximum extent possible to enable parents to work and become financially self sufficient.
 
 
s.411.01(2)f...."It is the intent of the Legislature that the school readiness program coordinate and operate in conjunction with the district school systems. However,It is also the intent of the Legislature the school readiness not be construed as part of the free public schools but rather as a separate program for children under the age of Kindergarten".....
 
 
s.411.01(3)b...."Nothing contained in this act is intended: 1.Relieve parents and guardians of their own obligations to ready their children for school; or".....
 
Dr.Rodgers points out the commendable efforts the Polk county school district has expended in preparing children for school and hopefully the district will continue to be part of the readiness equation. However, when we have such limited resources, why would we want to usurp the parental responsibility of stay at home parents to prepare children for school. Many families can not take jobs, so they can become self sufficient, because of limited resources, their children are on waiting lists Dr, Rodgers seems to suggest we just let those families stay on waiting list and allow the school district to maintain the status quo with school readiness and let stay at home parents enroll their children in school based programs. Readiness has two main purposes, First to help parents prepare their children for school and secondly, to help families become self sufficient. As an aside you might recall the Board discussion regarding this issue and the comments by both Senator Jennings an Deputy Director Hattie pointing out the need to focus on working families and self sufficiency when our resources are limited
 
Dr. Rodgers may wish to work with the readiness coalition in developing a out reach effort to help assist stay at home parents in readiness activities. $500,000 could fund many excellent developmentally appropriate teaching aids along with in home visits to assist stay at home parents.
 Dr. Rodgers suggestion that we have a transition year is surprising since we have had two transition years already. Perhaps a more intensified effort to work collective with the local coalition would ease this change for those who want to maintain the status quo.  
Thank you, Butch

[Butch@handnhand.org]

-----Original Message-----
From: nanette rodgers [mailto:nanetter@tampabay.rr.com]
Sent: Saturday, May 11, 2002 12:33 AM
To: fl_governor@myflorida.com
Cc: jim.thornhill@polk-fl.net
Subject: School Readiness

Dear Governor Bush,

 

 The  Reading First Initiative will be discussed at the Polk County  School Readiness Enhancements Committee meeting on May 14th. We are involved in a HUBS Project with the University of South Florida to empower parents to be their child's first teacher. 

 

I am concerned with Chapter  411 and the writing of the Rules that determine "eligibility for school readiness" programs. Please note in 411:   (6) Eligible children before kindergarten 3 (a) economically disadvantaged. It does not mention that two parents have to be working.  As I understand it, the definition of "economically disadvantaged" does not indicate that both parents have to be working. 

 

Moving from DOE PreK programs to Workforce Innovation and  combining subsidized child care with PreK, we may not be allowed to serve children we now serve in the  Polk County School System school readiness program because both parents have to work and be at least 150% of the poverty level.  

 

 I think we should continue to require that at least one parent work and not require that both parents work as long as they are economically disadvantaged, meet the 150% requirement and pay a sliding scale parent fee. We have collected over $500,000 to reinvest in the program with quality enhancements for the children. Holiday care and summer school care are two of the enhancements.

 

 

 If we do move in this direction, requiring that both parents work, we should be given time to implement the new initiative. If we change the now existing rule, 64% of our 1100 eligible children  in Polk County Schools'  school readiness programs will not meet the new eligibility requirements. We have had different PreK Early Intervention rules with DOE through the years. 

 

I believe we will have a large number of now eligible children in the state that will not be served and will not be ready for school. Could we initiate a PreK School Readiness Category in this transition year and evaluate this designation throughout  the 2002-2003 school year? 

 

Secretary Jim Horne stated in a directive recently to all school superintendents that he wants public schools to stay involved in the universality of all early education and care in Florida.  Please help us serve "economically disadvantaged' children regardless of  whether one or two parents are working.

 

 You are invited to visit our PreK programs in Polk County. We are pleased with our curriculum and other aspects of our program. Please check out our website: www.pcsb.k12.fl.us/prek and click on the "light bulb" icon. Is Your Child Ready For School "puppy dog" icon has received many hits around the nation. Please let us know what you think about the curriculum. We have correlated it to the  Sunshine State Standards, Core Knowledge and Polk County Standards.

 

 

Polk County Schools implement  57 public school PreK Early Intervention,Migrant PreK sites and 17 contracted child care center sites. We are planning to add 10 additional public school classes next year at the request of Superintendent Jim Thornhill and the School Board, if we can work out the "working parent" situation. We believe in partnering with our local child care providers. They contract with us for the 10 hour day and extended day and year care. 

 

We were pleased that you read at Family Fundamentals in Lakeland recently. We appreciate your efforts on behalf of all Florida's youngest citizens and their families.

 

Cordially, 

Nanette N. Rodgers Ed.D

Supervisor Child Care Services/PreK

Polk County Schools

-----Original Message-----
From: WinMarB@aol.com [mailto:WinMarB@aol.com]
Sent: Wednesday, May 15, 2002 11:02 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Funding for Citizen Review Programs, 39.702 FS


Governor Bush, 

Please support continuation funding for Florida's citizen review panels, as outlined in 39.702 FS.  These programs utilize trained, community volunteers to review the cases of abused and neglected children under court supervision.  Not only does this increase the amount of time the circuit court has to address other issues before the court, citizen review engages the community to find local solutions to crisis situations within their own community.  Additional federal dollars can be leveraged by using citizen review panels.  Utilization of circuit judges and/or general masters cannot be used for the state to remain eligible for the additional federal dollars.   

With the recent tragic events of Rilya and so many other innocent children, Florida must do all it can to help prevent additional sadness.  Take a stand to do that and preserve continuation funding for citizen review programs. 

Sincerely, 
Marcie Bailey

From: PRINGLE CLARENCE [mailto:pringleclan@msn.com]

Subject: For all children in Florida, please step in.


Jeb,
I know you do read my emails, I have tried not to be a pest this year. I am VERY concerned about Joey's situation for all children in Florida with special needs. Do you know that in deed his IEP states he will graduate May 2002 and his grades are scored in the A/B range? More frightening is- did you know he can only write his name? He can trace his address and phone number if you do the dashes or dot to dot. He can not read. This frightens me terribly as a parent of special needs children. I know we are fighting for inclusion education while our children are young and Kaitlyn being 7 with Downs is reading this year. She can write her name and by 18 will write a whole lot more. Please see this is not a school that educated or will educate a boy if he stays another year. This dear child fell through the cracks a long time ago. We need to use this time to educate the public that "now" children with Down Syndrome are being educated and yes they deserve to graduate. However we agree the diploma is not the same, their continued education won't be the same either but I do want my children to have the availability for continued education. 
I was thrilled when I heard other classmates stood up for Joey, I expect that for my children if ever a situation arises. I want to believe that in 2002 and beyond the fear of being friends with a child with a disability is gone. We have come a long way in America with women, the minority and now the disabled, please Jeb, step in with this school and help them undeerstand that pride can not blind them to the right decision, it is doing more damange for all Florida, than good. Educate everyone in the school about disabilities and inclusion- it is not a classroom, like many of the schools are treating it--it is the thoughts/concept and way we live our lives. We need to include all children right now regardless if everyone failed them, today is the time for change. Joey made it with what was presented to him. Yes, we wish it were more but it wasn't. If he were to stay until he was 22 would it help? probably not, children with Down Syndrome learn best 0-10years proven in Jacksonville at Hope Haven. This needs to be the beginning of the Public schools admitting they failed too. Lets make the changes and forget our pride, it is for the FUTURE of all children in the school system with disabilities not "Joey."
My heart goes out to you right now with everything you are dealing with, I am praying for our children in Florida and all those involved. 
Sincerely,
Mary Pringle

-----Original Message-----
From: Brantley, Michelle K. <brantlem@fdhc.state.fl.us>
To: Jeb Bush <jeb@jeb.org>; 'branker@myflorida.com' <Larry_Pintacuda@dcf.state.fl.us:Laura.>; 'Larry_Pintacuda@dcf.state.fl.us' <Larry_Pintacuda@dcf.state.fl.us>
Sent: Thu May 16 16:20:21 2002
Subject: RE: Follow up : our daughter Cynthia Szuka needs your help

FYI. The Children's Medical Assessment Interdisciplinary Team (CMAT)met
today. In attendance was the Client Cynthia Szuka, and both parents.  The
team did not agree on the need for some parts of the chair i.e. the Stander
and automated seat. A letter from Dr. Baynham presented to the team stated
the following:

"PATIENTS WHEELCHAIR WILL NOT NEED THE "STANDING" CAPACITY NOR AUTOMATED
SEAT THAT RAISES PATIENT.  THIS PATIENT ALREADY HAS A STANDER & DUPLICATION
OF THIS IS NOT MEDICALLY NECESSARY AND PATIENT SHOULD ATTEMPT TO PULL TO
STANDING ON HER TO INCREASE STRENGTH OF ALL MUSCLE GROUPS."

The CMAT team discovered in the home visit that DD Program had previously
paid more than $4,000.00 for a stander for this patient.  Mrs. Szuka said
she would be glad to give the stander away now to a well deserving disabled
child.

The team recommended that since Cynthia is in the CMS Network, CMS approved
Vendors and Therapist should be used.  The current recommendation is that
the child be evaluated in the CMS Wheelchair clinic by the Physiatrist, the
Orthopedist with an accompanying Therapist for a team evaluation on the most
appropriate chair for Cynthia.  This will be done at the next Wheelchair
Clinic. The Mother seems satisfied and plans to cooperate. 

Please don't hesitate to contact me if you have any questions or concerns.

Shelly Brantley

FYI. A new custom wheelchair for Cynthia has essentially been approved
by
Medicaid. The only item in question is the Power Recline Stander feature
which costs $11,007.00. (Total cost of the wheelchair with this item is
$27,000. We offered to pay for the custom wheelchair without the stander
until the stander issue is resolved, but the mother did not agree. The
hesitation seems to be on the part of the therapist who we rely on to
determine medical necessity. We need to know that Cynthia will be able
to
accommodate to this new feature and /or can use it appropriately. We
also
want to make sure that it would not cause more harm than benefit (i.e.
make
sure the chair is not too heavy for her to operate safely (with her
impaired
vision), or too heavy to get onto the porch of the house etc.)We will
continue to work closely with Cynthia and her family to make sure she
receives the most appropriate wheelchair in a timely fashion.
Shelly

> > > Dear Governor Bush:
> > > We are writing on behalf of our 16 year old daughter,
> > > Cynthia, who has cerebral palsy, is visually impaired
> > > and is in crucial need of a customized wheelchair.
> > > Cynthia currently uses a wheelchair (this is her main
> > > mode of mobility). Her current chair was purchased over
> > > 6 years ago and can no longer be modified. It is small
> > > for her. It is not positioning her appropriately.
> > > Cynthia dreads having to get up everyday and put in a
> > > full day in school and other activities using a chair
> > > that constantly gives her discomfort and tremendous
> > > pain. She strives for excellence in everything she
> > > does; however it is very difficult for her to be able
> > > to concentrate in school, study, take exams, help in
> > > the community and make a positive impact in other
> > > people's lives when she is constantly battling with
> > > physical pain due to not having appropriate seating and
> > > an appropriate wheelchair.
> > >
> > > Cynthia is covered under Medicaid. In December of 2001,
> > > we had appropriately requested a new power chair. We
> > > had a Medicaid provider complete all the necessary
> > > paperwork. Cynthia's physicians and therapists provided
> > > for letters of medical necessity. Cynthia's request
> > > was, for no reason, put on hold. When I telephoned our
> > > area 9 District Office and spoke with Debbie Kahn and
> > > William Albury to find out the status of Cynthia's need;
> > > I was told that it was being processed and my telephone
> > > call was not appreciated.
> > >
> > > At the beginning of January 2002, we were advised by
> > > our provider, Home Health Equipment Services, Marty
> > > Hopek; that Medicaid was revising policies and that we
> > > would have to re-submit the request with additional
> > > information. This we did. In January 24, 2002;
> > > Cynthia's request was re-submitted with the forms and
> > > documentation requested. We were advised by our
> > > provider to give Medicaid some time for processing.
> > > This we did. On March 5th, we telephoned our provider
> > > and spoke with one of their representatives Marianne.

> > > Representative, Topaz Williams, "nothing is going
> > > through until we know what to do." We were not given a
> > > date as to when Cynthia's request would continue on the
> > > path that was begun in December for approval of the
> > > wheelchair.
> > >
> > > We have gone to other sources for information as to
> > > what is happening with Medicaid. We have learned that
> > > although equipment is being approved in other areas;
> > > the area we reside in, Palm Beach County, Area 9 is
> > > doing nothing. Requests are not being processed. No one
> > > in the Medicaid office seems to know what they are
> > > doing. No one in the Medicaid office seems to care.
> > >

From:	Nina Oviedo <oviedon@sso.org>
Sent:	Thursday, May 16, 2002 6:41 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Cc:	Donna Arduin (E-mail); Mike Hansen (E-mail); Brian Yablonski (E-mail); Frank R. Jimenez (E-mail); KaS (E-mail); 'Jill Randolph'; 'Karen Hogan'
Subject:	 Welfare Reauthorization Bill Passed in House
Attachments:	s2524.pdf

Importance:	High

This afternoon the House of Representatives passed Welfare Reauthorization (TANF), HR 4737, by a vote of 229-197, primarily along party lines.  In a related vote, the House rejected the substitute amendment offered by Rep. Cardin (D-MD).
We will send down the final version of the bill, along with a brief summary tomorrow to appropriate personnel. 
 
In the Senate, we understand that the Finance Committee will not begin consideration of a bill next week.  A committee bill has not been drafted, and mark-up of a bill in the Senate is not expected to begin until after the Memorial Day Recess. 
 
All this says-----we have some time to work go to work on concerns…Nina

From:	Florida Coalition for Disability Rights <drg@drgglobal.com>
Sent:	Thursday, May 16, 2002 10:04 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	THE TRANSPORTATION DISADVANTAGED MATTER

For Immediate Release:
May 16, 2002

Contact:
Doug Towne
727-578-4440

THE TRANSPORTATION DISADVANTAGED MATTER
     The Florida Coalition for Disability Rights (FCDR) whose mission is to advance the human and civil rights of people with disabilities to ensure full and equal participation in all aspects of community life and the political process, is taking a stand in support of Transportation Disadvantaged (TD) legislation. It is a fully cross disability and statewide coalition that works to bring about clarity of purpose, understanding of disability issues and the collective facilitation of solutions. 
     The Pending legislation, which is now awaiting Governor Bush's signature, would take action to provide an annual place in the state's budget for funding the TD program. This has long been a goal of the combined TD constituent communities. 
     A more controversial part of the legislation would permanently remove Orlando's tri-county Transportation Authority's status as the Community Transportation Coordinator (CTC). Known as Links, the Authority has held the position as the CTC for many years. 
     During its tenure it has been subjected to much criticism and accusations. Until about a year ago most of these criticisms went unremedied. The locally owned and operated transportation providers working under contract to Links responded to some of the criticism aimed at them with calls for adequate funding so the kind of service being requested could be afforded by the providers. These requests were repeatedly denied while the complaints continued to build. 
     After a study of the situation, local political will seemed to fall in behind the idea that a proper job needed to be done for the TD and Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) paratransit services. Links finally would move in the right direction if they had the time. Putting out a request for participation, Links shocked many when it selected a single out of state company as the new transportation provider at a rate that amounts to a 76% increase.  This rate was similar to what was requested by the local providers over many years. To add insult to injury the choice of this single out of state company immediately began to put local providers out of business. By this time the complaints had built to a political crescendo and gained the attention of Speaker Tom Feeny and others in the legislature. Links intended changes were viewed by many as too little too late. 
     Seeing the opportunity to remedy the problem of complaints about Links and provide an annual commitment for funding the TD program through Senate Bill 100, members of the Florida legislature amended the bill to accomplish this. FCDR's executive committee is certainly sensitive to the concerns of the local community and the feelings expressed by some who feel that their right to choose has been preempted. However, when considering the issue on a statewide prospective it came to the conclusion that the legislation accomplishes several things. 
     First, it clearly sends the message to all transportation authorities in the state that if they fail to listen to the complaints of the TD and ADA communities they too may face a day of reckoning with Florida Lawmakers. Lawmakers who have proven their willingness to act to protect the rights of these populations. FCDR endorses this message and wishes to bring it strongly to the attention of systems in the state, which have troubled historical records where their relationships with these communities are concerned. The executive committee recommends that each transportation authority, CTC, and provider of services under TD and ADA programs carefully examine their relationship with their constituent communities and take actions to rectify any issues before similar legislative remedies are sought where they are concerned. 
     The second accomplishment embodied in the legislation will give the TD community comfort in knowing that each year the budget will include funding for the program. However, the FCDR executive committee is deeply concerned that the legislation does not specify the amount of this required funding. 
     Perhaps even more troubling is the dramatic rise in rates approved by Links. Such a 76% increase would not only wipe out any effective expansion of funding but could possibly increase the number of denied trips a year instead of providing more trips. This prospect is deeply troubling to FCDR's members and for this reason the Board will take up the question of the condition of the state of TD and ADA transportation programs in Florida at its next full meeting. There are many issues statewide not the least of which is that there is little rhyme or reason to the pricing of trips, no uniform standards, and little teeth in the current law to force change at the local level.  In the case of Links local government seems to be responding to a problem by throwing money at it without due consideration of the consequences. FCDR is not arguing against increased rates but is concerned that such a dramatic increase is either an overreaction to the troubles of a failed system or that the system statewide is so drastically under-funded that a review is not only necessary but vital to the welfare of Floridians who use these programs. To answer these questions, The FCDR Board will consider adopting a plan to inquire into the state of the TD and ADA transit systems in Florida. “The transportation problems faced by the disabled community in Florida are so concerning that it may be the next area the Board wishes to concentrate on," stated Douglas Towne, FCDR's Vice President. The last such decision to inquire, brought about landmark voting reform legislation passed this session. 
     FCDR's Executive Committee wishes to recommend to the Governor that he sign Senate Bill 100 into law and with apologies to the local community recommends that advocates work to ensure that the new CTC remain sensitive to the communities needs and complaints. It commends local advocates for speaking out, and local transportation providers for raising their concerns about the dramatic increases in cost. Furthermore it thanks Florida's legislature for acting to remedy the problem and send the message to others in the state that the concerns and complaints of Floridians who use and have a right to these programs had better not be ignored. FCDR's President, Chris Wagner, stated "The Board is committed to assure that the disabled community has full access, especially  transportation and we must make sure there is some compromise between our community and the Legislature to provide that full access."


###

From:	Jimenez, Frank <Frank.Jimenez@MyFlorida.com>
Sent:	Thursday, May 16, 2002 8:19 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	RE: dbpr search engine in real estate!

Mr. Fischer's first e-mail was acted upon by DBPR.  This is what they did:
"Dear Mr. Fischer:

Thank you again for your comments about the DBPR Online Services website. In your last email you indicated that you had problems locating some licensee's information, including yourself. I am happy to report that we have taken these comments and acted on them. Beginning the first part of June we are launching a new public search page that will provide the following new features: (1) The ability to search by just an individual's last name and board, (2) the ability to perform a "similar name" search that will allow you to search on a last name like Robert and get Robert, Robertsons, Roberts, etc. and (3) the ability to search by a board such as Real Estate or Appraisers.  Your other point about the ability to search by county has not been forgotten. We are currently gathering additional requirements for our next release, which we will be launching in late summer. The ability to search by county will be included in this change.  We appreciate your continued patience as the Department continues down the path of improved customer service. Your feedback is invaluable to making the DBPR Online Services website a success and we hope that you feel that we have taken your comments to heart and responded with something to better met your needs."

DBPR is taking a look at the new issue raised in the second e-mail below (searching by name instead of by number).  I will make sure that if it can be done, it will be done.  DBPR is being responsive, but I'm not sure Mr. Fischer will be completely satisfied unless we revert to the old-fashioned system he's used to.

From:	Mike Chap <chapsieml@hotmail.com>
Sent:	Thursday, May 16, 2002 8:36 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Technology help is here!

Brother Jeb,

-----Original Message-----
From: Gates, Lisa [mailto:Lisa.Gates@MyFlorida.com]
Sent: Thursday, May 16, 2002 4:17 PM
Subject: budget difficulties confronting other states


Katie Muniz, communications director for Governor Bush wanted me to share
the below interesting article to provide context for the budget difficulties
confronting other states.  Because the Governor and Legislature addressed
any potential negative impact to our state's budget early, we avoided what
other states are now facing.  As a result, we were able to increase
education funding by $1.1 billion, double the funding for child welfare
services, fund a prescription drug program for low-income seniors and
continue support for restoration of the Everglades.
Lisa Gates, deputy press secretary

May 16, 2002
States' Vast Budget Gaps Bring Higher Fees and Emergency Cuts
By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM
INDIANAPOLIS, May 15 - Faced with a large, unexpected drop in income-tax
revenue, states across the country are trying desperately to plug wide
budget gaps in ways voters can abide in an election year.
Some are raising cigarette taxes and various fees. Some are cutting spending
on the edges or using bookkeeping devices to make the deficits go away. A
few have taken drastic measures to avoid raising sales or income taxes or
cutting popular programs like education.
Missouri, for example, is so short of cash that it has stopped sending out
income-tax refunds. More than 400,000 taxpayers who filed returns on their
2001 income are owed nearly $170 million. Officials promise that the refunds
will be mailed when the state's cash flow improves.
Wisconsin is considering issuing bonds secured by the 30 years of annual
payments from the national settlement with tobacco companies. The effect
would be to spend all 30 years of the state's share of the tobacco money
this year and next.
The National Conference of State Legislatures reported last month that at
least 40 states and the District of Columbia were being forced this year to
make emergency cuts in their budgets totaling $27 billion. 
Like other states, New York has had a serious shortfall in revenue - $1.2
billion less in April tax receipts than had been expected - largely because
weakness in the stock market has resulted in smaller receipts from the
capital gains tax. 
But New York is in better shape than most others because during the fat
years, Gov. George E. Pataki squirreled away as much as $4 billion. He can
now draw on that as he begins his race for re-election. In his latest
budget, he sought increased spending on popular programs and avoided
proposing a repeal of tax cuts set to take effect this year.
Still, the final budget on which New York legislative leaders wrapped up
negotiations today does include increased fees or new surcharges on a
variety of products and state services, and an expansion of the state
cigarette tax to include cigars and chewing tobacco.
Circumstances here in Indiana are more severe, and more typical. Just three
years ago, the state was sitting on a $2 billion surplus, about 10 percent
of the whole state budget. Feeling flush, Gov. Frank L. O'Bannon and the
legislature approved deep tax cuts and undertook an ambitious plan to raise
school standards.
But times changed almost overnight. Indiana's deficit is now more than $1
billion, and the figure seems to grow with each recalculation. So this week,
irritable at having to leave their jobs and families, and pessimistic about
being able to resolve the crisis, legislators began meeting here in a rare
special session.
Nowhere is the situation more dire than in California. On Tuesday, Gov. Gray
Davis proposed closing a shortfall of $23.6 billion, one-third of the entire
budget, by raising vehicle license fees and cigarette taxes and making steep
reductions in health programs and aid to local governments.
The details of the problem and the solutions that officeholders are
considering vary by state, but the basics are the same.
In the prosperity of the late 1990's, the states acted as if good times
would always roll, slashing taxes for individuals and businesses and
spending with abandon.
When the economy turned sour, revenue fell sharply, higher spending was
locked into place, and the states, most of them required by their
constitutions to run balanced budgets, found themselves in deep holes.
The problem is complicated by the elections this fall. Budget-cutting
invariably requires bitter medicine, and few politicians are willing to risk
re-election to administer it.
"In an election year," said Governor O'Bannon, who called the special
session here, "you always get political policy mixed up with public policy."
New Jersey has one of the worst deficits of any state in percentage terms,
12 percent of the total budget, according to calculations by the conference
of state legislatures. But New Jersey holds its elections for state offices
in odd-numbered years, and that has eased the pressure on the new governor,
James E. McGreevey. He is reducing the budgets of state agencies by 5
percent and cutting back on construction and maintenance projects.
Connecticut has managed to control its deficit with a 61-cent-a-pack
increase in cigarette taxes, to $1.11 from 50 cents.
North Carolina raised income and sales taxes last year, but it is an
exception. Few states are using general tax increases to try to recoup the
$35 billion in tax cuts that were enacted in the eight years ended in 2000.
Spending reductions have been imposed almost everywhere. The conference of
state legislatures reported that 17 states had cut aid to elementary and
secondary education, or might do so. That aid is a big part of the budget in
all states but usually one of the last places politicians look to save
money.
Twenty-nine states are considering cuts in higher education, 25 in prisons
and 22 in Medicaid, the conference found. At least 10 may lay off state
employees.
But to a large extent, said Don Boyd, director of the Fiscal Studies Program
at the Rockefeller Institute in Albany, states are resorting to gimmicks and
procrastination, trying to sweep as much dust as possible under the rug and
hoping that good times will return quickly and close the budget gap
painlessly.
That is certainly the tendency here in Indiana. The only revenue increases
even under consideration involve more gambling receipts and higher cigarette
taxes. Governor O'Bannon has set aside some of his most ambitious plans,
like state aid for preschool programs, but most of the cuts so far have
involved bookkeeping devices like transfers from trust funds to the general
fund and a reduction in emergency reserves. 
"The political will is not there to do what is necessary," said William J.
Sheldrake, president of the Indiana Fiscal Policy Institute, a nonpartisan
research center. 
Most authorities doubt that Indiana or other states will return soon to a
time of plenty, given two serious structural problems. 
The first is that services, the dominant element of the economy in most
states, are not taxed. For years, Florida, among other states, has
considered taxing services, from haircuts to golf lessons, but those
proposals have never gone far and are not likely to now.
The other structural problem is the huge rise in health expenditures, in
large part a result of ever higher drug costs. Health care now accounts for
27 percent of all state spending, said Ray Scheppach, executive director of
the National Governors' Association.
As the legislature convened here in Indianapolis on Tuesday, lobbyists were
out in force, but the lawmakers' mood was grim. Governor O'Bannon, a
Democrat, has said that if the legislature does not act in the special
session, he will be forced to cut spending for education and other popular
programs on his own and seek new sources of revenue. But he is not the kind
of governor who strikes fear in his opponents, said Brian Howey, who
publishes a nonpartisan political newsletter.
The Indiana House is controlled by Democrats, but the Senate by Republicans,
and the chances of reaching a bipartisan agreement are remote, most
lawmakers say.
"No question we're going to have a tough time getting anything worked out,"
said Representative William C. Cochran, a Democrat from the southeastern
part of the state.
Representative Daniel A. Dumezich, a Republican from a suburb of Chicago and
a tax lawyer, agreed. Like many others, he said the special session was "a
major inconvenience" for the part-time lawmakers, who are paid $112 a day
when they are in session and whose regular session ended for the year in
March.
"I have a real job I have to attend to," he said.
