-----Original Message-----
From: Sandy Faulkner  [mailto:sfaulk@tampabay.rr.com]
Sent: Thursday, May 16, 2002 8:44  AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Continuning Department of Children  & Families



Jeb,

I just wanted to send you an update on Stefani  Stauffer and the Department
of Children & Families.   Thankfully,  I had cancelled my trip to
Washington DC, because yesterday, Stefani had a  status hearing at the
Pinellas Courthouse in Judge Irene Sullivan's Courtroom,  and I
was available to go with her. We spent the entire day there  trying
to resolve some simple issues.

Since I last wrote you, Stefani's case worker,  Debbie Hanson, withdrew
Stefani from Tarpon High School and was moving her to  St. Petersburg and
enrolling her in St. Petersburg High School with just 2 weeks  of classes
left and exams to take.  Stefani was beside herself with worry,  fearing
she would fail her junior year and not get her credits (she has a 3.5
GPA).  She also feared that her placement in a "theraputic facility" would
prevent her from pursuing her goal of joining the military.  She claims her
Airforce Recruiter told her that if she was on medication (her psychiatrist
had  her on Paxil which Stefani vehemently objects to) or living in a
theraputic  facility she would be ineligible for service.

Judge Sullivan listened to Stefani's case, and  ordered the case worker to
re-enroll Stefani in Tarpon High School until June  6th.  The judge felt as
I do, that taking her from the school with such a  little bit of time left
was the wrong thing to do.  The case worker argued  with the judge saying
that she needed to place Stefani in the facility  yesterday, and that St.
Petersburg High school was required to enroll her  anytime, even the last
day of school. Regardless, the judge instructed Ms.  Hanson to inquire as
to whether or not the bed could be held for 3 weeks so  that Stefani could
finish school where she was -- stating that taking exams  in a different
school for classes she never attended was not in Stefani's best  interest.
In the bed could not be held, then it was the case worker's  duty to find
transportation for Stefani to Tarpon Springs High School (about 20  miles)
or find out if Tarpon High would let Stefani  take her exams early,  so she
could finish the school year at her current school.

Immediately upon leaving the court room, the case  worker, Debbie Hanson,
called Stefani aside and told her to come with her  because she was taking
her to the facility in St. Petersburg right  then.   Stefani began to cry
and become very upset and called me over  and told me what was happening.
The case worker was very rude to me  when I asked her what was going on.
She told me that Stefani had to  go with her right then to the theraputic
facility.  I began to  disagree with the case worker saying that isn't what
the judge had just said in  the courtroom.   Because of our arguing, a
bailiff came over and  we explained the problem.  She offered to go get the
judge out of her  chamber to resolve the issue and left.   Immediately, Ms
Hanson got on  her cell phone, called the facility regarding the delay and
found out that it  was absolutely possible to hold the bed for Stefani
until school was  out.

I know for a fact that had Stefani not had me with  her,  she would have
been moved to the facility even though the judge had  instructed the
caseworker otherwise.    I am so appalled at the  way these case workers
are treating these children, and even defying the court  to do things their
own way -- and certainly not for the benefit of the  children.

I realize you have a committee looking into this  department already, and I
am seeing first hand why it is so needed.    The arrogance of these workers
is beyond belief.

Stefani has another hearing on June 12 with Judge  Sullivan where she will
be seeking emancipation.   I have committed to  helping Stefani through
this process, but unfortunately since it is all so new  to me, I am merely
a source of moral support.

Stefani wants to join the Airforce in August when  she turns 17 and is
willing to go to summer school or dual enroll at the  community college to
obtain enough credits for graduation so that she can join  this summer.
Stefani told me she needs structure and stability in her  life, and feels
that the military would provide her that plus the opportunity to  get
an education, job skills, and a certainty of a place to belong for the
next four years.  (She has lived in 18 locations in 16 yrs -- many of them
abusive). Her goal is to become a Forensic Scientist.

I can only help this one child, but I know as  Governor you can help many.
I hope this information is helpful in your  endeavor to improve the
Department of Children & Families.

Sandy

-----Original Message-----
From: Sandy Faulkner  [mailto:sfaulk@tampabay.rr.com]
Sent: Wednesday, May 08, 2002  12:36 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Department of Children  & Families


Dear Jeb,

I regret that I have to write you this e-mail  at a time when you are
already faced with mounting problems with the  Department of Families and
Children but a problem arrived on my doorstep  unexpectedly and I can't
just turn away.

Over the weekend, Debbie brought a co-worker,  Stefani home to join our
family for a Sunday BBQ. Debbie had  expressed concern for this girl
because she had no parents and said her  landlord wasn't very nice to her,
so we decided to have her join us for a  family day.   During the day,
Stephani, who is  16,  told us about the exorbitant rent her landlord was
charging  her.  She explained that she pays over $600 per month rent for a
room  in the home of an employee (case worker) of the Department of
Families  & Children.  In addition,  the woman charges her extra  for food,
telephone and other incidentals, and gets angry when she has to  pick
Stefani up from work.

If that wasn't bad enough, last night, the  woman told the girl to "Pick
up your sh#$ and get out!!"    Being 16, the girl the only person she knew
she could call, a  19-year-old former foster sister to come get her.   She
was  picked up and spent the night with her foster sister.  To make
matters even worse, the landlord/caseworker, reported the girl as a
runaway today, and then had the girl's only means of communication, her
cell phone (that Stephani pays for) shut off.

Before her phone was shut off,  Stefani called Debbie  asking her what she
should do.   Debbie handed the phone to me, and I have spent an entire day
trying to  find this girl some help.  To me, this is an inexcusable
situation . . . certainly not as heinous as that of the missing
5-year-old, but certainly of major concern when those in charge of
protecting these kids are the ones taking advantage of them.

I have contacted a family court judge, the  public defender's office, the
state attorney and Gus Bilirakis's office  and am awaiting replies.   When
I spoke with the State  Attorney's office I was told I needed to contact
the girl's  caseworker.   When I explained that the problem was  with one
of the case workers in the same office, they  still insisted that I would
have to talk with the case worker if  there is a problem.  It seem to me,
that calling the case worker  who placed the girl with a co-worker who
is charging this  girl rent plus is liking asking the "wolf to watch the
hen house!"  I  was so baffled by the response, that I asked the person at
the State  Attorney's office if there was anyone who looked out
for children in  these situations and the answer I received was "I don't
know.   You have to call the case worker."

I'm sure there are all kinds of rules and  regulations that I don't know
and probably wouldn't  understand.   But what I do know is that this "case"
is not a  number but a child, without any parents, who is working hard to
maintain an 3.5 GPA in High School, works 30-40 hrs a week, and is being
grossly taking advantage of by the very people who should be looking out
for her.   I can't even explain how disgusted and frustrated I  am.

I realize you can't get involved in all the  individual cases all around
the state, but considering the current  scrutiny of this department, I
wanted to share this situation since it  seems to involve employees of the
department using their positions in an  improper way.

I will continue to work with the  professionals locally until we can find a
suitable solution for  Stefani.  My only concern is that I am leaving on
Monday for a trip  to Washington D.C. with Debbie & Lisa. Although our main
purpose  of the trip is for Debbie to  visit Georgetown University where
she is seriously considering  applying to the  School of Foreign Service,
we plan to send a couple  of extra days touring the city, since neither of
the girls have ever  visited before.  We planned the trip early so when
Debbie  returns she can begin her search for a summer job/internship or
volunteer position with an agency or organization associated with
International or Latin American Relations to further explore her  possible
career choice.

Although I'm really excited and looking  forward to taking Debbie & Lisa to
Washington, I am very concerned  with leaving Stefani.  I hope we can get
her situation  resolved before I leave on Monday, but I'm not very
optimistic  at this point.

Regardless of what happens with the  Department and Stefani's immediate
situation, I have decided that I  will continue to meet and work with
Stefani and be an adult she can trust  and count on.  She seems to be a
remarkable young lady who has dreams  and goals and appears to have the
strength of character to overcome her  difficult childhood to achieve them.
I only I hope I can help her  see them come true.

Thank you for listening.


Sincerely,

Sandy  Faulkner

-----Original Message-----
From: Mary Beth Pridgeon [mailto:Mary_Beth_Pridgeon@dcf.state.fl.us]

Subject: RE: Update - Jerissa



Governor:

At Jerissa's hearing today, we had several staff members present along with
her private attorney and public defender (?) - not sure exactly how you
have both.  The Judge ordered her to jail for 90 days but gave her credit
for time served which means she will be released on Thursday of next week.
The FACT team will pick her up from jail as she has been sentenced to
community control for 18 months where she will also be required to wear a
electronic device.  The FACT team will transfer Jerissa to La Amistad in
Orlando where she will remain until she completes treatment or flees.  (If
she runs this time, I think the Judge may not be as lenient.)  After her 18
months of community control, she will still have to serve two years of
probation.

Below is the message I sent to the staff that worked very hard on this:
"Thanks to all of you for doing what  you have done to help this young lady
who as of yet has not been focused on helping herself.  You are angels who
are looking over her - hopefully one day she will realize it - but if not
- you all will know that you did your best to save a vulnerable client."

I pray that Jerissa will make the turn - it is now up to her to commit
herself to getting better so that she can become a functioning and
contributing member of society.  I know her mother has been through so much
and my heart goes out to her, but she must now let her daughter work
through her issues with her therapist.  Thank you for caring so deeply
about people.  You are a truly wonderful person and I so appreciate you
both as the leader of our state and as a person.  I also want to thank you
for supporting Judge Kearney - she is one of the finest and most committed
people I have ever had the pleasure of working for.

Mary Beth

regarding state business are public records available to the
public and media upon request.   Your e-mail communications
may therefore be subject to public disclosure.

Trudy,
Have the Blue Ribbon Panel addressed the issue of children drowning?  Seems to be a concern lately with the number of drownings in recent months.  
 
It's my opinion that children sent into fosterhomes with pools be given a swimming test.  IF they pass the test, they are okay to stay.  IF they do not pass the test, they must have a certified swimming class within 90 days of moving in to the home. (The YMCA offers the courses) I am all for pool barriers, but humans will err and leave gates open, fences down at some point in time.  Not to mention children will be visiting friends and there may not be pool protection.  I am an advocate for protecting the children, not the pools.  Protection that lasts for a lifetime and very cost efficient.
 
Phyllis

-----Original Message-----
From: Sandy Faulkner [mailto:sfaulk@tampabay.rr.com]
Sent: Thursday, May 16, 2002 8:44 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Continuning Department of Children & Families



Jeb,
 
I just wanted to send you an update on Stefani Stauffer and the Department of Children & Families.   Thankfully, I had cancelled my trip to Washington DC, because yesterday, Stefani had a status hearing at the Pinellas Courthouse in Judge Irene Sullivan's Courtroom, and I was available to go with her. We spent the entire day there trying to resolve some simple issues.  
 
Since I last wrote you, Stefani's case worker, Debbie Hanson, withdrew Stefani from Tarpon High School and was moving her to St. Petersburg and enrolling her in St. Petersburg High School with just 2 weeks of classes left and exams to take.  Stefani was beside herself with worry, fearing she would fail her junior year and not get her credits (she has a 3.5 GPA).  She also feared that her placement in a "theraputic facility" would prevent her from pursuing her goal of joining the military.  She claims her Airforce Recruiter told her that if she was on medication (her psychiatrist had her on Paxil which Stefani vehemently objects to) or living in a theraputic facility she would be ineligible for service.
 
Judge Sullivan listened to Stefani's case, and ordered the case worker to re-enroll Stefani in Tarpon High School until June 6th.  The judge felt as I do, that taking her from the school with such a little bit of time left was the wrong thing to do.  The case worker argued with the judge saying that she needed to place Stefani in the facility yesterday, and that St. Petersburg High school was required to enroll her anytime, even the last day of school. Regardless, the judge instructed Ms. Hanson to inquire as to whether or not the bed could be held for 3 weeks so that Stefani could finish school where she was -- stating that taking exams in a different school for classes she never attended was not in Stefani's best interest.  In the bed could not be held, then it was the case worker's duty to find transportation for Stefani to Tarpon Springs High School (about 20 miles) or find out if Tarpon High would let Stefani  take her exams early, so she could finish the school year at her current school.
 
Immediately upon leaving the court room, the case worker, Debbie Hanson, called Stefani aside and told her to come with her because she was taking her to the facility in St. Petersburg right then.   Stefani began to cry and become very upset and called me over and told me what was happening.   The case worker was very rude to me when I asked her what was going on.  She told me that Stefani had to go with her right then to the theraputic facility.  I began to disagree with the case worker saying that isn't what the judge had just said in the courtroom.   Because of our arguing, a bailiff came over and we explained the problem.  She offered to go get the judge out of her chamber to resolve the issue and left.   Immediately, Ms Hanson got on her cell phone, called the facility regarding the delay and found out that it was absolutely possible to hold the bed for Stefani until school was out.
 
I know for a fact that had Stefani not had me with her,  she would have been moved to the facility even though the judge had instructed the caseworker otherwise.    I am so appalled at the way these case workers are treating these children, and even defying the court to do things their own way -- and certainly not for the benefit of the children.
 
I realize you have a committee looking into this department already, and I am seeing first hand why it is so needed.   The arrogance of these workers is beyond belief.
 
Stefani has another hearing on June 12 with Judge Sullivan where she will be seeking emancipation.   I have committed to helping Stefani through this process, but unfortunately since it is all so new to me, I am merely a source of moral support.    
 
Stefani wants to join the Airforce in August when she turns 17 and is willing to go to summer school or dual enroll at the community college to obtain enough credits for graduation so that she can join this summer.  Stefani told me she needs structure and stability in her life, and feels that the military would provide her that plus the opportunity to get an education, job skills, and a certainty of a place to belong for the next four years.  (She has lived in 18 locations in 16 yrs -- many of them abusive). Her goal is to become a Forensic Scientist.
 
I can only help this one child, but I know as Governor you can help many.  I hope this information is helpful in your endeavor to improve the Department of Children & Families.
 
Sandy

-----Original Message-----
From: Sandy Faulkner [mailto:sfaulk@tampabay.rr.com]
Sent: Wednesday, May 08, 2002 12:36 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Department of Children & Families


Dear Jeb,
 
I regret that I have to write you this e-mail at a time when you are already faced with mounting problems with the Department of Families and Children but a problem arrived on my doorstep unexpectedly and I can't just turn away.  
 
Over the weekend, Debbie brought a co-worker, Stefani home to join our family for a Sunday BBQ. Debbie had expressed concern for this girl because she had no parents and said her landlord wasn't very nice to her, so we decided to have her join us for a family day.   During the day, Stephani, who is 16,  told us about the exorbitant rent her landlord was charging her.  She explained that she pays over $600 per month rent for a room in the home of an employee (case worker) of the Department of Families & Children.  In addition,  the woman charges her extra for food, telephone and other incidentals, and gets angry when she has to pick Stefani up from work.   
 
If that wasn't bad enough, last night, the woman told the girl to "Pick up your sh#$ and get out!!"   Being 16, the girl the only person she knew she could call, a 19-year-old former foster sister to come get her.   She was picked up and spent the night with her foster sister.  To make matters even worse, the landlord/caseworker, reported the girl as a runaway today, and then had the girl's only means of communication, her cell phone (that Stephani pays for) shut off.
 
Before her phone was shut off, Stefani called Debbie  asking her what she should do.  Debbie handed the phone to me, and I have spent an entire day trying to find this girl some help.  To me, this is an inexcusable situation . . . certainly not as heinous as that of the missing 5-year-old, but certainly of major concern when those in charge of  protecting these kids are the ones taking advantage of them.
 
I have contacted a family court judge, the public defender's office, the state attorney and Gus Bilirakis's office and am awaiting replies.   When I spoke with the State Attorney's office I was told I needed to contact the girl's caseworker.   When I explained that the problem was with one of the case workers in the same office, they still insisted that I would have to talk with the case worker if there is a problem.  It seem to me, that calling the case worker who placed the girl with a co-worker who is charging this girl rent plus is liking asking the "wolf to watch the hen house!"  I was so baffled by the response, that I asked the person at the State Attorney's office if there was anyone who looked out for children in these situations and the answer I received was "I don't know.  You have to call the case worker."    
 
I'm sure there are all kinds of rules and regulations that I don't know and probably wouldn't understand.   But what I do know is that this "case" is not a number but a child, without any parents, who is working hard to maintain an 3.5 GPA in High School, works 30-40 hrs a week, and is being grossly taking advantage of by the very people who should be looking out for her.   I can't even explain how disgusted and frustrated I am.
 
I realize you can't get involved in all the individual cases all around the state, but considering the current scrutiny of this department, I wanted to share this situation since it seems to involve employees of the department using their positions in an improper way.
 
I will continue to work with the professionals locally until we can find a suitable solution for Stefani.  My only concern is that I am leaving on Monday for a trip to Washington D.C. with Debbie & Lisa. Although our main purpose of the trip is for Debbie to visit Georgetown University where she is seriously considering applying to the  School of Foreign Service, we plan to send a couple of extra days touring the city, since neither of the girls have ever visited before.  We planned the trip early so when Debbie returns she can begin her search for a summer job/internship or volunteer position with an agency or organization associated with International or Latin American Relations to further explore her possible career choice.   
 
Although I'm really excited and looking forward to taking Debbie & Lisa to Washington, I am very concerned with leaving Stefani.  I hope we can get her situation resolved before I leave on Monday, but I'm not very optimistic at this point.  
 
Regardless of what happens with the Department and Stefani's immediate situation, I have decided that I will continue to meet and work with Stefani and be an adult she can trust and count on.  She seems to be a remarkable young lady who has dreams and goals and appears to have the strength of character to overcome her difficult childhood to achieve them.  I only I hope I can help her see them come true.  
 
Thank you for listening.   
 
 
Sincerely,
 
Sandy Faulkner

-----Original Message-----
From: Robinson, James <RobinsJ@mail.doe.state.fl.us>
To: Crist, Charlie <CristC@mail.doe.state.fl.us>; Horne, Jim
<Jim.Horne@flboe.org>; Wood, Larry <Larry.Wood@flboe.org>; Safley, Robin
<SafleyR@mail.doe.state.fl.us>; McKenzie, Syd <Syd.McKenzie@flboe.org>;
Pierson, Wayne <PiersoW@mail.doe.state.fl.us>; Lopez, Ruben
<Ruben.Lopez@flboe.org>; Coxe, Betty <CoxeB@mail.doe.state.fl.us>; Burt,
Cynthia <BurtC@mail.doe.state.fl.us>; Struhs, Sara
<Sara.Struhs@flboe.org>;
McCord, Ron <McCordR@mail.doe.state.fl.us>; Kincannon, Penny
<KINCANNP@mail.doe.state.fl.us>
Sent: Thu May 16 17:14:16 2002
Subject: E-mail public records

I want to bring to your attention an important Second District Court of
Appeals decision that was issued on May 10, 2002.  The case is captioned
Times Publishing Company v. City of Clearwater, 2002 WL 944630 (Fla.App.
2
Dist.).  The decision is not final until expiration of the 15-day period
for
filing of a motion for rehearing.  If a motion is timely filed, the
decision
would not be final until such motion is denied.
 
The case involves the Times' demand for e-mails between two City
employees.
The e-mails were withheld on the employees' assertion that they were
private
in nature and were not "public records."  The appellate court affirmed
the
trial court's opinion that: 

*	E-mails stored in government computers do not automatically
become
public records by virtue of that storage; 

*	"Private" or "personal" e-mails simply fall outside the current
definition of public records; 

*	Such e-mail is not "made or received pursuant to law or
ordinance...or received "in connection with  official business or the
transaction of official business of the City; and

*	Although digital in nature, there is little to distinguish such
e-mail from personal letters delivered to government workers via a
government post office box and stored in government-owned desk.

The Times argued that the City's official records custodian designated
by
section Sec. 119.021, F.S. (2000), was required to review each e-mail to
determine whether the employee properly designated it as "nonpublic
record."
Because the City allowed the individual employees to perform this
function
without any oversight, the Times maintained that it "failed to fulfill
its
obligations as custodian."  The court disagreed, pointing out that the
statute referred to the "custodian" as the elected officer "or his or
her
designee."

The court did say that the Times could seek an in camera inspection of
the
e-mails by the trial court to determine whether they were public or
private
in nature.

It is important to note what the case did not involve:

*	E-mail that may have been isolated by a government employee
whose
job required him or her to locate employee misuse of government
computers.

*	A balancing of the public's interest in open public records and
an
individual's right to privacy.  The two employees involved in the case
did
not assert such a right.  In fact, the City had published a computer
resources use policy stating generally stating that computer resources
belong to the City and that users have no expectation of privacy as to
documents created, stored, sent, ore received.  (Note: This policy could
preclude assertion of a right of privacy but could not and did not alter
the
statutory definition of public records.)

*	This case does not involve an in camera inspection of public
records.  The primary issue on appeal was whether all e-mail stored on a
public entity's computer system is public record simply by virtue of its
placement on a public resource. The Times sought a bright-line ruling
that
all e-mail on the City's computer system was "public record."

For as long as I've been at the Department, I have taken the position
that
private e-mails are not public records for the very reasons expressed by
the
appellate court. It is my understanding that our practice in responding
to
public records requests is consistent with this position.  Incidentally,
this has not been a position shared by the Attorney General's Office.  I
will let you know as soon as the decision is final.  In the meantime, if
you
have any question or comment, or if you would like a copy of the
decision,
please let me know.

Jim

From:	Terry L. Rice <tlrice@adelphia.net>
Sent:	Friday, May 17, 2002 8:27 AM
To:	LTG Robert Flowers
Cc:	MG Robert Griffin
Subject:	Fw: Magistrate's Report & Recommendation
Attachments:	ReportRecommendation.TIF

Bob ... attached is the Magistrate's recommendation to the Judge regarding the 8.5 Square Mile Area residents' case ... in a nutshell, the Magistrate says the Corps' 6D plan is contrary to law (PL101-229 as amended).  2 points:

*	As you well know we expected that this was the case ... and that Mod Waters would once again be delayed and Tribal land would continue to be destroyed.  Now hopefully this will inspire the Corps to move with haste in implementing it's 1992 congressionally approved plan which protects the 8.5 SMA as Congress explicitly directed and save the Everglades before it can't be saved ... immediately stop the condemnation of property that has already begun ... not destroy the 100 homes in the 6D plan that the Magistrate believes you have no lawful right to destroy. And certainly is not necessary for restoration. 

*	There will be those who now work to change the law ... waste more precious time and resources ... we must be vigilant to ensure that PL101-229 endures so that the project can be implemented as fast as possible so that the Tribe's land isn't totally destroyed, along with Everglades National Park, Florida Bay, and areas to the north ... so that the flooding of people in Miami-Dade county is greatly reduced ... and so that the incessant uncertainty and fear that the people of the 8.5 SMA have experienced for more than 2 decades stops.

The truth of the matter is that the quick accomplishment of this Mod Waters project is a strategic imperative ... a center of gravity ... for the long-term success of Everglades restoration as well as the future of the Corps ... you're the leader who can put the train back on the track ... we ask and hope for decisive action.
 
Sincerely,
 
Terry Rice
Miccosukee Tribe
305-321-3095

From:	LISA FINK <jade000@msn.com>
Sent:	Friday, May 17, 2002 2:21 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Will  you respond?

Governor Bush,
I have never personally emailed or written to you, but I feel the time has come.  I know you are a fan of email, but whether or not you respond is still a mystery.
First I must say that I am a Democrat.  When you were elected I accepted it and really had no significant grudge with you as the election was legitimate and you won fair and square (at least as far as I know).  I was not politically involved and basically just voted every 2 years.  However, after the 2000 election I have become involved, and in a big way locally.  I will help whoever is running against you to win because I feel that you have done the people of Florida and the USA a disservice.  The way you and Katherine Harris purged the voting rolls is just totally unacceptable in my view.  I have friends who marched in Selma with Rev. Martin Luther King, people who were willing to die for the right to vote.  Those same people feel as if they were taken back to the pre- 1965 Voting Rights Act days.  By disenfranchising them, we all were disenfranchised.  Now, it seems as if you are just so pro big business and corporations and so against the average person.  Did your children go to public schools?  If not, you most likely have no idea how crowded they are.  My daughters pre-IB French class has over 45 kids in it!!! 45!!!! And she goes to an A school.  If we don't fund education now, our future will be grave as these kids are the future.  If we don't watch out for our environment now, we may not have a future.  There has been reports that show that 60% of Florida may be underwater in less than 100  years if we don't level off Global Warming, which is indeed a real phenomenon.  Look at our weather patterns and the melting of the polar ice caps.  Don't you care what the future will hold for your children, and their children?  We all have a responsibility to do our best.  The almighty buck is not everything.  We must stop and access what is really important. I know what Florida used to be like, and when I stop and think of it now I feel like crying.  Gone is the Florida of my youth, and in its place is an ever growing cement state.  Just remember that people in Florida want results not just talk, and they want someone who really cares about the people, the land, and the future of our great state.
Sincerely,
L.Fink
St. Pete

--------------------
Jupiter resident continues to battle homeowners group over flag 
--------------------

By Randall Murray
The Jupiter Courier

May 15, 2002

JUPITER * Even though the homeowners association that has battled
Jupiter resident George Andres for 18 months over his flag and flagpole
has filed foreclosure proceedings against the former Marine, Andres'
attorney said a new state law should help protect him.

Andres' attorney, Barry Silver, called the Indian Creek Phase III-B
association unreasonable and mean-spirited" for its effort to collect
more than $30,000 in fines.

He said he does not think Andres and his wife, Ann, are in any immediate
danger of losing their modest home at 125 Doe Trail.

"We had to have a law passed to get this ridiculous association off the
Andreses' back. But they disregard the governor and relentlessly pursue
this nonsense."

Andres, 64, has attracted international attention with his fight against
the association over a 12-foot flagpole and American flag he erected in
his front yard in 2000.

This week, the association filed a lawsuit to foreclose on the Andreses'
one-story home for payment of fines and penalties assessed by Palm Beach
County Circuit Court Judge Catherine Brunson.

Brunson has ruled twice against Andres.

The association's action was taken in spite of passage in March by
Florida's Legislature of a law that prohibits homeowners associations
from restricting the display of the American flag by property owners.

The law stipulates the flag must be displayed in a "respectful" manner
and that the pole be "portable." According to Andres, his flag and pole
meet both standards.

West Palm Beach attorney Steven Selz, who represents the association,
said "the new law does not change the fact that there has been a
judgment entered [by Brunson]. The new law does not undo that."

Selz said the association will move "as soon as possible" on the
foreclosure. Selz put the value of the Andres home at "about $65,000."

But Ann Andres put the price tag higher -- "at least $80,000," she said.
"We put a new kitchen and bathroom in here." They moved into the home in
June 1998.

Silver said he will file an appeal and motions to have the original case
reheard. 

Copyright (c) 2002, South Florida Sun-Sentinel 

Visit Sun-Sentinel.com

From:	Ladykilligrew1@aol.com
Sent:	Friday, May 17, 2002 5:23 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Fwd: Please take a moment...
Attachments:	Please take a moment...



   Dear Governor Bush:                                                          5/17/02




I would like to take a moment of your time and express my support for CS/SB 160 also known as the "Debbie Wasserman-Schultz Act."

During the recent legislative session, members of both the House and Senate recognized the benefit of a charity and scholarship day fundraising by granting dog tracks the authority to conduct a special "Greyhound Adopt a Pet Day" to raise funds to promote greyhound adoption. CS/BS 160 will also help to fund the volunteer operated greyhound adoption program.

CS/BS 160 further provides for changes to the number of days and hours of operation of card rooms as well as replacing the ten-dollar "pot limit" with a limited two-dollar "bet limit."  These changes will re-energize the State's declining racetrack card rooms, create needed jobs and generate purse money, State tax and track revenue.



   We as a Not for Profit local social group work with the PAL and feel strongly about   
   those who want to give old greyhouds a home. 




Thank you for your time and consideration. 

Sincerely,


   Marybeth Michaels (and all of our 50 members)

   Thee Royal Krewe of Lady Killigrew Inc.

			Invitation


The Florida State Business and Professional Women's Annual Conference is
in Palm Beach Gardens this year. On Saturday, June 22, the Florida Education
Foundation of the Florida Federation of Business and Professional Women
would like to invite you to participate in a panel discussion on:
 "The State of Education in the State of Florida"  "Where are we now and
where do we need to be.  What will it take to get us there."
Each candidate for the office of Governor for the State of Florida has been
invited to participate.

This year, with the race for governor in Florida, being as important as it
is to Education Issues within Florida, the board felt it was important that
each BPW member had an opportunity to hear the philosophy and plans of each
of our candidates.  I would like to invite each of you to participate in a
panel discussion on this issue.  This discussion will be held during the
Education Foundation's Formal Luncheon, 11:00 am till 2:00 pm.  We will
provide a professional moderator for the event. Your participation is
crucial.  Further information will be supplied prior to the event.  Please
check your calendars and let me know your plans.  The conference will be
held at the Palm Beach Gardens Marriott located at 4000 RCA Blvd.

The Education Foundation of BPW Florida was created in 1965 for the specific
and unique purpose of building Scholarship Houses to accommodate the housing
needs of female university students who would otherwise be unable to further
their education. BPW Scholarship Houses are located on University campuses
located in Tallahassee at FSU, in Orlando at UCF and the newest house was
dedicated in August of 1996 in Boca Raton at FAU.

In the beginning, piggy banks were given to each member to donate $.25 per
month and asked to return the filled bank at the Annual Conference at a "Hog
Callin" Event- we still collect money in this fashion thirty years later
(with a few other fundraising methods in between!

As you can see, education is very important to us.
I look forward to speaking with your representative in the near future.
If you wish further information on BPW Florida, you can visit our web site:
www.bpwfl.org.


Information on our house on the University of Central Florida Campus.

http://pegasus.cc.ucf.edu/~bpw/

Sincerely,



Christine Weigle
Board Director for Education Foundation of the Florida Federation of
Business and Professional Women.
Christine.Weigle@verizon.net
727-515-4376

We are looking at a moderated event beginning at 11:30 and ending at 1:00.
Please reply at your earliest convenience so press coverage will be correct.

----- Original Message ----- 
From: Jay Wheeler <mailto:jwheeler@kua.net>  
To: insight@orlandosentinel.com 
Sent: Friday, May 17, 2002 12:52 PM
Subject: FCAT 

The latest FCAT results for Central Florida Schools still has a lot of room for improvement. In order to significantly change the results we get from our schools every parent of every student needs to spend at least two to three hours per month in their childrens class. Without a productive partnership between teachers and parents nothing will change. The only way to get parents in the classrooms is by getting employers to encourage or maybe even make it mandatory for employees of school age children to spend paid time in the schools. If these employers care about the community they will embrace this approach realizing it is good for their workers, the workers families, and the community at large. Plus in the long run the employee will be enriched, and the employer will have a better trained pool of workers to hire from as results in our schools get better. Our county commissions can help by maikng a concerted effort for every student to have a library card and work with the schools to track use. Lets stop heaping blame on schools and teachers because they can not do this alone. To improve School performance the cities, counties and business community has to get involved in ways they are not currently. Namely work to get parents who are emplyed by the various entities in the schools. Results take effort and a new type of leadership. If these FCAT scores do not signal a wake up call, what will ? If we are not making things better for our children then shame on us. More money for education is no substitute for parental involvement. From: Jay Wheeler 1524 Four Winds Blvd  Kissimmee FL 34746 Cell/407-460-3034-Home/407-390-0505

-----Original Message-----
From: Rick Webster [mailto:rwebster@tia.org]
Sent: Thursday, May 16, 2002 3:36 PM
To: Austin Mott; billhardman@mindspring.com
Subject: Article of interest on Snowbirds...


Austin and Bill-

Just was told by a reporter from the Globe and Mail that at their meeting
today in Buffalo, Gov. Ridge offered to Deputy PM Manley to exempt Canadian
Snowbirds from the new, proposed rule.

I always saw the Canadians as being treated separately, but I do wonder if
the folks over at the Justice Department are going to like Ridge's offer.

Here's the text from the Globe and Mail article:

?--------------------------------
Visa rules won't affect 'snowbirds,' Ridge promises

By OLIVER MOORE

Globe and Mail Update

Thursday, May 16 * Online Edition, Posted at 1:33 PM EST



Deputy Prime Minister John Manley received personal assurances Thursday from
a senior U.S. official that Canadians who prefer to spend their winters in
sunnier climes will not be subject to strict new visa rules proposed by the
White House.

The U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service is mulling over new
regulations restricting foreign visitors to a maximum of 30 days, instead of
the current six months. Snowbirds' associations have lobbied fiercely for an
exemption from any such rule, and have been bolstered in their fight by
vocal support from business groups in southern U.S. states.

INS spokesman Chris Bentley told globeandmail.com early this week that
Canadians could not expect to be given special treatment. He said that
immigration officers would have the latitude to assess how long visitors
might need to fulfil their stated purpose for visiting.

But Director of Homeland Security Tom Ridge, at an announcement with Mr.
Manley in Buffalo, said Thursday that his government has no intention of
impeding the travel plans of the more than 100,000 Canadians who live in the
United States part of the year. Rules have not been completed, he said, but
he was confident that they would not "alter in any way the relationship
[snowbirds] have with us."

Canadian Snowbird Association executive director Heather Nicholson-Morrison
said this week that they appreciate assurances from the U.S. government that
new regulations would not affect them, but that they'd also prefer to see it
in writing.

Mr. Ridge said he could not immediately offer the guarantee that Ms.
Nicholson-Morrison had demanded, but promised that the appropriate agencies
would work out the details.

"We understand their concern, but we don't think there's any need for
concern." 

 
 

----------------------------------------------------------------------------
----

Copyright © 2002 Bell Globemedia Interactive Inc. All Rights Reserved.

From: Jerry Wilkinson [mailto:jerry142@terranova.net]
Sent: Saturday, May 18, 2002 10:52 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Monroe County New Commissioner


Dear Governor and Staff:
	We all express our concerns for the loss of Nora Williams. As resident of
unincorporated Monroe County I wish to express my concerns about any to the
candidates listed in the Key West Citizen as a replacement for Commissioner
Nora Williams. The approximate 40,000 concerned unincorporated county
residents see their representation evaporating already by the actions of
McCoy and Neugent, residents of municipalities. Adding one resident of a
municipality will be the final straw. We understand part of the reason is
because candidates are elected at large but commission business is about 90
percent unincorporated county items.
	I wish to offer and enter my name for services for the remainder to
Commissioner Williams' tenure with an absolute promise not to be a candidate
for the slot in November. I know everyone is interested in the votes the
municipalities carry we cannot let the balance be upset. I am 73 years old
and expect to last another seven months and will serve the Republican Party
well. If not accepted, of all those listed, I favor Islamorada resident
Keith Douglas as he has the experience to immediately be in position for the
forthcoming budget although he will not be as good as I.
	We do not wish to turn upside down as the Spiegel Grove did yesterday -
remain afloat!
Respectfully,
/s/Jerry S. Wilkinson

Tavernier, FL 33070

www.keyshistory.org

From:	Jeb Bush
Sent:	Saturday, May 18, 2002 4:49 PM
To:	Robert Lechner
Subject:	RE: A World Of Individuals

Robert, I concur with you completely. The intangibles of learning are important. They are the stimulus to achieve. Having said that, I don't believe measuring where kids stand compared to standards established by educators is contradictory to what you say. I am glad you concur. Have a great weekend.

-----Original Message-----
From: Robert Lechner [mailto:rplechner@hotmail.com]
Sent: Saturday, May 18, 2002 12:33 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: A World Of Individuals


As is the case with many other teachers, I have always been amazed by the 
number of former students who phone from Los Angeles, Boston, S. Korea, and 
Germany. Then there are e-mails from all over the world. In the past month I 
have had dinner with a former student from Los Angeles, a call from a former 
student, now an attorney in Boston, and lunch with someone returning from 
duty in the Army. Today I'm having lunch with the football kicker from 
Syracuse University who wants to show me his bowl ring and an advance copy 
of the Syracuse football brochure for the coming season. Friday it's lunch 
with a young lady studying to be an English teacher at USF who wants me to 
meet her husband-to-be. Last week it was an e-mail from Qatar and a former 
student in the Air Force who once asked me if I'd like a tour of Air Force 
II and a chance to meet his boss--the Vice President of the United States!

I started to think of my experiences of just the past week in connection 
with a recent 60 Minutes II television program. The show examined a report 
by the Secret Service and the U.S. Department of Education. Their study 
involved interviews with students who have been responsible for a number of 
school shootings across the country. A profile has emerged of these school 
shooters. This school violence profile depicts a young person who is 
alienated from adults and peers, bullied by classmates, experienced a recent 
large scale sense of failure, revealed his feelings of anguish and rejection 
to another student, and one who has no significant adult who is desirous of 
listening to his plea for help. In essence, he is one who cannot cope and 
who perceives death as a better alternative to life. Safety in our schools 
must be our major concern. We must learn how to listen to the stress our 
students are experiencing and provide a caring ear and the hope they so 
desperately seek. As educators and parents, we are already a large part of 
our students' lives. It isn't really another responsibility on top of those 
we had before. It is a study of the environment in which kids exist and one 
we must understand in order to address their needs.

Yesterday I asked my former student now in the Army what he thought was the 
reason former students continue to stay in touch with me 10, 20, and more 
than 30 years later. "When I see an officer in the Army," he said, "I salute 
out of respect for his rank and his authority. Your students are saluting 
you because they and you remember the nicknames you gave them. You were 
saying, 'There isn't anyone now, nor has there ever been anyone as unique as 
you.' We felt important because you recognized our individuality; our 
opinions mattered; we could disagree, but we knew all along that if you said 
it, it was probably right. In short, you cared at a time when we sensed many 
others did not." Every teaching methods book should reflect the beliefs that 
each child is important; no student deserves to be bullied by another; 
teachers need to teach children first and subject matter second; and we must 
broaden the scope of our teacher training to include sensitivity to our 
students' feelings and create a school environment which is inviting and 
exciting for young learners.  Similarly, schools must be places of 
intellectual investigation which reward our teachers and not places in which 
they are asked to check their intellectual curiosity and sense of scientific 
inquiry at the front door. As a society, we must do more than pay lip 
service to the valuable role played by our teachers. Parents need to spend 
more time with their kids helping them to adjust to the complexities of the 
adult world.

Schools of stagnation and factory like relationships must give way to a new 
era of respect, true intellectual inquiry, and a renewed dedication to 
listening to our students. For every young person who causes trouble, there 
are 97 who are sincere, ready to learn and follow direction, and searching 
for a nickname to make them feel unique and a way to demonstrate their 
skills. The answers are there, and the outstanding kids have always been in 
place. Schools must be places of thought and not places of violence. It's a 
shame it took the Secret Service to show us the way, for there is no secret 
to unlocking the minds and hearts of our young people. In fact, those who 
are fourteen years old want the same respect, freedoms of expression, and 
recognition of individuality and talent enjoyed by those of us who would 
presume to be their teachers. While complex governmental studies tell us 
these incidents could occur anywhere, common sense tells us that violence 
and school shootings don't occur in places where there is love, respect, and 
understanding.

Of course, school budgets, class sizes, and test results are important. 
However, when it comes to an individual child, success may hinge on a 
moment's worth of attention or even something as small and unique as a 
nickname.

Robert P. Lechner
Former Sarasota County Teacher of the Year
University Supervisor and Adjunct Professor
University of South Florida


4401 Glebe Farm Rd.
Sarasota, FL 34235
(941) 371-1116

-----Original Message-----
From: David Royal [mailto:yumaroyal@yahoo.com]
Sent: Thursday, May 16, 2002 11:45 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Need to ask a favor


Governor Bush:

I need to ask you a favor if I may. I don't know if
you can help me or not- but you don't know unless you
try. I was working for a citrus co-op until Dec 3rd
when the long term lender took over and terminated us
all the following morning. I was fortunate, because a
local business man ask me to come work for him in the
real-estate business. So, I went to school and got my
state license and started the middle of January. It
seems kind of odd not working in the agriculture field
even though 97% of their business is agricultural
land. Well, I've stayed with it for four months today
and not much is happening. With the economy the way it
is and so much agricultural land is old family land
and they really don't want to let it go. I was going
to ask you if you knew of any openings with the Dept.
of Agriculture. I would like to be out there making a
difference in the agriculture industry.

 A little of my background- I was raised in the citrus
industry and cattle. My family has been in Florida
agriculture for many generations. I have a degree in
Animal Science with a business minor from Berry
College in Rome, Ga. after graduation I moved to
Placedo, Texas and managed the 3X Ranch (oldest
Brahman Ranch in the US) for almost five years. I got
a little homesick not seeing my family but eight days
out of the year- that I moved back to Florida. I went
to work at the IFAS Range Cattle Station in Ona as the
Farm Adm. I remained there for five years and the
state kept telling me about a pay increase, but only
seemed to be able to change my title all the time. The
opportunity came and I went to work for Golden Gem
Growers (a grower owned citrus co-op) as a field rep.
I was responsible for fourteen counties in South and
Southwest Florida and some on the East Coast. I was
with them right at ten years, then the take over took
place and I walked away with nothing. I'm not giving
up on my new career, but it's hard when you are in the
second poorest county in the state, plus I miss my
full time agriculture work. I have been president of
our county Farm Bureau for the past seven years and
have been a big advocate of this industry all my life.
I truly know how important this industry is to our
state, being the second largest industry, but most of
all our life support system. I feel that Florida can
strive in our agriculture industry once again,
especially now that we have you. You are willing to
listen to our needs and our concerns, but most of all
willing to try and help our industry. We really need
to be pushing Florida Agriculture across the U.S. and
other countries. We grow and raise the highest quality
and safest product their is.

Also, being in the real estate business for a short
period of time, I have spent alot of time looking at
plat books. I didn't realize the state owned so much
land. I don't have a problem with this, but I do see
alot not being managed the way it should be. I didn't
know if the state had a land manager to over see the
other entities that managed the land (water districts,
mainly, wildlife land, ect.) I would like to see alot
of this land leased back to the farmer and rancher for
the tax role money. This way our state is still
receiving revenue off of it. Besides, who is going to
take better care of the land than someone in
agriculture, because they know the land is going to
take care of them. I really feel this plan is a win-
win for everybody. The state owns the land so it is
protected, you have the farmer/rancher taking care of
the land and placing the tax base loss back into the
state budget. It will work for everyone. Having
someone to over see this will more than pay for
itself.

I'm not sure what you can do for me if anything. Thank
you for your time and I appreciate you always willing
to listen to me and always responding. That means alot
to me and shows that you are concerned about the
people of Florida. If you need me to send a copy of my
resume to you, I will be glad to.

David B Royal

Wauchula  FL  33873
863-773-5646

-----Original Message-----
From: gene browning [mailto:wwwdotme@bellsouth.net]
Sent: Friday, May 17, 2002 2:06 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: DCF


I used to be a CPO in the navy.  When we had a large project looming all the officers and chiefs and high-ranking civilians would scurry to anf fro making plans, ordering supplies and setting schedules.  I used to make it ahabit to run all the plans by the lower rated persons because that was where the rubber met the road.  They would ask questions like: "How are you going to get that 48 inch machine through the 38 inch door."  Seemingly small items that were lost in the big picture.


About 3 years ago you and I met in Indian Harbor Beach.  I was trying to relate problems at DCF.  You gave me your e-mail address and I tried to explain the situation at DCF over the next few weeks.  I had also told the big shots from Orlando about the problems - for that I was fired.

These 4500 missing children are just the tip of the iceberg. When I was a Protective Investigator I found that the job itself was very rewarding.  The problem was the middle and upper level management's near-sightedness, and the lack of employees.  I was only allowed the have 30 cases - I had almost 200 (and I was still in training).

24 people started off in my training class and 24 in the class after me.  Within a year virtually all of them were no longer with the department.  I would like to have stayed with the department, and would go back even now.  But the attitude of the middle management needs to change.

I'll tell you more if you care to hear.



Gene Browning
Indialantic

-----Original Message-----
From: Deborah Richards [mailto:debandken@peoplepc.com]
Sent: Friday, May 17, 2002 3:26 AM
To: jscarborough@levinlaw.com
Subject: Michelle T. Bolin


Honorable Jeb Bush
Governor of the State of Florida
 
This letter comes to you from the heart of a mother.  My daughter, Michelle Bolin, is a Florida State prison inmate.  She is a paraplegic.  This is a result of the traffic accident she caused.  She was convicted of DUI manslaughter and sentenced to 15 years in prison in 1997.  Because of extremely negligent medical care she is now serving a death sentence.
 
Michelle was married and had two little girls who are now 9 and 8.  Their father has custody of them and is doing a great job of raising and caring for them as a single father.
 
Michelle's problem was addiction to drugs.  She would drink alcohol to enhance the effects of the drugs.  This was her condition the day of the accident.
 
Michelle and I both know that justice must be served for her crime.  For that reason we are not asking for anything but reasonable and adequate medical care so that she might survive her sentence and come home.
 
Her major medical problems began in September of 1999 when she was transferred to Lowell Correctional Institute in Ocala, Florida.  While there, she has had to have surgery for a colostomy, a permanent catheter, and developed decubitus ulcers on her buttocks.  These ulcers developed because of pressure from sitting too long in her  wheelchair.  (Her chair is custom made for her).  Because of her medical problems she has to see the prison doctor almost daily.  She is forced to sit and wait for hours  to see the doctor for so much as an aspirin.  She has lain and sat in her own urine because her catheter leaks.  This causes further infection which leads to pseudomonas infection which causes death.
 
The staff at Lowell are unable to care for her medical needs and have contributed further to her problems with unsanitary practices.  They have at times not worn gloves when changing her dressings and, at times left some of the old packing in the wound.
 
Michelle has twice been transferred to North Florida Reception Center (NFRC), which is a men's prison with a hospital facility, because of her medical condition.  She is currently housed at NFRC with large decubitus ulcers on both sides of her buttocks.  She has now developed osteomilytis, a bone infection, and a hole in her intestines.
 
Michelle has had four surgeries to close these ulcers since 1999.  This current situation is the worst yet.  This ulcer developed while at Lowell early this year.  In February the plastic surgeon, Dr. Obie, told her it needed to be closed right away in order to prevent enlargement and infection.  At that time she still had enough good tissue on her buttocks to use for the procedure.  That is in doubt now.  The previous surgeries have used all of the available muscle tissue for a muscle flap procedure to close the sores.
 
The medical staff at Lowell was supposed to transfer her back to NFRC for this procedure in April but  there was always an excuse.  "The van broke down" is a favorite.  After 8 missed appointments, I called the Regional Director of impaired inmates, Dr. Diane Rechtine.  After hearing the problem, she immediately ordered an ambulance transfer to NFRC.  It is now May 16, and still nothing has been done.  The ulcers on her behind are now down to the bone.  A staff member called me, jeopardizing her job,  to tell me that Michelle is in very bad shape and even urged me to get an attorney.  The medical staff at NFRC said that Michelle has too many doctors involved in her case and cancelled the plastic surgeon, the very doctor she needs the most.  I don't understand this and no one will give me or Michelle any answers.
 
I have spoken with Mr. Emile Baudoin, Coordinator of impaired inmates, several times and he has assured me he would look into the problems but nothing changes.
 
Michelle's custom made wheelchair needed repairs in January.  She had to write a grievance to get the repairs and it still has not been repaired.  Her chair helps to relieve the pressure on her spine when sitting for prolonged periods.  The chair is still at Lowell.  It should have been fixed and transferred with her.
 
These problems just scratch the surface.  Michelle's medical records cover seven volumes.
 
Governor Bush, from one parent to another, I am asking for your help and or guidance to save my daughter's life.
 
There are only two women's prisons in Florida, Lantana in South Florida and Lowell in North Florida.  Can she possibly be transferred to some facility here in Northwest Florida such as a county jail or correctional facility?  There is no state prison for women in Nothwest Florida, but there is certainly a need for one.
 
I was told today that if someone does not help Michelle soon, she will die.  
 
I am not asking for Michelle's sentence to be reduced or for an early release.  I only ask that she be accorded the human and humane treatment that she has been refused.
 
Thank you for listening.
 
Debbie Richards
4866 Blakemore Drive
Pace, Florida  32571
(850) 994-2386 Home
(850) 435-7963 Work (Delta Air Lines)
 
Michelle T. Bolin
DC-0P05007
Lowell Correctional Institute
Women's Unit
Lowell, Florida  32663-0147
 
Emile Baudoin, Coordinator, Impaired Inmates
2601 Blair Stone Road
Tallahassee, Florida  32399-2580
(850) 922-6645
 
Dr. Diane Rechtine, Regional Director
(407) 207-7341
Tallahassee, Florida  32399-2580

Friday Afternoon May 17, 2002

Dear Governor Bush,

I am writing to ask for your help in a serious matter
that needs your immediate attention.

In Miami, there is a community known as Miramar/Vista
Verte. In this community resides retirees, single moms
with numberous children, disabled citizens, emotional
and mentally handicapped and primarily low income
families. 

Miramar/Vista Verte is a community of townhouses, all
one story situated over several blocks. A total of 511
residences are located inside of this community. The
ethnic background of the majority of the residents of
this community is Hispanic. It is conviently located
next to the Florida Turnpike.

As relayed to me by my friend Tay here are the details
of what she has shared with me.

There has been an ongoing problem for years of outside
individuals trying to take control of the community
for apparent reasons of financial gain. A Homeowners
Association has taken control of this community and
made the residents LEGALLY subject unto them.

This Homeowners Association is contolled by a
management company. One if not both of the owners of
the homeowners association management company appear
to be attorneys licensed by the bar association.

The people of this community have not been able to
break away from the clutches of the Homeowners
Association that have taken control of their
community. None of the aggressors reside within the
community. Now 378 of the residences are being
foreclosed because of leins placed on their properties
in reference to the Homeowners Association. 

The people of this community NEVER agreed to having
this Homeowners Association in the first place. It has
been forced upon them. My friend Tay has never paid
the $35 per month homeowners fee assessed to her. She
can not afford to pay a homeowners association
anything. The small amount of money she has must be
spent on food, clothing, medicine, school for her
children, electricity, etc. It is wrong to force a
lien on her for a homeowners association that she
never agreed to. But that is exactly what has
happened. And the legal instruments have been filed by
the HOA to complete the job!

Last week I went to Miami to visit my friend. 

In looking into the faces of Tay's children (ranges 6
to 21) as I watched them work, do their homework and
constructively spending their time on the computer. I
ask myself? Where are these children going to live?
OMG They have the security of a home, food and shelter
here. What if their home is foreclosed on? What would
happen to them then? How would this affect their
lives?

They have no one to defend them. There is a church
involved in the foreclosures. The church has been
designated by the Miami Legal Services as "their
client", therefore there is a conflict of interest for
any representation.

My friend is subject to losing her home. When she
loses her home so will the six children whom all live
with her. She recently had surgery for the removal of
breast cancer. She need help!!! The people who own the
management company are filing the FINAL paperwork to
foreclose on her home, WRONGFULLY...Tay has boxes and
boxes of proof that will support the information that
I have shared with you.

Seems to me,,,that you being her Governor and my
Governor...and when all other sources for help have
been depeleted that it is time for you to step into
this matter to offer assistance and protection for her
and those others being WRONGFULLY foreclosed on in
this neighborhood. Please help my friend Governor
Bush,,,please help Tay, her 6 children and the other
residents of Miramar. They are citizens of Florida and
need you!!!

I ask you to please do the right thing in this case
and to send justice and peace to their community. Soon
they will be homeless if you do not help them based on
the time frame of all the legal paperwork that has
been filed with the courts.

I hope you will contact me.. ASAP..and that I can
direct you to my friend Tay in Miami...

May God Bless You and Be With You Always and as you
make the right decision in helping these defenseless
people.

Sincerely,

Sharon Hirschfield

From:	WR290@aol.com
Sent:	Saturday, May 18, 2002 5:27 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Please veto HB 1307

BT Builders Inc 
1773 Blount Rd. # 303 
Pompano Beach, Florida 33069 

954-975-5102 Phone 
954-978-3066 Fax 

May 18, 2002 

Governor Jeb Bush 
The Capitol 
Tallahassee, Florida 

Re: Veto House Bill 1307 

Dear Governor Bush; 

We met about four years ago at a Holiday Inn where you we presenting a speech to a disabled group. At that speech I asked you a question, "taken that if a bill was to come before you that eliminate accessibility would you sign it." You were offended for the question. It was not my intent to offend you, but to open your eyes up to that fact. After the meeting we spoke, but not of that issue. 

Well,  it appears that is exactly what is before you in House Bill 1307. I ask you to veto this bill and not let this bill go into law without your signature. 

Florida has always been the forefront to allow all our citizens in our great state,  to access buildings  and to be able work,  in all of our buildings in our great state. 

The law before you, has such a drastic negative impact that it will take those opportunities away. I know,  you are a strong believer in human rights and I know,  you would never intentionally hurt the civil rights of our disabled population, and for that,  was the reason I wanted you in office and voted for you, because I know,  you would,  and have protected  the rights of our disabled citizens and you do care. 

Another negative impact to this bill is relating to the  private inspection service which will be a  life safety concern to our citizens of our state. 


Please believe me, I am a great opponent for privatization. It's just the language in this bill that concerns me, It states that a private inspector, has to sign an affidavit to the best of his knowledge.   

As I am licensed building official, it has always been my responsibility by Florida Statue 468 to ensure ( guarantee) that the buildings I inspect have been built according to all the law's of Florida, not to the best of my knowledge. ( This is a negative impact and a life safety concern). An example of this; I may have gotten my license when the law just came into effect and have obtained my minimum requirements of 16 hours of continuing education every two years. This does not mean I am aware of the many changes that occur to our statues as currently required. ( Ensure ( guarantee)). I can just sign the affidavit and the Building Official has to accept it. This in my opinion is a life safety concern. 

Attached find a letter from the Broward County Board of Rules and Appeals addressing this bill from another aspect. 

The letter speaks from the point of home rule. Even though this would be a statue, not all the counties in the state would be required to adhere to it. If in fact it was equal to the language in Florida Statue 468, then perhaps it would be adopted by the local counties administrate chapters of the new Florida Building Code. , which would make it a positive impact. 

For the above reasons I ask you to veto HB 1307 and do not allow this bill to become law without your signature. 

Please feel free to contact me if you have any questions. 

Sincerely: 
Thomas J. Ricci CBO

From: Mark Maxwell [mailto:maxwellmark@msn.com]

Subject: K-12 Data


Governor:

Attached is a file containing the FEFP funding increases for you 1st term in
office.  Pay attention to the 1st two tabs.  The "Historical Bush" tab has
increases by district, 1st three and 1st four years.  The first three years
are provided FYI.  What I see as the most powerful message is the
relationship between the percentage increase in funds compared to the
perecentage increase in students.  For instance, in your 1st term, statewide
K-12 enrollment grew by 10.4% while statewide total funding grew by a
whopping 27.1%.  Take the same comparison for a specific district....Duval
enrollment grew by 1.3% while total funding grew by 14.5%.  The other tab
has some comparison data that you might interest you.

Let me know if you have any questions on this info.  I look forward to a
very successful Bush/Brogan re-election campaign!

Mark

-----Original Message-----
From: Paul Ferguson [mailto:paulferguson@worldnet.att.net]
Sent: Thursday, May 16, 2002 10:30 AM
To: Jeb Bush; Dennis Baxley (E-mail); Rod Smith (E-mail)
Subject: Home owner foreclosures by Home Owners Associations


	I have been reading about people across Florida losing their homes --
including one tragic story in Ocala two years ago -- because property owners
have failed to pay Home Owners Association dues -- for whatever reason.
This is obviously getting to be a major problem. I understand there are
about 378 such foreclosures pending now, and I am told 12 sales on the
courthouse steps today in various counties.
	Admittedly, all or certainly most of these property owners have had notice
from their associations.  In some cases, particularly with older people,
there may be real troublesome cases where widows (or widowers for that
matter) simply do not understand what they are getting in the mail.
Sometimes it is just stubbornness.

	Every problem ahs a solution if we will but seek it out. As a solution that
I believe is worth considering, and I believe would be a good issue for you
to solve the problem with is to:

	Propose to the legislature a different way of handling the matter. 	If
property owners assessments were handled like unpaid property taxes . . . a
certificate sold this year, another certificate sold next year and then a
court ordered foreclosure with proper advertising, notice etc AFTER the two
certificates . . . the chances of a real tragic case slipping through the
cracks would be lessened considerably.

	I am not a lawyer and do not know just how to make it work, and I am sure
the homeowners association lobbyists will object . . . but government can do
anything it wants to solve real or imagined problems.  This is an issue that
is embarrassing to every public official when questions arise.  In a case
here two years ago, Ed Dean, an attorney who was named Sheriff late in the
Chiles administration to replace a popular sheriff who stole county money,
had his own old law firm buying a widow's house during his campaign.
Fortunately, we were able to get it worked out for the time being, and the
lady got her house back but later was declared incompetent when it was about
to go to be sold again . . . but a delay process such as I suggest might
really help the situation.

	I am going to propose this to Dennis Baxley and Rod Smith too.  I hope you
will get your people to figure out a way to make it work, and let's solve a
real problem.
	And thanks for being our Governor!!!

	Paul Ferguson
	Ocala

-----Original Message-----
From: KRobin0234@aol.com [mailto:KRobin0234@aol.com]
Sent: Tuesday, May 14, 2002 10:07 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Response to Governor Bush's question at Wimauma Elementary
School on May 14th


Dear Governor Bush,
    During your visit to Wimauma Elementary School in Hillsborough County 
today, May 14th, you asked Betty Womack, their math specialist, to have the 
author of the math centers series that she uses to contact you.  I have to 
admit that I am the author.  

I originally wrote them for my classroom students in grades 3-5 to support my 
math instruction.  My students never remembered the concepts that they needed 
to know since most math series allocate one chapter per concept resulting in 
students only practicing the concept for a short period.  This lack of 
repetition results in students not retaining most of the concepts for a full 
year.  During 20+ years of teaching I realized that my students struggled in 
16 areas of math.  I developed sequential centers in each area with a 
question or two per day for the students to maintain their skill, practice 
the concept, and have fun doing it.  I also employed material that students 
would see and use in the outside world.  For example, they learned time with 
TV, movie, amusement park and tide schedules; perimeter and area used 
architectural plans; temperature used newspapers like weather maps; weight & 
mass weighed everyday items like cans of beans; etc.  

I wrote the centers to compliment any math program in use.  My ideal math 
lesson involved a 45 minute-session of the standard curriculum math and then 
my students would actively participate in each of the 16 centers for an 
additional 30 minutes four days per week.  I used the fifth day of each week 
for active math involvement activities.  Children enjoy these centers 
immensely and at the same time were meeting and exceeding FCAT standards.  I 
am happy to report that a large number of schools in Florida are using the 
centers with great success.  I will gladly provide you their names at your 
request.  Please feel free to contact me if you have any questions.

Best of luck in your re-election bid!  Go Jeb!

Yours truly,
Kathy Robinson
www.writemath.com 
813 685 0392





From:	Sidney Miller <sidneymiller@cfl.rr.com>

-----Original Message-----
From: Sidney Miller [mailto:sidneymiller@cfl.rr.com] 
Sent: Saturday, May 18, 2002 6:45 PM
To: 'Lorna Noren'
Cc: Bush Jeb (Business Fax); Tom Feeney (Business Fax); Senator Lee
Constantine; David Mealor (mealor.david@leg.state.fl.us);
'diezj@doi.state.fl.us'; LAWHUN.CARISSA
Subject: State Farm request to increase rates

Lorna Noren

Lorna,

Please consider me an intervener in the State Farm request for a rate
increase. Their motivation to increase Florida rates is driven from 2
causes. 

First, they have invested poorly creating a $1.2 Billion corporate loss.
This is not due to claims or natural disasters, but due primarily to
poor investment decisions at State Farm corporate.

Secondly, their internal processes are unbelievably inefficient and
incredibly difficult for customers to understand and utilize. As a 42
year customer who changed from State Farm this year, I have first hand
recent experience of just how incredibly poorly they manage claims and
billing. 

They have used their losses due to poor investment strategies to
consumer disadvantage and should not be allowed to increase rates
because of poor management. The state should not be a party to allowing
poorly managed companies to gouge consumers who are already
disadvantaged from home damage.

Mssrs. Diez and Lawhun,

Please ensure that Mr. Feeney ,Mr. Constantine, and Mr. Gallagher are
personally aware that this action is a thinly veiled consumer gouging
act (in an election year) by a company that does not deserve their
support.
If elected officials will only pause for staff to research the basis for
corporate losses, I think the case for a rate increase will come
crashing down.

Many investors have lost ground in the past 12 months but are not
seeking support from the state to recover losses from consumers.


Sid Miller 


-----Original Message-----
From: Lorna Noren [mailto:NorenL@doi.state.fl.us] 
Sent: Friday, May 17, 2002 2:44 PM
To: sidneymiller@cfl.rr.com
Subject: RE: How do I comment on State Farm request to increase rates

Mr. Miller: 
 
As you may know, Florida requires companies to submit their rates to the
Department of Insurance and justify the need for any increase.  The
Department reviews these rates to ensure that they are not excessive or
unfairly discriminatory.  However, Florida Law permits rate increases if
they can be justified so the company can continue to provide benefits
under their policies.

We will pass your comments on to the area that reviews the request for
increases.  Some of the information they look at is the loss experience
versus premiums paid plus operating expenses.  

Thank you for taking the time to let us know your thoughts. 

Sincerely,

Lorna J. Noren, CPM, PAHM, MCP
Insurance Specialist III 
Florida Department of Insurance



-----Original Message-----
From: Sidney Miller [mailto:sidneymiller@cfl.rr.com]

Conversation: How do I comment on State Farm request to increase rates
Subject: How do I comment on State Farm request to increase rates


Webmaster,
Please forward this to appropriate entities in State Government
responsible for approving State Farm's request for a rate increase.
It's my belief that State Farm Florida is a poorly managed enterprise. I
was a customer for 42 years. They can manage their customer base more
effectively, not more expensively.
The rate increase is simply compensation for State Farm's failure to
serve its customer base. My final 2 experiences cost State Farm a
substantial amount (internal administrative expense) and left me
dissatisfied enough to change companies after 42 years. The unusual
process for handling claims is foreign to customers but well understood
and manipulated by State Farm to the significant disadvantage of
taxpayers.
Giving them a rate increase without demanding improvements in service
and performance is simply giving them a governmental approval to
continue to be ineffective.
Sid Miller

-----Original Message-----
From: Anne & Chuck Edwards [mailto:aedward1@cfl.rr.com]
Sent: Saturday, May 18, 2002 6:53 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: question from teachers


After much discussion with fellow teachers this past week about your visit, I was chosen to ask why the FCAT standards/expectations were not introduced to all students entering the first grade in such and such a year and thus implemented over 12 consecutive years while being monitored on a yearly basis, making adjustments to the curricula and calendar as needed?  It seems to us that this would have reduced the failure rate, the stress level and the accountability concerns as every teacher, student and school would have the necessary time to work towards those standards.  We don't think there is an educator out there who doesn't believe in the FCAT but rather is more concerned with how it has been implemented ...."the cart before the horse"...so to speak.
Thanks
Anne Edwards
