****************
NEWS RELEASE
****************


AMERICAN FARM BUREAU FEDERATION
Public Relations
225 Touhy Avenue, Park Ridge, IL 60068

Contacts:		Mace Thornton		Amy Bakker
			847-685-8755			847-685-8751
			macet@fb.org <mailto:macet@fb.org>
amyb@fb.org <mailto:amyb@fb.org>


Farm Bureau Challenges Plowing Decision in U.S. Supreme Court

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE

PARK RIDGE, Ill., May 16, 2002 -- The American Farm Bureau Federation
has filed a friend-of-the-court brief in the U.S. Supreme Court on
behalf of a California farming operation. The Borden Ranch orchard and
vineyard has been prevented from expanding by federal agencies that
claim routine deep plowing is not a "normal farming activity." The
Supreme Court is being asked to grant a review of this earlier decision
from the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals.

The Borden Ranch orchard and vineyard, located in Sacramento County,
Calif., has been prohibited from planting additional vineyards on its
private farmland due to faulty interpretations of federal wetlands
regulations and of allowances for normal farming activities. The U.S.
Army Corps of Engineers and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency
have ruled that routine deep plowing, required to plant the vineyards,
"pollutes" the temporary wetlands with dirt. The agencies claim,
therefore, that a permit is required.

According to the Farm Bureau brief, Section 404 of the Clean Water Act
(CWA), which governs wetlands, clearly contains an "exemption of normal
farming practices from the burden of the...permit program." The lower
court ruling, according to AFBF, "expands the reach of the CWA far
beyond what Congress intended, at best creating uncertainties about
permissible conduct and at worst exposing farmers and ranchers pursuing
routine farming activities to substantial penalties."

"The federal agencies, especially the Environmental Protection Agency,
Corps of Engineers and the Fish and Wildlife Service, with the aid of
the lower courts, have been happy to cooperate in expanding the reach of
the Section 404 wetlands program," AFBF stated. "Now the Ninth Circuit
has planted the seeds for further expansion."

AFBF is concerned about the ramifications of the lower court's decision
because it:

*	Narrows the normal farming exemption of Section 404 of the CWA
and places the Corps of Engineers and the EPA in the business of
regulating day-to-day farming and ranching practices.
*	Rules that normal agricultural plowing can result in the
discharge of a pollutant (soil).
*	Finds that a farmer or rancher's plow can be defined as a point
source of pollution.
*	And expands interpretations of the Section 404 so that a farmer
or rancher would not be able to change his or her cropping patterns
without a federal permit out of concern of a penalty for violating the
CWA.

According to the AFBF brief, deep ripping (plowing) is a normal tillage
practice and is, therefore, "a normal farming or ranching activity that
is excluded or exempted from Section 404 regulation."

"As this case perfectly demonstrates, implementation of the normal
farming exemption has not proceeded as Congress intended...and (has) not
fulfilled Congress' aim of minimizing the interference of federal
regulators in the routine decisions of farmers and ranchers," AFBF
stated.

"This is not a case about a farmer or rancher indiscriminately
discharging dredged or fill material into navigable waters. This is a
case of a farmer attempting to plant a different crop on his farmland, a
very normal farming activity."

If review is granted by the Supreme Court, the appeal will be heard by
the nation's highest court during its 2002-2003 fall term.

(30)

-----Original Message-----
From: Genltben@aol.com <Genltben@aol.com>
To: Jeb Bush <jeb@jeb.org>
Sent: Mon May 20 11:26:10 2002
Subject: To Governor Bush from Ben Ritter, Paralyzed Veterans of America in Tampa

May 18. 2002                          Concerning HB 1307

Dear Governor Bush:

We met last Tuesday morning at the Tampa Vandenburg Airport.  Thank you for 
taking the time to listen to me.  I apologize for throwing a curve ball at 
you, but I needed to get your attention on the negative aspects of HB 1307.  
Six PVA members, including myself, had met with Alan Florez and Kevin Tang 
and others on May 2nd, but after the meeting, we got the sense that we hadn't 
"gotten through" to them.  You put me in touch Tuesday morning with Greg 
Turbeville. When I spoke with Greg, he assured me that he will investigate 
the issues that PVA and others have raised.

In spite of what Julie Shaw told us at the Florida Building Commission 
Hearings in St. Pete Beach last Monday, people with disabilities are 
convinced that this is a bad bill.  Also, code officials do not like the 
"privatization" aspect of 1307.  The "Waiver Process" system is working OK 
now.  We don't need a 20% cap on accessibility renovations.  If it ain't 
broke, why fix it?

By the way, I was a resident of New Jersey, a businessman and a member of the 
NJ Republican Party before I moved to Tampa five years ago.  I was a neighbor 
of Christie Whitman and was on her election campaign committee. We went to 
the same church.  I was present on the Whitehouse lawn when your dad signed 
the Americans With Disabilities Act on July 26, 1990.  Before your election 
to Governor, you and I talked at a Republican Rally at the Hyatt in Tampa.  
Based on my experiences as a wheelchair-user, I offered these words of 
wisdom:  

"People with disabilities perceive that Democrats do more for them than 
Republicans."  

Since your election to the Florida Statehouse, you and your administration 
have earned the respect of Floridians with disabilities.  May I request that 
you follow through and veto 1307?  Allow time for a thorough review and a 
rewrite of this bill during the 2003 legislative session.  

Respectfully yours,

Ben Ritter
Government Relations Director
Florida Gulf Coast Chapter
Paralyzed Veterans of America
121 W. 122nd Avenue
Tampa, FL  33612
(813) 935-6540

From:	Campsmoak@aol.com
Sent:	Monday, May 20, 2002 2:38 PM
To:	colleencastille@myflorida.com
Subject:	Docks, Port of the Islands, Lee County, New Plans

Colleen, 

1) I am assuming that I will not hear back from you on the Lee County dock permit issue - unless there is still "dialogue" going on with Atlanta? It's been over a month. Is the Governor aware that people cannot get permits to build single-family docks in Lee County? 

2) I don't understand why you continue telling people that you differ with me on whether or not the Federal restrictions in Port of the Islands forced me out of business. The "no in-water construction zone" has been in place for years - so I am told, and I was allowed to work. But, now, the zones have been made public, and the last communication from USFW on the subject (facilitated by you) made it clear to me that the zone would be enforced from this time forward. If this information was accurate, and I had kept working, I would have been forced to close my operation in mid-stream. I chose to give my employees notice, and let them find other work. I also chose to quit charging supplies, equipment & repairs as I could not carry a heavy debt load if my business could not operate during that time. 

I did come up to Naples, and I tried to farm new work - but in the dock business, specifically in our market, selling a job has a 2 month to 1 year lead time. I could not fill my schedule as the majority of our waterfront people were out of town during the time I had to make my decision. 

Let's assume that I followed your advice, and kept on working through the "no in-water construction window" in defiance of the law that was brought to my attention. How long would it have been before the "Club" would have lowered the boom on my operation? Who would have paid my ongoing business expenses, legal fees, fines, etc? In the private sector, we weigh risks - especially those of us that pay last month's bills with this month's proceeds. The FACT that the zones were to be enforced, the pressure that was being brought to bear from the "environmental" community, and the lack of response from our State Government made my mind up for me. I CHOSE not to VIOLATE the federal rule. Are you saying - to me, Commissioner Rood, and whoever else heard the conversation between you and Bonnie - that you condone my working in defiance of a federal rule designed to protect manatees? 

I can't afford that risk. January 10th, 2,000, I wrote the Governor, and laid out my concerns. He instructed you to schedule a meeting with me - which you never did. The rest is history, and was in the best interests of my family. 

3) Now, Lee County is under a Federal ban on the issuance of single family docks. Again, I have tried to work within the bounds of the established chain of communication. Again, response is slow - if there is any at all. The fact that manatee mortality sky-rocketed the year that the new FFWCC plans were implemented in Lee County has not been revisited - even though Jim Antista and David Arnold both say that something is wrong "down there." Arnold, Hartman, & Kipp Frolich have all been asked about the situation. All tell me that I am wrong - that the new zones did not exacerbate the mortality problem. But nobody can give me another explanation - they won't even try! 

4) The most disturbing thing is that the new plans that we reviewed with David Arnold last week all look very similar to the Lee County plan - vast shore-line buffer zones that force all vessel traffic into the intracoastal channels. Our questions continue to go unanswered, more restrictions are being discussed, planned, and implemented, and more people are being hurt - both economically and by the permanent alteration of their life-styles. 

The frustration of the masses is higher than I have ever seen it - but the people, for the most part, have lost the urge to go to meetings and speak. They did that for a whole year, and neither Staff nor the Governor's office would, or could help. They now feel as though it is a waste of their time to participate - that driving to meeting after meeting after meeting - attended by a VAST majority of boaters - went un-noticed, or ignored by those in any position to help. The people now say that they will take their concerns to the polls in November. 

Things are not getting better - they are getting worse. 

Jim Kalvin
From:	JJRV@aol.com
Sent:	Monday, May 20, 2002 2:41 PM
To:	shirley.collins@dca.state.fl.us
Subject:	Thank You From The Wind Storm Consortium Of Florida

Dear Ms. Collins;


     I would like to thank you and your staff for taking the time to meet with the Wind Storm Consortium of Florida Friday. 

     I'm looking forward in working with you and I believe that we will be able to learn a great deal from you and your staff. It is very obvious that you all have a great deal of experience to share with the consortium members.

    Ms. Collins, the agenda of the consortium is a very simple. It is designed to offer help and experiences from the private sector to make an even more positive difference on the wind storm risk we all face. We feel that you and your staff have put in place with the new building codes, a great platform to expand on. We feel that going the next step by forming a public-private partnership that focuses on even  stronger building will pave the way for stronger mandated building codes in the years to come. When we started forming the consortium I was impressed with desire that we found from the members to focus on the wind storm issues and come up with the suggestions that we have shared with you and your staff. The consortium has great concerns on this issue due to the fact that the wind storm issue effects each and every homeowner in our state. If not addressed now, it will be a much larger issue for their children and so on. I hope that you recognized that on Friday. Also exciting is the related positive influences that our partnership will create. For example, 850 plus job very quickly, education for unskilled labor, the drive for more technology, and a think tank of new idea's and products in one location focusing on one common cause. That added value will benefit all of us here in Florida. This opportunity has possibilities that we have not even come close to uncovering. Now we both have the opportunity to uncover them, together. I will predict that this public-private partnership will become a model for the rest of country, not only to midigate wind damage and drive new technologies and create needed jobs. We can demonstrate what can be accomplished when two motivated partes come together under the structure of a public-private partnership to protect one of life's major staples, homeownership. 


     Again, thank you for taking the time to meet with the consortium members last Friday. I'm looking forward to working with you and your staff.

Thank You,


Jay E Jones, Consortium Chairman,

St. Petersburg, FL  33701


Mark Howard's May 2002 editor's page, "Political Football," fumbled the data
on per-pupil spending in Florida's public schools.

He states that our claims of funding increases are "true in the aggregate,
but spending per student has fallen."  In fact, funding per-student has
increased over the past four years, despite huge growth in the number of
students attending Florida's public schools.

We have increased funding by 27 percent, while the number of students has
increased by 10.5 percent.  Next year's $1.1 billion increase, for example,
is a 9 percent increase in total funds and still a 6 percent increase per
student.  Districts will receive on average $295 more per student next year
than this year.

Although accountability and performance - not funding - are the most
important criteria in judging Florida's public schools, our funding record
is better (in the aggregate, per-student, adjusted for inflation, however
you want to count it) than that of my predecessor in either of his two
terms.

I welcome honest debate on how we can build on the success of the last four
years in Florida's public schools.  But misinformation about funding makes
honest debate less likely to happen.



Sincerely,



Jeb Bush


Mark Busse
Chief Speechwriter
Office of Governor Jeb Bush

JEB IN WONDERLAND

     Once upon a time, in a land far, far away, there was a tropical paradise called Phlorida.  The people there were generally happy, but they had a problem with their children.  They were all born needing hospitalization, and the caring adults were quite concerned as many of their children, after spending years in hospitals, and finally leaving with "Certificates of Excellent Health," seemed unable to function well.  The Hospital Leaders said "Everything is fine in this best of all possible tropical paradises, and, look, almost all your children have Certificates of Excellent Health!"  "But," said the parents, "many of them can't walk or talk."  "How can you tell?" asked the Health Leaders, "They look fine to us, but just give us some more money and everything will be even better!"

     And so for many years the parents did just that, but things didn't seem to change much.  "If only the children weren't so young, or so small, or if we only had more money for the doctors and nurses, then things would be even better,...and, anyway, look at ALL these health diplomas, things are fine!" said the Health Leaders.

     Then one day the Phloridians elected (yes, really!) a new governor named Jeb. Half the voters said, "He's too tall," the other half said, "He's not too bright," and the other half said, "Maybe he'll help our kids."  (You see, in Phlorida elections, half plus half plus....oh, never mind.)

     Well, Jeb visited the hospitals and asked, "Just how sick are these kids?"  "They're fine," said the Health Leaders, "Just give us more money and go away."  "They're sick," said the parents, "Look, many of them can't even sit up!"

     Jeb said, "Well, why don't we count how many can sit up, how many can walk, and how many can talk, and if there are some hospitals where almost no one can do this, let's let those kids go to a different hospital?"  

     "Gee," said the Health Leaders, "You really are not too bright, are you?  Of course we can't count what the kids can do, and even if we did, what would that prove?  Look how happy they are! Look how pretty the hospital rooms are!  We deal with the whole patient here, not just with their physical condition."

     "But, said Jeb, "you people are running hospitals, and we really need to see that our kids are healing......"

     "No, no, no, you just don't get it, do you?" said the Hospital Leaders. "It wouldn't be fair to measure health and, anyway, there's no accurate way to do it, and some hospitals, where no one is getting better, might not get any new patients and just think what that would cost the taxpayer!  If only the kids didn't have such short hair, or so little money, things would be different."

     And so it became clear to all Phloridians that the only answer was to elect a different governor.

----- Original Message -----
From:    "Paul"
To:        "Bob Janauskus (E-mail)" <wishfer@worldnet.att.net>
cc:        doranb36@aol.com
Sent:     Thursday, May 16, 2002 11:21 AM

Bob,

I sent this message to the Governor, Rep. Dennis Baxley and Senator Rod
Smith:
********************************
I have been reading about people across Florida losing their homes --
including one tragic story in Ocala two years ago -- because property owners
have failed to pay Home Owners Association dues -- for whatever reason.

This is obviously getting to be a major problem. I understand there are
about 378 such foreclosures pending now, and I am told 12 sales on the
courthouse steps today in various counties.

Admittedly, all or certainly most of these property owners have had notice
from their associations.  In some cases, particularly with older people,
there may be real troublesome cases where widows (or widowers for that
matter) simply do not understand what they are getting in the mail.

Sometimes it is just stubbornness.

Every problem has a solution if we will but seek it out. As a solution that
I believe is worth considering, and I believe would be a good issue for you
to solve the problem with is to:

Propose to the legislature a different way of handling the matter. If
property owners assessments were handled like unpaid property taxes . . . a
certificate sold this year, another certificate sold next year and then a
court ordered foreclosure with proper advertising, notice etc AFTER the two
certificates . . . the chances of a real tragic case slipping through the
cracks would be lessened considerably.

I am not a lawyer and do not know just how to make it work, and I am sure
the homeowners association lobbyists will object . . . but government can do
anything it wants to solve real or imagined problems. This is an issue that
is embarrassing to every public official when questions arise.

In a case here two years ago, Ed Dean, an attorney who was named Sheriff
late in the Chiles administration to replace a popular sheriff who stole
county money, had his own old law firm buying a widow's house during his
campaign.

Fortunately, we were able to get it worked out for the time being, and the
lady got her house back but later was declared incompetent when it was about
to go to be sold again . . . but a delay process such as I suggest might
really help the situation.

I am going to propose this to Dennis Baxley and Rod Smith too.  I hope you
will get your people to figure out a way to make it work, and let's solve a
real problem.

And thanks for being our Governor!!!

Paul
Ocala

=============================================================

-----Original Message-----
From: steve hughes [mailto:shughesfl@yahoo.com]
Sent: Wednesday, May 15, 2002 9:24 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: RE: FCAT irregularity fup


Dear Governor:

Seven weeks after my e-mail to you , our test results
for FCAT came in (today).  Not one word about any
re-take, just a notation that we had slight
improvement in our scores.

In the intervening seven weeks, the other teacher who
reported irregularities has been "railroaded" out of
his job and an obvious (to me) campaign of harassment
has begun against me.

This is the thanks one gets for trying to do what's
right - and for trying to obey the law, even if it
means "whistle-blowing" on their own place of
employment?

I no longer wonder why so few people ever bother to do
so.
Never again will I bother to do so either.

Disappointed,

Steve Hughes
SHUGHESfl@yahoo.com

> Osceola

> areas of concern...appropriate actions have been
> taken

> remain a mystery to me.

> to

> the
> fact that from a legal standpoint, once the findings
> are released all documents become public records,
> and
> can be accessed by any individual requesting them."
> This ending of the letter from the County office
> sounds like some sort of veiled threat against
> myself
> or others who felt it was our duty, our legal
> obligation, to report irregularities.
> 
> Since I have heard nothing further, I have a nagging
> suspicion that any "investigation" will remain in
> limbo until after the tests have been scored.  Then
> ,
> depending on the test results, test(s) may or may
> not
> be re-taken.
> 
> It is a horrible thing to believe that an
> administrator could be guilty of irregularities to
> begin with, but I witnessed - and attested to - many
> such examples. It is also very unpleasant to suspect
> any subsequent cover-up, but you can see that I
> clearly suspect precisely that.

> everyone involved - including of course, innocent
> students themselves.

> your

state? I would be willing to give you some pro bono assistance. It would
be

been

-----Original Message-----
From: Eduardo Stern <es@landstarhomes.com>
To: Jeb Bush <jeb@jeb.org>
Sent: Mon May 20 17:45:08 2002
Subject: Today's meeting.

Dear Mr. Governor:              
 
I want to take this opportunity to thank you profusely for your time today.  As you know, I share your passion for the safety, education, and overall well-being of children; especially the children of the great State of Florida, my home.
 
When I first learned about the program from the Save-A-Friend group, which I introduced you to this afternoon, I immediately recognized the benefits of having a centralized mechanism that would provide both consistency and efficiency to intelligence gathering about security threats to our schools, their respective students, teachers and administrators.  I was, and still am, excited about what such a program would mean to the State of Florida’s school systems. 
 
Given your leadership and unyielding commitment to protecting and educating Florida’s children, I felt an obligation to introduce you to the Save-A-Friend program and wanted you to hear directly from its authors.  Unfortunately, as I found out to my surprise in today’s meeting, pride of authorship may be getting in the way of an otherwise very good program that could be implemented at the state level.  I hope the Save-A-Friend group finds it wise to follow your advice; I have strongly recommended that they do. 
 
Warmest personal regards from your friend,
Eduardo Stern

-----Original Message-----
From: Victor Rose <vicr@adelphia.net>
To: Jeb Bush <jeb@jeb.org>
Sent: Mon May 20 11:06:46 2002
Subject: Re: Tenure for teachers tranferring from one county to another

Dear Governor Bush:

I hope this finds you doing well.

Last Friday, my fiancé Donna attended the Palm Beach County Job Fair to seek
employment in order to work closer to our home.  As you know, we presently
live in Palm
Beach County and Donna's present commute is about 45 minutes each way to and
from Sunrise, Florida.

There is a elementary school in Delray Beach about 7 miles from our house,
called Pine Grove.  Pine Grove's student body consist of students of low
income families, with low test scores.

Donna teaches fourth grade and has had enormous success working with low
income students who are below grade level.  Based on the makeup of Donna's
classroom, she continually achieves high FCAT test scores even higher than
schools in better areas like Boca Raton and other upscale communities. (see
test scores below). Donna achieves these high scores even though 95% of her
classroom receives free or reduced lunches.  Like I told you before, if all
things are equal, I will put Donna up against not only any fourth grade
teacher in Florida but any fourth grade teacher in the US.

Pine Grove is very interested in hiring Donna and would like to have her as
one of their teachers.   Unfortunately, if she moves from Broward County to
Palm Beach County, Palm Beach County will only accept 10 years and instead
of 12 and
they want to put her on a three year probation/annual contract.

I believe it is in your best interest and the State of Florida to make
exceptions in order to assist great teachers like Donna, to stay in the
profession as long as possible.  Also, it is not fair for teachers of
Donna's ability that have dedicated so many good years to the state
education program to be put on probation or lose two years just because they
are moving from one county to another.

I would greatly appreciated it if you would have someone contact me this
week to discuss this matter in more detail.  I can be reached on my cell
phone at 310.867.4365. Though my cell # is a LA number, I am located in Boca
Raton, Florida.

Thank you for your time and consideration to this matter.

Best regards,

Vic Rose

From:	Susan  Alyn <susanalyn@mindspring.com>
Sent:	Monday, May 20, 2002 9:58 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	This is NOT about FR

Gov, Bush, Do you think this is fair:

(1) FOX Tv's Hannity & Colmes is reporting that several Middle Eastern men
in
Connecticut were stopped after they were found to be videotaping a water
reservoir.
They were "stopped" by the FBI because the FBI thought they were terrorists
planning
to poison the water supply. The middle eastern men politely explain they
liked the view,
and that's why they were videotape. Since enjoying a view is not against the
law, the FBI
let the men go, and that's the end of it.

CONTRAST WITH:

(2) I was stopped by police in October 2000, who mistakenly thought my
search for a destination,
and my "weaving" they claimed they witnessed, is "PROBABLY CAUSE" in this
state to arrest
me for "DUI" and driving under the influence of DRUGS OR ALCOHOL. I just
received my
order from the Civil Court Judge today in this matter who basically said
this: there is no law
in this state concerning "what" exactly is probable cause. The fact that I
had a urine test showing
NO TRACE OF ANY DRUG IN MY SYSTEM, and two police officers testified and
wrote on my
arrest report NO SMELL OF ALCOHOL ON MY BREATH, and NO DRUGS OR ANYTHING
LIKE THAT
were found on my person, purse, or my car which they impounded, all did not
"count" as much
as one cop who claimed; he is an expert, he thought I was on drugs, and his
word is enough.
The judge agreed. To me, this is terrifying news for people who actually are
recovering
addicts (I AM NOT ONE), and who could be devastated by something like
this -- a MISTAKE
by an expert, who's "WORD" is more important than the LACK OF ANY AND ALL
PHYSICAL EVIDENCE
OF ANY CRIME.

Unlike the Middle Eastern guys who are quickly let go by the FBI after they
videotape a reservoir
for "the view" -- I, a woman who is a teacher and never been arrested and do
not do drugs or alcohol,
gets put jail for 14 hours, not allowed to make a phone call, and am now
told by this judge too: Well,
too bad honey.

A cop  "thinks" your weaving was drug-related, and, so: It is, according to
this civil court, which upheld
the license suspension (the one year suspension is already over).

Gov. Bush, not tonight, but when you have a chance, I would like to fax you
this court decision. There needs
to be a clearer law in this state, requiring these cops to have PHYSICAL
EVIDENCE of drug use
when they arrest someone for it in a DUI arrest. Right now - NO PHYSICAL
EVIDENCE is required from them.
Their "word" is enough.

Again, I shudder to think what this means for someone who is a recovering
addict, and has stayed clean. Who would you believe? The cops or the
recovering addict who tells
you the cops were wrong?

Well, under current state law, you are supposed to believe the cops,
even if there was no physical evidence of drugs, drug use or anything. Just
a minor traffic violation
is ENOUGH.

I say: NOT FAIR. Not fair to me, who has not used drugs now nor in the
past -- nor is it fair to
someone like your daughter who, when NOT using, could likewise be falsely
and wrongly arrested
like I was -- and,  find herself in this same boat, with worse consequences
because of her history.

"Probable cause" requirement, prior to a DUI arrest of an individual,
needs to be amended to: "probable cause consisting of physical evidence
beyond a traffic violation."

Because right now: anyone can be arrested for "driving while under the
influence of drugs"
even when (1) there are no drugs on the person, in the person, in the
person's car or anything,
and (2) the person is not driving under the influence of drugs -- but there
is an appearance of
such, because the person may be someone suffering from a panic attack, an
anxiety attack,
a bout of depression, whatever. This is not a criminal offense. Taking a
video of a reservoir
is not a criminal offense, even though it looks like one. But the FBI is
more lenient than a city cop
in this state. Seriously.

I will fax you this court decision on Saturday, and a brief letter less
emotional than this. It is
frightening to think the police in this state can just "say" a person
"looks" like her depression/anxiety/panic
is drug use - AND THE COURT SAYS: YEAH, THEY CAN JUST SAY IT. NO PHYSICAL
EVIDENCE
NEEDED.

Thank you if you read this.

Susan

From:	Doster, Brett <Brett.Doster@MyFlorida.com>
Sent:	Monday, May 20, 2002 11:10 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Tech Bill Signing

Governor,

Slater just told me that you had some concerns about our choice of locations
for the bill signing on Wednesday.  We were originally scheduled to do one
in Tampa with Chris Hart and one in Jacksonville with Jim King.  The event
in Jacksonville, however, is part of another scheduled event with the
opening of the Advanced Technology Center of the Florida Community College.
King, Hart, Klein, and Connie Mack all are either out of the state or out of
the country on the 22nd.  We are getting no bang for our buck with
legislators.  We were already going to be in Tampa for the Hurricane
Awareness Conference, and so we were concerned about a lack of press at the
bill signing.  With no legislators and concerns about no press, we cancelled
the event in Tampa before our conference with you this morning, and we
decided to keep the one in Jacksonville on the schedule because it was part
of an event that you were scheduled to attend with or without the bill
signing component.

However, you rightly noted, Chief, that this is a major victory that we need
to be holding high during these bill signings, and that is why we made the
move to put Orlando on the schedule.  I believe that the event in Orlando
will be a good one, and we will still have you home by 5:30.  If you need us
to revisit, we will definitely do so.

Brett

the person's opportunity to obtain the independent [urine] test and shall
provide the person with timely
telephone access to secure the test, but the burden is on the person to
arrange and secure the
test at the person's own expense."

Now, here is a fact: I knew I was not on drugs or alcohol, so I did ask to
use the phone,
immediately. And, they would not let me, For 14 hours they kept me
incarcerated, without
access to a phone, but when I did finally get to use the phone, I posted
bail and immediately
went and took an independent urine test. Yet, the police had no right to
interfer with my
right, by state law, to take that urine test ASAP.

I hope you will tell your daughter someday that she has the right to request
that. Even if they
deny her, like they did me, and tried to interfer with proof of innocence in
an unlawful arrest.

Why the court did not give greater weight to physical evidence of a urine
test, showing NO TRACE
of anything, as opposed to a cop's word of the appearance of drug use,
remains a mystery to me,
but I will appeal to the next level and keep trying.

Thanks, and again, sorry to bother you with this. But it is frightening how
this system works
when a person is not guilty.

Susan

>            316.1932  Breath, blood, and urine tests for alcohol, chemical
>substances, or controlled
>            substances; implied consent; right to refuse.--

>            3.  The person tested may, at his or her own expense, have a
>physician, registered nurse,
>            other personnel authorized by a hospital to draw blood, or duly
>licensed clinical laboratory
>            director, supervisor, technologist, or technician, or other
>person of his or her own choosing
>            administer an independent test in addition to the test
>administered at the direction of the law
>            enforcement officer for the purpose of determining the amount
of
>alcohol in the person's blood
>            or breath or the presence of chemical substances or controlled
>substances at the time alleged,
>            as shown by chemical analysis of his or her blood or urine, or
>by chemical or physical test of his
>            or her breath. The failure or inability to obtain an
independent
>test by a person does not
>            preclude the admissibility in evidence of the test taken at the
>direction of the law enforcement
>            officer. The law enforcement officer shall not interfere with
>the person's opportunity to obtain
>            the independent test and shall provide the person with timely
>telephone access to secure the
>            test, but the burden is on the person to arrange and secure the
>test at the person's own

-----Original Message-----
From: CAPE List [mailto:cape@capenet.org]
Sent: Monday, May 20, 2002 7:04 PM
To: lgkeegan@aol.com
Subject: CAPE Update -- National Moment of Remembrance


CAPE Update -- May 20, 2002

NATIONAL MOMENT OF REMEMBRANCE

The following is a letter to educators from Secretary of Education Rod Paige
regarding the National Moment of Remembrance to be observed on Memorial Day,
May 27.

-----------------------------

Dear Educators:

The White House Commission on the National Moment of Remembrance was
established by Congress to put the "memorial" back in Memorial Day.
Unfortunately, too many Americans have lost sight of the meaning of the
holiday.  In fact, the idea of the Moment was born in 1996 when children
touring our Nation's capital were asked what Memorial Day means and
responded, "That's the day the pools open."

As a member of the Commission, I am writing to ask for your support to
reclaim this noble holiday for its intended purpose of honoring those who
died in service to our great country.  On Memorial Day, May 27, a National
Moment of Remembrance will be observed by Americans everywhere at 3:00 p.m.
local time.  The theme is "One Nation, One Moment."  We need your help to
gain the broadest possible awareness and participation among young people.

Please let teachers and students know about the opportunity to participate
in a new American tradition simply by pausing wherever they may be at 3:00
p.m. for one minute to reflect on our fallen heroes.  They can encourage
their families and friends to join them.  The activities they are enjoying
on the holiday reflect the freedoms guaranteed by the sacrifices of the men
and women who gave their lives.  If they are driving at 3:00 p.m., they can
simply turn on their vehicle's headlights.

For schools that are still in session after the holiday, teachers can ask
students to recount how they observed the Moment.  This may be appropriate
to integrate into end-of-year classes and activities.

A variety of tools, including the Remembrance poster, are available to
download at the official website, www.remember.gov.  Click the "Download
Media" menu on the left side of the main page, and the poster is at the top
of the page under Artwork - it's the third file, National Moment of
Remembrance Poster Art.  You and your students are encouraged to download
and distribute the items as needed.

I hope that all educators and students will join with the President and me
in encouraging all Americans to honor the men and women who died in service
to our Nation and left us a legacy of service, a heritage of sacrifice, and
the gift of freedom.  Let us never forget.

Thank you for your support and participation.

Sincerely,

Rod Paige 

-----------------------------
Joe McTighe
Executive Director
Council for American Private Education (CAPE)
Tel - 301-916-8460
Fax - 301-916-8485
E-Mail - cape@capenet.org
Web - http://www.capenet.org


To unsubscribe from CAPE List, just follow this link:
http://www.capenet.org/mojo/mojo.cgi?f=u&l=CAPE_List&e=lgk@educationleaders.
org&p=8218
Click the link, or copy and paste the address into your browser.

-----Original Message-----
From: Bob & Candi McLester <mclester@sunet.net>
To: Jeb Bush <jeb@jeb.org>
Sent: Mon May 20 15:29:49 2002
Subject: Medicaid

The state pays for four "brand name" medications per month for medicaid
recipients.  There is no limit placed on the number of "generic" meds a
patient can receive.  Some generic manufacturers give their meds their
own "trade name."  Rugby pharmaceuticals is (was) the champion of this
practice.  Here is the problem.  Medicaid is treating these "branded
generics" as true "brand name" products and counting them against the
limit of four per month.  This should not be as the branded generics are
not true brand name products, and are generally as inexpensive as the
non-branded generic products.  Someone needs to look into this as soon
as possible.  Is there a "consultant job" here for me??????  You need
someone (a pharmacist) to assist here.  Later....................bob

-----Original Message-----
From: Langford, Brandi 
Sent: Monday, May 20, 2002 2:48 PM
To: Shanahan, Kathleen; Oviedo, Nina; Muniz, Katie; Dana, Pam
Cc: jeb@jeb.org; Freedman, Melissa; DiBenigno, Arlene
Subject: RE: Glades County/INS and Iberia / Aviation issue


Spoke with Sheriff Rider and Chief Holley.  Both confirmed that their
meeting with the local INS folks went well.  It was very positive and they
are moving forward with the building of the facility.  While they received
no written agreement, they did receive a verbal agreement.  
Their bond underwriters are secured and they are shooting for a July 11
deadline for having all the bonds sold and a closing date of July 30.  
The county commission has signed off on the land purchase.  They are
currently working on the interlocal agreement.
Sheriff Rider heard from Donald in Sen. Nelson's office.  Donald told the
Sheriff that Senator Nelson is meeting with James Zigler within the next few
weeks and will bring the situation up.

-----Original Message-----
From: Nina Oviedo [mailto:oviedon@sso.org]
Sent: Wednesday, May 15, 2002 10:33 AM
To: 'Muniz, Katie'; 'Dana, Pam'
Cc: 'Shanahan, Kathleen'; jeb@jeb.org; Clint Fuhrman (E-mail); Melissa
Freedman (E-mail)
Subject: Glades County/INS and Iberia / Aviation issue


Sorry---long but important.

The Governor should get all the credit.  I have been meaning to write....10
days ago I called the Miami INS Director's office and spoke with his COS,
John Shewairy, to talk about the Glades County facility.

Glades County-INS detention facility

I explained the Glades County situation, including the personal e-mails from
the Gov, the calls we receive from Sheriff Ryder and National INS, and the
calls we were getting from Congress Foley's office.  We were not making
progress with the National INS office and I thought that working with the
District Office might prove more helpful.  John promised to look into the
situation and meet with the Glades County officials.

John Shewairy called back last week----at our request, he and his team met
with Chief Ken Holley (I believe Sheriff Ryder's deputy) on 5/9-----John
reported that the meeting went very well.  INS cannot, legally, give Glades
a contractual promise to use the facility and Glades understands this...and
although there are no promises, John explained that all indications are that
there is a need for the facility and given the community's willingness,
interest, etc, the hope would be that if a facility were built...it will be
used.  But, this is not w/out risk.  If the community decides to build the
facility (they already have $30K in sunk costs), they will be making the
decision to assume the risk.  Apparently everyone went home happy.
(Clint----you might want to check in with the Glades County folks.)

Iberia/Aviation

While I had John on the phone I asked him to look into the Iberia
Customs/INS issue.  I explained our prior discussions with Customs
Commissioner Bonner's COS and told him about the Governor's letter.  I
explained that our airport team was telling us that it was truly an INS
problem and not Customs.  He jumped at the chance to help and promised to
get back.  He knew the issue and players.  This was last Thursday.  He has
yet to call me....my guess is that you're hearing about his efforts before
he's had a chance to call me back.  I think I should get confirmation from
John prior to a press release...we would hate to backtrack.  I will call him
this morning.

Nina

Importance: High


Dear Pam



I just had a lengthy conversation with Ana Sotorrio of MIA on this issue and
she strongly feels that the Governor's intervention could be decisive in
obtaining a favorable resolution on the INS issue and resolving this problem
for our air carriers. She feels that a letter from the Governor to the INS
Commissioner accompanied by a phone call from the Washington office or
yourself, should provide the needed nudge to get INS to reach agreement with
MIA.

It is a time sensitive issue since they would like to see this issue
resolved by May 15th which is the start of the summer travel season. If you
would like I can start working on a draft along the lines of what we wrote
for the US Customs Commissioner for the INS Commissioner. Let me know.


Manny


-----Original Message-----
From: Ana Sotorrio [mailto:ASOTORRIO@miami-airport.com]
Sent: Wednesday, May 08, 2002 3:52 PM
To: Dana, Pam
Cc: Miguel Southwell; Manny Mencia; Eric Olafson (E-mail)
Subject: RE:


Unfortunately, Pam, it didn't go at all.  Once again, INS was not available
to meet with us.  It was not until this morning that Miguel Southwell met
with Mr. Jack Garafano, INS Miami District Director, and Port Director Jorge
Roig.  Mr. Garafano claims that he has not seen the Department of Justice
Memorandum for Regional Directors regarding ITI Transit and Progressive
Clearance Procedures, which was issued on April 22,2002.  We gave him a copy
and could not move the conversation beyond the first line of the section of
the memo on ITI Flights, which states "The carrier must provide 100% Advance
Passenger Information (API) electronic data in advance of the aircraft's
arrival."  Mr. Garafano interprets this to mean that air carriers must be
100% APIS compliant. No airline is 100% APIS compliant.  Mr. Garafano's
interpretation is not consistent with ours, or Customs, or the airlines, or
anybody else who understands these issues and has seen the document.  Mr.
Garafano said he needs to review the memo carefully and then call
headquarters.  In the meantime, we are also attempting to get clarification
from INS headquarters.

If we can get beyond this issue, the next battle with INS will be about
facilities and technology.  Our ITI lounges do not contain INS-approved
inspection booths, nor does the capability exist to conduct IBIS computer
queries.  We can provide the booths and IBIS capability in the future, but
not in time for the peak summer travel season.  At our meeting in
Washington, we were led to believe that INS would work with us on interim
solutions, but given our current experience with INS we are less than
confident that this will be the case.

We could use your help in getting INS Headquarters to clarify the APIS
issue.  We and the airlines interpret the requirement to be 100%
transmission of APIS electronic data - 100% APIS compliance is quite
different and not attainable.

We are still trying to implement the full modified procedures on May 15.
Without INS's cooperation, this will not be possible.  Please call me at
305-876-7533 to discuss this in greater detail.  Thank you.

From:	Kathleen Kearney <Kathleen_Kearney@dcf.state.fl.us>
Sent:	Tuesday, May 21, 2002 9:36 AM
To:	Heacock, Jack
Cc:	'jack_moss@dcf.state.fl.us'; Horace Goldson
Subject:	Re: Adoption Caseworker


Dear Mr. Heacock,

Thank you so much for taking the time to e-mail me about your experiences
with DCF and with Mr. Goldson.  It is often difficult to find good in
situations like the one we are facing in Miami at the present time -- but
e-mails like yours put it all into perspective.  There are many competent
and compassionate child welfare workers employed by DCF and our
community-based partners.  They are grieving at this time over the loss of
Rilya and over the media's trivialization of their hard work and efforts to
improve a system that was beyond broken.  Your words inspire all of us to
stay focussed on the task at hand -- protecting Florida's children from
abuse and neglect, and finding them permanent, loving homes such as yours.
Thank you so much for your support of District 10 and the fine men and
women that dedicate their lives to work there.




                                                                                                  
                    "Heacock, Jack"                                                               
                    <JackHeacock@fdle.st       To:     Jack Moss/D10/DCF@DCF                      
                    ate.fl.us>                 cc:     Kathleen Kearney/D20/DCF@DCF               
                                               Subject:     Adoption Caseworker                   
                    05/21/02 09:03 AM                                                             
                                                                                                  
                                                                                                  




Dear Mr. Moss,

I have been closely following the slings and arrows launched at DCF in the
aftermath of the Rilya Wilson case.  I also read the article in the Miami
Herald regarding Broward's efforts to encourage local adoption by reducing
the
bureaucracy and speeding the process up.  I applaud that effort because we
both know it is a burdensome process, albeit a process designed to ensure
correct adoptive decisions are made.

I am the father in one of your pre-adoptive families in Broward, my wife
and
I having signed the application and submitted it to DCF just last month.
Having followed the Rilya Wilson situation, I thought I'd take a moment to
remind you and others that there are dedicated and responsive caseworkers
in
your organization.  I have one assigned to my case: Horace Goldson.  Mr.
Goldson has quickly become an ally in our efforts to make the proper
decision about adoption.  He is the kind of caseworker I think the
Department of Children and Families would want to recognize in some way for
dedication to his job, his authentic concern for the children he is
responsible for, and his responsiveness to the needs or questions of the
prospective family.  It doesn't take long to realize that Mr. Goldson is
truly interested in doing what is right for the families and the children
with which he is entrusted.  Mr. Goldson never fails to make his monthly
visits and his visits are not cursory stops.  He spends time with the
children and with members of my biological family.  His presence in our
home
is never an imposition and we are truly grateful for the efforts he expends
on behalf of the children we are adopting, ourselves, and the other
families
fortunate enough to have him assigned to their cases.

It's easy to kick an organization when it stumbles and there has been no
shortage of those seizing the opportunity to do just that.  The Miami
Herald
contained another article about comments made by politicians at the
proceedings of the Blue Ribbon panel directed specifically at Secretary
Kearney, shamelessly designed for political gain rather than improving the
system.  I may lack the public forum that the Miami Herald and some
transparent politicians enjoy, but I hope the feedback from the people you
serve mean far more than the frenzied rants from the media.  You have good
people in your organization and I hope you can take some solace in the
knowledge that to those who matter the most, we are grateful for them and
your efforts.

Jack Heacock
PAF Chief, MROC
(305) 470-5500/(786) 336-1013
Suncom 429-1013

-----Original Message-----
From: Nina Oviedo [mailto:oviedon@sso.org]
Sent: Monday, May 20, 2002 5:18 PM
To: 'Nina Oviedo'; Governor Bush (E-mail)
Cc: Greg Turbeville (E-mail); Melissa Freedman (E-mail); Brian Yablonski (Jeb) (E-mail); Brian Yablonski (E-mail); Frank R. Jimenez (E-mail); KaS (E-mail)
Subject: RE: Trade Promotion Authority Letter Reminder....


Governor, Brian and I just talked about the letter-----he raised concerns over the 4th paragraph that talks about a “clean TPA” (bolded and underlined below).   I agree.  Since we have been working with citrus for a narrow amendment and will continue to work w/ them; we suggest not signing.  The Administration should understand…you indicated your support early on while TPA was debated on the House side.
 
Pls advise.  Nina.
 
-----Original Message-----
From: Nina Oviedo [mailto:oviedon@sso.org]
Sent: Monday, May 20, 2002 3:31 PM
To: Governor Bush (E-mail)
Cc: Greg Turbeville (E-mail); Melissa Freedman (E-mail); Brian Yablonski (Jeb) (E-mail); Brian Yablonski (E-mail); Frank R. Jimenez (E-mail); KaS (E-mail)
Subject: FW: Trade Promotion Authority Letter Reminder....
Importance: High
 
There is a letter in support of TPA being circulated for signatures.  At the moment only Governors Johanns (R-NE) and Hoeven (R-ND) have signed-on; they are leading this effort.  Although they’re off to a slow start, they are hoping to get 20 bi-partisan signatures.  They would like to send the letter Wed morning….a vote is likely in the Senate on Thursday.
 
We have been working with the citrus industry on a TPA amendment.  They understand the Gov’s support for TPA but want citrus off the tariff reduction table.  This morning Andy LeVigne made it clear that the industry would work w/ Sen Nelson on the Nelson/Graham amendment; last Friday, citrus rejected a WH compromise…saying they did not want to “assume tariff reductions.”  They want no tariff reductions.
 
The letter is attached and copied below.
 
Dear (House and Senate Leadership):

We are writing in strong support of current legislation restoring permanent 
Presidential Trade Promotion Authority (TPA) that is vital to America, the states, its workers, families and businesses.

With many difficult challenges facing our country both domestic and abroad, 
TPA will go a long way in expanding consumer confidence, spurring economic 
growth and opportunities, creating high paying jobs, and providing a high 
quality of life for our citizens.

For too long, the United States has been limited and unable to negotiate and enter into trade agreements with other countries because of the absence of TPA.  Trade agreements between the United States and other countries address many issues and do not occur overnight, but, rather, are the result of long deliberative 
negations.  TPA will restore Presidential authority to negotiate fair and 
balanced agreements that open markets and bring down trade barriers, while 
maintaining congressional oversight and authority to review trade agreements 
and either accept or reject them based on their merits.

This is not a partisan issue, but rather an American issue with Governors in 
unified support of clean TPA legislation that will stimulate our economies 
and enhance America's position as a global leader.

Restore Trade Promotion Authority.

Sincerely,

This will be a great source of info on the perceptions of the foster

keep a finger on the pulse of out of home care, worker performance and give

us a chance to dispel myths, get feedback, understand where they are coming
from and monitor our performance.Trudy is a great supporter of the
administration and DCF in general. She is positive and exhibits great
common sense. The other foster parents respect her statewide. Hopefully we
can institute this statewide in an effort to show the DCF is truly not
hiding anything and welcomes the input from these valued partners. ( my 2
cents worth). A great result of the panel, one that is free, can be
instituted immediately.

  Sharon,

  This was our idea.  So I now need to put some "meat on the bones" of this
idea!  We are looking to have 6 foster parents and administration sit
monthly to discuss the issues of intimidation, lack of visitation,
falsified information, lack of information, things like that.  If there is
a particular case and counselor this would be investigated by the
administration and reported back to the board and the foster parent.  We
want to be able to present issues, wide and specific, and get results!

  We want to use this as a means of communication also.  Like many of us
complained about the Unit Rilya was in but it went no place.  Also there is
a new Electronic Blue Book with the children's information...of course we
knew nothing about it...where was our input?

  Any suggestions would be greatly appreciated!

Please note: Florida has a very broad public records law.
Most written communications to or from state officials
regarding state business are public records available to the
public and media upon request.   Your e-mail communications
may therefore be subject to public disclosure.

Governor,
 
Below is a letter from a friend who has sought my help in the past regarding her daughter. I would not bother you with it but for the fact that people knowledgible with Michelle's condition say she is doing very poorly at present because of inattention. 
 
I would not have written you with this except that her parents (who are wonderful people) have been told by a case worker that their daughter may die soon from lack of care. Hopefully, Michelle can be transferred closer to home where her family can assure that all her medical needs are met.
 
Thank you in advance for any help you can provide.
 
 
Joe
-----Original Message-----
From: Deborah Richards [mailto:debandken@peoplepc.com]
Sent: Friday, May 17, 2002 3:26 AM
To: jscarborough@levinlaw.com
Subject: Michelle T. Bolin


Honorable Jeb Bush
Governor of the State of Florida
 
This letter comes to you from the heart of a mother.  My daughter, Michelle Bolin, is a Florida State prison inmate.  She is a paraplegic.  This is a result of the traffic accident she caused.  She was convicted of DUI manslaughter and sentenced to 15 years in prison in 1997.  Because of extremely negligent medical care she is now serving a death sentence.
 
Michelle was married and had two little girls who are now 9 and 8.  Their father has custody of them and is doing a great job of raising and caring for them as a single father.
 
Michelle's problem was addiction to drugs.  She would drink alcohol to enhance the effects of the drugs.  This was her condition the day of the accident.
 
Michelle and I both know that justice must be served for her crime.  For that reason we are not asking for anything but reasonable and adequate medical care so that she might survive her sentence and come home.
 
Her major medical problems began in September of 1999 when she was transferred to Lowell Correctional Institute in Ocala, Florida.  While there, she has had to have surgery for a colostomy, a permanent catheter, and developed decubitus ulcers on her buttocks.  These ulcers developed because of pressure from sitting too long in her  wheelchair.  (Her chair is custom made for her).  Because of her medical problems she has to see the prison doctor almost daily.  She is forced to sit and wait for hours  to see the doctor for so much as an aspirin.  She has lain and sat in her own urine because her catheter leaks.  This causes further infection which leads to pseudomonas infection which causes death.
 
The staff at Lowell are unable to care for her medical needs and have contributed further to her problems with unsanitary practices.  They have at times not worn gloves when changing her dressings and, at times left some of the old packing in the wound.
 
Michelle has twice been transferred to North Florida Reception Center (NFRC), which is a men's prison with a hospital facility, because of her medical condition.  She is currently housed at NFRC with large decubitus ulcers on both sides of her buttocks.  She has now developed osteomilytis, a bone infection, and a hole in her intestines.
 
Michelle has had four surgeries to close these ulcers since 1999.  This current situation is the worst yet.  This ulcer developed while at Lowell early this year.  In February the plastic surgeon, Dr. Obie, told her it needed to be closed right away in order to prevent enlargement and infection.  At that time she still had enough good tissue on her buttocks to use for the procedure.  That is in doubt now.  The previous surgeries have used all of the available muscle tissue for a muscle flap procedure to close the sores.
 
The medical staff at Lowell was supposed to transfer her back to NFRC for this procedure in April but  there was always an excuse.  "The van broke down" is a favorite.  After 8 missed appointments, I called the Regional Director of impaired inmates, Dr. Diane Rechtine.  After hearing the problem, she immediately ordered an ambulance transfer to NFRC.  It is now May 16, and still nothing has been done.  The ulcers on her behind are now down to the bone.  A staff member called me, jeopardizing her job,  to tell me that Michelle is in very bad shape and even urged me to get an attorney.  The medical staff at NFRC said that Michelle has too many doctors involved in her case and cancelled the plastic surgeon, the very doctor she needs the most.  I don't understand this and no one will give me or Michelle any answers.
 
I have spoken with Mr. Emile Baudoin, Coordinator of impaired inmates, several times and he has assured me he would look into the problems but nothing changes.
 
Michelle's custom made wheelchair needed repairs in January.  She had to write a grievance to get the repairs and it still has not been repaired.  Her chair helps to relieve the pressure on her spine when sitting for prolonged periods.  The chair is still at Lowell.  It should have been fixed and transferred with her.
 
These problems just scratch the surface.  Michelle's medical records cover seven volumes.
 
Governor Bush, from one parent to another, I am asking for your help and or guidance to save my daughter's life.
 
There are only two women's prisons in Florida, Lantana in South Florida and Lowell in North Florida.  Can she possibly be transferred to some facility here in Northwest Florida such as a county jail or correctional facility?  There is no state prison for women in Nothwest Florida, but there is certainly a need for one.
 
I was told today that if someone does not help Michelle soon, she will die.  
 
I am not asking for Michelle's sentence to be reduced or for an early release.  I only ask that she be accorded the human and humane treatment that she has been refused.
 
Thank you for listening.
 
Debbie Richards
4866 Blakemore Drive
Pace, Florida  32571
(850) 994-2386 Home
(850) 435-7963 Work (Delta Air Lines)
 
Michelle T. Bolin
DC-0P05007
Lowell Correctional Institute
Women's Unit
Lowell, Florida  32663-0147
 
Emile Baudoin, Coordinator, Impaired Inmates
2601 Blair Stone Road
Tallahassee, Florida  32399-2580
(850) 922-6645
 
Dr. Diane Rechtine, Regional Director
(407) 207-7341
Tallahassee, Florida  32399-2580

From:	Alicia Szuka <jobeulah@worldnet.att.net>
Sent:	Tuesday, May 21, 2002 12:57 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Cc:	Larry_Pintacuda@dcf.state.fl.us; Alicia Szuka
Subject:	Cynthia Szuka

Dear Governor Bush:
Thank you so much for taking your time out of your busy schedule and together with Mrs. Bush attending the Family Cafe. We are writing to you again, regarding the problem in District 9 and the wheelchair that our daughter Cynthia needs and was recommended by her doctor. Following the CMAT meeting held in District 9 on Thursday May 16th and because of what transpired in that meeting, Cynthia was ill. Cynthia has a history of asthma and had not had an episode in a long time. She was so upset and discouraged that she had an asthmatic episode and I had to give her her asthma medication throughout the following days, which she had not had in a long time. She was also very depressed and anxious the days that followed. The CMAT team did not recognize her prescence in that meeting, and we left with a strong belief that Cynthia's welfare and health is not in their agenda, that we were decieved. Cynthia has had 2 evaluations completed, per Medicaid guidelines with all the paperwork and detailed letter of medical necessity by her othopedic doctor and surgeon ( approved Medicaid and CMS doctor). The wheelchair specialist came to our home and brought a DEMO wheelchair in which Cynthia drove around the house, stood on it, reclined, they also evaluated our van to make sure it fit in it. There is no question that Cynthia can operate this wheelchair, no question that it fits in the home, no question that it fits in the van, no question that it will help her get better, be independent, be healthy, have her life.The CMAT team continues to insist upon yet another evaluation, with Cynthia present, in their office not Cynthia's home, with the same people that made her so ill at the 5/16 meeting... for what reason??? Mr. John Grocki had suggested that we as Cynthia's parents meet with the CMAT without Cynthia there, including Cynthia's doctor and clarify the concerns, we as Cynthia's parents have no probem with this suggestion; however CMS does not want to do this. CMS wants Cynthia and her mother in their office, at their appointed date and time neglecting the fact that it poses a health hazard for Cynthia being placed into this situation with the experience she has had at the CMAT meeting, and her past experiences at this same CMS office. Neglecting the fact that Cynthia goes to school and these last two weeks are crucial with exams and finals, and what it would mean for Cynthia to miss school, neglecting the fact that her mother works and asked two days off last week for this same issue and cannot just... not go to work. Cynthia's mother and father have no problem in meeting with these people as soon as possible, at a time best for all; however after so many evaluations and doctor recommendations, there is no need to subject Cynthia to yet another horrific experience for her that may leave her ill.We appreciate Mr. John Grocki's efforts in resolving this issue, although he is not directly involved, however tried to get the facts from both sides and come up with a solution.Mr. Grocki did disclose that the funds for Cynthia's wheelchair was not an issue as he saw it. But at the same time we are not pressing Medicaid to pay, we are only looking at Cynthia's health. The unfortunate thing is that the CMAT team is inflexible, says one thing and does another, and we are very upset and concerned. Knowing what we know now to be a medical necessity for Cynthia, to be healthy and live and impact others and be happy, what type of parents would we be if we were to neglect this fact. We will go to the community, to the media if needed and not look at the money factor but at the medical needs for her well being and the needs for her to have this type of wheelchair. We continue to support you and believe in your message as well as your actions and are looking to you and those you have assigned in helping us with this crucial and unfortunate issue.We appreciate you. With deep concerns, Juan and Alicia Szuka

Subject: Call from DOJ re Miami
Importance: High


I received a call today from Sharee Freeman, head of DOJ--Community Relations Services.  As Sherrie put it, this is the office that handles riots, KKK, Black Panther, police shootings, etc. (Sharee used to work with Chairman Hyde, House Judiciary.)
 
This weekend is "Miami Black Beach Reunion Weekend."  Apparently in the past a criminal element comes in and makes a mess of the weekend....destruction of property, little riots, etc. DOJ has been working w/ the community---police, God Squad, other volunteers---and Congressional Offices (Meek, Graham, Nelson) to have control over the celebrations and keep the criminal element in check. 
 
There will be a DOJ Briefing this Friday, May 24th at 7:00 pm.  Sherrie says these briefings are very impressive...will show how much coordination and effort goes into the event.  Local police Congressional staff from Meek, Graham and Nelson's offices will attend----DOJ wanted to make sure we had representation at the briefing.  
 
I've tried to reach Andriena...and have left messages.   I also alerted Al Dennis, Community Relations w/ FDLE.  For more details, our DOJ contact is Francis Nam 202/305-3001.  Andriena, Al, feel free to call her.  I think it's important that we have representation at the briefing Francis can give you location and other details.  Thanks.  Nina.

<http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/art/ui/dot_clear.gif> 	Tuesday, May
21, 2002 - 12:00 a.m. Pacific


Criminal histories put jobs of 71 DSHS workers at risk 


By Ralph Thomas <mailto:rthomas@seattletimes.com> 
Seattle Times staff reporter

  <http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/art/ui/dot_clear.gif> 	


 
<http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/cgi-bin/EMailStory.pl?document_id=13445836
0&zsection_id=[REDACTED]&slug=checks21m0&date=20020521> E-mail	 E-mail
<http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/cgi-bin/EMailStory.pl?document_id=13445836
0&zsection_id=[REDACTED]&slug=checks21m0&date=20020521> this article	
  <http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/art/ui/dot_clear.gif> 	
 
<http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/cgi-bin/PrintStory.pl?document_id=13445836
0&zsection_id=[REDACTED]&slug=checks21m0&date=20020521> Print	 Print
<http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/cgi-bin/PrintStory.pl?document_id=13445836
0&zsection_id=[REDACTED]&slug=checks21m0&date=20020521> this article	
  <http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/art/ui/dot_clear.gif> 	
 <http://archives.seattletimes.nwsource.com/web/> Print	 Search
<http://archives.seattletimes.nwsource.com/web/> web archive	
 0 <http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/art/ui/dot_clear.gif> 	

OLYMPIA - As it nears the end of a months-long check into employee
backgrounds, the state Department of Social and Health Services said
yesterday it has found 71 workers with criminal histories that could cost
them their jobs. 


But department officials predicted that when further reviews are done, fewer
than half of those people will be forced out of their current jobs. So far,
four people with criminal pasts have been terminated, and possible action
against 16 others is pending. Seven employees have resigned. 


As required under a law passed last year, the state is checking the
background of all employees who have "unsupervised contact" with children,
the elderly and other vulnerable people. 


The department has refused to reveal the names or jobs of any employees
found with criminal pasts. Officials said they will not release the
information until the review, including appeals by employees, is completed. 


Aside from identifying criminal pasts of current employees, the law requires
applicants to undergo background checks. That will make it harder for people
with criminal pasts to get hired in the first place, said DSHS Secretary
Dennis Braddock. "It has definitely made people more sensitive about the
protection of our clients," he said yesterday. 


Since February, the department has released the results of background checks
on 13,314 employees. Three-fourths were in three agencies: Children's
Administration, Division of Developmental Disabilities and the Mental Health
Division. 


The department has only 40 employees left to check, all of them at Western
State Hospital, a psychiatric facility. The department expects to have that
done by next month. 


Through three rounds of background checks, including the latest released
yesterday, the department has found 204 workers with criminal records. Their
crimes included murder, manslaughter, child molestation, prostitution,
arson, forgery and drug offenses. 


Of those employees, 133 were able to prove that their background checks were
inaccurate, that they had been misidentified or that their records had been
cleared, said department spokesman Steve Williams. 


He said seven employees found to have criminal pasts resigned instead of
taking their cases to the Background Assessment Review Team. 


Braddock predicted yesterday that of the 71 remaining cases of employees
with criminal histories, only 20 to 30 will be terminated or reassigned to
other jobs. Workers who are forced out of their jobs can appeal those
decisions to the state's Personnel Appeals Board. 



Ralph Thomas can be reached at 360-943-9882 and rthomas@seattletimes.com
<mailto:rthomas@seattletimes.com> .

From:	Reinshuttle@aol.com
Sent:	Tuesday, May 21, 2002 8:56 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Dr. Medows at AHCA

Dear Governor Bush: 

Several friends on your staff have indicated you may have the opportunity to read this note, and have encouraged me to write.  I am writing this evening regarding an egregious abuse of the Service First Initiative by Secretary Medows at AHCA.   

Prior to being recruited to Florida in 1992 by the Governor's Office, I was Director of Texas Governor Bill Clements Washington Office.  As part of Lawton Chiles staff, I was a policy coordinator/Intergovernmental Affairs Director within EOG/OPB for nearly six years before moving to AHCA in 1997.  Both Tom Herndon and Doug Cook 
can verify the quality of my work.  At AHCA I held several positions including Senior Analyst and Health Policy Chief of Staff, and had an outstanding record of accomplishment as evidenced by Special Recognition Awards, Davis Awards, promotions, bonuses and excellent performance reviews. 

On August 3, 2001, Dr. Medows started at AHCA, and, after checking with Agency executives appointed me to the position of Bureau Chief of Health Policy.  Several weeks later, I was told the title would temporarily be "Acting Bureau Chief" until all the paperwork was completed and sent through your office.  A mere formality.  I would have been very proud to serve in your Administration in this capacity.  However, on September 21, 2001, I was advised that I was not going to be the Bureau Chief.  The reason cited by Dr. Medows was the need to place someone in my position from the Governor's Office (i.e., Emily Fritz) and the fact that your staff (i.e., Laura Branker) objected to appointing someone that have worked for the previous Administration.  I have never been political, but I accepted that decision. 

Several months earlier, on July 1, 2001, my career service position at AHCA had been involuntarily changed to an SES position.  Thus, the result of the September 21 action by Dr. Medows to place me back in career service had the effect of placing me "on probation" for one year as provided by Service First, even though I had achieved permanent status in that position long ago. 

On January 9, 2002, (three months later) I was terminated from my position.  There was no cause cited, merely a letter stating that I had "failed to successfully complete my probationary period."  It also said it was effective at 5pm that day. 
I have been without a job since that time and my excellent work record has been damaged.  There had been no review or any other indication that this action was imminent prior to termination.   

As you can imagine, this termination has been devastating to both me and my family.  Secretary Medows refuses to discuss her actions, even with members of the Senate who know me and have attempted to receive information on this matter. 

In my view, terminating an accomplished employee on an alleged technicality for no stated reason is an abuse of the system, and I'm certain this was not your intent when signing this measure into law. 

I am requesting your help Governor.  I would like to be (truly need to be) reinstated as soon as possible and would appreciate any assistance you may be able to render.  I will provide a copy of this memo along with supplemental material to Betty Hampton, and request that it be placed in your reading file. 

Thank you so much, 

Bob Reinshuttle 
422-3420

-----Original Message-----
From: Castille, Colleen [mailto:Colleen.Castille@MyFlorida.com]
Sent: Tuesday, May 21, 2002 6:44 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: Shanahan, Kathleen; Jimenez, Frank
Subject: Ichetucknee



Governor, 

I just thought I would let you know that Anderson Columbia has applied to
modify it's Ichetucknee Mine permit that is adjacent to the
under-construction Cement Plant.  The original intent of the mine at this
location was for minimal amount of limestone to assist in the burning
process.  The request was for 100 acres and down to 70 feet deep.

Anderson Columbia now has applied to modify that permit to encompass 800
acres and 125 feet deep.  DEP says that it is harmless.  The mine is not in
the same watershed as the Ichetucknee River.  And in the words of our
secretary it could be 1000 feet deep and it wouldn't harm the Ichetucknee. 

If you recall, that is was announced at the Cabinet meeting by one of the
environmentalists that this original permit request existed and that the DEP
and the Company kept responding that "the mine was a small one, it was only
100 acres, only 70 feet deep, it's not in the same watershed."  This seemed
to damper the opposition on that issue. 

But now, if DEP approves this permit modification, we will never hear the
end of it, I fear. 

Can we talk about this with David? 

colleen

----- Original Message ----- 
From: Ron Nehring <mailto:rnehring@atr-dc.org>  
To: Paycheckgroup@Yahoogroups.com 
Sent: Tuesday, May 21, 2002 4:55 PM
Subject: [PaycheckGroup] Colorado House Kills Anti-Paycheck Bill

FYI, the Colorado House of Representatives has killed SB 171, a union-supported bill that would have overturned Governor Bill Owens' 2001 Executive Order putting an end to payroll deductions for state employee union dues.
 
Here's a description of the impact of Governor Owens' Executive Order from his speech to CPAC:
 
...we stopped withholding dues from Colorado's 30,000 employees. We stopped withholding union dues in the State of Colorado. This affected unions such as the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees; the American Federation of Teachers; and the Colorado Association of Public Employees. In just 60 days, the impact has been very dramatic. It is interesting what happens when you require the unions to be very upfront and direct in terms of asking for the $300 or $400 a year they typically exact in terms of their membership. 
 
Here is what has happened to our largest non-education union, the Colorado Association of Public Employees -- in just 60 days, they have lost 70 percent of their members. 
 
They have had to lay off all 17 of their field workers. And what is important here is just the principle. Why should government be withholding these dues? Why not have the union do it itself? And I think you can see the impact on the union membership structure when you simply do the right thing as we are doing in Colorado. 
 
Thanks,
Ron

-----Original Message-----
From: KTailer@cs.com [mailto:KTailer@cs.com]
Sent: Tuesday, May 21, 2002 5:28 PM
To: jacklevine@floridakids.com; dlawrence@childreadiness.org; Jeb Bush
Subject: Adopting children from District 11


Dear Sirs, 
      My husband and I are trying to adopt four siblings that are currently living in a foster home in Miami run by Hazel Langston.  The children's names are Mary, LaPorsha, Steven and Darcella.  Their worker is Lavata King. 
      We were foster parents for 6 years, and then adopted four special needs children from Florida's DCF.  We also have three biological children.  Three of our adopted children came from District 11 in Miami, and two of them were living in Mrs. Langston's foster home, so our adopted children are good friends with these new children that we would like to adopt.  If we do not adopt these four, Ms. King has told me that she will split up the siblings, and has already started placement proceedings for the younger two to be adopted separately. 
      Although we are ready and willing to adopt these siblings and keep them together, we are being told by Ms. King's supervisor, Lita Fowler, and her supervisor, Ada Gonzales, that we cannot adopt them because we already have too many children.  While I agree that having such a large family is not for everyone, my husband and I believe that we are more than capable of parenting these children. 
      We have filed a grievance with Janice Harris and with Charles Oslander in Miami, but as of today, we still have heard no response. 
      We look forward to any help that you could give us in this matter. 

      Thank you for your time. 

Sincerely, 

Kathleen and Jim Tailer 
4688 Whispering Oaks Drive 
Tallahassee, Florida 32309-7406 
(850)877-5800
