-----Original Message-----
From: Gersh Morningstar [mailto:bluesheet@juno.com]
Sent: Tuesday, May 21, 2002 1:51 PM
To: secretary@mail.dos.state.fl.us
Cc: Jeb Bush; pakaproductions@bellsouth.net; GHstunts@aol.com
Subject: Are you out of your mind?


Dear Secretary Harris,

I have been informed that you have contracted with an out of state
production company for production of  a video on Political History and
Governance in Florida when our own, world renowned, superior  production
infrastructure is begging for work. Not only was your decision to go out
of state an absolute contradiction to  your assurances to members of
Florida's production community at the Langford Hotel in Winter Park, but
it flies in the face of Governor Bush's assurances to us that state
production would stay in the state.

You may or may not be aware (probably not, you seem maze dull with
respect to Florida's entertainment production industry), but I publish
the Florida Blue Sheet, the primary trade publication for the industry in
Florida and throughout the south. Our 20,000+ readers represent both rank
and file members of the industry and the principal industry leaders. Ours
is a small voice, but it is one heard by many  big, loud, and commanding
voices. As the only Florida publication of any kind that circulates to
all 50 states and to 15 foreign countries, you may be sure that your
flagrant betrayal of our industry will be trumpeted  not only throughout
the state, including the district you seek to represent in Congress, but
throughout the country.

This was a major and foolish blunder, Secretary Harris. Cancel the
contract with the Washington interlopers immediately and award it to a
Florida company, or suffer the consequences politically. You have chosen
to pick a fight with a group of people whose voices are measured in
megahertz and who buy ink by the barrel. Is this a fight you really want?
Florida production is to be done by Florida companies. That was your
avowed mandate. That was the assurance of the Governor.

Gersh Morningstar
Publisher

Also, as the newly elected chairman of the Florida Inland Navigation
District Commission, I wanted to bring to your attention an issue dealing
with a pending appointment to this agency.  One of your 1999 appointees to
the commission, Ji-Ang Song, an engineer from West Palm Beach, has recently
had to resign his post due to a conflict with a new job.  That leaves the
Palm Beach County seat vacant as we enter a crucial time of the year when we
develop and adopt our FY2002-03 budget.  Although our annual budget is
rather small by comparison to other agencies ($40 million, and we have
managed to hold it to roll back rates for the past several years), it
nonetheless does involve a number of local cost share projects in each of
our eleven counties.  As such, I suspect that Palm Beach County would
benefit from having a newly appointed commissioner looking after their
interests in this process.  I understand that you have several highly
qualified applicants pending at this time, and with all due respect, would
like to call your attention to their interest in the commission appointment.
Thank you!  I look forward to seeing you soon,
Cathy

From:	Susan  Alyn <susanalyn@mindspring.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, May 21, 2002 9:47 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	good news - police are helping me change the law

Gov. Bush,.

I just had to quickly tell you this good news --
today I did something to prevent what happened to me
with that false, wrong and mistaken DUI arrest from happening to others.

I remembered that in NY, when I was going through a rough time,
the people who helped me most and were honest were two Community Police
officers.

So, today I went to see the head of the Community Police for Collier. And, I
told
him, I have a situation that is a lemon, and I would like him to help me
make some
lemonade out of it. And, he was very interested.

He met with me in his office for a long time, listened to my whole sorry
saga, and then,
I showed him that law I wrote to you about last night, where people are
allowed to
call and get an independent blood or urine test AT THE TIME OF ARREST.

He looked up the law, highlighted it, and said: This info needs to be given
to people
arrested at the same time they are requested to blow into the breathalizer.
(I did not
blow because I was afraid the police could manipulate that machine.) And,
people should
be on videotape showing the police give them the phone and the option to
call a lab, and
the phone numbers to the lab. This was all his idea. I was thrilled. Because
if that had happened
to me, then, I would have made the call then (instead of 14 hours when I got
out of jail),
AND I would have blown -- because then I would feel I had a chance, no
matter what the
results of the breathalizer, since I knew nothing was in my blood or urine.

He then told me he would get in touch with the jail, and find out why they
are not doing this now,
and talk to Rep Burt Saunders, so that a new law can be made to require the
jails to do this.

And, I told him: my DUI instructor told me she sees more and more people
like me in her classes
now. People who claim, as I did then and now, that no drugs or alcohol was
in their system, but
they were arrested for the first time, afraid, lost, frightened, etc., (all
these things that look like
symptons of drug use to a police officer).

So, maybe next year you will have this bill on your desk to sign, which
would help people like
me, who are not guilty of a criminal offense but get mistakenly entangled in
this system,. and will help
people who are especially concerned about proving their innocence because
they may have
a past history of drug use but are now clean.

And, it will help police, because this will givethem a more favorable image
to the public, as they will be helping people preserve their  due process
rights, and this will help them weed out those cases which should not be in
this criminal system in the first place. I could tell he saw a lot of
benefits in this for the police. And, I explained to him I am not anti-cop,
as I have worked with good cops in the schools.

He also mentioned to me that beginning this July, in FL, refusing to blow is
now a criminal offense --
all the more reason to ensure people who are too frightened to blow, like I
was, but are not guilty of a crime,
are given a chance to get an independent blood or urine test at the time of
arrest,
as police are not required to give those tests.

All in all, a great day. No help to any lawyers, I might add. LOL... :)

Susan

-----Original Message-----
From: Kitchens, George <kitcheng@fdhc.state.fl.us>
To: 'mclester@sunet.net' <mclester@sunet.net>
CC: Medows, Rhonda M.D. <medowsr@fdhc.state.fl.us>
Sent: Tue May 21 07:57:25 2002
Subject: brand limit

Mr. McLester, your email was forwarded to me from Dr. Medows/Gov. Bush in
regards to your question concerning branded generics counting against the 4
brand limit.
As you may know, we take our data feed from First Data Bank which classifies
the drugs  as generics, single source brands, or multi source brands.
Typically it is very straight forward such as furosemide being classified as
generic and Lasix as a multisource brand. On occasion a generic will be
classified as a brand because of their inflated AWP making it more expensive
than what a generic should be in comparison to the multisource brand. 
We are currently putting together a list of drugs that fall into that
situation and will do 2 things with them: 1. Apply a state MAC to the price
thus lowering to an acceptable and comparable price within that therapeutic
category 2. Reclassify as a generic and therefore not count against the 4
brand limit.
Please feel free to call me at 850-922-7702 if you need further
clarification.

George Kitchens  Rph

-----Original Message-----
From: Dan Scupin [mailto:dscup@cox.net]
Sent: Tuesday, May 21, 2002 11:16 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: what is SB 1844 in English?


 Jeb,
Hopefully this will give you some info regarding this Bill.  FL Dept of
Children & Family Services is intrusive enough and doesn't need more "nanny
state" powers.  When is the state going to stop trying to run the lives of
FL citizens.  We have enough laws and don't need "fishing expedition" laws
to further intrude on citizens.  What happened to the "small government"
Republicans? And why do these "legislators" have to SNEAK this Bill through
on a completely unrelated Bill...this smells.  Why don't you veto it and
REQUIRE the legislators to pass it on it's own merit.
Dan

Background:


S.B. 1844 is an economic development bill that has nothing to do with early
education. Yet Senate Majority leader John McKay slipped his Government
Nanny bill (formerly S.B. 88) into S.B. 1844.


Therefore, S.B. 1844 is now the vehicle to create a new government program
called Learning Gateway and will involve "developing strategies for offering
hospital visits or home visits by trained staff to new mothers."


The purpose of Learning Gateway is to screen children from birth to age 9
for "biological, environmental, and behavioral risks," and "learning
problems." Furthermore, Learning Gateway providers will conduct "intake with
families," conduct "needs/strength based assessments of families," and "make
referrals for needed services" and "developmental monitoring."


This will all be done in collaboration with the Florida Department of
Children and Family Services and numerous other big government agencies and
programs.


Some additional reasons to opposes S.B. 1844:



S.B. 1844 mandates automatic referrals of high risk newborns to the local
Learning Gateway through the Office of Vital Statistics. Who determines what
is considered high risk? There is no parental consent required for this
referral. What happens if the parent chooses not to follow up on this
referral?


S.B. 1844 directs that screening processes be developed and tested to
address social/emotional/behavioral indicators which could be a sign of
future problems. Will the Florida Department of Children and Families take
the child away if the parent chooses to follow his own doctor's advice
instead of the government's?


S.B. 1844 requires that an electronic data system be developed to track
children who are screened, assessed, and referred for services. Will mom and
dad be able to remove the child from the government programs if the initial
screening is done without parent's consent?


S.B. 1844 creates a huge, expensive bureaucracy, with the intent of
expanding the program statewide. The pilot project is $6 million the first
year for only three counties what will it cost taxpayers to fund this
program for the whole state?

-----Original Message-----
From: Openshaw, Mary Laura [mailto:OPENSHM@mail.doe.state.fl.us]
Sent: Tuesday, May 21, 2002 9:25 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: RE: literacy/reading events


Governor,
I went straight to the expert on this one -- here are Joe T's thoughts on
Reading Rescue:

ML,

I am supportive of Reading Rescue.  They took some good ideas from Reading 
Recovery and developed them further by adding a more explicit component to 
their tutoring.  I have actually spoken at one of their training 
meetings.  We are also hiring Dr. Marcia Grek, who has been working as 
their head of professional development, to be one of our staff at 
FCRR.  (Marcia worked for us before she spent the last year working for 
Reading Rescue).

I think this model has a lot of potential-and will certainly continue to be 
a prominent player in the mix of solutions that schools develop for 
providing immediate intensive interventions to their children.  My concern 
at present is whether the model (it uses regular classroom teachers to 
provide the interventions, and involves using aides as substitutes while 
the teachers are out of the classroom) has the delivery capacity for 
schools that have a very high proportion of at risk children.  However, the 
basic instructional approach is much better than Reading Recovery, which 
continues to advocate a less explicit form of instruction, and the 
professional development they provide is very good.  It is clearly one of 
the models for early intervention that deserves our support.  They do have 
available some relatively impressive empirical data showing effectiveness, 
however, I have not had a chance to examine this data in close detail.

Cheers,

Joe T.

Sent: Mon May 20 00:51:17 2002
Subject: literacy/reading events

TO: Governor Jeb Bush, Lisa McFadden, Mark Nelson

	On May 29, Chancellor Levy of the New York City Schools, Jack
Rosenthal, President of the New York Times Foundation, Manhattan
Councilwoman Eva Moskowitz, businessman/philanthropist and UF grad,
Benedict Silverman, will attend a celebration in Manhattan
congratulating the educators who have achieved success with Reading
Rescue, Florida's economical, effective literacy intervention, in
District 6 schools (Washington Heights, an Hispanic community).

	Governor Bush can celebrate the success of Reading Rescue with
Florida
educators on June 17, 18, 19, 20, or 21, when The Literacy Trust (a
charitable, nonprofit foundation) will be holding the first of its
Reading Rescue Summer Institutes on campus at UF in the Academic
Research Building. The second Institute the week of July 15th will be at
the Hampton Inn on the beach at St. Augustine.  Reading teachers and
coordinators from several Florida counties and from six other states
will participate as distinguished researchers share their latest
findings. 
We would love to welcome the Governor to one or both of these Institutes
where he could hear first-hand reports from the
educators who are seeing success with Reading Rescue. Others who may
wish to attend are invited to contact us.

	While Florida has looked to other states for ways to improve
reading
instruction and test scores, other states have been turning to us for
help. The Governor should know how powerful our model, developed in
cooperation with the University of Florida with support from the Florida
DOE, is when fully implemented in raising achievement among at-risk
students, and how cost-effective for schools to implement. This is
a model taxpayers can love and - in the words of one superintendent
whose district has 53% bilingual students (see the attached letter) -
ours is a model for which schools have been waiting.

	Reading Rescue is not a program schools purchase; it's not a set
of
books, it's not computer software. Rather, the adoption of Reading
Rescue reflects an elementary school's decision to use their existing
resources differently in order to improve instruction in classrooms and
to provide high-quality, one-on-one instruction for those students who
will not learn to read successfully without it. Our organization
provides the technical assistance and delivers the training to prepare
members of a school's staff to tutor during the regular school day while
improving instruction for all in classrooms.  Thus, the number of high
quality instructional hours for students who need them most
increases without a commensurate increase in costs. And, not just the
students who are tutored benefit with this model - instruction is
enhanced in the classrooms of all participating teachers. Test scores
rise overall - not just among those who are tutored.
  
	Volunteers and after-hours programs are needed but they're not a
permanent solution to the problem of reading failure in the early
grades. Schools that adopt Reading Rescue are committed to a permanent,
feasible solution during the school day and using their regular staff.
In visiting a Reading Rescue Institute, the Governor will be showing his
support for Florida schools that are accepting responsibility for their
most basic mission of teaching each student to read.

	The Elementary Supervisor and Title 1 Coordinator in Walton
County,
Marsh Pugh, has already invited the Governor to visit their schools and
Marsha can verify that, in 2001-2002, no child whose performance was in
the the bottom quartile at the beginning of the year, and who received
Reading Rescue tutoring during the year, scored in the bottom quartile
on the standardized test administered at the end of the year. Most were
brought up into the average and above average ranges.  Walton County
achieved those results by using their existing staff who tutored over
100 children during the regular school day. Test scores have risen
dramatically for all students as a result of Reading Rescue.  

	Reading Rescue represents a successful business/education
partnership
since the program's development and evaluation was supported through
gifts from a businessman to the UF College of Education.  The same
individual, Benedict Silverman, now supports national expansion of
the model. 

	 The Governor can learn about Reading	 Rescue by visiting one
of our
Summer Institutes and we would be honored to welcome him.

Kindest regards,
Nora L. Hoover, Ed.D. President
The Literacy Trust, Inc. - A
charitable, not-for-profit educational foundation
3324 West University Ave.
Gainesville, Florida 32608

-----Original Message-----
From: Jeane McCarthy [mailto:jmc123@tampabay.rr.com]
Sent: Tuesday, May 21, 2002 2:50 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Children


Dear Governor Jeb:

You are probably receiving many suggestions regarding improving the welfare
of children in Florida, but I would like to offer several.

Prevention:

1.   Mandatory child development and parenting education for all high school
students.  Many children are currently being raised in homes with absentee
or "busy" parents and do not have a good parenting role model.  With smaller
families, many children grow up without exposure to younger siblings.
Therefore they are unaware of the difficulties of parenting small children.

2.   Expansion of the Healthy Families program.  The Healthy Start and
Healthy Families programs could be merged and controlled more directly by
local communities, as the Healthy Start programs are currently managed.

Intervention:

1.   A modified mandatory Healthy Families program would put family support
workers in the home three to four times a week and may permit more children
to remain in their homes or to be returned home sooner.

2.   Children, whose parents will probably have their parental rights
terminated, should be placed on a dual track from birth, both for foster
care and adoption.  Then, after one year, when parental rights were
terminated the adoption could rapidly progress.

Thanks for your consideration.

Keep up the good work.

Doctor Jeane

-----Original Message-----
From: Benjamin Gilbert [mailto:bgilbert@helios.acomp.usf.edu]
Sent: Tuesday, May 21, 2002 12:51 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Hyperbaric O2 Treatment



Governor Bush,

We met at the Family Cafe.  I was the Physical Therapist who was
vehemently opposed to Medicaid covering Hyperbaric Oxygen Treatment for
Children and Adults with Neurological Disorders such as Cerebral Palsy
etc.  I apologize for the intensity of my emotion; however, I am an
advocate for the disabled community and will not tolerate the waist of
precious government funds.

After our conversation, I spoke with Lynn Metz at the State Medicaid
Office.  She states that she has been researching the subject since
yesterday per your instructions.  I asked whether she had found any
information which indicated Hyperbaric Oxygen Treatment was effective in
the treatment of Neurological Disorders.  She said "No" all the date
indicated Hyperbaric Oxygen Treatment was ineffective in treating
Neurological Disorders.  Just as I had said at the conference.  It is
notable that Hyerbaric Oxygen Treatment has been effective in wound care
however when treating anaerobic wounds.

I appreciate your quick attention to this matter.  Quite frankly I am
impressed with your diligence and honesty.  Mostly when a government
official tells you "I'll look into it" it is an empty promise.

I believe the State of Florida will save millions of dollars by
eliminating funding for Hyperbaric Oxygen Treatment for Neurological
Disorders, all of which can be directed towards aides which are
effective.  Additionally, individuals who advocate these treatment
regimens for children and adults with Cerebral Palsy are charlatans,
similar to those who advocate Chelation therapy etc.  They promise hope
to these families and deliver nothing.

Thanks again for your quick attention,
You are great,

Benjamin Gilbert MSPT

-----Original Message-----
From: Victor Rose <vicr@adelphia.net>
To: Jeb Bush <jeb@jeb.org>
Sent: Mon May 20 11:06:46 2002
Subject: Re: Tenure for teachers tranferring from one county to another

Dear Governor Bush:

I hope this finds you doing well.

Last Friday, my fiancé Donna attended the Palm Beach County Job Fair to
seek
employment in order to work closer to our home.  As you know, we
presently
live in Palm
Beach County and Donna's present commute is about 45 minutes each way to
and
from Sunrise, Florida.

There is a elementary school in Delray Beach about 7 miles from our
house,
called Pine Grove.  Pine Grove's student body consist of students of low
income families, with low test scores.

Donna teaches fourth grade and has had enormous success working with low
income students who are below grade level.  Based on the makeup of
Donna's
classroom, she continually achieves high FCAT test scores even higher
than
schools in better areas like Boca Raton and other upscale communities.
(see
test scores below). Donna achieves these high scores even though 95% of
her
classroom receives free or reduced lunches.  Like I told you before, if
all
things are equal, I will put Donna up against not only any fourth grade
teacher in Florida but any fourth grade teacher in the US.

Pine Grove is very interested in hiring Donna and would like to have her
as
one of their teachers.   Unfortunately, if she moves from Broward County
to
Palm Beach County, Palm Beach County will only accept 10 years and
instead
of 12 and
they want to put her on a three year probation/annual contract.

I believe it is in your best interest and the State of Florida to make
exceptions in order to assist great teachers like Donna, to stay in the
profession as long as possible.  Also, it is not fair for teachers of
Donna's ability that have dedicated so many good years to the state
education program to be put on probation or lose two years just because
they
are moving from one county to another.

I would greatly appreciated it if you would have someone contact me this
week to discuss this matter in more detail.  I can be reached on my cell
phone at 310.867.4365. Though my cell # is a LA number, I am located in
Boca
Raton, Florida.

Thank you for your time and consideration to this matter.

Best regards,

Vic Rose

-----Original Message-----
From: Joanie Schirm [mailto:jhschirm@g-e-c.com]
Sent: Tuesday, May 21, 2002 8:58 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Favor: please ask Georgia's Governor Barnes about www.getfitgeorgia.com


May 22, 2002 
 
 
Dear Governor Bush: 
 
As a member of the Florida High Tech Corridor Council, I have been a volunteer working with a program which I believe is a revolutionary on-line training course to actually use technology to allow K-12 educators to learn how to use technology efficiency and integrate it in to their curriculum.    It is called "Teachers Discovering Computers" and I have now seen it's results for the past two years, reviewed the research on it's results with both teachers and administrators, and believe it is a perfect candidate for 
federal Title 1 Professional Development Funds.    When you see what it does for teachers, and the subsequent environment for learning for today's world that it creates for students,  you will become a huge fan.     This is obviously not just about teacher training, it is about teaching the workforce of tomorrow - it is about economic development and therefore the Florida High Tech Corridor Council has a keen interest in finding appropriate ways to assist.
 
The exciting part is that I have now connected with the President of Georgia G.L.O.B.E. (Global Learning Online for Business & Education), Dr. Richard Skinner, and we believe that together, the states of Georgia and Florida could be most effective in sharing our initiative and proposal for funding and implementation. 
 
It is my understanding that you will be with Governor Barnes in Atlanta from June 22 - 24th in conjunction with the 16 Governors who make up the SREB.     Dr. Skinner has spoken with Ron Newcombe, GA Governor Barnes' education advisor, about the possibility of your discussing Georgia "Get Fit" program and "Teachers Discovering Computers" in depth during your visit.     Get Fit = Giving Educators Training for Integrating Technology. 
 
In Orange County,  hundreds of teachers (K-12 and Workforce Development Teachers and Administrators) have now taken this course and it's success is well documented.    The last pilot training program of over l00 teachers was jointly funded by the Florida High Tech Corridor Council, 
Orange County Public Schools, and the Teacher Education Institute.    
 
To learn more about Georgia's program, please visit the site: 
www.getfitgeorgia.com 
 
In the near future, I will send you more information, but I would greatly appreciate your guidance on how this program may receive the best "audience" for Florida.      I ask you to please inquire of Governor Barnes when you are in Atlanta in June.     I look forward to answering any questions you may have.
 
Thank you.
 
Joanie Schirm

Joanie Schirm 
President 
Geotechnical and Environmental Consultants, Inc. 
1230 East Hillcrest Street 
Orlando, Florida  32803-4713

From:	Terry L. Rice <tlrice@adelphia.net>

Subject:	Re: ACE covers up NPS violations of CWA?

Jack ... I do not know all the details yet but you are right regarding the FL FWC ... FWC did commit a 404 violation 5 or 6 years ago ... even though it was in conjunction with the restoration of Lake Kissimmee, I felt compelled to fine them ... the way I saw it, what's good for the goose is good for the gander ... actually I felt that the agencies must set an example to an even higher standard than the public at large or the public will continue to lose confidence in government ... surely the Corps will have to set the right example with the Big Cypress Preserve in this case too if there was in fact a violation ... but I do not know the details either what exactly happened or what the Corps is contemplating ... just that it seems to have been illegal according to all reports I am privy to.  In general, my feeling is that agencies are public servants ... not agency servants ... and this always needs to be clear with every action ... but what do I know?
 
Terry Rice

From:	Dempsey, Hayden <Hayden.Dempsey@MyFlorida.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, May 22, 2002 10:36 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	FW: GOVERNOR BUSH CREATES COMMISSION ON WORKERS' COMPENSATION REFORM



>  -----Original Message-----
> From: 	Shannon, Meg  
> Sent:	Wednesday, May 22, 2002 9:57 AM
> To:	ALL OF EOG, OPB & SDD
> Subject:	GOVERNOR BUSH CREATES COMMISSION ON WORKERS' COMPENSATION
> REFORM
> 
> 
> FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
> CONTACT: ELIZABETH HIRST
> WEDNESDAY, MAY 22, 2002
> (850) 488-5394				           
> GOVERNOR BUSH CREATES COMMISSION ON 
> WORKERS' COMPENSATION REFORM
> ~~Commission charged with improving insurance, benefits for injured
> workers ~~
> 
> TAMPA--Governor Bush today issued Executive Order 02-158, creating the
> Governor's Commission on Workers' Compensation Reform.  Governor Bush
> charged the Commission to study and make policy recommendations regarding
> the availability and affordability of workers' compensation insurance,
> impediments to quicker resolution of workers' compensation claims, changes
> necessary to reduce the cost of workers' compensation insurance and the
> adequacy of benefits for injured workers.
> 
> 	"The cost of workers' compensation insurance in the state of Florida
> is among the highest in the nation, yet benefits paid to or on behalf of
> injured workers in Florida are among the lowest nationwide," said Governor
> Bush.  "The workers' compensation system needs to be reformed to better
> serve those it is intended to benefit, both employers and injured
> employees."
> 
> 	Studies related to workers' compensation indicate Florida's costs
> for:
> 
> *	Permanent and total disability claims are more than two-and-a-half
> times the national average; 
> *	Medical costs related to permanent partial impairment claims are two
> times the national average; 
> *	Medical claims for temporary total disability claims are 60 percent
> higher than the national average; and 
> *	Medical and indemnity costs for cases with legal involvement average
> over $40,000, more than 25 percent higher than the national average.
> 
> "The high cost of this insurance is placing an unnecessary burden on
> Florida's employers and remains an impediment to the state's ability to
> attract and retain businesses in this state," said Governor Bush.  "In
> order for Florida to be competitive with other states in attracting
> diverse industries to this state, the cost of workers' compensation
> insurance must be reduced."
> 
> "I applaud the Governor's goal of improving the availability and
> affordability of workers' compensation insurance in Florida," said
> Treasurer and Insurance Commissioner Tom Gallagher, whose department will
> oversee the Division of Workers' Compensation starting July 1.   "We look
> forward to being part of the solution to the escalating problems in our
> workers' compensation system - cost, safety, fraud and inefficiency.  I'm
> committed to supporting reforms that will reduce rising costs for
> employers while also improving the delivery of medical services to injured
> workers."
> 
> 	Governor Bush announced the following appointments to the Commission
> on Workers' Compensation Reform:
> 
> *	Pete Carpenter, of Jacksonville, Former Chief Operating Officer, CSX
> Transportation, Inc. (Chair).
> *	Claude Revels, of Keystone Heights, Corporate Safety Director, JM
> Family Enterprises, Inc. 
> *	Kathleen Davies, of Miami, Sr. Director of Safety and Risk
> Management, Burger King Corporation.  
> *	Carlos Cantero, of Orlando, Owner, C.D.S. Sitework and Trucking,
> Inc. 
> *	Derrick Wallace, of Orlando, President and Chief Executive Officer
> of Construct Two; President of the Economic Development Commission in
> Orlando; Board of Directors, Florida Chamber of Commerce.
> *	Judge Maria Ortiz, of Miami, Judge of Compensation Claims, District
> K.
> *	Hayden Dempsey, of Tallahassee, Executive Office of the Governor.
> *	Kevin McCarty, of Tallahassee, Department of Insurance.
> *	Dwayne Sealey, of Tallahassee, Secretary-Treasurer, Florida AFL-CIO.
> *	Stuart Colling, of Maitland, President of Florida Workers Advocates.
> *	Michael Ozegovich, of Key Largo, Community Services Director; South
> Florida Carpenters Regional Council.
> *	Sen. Bill Posey, of Rockledge, Chair of the Senate Banking and
> Insurance Committee.
> *	Rep. Leslie Waters, of Largo, Chair of the House Insurance
> Committee. 
> 
>      The Commission will hold public hearings throughout the state and
> shall submit its report and recommendations to the Governor and
> Legislature by January 31, 2003. 
> 
> 
> # # #
> STATE OF FLORIDA
> OFFICE OF THE GOVERNOR
> 	EXECUTIVE ORDER NUMBER 02-158
> 
> 
> WHEREAS, the cost of workers' compensation insurance in Florida is among
> the highest in the nation; and
> 
> WHEREAS, the high cost of workers' compensation insurance places an
> unnecessary burden on Florida's businesses and places Florida at a
> competitive disadvantage at attracting and retaining businesses to
> Florida; and
> 
> WHEREAS, workers' compensation benefits paid to or on behalf of injured
> workers in Florida are among the lowest in the nation; and
> 
> WHEREAS, recent studies have shown that Florida's workers' compensation
> system fails to perform as well as workers' compensation systems in other
> states.  According to recent studies, costs for permanent total disability
> claims and permanent partial impairment claims are more than two times
> higher than the national average; medical costs for temporary total
> disability claims are 60% higher than the national average; costs for
> cases with attorney involvement average more than 25% higher than the
> national average for cases with attorney involvement; and benefit delivery
> expenses and vocational rehabilitation costs have been increasing by 42%
> per year; and
> 
> WHEREAS, Senate Bill 108, passed during the 2002 Regular Session, requires
> the workers' compensation three member panel to evaluate the availability
> and accessibility of medical treatment for injured workers and the
> adequacy of the workers' compensation medical fee schedule and to submit
> its findings to the Legislature by January 1, 2003; and
> 
> WHEREAS, Florida's workers' compensation system requires a careful,
> deliberate evaluation to explore methods for reducing costs while
> protecting and improving the delivery of benefits to and on behalf of
> injured employees. 
> 
> Now, Therefore, I, Jeb Bush, as the Governor of the State of Florida, by
> the powers vested in me by the Constitution and laws of the state of
> Florida, do hereby promulgate the following Executive Order, effective
> immediately:
> 
> 
> Section 1.
> 
> A.	There is hereby created the Governor's Commission on Workers'
> Compensation Reform ("Commission").
> 
> B.	The Commission shall be comprised of 13 members, each appointed by
> the Governor.  The Governor shall designate one member to serve as the
> chair.  The Commission members shall receive no compensation, but shall be
> entitled to per diem and travel expenses while attending meetings of the
> Commission to the extent allowed by Section 112.061, Florida Statutes.
> 
> 	C.	The Commission shall act by a vote of the majority of its
> members.  A quorum of at least 9 members shall be required for an act of
> the Commission to have effect.  No member may grant a proxy for his or her
> vote to any other member or member designee, except with the prior
> approval of the chair.
> 
> 	D.	The first meeting of the Commission shall be held no later
> than June 28, 2002.
> 
> Section 2. 
> 
> A.	The Commission shall study and make written policy recommendations
> to the Governor, the President of the Senate, and the Speaker of the House
> of Representatives by January 31, 2003, regarding the following:
> 
> 		1.	The relative availability and affordability of
> workers' compensation insurance in Florida as compared to other states
> with similar relevant characteristics.
> 
> 		2.	Impediments to quick resolution of disputes and
> statutory changes necessary to facilitate quicker resolution of workers'
> compensation cases.
> 
> 		3.	Major cost drivers in the workers' compensation
> system and statutory changes necessary to reduce the cost of workers'
> compensation insurance in Florida.
> 
> 		4.	The adequacy of compensatory benefits for injured
> workers and statutory changes necessary to equitably compensate injured
> workers in the workers' compensation system.
> 
> 	B.	The Commission shall also review the report and findings of
> the workers' compensation three member panel to be completed pursuant to
> Committee Substitute for Committee Substitute for Senate Bill 108 and make
> specific recommendations based upon the report.
> 
> 
> Section 3. 
> 
> The Commission shall continue its existence until its objectives are
> achieved, but not later than July 1, 2003.  
> 
> 			IN TESTIMONY WHEREOF, I have hereunto set my hand
> and seal of the State of Florida to be affixed at Tallahassee, the
> Capitol, this 22nd day of May, 2002.
> 					
> 
> 
> 					___________________________________
> 					GOVERNOR
> 
> ATTEST:
> 
> 
> 
> ___________________________
> SECRETARY OF STATE				
>

Hello Governor,
Well you and your brother certainly wowed us in Miami yesterday!
Congratulations on a wonderful event, and also thanks and
congratulations to
you and your staff for all the hard work in bringing us through the very
difficult legislative process this year.  All in all, I think everyone
can
return home proud of the work that was accomplished under  trying
circumstances, but you deserve much of the kudos for bringing players to
the
table and reaching consensus.  Now, on to the 2002 election!

Also, as the newly elected chairman of the Florida Inland Navigation
District Commission, I wanted to bring to your attention an issue
dealing
with a pending appointment to this agency.  One of your 1999 appointees
to
the commission, Ji-Ang Song, an engineer from West Palm Beach, has
recently
had to resign his post due to a conflict with a new job.  That leaves
the
Palm Beach County seat vacant as we enter a crucial time of the year
when we
develop and adopt our FY2002-03 budget.  Although our annual budget is
rather small by comparison to other agencies ($40 million, and we have
managed to hold it to roll back rates for the past several years), it
nonetheless does involve a number of local cost share projects in each
of
our eleven counties.  As such, I suspect that Palm Beach County would
benefit from having a newly appointed commissioner looking after their
interests in this process.  I understand that you have several highly
qualified applicants pending at this time, and with all due respect,
would
like to call your attention to their interest in the commission
appointment.
Thank you!  I look forward to seeing you soon,
Cathy

From:	Brantley, Michelle K. <brantlem@fdhc.state.fl.us>
Sent:	Wednesday, May 22, 2002 11:26 AM
To:	'bgilbert@helios.acomp.usf.edu'
Cc:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	FW: Hyperbaric Oxygen Research on Cerebral Palsy and Autism


Mr. Gilbert,

In addition to the information provided below, it may also interest you to
know Medicare, BCBS and Aetna do not cover HBO therapy for conditions other
than those that are recognized as medically proven by HHS and the FDA. 

Thank you again for bringing your concerns to our attention.

Shelly
>  -----Original Message-----
> From: 	Brantley, Michelle K.  
> Sent:	Wednesday, May 22, 2002 9:15 AM
> To:	'bgilbert@helios.acomp.usf.edu'
> Cc:	'jeb@jeb.org'
> Subject:	Hyperbaric Oxygen Research on Cerebral Palsy and Autism
> 
> Dear Mr. Gilbert
> 
> Thank you for your recent e-mail to the Governor regarding the use of
> hyperbaric oxygen therapy for the treatment of cerebral palsy and autism.
> As I indicated at the Family CAFE Conference, Florida Medicaid reimburses
> for all medically necessary hyperbaric oxygen treatments provided by
> qualified and enrolled inpatient or outpatient hospitals with no
> limitations to eligible recipients under the age of 21.  However, in
> discussing hyperbaric oxygen therapy with hospitals across the State of
> Florida, we discovered treatment has been denied based on inclusive
> research and literature as to the overall benefits and risks of HBO for
> cerebral palsy and autism. In addition, the Department of Health & Human
> Services issued a warning letter on March 2001 expressing concerns about
> providers promoting hyperbaric oxygen therapy systems for numerous
> diseases, including cerebral palsy and autism, for which the FDA (Food and
> Drug Administration) has not authorized marketing clearance due to lack of
> scientific proof.  Similar warnings have been issued in other countries,
> such as Canada where other Medical Doctors have been attempting to provide
> this type of treatment on an experimental basis. Therefore, the use of HBO
> therapy is considered experimental in nature and does not meet the set of
> conditions established by the Agency for Health Care Adminstration (AHCA)
> in  Chapter 59G- 1.010 (166) Florida Administrative Code, for determining
> the need for and appropriateness of Medicaid services for an individual.
> Furthermore, because the FDA considers these conditions "off the label" ,
> by law no claims can be made. It may please you to know that a thorough
> review of Medicaid claims has been completed and we have confirmed that
> Medicaid has not reimbursed for any HBO therapy for the treatment of
> cerebral palsy or autism.
> 
> According to the Department of Health and Human Services, the FDA and the
> Undersea & Hyperbaric Medical Society, Hyperbaric Oxygen (HBOT), is a
> proven medical treatment for the following diseases and conditions:
> 
> Air or Gas Embolism;
> Carbon Monoxide poisoning or Carbon Monoxide Poisoning Complicated by
> Cyanide Poisoning;
> Clostridial Myostitis and Myonecronis (Gas Gangrene);
> Crush Injury, Compartment Syndrome, and other Acute Traumatic Ischemias; 
> Decompression Sickness;
> Enhancement of Healing in Selected Problem Wounds;
> Exceptional Blood loss (Anemia)
> Intracranial Abscess;
> Necrotizing Soft Tissue Infections; 
> Ostemyelis (Refactory);
> Delayed Radiation Injury (Soft Tissue and Bony Necrosis);
> Skin Grafts and Flaps (Compromised); and
> Thermal Burns.
> 
> Cerebral Palsy and autism are not list as approved indications of HBO.
> 
> A randomized, multicenter trial of HBO for children with cerebral palsy
> was published in the February 24, 2001 issue of the Lancet (Lancet
> 357:582-6). According to the publication "hyperbaric oxygen did not
> improve the condition of children with cerebral palsy compared with
> slightly pressurized air." The improvement seen in both groups for all
> dimensions tested deserves further consideration."
> 
> The United Cerebral Palsy research &Education Foundation also issued a
> statement. "During the past few years, a few clinicians have explored the
> use of hyperbaric oxygen in a variety of conditions such as stroke, head
> injury, spinal cord injury and multiple sclerosis. At this time, the
> published scientific literature does not support the use of this technique
> in any of those conditions. The same is true in regard to the use of
> hyperbaric oxygen in the treatment of developmental brain damage such as
> cerebral palsy or in the treatment of the impairments (e.g. spasticity) or
> disabilities (decreased mobility) associated with it. The problem has been
> lack of well controlled clinical trials evaluating the usefulness of the
> procedure utilizing a scientifically acceptable protocol. Individual
> stories (anecdotes") tell us very little; they are interesting; but not
> informative. There is no biological reason to assume that increased oxygen
> availability will have any effect on the old lesions in the brain of a
> person with disabilities due to a developmental brain disorder. Thus,
> until there is reasonable evidence that this is wrong, be cautious about
> claims to the contrary."
> 
> Our review of this issue also found that the few physicians that are
> willing to provide this treatment for individuals with cerebral palsy and
> autism in Florida are NOT Medicaid enrolled providers. These providers
> administer treatment in free-standing HBO centers which are not authorized
> for Medicaid reimbursement and these physicians are requesting payment on
> a private pay basis.
> 
> We hope this information helps to clarify the appropriate use of HBO
> therapy. We appreciate your interest in ensuring that Medicaid recipients
> with disabilities receive the most appropriate treatment for their health
> care needs. Please don't hesitate to contact me if additional information
> or assistance is needed.
> 
> Thank you for your service and advocacy on behalf of individuals with
> developmental disabilities.
> 
> Sincerely,
> 
> Shelly Brantley
> Bureau Chief
> Health Systems Development
> Agency for Health care Administration
>

-----Original Message-----
From: Benjamin Gilbert [mailto:bgilbert@helios.acomp.usf.edu]
Sent: Tuesday, May 21, 2002 12:51 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Hyperbaric O2 Treatment



Governor Bush,

We met at the Family Cafe.  I was the Physical Therapist who was
vehemently opposed to Medicaid covering Hyperbaric Oxygen Treatment for
Children and Adults with Neurological Disorders such as Cerebral Palsy
etc.  I apologize for the intensity of my emotion; however, I am an
advocate for the disabled community and will not tolerate the waist of
precious government funds.

After our conversation, I spoke with Lynn Metz at the State Medicaid
Office.  She states that she has been researching the subject since
yesterday per your instructions.  I asked whether she had found any
information which indicated Hyperbaric Oxygen Treatment was effective in
the treatment of Neurological Disorders.  She said "No" all the date
indicated Hyperbaric Oxygen Treatment was ineffective in treating
Neurological Disorders.  Just as I had said at the conference.  It is
notable that Hyerbaric Oxygen Treatment has been effective in wound care
however when treating anaerobic wounds.

I appreciate your quick attention to this matter.  Quite frankly I am
impressed with your diligence and honesty.  Mostly when a government
official tells you "I'll look into it" it is an empty promise.

I believe the State of Florida will save millions of dollars by
eliminating funding for Hyperbaric Oxygen Treatment for Neurological
Disorders, all of which can be directed towards aides which are
effective.  Additionally, individuals who advocate these treatment
regimens for children and adults with Cerebral Palsy are charlatans,
similar to those who advocate Chelation therapy etc.  They promise hope
to these families and deliver nothing.

Thanks again for your quick attention,
You are great,

Benjamin Gilbert MSPT

From:	Kathleen Kearney <Kathleen_Kearney@dcf.state.fl.us>
Sent:	Wednesday, May 22, 2002 12:55 PM
To:	timmo939@tcc.cc.fl.us
Cc:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	FW: Letter to Judge Kathleen Kearney

Dear Chris,

Governor Bush forwarded your e-mail to me at your request.  Thank you so
much for taking the time to write such thoughtful and compelling words.
Chris, you are one of the true heroes.  You have experienced first hand the
good and the bad of our foster care system.  Kids like you are why Governor
Bush always challenges us to do better every day. We have been working very
hard to bring about the systemic change that you refer to in your letter.
But, no matter how hard we work, the "system" will always depend on people
like Katherine Smith who dedicate their lives to protect children.  I am
glad that your relationship with your caseworker is such a positive one.

I would be interested in knowing your thoughts about what could be done to
discourage foster teens from running away.  This is a challenge for all
child welfare programs and your perspective would be very valuable to us.

I really appreciate the time you took to write.  Thanks for keeping all of
us that work in child welfare in your thoughts and prayers.

Judge K

-----Original Message-----
From: CHRISTOPHER TIMMONS [mailto:timmo939@tcc.cc.fl.us]
Sent: Tuesday, May 21, 2002 2:31 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Letter to Judge Kathleen Kearney


Governor Bush:

If you or your staff would send this letter to Secretary Kearney, I
would be eternally grateful.




                  21 May 2002



The Honorable Kathleen Kearney, Secretary
Florida Department of Children & Families
1317 Winewood Blvd., Building 1, Room 202
Tallahassee, Florida 32399-0700


Dear Secretary Kearney:


The Department of Children & Families is committed to working in
partnership with local communities to ensure safety, well-being and
self-sufficiency for the people we serve.  ----Florida Department of
Children & Families, Mission Statement.

In recent weeks, it has been found that the Florida Department of
Children & Families has not fully met its requirements to ensure that
all children under its care are safe, and free from harm. In the case of
Rilya Wilson questions, reasonably raised, about the state's performance
in protecting children in the child welfare system are very troubling.
It is essential that these issues are resolved quickly and that our
child welfare system is equipped with the tools necessary to guard
against failures similar to this in the future.

In the few weeks after the Rilya tragedy, our Governor Jeb Bush and the
Florida Legislature passed and signed into law, House Bill 71-E,
tailored specifically to prevent caseworkers that will not live up to
the high standards established by law, from falsifying records and
getting away with it.

This law sets penalties for those who would try to circumvent the law by
falsifying official state records of persons under the care and custody
of the state of Florida. In addition, it provides for 15 years in prison
for any record falsified that would eventually cause bodily harm or
death to any child under the state's care and supervision.

I commend the leadership of our Governor nd the Legislature, and
yourself madam Secretary in confronting this problem head on, and trying
to use all available resources to adequately deal with it.

A few days after the tragedy, the Governor formed a Blue Ribbon Panel
commissioned to provide an interim and definitive set of recommendations
for DCF to better fulfill its mission, and goals.

I sincerely hope, that these recommendations will encourage DCF to look
at what needs to be done, what has been done, and what will meet the
needs and safety of every child under its care for the 21st century.

Its so very important that DCF make systemic changes, because so many
children and families depend upon your agency, madam Secretary for their
very livelihood.

In this context, we need to look beyond the actions of a few caseworkers
that do not meet the high standards, and high demands our law and the
Department places on them; and look to the hardworking, committed
caseworkers across our state, working tirelessly, day in and day out to
help our most vulnerable---our children chart the path to live out their
dreams.

As a foster kid, here in Leon County, who happens to have benefited from
one such person, Katherine Smith, I see the need, and the eventually
inevitable urgency for affirmative action.  In the end, the long run,
this finally tears down a wall, built steadily over the years, that has
blocked the voice, and potential of so many kids throughout our state.


God bless.


Sincerely,


                                                                    Chris
Timmons

From:	Ann Thomson <ann@cilncf.org>
Sent:	Wednesday, May 22, 2002 2:13 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	House Bill 1307

I am writing to ask you to Veto House Bill 1307.

I work with High School Students with disabilities and help them make the
transition from High School to work or to post-secondary education or
training.  This is challenging for many reasons.  Decreasing accessibility
into buildings in our community will only add to the issues that prevent
these very capable students from being successful workers.

On behalf of the disabled community, we want assurance that our Florida
Statutes listing our more stringent accessibility laws not be changed,
altered, amended, deleted, or defaulted to the Federal Code in any way.  We
need to know that no one has changed the privileges and rights afforded to
Floridians that we worked so hard for.  Please veto HB 1307.

Thank you,

Ann W Thomson, MS, OTR/L
High School / High Tech Program Director

-----Original Message-----
From: Frark@aol.com <Frark@aol.com>
To: Jeb Bush <jeb@jeb.org>; frank.brogan@myflorida.com <frank.brogan@myflorida.com>
Sent: Wed May 22 14:05:17 2002
Subject: Messersmith: Email Version of Letter Mailed Today

Dear Gov. Bush and Lt. Gov. Brogan:

Last week a special committee of the Florida Sheriffs Association (FSA) 
gathered in Tallahassee to discuss the continuing and growing crisis 
involving law enforcement and the Florida Baker Act.
The meeting was called as a result of the unsuccessful effort to pass 
substantive legislation last session to amend the Baker Act to remove law 
enforcement from the “front lines” of dealing with and housing the mentally 
ill.

The Florida Sheriffs Association proposes reforming the Baker Act to permit 
intervention for those with severe mental illnesses who need treatment before 
they deteriorate to dangerousness and to allow court-ordered treatment in the 
community. These changes are necessary to reverse the current Baker Act trend 
of law enforcement agents increasingly acting as the front line contact for 
people with severe mental illnesses in crises.  Across the state law 
enforcement initiates 100 Baker Act petitions per day, nearly as many as 
those initiated by mental health professionals.  In nearly a third of our 
counties, law enforcement initiates nearly all of the petitions and mental 
health professionals initiate none.

The current Baker Act creates a public safety and quality of life problem for 
all Floridians.  People with severe mental illnesses are placed at risk 
because the law requires dangerousness before medical intervention can occur. 
 When someone finally reaches the point of dangerousness, other people and 
law enforcement are placed at substantial risk. Altercations between law 
enforcement and people with severe mental illnesses too often result in 
injury or death.  Additionally, the failure to receive prompt treatment 
results in an increasing number of these individuals to be placed in our 
correctional facilities. 

Reforming the Baker Act will allow for those with “revolving door” histories 
to be treated before they become dangerous.  The new criteria is designed 
specifically to ensure earlier intervention for recidivists.  The proposal 
also allows judges to order community based treatment rather than just 
hospitalization.  The reforms, the Sheriffs believe, should not require a new 
infusion of funding: the criteria is limited to recidivists and does not 
establish a new class to be treated; the community based treatment provisions 
are an option rather than a mandate; and, effective treatment will result in 
offsetting costs due to decreased hospitalizations, violence, and arrests.



However, in our effort to reform the Baker Act, we were opposed by numerous 
groups involved in the Florida judicial process (Public Defenders, Judges, 
Court Administrators, and so forth) due to their concern about lack of 
funding presently and fear that amendments will result in more costly 
processes and caseload changes.

Therefore, the Sheriffs are beginning a summer of meetings with 
“stakeholders” to attempt to resolve conflicts prior to next session when 
legislation will be filed again.  In that regard, and since this will require 
input, direction and budget considerations, the Sheriffs would like to meet 
with you and your staff to discuss this crisis, inform you about the proposal 
and fiscal issues posed, and seek your support and assistance for this 
crucial endeavor.

Sincerely, 

Frank S. Messersmith

-----Original Message-----
From: Lila Jaber [mailto:LJaber@PSC.STATE.FL.US]
Sent: Wednesday, May 22, 2002 12:54 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: Kathleen Shanahan (E-mail)
Subject: RE: PSC 



Governor,

This is in follow up to the email below from residents in the Boca Raton
area that are trying to get a FPL transmission line moved from their
neighborhood.  The concerns of the residents relate to whether the line in
question is in compliance with safety standards and other concerns, such as
diminished property value, loss of quiet enjoyment of their property, and
improper notice of other agency permitting proceedings.  Yesterday, after 4
1/2 hours of testimony from the residents, the Commission decided that we
did not have jurisdiction to address the concerns of the residents other
than whether the line meets national safety codes.  

On the issue of safety of transmission lines, the Commission has been given
statutory authority to enforce the National Electric Safety Code.  On
Tuesday, the Commission voted that the transmission line is in compliance
with this safety code.   Our decision on safety compliance will be issued as
proposed agency action since the matter has not been to hearing.  This means
the residents can protest our order and request an evidentiary hearing.  

With regard to jurisdiction, the Commission voted that the PSC lacks
statutory authority over the siting of this transmission line.  The PSC has
siting authority over transmission lines greater than 15 miles in length
under the Transmission Line Siting Act.  However, lines under that threshold
do not require certification under this act.  The transmission line in
question in this case is 4.5 miles in length.  Therefore, we lack any siting
authority.  Further, we decided that the PSC is not the proper forum to
address the other concerns of the residents relating to diminished property
value, lack of any notice to the residents of the line's construction, or
any of the aesthetic concerns raised by the residents.  Our General Counsel
advised that the circuit court system is the appropriate venue for this
debate.  

Let me know if you want more detail on this case.  Thank you.  Lila

Dear Governor:  I am one of three people from my community that have
filed a case with the PSC: Teresa Badillo FPSC Log: 344754E, Jose Gutman
FPSC Log: 366172E and Jeffrey Leserra FPSC log:  367987E.  The PSC flew
down and had a meeting on June 15,2001 with some of the representatives
from our community concerning the 100 Ft. Transmission Lines that were
placed on the right of way of the SFWMD in the back of our homes without
notification.  At that meeting we presented our issues and we were told
a "Resolution" would be given within a couple of weeks.  Well, months
and months passed and we never received the final resolution until I had
contacted your office a month ago and that precipated the PSC to finally
keep their word.  However, the individuals from the PSC's meeting last
June who were working with us trying to find an alternate route for FPL
(that was the main discussion of the meeting in June) no longer are
employed by the PSC for various reasons.  The new individual overseeing
everything is Mr. McLean at 850 413-7286.  Mr. McLean has shown no
interest whatsoever in helping us or at least continue what had been
initiated by the other individuals at the PSC who are now gone.
Consequently, the resolution sent to us indicated on very strong ground
that the case be dismissed.  None of the original issues at the meeting
in June had been taken into consideration nor have any of the
individuals involved with this resolution had first hand involvement
with us.  Now we are faced with a hearing with the Commissioners on May
21st and the odds are heavily weighted against us.  We have no
explanation why the PSC waited months to write a resolution and then
give us one with no regard to our original meeting that took place to
establish the issues in the first place.  I have tried to determine how
much impact this resolution will have on the Commissioners at the
hearing (which means we travel from Boca Raton to Tallahassee) by
speaking to Dr. Cochran Keating who has not been able to give me any
information in that regard.  I feel that resolution should be null and
void for two reasons - it should have been sent to us immediately after
the original meeting with the individuals involved with the case.  Plus
the Agenda for the Commission Conference is based on resolution which
has dismissed our case.  We are limited to 3 issues they feel relevant
which have nothing to do with our original meeting or complaint.  If
something could please be done so that justice could prevail here!  We
are walking into a den of lions with no recourse.  The writing is on the
wall and our hands are tied.  Please help!!  One of the issues I brought
up at this meeting in June was concerning a zoning violation.  FPL had
been running electricity through these transmission lines for over three
months without a CO.  The PSC wants to have safety issues - well,
nothing was said but a letter sent to me stating that FPL recitified the
situation after the fact.  I was expecting to get an injunction for a
zoning violation because the PSC lawyer Ms. Isaac had said that would be
the case if we found a  zoning violation.  I have all the information
and the paperwork to prove this happened.  I can be reached at 561
482-2855 or Badillo9@aol.com.  Please let us know what we need to do.
Thank you so very much for any input you may have.  Teresa Badillo

From:	Terry L. Rice <tlrice@adelphia.net>
Sent:	Wednesday, May 22, 2002 3:42 PM
To:	Joette Lorion
Subject:	IOP Public Mtg
Attachments:	8.5-IOPMtg-020522.pdf

Joette ... from the attached letter that I just received, it appears that the 8.5 SMA residents were not permitted to give public comment at the IOP public meeting last night on anything to do with the 8.5 SMA, to include on the Corps modeling which indicates increase flooding in their area due to the degradation of the southern 4 miles of the L-67 extension levee.  Not sure I understand why ... since you were there maybe you can explain?
 
This L-67 removal issue strikes at the heart of our objections with how the IOP is being implemented, i.e. making structural changes now before the modeling is finalized or the IOP EIS ROD has been signed ... both modeling and ROD are not expected to be finalized until June but implementation has already begun.  In the case of the L-67 levee degradation, which has always been scheduled to be the last component of Mod Waters completed because of such flood protection issues, it is already being completed, modeling indicates it will in fact exacerbate flooding, and it can't be reversed ... if in fact the final modeling demonstrates increased flooding, residents in Miami-Dade County will experience increased flooding until Mod Waters is complete ... "the bell can't be un-rung" unless the L-67 extension is reconstructed or the 8.5 protection levee is built quickly ... what was already a bad situation for flooding in M-D county has just gotten worse ... and this without a completed EIS which is our safeguard to preventing such.
 
And by the way, the Corps current modeling results have been removed from public access on the Jax Corps web site ... did they explain this at the meeting last night?  Do agencies get to see them?  Tribes are to be treated by the federal agencies in a "government-to-government" relationship ... was this addressed as a reason to give the Miccosukee Tribe access if other government entities have access?
 
Did someone bring up the Miami-Dade County Flood Management Task Force resolution of last week that IOP should never be implemented until it is clear that there is solid evidence that flooding in Miami-Dade county will not be exacerbated? And this was after a Corps presentation that said the current modeling did show increased flooding.
 
Please give me your insights!
 
Terry

<<Blue Ribbon Panel Correspondence to Governor Jeb Bush.doc>> 

From:	HERBERT.LAURENCIA <HERBERT.LAURENCIA@leg.state.fl.us>
Sent:	Wednesday, May 22, 2002 5:00 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Blue Ribbon Panel Correspondence
Attachments:	Blue Ribbon Panel Correspondence to Governor Jeb Bush_.doc

Importance:	High

From:	HERBERT.LAURENCIA <HERBERT.LAURENCIA@leg.state.fl.us>
Sent:	Wednesday, May 22, 2002 5:07 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Blue Ribbon Panel Correspondence to Governor Jeb Bush.doc

Importance:	High

May 22, 2002
 
Dear Gov. Bush:
 
On Monday, May 6, 2002, you established a Blue Ribbon Panel on Child Protection to review the performance of the states child protection system in Miami Dade County.  The panel is comprised of community leaders who I am sure bring a wealth of experience and wisdom to the task before them as you stated in your press release before appointing them.  Any panel created to investigate any inappropriate actions in the Department of Children and Family (DCF) should be ethnically and racially diverse, especially in Miami-Dade County.  The panel should reflect the citizens of Miami-Dade County, since 85% of the children in the custody of the DCF are African American.  Members of the African American community called this fact to the attention of your office.   Their requests and cries for inclusion went unheeded. Therefore, today as an elected member of the Florida Legislature, I am asking you on behalf of my community that you diversify the Blue Ribbon Panel on Child Protection.  It is my belief that without the proper racial and cultural diversity, the Blue Ribbon Panel will be unable to make meaningful recommendations that will holistically address the needs of the population of children within the DCF. Consequently, the Black community will meet any recommendations with skepticism and suspicion. 
 
I am recommending to you three (3) African American Health Care Professionals and Child Advocates to serve on the Blue Ribbon Panel.  They are Dr. Marietta Mischia, former M-DCPS Principal and member of the Community Relations Board; Ms. Tangela Sears, former employee of the DCF; and Ms. Irene Brown Humes, Foster and Adoption Parent.  I have contact information for all of them and they are willing to serve on the panel.
 
It is of the utmost importance that before the panel completes their final report, there is input reflected from all segments of the community.  The problem in foster care is systemic and we must be diligent about changing the system from top to bottom. It is my understanding that the present panel members, excluding Sarah Herald, were recommended to you by Judge Kathleen Kearney.  Also, Judge Kearney told you the questions that the panel should ask and what they should do.  She also suggested that Dave Lawrence serve as Chair and laid out the specific questions for the panel.  It is insidious to think that Judge Kearney would recommend the panel to review the agency that she heads when she should be the target of the investigation.  In fact, I am appalled at the lack of public outcry for the resignation of Judge Kearney and Charles Auslander.  In fact, I am utterly disgusted over the fact that Mr. Auslander has not been arrested.  He is guilty of failure to report the disappearance of a minor and guilty of obstruction of justice.  He failed to immediately report Rilya’s disappearance and he obstructed justice when he deliberately withheld this information for six days.  If a biological parent had committed such an offense, the DCF would have moved swiftly to remove the child from the home and prosecute. In his position, Mr. Auslander is the surrogate parent of thousands of unwanted children.  They are trusted to his care and, as their state appointed guardian, he should be more responsible to them. If we want to change the system for the benefit of our children, we must change the system at its root. To that end, we must hold administrators accountable just as we would hold the general public accountable. 
 
I am also asking that you extend the deadline date, of the final report, in order for you to have the opportunity to diversify the membership of the panel.  I look forward to a response from you today.  I can be contacted at (305) 995-2451 or e-mailed at mdelancey@sbab.dade.k12.fl.us.
 
Respectfully,
 
Rep. Frederica S. Wilson, Member
House District 104
 
cc:  Mr. Dave Lawrence                   Rev. Willie Simms                        Members of Dade Delegation
       Mr. Larry Capp        Adora Obi Nweze Bishop Victor T. Curry
 
From:	MBA President <jackm@mbacompanies.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, May 22, 2002 6:13 PM
To:	Peter's Mail
Cc:	Jerry Maygarden; Jerry Melvin
Subject:	Re: Beach Patrol

From:	Jimenez, Frank <Frank.Jimenez@MyFlorida.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, May 22, 2002 7:08 PM
To:	Jeb Bush; Canady, Charles T.
Subject:	RE: IMPORTANT!!!

Someone from DBPR will call Mr. Tilton and tell him he can call himself
"Practical Engineer," but call himself nothing else.  See the following from
DBPR's Geoff Becker: 

"Sorry it has taken so long to get back to you on this.  Several years ago,
the licensing, regulation and enforcement of the engineering profession was
privatized.  The state now contracts with a private corporation to manage
this function.  The corporation is called the Florida Engineering Management
Corporation (http://www.fbpe.org/femc/).  Our acting-director of the Div. of
Professions (David Minacci), who is also the executive director of the
Florida Engineering Society, contacted them about Mr. Kononoff's e-mail and
Mr. Tilton's situation.  Here is his response...

'Unlike almost all other professions, the term "engineer" is not protected
under Chapter 471.  The only term that was protected was "professional
engineer".  This resulted in people holding themselves out as "civil
engineer", "structural engineer", or "chemical engineer" that were not
licensed which is very misleading to the public.  For example, there was
nothing in F.S. 471 that would prohibit someone from advertising as 'John
Doe, Structural Engineer.'  Florida Chapter 471 only prohibited someone from
holding themselves out as 'John Doe, Professional Engineer.'  During the
last legislative session, the Florida Engineer Society pushed for a bill (SB
990), and Legislature passed it, that protected those disciplines that are
actually tested to become a professional engineer resulting in not only the
term "professional engineer" being protected but many other disciplines
including those mentioned above.'

The point not included in his remarks here is that the term "practical" is
not covered in the new legislation.  Therefore, there is nothing precluding
Mr. Tilton from calling himself a "practical engineer."  We have checked
with FEMC and they have no record of anyone calling about such a
classification and would not advise them they needed some type of licensure.
However, should they want to practice themselves under the new provisions or
classifications, they would need to be properly licensed.  

Please let me know if you need anything else.  Again, sorry for the delay."

-----Original Message-----
From: mboland_@bellsouth.net [mailto:mboland_@bellsouth.net]
Sent: Wednesday, May 22, 2002 5:16 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: University of Florida Police Department


Dear Sir:
     My name is Michael S. Boland and I work as a Police Officer for the University of Florida Police Department.  I am writing you this letter in reference to our budget problem.  Our administration informed us that our operating budget has been cut in the amount of approximately 130,000.00 Dollars.  As a result we can only operate 4 patrol vehicles on shift because of the cost of gasoline and we do not have the funds to properly repair our vehicles.  This places officers at unneeded risk due to the extended response time for "back-up" to arrive and does not allow us the properly patrol the "sensitive" areas as needed.  I honesty do not know where the operating budget is spent or how it is divided and dispersed.  I know the state leaders would not cut the budget so severely that our department could not afford gasoline for our patrol vehicles. I realize that you alone do not have the resources to look into this problem but could you please tell me who could?  Any information you could provide would be helpful.

Thank You,
Michael Boland

-----Original Message-----
From: Bill Sammons [mailto:whsammons@msn.com]
Sent: Wednesday, May 22, 2002 6:03 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: Kathleen_Kearney@DCF.State.FL.US
Subject: Request From Noah's Ark for help re: the criminalization of disabilities



Jeb:

First, all of the parents and kids at Noah’s Ark appreciate your support. It has been essential. And thanks for your help and participation with the Family Café.

This email is to let you know of a practice of the State of Florida, a practice that I believe you would work to stop immediately if you knew about it.

I am working as a volunteer advocate for Steven, a 5th grader with significant development disabilities. He appears to be somewhere on the autism continuum. In the third grade Steven was arrested for hitting his teacher.  For the next year instructors from The Brown School came to his house twice a week, for an hour to two hours a session, in an effort to train him to be competent so he could be prosecuted for hitting his teacher. After a year they were unsuccessful.  Steven was not prosecuted. 

The Brown School is a company contracted by the State of Florida, and I am guessing at the direction of the state attorneys and/or judges, to train the developmentally disabled charged with crimes to become competent to stand trial. What I can’t understand is that a representative of the Browns School boasted that approximately 30 percent of the people they work with have IQ’s of 50 or below. They claim they are able to make 50% of those with IQ’s 50 or below competent to stand trial. To me, this is absurd. 

Back to Steven …Steven again has been charged with hitting his teacher. Steven needs services to help overcome his disabilities, not training so he can parrot answers that will put him in a juvenile detention center. If behavioral therapists had come to Steven’s house once a week and to his school once a week for a year, instead of receiving the Brown’s School instruction, there would have been a much better chance he, and his single mom, would not be facing the current charges. The State has money for competency training that hopes to permit the state to prosecute a developmentally delayed third grader, but the schools do not have the money for behavior therapists. 

In October Drew, my 16 year old son with Asperger’s Syndrome ( a high-functioning autistic), was arrested on complaints by teachers in his center school and taken to the Juvenile Detention Center. Often teachers are not properly trained and can't get the support services they feel they need.  The week before Drew’s teacher filed charges, she was scheduled to get long sought training.  That training that was canceled due to lack of funds.  The teachers and staff are frustrated and strike out though the criminal justice system.  She filed charges. 

The system in the State of Florida is criminalizing many of those with developmental disabilities in the year 2002. We had to have my son declared incompetent.  In the behavior arena, the State is destroying the self esteem the developmentally disabled and is demoralizing their parents. 

Please look into The Brown School. See if the information I believe to be correct really is. Please look into the lack of behavioral therapists and the criminalization of those with developmental disabilities. My special needs attorney promises me teachers are having developmentally disabled students arrested all over the state.  And finally, let’s amend the law that says anytime a teacher is hit or kicked by a student, a felony has been committed.  The very young and those with significant developmental disabilities should be exempt.  You have to know that just in Polk County alone over 20 “felonies” a day are being committed by elementary school children with developmental disabilities when they kick or hit their teachers.  Each teacher can chose to deny the student reentry to their classroom and go through due process and/or the teacher can file criminal charges.  More and more teachers are just filing criminal charges.     

Steven’s mom is a single parent and can’t afford the special needs attorney, the criminal attorney, and the expert witness I hired for my son Drew. Steven has a pro bono attorney who is giving the matter a little attention.  Most developmentally disabled kids and their families are thrown out of the education system and into the criminal justice maelstrom without a rudder.  What they need are trained staff and teachers and the active involvement of behavior analysts. 

Your help in doubling the developmentally disabled budget in the last three years has been amazing.  Your help with Noah’s Ark has been amazing.  Steven, his mom, Drew, my wife, myself, and kids all over the state need yet another miracle. 

Noah's Ark of Central Florida

Bill Sammons, President

 <mailto:Bill@SCRproperties.Com> Bill@SCRproperties.Com

Phone : (863) 688-3323

Fax: (863) 680-1603

505 Bartow Road

Lakeland, Fl 33801-5466

have done stories on this issue and the nation media has picked up on
it.

our complaints are kicked back to the DPR for a reply but the main
problem is the DPR!!!.

jurisdiction.

these fraudulent scams
 to continue unabated.

this industry or enforce the state laws that they are charged with
enforcing.
Julie Baker and her (personal staff attorney) should be fired for
ignoring all the well documented and reported crimes of these victims. 

I know first hand about this issue because I've been trying to get some
action taken
 on behalf of the many victims for the last year and a half. 
As a victims we've been forced to spend our own funds to investigate and
pursue this matter 
and that's a crime.

Three (3) Tampa area modeling and talent agencies have had a DPR issued
licenses that have allowed them to continually steal from the public
while stealing unreported income tax
and sales tax dollars from the State of Florida. 
We're seeking a solution to this pressing issue before the national
televised segment airs.

From: Michael S. Blake, Sr. CFP [mailto:mblake@strategix.org]
Sent: Wednesday, May 22, 2002 11:47 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Tri-County League of Cities (central Florida) Luncheon engagement for Growth Management



Dear Governor Bush,

 

Thank you for taking time to call me last evening!  WOW! I am honored by your personal response!

 

Please accept our invitation to be the honored guest speaker on your Growth Management initiatives at the Tri-County League of Cities luncheon at noon on Tuesday, Wednesday or Thursday during the weeks of July 9-11 or August 6-8 in Seminole County. We will be flexible to accommodate your schedule, and an alternate date could be arranged with your staff if necessary.

 

The Tri-County League of Cities membership includes all 22 cities of Orange, Seminole, and Osceola counties as well as the counties themselves.  Each month we gather together at alternating locations throughout central Florida to discuss common issues affecting the heart of Florida. As we discussed during our telephone conversation, this engagement would provide an audience of local elected officials, members of the business community and regional leaders.  

 

The exact location would be determined by your chosen date, but will generally be within 30 minutes of Orlando-Sanford Airport or Orlando International Airport. On another note, our luncheons are typically sponsored by the business community to help defray the costs.  Please have your staff contact me regarding the selection of the most appropriate sponsors for an event of this type.

 

Mr. Governor, this occasion will provide excellent exposure for your Growth Management initiatives to the leaders in central Florida who tackle these challenges on the front line, and are the primary contact point for citizens interacting with their government.  I look forward to working with your staff through the planning process.

 

 

With warm regards,

 

 

Michael Blake

Commissioner, City of Winter Springs
