From:	Sara Struhs <sstruhs@nettally.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, May 22, 2002 10:57 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Re: ichetucknee cement plant fup

Governor:
I think this issue is being somewhat misrepresented to you.

BASIC FACTS
The 100 acre mine has been there for probably at least 20 years... certainly
well before there was a DEP and before any environmental permits were
required.

When the County made the zoning decisions to allow the cement plant to be
built adjacent to the rock mine, it based that decision on the expectation
of future, expanded mining to support the plant.  This was well understood
by all involved.

Indeed, the company applied for a permit for mine expansion two years ago.
Curiously, during this entire period, not a single protest or objection was
filed by anyone.  The department is now compelled by law to issue the
permit.

I am scheduled to speak to Julie Hauserman about this tomorrow morning.  I
am also schedule to see you in the afternoon.  I will let you know how it
goes.

MORE BACKGROUND
As you know we took the bold step of denying initial permit applications to
build the cement plant because the company had outstanding environmental
compliance problems with other operations.  It is fair to say that under
previous Administrations, they would not have encountered any delays or
objections -- we raised the bar by saying that past performance should count
before new permits are issued.

Eventually, the compliance problems were resolved and restitution was made,
and existing laws compelled the Department to issue the permit to build the
cement plant.

For the past two years, we have filed bills in the Legislature that would
enhance DEP's ability to fairly and predictably consider an applicant's past
performance before new permits are issued.  (For example, we would issue
longer term permits for good performers and shorter term permits for poor
performers.  In exceptional cases, we could determine not to issue a permit
at all.)  The Legislature has not been eager to pass these bills.

Bottom line: we are both executing the law and trying to improve the law.
We are also holding the company more accountable than ever before.  I can
share more on these points with you tomorrow.

Frank and Kathleen are both alert to this issue and are aware of my call
tomorrow.

Thanks,
David


----------

From:	Burt Hampton <burt@enstechlabs.com>
Sent:	Thursday, May 23, 2002 1:57 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	A new development in landfill technology.

Importance:	High

Enstech Inc.
Environmental Services and Technologies
 
 
Thursday, May 09, 2002
 
RE: New generations of safe landfill containments that can pinpoint the liner leaks, contain the escaping leachate, and repair the leaks, allowing landfills for the first time in history to be able to be maintained.
 
Dear Sir or Madam,
 
In the 10 years of the R.C.R.A. rules becoming law, every aspect of the way this nation and industry addresses its waste has dramatically improved to better protect our environment, except for landfill containments. The same basic landfill design and technology used 10 years ago is still used today, and all past and present day landfills contain a serious flaw. 
The current landfill designs and systems lack the ability to monitor their barrier liners. The lack of ability to accurately monitor their lining systems prevents today’s lining systems from being maintained. Any science or technology that does not have the ability to accurately evaluate it’s own integrity in regards to its intended purpose and usage by using reliable checks and balances, is flawed and incomplete. The current need for improved landfill science and technology becomes apparent when it is estimated that out of all of the disposal methods used today, 47% of all waste generated goes into landfill containments.
After 10 years of research and development, there is a new science and technology that will allow all new landfills, containments, and their liners to be maintained. I have created a web presentation of the ENSTECH system, showing how the system works in a typical landfill application, on www.enstechinc.com <http://www.enstechinc.com/>  . The web presentation will show how the ENSTECH system will work in pinpointing the leaks, and then contain and repair the leaks in municipal, industrial, hazardous, and cold radioactive landfills. It must be understood that until the ENSTECH system’s development, no previous containment technology has had the ability to accurately find, contain and repair any leaks.
Not shown in this web presentation is the Enstech high heat resistant metal lining system. For an example of the liner module made of heat resistant metal, refer to the diagram at  <http://www.enstechinc.com/diagram.jpg> http://www.enstechinc.com/diagram.jpg . As you watch the web presentation, in your mind, replace all the plastic lining and piping with nuclear grade stainless steel or titanium. This containment system can be used under heat generating sources in industrial manufacture, such as hot caustic or cooling tanks. The same system can be employed under heat generating nuclear material and waste, such as radioactive water, sludges, and solids including used nuclear fuel rods. By using this simple design change, the public and government alike can be assured that no radioactive waste or material has escaped from the containment. The same critical assurance can be made that no out-of-containment water will leak back into the containment. With the development of the Enstech high-heat lining system comes the ability to safely contain and monitor hot waste and materials.
I have sent this same letter to Administrator Whitman, asking for her help in establishing this new containment system as Best Available Control Technology (BACT). I have also asked for her help with all E.P.A. programs and awards that will apply in bringing this technology to this nation. I hope to gain written permission to use the E.P.A. logo endorsement that has been given to other such technologies.
Please review the presentation and write me back with your thoughts and suggestions regarding this new technology. I look forward to your response regarding this matter. 
 
 
 
 
 
Thank you,
                                         
 
 
Burt Hampton, C.E.O.

P.O. Box 1557

Magnolia, AR 71753
(870)-234-1421
burt@enstechinc.com 
burt@enstechlabs.com

Dear Governor Bush:
 
I am writing you to express my support for Allen Register as Circuit Judge in the Fourteenth Judicial Circuit.  I have known Judge Register for almost twenty years now and know of his active involvement in our community.  He has served as our County Judge since 1992 and has the reputation of being a fair and informed judge. I believe Judge  Register holds and reflects the same conservative values most of us here in Washington County hold dear.

Importance: High


Dear Pam



I just had a lengthy conversation with Ana Sotorrio of MIA on this issue and
she strongly feels that the Governor's intervention could be decisive in
obtaining a favorable resolution on the INS issue and resolving this problem
for our air carriers. She feels that a letter from the Governor to the INS
Commissioner accompanied by a phone call from the Washington office or
yourself, should provide the needed nudge to get INS to reach agreement with
MIA. 

It is a time sensitive issue since they would like to see this issue
resolved by May 15th which is the start of the summer travel season. If you
would like I can start working on a draft along the lines of what we wrote
for the US Customs Commissioner for the INS Commissioner. Let me know.


Manny 


-----Original Message-----
From: Ana Sotorrio [mailto:ASOTORRIO@miami-airport.com]
Sent: Wednesday, May 08, 2002 3:52 PM
To: Dana, Pam
Cc: Miguel Southwell; Manny Mencia; Eric Olafson (E-mail)
Subject: RE: 


Unfortunately, Pam, it didn't go at all.  Once again, INS was not available
to meet with us.  It was not until this morning that Miguel Southwell met
with Mr. Jack Garafano, INS Miami District Director, and Port Director Jorge
Roig.  Mr. Garafano claims that he has not seen the Department of Justice
Memorandum for Regional Directors regarding ITI Transit and Progressive
Clearance Procedures, which was issued on April 22,2002.  We gave him a copy
and could not move the conversation beyond the first line of the section of
the memo on ITI Flights, which states "The carrier must provide 100% Advance
Passenger Information (API) electronic data in advance of the aircraft's
arrival."  Mr. Garafano interprets this to mean that air carriers must be
100% APIS compliant. No airline is 100% APIS compliant.  Mr. Garafano's
interpretation is not consistent with ours, or Customs, or the airlines, or
anybody else who understands these issues and has seen the document.  Mr.
Garafano said he needs to review the memo carefully and then call
headquarters.  In the meantime, we are also attempting to get clarification
from INS headquarters.  

If we can get beyond this issue, the next battle with INS will be about
facilities and technology.  Our ITI lounges do not contain INS-approved
inspection booths, nor does the capability exist to conduct IBIS computer
queries.  We can provide the booths and IBIS capability in the future, but
not in time for the peak summer travel season.  At our meeting in
Washington, we were led to believe that INS would work with us on interim
solutions, but given our current experience with INS we are less than
confident that this will be the case.

We could use your help in getting INS Headquarters to clarify the APIS
issue.  We and the airlines interpret the requirement to be 100%
transmission of APIS electronic data - 100% APIS compliance is quite
different and not attainable.

We are still trying to implement the full modified procedures on May 15.
Without INS's cooperation, this will not be possible.  Please call me at
305-876-7533 to discuss this in greater detail.  Thank you.

  <http://www.broward.com/images/common/spacer.gif> 	Posted on Thu, May. 23, 2002	   <http://www.broward.com/images/component/topstory_fromthe_txt.gif>  story:PUB_DESC <http://www.broward.com/images/logos/site/miami/miamiherald/archives_title.gif> 	  <http://www.broward.com/images/common/spacer.gif> 	
  <http://www.broward.com/images/common/spacer.gif> 	

Big gun takes on Wingate
BY BRAD BENNETT
bbennett@herald.com


 Jan Schlichtmann, the attorney portrayed in the movie îA Civil Action,' will try to prove a link between chemicals at the landfill and disease around it.
 <http://www.broward.com/images/miami/miamiherald/3317/11003317250.jpg> 	
J. Albert Diaz/Herald Staff	
  <http://www.broward.com/images/common/spacer.gif> 	
Jan Schlichtmann, the attorney portrayed in the movie îA Civil Action,' will try to prove a link between chemicals at the landfill and disease around it. 	

Jan Schlichtmann, the attorney portrayed by John Travolta in the movie A Civil Action, has joined the fight over Fort Lauderdale's Wingate landfill.

The Beverly, Mass., attorney won $8 million in 1986 for families who alleged that their children died of leukemia due to pollutants dumped in the Boston suburb of Woburn, Mass.

Now, Schlichtmann and at least eight other attorneys have filed papers to form a new local law firm that will try to prove a link between toxic chemicals buried at the Wingate landfill and high rates of disease around it, primarily in the 33311 and 33313 ZIP codes.

The firm, the Environmental Justice Project, will seek damages from the city of Fort Lauderdale and at least 38 companies that allegedly dumped toxic waste there.

''We're going to approach them and ask them a lot of questions,'' Schlichtmann said. ``We want to do it in an atmosphere in which we're sharing information.''

Schlichtmann's involvement will undoubtedly bring greater attention to a battle that has raged for years. The landfill, at 1300 NW 31st Ave. in Fort Lauderdale, operated from 1954 to 1978. Some residents believe its contaminants are to blame for illnesses they have had.

''We're always willing to sit down and talk,'' said Greg Kisela, a Fort Lauderdale assistant city manager. ``But at this point we have not seen any link between Wingate and any particular illness.''

The city has capped the landfill and wants to create a golf course on the site, a plan which is controversial. Legal Aid Service of Broward County plans next month to appeal the capping plan, which was approved by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency.

Schlichtmann said it is critical that the community come together to reach a solution -- a lesson he said he learned in the Massachusetts case. ''If anything will be done, it will be because the community comes together,'' he said. ``You can't do it on your own.''

The lawyers, who have kicked in about $500,000 of their own money to get started, hope to reach a settlement without having to sue. They would take a percentage of the settlement, and have not ruled out a class-action lawsuit.

They include Miami attorneys J.B. Harris, Edward Montoya and Buddy Payne as well as Johnny McCray Jr. of Fort Lauderdale, Grover Hankins of Houston -- a former general counsel for the national NAACP -- Tab Turner of Little Rock, Ark., Frederick Kuykendal of Alabama and the law firm of Levin Papantonio of Pensacola.

To quantify the landfill problems -- including a link between the landfill and disease -- the attorneys have hired a private investigator who will look at the site and people living around it.

They also plan to consult doctors, scientists, epidemiologists, sociologists and psychologists to determine whether Wingate residents have suffered any damage.

Some of the 38 companies say they are doing their part to solve the Wingate problem by participating in the EPA-ordered, plastic-capping plan.

''The cleanup has been successfully completed. We were very cooperative,'' said Peggy Palter, spokeswoman for Sears, Roebuck and Co., who added that more than a thousand other companies and the general public dumped in the landfill. ``We did what we were asked to do by the EPA.''

Mike Haggerty, a spokesman for Florida Power & Light, said FPL also has agreed to cooperate with approved solutions to the Wingate problem.

''The group formed to manage and clean up the Wingate site has always supported a study of the health effects,'' Haggerty said, adding that his firm had minimal participation.

Schlichtmann, 51, who also works with a Pensacola law firm, said Wednesday he is trying to gauge whether the community will stand behind the new law firm's plan.

If so, he and other attorneys will form a nonprofit community coalition made up of Wingate area residents named TOXIC, which stands for Team of Exposed Individuals to Contaminants.

Civic activist Leola McCoy, who has long fought to have the Wingate toxins cleaned up properly, showed her support on Wednesday by inviting the lawyers to her home for lunch.

''I think the community needs to understand that it needs to play its part,'' McCoy said.

Subject:	RE: MESSAGE FROM THE FBI COUNTERTERRORISM DIVISION

Tim,

Thanks for the heads up.  As you know we are conducting information
technology security audits on state agencies.  As part of this process, our
Security Office received this alert May 21, 2002 at 9:50AM; it was
immediately forwarded to the Agency Chief Information Officers and
Information Security Officers/Managers.

Our Security Office action is to follow-up to ensure agencies take
appropriate action.

thanks again,

Kim

>  -----Original Message-----
> From: 	Arnold, Rod

> --NLETS--
> ***** UNABLE TO ROUTE MESSAGE TO ORI *****
> AM.DCFBIWAE6
> 16:05 05/22/2002 06136
> 16:05 05/22/2002 20033 FL
> TXT (AP,PA009015Y)
> REQUEST NATIONAL BROADCAST
> ML01DGROSS
> 
> NLETS MESSAGE (ALL POINTS)
> 05/22/02
> MESSAGE FROM FBI COUNTER-TERRORISM DIVISION, WASHINGTON, 
> D.C.
> SUBJECT: NATIONAL INFRASTRUCTURE PROTECTION CENTER 
> INFORMATION SYSTEM ADVISORY 02-003, 
> "MICROSOFT SQL WORM SPIDA".
> SUMMARY:
> THE NATIONAL INFRASTRUCTURE PROTECTION CENTER (NIPC) IS 
> MONITORING AN INTERNET WORM CALLED "SPIDA", ALSO KNOWN AS 
> SQLSNAKE. THIS WORM TAKES ADVANTAGE OF DEFAULT SETTINGS 
> WITHIN MICROSOFT'S SQL SERVER (MSSQL) WHEN THERE IS A 
> SYSTEM ADMINISTRATOR USERNAME OF "SA" AND NO
> PASSWORD. THE DANGER IN THIS WORM IS THAT IT COPIES THE 
> PASSWORD FILE AND THE NETWORK CONFIGURATION OF THE 
> INFECTED MACHINE AND SENDS THE INFORMATION ELSEWHERE VIA 
> EMAIL. THIS WORM CAN EVOLVE INTO A DENIAL OF SERVICE 
> (DOS) ATTACK AGAINST THE INFECTED MACHINE AND OTHERS ON 
> THE SAME NETWORK BECAUSE OF THE VOLUMINOUS EMAIL TRAFFIC 
> THE WORM INITIATES ONCE INSIDE THE INFECTED
> MACHINE.  
> DESCRIPTION:
> THE SPIDA WORM SEARCHES FOR MSSQL SERVERS THAT HAVE BEEN 
> SET UP WITH THE DEFAULT SYSTEM ADMINISTRATOR ACCOUNT WITH 
> USERNAME OF "SA" AND A BLANK PASSWORD FIELD THAT WAS NOT 
> CHANGED AFTER INSTALLATION.  ONCE INSIDE, SPIDA SENDS THE 
> INTERNET PROTOCOL (IP) CONFIGURATION OF THE MACHINE AND 
> THE DOMAIN PASSWORD FILE AS WELL AS A VARIETY OF 
> MACHINE-SPECIFIC INFORMATION TO A TEMPORARY FILE.  THE 
> TEMPORARY FILE THAT CONTAINS THE IP AND PASSWORD FILES IS 
> THEN SENT TO A COLLECTION POINT FROM A FULLY PRIVILEGED 
> "GUEST" ACCOUNT THAT SPIDA SETS UP.
> MSSQL SERVERS INSTALLED WITH "INTEGRATED SECURITY MODE" 
> SETTINGS ARE NOT AT RISK.  THOSE SERVERS INSTALLED WITH 
> "MIXED MODE" SECURITY SETTINGS, WITHOUT A PASSWORD FOR 
> THE "SA" ACCOUNT, ARE AT RISK.  TO SET THE PASSWORD AFTER 
> INSTALLATION, SEE:  HTTP://WWW.MICROSOFT.COM/SQL
> 
> THE SUCCESS OF THIS WORM HIGHLIGHTS SHORTFALLS IN BASIC 
> CONFIGURATION MANAGEMENT AND SYSTEM SECURITY.  ONCE 
> SOFTWARE IS INSTALLED, DEFAULT USERNAMES AND PASSWORDS 
> THAT CAN BE CHANGED, SHOULD BE CHANGED.  NOTE THAT 
> USERNAME "SA" CANNOT BE CHANGED.   ALL PASSWORDS SHOULD 
> BE UNDER THE SYSTEM ADMINISTRATOR'S CONTROL, WITH STRICT 
> ADHERENCE TO SECURITY CONVENTIONS FOR ALL USER
> ACCOUNTS.
> RECOMMENDATIONS:
> CHANGE ANY EDITABLE DEFAULT USERNAMES AND PASSWORDS ON 
> MSSQL AND ALL OTHER SOFTWARE AS SOON AS THE SOFTWARE IS 
> INSTALLED.  CHANGE THE DEFAULT "NULL" PASSWORD ON THE 
> "SA" ACCOUNT IN ACCORDANCE WITH STRICT ADHERENCE TO 
> SECURITY CONVENTIONS.
> CONSIDER RESTRICTING PORT 1433 ACCESS ON THE MSSQL SERVER 
> TO ONLY THOSE MACHINES THAT REQUIRE CONNECTION TO THE 
> DATABASE(S).
> MICROSOFT SQL SERVER CUSTOMERS SHOULD REFER TO THE 
> FOLLOWING ADDRESS FOR INFORMATION ON SECURING MICROSOFT 
> SQL SERVER: 
> HTTP://WWW.MICROSOFT.COM/SQL/TECHINFO/ADMINISTRATION/2000
> /SECURITY.ASP.
> THE ANTI-VIRUS COMMUNITY AND SECURITY COMMUNITY ARE AWARE 
> OF THIS WORM, AND THERE ARE VIRUS DEFINITIONS FOR THIS 
> WORM. AS IT PRIMARILY AFFECTS SERVERS, VIGILANCE, BASIC 
> SECURITY PRACTICES AND SECURITY MEASURES ARE THE BEST 
> DEFENSE AGAINST THIS WORM.  ADDITIONAL INFORMATION ON 
> THIS WORM, CAN BE FOUND AT THE FOLLOWING SITES:
> INCIDENTS.ORG:
> HTTP://WWW.INCIDENTS.ORG/DIARY/DIARY.PHP?ID=157
> INTERNET SECURITY SYSTEMS:
> HTTP://WWW.ISS.NET/SECURITY_CENTER/ALERTS/ADVISE118.PHP
> FOR BASIC TIPS AND SUGGESTIONS ON PASSWORD CREATION, SEE:
> HTTP://WWW.NIPC.GOV/PUBLICATIONS/NIPCPUB/PASSWORD.HTM.
> RECIPIENTS OF THIS ADVISORY ARE ENCOURAGED TO REPORT 
> COMPUTER CRIME TO FEDERAL, STATE, OR LOCAL LAW
> ENFORCEMENT AND OTHER APPROPRIATE AUTHORITIES. INCIDENTS 
> MAY BE REPORTED ONLINE AT
> HTTP://WWW.NIPC.GOV/INCIDENT/CIRR.HTM. 
> THE NIPC WATCH AND WARNING UNIT CAN BE REACHED AT (202) 
> 323-3204/3205/3206 OR
> NIPC.WATCH@FBI.GOV.
> END OF MESSAGE------------------------------------------
> --END--
> 
>

From:	Branker, Laura <Laura.Branker@MyFlorida.com>
Sent:	Thursday, May 23, 2002 12:26 PM
To:	Shanahan, Kathleen; Jeb Bush; Hansen, Michael
Subject:	FW: PhRMA Oral Argument



-----Original Message-----
From: Grigas, Steve [mailto:GRIGASS@fdhc.state.fl.us]
Sent: Thursday, May 23, 2002 11:15 AM
To: Medows, Rhonda M.D.; Kitchens, George; Sharpe, Bob; Roberts,
William; Moore, Mary Pat
Cc: 'laurabranker@myflorida.com'; 'woodrid@eog.state.fl.us';
'munizc@eog.state.fl.us'; 'canady@eog.state.fl.us';
'oviedon@myflorida.com'
Subject: PhRMA Oral Argument


This is a general note to let everyone know how the PhRMA oral argument went
yesterday.  Without wishing to jinx the matter, I will say that it seemed to
go well for the state.  The bulk of difficult questions were directed to
PhRMA, and the panel seemed to ask whether this case was filed as a result
of lost profits or out of concern for the welfare of Medicaid recipients.
PhRMA conveniently ducked the question.  The questions that were tossed out
to PHRMA were as follows:

Cudahy:  Isn't this a case that will need research of the legislative
history behind SSA 1927(d)(4),  1927(d)(5) and OBRA 90 and 93?

Marcus:  How does the "prior authorization" referenced in D5 nullify the
"formulary" considerations of D4?  

Birch:  Isn't it true that "prior authorization" doesn't really exclude
drugs - but rather only poses an additional step for prescribing parties to
go through?

Birch:  Let's forget the form over substance argument (state statute
inartfully worded - references formulary and preferred drug list
interchangeably) - how does a prior authorization program adversely affect a
medicaid recipients?

Marcus:  What deference should be given to the state legislature's blessing
of the prior authorization scheme and the federal CMS blessing of the prior
authorization scheme?
[PhRMA said no deference to either.  That went over like a lead balloon]

The questions to the state seemed (to my opinion) much simpler and less
heated:

Birch:  Doesn't D4 provide for all drugs (under the federal rebate) to be
covered?  How then can you reconcile D5 with D4?

Cudahy:  How do you reconcile the actions of OBRA 90 and 93 with respect to
this issue?

Cudahy:  Is there any treatise definition of the word formulary that goes
beyond merely a "listing of phramaceuticals"?


It was a relatively short argument (15 minutes each side).  At the end,
Judge Birch asked PhRMA if settlement discussions had occured between the
parties.  PhRMA responded that the parties had followed the scheduling order
(which calls for such).  Birch then suggested (in a throw away comment) that
the parties may wish to continue such discussions "so as to avoid [and here
the record is unclear - he kind of mumbled] either "bad precedent" or "bad
press on it".

Hope this is of help to you all.  The Judges said that a decision would
likely take a while (that could be an indication that they want to see if
the SCT accepts certiorari on Concannon, or that the panel is divided in how
they percieve the case, or that they just have a heavy caseload they are
presently workin with).  I guess we will know when we know.  

Let me know if you have any questions or comments.

-SAG-

-----Original Message----- 
From: One of the Grimms [ mailto:egrimm@nettally.com
<mailto:egrimm@nettally.com> ] 
Sent: Thursday, May 23, 2002 6:24 AM 
To: Eric Grimm; David Johnson; sharon_heber@doh.state.fl.us; Randy Merchant;
Beth_Copeland@doh.state.fl.us; Connie Garrett; Shaun Crawford; Lu; Susan
Bland; Joe Sekerke

Cc: dfg0@cdc.gov; safay.robert@epa.gov; bxp3@cdc.gov 
Subject: Big gun takes on Wingate (Jan Schlichtmann) 


Posted on Thu, May. 23, 2002       story:PUB_DESC               
        
Big gun takes on Wingate 
BY BRAD BENNETT 

Jan Schlichtmann, the attorney portrayed by John Travolta in the movie A
Civil Action, has joined the fight over Fort Lauderdale's Wingate landfill.

The Beverly, Mass., attorney won $8 million in 1986 for families who alleged
that their children died of leukemia due to pollutants dumped in the Boston
suburb of Woburn, Mass.

Now, Schlichtmann and at least eight other attorneys have filed papers to
form a new local law firm that will try to prove a link between toxic
chemicals buried at the Wingate landfill and high rates of disease around
it, primarily in the 33311 and 33313 ZIP codes.

The firm, the Environmental Justice Project, will seek damages from the city
of Fort Lauderdale and at least 38 companies that allegedly dumped toxic
waste there.

''We're going to approach them and ask them a lot of questions,''
Schlichtmann said. ``We want to do it in an atmosphere in which we're
sharing information.''

Schlichtmann's involvement will undoubtedly bring greater attention to a
battle that has raged for years. The landfill, at 1300 NW 31st Ave. in Fort
Lauderdale, operated from 1954 to 1978. Some residents believe its
contaminants are to blame for illnesses they have had.

''We're always willing to sit down and talk,'' said Greg Kisela, a Fort
Lauderdale assistant city manager. ``But at this point we have not seen any
link between Wingate and any particular illness.''

The city has capped the landfill and wants to create a golf course on the
site, a plan which is controversial. Legal Aid Service of Broward County
plans next month to appeal the capping plan, which was approved by the U.S.
Environmental Protection Agency.

Schlichtmann said it is critical that the community come together to reach a
solution -- a lesson he said he learned in the Massachusetts case. ''If
anything will be done, it will be because the community comes together,'' he
said. ``You can't do it on your own.''

The lawyers, who have kicked in about $500,000 of their own money to get
started, hope to reach a settlement without having to sue. They would take a
percentage of the settlement, and have not ruled out a class-action lawsuit.

They include Miami attorneys J.B. Harris, Edward Montoya and Buddy Payne as
well as Johnny McCray Jr. of Fort Lauderdale, Grover Hankins of Houston -- a
former general counsel for the national NAACP -- Tab Turner of Little Rock,
Ark., Frederick Kuykendal of Alabama and the law firm of Levin Papantonio of
Pensacola.

To quantify the landfill problems -- including a link between the landfill
and disease -- the attorneys have hired a private investigator who will look
at the site and people living around it.

They also plan to consult doctors, scientists, epidemiologists, sociologists
and psychologists to determine whether Wingate residents have suffered any
damage.

Some of the 38 companies say they are doing their part to solve the Wingate
problem by participating in the EPA-ordered, plastic-capping plan.

''The cleanup has been successfully completed. We were very cooperative,''
said Peggy Palter, spokeswoman for Sears, Roebuck and Co., who added that
more than a thousand other companies and the general public dumped in the
landfill. ``We did what we were asked to do by the EPA.''

Mike Haggerty, a spokesman for Florida Power & Light, said FPL also has
agreed to cooperate with approved solutions to the Wingate problem.

''The group formed to manage and clean up the Wingate site has always
supported a study of the health effects,'' Haggerty said, adding that his
firm had minimal participation.

Schlichtmann, 51, who also works with a Pensacola law firm, said Wednesday
he is trying to gauge whether the community will stand behind the new law
firm's plan.

If so, he and other attorneys will form a nonprofit community coalition made
up of Wingate area residents named TOXIC, which stands for Team of Exposed
Individuals to Contaminants.

Civic activist Leola McCoy, who has long fought to have the Wingate toxins
cleaned up properly, showed her support on Wednesday by inviting the lawyers
to her home for lunch.

''I think the community needs to understand that it needs to play its
part,'' McCoy said.

From:	Kathryn Shea <kshea@cdc4kids.org>
Sent:	Thursday, May 23, 2002 1:42 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Cc:	PeterHoward; Sanadams@aol.com
Subject:	Re: Specific Appropriation 387A.

Governor Bush:
 
I wanted to let you know that we are seeing substantial success with the pilot project in Sarasota.  Because our agency is a part of the Community Based Care Partnership with the YMCA, we are able to screen and refer children in care directly to the infant/young children mental health pilot as soon as they enter the system or obtain referrals directly from our case managers.  
 
Our infant mental health therapist has been able to work intensely with the biological parent(so) and the targeted child.  All of the goals on these cases is reunification/adoption.  We have been able to reunite 5 out of the original 10 children referred with their parent and 2 are pending.  There have been no  further abuse reports or return to the system.  All of these parents were headed toward termination of parental rights.  While the numbers seem small, the results have not been.  We are using what we are learning from this pilot experience to staff other cases in the partnership differently and move cases to mental health services more quickly. We are learning what resources are lacking that are critical to positive outcomes and how we can use existing resources more productively.  It makes good sense to invest in these families while the children are young and the possibility for success is much higher.  If I can be of any further assistance, please let me know. Thank you.
Kathryn Shea, MSW
Vice President, Community Based Services
Child Development Center
941-371-8820 ext. 16   

----- Original Message ----- 
From: Sanadams@aol.com 
To: Jeb@Jeb.org 
Sent: Wednesday, May 22, 2002 10:35 PM
Subject: Fwd: Specific Appropriation 387A.

Gov. Bush, 

The purpose of the infant mental health pilot project is to determine the value of identifying infants and toddlers at high risk for emotional problems and intervening early in development in order to promote healthy mother/baby interactions and relationships, rather than waiting until a child is older and problems are more severe before getting help. 

Approximately 40% of children in foster care are under 5 years of age, and many of them are at high risk for mental health problems because of abuse, neglect, substance abuse, maternal mental illness and domestic violence.  Currently, most infants and toddlers have to wait until they are older and their problems much more severe before they are identified and receive any mental health services.  This pilot project was established to train mental health therapists in infant mental health and to explore effective mental health assessment and treatment services for children under 3 years of age who are in protective services or known to DCF. 

The performance outcome measures include: 
       
1.  Improved measures of attachment and bonding.      
2.  Increased rate of successful reunifications or permanency placements within 12 months time.     
3.  No repeat abuse reports on children enrolled in the study·        
4.  Decreased rate of entry into child welfare system, if not yet involved. 

It is a small N for the study because of the limited funding for 3 sites and we are pioneering new ground here.  However, we feel that we will be able to make recommendations regarding effectiveness at the end of the 3rd year.  We are in the middle of the second year right now.   

You didn't veto it the first 2 years, and I am asking you to once again not veto it for the 3rd year so that we can finish this project. 

Thank you, 
sandra adams

From:	POSEY.BILL.SEN.S15 <POSEY.BILL.SEN.S15@leg.state.fl.us>
Sent:	Thursday, May 23, 2002 4:33 PM
To:	'rjo_ii@email.msn.com'
Subject:	RE: FCAT results

Thank you for taking the time to write, Mrs. Oswalt.  I am very sorry to hear your daughter's needs are not being met in school. I know at least one school board member expressed concern about giving passing grades to children who would not be able to pass the FCAT. I receive quite a bit of mail about the "funding crisis," but have heretofore received very little from concerned citizens about the "learning crisis" - which apparently was never as important to those crusading for more money. Unfortunately, it is my understanding that of the 58% of our students statewide who graduate from high school, less than half of them can read on a third grade level. That trend began long before the current "funding crisis" and while it may have been acceptable to many people over the years, the Governor and legislature are trying to reverse the trend. Fortunately, in part because of the FCAT, your daughter will no longer be overlooked and left to become a future graduate who can not read. The legislature has been researching, evaluating and funding additional reading programs at the state level.  I am not sure which school districts or individual schools are participating in the various programs. Bill

-----Original Message----- 
From: Robert J Oswalt and Family [mailto:rjo_ii@email.msn.com] 
Sent: Thursday, May 23, 2002 4:29 PM 
To: POSEY.BILL.SEN.S15; FUTCH.HOWARD.WEB; BALL.RANDY 
Cc: HARIDOPOLOS.MIKE; NEEDELMAN.MITCH; ALLEN.BOB 
Subject: FCAT results 


Dear Florida Senators and Representatives, 
        Some people should be singing praises now that we have ended social 
promotion. No more graduates who can't read! Many other parents are now 
angry that their children are going to repeat the fourth grade because they 
didn't pass the FCAT test. I have heard figures stating that 25% of fourth 
graders will be retained! This is unacceptable to me and I hope to you. My 
child will also be retained but I am not one of the surprised ones. I knew 
she needed help and was not getting it. She is a child that would have 
fallen through the cracks in the system had we not had the resources to get 
her help outside the system.  Now I hope she will get the extra help in 
school that she has needed all along. But how will that be possible with the 
budget cuts that have occured? We have identified a problem. That's only the 
first step. What is now going to be done about the problem? Just having 
children repeat a fourth grade curriculum is not going to help them read any 
better. Are more special reading teachers going to be hired? Are we now 
going to focus more on reading at the second and third grade levels? I was 
told that if a child doesn't 'get' reading by second grade that no more time 
is spent just teaching reading. Summer school is gone, so there is no help 
there. What is to be done? Now that this law has passed, how are you 
planning on dealing with the results? I am very interested in hearing your 
reply. 

Sincerely, 
Angela Oswalt

John William, circuit administrator out of Bartow, called to warn of release
of serious sex offender from county jail tonight.
Offender Robert Neal DC#13181 was seen several months ago outside his
victim's home.  The victim called law enforcement and after staking out his
residence and seeing the offender drive home in white van,  the probation
officer violated his probation.  Today the judge did not sentence him to
prison time, but amended his probation to include GPS monitoring.  He will
be released from county jail tonight.   The probation office will provide
extra contact visits and the victim will be issued a pager that will sound
an alarm should the offender's GPS unit come near. 

From:	Renee Althouse <althousr@osceola.k12.fl.us>
Sent:	Thursday, May 23, 2002 5:09 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Cc:	campbela@osceola.k12.fl.us; paswater@osceola.k12.fl.us; heathg@osceola.k12.fl.us
Subject:	PLEASE!  HELP OUR SCHOOLS!

								May 23, 2002


Dear Governor Bush,

As a teacher in Osceola County and as a parent of three children, I am
writing to ask you to continue to support  funding for fast growing
counties.  This funding is needed to continue to effectively educate the
children of Florida.  I am referring  to Section 28, page 416 of the
Budge.  Osceola County has had the fastest growing school system in the
state for the past five years, and is projected to have the fastest
growing school system for the next five years.  In addition, Osceola
County has received the lowest amount, per capita, for school construction
in the state for the past five years.  Osceola County is the only county
in the state that has exhausted all local sources for school construction:
 levying a full 2 mills, sharing in the Local Option Sales Tax, levying
the highest School Impact Fees in the state, levying additional mills for
a School Construction Bond Issue, using all effort index dollars and
classroom 1st dollars, and establishing seven charter schools.  In fact,
Osceola County has one of the highest percentages of students in charter
schools in the State.  

We are slated to receive $8.5 million  of the $10 million approved by the
State Legislature.  We desperately need these dollars to build new
schools.  Please,  in your review of the budget, continue to support fast
growing counties and  DO NOT VETO these critical funds!   Thank You.


Sincerely, 
Renee Althouse- Reading Specialist
Discovery Intermediate School
 althousr@osceola.k12.fl.us

"Every obstacle presents an opportunity
  to improve our condition."

From:	Sharon Lowen <lowens@osceola.k12.fl.us>
Sent:	Thursday, May 23, 2002 6:38 PM
To:	Jeb@jeb.org.
Cc:	mannm@osceola.k12.fl.us; schaferd@osceola.k12.fl.us
Subject:	State Budget. Section 28

Dear Governor Bush,
I am writing to you on behalf of my community and school system: Osceola
County.
I have lived in Osceola for 15 years and have been a teacher in the school
system here for all that time.  I am a Republican and yes - I did vote for
both you and your brother, without having any difficulties with the
ballots!

I am asking you to pay close attention to the state budget this year,
especially the parts that effect education.  In
Section 28 of the Budget, on page 416, there is an item that greatly
impacts my county and our schools.  This item provides money for school
construction to the fastest growing districts, and would mean Osceola
County could receive a large amount of money for construction funds.

As you know, Osceola County has had the fastest growing school system in
the state for the past five years, and is projected to have the fastest
growing school system for the next five years.  At the same time, however,
 Osceola County has received the lowest amount, per capita, for school
construction in the state for the past five years.

On your recent visits to Osceola County, you have commented on how well
our School Board and local governments have developed alternative funding
for education.  You noticed that our county has one of the highest
percentages of students in charter schools in the State.  You may have
also noticed that Osceola County is the only County in the state that has
exhausted all local sources for school construction:
	- Levying a full 2 mills
	- Sharing in the Local Option Sales Tax
	- Levying the highest School Impact Fees in the State
	- Levying additional mills for a School Construction Bond Issue
	- Established seven charter schools
	- Using all effort index dollars
	- Using all classroom 1st dollars

Without a doubt, Osceola County has proven itself as a supporter of
education and as an example of creative and alternative funding.  Osceola
County has done all it can possibly do to keep up with the overwhelming
growth in Central Florida.  We can do no more on our own.  We need - and
we have earned - your help.  This help is the State Budget with Section 28
left intact.  Please maintain that portion of the state budget which would
allow us to provide needed classrooms for the children of Osceola County. 
Programs have been dropped, positions have been cut (including the one I
have held for four years- it was lost when the TLCF Grant was deleted),
and supplies have been neglected, but we cannot do without the space
necessary for educating our students.  Please recognize our efforts here
in Osceola County by providing building construction dollars (all of what
was recommended by the legislature) to the School Districts who need it so
desperately.

Thank you,
Sharon Lowen
1801 Cheryl Lane
Kissimmee, Florida
34744

Sharon Lowen, Technology Resource Specialist
Osceola County School District, IMC
817 Bill Beck Blvd.
Kissimmee Florida   34744
email at:  lowens@osceola.k12.fl.us

-----Original Message-----
From: Breeden, Bob 
Sent: Thursday, May 23, 2002 2:58 PM
To: Ramer, Phil; Moore, Tim
Cc: Lauer, Stephen; Browdy, Shirley
Subject: RE: viable threat to s. Florida?


Phil,
We have done a background investigation on this person and investigated her
claims.  Here are my findings on this matter:
1) The information she claims to have is publicly published information.
She stated to me that she was "working" with the FBI and that they had
provided the info to her.  I personally spoke to the FBI agents that she
referenced in her email to the Governor.  SA Carlos Cintron stated that he
"is not working with this lady on anything".  He further stated that she
calls him about once a month claiming to have "critical information" that
she has developed, but that it is always publicly published info that she
claims to have "hunches on".  Cintron has told her to "stop using his name
or the name of the FBI to gain credibility so as to sell market her
business/product."   Nenortas further claimed to FDLE staff that she was the
person responsible for "cracking the terrorist money ring in South Florida"
related to the 19 terrorists that hijacked the planes on September 11, 2002
and that she was responsible for determining the origin of the Anthrax laced
letters sent out soon afterwards. These revelations apparently come to her
through "hunches" she receives from the news. 
2) We asked her to provide us with the information on the 45 Al-Quida
connected websites and she has yet to produce that info.
3) Subsequent to a conversation with FDLE's Brett Cureton on Wednesday
morning, this lady called the South Florida Water Management District and
asked to speak to their security department.  She stated to them that she
needed to meet with them ASAP to discuss a "viable threat to the south
Florida water supply."  She told them that she was "working with FDLE on
this matter".  It is obvious to me that she is consistently name dropping in
an effort to gain credibility.
4) I have spoken to Ms. Nenortas myself on Wednesday afternoon and
encouraged her to stop claiming that she is "working" with either FDLE or
the FBI.  I explained that while we are more that willing to accept her
"hunches" and information regarding terrorist activities, that she is
creating a problem when she goes from agency to agency claiming to be
working on "viable threats" with a law enforcement agency.  
5) Note that she has a sealed criminal record, having been arrested by Palm
Beach County SO in 1989 for Filing False Insurance Claims.  We are writing
an Intel report in AIM regarding this contact and investigation so that if
anyone else deals with her they will be able to read about this interaction.
Finally, I communicated with SAS Shirley Brody, the supervisor of the South
Florida Domestic Security Taskforce and made her aware of this lady since
she lives in Broward County and continues to create ripples.  SAS Brody was
going to call Broward SO and make them aware of this person.
Please let me know if you want any further action on this matter.
Bob

From:	Castille, Colleen <Colleen.Castille@MyFlorida.com>
Sent:	Thursday, May 23, 2002 7:33 PM
To:	Flack, Christopher; Jeb Bush
Subject:	RE: Fishermen in Florida

Governor, 

Efforts to create certain exemptions from the net ban for disabled folks
have failed, because they don't want our solution which is to have a
particular device on board each individual boat.  Instead, they want to have
a larger mesh and more than 500 square feet.  DIrect conflict with the
constitutional provision limiting nets. 

colleen castille

-----Original Message-----
From: Flack, Christopher [mailto:Christopher.Flack@LASPBS.STATE.FL.US]
Sent: Thursday, May 16, 2002 4:03 PM
To: Governor Jeb Bush; 'jeb@jeb.org'
Cc: Castille, Colleen; Furney, Jack
Subject: RE: Fishermen in Florida


Governor, we met with Mr. Pine a couple of times during session (myself,
Jack and Colleen).  There was a lower court decision locally that stated the
FWCC's net rule was invalid and provided fishermen in Franklin, Wakulla and
Jefferson counties the ability to use nets that didn't meet the new FWCC
standard. At the time Mr. Pine and Mr. Crumb were asking for an Executive
Order that would apply the lower court decision to the state so that the
court ordered exemption applied to all.  The First DCA then reversed the
stay that allowed the fishermen in the local counties to use the
"un-approved" nets.  It is my understanding that the First DCA has not made
a decision on the lower court ruling overall.  Mr. Pine and Mr. Crumb have
also been lobbying the legislature as well as our office to get some changes
made to the net rules believing some acts of discrimination have occurred
under the new rules because not all (elderly/disabled) are able to use the
nets that comply with the FWCC standard, thereby taking away their ability
to fish and work.  The judge (Sanders Sauls) in the lower court purposely
stated he was not addressing this issue when he ruled on the rule's
validity.  Colleen and I have talked several times on the issue and believe
Mr. Pine is trying to get around the Constitutional limitations and we don't
have the authority or need to make any changes.  Colleen may have some other
views she'd like to add also?

-----Original Message-----

-----Original Message-----
From: Walter D. Pine [mailto:muletman@bellsouth.net]
Sent: Wednesday, May 15, 2002 9:30 PM
To: fl_governor@myflorida.com
Subject: Fishermen in Florida


Governor,

  My name is Walter Pine I am the Executive Director of the Center for Civil
Rights Advocacy. I want to thank you for the time that your staff has spent
in listening to the plight of the Florida commercial fishing families.  We
represent a number of Floridians who believe that their civil rights have
been violated by resource regulations.  The issues are age, disability,
race, and nationality based.  The Center for civil Rights Advocacy has asked
that you issue an executive order or request and opinion from the Florida
Supreme Court that would grant and/or provide for equal access to the
fisheries of Florida.  I have spoken numerous times to Chris Flack and Jack
Furney.  I believe that they have an understanding of the equal access
issues.  They explained that at the time the budget and other legislative
concerns made it impossible for you to give time to these issues.  Now that
the special sessions have been concluded  I would like to have an
opportunity to present the issues to you and answer any questions or resolve
any conflicts that you may have with granting Floridians equal access to
fisheries.

I look forward to your response.

Thank You
Walter Pine
321-264-2959

Governor:

 I would like to urge you to consider vetoing the portion of specific 
appropriation 319A that appropriates $700,000 from DCF for a contract with 
C-NOW. It is for a pilot program to implement an interactive video monitoring 
program in selected foster homes or residential group care facilities. 

The concept of videotaping in foster homes or residential care facilities was 
never discussed in Committee, nor voted on by the House. I believe this is a 
policy decision that requires a thorough discussion as to its pros and cons 
before moving in this direction. In addition, I believe, even if we decided 
to do it, it should go out for bid, not be handed to one company.

Thank you for your consideration.

Nan Rich

-----Original Message-----
From: Vera Filipelli [mailto:vera@derbylane.com]
Sent: Thursday, May 23, 2002 7:00 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: FW: GPA LARGO RESPONSE TO ALABAMA STORY....


 
-----Original Message-----
From: TONYA BEADER [mailto:GREYEYES3@hotmail.com]
Sent: Thursday, May 23, 2002 11:58 AM
To: vera@derbylane.com
Subject: GPA LARGO RESPONSE TO ALABAMA STORY....


Vera,
At the request of Maryann Tolliver, I am sending you a copy of a letter that has been forwarded to all major TV stations and newspapers. We as a group feel this best describes our position on Derby Lane, the kennels, and the relationships that have resulted from our experiences with the above. If you know of anyone willing to listen to OUR side of this issue, please let us know.
 
 
To Whom It May Concern:
In light of the story that broke on 5/22 about the Alabama shootings of thousands of racing greyhounds, I feel compelled to make a plea to your segment. I am a volunteer with GREYHOUND PETS OF AMERICA, LARGO FLORIDA CHAPTER. You may not realize it, but one of the things that is RIGHT with Tampa Bay is the PRO ADOPTION stance that the local greyhound tracks, DERBY LANE and the TAMPA GREYHOUND TRACK have. Just this past weekend, our group had a GREYHOUND PICNIC at Lake Seminole Park, and kennel owners attended just to get a glimpse of their former pupils....The kennels at St. Pete care a great deal about the post racing lives of their greys.  This should be a source of pride for our area, and GPA/LARGO would like to have the opportunity to prove that there ARE tracks and kennels who do care about their greyhounds. For example, last season (2001), I went to  Derby Lane with one of my retired racers I adopted in 1998. While in the elevator, a man smiled at my greyhound, looked at me and said;" Is that Charley?" and began loving on him. Charley's tail wagged happily, and much to my surprise, this man turned out to be one of his trainers. Charley is a black male, with no apparent distinguishing marks from any other black male greyhound, yet, this man remembered Charley from years ago. Charley never broke his "maiden race"..... Likewise, there was the time that one of the prominent kennels at Derby Lane called us to help search for one of their dogs when he accidentally escaped from his family's home months after he had been adopted out. Block after block, road after road, both kennel and family searched. Fortunately, he was found and taken home completely unharmed or injured.
 
Many times, the owners, trainers and workers will visit our third floor booth at Derby Lane just to see one of their former pups, and to meet and speak with the new adoptive family. They meet and exchange stories of lives past and present. Oftentimes both trainers/owners and new "parents" walk away with tears in their eyes. Kennels are reassured  that their "babies" are doing well, and the new owners are blessed with a wealth of knowledge on their greys' personal and professional history. Racing and Retirement meet on common ground with mutual respect and admiration.
 
Our group (GREYHOUND PETS OF AMERICA, LARGO FLORIDA) has many testaments just like the above that can attest to the things POSITIVE about how racing greyhounds are treated by our local tracks and kennels. In the light of stories like Dan Shonka, who sold retired racers to laboratories instead of adopting them out as promised, and the atrocities in this Alabama story, wouldn't it be nice to show that OUR tracks and kennels DO CARE??? Is that not something RIGHT WITH TAMPA BAY?  Derby Lane and the Tampa Greyhound Track are strong supporters of greyhound adoption, and we, as residents of this area should be PROUD of that....With movies like "Oceans Eleven" coming to our area to film, a subtle statement was made that we have a first class act here. Everyone should know that.  Trainers cry when they hand over greyhounds. I have seen it personally. They feel like they are losing a family member. Many, they keep as their own because they just cannot part with them....they call about their former racers to check up on them, they attend our picnics in the hopes of seeing them....
 
A few years ago, Animal Planet featured Greyhounds on their Breed All About It series, and the program chose to feature Derby Lane and Greyhound Pets of America, Largo.  The segment still runs today.  This too should speak highly of our region, and our local tracks' efforts to encourage and promote greyhound adoption. (Copies of this program can be purchased through the Animal Planet Channel.)
 
Do greyhounds make GREYT PETS? Ask us about our 14 yr. old grey girl who saved the life of one of her owners just a couple months ago...(Tierra Verde).
 
Again, is this not one of the MANY things that is RIGHT about Tampa Bay???  Our group is always contacted (this time, by the Tampa Tribune) when a horrific, tragic, and heartbreaking story is exposed. While ALL our hearts break if this story turns out to be true, and we all at GPA/LARGO mourn the senseless loss of greyhounds lives; We feel it is just as important to let people know that in our region, EVERY EFFORT is extended and acted upon to assure that these beautiful, marvelous athletes are given the retirement life they deserve.
 
Thank you in advance for your attention.
Tonya Beader
GREYHOUND PETS OF AMERICA
LARGO, FLORIDA CHAPTER 
501-C3 NON PROFIT ORGANIZATION
ACTIVE AND PARTICIPATING CHAPTER 
OF 
GREYHOUND PETS OF AMERICA, NATIONAL NON PROFIT ORGANIZATION

-----Original Message-----
From: Sandyj516@aol.com [mailto:Sandyj516@aol.com]
Sent: Thursday, May 23, 2002 7:13 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Please help Osceola County Schools.


Dear Governor Bush:

I am an educator employed by the Osceola School District.  My daughter will 
be in first grade in August and attends an Osceola County School.  I 
understand that the State Legislature has approved $10 million to help fast 
growing counties.  If you support this legislation, Osceola County would 
receive $8.5 million of those funds.  (This item can be found in Section 28, 
page 416 of the proposed Budget.)

We desperately need these dollars to help build new schools in Osceola 
County.  Please take the following points into consideration when it is time 
to sign or veto the proposed legislation:

* Osceola County has had the fastest growing school system in the state for 
the past five years, and is projected to have the fastest growing school 
system for the next five years.

* Osceola County has received the lowest amount, per capita, for school 
construction in the state for the past five years.

* Osceola County has one of the highest percentages of students in charter 
schools in the State.

* Osceola County is the only County in the state that has exhausted all local 
sources for school construction:
- Levying a full 2 mills
- Sharing in the Local Option Sales Tax
- Levying the highest School Impact Fees in the State
- Levying additional mills for a School Construction Bond Issue
- Established seven charter schools
- Using all effort index dollars
- Using all classroom 1st dollars

As both an educator and a parent of a student in Osceola County, I urge you 
to please support this legislation.  

Thank you for your time in reading this.

Sincerely,

Sandra J. Maye
(sandyj516@aol.com)

-----Original Message-----
From: Karen Pruitt [mailto:pruittk@osceola.k12.fl.us]
Sent: Thursday, May 23, 2002 7:42 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: funding for more schools


Governor Bush:

I am a Kindergarten Teacher from Osceola County. I do not want to take up
much of your time, but as you look at the budget please keep in mind the
following facts:

? Osceola County has had the fastest growing school system in the state
for the past five years, and is projected to have the fastest growing
school system for the next five years.
? Osceola County has received the lowest amount, per capita, for school
construction in the state for the past five years.
? Osceola County has one of the highest percentages of students in charter
schools in the State.
? Osceola County is the only County in the state that has exhausted all
local sources for school construction:

- Levying a full 2 mills
- Sharing in the Local Option Sales Tax
- Levying the highest School Impact Fees in the State
- Levying additional mills for a School Construction Bond Issue
- Established seven charter schools
- Using all effort index dollars
- Using all classroom 1st dollars

Since you have taken office,  I  have received more money to spend on the
materials my children need. Thank you for that. However, we usually have
25-30 students in the Kindergarten and First grade classes because we do
not have adequate money for building new schools at a rate that can keep
up with our tremendous growth. It is very difficult to give these students
the one-on-one attention they have a right to in such large classes.

I realize you keep giving money to school systems and then wonder where it
all goes. I agree with you there needs to be accountability for this
money. Where is it going? I know of several instances of waste at the
county level, but that is another issue. PLEASE, we have old portables
that have been at this school since I came here 11 years ago. It is not
right for 7-8 year old students to be placed in these old dilapidated
buildings. Thank you for your consideration in this matter. I realize the
job ahead is a difficult one. However, I know you really care about what
is best for the students. 

Thank you,

Karen Pruitt
Kindergarten
Ventura Elementary
pruittk@osceola.k12.fl.us
407-344-5040 ext 229

-----Original Message-----
From: Kathleen Kearney [mailto:Kathleen_Kearney@dcf.state.fl.us]
Sent: Thursday, May 23, 2002 6:07 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Response to Request From Noah's Ark for help re: the

Governor -- Here is the response to the issues raised by Mr. Sammons in his
e-mail to you last night regarding his son Drew.   I have asked Susan
Dickerson of the Developmental Disabilities Office to either call him or
e-mail him immediately to go over these issues with him in more detail.
Laura Branker was also cc'ed on this reply from Susan.
_______________________________________________________________________________________


Laura, Secretary Kearney:
Below is the information we have regarding the issues raised in Mr. Sammons
email to Governor Bush.  If you  need additional information, please let me
know.


The following is a response to the main issues raised in the email from Mr.
Sammons, of Noah's Ark to Governor Bush.  The children mentioned in the
email are not clients of the Developmental Disabilities program.  Drew
Sammons,  does not have a qualifying diagnosis under Chapter 393.  The
other child, Steven Graham is not a client and has not been referred to the
developmental disabilities program according to our records.

1. " Brown school claims that they are able to make 50%of those with IQs 50
or below competent to stand trial.  That is absurd"  Children committed to
the Department as incompetent to proceed to trial are served by the Brown
Schools for community competency services and Apalachicola Forest Youth
Camp for residential services (both via contract managed by the Mental
Health program office )  The claim made by Mr. Sammons is correct based on
an OPPAGA justification review  (December 2000) of the Juveniles
Incompetent to Proceed program which reports that competency was restored
for 35% of juveniles below IQ of 50.    Additional data provided by the DCF
Mental Health Program office indicates that 57% of all mentally retarded
juveniles are restored to competency and 43% are not restored.

2.  " If a behavioral therapist had come to Steven's house once a week and
to the school once a week for a year, instead of receiving the Brown's
school instruction, there would have been a much better chance that he and
his single mom , would not be facing the current charges"  We do not know
if these children receive behavioral services from their schools at this
time.  Mr. Sammon's email would lead us to believe they do not.  However,
according to Michelle Polland, Dept of Education, behavior analysis
services may be provided by the schools to children who need this service
as long as it is in their Individual Education Plan (IEP).  The school
should be asked to review the need for behavior analysis services as
suggested by Mr. Sammons.  Dr. Bob Mitty at the Department of Education
oversees behavior services for children in schools.

3   "And finally, lets amend the law that says anytime a teacher is hit or
kicked by a student, a felony has been committed"   According to our
research into this issue (FS 784.081)  the police officer has a range of
charges which may be filed which include misdemeanor to felony.  Therefore
it is not an automatic felony charge each time a teacher is hit.


`````````````````````````````````````
Thank you,
Susan Dickerson, Acting Director of
Developmental Disabilities Program, Tallahassee, Fl
Ph 488-4877, ext. 144, suncom 278-4877, ext. 144

Dear Mrs. McCoy,

Thank you for your recent e-mail to the Governor regarding your
daughter's
denial in insurance coverage to see a "specialist." This request was
forwarded to the Agency for Health Care Administration, Medicaid Health
Systems Development for response. Your letter describes your difficulty
in
obtaining insurance coverage approval from United Health Care for
consultation and diagnostic testing from The Chiari Center. We are
committed
to assisting your daughter, Courtney and appreciate you bringing this
matter
to our attention. 

In response to your concerns, we plan to contact United Health Care
directly
to request further information and consideration of your daughter's
health
care needs. You may also contact the Agency's Statewide Provider and
Subscriber Assistance Program (SPSAP) which is a State of Florida
program
designed to assist consumers of managed care entities, such as Health
Maintenance Organizations, with grievances that have not been
satisfactorily
resolved. You must first complete the entire grievance process of the
managed care entity before filing a grievance with the program, unless
the
grievance is of an urgent nature. If your grievance meets required
criteria,
the program's staff will schedule the grievance for a hearing before an
independent panel. After the hearing, the panel will make a
recommendation
based on the finding of fact either to the Department of Insurance or
the
Agency for Health care Administration to ensure that your daughter
receives
the quality medical services rightfully due. 

In addition, please find a link below to the Department of Insurance
website
which publishes a consumer guide for Health Maintenance Organizations to
help you in this task. The guide contains basic information and your
rights
and responsibilities as an insurance consumer. You may also contact the
Florida Department of Insurance Consumer Helpline toll-free at
1-800-342-2762.

http://www.doi.state.fl.us/Consumers/guides/newguides2.htm#HEALTH 

Thank you for taking the time to write the Governor in support of your
daughter's health care needs. She is very fortunate to have such a
wonderful
advocate.


Shelly Brantley
Bureau Chief
Health Systems Development
Agency for Health Care Administration

-----Original Message-----
From: Martha Pratt 
Sent: Thursday, May 23, 2002 8:50 AM
Subject: FW: Hrricanes 'not a joke,' Bush warns. Palm Beach Post 5/23/02


Hurricanes 'not a joke,' Bush warns
By Eliot Kleinberg, Palm Beach Post Staff Writer
Thursday, May 23, 2002

TAMPA -- Ten years ago, South Florida businessman John Bush huddled in
the hallways of a friend's home with his wife and children as Hurricane
Andrew raged.

Now, John Ellis Bush is governor of Florida and worries about the
millions of people who were born or moved to South Florida after Andrew.
Or who felt its breezes in Boca Raton or emptied grocery shelves in
Jupiter and believed they had experienced it.

His message Wednesday at the opening of the Florida Governor's Hurricane
Conference: "We're not kidding. It's not a joke."

Bush "is one of the few governors who's been in the eye wall of a major
hurricane," National Hurricane Center Director Max Mayfield mused. "If
any."

Bush, then a developer, had evacuated his home at Deering Bay, near the
coast in southern Miami-Dade County, and had gone west to stay with a
friend. With him had been his wife, Columba; their three children;
Columba's mother; and two Secret Service agents -- he was, after all,
the son of the president of the United States. They arrived around 9
p.m. and waited. No one talked about politics or business. They just
watched the news reports grow more and more grim.

Growing up in Houston, Bush said, "my recollection was it blew a little
bit, it rained a lot. We got to go outside and play in the rain. This
was not like that." 

The children were put to bed about 1:30 a.m. A little more than an hour
later, the house began to shake.

"There was this feeling," Bush said. "It got like the house was going to
implode. It was a very eerie, scary feeling."

Bush told the emergency workers Wednesday their efforts had been steeled
by the Andrew experience and a plague of natural and man-made disasters
since. But he said he is concerned people haven't caught on.

"Human nature is fairly consistent," Bush said. "We all respond to
emergencies when they happen, rather than planning in advance."


Staff researcher Sammy Alzofon and Miami Herald archives contributed to
this story.


eliot_kleinberg@pbpost.com

From:	Vicki DiGiacomo <digiacov@osceola.k12.fl.us>
Sent:	Thursday, May 23, 2002 8:59 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Budget for school construction

Governor Bush:

	Please support the budget legislation (Section 28 on page 416 ) that
provides $10 million to help fast growing counties. Osceola County needs
those funds to help make room for the students who are pouring into our
district.
	We are projected to have the fastest growing school system for the next
five years, yet for the past five years, we have received the lowest per
capita dollars in the state for school construction.
	We've made every effort to overcome the imbalance created by the state's
funding formula. We have the highest school impact fees in the state, we
have a school construction bond issue, and we levy the full 2 mills in
taxes, among other efforts.
	I have lived in this county since 1966, and its population expansion has
been incredible. Please help us to help these students as we all deal with
the effects of growth. It is sad to see so many students whose needs we
can barely meet because we are constantly struggling to build enough roofs
over their heads.


Vicki DiGiacomo

FOX News
Thursday, May 23, 2002
By Radley Balko


Samantha Monroe was 12 years old in 1981 when her parents enrolled her in
the Sarasota, Fla., branch of Straight Inc., an aggressive drub rehab center
for teens.


Barely a teen, Samantha also had no history of drug abuse. But she spent the
next three years of her life surviving Straight.

She was beaten, starved and denied toilet privileges for days on end. She
describes her "humble pants," a punishment that forced her to wear the same
pants for six weeks at a time. Because she was allowed just one shower a
week, the pants often filled with feces, urine and menstrual blood. Often
she was confined to her closet for days. She gnawed through her jaw during
those "timeout" sessions, hoping she'd bleed to death.

She says that after she was raped by a male counselor, "the wonderful state
of Florida paid for and forced me to have an abortion."

There are hundreds of Straight stories like Samantha's. Wes Fager enrolled
his son in a Springfield, Va., chapter of Straight on the advice of a high
school guidance counselor. Fager didn't see his son again until three months
later — after he'd escaped and developed severe mental illness.

Since then, Fager's set out to clear the air on Straight. He has accumulated
stories like Samantha's and his son's on a clearinghouse Web site. They are
stories of suicides and attempted suicides, rapes, forced abortions,
molestations, physical abuse, lawsuits, court testimonies, and extensive
documentation of profound psychological abuse at Straight chapters all over
the country.

Yet, the Straight model of drug treatment is thriving, with the trend toward
"boot camp" style rehab centers growing more and more en vogue and
Straight's founders, high-powered Republican boosters Mel and Betty Sembler,
wielding enormous influence over U.S. drug policy.

Mel Sembler is currently serving as President Bush's ambassador to Italy,
and the Semblers serve on the boards of almost every major domestic
anti-drug program. They are longtime close associates of the Bush family,
and are behind efforts to defeat medicinal marijuana initiatives all over
the country. Despite the horrors that have surfaced about Straight's
history, they are proud and unrepentant about the program.

With more and more U.S. states turning to mandatory treatment instead of
incarceration for minor drug offenses — with Mel and Betty Sembler
continuing to flex political muscle in the power corridors of the drug war —
the story of Straight is one worth hearing.

Straight was spun off of a Synanon, Fla., based rehab program called The
Seed. Established in 1972, the program lost its funding after a
congressional investigation turned up evidence of brainwashing and cult-like
mind control tactics. But a Florida congressman named Bill Young persisted.
He found advocates in the Semblers and persuaded them to start a similar
rehab center in St. Petersburg, which they called "Straight Incorporated."

Despite allegations of abuse from escaped members and pending lawsuits, over
the next 15 years Straight won laudatory praise in Republican circles.
Luminaries from Nancy Reagan to Princess Diana visited Straight branches and
touted their successes (though by most estimates only about 25 percent of
Straight "clients" ever completed the program).

But Straight's tactics soon caught up to it in the courts. A college student
won a false imprisonment claim of $220,000 in 1983, and another claim cost
Straight $721,000 in 1990. A Straight spin-off called Kids of North Jersey
lost a $4.5 million claim in 2000. Straight chapters across the country
began to shut down, culminating with the last branch in Atlanta closing in
1993.

But the Straight philosophy was far from finished. Many chapters and
directors reopened new clinics that employed the same tactics under
different names — such as KIDS, Growing Together and SAFE. Florida Gov. Jeb
Bush visited and praised SAFE, despite the fact that an Orlando television
station reported widespread Straight-like abuse at the facility in a 2000
expose.

Amidst mounting lawsuit losses and bad publicity throughout the 1990's, the
umbrella organization Straight Inc. changed its name in 1996 to the Drug
Free America Foundation. DFAF thrives today with $400,000 in annual federal
subsidies.

"It amazes me that despite the pattern of complaints and abuse allegations,
Straight chapters can simply change their names and continue to operate,"
says Rick Ross, a cult expert and intervention specialist. Ross says there's
an unfortunate market for "rehab" centers that take burdensome children off
the hands of troubled parents.

Most troubling, however, is the considerable and continuing political clout
of Straight Inc.'s founders. Former President Bush once shot a television
commercial for DFAF, and designated the Semblers' program as one of his
"thousand points of light."

Long a presence in Florida Republican circles, Mel Sembler was tapped as
ambassador to Australia in 1989. Today he serves the younger Bush as
ambassador to Italy, and he served on the board of the 2000 Republican
National Convention.

Betty Sembler co-chaired Jeb Bush's campaign committee. In return, the
governor declared Aug. 8, 2000, "Betty Sembler Day" in Florida — due, he
said, to her work "protecting children from the dangers of drugs."

She also serves on the board of DARE, the largely failed anti-drug program
for elementary school students.

DFAF also worked with then-governor Bush on anti-drug programs in Texas, and
today claims to have his ear on national drug policy as well. Indeed,
Arizona prosecutor and Sembler favorite Rick Romley was on Bush's short list
for drug czar. Though Romley wasn't nominated, Bush did tap staunch drug
warrior John Walters. The nomination caused Betty Sembler to remark, "....
we have lacked the leadership and support of the White House ... until now."

"It's really shocking that the Semblers are still lauded and honored after
all that's come out about their organization," says cult expert Ross, a
self-described Republican.

Last year, a reporter from the Canadian e-zine Cannabis News asked Betty
Sembler in person about the horror stories he'd read from Straight
survivors. "They should get a life," Sembler replied. "I am proud of
everything we have done. There's nothing to apologize for. The legalizers
are the ones who should be apologizing."

That's the attitude of the drug war's power duo, who can be unrepentant
about the lives their program destroyed because they believe a
win-at-all-costs approach is the only way to remove the scourge of drugs
from society. Shattered lives, suicides, forced abortions, fractured
psyches — all necessary casualties of the drug war, and nothing to apologize
for.

Radley Balko is a writer living in Arlington, Va., a

===================================
New Tampa Schools Score Well On FCAT
By LENORA LAKE and MICHELE SAGER The Tampa Tribune 
Published: May 23, 2002
   
TAMPA - Some schools credited tutoring and mentoring programs for high FCAT scores in reading and math, while struggling schools searched for reasons why results remain below average. Most New Tampa schools scored above the county and state averages on the Florida Comprehensive Assessment Test. Scores were released last week by the state Department of Education. Mary Frances Ledo, assistant principal of Clark Elementary, said increased parent involvement and the use of volunteer reading tutor programs throughout New Tampa helped the schools. Ledo said Clark's after-school extended- learning program in part helped her students achieve scores well above the Hillsborough County average. ``Clark was fortunate because many of the teachers in third and fourth grade were the ones who stayed after school and taught in it,'' Ledo said, adding that the teachers knew many of the children and their specific needs. But not all New Tampa schools were celebrating their scores. Wharton High's ninth- and 10th-grade scores in reading and math were below the county average. Principal Mitchell Muley pointed out that Wharton draws from middle schools with varying levels of success in preparing their students for high school. ``We see a big difference in improvement between ninth grade and the 10th grade, when we have had them [the students] for more than a year,'' Muley said. In fact, 10th-grade scores were just 1 point below the county average and above the state average. Wharton's block schedule also may be a disadvantage for students taking the FCAT. Under block scheduling, a ninth-grader may not take math or English the first semester of the school year. This means a student would have that subject only from January until when the test is administered in February or March, Muley said. Some previously struggling schools showed little improvement despite new programs to boost achievement. Scores at Mort and Shaw elementary schools, where the district started school-within-a- school programs, were below county averages. Both schools were given extra resources by the district to create two minischools at each site, one for younger students and one for older elementary students. By creating two smaller schools, educators had hoped to improve academic performance. But both Mort and Shaw students scored low marks on all portions of the FCAT. Mort Principal Lamar Hammer said this year's FCAT scores may not be an accurate measure of the success of the program. ``It may take a few years before we see significant results on test scores,'' he said. ``We were very surprised by the scores because our students have shown so much improvement in class.'' School districts should get individual student scores Friday and will make them available to families. Scores from some students - including those in exceptional education classes and those with limited English proficiency - will not be factored into each school's grade from the state, expected by mid-June. 
For a complete list of FCAT results, go to TBO.com, keyword ``Education.`` 
Reporter Michele Sager can be reached at (813) 977-2854, Ext. 32.

Kathleen,
 
We have worked this issue almost daily and finally feel that we have a good handle on all the nuances----it is a very complicated situation (sometimes we feel we know more than Jorge’s lawyers!).  We have run the traps at both the Patent and Trademarks Office (PTO), and the State Dept.  
 
Best strategy-----at this time, our recommendation is that the Governor write to the newly appointed Director of PTO, Jim Rogan (former CA Congressman).  The process is essentially a judicial process…so we must be somewhat careful not to “cross lines,” but since the Governor is writing on behalf of his constituent, and to the Director, not the Board that’s making the ultimate decision…we’re OK.
 
Also, Jorge has been urging us to write to the State Dept about a similar decision pending at Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC).  We spoke with Alan Larson, Under Secretary for Economics, Business and Agricultural Affairs.  He has been working w/ Jorge as much as we have…a letter to Alan is not necessary at this time and could actually complicate matters.  Governor should hold off sending any letter to the State Department.
 
Attached is our draft.  We asked Jorge to review the facts.  He cleared up a few items and we’re good to go.  If Gov decides to send letter, pls fax signed copies to us…we will send to staff.  Pls also fed-ex original and we will hand-deliver to PTO.
 
Thanks.  Nina.
