-----Original Message-----
From: CHRISTOPHER TIMMONS [mailto:timmo939@tcc.cc.fl.us]
Sent: Tuesday, May 21, 2002 2:31 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Letter to Judge Kathleen Kearney


Governor Bush:

If you or your staff would send this letter to Secretary Kearney, I
would be eternally grateful. 

                  


                  21 May 2002



The Honorable Kathleen Kearney, Secretary  
Florida Department of Children & Families 
1317 Winewood Blvd., Building 1, Room 202
Tallahassee, Florida 32399-0700


Dear Secretary Kearney: 


The Department of Children & Families is committed to working in
partnership with local communities to ensure safety, well-being and
self-sufficiency for the people we serve.  ----Florida Department of
Children & Families, Mission Statemet. 

In recent weeks, it has been found that the Florida Department of
Children & Families has not fully met its requirements to ensure that
all children under its care are safe, and free from harm. In the case of
Rilya Wilson questions, reasonably raised, about the state's performance
in protecting children in the child welfare system are very troubling.
It is essential that these issues are resolved quickly and that our
child welfare system is equipped with the tools necessary to guard
against failures similar to this in the future. 

In the few weeks after the Rilya tragedy, our Governor Jeb Bush and the
Florida Legislature passed and signed into law, House Bill 71-E,
tailored specifically to prevent caseworkers that will not live up to
the high standards established by law, from falsifying records and
getting away with it.

This law sets penalties for those who would try to circumvent the law by
falsifying official state records of persons under the care and custody
of the state of Florida. In addition, it provides for 15 years in prison
for any record falsified that would eventually cause bodily harm or
death to any child under the state's care and supervision. 

I commend the leadership of our Governor nd the Legislature, and
yourself madam Secretary in confronting this problem head on, and trying
to use all available resources to adequately deal with it. 

A few days after the tragedy, the Governor formed a Blue Ribbon Panel
commissioned to provide an interim and definitive set of recommendations
for DCF to better fulfill its mission, and goals. 

I sincerely hope, that these recommendations will encourage DCF to look
at what needs to be done, what has been done, and what will meet the
needs and safety of every child under its care for the 21st century. 

Its so very important that DCF make systemic changes, because so many
children and families depend upon your agency, madam Secretary for their
very livelihood. 

In this context, we need to look beyond the action of a few caseworkers
that do not meet the high standards, and high demands our law and the
Department places on them; and look to the hardworking, committed
caseworkers across our state, working tirelessly, day in and day out to
help our most vulnerable---our children chart the path to live out their
dreams. 

As a foster kid, here in Leon County, who happens to have benefited from
one such person, Katherine Smith, I see the need, and the eventually
inevitable urgency for affirmative action.  In the end, the long run,
this finally tears down a wall, built steadily over the years, that has
blocked the voice, and potential of so many kids throughout our state.  


God bless.

							Sincerely,


						      Chris Timmons

Subject: Problems with abstinence education program



Dear Jeb, 

How are you?  I am trying email instead of a call.  I am getting some
letters and phone calls from abstinence providers about the Florida
Department of Health and an apparent  shift in direction that the department
seems to be headed regarding abstinence education.

Abstinence educators report to me that the Health Department is trying to
satisfy certain vocal members of the state legislature by pushing evaluation
so hard as to set up this program for failure.  The ultimate result may be
that fewer adolescents will be served and ultimately fewer abstinence
education programs will exist in Florida.

Knowing you and your support for abstinence I believe you would find that
unacceptable.  Florida's commitment to abstinence education leads the nation
and any decrease in its programs would be a significant blow felt across the
country.  

Please review the attached letter and memo I am sending to Dr. Agwunobi.  It
lays out the issue and recommends a process to come to consensus on the
issues addressing abstinence education.

Thank you for all that you do for our state!  I hope to see you soon.

Sincerely, 

Dave Weldon, M.D.

Hi Governor,
 
I understand from our Tallahassee representatives that SB 100 has been delivered to you.  They said that HB 69-E, which is the bill that gave us a year's reprieve, has not been sent yet.  In looking at HB 69-E, Section 3 states that "section 1 of Senate Bill 100, 2002 regular session, is repealed".   I have heard some say you must still veto SB 100 - I'm not sure.
 
I did hear that you are considering vetoing both SB  100 and HB 69-E.  That would not hurt my feelings, since that would but us back where we were, which was trying to fix out para transit service.  There has been alot of discussion regarding "home rule issues" which started with the passage of SB 100.  If HB 69-E becomes law, we will have to go back next year to prove that we are worthy of continuing as the CTC for Central Florida prior to June 30, 2003 in order to prevent this from occurring again next year.
 
I am confident that you will do what you believe is best for the customers of the para transit service.  I believe that we are headed in the right direction to improve our agency overall and especially the para transit issue, without intervention from the state.  We have a number of issues we are working on, but Lynx did not get were it is today overnight and we cannot fix it overnight either.  
 
I appreciate your expression of confidence in me by appointing me to the Lynx board.  I am working hard to utilize my business knowledge and experience to strengthen the Lynx Board and make you proud of your decision to appointment me to this agency.
 
Warmest regards,
 
Brenda Carey

developers are limited to 2 stories on any buildings BUT, since an option
has been put down on some PRIME waterfront property down here AND since
Baskerville Donovan is pushing to get MORE money from state grants to "help"
us develop water and sewer further (first out to the golf course being built
and now.....for the condos I'm SURE are being considered for THAT property),
this place truly WILL be turned into the mess that Carl Hiassen was talking
about in his article. Let's just turn this picturesque little fishing
village into ANOTHER Destin....with the help of state funding, of course!

Meanwhile, our schools are in desperate need of help but, since Baskerville
Donovan can't scrape 20% off the top of any educational funds, they're not
being helped. The water sewer project that is going on now is a JOKE! Things
have to be torn up 4,5,6....even 7 times in one place...thanks to the LACK
of engineering and knowledge. Replacement sewer lines are NOT going back to
where they came from (in our case, the alley which is a city easement) but
rather, NEW places are being torn up and dug up. If the city is NOT going to
use their easements for water and sewer lines, why not just close the
alleys? And, at the end of it, everyone will wonder WHY there were so many
cost over-runs....AARRRGGHHHH!

I'm just sick about the whole mess and Baskerville Donovan is even asking
DEP and DCA to rush their approvals through, which will probably be done.
They hint that they have some "ins" there, anyway. State funding should NOT
be given to a town like this without State oversight! Not when we have an
illiterate mayor who has to sign off on all these "miracle grant funds"!
Asking BDI to oversee it is like asking the fox to guard the henhouse. Sure
they can solicit grant funds and take THEIR money off the top of that, then
WE have to live with inadequate work being done because of lack of knowlege.
*sigh*

Sorry to unload but you have NO idea how frustrating this gets down here.

Dear Michelle,
Thank you so much for replying to my letter concerning my daughter.. I
wanted to let you know that I was denied and did the appeal process and we
were just notified on Friday that the denial was overturned by a physician
in California that reviewed the case & we are able to go to the "Chiari
Clinic" to see Dr. Milhorat!!!  We have a appointment for June 7th with 2
days of testing the 5th & 6th.  Someone finally saw all of her
reports/surgery notes and newly diagnosed conditions & realized we needed
this approval.. Thank you so much for all your time & help for us..  I will
do whatever it takes to get her the care she needs & deserves.. It so hard
to see your little one having such a hard time..
Thanks Again,

Amie McCoy
----- Original Message -----
From: "Brantley, Michelle K." <brantlem@fdhc.state.fl.us>
To: <amiecj@netzero.net>
Sent: Thursday, May 23, 2002 8:35 PM
Subject: FW: Need help on Insurance Denial


> Dear Mrs. McCoy,
>
> Thank you for your recent e-mail to the Governor regarding your daughter's
> denial in insurance coverage to see a "specialist." This request was
> forwarded to the Agency for Health Care Administration, Medicaid Health
> Systems Development for response. Your letter describes your difficulty in
> obtaining insurance coverage approval from United Health Care for
> consultation and diagnostic testing from The Chiari Center. We are
committed
> to assisting your daughter, Courtney and appreciate you bringing this
matter
> to our attention.
>
> In response to your concerns, we plan to contact United Health Care
directly
> to request further information and consideration of your daughter's health
> care needs. You may also contact the Agency's Statewide Provider and
> Subscriber Assistance Program (SPSAP) which is a State of Florida program
> designed to assist consumers of managed care entities, such as Health
> Maintenance Organizations, with grievances that have not been
satisfactorily
> resolved. You must first complete the entire grievance process of the
> managed care entity before filing a grievance with the program, unless the
> grievance is of an urgent nature. If your grievance meets required
criteria,
> the program's staff will schedule the grievance for a hearing before an
> independent panel. After the hearing, the panel will make a recommendation
> based on the finding of fact either to the Department of Insurance or the
> Agency for Health care Administration to ensure that your daughter
receives
> the quality medical services rightfully due.
>
> In addition, please find a link below to the Department of Insurance
website
> which publishes a consumer guide for Health Maintenance Organizations to
> help you in this task. The guide contains basic information and your
rights
> and responsibilities as an insurance consumer. You may also contact the
> Florida Department of Insurance Consumer Helpline toll-free at
> 1-800-342-2762.
>
> http://www.doi.state.fl.us/Consumers/guides/newguides2.htm#HEALTH
>
> Thank you for taking the time to write the Governor in support of your
> daughter's health care needs. She is very fortunate to have such a
wonderful
> advocate.
>
>
> Shelly Brantley
> Bureau Chief
> Health Systems Development
> Agency for Health Care Administration
> (850)488-9347
>
>
>

 Subject: Re: DD Waiver Handbook                                             
                                                                             

I can talk only about respite because that is the only service that I am
getting sometimes for my child, not that I don't need any other services
for my child but living in Osceola County that is depraved of everything,
bare with me. As a respite provider I know what the parents would like .
Our children shouldn't be limited as far as place to respite. Any Child day
care of Family Day care licensed by DCF should be able to accommodate
respite. Respite shouldn't be limited, providers should be able to take
those
children OUT, like at any theme park or libraries or park and recreation,
like a companion who can take anywhere the consumer.
Parents should have a choice where respite should be provided. I feel like
we are putting our children in a cage by giving limitations
of place of respite. Who ever agree with me, just do like I do, give your
opinion and send it to Tallahassee or to Donna Rauber our co-chair for FCC
District 7. Thanks
It is important that we speak now....

Beatrice

From:	Elaine Grohol <grohole@osceola.k12.fl.us>
Sent:	Friday, May 24, 2002 7:42 AM
To:	Jeb@jeb.org.
Subject:	A County in Crisis

Dear Governor Bush,
We are facing an educational crisis here in Osceola County.  Osceola
County has had the fastest growing school system in the state for the past
five years, and is projected to have the fastest growing school system for
the next five years.  Osceola County has received the lowest amount, per
capita, for school construction in the state for the past five years. 
Osceola County has one of the highest percentages of students in charter
schools in the State.  We need legislative dollars in order to build new
schools.  Several of our elementary schools house over 1200 students (in
buildings that were constructed to hold 700 students).  Please consider
Osceola County for additional funding.  The education of Florida's
children depend on your support.

Respectfully yours,

Elaine M. Grohol
Elementary Instructional Specialist
Osceola District Schools
407-870-4953
"A smile is the shortest distance between two people." -- Victor Borge

From:	Kenneth Meyers <meyersk@osceola.k12.fl.us>
Sent:	Friday, May 24, 2002 7:08 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	veto of funds for Osceola schools

Governor:  As a principal in Osceola County, I can't tell you how
important the money set aside in the budget for fast growing counties is
to our school district.  Every year we struggle with tremendous growth,
crowded classrooms and discouraged teachers with low pay because money has
to go toward growth instead of teacher and employee raises.  You have been
to our district a couple of times this year and surely you saw the needs. 
Put aside the politics of cutting spending on this issue.  Don't demand of
us another year of "making do"  Our schools and district are bursting and
we need help.  Thanks for reading this.


Dr. K. Meyers, Principal;  Kissimmee Elementary
"Don't worry too much that children don't listen to you.
 Worry more that they are always watching you."  Robert Fulgham

5/24/02

Governor Bush,  

Good Morning!  I have worked for the past 34 years in Osceola County

county is something to behold and will continue to grow.  Osceola county
has had the fastest growing school system in the state for the past five
year, and is projected to have the fastest growing school system for the
next five years.    Our county has received the lowest amount, per capita,
for school construction in the state for the past five years.  Our county
has one of the highest percentages of students in charter schools in the
state.  Our county has exhausted all local sources for school instruction.

Bottom line!  Help our county we need alot of dollars to build new schools
as our population is growing so fast every week more new people means more
new students!

Help Osceola County, Please!

From:	Carol Lenderman <lendermc@osceola.k12.fl.us>
Sent:	Friday, May 24, 2002 8:18 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Funding for Osceola County

Dear Honorable Governor Bush,

I am sending this email in the hopes of persuading you to sign the budget
item in Section 28 on page 416.  This will provide Osceola County School
District with an extra 8.5 million in funds for construction.  

Osceola County has had the fastest growing school system in the state for
the past five years, and is projected to have the fastest growing school
system for the next five years.

Osceola County has received the lowest amount, per capita, for school
construction in the state for the past five years.

Osceola County has one of the highest percentages of students in charter
schools in the State.

Osceola County is the only County in the state that has exhausted all
local sources for school construction:
- Levying a full 2 mills
- Sharing in the Local Option Sales Tax
- Levying the highest School Impact Fees in the State
- Levying additional mills for a School Construction Bond Issue
- Established seven charter schools
- Using all effort index dollars
- Using all classroom 1st dollars

Thank you so much for your consideration.  Keep up the good work.

Carol Lenderman
Learning Resource Specialist
Discovery Intermediate
407-343-7300 ext. 237

We are each gifted in a unique and important way.  It is our privilege
and our adventure to discover our own special light.
---Mary Dunbar

                                                                          
                                                                          
                                                                          
                







From:	Elena Palmeri <palmerie@osceola.k12.fl.us>
Sent:	Friday, May 24, 2002 8:24 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Funding support

Governor Bush,

I am writing this email as a concerned citizen as well as a concerned
educator.  I am employed by the Osceola County Board of Education. 
Currently my position is Pre-K Exceptional Student Education Program
Specialist.  I am amazed as to the number of very young children who have
moved into Osceola County who are exhibiting developmental delays and/or
other disabilities.  It is crucial that Osceola County receive as much
money as possible to help these young children receive a strong foundation
on which they can build a successful future.  It is extremely difficult to
do this when classes are so overcrowded.  Unfortunately, funding (or
rather lack of appropriate funding) is the main element that stands in the
way of our children's success.  We have an outstanding team of educators
in Osceola County.  I understand that the State legislature has approved
$10 million to help fast growing counties.  I beseech you not to veto
this.  Please consider the following points when determining the need for
added funds to Osceola County Schools:



1. Osceola County has had the fastest growing school system in the state
for the past five years, and is projected to have the fastest growing
school system for the next five years.

2.  Osceola County has received the lowest amount, per capita, for school
construction in the state for the past five years.

3.  Osceola County has one of the highest percentages of students in
charter schools in the State.

4.  Osceola County is the only County in the state that has exhausted all
local sources for school construction:
- Levying a full 2 mills
- Sharing in the Local Option Sales Tax
- Levying the highest School Impact Fees in the State
- Levying additional mills for a School Construction Bond Issue
- Established seven charter schools
- Using all effort index dollars
- Using all classroom 1st dollars

(Budget, Section 28, page 416)


I thank you and appreciate your attention and consideration.

Elena Palmeri,
Pre-K Exceptional Student Education
Program Specialist
Osceola County Schools
805 Bill Beck Boulevard
Kissimmee, FL 34744
(407)343-8773





From:	Barbara Thompson <Barbara.Thompson@school.celebration.fl.us>

Subject:	Fund for Osceola County Schools

Dear Governor Bush,

Greetings in the mighty name of Jesus our soon coming King.

I am writtng in support of funds for the Osceola County Schools. Our
district is undoubtedly the fastest growing system in this area.  It's
recognition as such can be vividly seen as we take a look at our new
home sales record. In the little area of Poinciana some 400 new families
are moving in on a monthly basis.  Deerwood elementary school which goes
from PreK through 3rd grade is home to at least 1058 students.

Please vote yes for the funds allocated by the State Legislature, we
desperately need these dollars to build new schools. Our county has
eshausted all local sources for school construction. Please don't turn
your back on us.

I am praying and beleiving that God will speak to your heart so that you
will vote in favor of our School District's desparate needs for more
dollars for our schools.  I close in Jesus name.

Barbara Thompson

From:	Ralph Barrett <barrettr@osceola.k12.fl.us>
Sent:	Friday, May 24, 2002 8:38 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Cc:	museb@osceola.k12.fl.us; stonede@osceola.k12.fl.us; greert@osceola.k12.fl.us; robertsj@osceola.k12.fl.us; harfordm@osceola.k12.fl.us; chalifot@osceola.k12.fl.us
Subject:	Help!

Dear Governor Bush -

As a 43 year resident of Osceola County, as well as a teacher whose career
in the Osceola District began in 1971 and culminated in being selected
District Teacher of the Year for the 2001/2002 school year, I am writing
to ask you to please support the funding provided to our district in the
proposed Budget, Section 28, page 416.

Not only has the Osceola District tapped all available funding sources,
for the past five years we have been the fastest growing district in the
state, while receiving the lowest amount per capita for school
construction in Florida.

And our test results show the lack of commitment from our state leaders,
as year after year we are at the bottom of the districts in Central
Florida in all aspects of the FCAT.

Please "walk your talk" and sign the bill which appropriates some special
funding for the Osceola District Schools.  After doing so, please contact
me and I will gladly serve on your re-election campaign in our area.

Thank you.

Ralph Barrett
2001/2002 Osceola District Teacher of the Year
Rbarrett13@aol.com
Barrettr@osceola.k12.fl.us

From:	Laura Wakefield <wakefiel@osceola.k12.fl.us>
Sent:	Friday, May 24, 2002 8:39 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	School funding - budget

Dear Governor Bush,
Please support the funding for fast growing counties in the new budget
(section 28, p. 416).  The county where I teach (Osceola) has been the
fastest growing school system in the state for the past 5 years and we
really need the money to improve student learning.  We have already levied
our full 2 mills and use the local option sales tax to try to keep up with
the need for new schools.  We have opened seven charter schools  and use
all the dollars available to us through other legislative programs.  This
budgeted  money is crucial to our county.  It would be nice if teachers
and administrators could focus more on improving student learning instead
of where to put a student when there is no money for new classrooms.  This
money will make that more possible.  Thank you for your support. 

Laura Wakefield,  NBCT
History Teacher
Neptune Middle School
2727 Neptune Road
Kissimmee, Florida 34744

Governor Bush,
     I would just like to take a minute of your time to appeal to you to
support the funding for Osceola county schools.  I work in the school
system and see on a daily basis the extreme need for such funding.  We are
the fastest growing county for the past five years and are projected to
remain so for the next five.  We receive the lowest amount per capita in

From:	Glidden Nieves <nievesg@osceola.k12.fl.us>
Sent:	Friday, May 24, 2002 8:51 AM
To:	Jeb Bush; Museb@osceola.k12.fl.us
Subject:	New schools

As incoming citizens pursue the American Dream, they choose Osceola
County as their residence. As a seasoned educator of 22 years, I have
seen the growth in this county quadruple. Osceola High School is
projected to house over 2300 students this Fall. That is more than 150
students from the 2001-2002 school year. These numbers significantly
increase every year. Taking into consideration that the county has more
than 35 schools, this growth is overwhelming. Our growth is not constant
with the number of schools currently being built. Schools are becoming
portable cities and our children need a better learning environment.
Your support is desperately needed. Please consider giving back to the
communities by helping us build more schools, so our students can give
back to society. Yours Truly,Glidden Nieves.Thank you.

From:	Kendra Belson <belsonk@osceola.k12.fl.us>
Sent:	Friday, May 24, 2002 8:55 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	A request

Dear Mr. Bush:

I am currently serving as a school psychologist with Osceola County
Schools. In this position, I work with a wide variety of students,
teachers, and parents.  Therefore, I have the opportunity to assess the
evergrowing concerns about our student's education.  

We service children of many different ethnic and socioeconomic
backgrounds, which of course offers it's challenges.  As such, I have
found that many students need services that are simply unavailable due to
a large and growing student population and limited funding.  We have been
notified that we may be able to receive extra funding.  My e-mail is
simply to request that you allow our students to receive this money.  Our
classrooms have as many as 35 children in a room, and no assistant.  This
may work for children with average intelligence, but what of the children
below average intelligence who do not qualify for exceptional student
education?  They need extra help that is not available with the number of
students in a regular class.  Otherwise, we risk failing these children,
and not allowing them the opportunity to become productive citizens
through education.  

Please do not veto the money available to our school district.  This could
truly make a difference in our children's lives.  

Sincerely,
Kendra P. Belson, Ed.S., BCABA
School Psychologist

From:	Carolyn Chalifoux <chalifoc@osceola.k12.fl.us>
Sent:	Friday, May 24, 2002 8:57 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Help for Osceola County schools

Dear Governor,

Please do not veto the funds to help Osceola county schools found in
Section 28 page 416 of the budget.  Osceola County schools are suffering
from the large influx of students.  I teach special education students at
the high school level.  I had as many as 30 students in my room last year,
and the room is 1/2 the size of regular classrooms.  

I do not know if you are familiar with special education students, but it
is best if they have space between them  to help with their
distractibility.  Currently, my students sit one on top of the other.  I
am worried.  I have seen my caseload for next year, and I have over 24 in
three classes.  My students range in reading levels from 1st grade to 10th
grade, and they range in age from 14 to 21 years of age.  It is a
challenge to engage all of these levels, but with so many students in a
classroom it becomes quite difficult.

I am more worried when I drive around our county and see more and more
apartments going up.  People want to live in Osceola County, and our
county has exhausted so many efforts to accomodate their students, but it
is not enough.  We need your help.  As the Education Governor, won't you
please recognize that Osceola County is in need.  The teachers won't let
you down.

Thank you.

Carolyn Chalfioux
Special Education Teacher, Gateway High School
Osceola County

From: Maria Cruz [mailto:cruzm@osceola.k12.fl.us]
Sent: Friday, May 24, 2002 8:44 AM

Subject: Please reconsider


Dear Jeb, (May I call you Jeb?)

It is my understanding that  the State Legislature approved $10 million to
help fast growing counties and that you are in the process of reviewing 
the budget, and may veto it.  This email is to ask you to please, please
reconsider! Osceola county is one the faster growing in Central Florida
and it is projected that this grow will continue.  These funds are very
much needed.

Take my school for example, we are only 2 years old and we were
overcrowded this past school year and we are projected to be overcrowded
again next school year!  With this much grow new schools would need to be
built.

When reviewing the budget, please consider the following and think, think
very hard how this is going to affect the children in Osceola county, a
county with high number of non-English speaking Students. 

Osceola County has received the lowest amount, per capita, for school
construction in the state for the past five years.

 Osceola County has one of the highest percentages of students in charter
schools in the State.

Osceola County is the only County in the state that has exhausted all
local sources for school construction:
- Levying a full 2 mills
- Sharing in the Local Option Sales Tax
- Levying the highest School Impact Fees in the State
- Levying additional mills for a School Construction Bond Issue
- Established seven charter schools
- Using all effort index dollars
- Using all classroom 1st dollars

Respectfully,
Mrs. Maria A. Cruz
ESOL Compliance Specialist
Kissimmee Elementary, Osceola County

This is excellent, Shelley.

The key problem with the current funding system is that the money goes
directly to the state's central bureaucracy and then to the school district
bureaucracies.  Our challenge is to get the money past all of these folks
and into the classrooms.

It will never be a matter of how much money is allocated for school, it's a
matter of how closely the money follows the student.

Best of luck,
Marie

From:	Susan Dickerson <Susan_Dickerson@dcf.state.fl.us>
Sent:	Friday, May 24, 2002 9:46 AM
To:	Jeb Bush; Kathleen Kearney; Laura.Branker@MyFlorida.com
Subject:	Re: Request From Noah's Ark for help re: the criminalization ofdisabilities

Thank you,
Susan Dickerson, Acting Director of
Developmental Disabilities Program, Tallahassee, Fl
Ph 488-4877, ext. 144, suncom 278-4877, ext. 144
```````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````

----- Forwarded by Susan Dickerson/D20/DCF on 05/24/02 09:47 AM -----
                                                                                         
                    Susan                                                                
                    Dickerson            To:     whsammons@msn.com                       
                    Sent by:             cc:                                             
                    Darlene Golden       Subject:     Re: Request From Noah's Ark for    
                                          help re: the criminalization of disabilities   
                                                                                         
                    05/24/02 09:32                                                       
                    AM                                                                   
                                                                                         
                                                                                         



Dear Mr. Sammons:

Thank you for your May 22 e-mail to Governor Bush regarding your concerns
with Brown School.  Governor Bush asked me to respond to you on his behalf.

The children mentioned in your email are not clients of the Developmental
Disabilities program.  Our records indicate that Drew does not have a
qualifying diagnosis under Chapter 393.  The other child, Steven Graham is
not a client and has not been referred to the developmental disabilities
program according to our records.  In reference to your statements, I offer
the following comments.

1. " Brown school claims that they are able to make 50%of those with IQs 50
or below competent to stand trial.  That is absurd."  Children committed to
the Department as incompetent to proceed to trial are served by the Brown
Schools for community competency services and Apalachicola Forest Youth
Camp for residential services (both via contract managed by the Mental
Health program office).  The claim made is correct based on an OPPAGA
justification review (December 2000) of the Juveniles Incompetent to
Proceed program which reports that competency was restored for 35% of
juveniles below IQ of 50.    Additional data provided by the DCF Mental
Health Program office indicates that 57% of all mentally retarded juveniles
are restored to competency and 43% are not restored.

2.  " If a behavioral therapist had come to Steven's house once a week and
to the school once a week for a year, instead of receiving the Brown's
school instruction, there would have been a much better chance that he and
his single mom, would not be facing the current charges."   We do not know
if these children receive behavioral services from their schools at this
time.  Your email would lead us to believe they do not.  However, according
to Michelle Polland, Department of Education, behavior analysis services
may be provided by the schools to children who need this service as long as
it is in their Individual Education Plan (IEP).  The school should be asked
to review the need for behavior analysis services as you suggested.  Dr.
Bob Mitty at the Department of Education oversees behavior services for
children in schools.

3   "And finally, lets amend the law that says anytime a teacher is hit or
kicked by a student, a felony has been committed."   According to our
research into this issue (FS 784.081) the police officer has a range of
charges which may be filed which include misdemeanor to felony.  Therefore
it is not an automatic felony charge each time a teacher is hit.

I hope you find this information helpful.  If you need anything further,
please let me know.  Best wishes to you and the families at Noah's Ark.

`````````````````````````````````````
Thank you,
Susan Dickerson, Acting Director of
Developmental Disabilities Program, Tallahassee, Fl
Ph 488-4877, ext. 144, suncom 278-4877, ext. 144
```````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````

```````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````


                                                                                         
                    "Bill Sammons"                                                       
                    <whsammons@msn       To:     "'Jeb Bush'" <Jeb@Jeb.org>              
                    .com>                cc:     Kathleen Kearney/D20/DCF@DCF            
                                         Subject:     Request From Noah's Ark for help   
                    05/22/02 06:02        re: the criminalization of disabilities        
                    PM                                                                   
                                                                                         
                                                                                         




Jeb:
First, all of the parents and kids at Noah's Ark appreciate your support.
It has been essential. And thanks for your help and participation with the
Family Café.
This email is to let you know of a practice of the State of Florida, a
practice that I believe you would work to stop immediately if you knew
about it.
I am working as a volunteer advocate for Steven, a 5(superscript: th)
grader with significant development disabilities. He appears to be
somewhere on the autism continuum. In the third grade Steven was arrested
for hitting his teacher.  For the next year instructors from The Brown
School came to his house twice a week, for an hour to two hours a session,
in an effort to train him to be competent so he could be prosecuted for
hitting his teacher. After a year they were unsuccessful.  Steven was not
prosecuted.
The Brown School is a company contracted by the State of Florida, and I am
guessing at the direction of the state attorneys and/or judges, to train
the developmentally disabled charged with crimes to become competent to
stand trial. What I can't understand is that a representative of the Browns
School boasted that approximately 30 percent of the people they work with
have IQ's of 50 or below. They claim they are able to make 50% of those
with IQ's 50 or below competent to stand trial. To me, this is absurd.
Back to Steven ?Steven again has been charged with hitting his teacher.
Steven needs services to help overcome his disabilities, not training so he
can parrot answers that will put him in a juvenile detention center. If
behavioral therapists had come to Steven's house once a week and to his
school once a week for a year, instead of receiving the Brown's School
instruction, there would have been a much better chance he, and his single
mom, would not be facing the current charges. The State has money for
competency training that hopes to permit the state to prosecute a
developmentally delayed third grader, but the schools do not have the money
for behavior therapists.
In October Drew, my 16 year old son with Asperger's Syndrome ( a
high-functioning autistic), was arrested on complaints by teachers in his
center school and taken to the Juvenile Detention Center. Often teachers
are not properly trained and can't get the support services they feel they
need.  The week before Drew's teacher filed charges, she was scheduled to
get long sought training.  That training that was canceled due to lack of
funds.  The teachers and staff are frustrated and strike out though the
criminal justice system.  She filed charges.
The system in the State of Florida is criminalizing many of those with
developmental disabilities in the year 2002. We had to have my son declared
incompetent.  In the behavior arena, the State is destroying the self
esteem the developmentally disabled and is demoralizing their parents.
Please look into The Brown School. See if the information I believe to be
correct really is. Please look into the lack of behavioral therapists and
the criminalization of those with developmental disabilities. My special
needs attorney promises me teachers are having developmentally disabled
students arrested all over the state.  And finally, let's amend the law
that says anytime a teacher is hit or kicked by a student, a felony has
been committed.  The very young and those with significant developmental
disabilities should be exempt.  You have to know that just in Polk County
alone over 20 "felonies" a day are being committed by elementary school
children with developmental disabilities when they kick or hit their
teachers.  Each teacher can chose to deny the student reentry to their
classroom and go through due process and/or the teacher can file criminal
charges.  More and more teachers are just filing criminal charges.
Steven's mom is a single parent and can't afford the special needs
attorney, the criminal attorney, and the expert witness I hired for my son
Drew. Steven has a pro bono attorney who is giving the matter a little
attention.  Most developmentally disabled kids and their families are
thrown out of the education system and into the criminal justice maelstrom
without a rudder.  What they need are trained staff and teachers and the
active involvement of behavior analysts.
Your help in doubling the developmentally disabled budget in the last three
years has been amazing.  Your help with Noah's Ark has been amazing.
Steven, his mom, Drew, my wife, myself, and kids all over the state need
yet another miracle.
Noah's Ark of Central Florida
Bill Sammons, President
Bill@SCRproperties.Com
Phone : (863) 688-3323
Fax: (863) 680-1603
505 Bartow Road
Lakeland, Fl 33801-5466


From:	Leo Huott <huottl@osceola.k12.fl.us>
Sent:	Friday, May 24, 2002 9:58 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Osceola School District

Dear Govenor Bush,

It is my honor to write you concerning the proposed funding for rapidly
growing school districts.  It is imperitive the funding is approved for
Osceola County so we can keep pace with the rapidly growing population. 
As a high school algebra teacher it is of extreme important to have small
class sizes to provide the necessary instruction and one on one
interaction with algebra students. 

Should the funding not be approved, I personally face class sizes of
thirty plus, my colleages who teach Algebra II and Geometry face class
sizes of forty.  If I were a college professor, I say "bring it on!"  Yet
this is high school and we are dealing with children not adults.  Class
sizes of this size are detrimental to the education and success of our
future in Florida and the Nation.  It is bad enough that children come to
high school not prepared and we have to play catch up for a year.  To
support this more than 25% of the incomming 800 freshman read below the
third grade level.  By adding more students to the classes we will hurt
the education system further.

Govenor Bush, I implore you to approve the funding so we can add
classrooms, hire new teachers, and raise teacher salaries so as to provide
a quality education for our youth.  Yes I stated raise teachers salaries,
I could easily go to Orange or Seminol County and make more money, yet
Osceola is more personable and more supportive of its staff that is why I
choose to stay here.  Please approve the funds so we can do more for our
children.

Very Respectfully,

Leo S. Huott

Ps.  Jeb,  You have my vote in 2002!  I do not want to see the Democrats
in power and bring forth their programs that erode family values.

From:	Audie Confesor <confesoa@osceola.k12.fl.us>
Sent:	Friday, May 24, 2002 10:02 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Osceola County Schoos

Dear Mr. Bush,

Thank you for taking the time out of your busy schedule to read this e
mail.  I would like to introduce myself.  My name is Audie Confesor, and I
am a teacher in Osceola County.  The reason for my e mail is a request
that you do not veto the money that was approved by the State Legislature
to aid rapid growing counties.  I plan on finishing my career here in
Osceola County, and with your help, this county can flourish. Osecola
County has had the fastest growing school system in the state for the past
five years, and we may be the fastest growing for the next five years. 
Per capita, Osceola County has received the lowest amount for school
construction. There are some schools in this county that have thrity two
students per classroom. Many of the elementary instututions are old and
worn down. As an educator, I feel that smaller class size is beneficial to
the growth and development to your youth.  With the money, we can build
more schools, and attain the help that is necessary to help our students.  

Osceola County has exhausted all local sources for school construction by
levying two full mills, sharing in the local option sales tax, levying the
highest school impact fees in the state, and establishing seven charter
schools.  Osceola County also has one of the highest amount of charter
schools in the state.  In addition, Osceola County has used all effort
index dollars, as well as all classroom 1st dollars.  

In conclusion, I would like to say how much I do enjoy working for this
county.  I enjoy my career, and I treasure every minute of the time I
spend at my facility.  Please consider the State's decision to aid rapid
growing counties.  Thank you once again for your time and your
understanding.  

Sincerely,
Audie R. Confesor
Narcoossee Community School
3rd Grade Teacher

Subject:	Please help us!

Dear Mr. Bush sir,
	I urge you not to  veto the 10 million dollars that the state legislature
has approved for fast growing counties.  Osceola County has had the lowest
amount per capita for school construction in the past 4 or 5 years.
	Why do we need more school construction?  I am in the biggest elementary
school in this county (1100 students).  A new school is being built close
by and through redistricting we will be losing 300 students and 18
teachers and staff for the upcoming school year.  My dream for the
upcoming year was to have a "small first grade classroom" but already I
see I am "starting" the year with 25 children.  I had 25 students this
year also.  We have one teacher assistant per 8 teachers.
	Now, although I have been Teacher of the Year twice and District Teacher
of the Year once, I am also ESOL endorsed (with 7 Hispanic children this
yr. and will have 7 next year) and National Board Certified.......teaching
these children to read and write well is a very difficult task. Many of us
at Lakeview stay late and work and also come down on the weekends working
hard to make our academic lessons stimulating.  However, it continues to
be stressful and difficult to meet the needs of these ESOL students, low
students, gifted students and also the average students in our classrooms
when there are so many.   I don't need to tell you that the single most
important factor in a classroom is the quality of its teacher.  I have
been teaching for 28 years and I still love every single day in the
classroom but I do get frustrated when children coming into my classroom
come with some many home/ discipline/health related problems and I am
responsible for all of these areas as well as the academics.  I'm a good
teacher but I'm not "WonderWoman!" Please support the 10 million dollars
so class sizes will be reduced, I can continue to enjoy teaching and I can
prevent an early onset of gray hair!   Thank you for your time Mr. Bush.

							Sincerely,
							One of Florida's many dedicated teachers,
							Cynthia Beasley

From: Gene Wells [mailto:gw@copaparts.com]

Subject: Gandy Update


Gov:
 
Last night's public meeting revealed a new version of the elevated Gandy...instead of down the middle of Gandy FDOT shifted a Land Bridge over the north side of Gandy completely wiping out the 37 businesses affected...one wonders how all of a sudden this option appeared.  
 
However, the absence a Right of Way Cost really was a disservice to the commmunity.  I cannot understand after 12 years of study and millions of dollars, FDOT could not (or would not) have ROW Costs available.  In my opinion, this will be what finally decides the option that will be ultimately selected by FDOT.
 
Historically, an elevated Gandy was widely unacceptable to the community (except the south of Gandy folks who have opposed the By-pass all along) because of the devastation of the Gandy Business District and the unsightly ala Hwy 19 feel of this proposal.  I am unsure now, without ROW costs, of whether now an unsightly Land Bridge would be rejected because of it's reduced impact to the business district by taking 37 businesses which are primarily small businesses or parking lots.
 
FDOT did a better job of defining the on and offs of both facilities which seem to answer our concerns of getting folks on to Gandy that want to.  They also reaffirmed their commmitment to the $23 million Gandy improvements.  THe price tag of the Westshore truck ramps was put at $8-9 million if they do it.
 
Until the ROW costs are defined we will not know the direction FDOT is going. Or whether the No-build remains viable.
 
FDOT will be presenting to the South Tampa CHamber Board of Directors on June 6th at 6pm at the Jan Platt Library.  A first of them coming by a seeing us.
 
I will keep you all posted as I learn more and determine what the STCC feels about the project.
 
I would appreciate if you encourage FDOT to get the ROW costs to us and the public.
 
Hope all is well.
 
Gene Wells

From:	Keith Cooper <kcooper@amenityservicesinc.net>
Sent:	Friday, May 24, 2002 11:08 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Osceola School Funding 

Dear Governor Bush:
 
As a concerned citizen and taxpayer I would like to express my support of the upcoming budget review for school funding in Osceola County.
 
Osceola County has had the fastest growing school system in the state for the past five years and is projected to have the fastest growing school system for the next five years.
 
- Osceola County has received the lowest amount, per capita, for school construction in the state for the past five years.
 
- Osceola County has one of the highest percentages of students in Charter Schools in the State.
 
- Osceola County is the only County in the state that has exhausted all local sources for school construction:
-         Levying a full 2 mills
-         Sharing in the Local Option Sales Tax
-         Levying the highest School Impact Fees in the State
-         Levying additional mills for a School Construction Bond Issue
-         Established seven charter schools
-         Using all effort index dollars
-         Using all classroom 1st dollars
 
Your approval of the 8.5 million dollars appropriated by the state legislature is vital to the future of our community and more importantly our children.
 
Please approve and sign the appropriation bill that can be found in the Budget in Section 28 on pate 416.
 
Sincerely,

From:	Ana Smith <smitha@osceola.k12.fl.us>
Sent:	Friday, May 24, 2002 11:10 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Help for Fast Growing Counties

The Honorable Jeb Bush:

My name is Ana De Benedictis Smith (Yo soy Latina) an employee of The
School District of Osceola County, FL.  I have a work history with Osceola
County of 22 years, and seen our County grow.  We are the fastest growing
school district in the state for the past five years; however, I have seen
an incredible transformation in our district.  When I started working here
in 1981 the student population was about 8,480, and today we have a little
over 38,000.  This is amazing!!! Unfortunately as you well know with
growth also comes growing pains, and we have them.  This explosion in
growth has created a great need for new facilities/schools.  The funds are
not there.  Osceola County is  the only County in the state that has
exhausted all local sources for school construction: Levying a full 2
mills, sharing in  the Local Option Sales Tax, Levying the highest School
Impact Fees in the State, levying additional mills for a School
Construction Bond Issue, Established seven charter schools, using all
effort index dollars, and using all classroom 1st dollars.  Amazing!!!
Respectfully, I am requesting that you support the approval of $10 million
to help fast growing counties.  I believe Osceola County would benefit
from these needed funds.  Believe me, the funds will be well expended to
help the children of Osceola County.

Thank You,

Ana D. Smith

-----Original Message-----
From: Muniz, Katie [mailto:Katie.Muniz@MyFlorida.com]
Sent: Thursday, May 23, 2002 9:55 AM
To: Shanahan, Kathleen
Cc: Jeb Bush
Subject: MWI


Water district scrutinizes $1.9 million contract with former partner of
Gov.
Bush

By David Fleshler 
Staff Writer 
Posted May 23 2002 
Investigations into the company have become a potential source of
embarrassment for Bush as he campaigns for a second term. Last month,
the
U.S. Department of Justice filed suit against the company over the
alleged
misuse of a U.S.-backed loan to sell equipment to Nigeria. Bush, who was
not
accused of wrongdoing, had traveled to Nigeria in 1989 as a
representative
of a company he owned jointly with MWI's president, David Eller, to sell
irrigation and flood control equipment.  The water management district
investigation concerns a contract the district awarded Sept. 25, 2000,
as
the region entered the third year of a drought. As the water level of
Lake
Okeechobee fell, the district desperately needed submersible pumps to
siphon
up water that would not flow out on its own by gravity. The water was
needed
for farms, wells and to prevent saltwater from intruding into the
groundwater that serves cities.  To build the pumps, the district turned
to
MWI, which had supplied equipment to the district since 1965. Eller, the
company's president, is a second-generation member of the family-run
firm.
He is also a generous Republican contributor. He and his company have
given
$18,490 in political contributions in Florida since 1996, nearly all of
it
to Republicans, according to state campaign finance records. He also has
personally contributed $21,100 to federal candidates and political
organizations, including $15,900 to the Republican Party, according to
the
Federal Election Commission.  The district's nine-member board is
appointed
by the governor. At the time the contract was awarded, most members were
Bush appointees. Phone calls to Bush's media relations office were not
returned Wednesday.  Because the pumps were needed immediately to deal
with
the drought, the board waived its normal procurement rules and allowed
its
staff to award the contract. A total of 15 pumps were installed along
the
lake's southern rim. The pumps worked well, allowing the district to
draw in
water that would have otherwise been out of reach.  But the district's
inspector general has launched a complaint about the circumstances under
which the contract was awarded.  "The inquiry is into the propriety of
the
district's actions in procuring pumps," said Smith, the district's
spokesman.  He said that MWI is a well-known company, with a good
record.
And it could offer a fast turn-around time for orders that needed to be
filled immediately, a crucial point with a drought on.  But he
acknowledged
that the district's staff had contacted MWI and worked with the company
to
develop specifications before other companies were allowed to bid. He
said
such contacts are not unusual, when staffers need to know whether a
project
is doable or not. And he acknowledged that staffers drafted a memo
awarding
the contract to MWI before making a last-minute decision to solicit bids
from other companies.  Michael Collins, a Bush appointee who was
chairman of
the district's board at the time, said he thinks the district's staff is
too
close to many contractors, appearing to favor certain ones over others.
But
he said there's no hint that the governor exerted any influence on
behalf of
his former partner.  "That's total garbage," he said. "We don't play
those
games. I have never gotten a call from anyone in the governor's office
about
doing a favor. Am I concerned over the procurement process and over
staff
doing a favor? We're looking into it. We have been extremely upset, as a
board, over staff bringing the same companies back again and again."
MWI
spokesman Kevin Boyd said the company did nothing wrong in obtaining the
contract. Other companies were offered the chance to bid on the pump
deal,
and several did, he said.  "MWI operates on a level playing field with
the
competition," he said. "Water management district contracts are not that
easy to come by, and you have to do your homework. They've done plenty
of
work under Chiles and other Democratic governors. It's not like when a
Republican came in they suddenly got business."  In the Nigeria deal, he
said the company did nothing wrong. The federal government's suit
accuses
the company of misusing a $74.3 million loan through the Export-Import
Bank
of the United States. The lawsuit says the company gave one-third of the
loan money to a Nigerian representative who used it to make payoffs to
Nigerian officials.  Boyd said the federal government has dropped a
criminal
investigation into the Nigeria allegations and that he expected the same
result for the civil suit.  David Fleshler can be reached at
dfleshler@sun-sentinel.com or 954-356-4535.

Copyright © 2002, South Florida Sun-Sentinel
<http://www.sun-sentinel.com>

that will complete our goal of conducting Table Tops in ALL 7 regions by the
end of June.

capabilities statewide.

steps etc.

considering includes $8.5 million which would be of great assistance in
helping Osceola "catch up" with the burgeoning demand for schools.

- Osceola County has had the fastest growing school system in the state for
the past five years and is projected to have the fastest growing school
system for the next five years.
- Osceola County has received the lowest amount, per capita, for school
construction in the state for the past five years.
- Osceola County has one of the highest percentages of students in Charter
Schools in the State.
- Osceola County is the only County in the state that has exhausted all
local sources for school construction: - Levying a full 2 mills - Sharing in
the Local Option Sales Tax - Levying the highest School Impact Fees in the
State - Levying additional mills for a School Construction Bond Issue -
Established seven charter schools - Using all effort index dollars - Using
all classroom 1st dollars

Subject:	School Construction Assistance for Fast Growing Counties

Governor Bush:
As a long time supporter (I still have the bumper sticker on from the last
time), the owner of a successful High-Tech firm, and the Republican
Candidate for County Commissioner District 2 here is Osceola County, I
request that you sign the Bill that will support the funding of schools for
fast growing counties in our state (which may be found in the Budget in
Section 28 on page 416).

Osceola County has had the fastest growing school system in the state for
over five years, but as you probably know, we received the lowest amount,
per capita, for new school construction for the past five years.  We have
made the maximum local effort to resolve this issue LOCALLY.  We have one of
the highest percentages of students in Charter Schools in the State.  We are
the ONLY County in the state that has exhausted ALL local sources for school
construction by levying the full 2 mills, procuring a share of our Local
Option Sales Tax, levying the highest School Impact Fees in the State and
additional mills for a School Construction Bond Issue, using all effort
index dollars and all classroom 1st dollars.  We are simply out of options
and truly need these additional dollars.

I would appreciate your support in this manner.

Sincerely,

Subject:	Bioterrorism

Chambers have approved the Conference Report and it’s ready for the President’s signature.  The attached is a summary outline of the Bill.  Please keep in mind that the following represents both FY02 appropriated funds and the authorization for FY03 levels.  We don’t know yet----how specifically this will affect Florida financially, but we are affected in a number of policy areas.
 
Our memo is divided into two sections------first section gives you some background and how, generally, Florida is impacted.  The second section is a summary outline of the bill.  Each section w/in the summary outline is noted with the DC staff responsible for those issues.  Please feel free to call with any questions or concerns (202/624-5885).
 
Page 1             General background, Florida Impact
 
Page 2             National Preparedness and Response Planning
 
Page 3             Strategic National Stockpile 
 
Page 4             Improving State, Local and Hospital Preparedness; Emergency Authorities, Other provisions--- Stafford Act, rapid detection systems, worker health and safety, emergency preparedness for VA
            
Page 5             Department OF HHS; Department of Agriculture
 
Page 6             Interagency Coordination Regarding Agents and Toxins; Criminal Penalties regarding Biological Agents and Toxins; Protection of Food Supply
 
Page 7             Protection of Drug Supply; Upgrade of Agriculture Security

                                                                        May 23, 2002
 
 
Dear Governor Bush,
 
As a public school teacher in Osceola County and a parent of three students, I am writing to ask you to continue to support  funding for fast growing counties in Florida.  If you refer to to Section 28 page 416 in the Budget, you will find that Osceola County has had the fastest growing school system in the state for the past five years and is projected to have the fastest growing school system for the next five years.  In addition, Osceola County has received the lowest amount, per capita, for school construction for the past five years and is the only county in the state that has exhausted all local resources for school construction:  levying a full 2 mills, sharing in the Local Option Tax, levying highest school impact fees in the state, levying additional mills for a school construction bond issue, using all effort index dollars, using all classroom 1st dollars, and establishing seven charter schools..  In fact, Osceola County has one of the highest percentages of students in charter schools in the state.  
 
We are slated to receive $8.5 million of the $10 million approved by the State Legislature.  We desperately need these dollars to build new schools.  Please DO NOT VETO these critical funds.  Thank You.

Dear Governor Bush, 
I have been an employee for the Osceola County School Board for 13 years.

significant being the change in size. As a result of the increase in our
population I have also seen an increase in class size. I worked at a
school that had 32-35 students in each fourth grade class. This is
ridiculous - especially with the recent legislation regarding students
reading on grade level by third grade. 
We will have 2 new elementary schools for the coming school year but still
our schools are overcrowed. I was pleased to read about the $8.5 million
that Osceola was to receive for new schools. That's great but we still
will not be able to keep pace with the growth we are experiencing. 
Now I have been told that you may veto the allocation of these funds. I
ask that you think carefully about this decision, as I am sure you will.
Osceola County needs more classrooms so that we may better serve our
students. Come visit us. I think you will be impressed with what you will
see in our crowded classrooms. Imagine what you might see if the classes
were smaller and the students had more individual teacher contact time. 
Thank you for your time!

Maureen A. Donohue

From:	MCLEANED@aol.com
Sent:	Friday, May 24, 2002 3:40 PM
To:	insight@orlandosentinel.com
Subject:	FCAT  Results

When my wife and I and our four sons moved to the Orando area from Jacksonville, our main goal was to move into the Winter Park High School district and it's feeder schools. We therefore moved to Maitland so our sons could attend Dommerich Elementary, Maitland Middle School and Winter Park High School. We have since learned that a lot of other parent's have done likewise including your columnist Mike Thomas.
When we recently saw the FCAT results, we realized what a good decision we had made. The scores at these schools stood out like a sore thumb. When you see that a school like Dommerich scores 84% on the third grade reading section, it makes one wonder why? We know why. First, this is a community with parents that care. Most of these students come from two parent families who really care about their children's education. It is an above average income area with a lot of parents with college educations and many professional people.These parents take the time to sit down and read to their children and also listen to the child read to them.They know their children's  teachers and take part in parent-teacher activities. This school is blessed with children from a wholesome back ground.
There are those among us that think that raising taxes and throwing money at education solves all educational problems. Money can build buildings, but it won't get parents involved in educating their children. They think that educating their children is a government function and they can't be bothered in helping.
Mike Thomas and the liberal Democrats including the leadership of the teachers unions blame Jeb Bush. The Republicans blame Lawton Chiles and the Democrats because they controlled education in Florida for many years. The last three or four teachers of the year are supporting Jeb Bush in his re-election campaign as witnessed by his TV commercials..
Ladies and gentlemen, education is the biggest political football  there is. There are many children who don't come from a home background like I have described. Some have one parent, some live with a grandparent, some can't even speak the English language. How can any one expect them to read?
Why don't all of these people who are complaining about our schools go to a school that didn't have the scores that Dommerich had and volunteer to mentor an unfortunate child? The blessings I can assure you will be many. In spite of all the criticism our governor gets, he is doing just that. If you think he is doing it for political reasons so be it. The bottom line however is that he is doing it.
Ed & Barbara McLean
Maitland, Fl

>  -----Original Message-----
> From: 	Thomas, Mandy  
> Sent:	Friday, May 24, 2002 1:49 PM
> To:	ALL OF EOG, OPB & SDD
> Subject:	GOVERNOR BUSH PRAISES REVISED FEDERAL PROCEDURES FOR
> INTERNATIONAL PASSENGERS CONNECTING AT FLORIDA AIRPORTS
> 
> 
> FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
> CONTACT: ELIZABETH HIRST
> FRIDAY, MAY 24, 2002
> (850) 488-5394 OR
> 	
> DAVID BISHOP
> 	
> (850) 487-2658
> 
> GOVERNOR BUSH PRAISES REVISED FEDERAL PROCEDURES FOR INTERNATIONAL
> PASSENGERS CONNECTING AT FLORIDA AIRPORTS
>   
> 	TALLAHASSEE - Governor Jeb Bush today announced that the federal
> government has approved a significant amendment to its policy dealing with
> international airline passengers connecting in Florida, but whose final
> destination is another country.  The new procedures for the Immigration
> and Naturalization Service (INS) and U.S. Customs Service comes at the
> request of Governor Bush, who intervened after at least one international
> airline made public its intent to consider moving its Miami hub to another
> country.  
>  
> 	"I want to thank U.S. Commissioner Robert Bonner and INS
> Commissioner Jim Ziglar for their willingness to work with all concerned
> parties to expediently reach an agreement that provides for strict
> security measures while also ensuring that international visitors landing
> at Florida airports can make connecting flights to other countries," said
> Governor Bush.  "Once we presented our case, both the U.S. Customs and INS
> worked proactively with our state and local leaders to reach a fair
> resolution for all concerned."
>  
> The concern was brought to Governor Bush's attention in February, during a
> visit by a Spanish delegation to Florida led by the President of the
> Madrid Community.  Representatives of Spain's Iberia Airlines informed the
> Governor that the problem was so severe that the airline was considering
> moving its hub out of Miami and to another country.  Governor Bush sent a
> letter to Commissioner Bonner requesting that the Customs Service work
> with Florida aviation authorities to find alternatives that would continue
> to ensure the safety of travelers while allowing airlines to conduct
> business efficiently. Commissioner Bonner responded within two weeks,
> agreeing to look at the issue, which today's announcement brings to
> conclusion.  The Governor's Office also worked with INS authorities to
> incorporate them in a satisfactory resolution.
>  
> 	Under the revised procedures, air carriers are required to submit
> 100 percent Advance Passenger Information (API) electronic data prior to
> the aircraft's arrival.  Upon arrival, international-to-international
> transit (ITI) passengers are to deplane their aircraft and, under airline
> supervision, be presented to INS for Primary Inspection.  Once cleared by
> INS, the passengers will proceed, via sterile corridors, to in-transit
> lounges, where they will await connecting flights.  
>  
> Prior to the revisions set to go into effect, the INS and U.S. Customs had
> elevated its security as a result of the tragic events of September 11.
> Although the destination of ITI passengers is not the United States, they
> were required to clear INS and Customs.  After inspection they were
> released into the general airport population to find the gate for their
> connecting flights.  This especially presents problems for passengers
> transiting the U.S. without visas (TWOV), requiring the airlines to
> maintain custody of the TWOV passengers in a public airport environment.
> Over time, these procedures caused significant disruptions in flight
> connection times--causing schedule delays and cancellations, as well as
> significantly increasing operating costs for an already battered
> commercial aviation industry.
> 
> "We believe that the new procedures will strengthen security, which is our
> top priority, while at the same time, improve customer service by
> facilitating the movement of these passengers," said Miami International
> Airport Aviation Director Angela Gittens.
>  
> Florida is a leading international tourism destination and air cargo hub
> particularly sensitive to disruptions in airline traffic and schedules.
> The resolution of this issue is a boost not only to Florida aviation, but
> also to our hospitality and foreign trade sectors.
>  
> 	Governor Bush praised the exemplary team effort between the
> Miami-Dade Aviation Department, several airlines, and Florida's
> Congressional delegation in proactively working to resolve this important
> issue.  
>  
> # # #
> 
>

I understand certificates issued by DOI are transferable.  Theoretically, a
minority insurer could purchase a certificate issued during that time period
and qualify.  The bill was amended to include an end date because the
president wanted a known fiscal impact.

> From: 	Flack, Christopher

> Subject:	385 and 1822 - Insurance

> 
> 
> Governor, I just spoke with Ben Watkins who had a conference call with
> those dealing with the language relating to the liabilities upon
> dissolution of the newly created CPIC; 385 and 1822 provide that the
> corporation will not be dissolved unless adequate provisions for payment
> for all of the bonds it has outstanding has been made.  According to Ben,
> folks at Insurance (Dan Sumner), Squire Sanders (Represents JUA), Gordon
> Arkin, and David Koshak (White and Case, NY), this language does not have
> to be passed this year, if the language does not pass, they are
> comfortable it will not impact the existing ratings on bonds.  To follow
> this up, Ben also got informal agreement from folks at S&P.  In addition
> to this issue, they all agreed that the technical issue of "subsection"
> rather than "paragraph" and  JUA's ability to give legal justification to
> the extension of Lines of Credit for JUA would not be a problem in getting
> a line of credit renewal.
> 
> All of the people involved expressed a desire however to have these
> changes made in subsequent legislation.   Don Langston has a call in to
> the Dept. of Revenue to check to see if anyone has qualified for the tax
> break.
From:	MKSkins@aol.com
Sent:	Friday, May 24, 2002 6:29 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Expressing Support For Bill CS/SB 160

Governor Bush:

   I would like to express my support of bill CS/SB 160.

   The Bill CS/SB 160, otherwise known as the "Debbie Wasserman-Schultz Act", 
would help fund the volunteer operated greyhound adoption program.
   This bill would further provide changes to the number of days and hours of 
operation of the cardroom as well as replacing the ten-dollar "pot limit" 
with a limited two-dollar "bet limit." These changes will reenergize the 
State's declining racetrack cardrooms, create needed jobs and generate purse 
money, State tax and track revenue.

   Thank you!

Michael Karr

From: Hsep1072@aol.com [mailto:Hsep1072@aol.com]
Sent: Thursday, May 23, 2002 7:48 PM
To: bob_graham@graham.senate.gov; Jeb Bush
Subject: Military Request


Hello Sirs, 

I am SFC Heath Nierman from Ft Lauderdale, FL.  I have been on active duty for twelve years and am currently stationed at FORT BENNING, GA B CO 2/29th IN.  I have been trying for the past year to turn in an Officer Candidate Selection Packet for review in order to become a commissioned officer.  The only thing I have wanted to do in my life since I was a child is be in the ARMY I am here and love it.  I have set many goals along my career and am proud to say I have achieved them. Several years ago my wife who is also active duty mentioned to me becoming an officer, a friend of hers was going to OCS and when I thought it through I decided that I would like to do that as the next step in my career. I set out to get the required college hours by reenlisting for the college option.  I never dreamed I would encounter what I have.  Attached is an outline of the situations that I have tried to overcoming in my attempts to submit this packet.  Today I was denied the opportunity to go to the post Inspector General's Office to voice my concerns off possibly being "black balled" by my chain of command.  This reality hit me hard as I have always fully trusted in my chain of command to take care of me as a soldier like I take care of those soldiers that serve under me.  I feel now like it is becoming a hostile working environment for me there as they attempt to brand me for stirring up trouble in an attempt to submit my OCS packet.  This will be damaging if not detrimental to my career.  I also fear repercussions for further pursuing submission of my packet but I know that I must set an example for those under me that if they have a goal they should do what is right to pursue that goal and not allow it to hampered by the invalid attempts of others. If there is anything you can do to aid me in submitting this packet I respectfully ask for your help.  If you would like to speak with me concerning this please call me at :  334-448-4134 (home), 706-545-6459 (work), or 706-570-4796 (cell). 


Sincerely, 

SFC HEATH NIERMAN 
"FAMILY OF ONE IN AN ARMY OF ONE"

From:	Robert Janauskas <wishfer@worldnet.att.net>

Joe H. Pickens; Rep. Perry C. McGriff; Rep. Hugh H. Gibson; Rep. Dennis K. Baxley; Rep. Nancy Argenziano
Subject:	CA Foreclosure & Assuring Complaince of HOA Members in FL 

Cyber Citizens For Justice Dispatch - Distribute Widely -
http://www.ccfj.net/  
 
Dear members and friends, 
 
Two recent HOA stories are of particular interest. The latest is about foreclosures in CA. The other is about how a Florida community is attempting to achieve its goal of complaince.  
 
These are excerpts from the CA foreclosure story. Please note the stance of CAI,  (A RED ALERT?)
 
Associations sometimes show teeth 

Homeowners fight foreclosures by their community associations 


By Jessica Brice, The Associated Press
May 24, 2002 


SACRAMENTO -- Ellen D'Agostino nearly lost her home over $250 in back dues she owed to her homeowners association. 


Having her association foreclose on her home was not something she signed on for when she moved into Creekside Circle, a gated community in Sacramento, D'Agostino says. 


But representatives for the Creekside Circle Homeowners Association maintain that's exactly what she did. Spelled out in the contract D'Agostino signed when she bought her home was an agreement giving the association the right to foreclose to obtain back dues. 


More than 19 million homes and one out of every six Americans belong to a homeowners association within a common interest development, according to the Community Associations Institute in Alexandria, Va. 

The institute is one of the largest opponents of a California bill that seeks to give homeowners more time when faced with association foreclosure. 

The best to you and yours, 
Bob, 
Ocala, FL 
Public Relations - CCFJ, Inc., 
 <http://www.ccfj.net/> http://www.ccfj.net/

-----Original Message-----
From: Berger, Wendy [mailto:Wendy.Berger@MyFlorida.com]
Sent: Friday, May 24, 2002 10:39 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: Canady, Charles T.
Subject: RE: Special request fup


Governor, I checked with the prison. Since Mr. Oliveros will not be eligible
for release until 2007, they will not allow a furlough for his son's
graduation.  If he had a terminally ill family member, they might be able to
make an exception, but this is not the case.  The federal system  allows 5
day furloughs for inmates with 12 months or less remaining on their
sentence.  As such, Mr. Oliveros does not qualify.  I called Mrs. Krutulis
and let her know. I also provided her with the phone number and name of the
Associate Warden at the prison.  Warden Stevens indicated she would be happy
to explain the policy to Mrs. Krutulis.  Wendy

Hello Governor Bush

   I sure hope that you do not ever get tired of hearing from me. I felt the 
email attachment as many others is very important. This pre-adoptive parent 
has had Temeka since Dec 2001 and has received no foster care or as the 
parent states they have not received any financial help from anyone, not 
even one cent. This child is in a foster care status at this time. Could the 
agency be holding up funds because the family has made a special needs 
subsidy request? That certainly wouldn't be fair to the child, if this is 
the case or not. It appears to me, that the state is making exceptions all 
over regarding adoption subsidies depending on the county the child resides 
in. Some counties are giving a little extra yet other counties are saying 
there is no funding to give a special rate. It appears that Florida's 
children are suffering from lack of funds and services. I get a great number 
of emails from people who have adopted Florida's special needs children 
without any subsidy/medicaid at all. These families contact me at a later 
date once they have found out their child was entitled to an adoption 
subsidy. I thought that is what the Federal Subsidy Program was designed 
for. I have been asking questions regarding the subsidy, medicaid and large 
foster care rates that adoptive parents have had to pay but other than Carol 
answering some of my questions no one is giving me answers I need. If you 
can help I would greatly appreciate it as I am unsure how to respond to 
adoptive/foster parents at times. Also if you ever come our way again, I 
would love to meet with you to express my gratitude on the adoption issues, 
as well a the medical school (it was fianlly closed down) and also I would 
like to become more educated on the adoption issues in the state of Florida.

Subject: FW: Medicaid Related Expenditure Report April 2002.xls


Highlights of the April Medicaid Expenditure Report:

We are using a new format for the report and are including information from
DOH, DOEA, and DCF on each department's Medicaid-related budget.

The Projected Medicaid deficit for FY2001-02 as of April is $18.7 million-
$3.4 million less than projected last month. Nursing home care and hospital
outpatient services cost were lower compared to last month's projections.
These line items are highlighted on this report.

Sent from my BlackBerry Wireless Handheld (www.BlackBerry.net)

($18,715,221)	 ($3,475,428)	
 	  	  	  	  	  	
(1)   Fiscal year state portion of total budget as amended through the LBC
process.	
			
(2)  State portion (GR and GR-related) of estimated fiscal year expenditures
based on spending through April  2002 and estimated spending for the
remaining months in the fiscal year.	
			
(3)  State portion (GR and GR-related) of estimated fiscal year expenditures
based on spending through March  2002 and estimated spending for the
remaining months in the fiscal year.	
			
(4)  Estimated state portion of surplus/deficit estimate.  For example,
through April 2002 the GR-related Medicaid deficit is estimated at $18.7
million.

>- Sharing in the Local Option Sales Tax

>- Established seven charter schools
>- Using all effort index dollars
>- Using all classroom 1st dollars
