-----Original Message-----
From: Sally Feehrer [mailto:feehrers@mail.oakridge.leon.k12.fl.us]
Sent: Friday, May 24, 2002 3:58 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Why not?


Dear Jeb-
	Since McBride brought up the idea of using a tax on cigarettes to
better fund education, I'd like to add the idea of taxing liquor and
alcoholic beverages 50 cents more, too.  I know you were against more
taxes, but you also said you are for education.  These two products often
have a negative effect on our innocent children.  As teachers we encounter
these effects often, and have an even more difficult job educating children
whose lives are disrupted by alcohol abuse, or who suffer from
alcohol-fetal syndrome and have learning disabilities.  We have had a huge
increase in asthmatic children who miss many days of school and often do
not have the money or resources to get the medical care they need.  Often
the asthma is related to the smoking in their household.
	My class size increased last year, from 14 to 21.  They said next
year it may go up again.  Why are we shortchanging our future generation?
If you really want to see us improve what we are doing, we need a higher
ratio of adults to students.  We need after school tutoring that doesn't
depend on grant funding or the generosity of more donated "teacher time".
We are striving mightily to improve-there is so much to be done!!  We work
untold numbers of unpaid hours documenting children's needs, doing
fund-raisers, conferencing with parents and doing home visits, planning and
learning new strategies, attending school sponsored events after hours and
on weekends.  We need facilities improved and portables removed in many
schools.  Please give these taxes a second thought and think of them as an
investment in our future.
	Yours truly,
	Sally Feehrer

>  -----Original Message-----
> From: 	Boxold, Jim  
> Sent:	Thursday, May 23, 2002 11:17 AM
> To:	Castille, Colleen; Munson, Greg
> Cc:	Leighty, Barbara; Tinker, Teresa
> Subject:	Jacksonville v. Property Appraiser
> 
> Following our discussion earlier, I called Revenue for a timeline of
> events.  Spoke with Darrell Smith and Kathy Collins (488-5009).
Bottom
> line is that the Property Appraiser signed the contract for the system
> before he requested funding in the budget.
> 
> 
> 
> May 16, 2001 -- Property Appraiser's Office signs contract with vendor
for
> new computer system.  Does not have budget authority for the system.
> 
> June 1, 2001 -- Property Appraiser provides his entire budget
submission
> to Department of Revenue, which includes funding request for the
computer.
> 
> July 10, 2001 -- Revenue gives preliminary approval to the budget
request,
> including the computer system.  After this approval, the City of
> Jacksonville contacts the Department with its concerns.
> 
> August 15, 2001 -- Revenue issues the final approved budget.  Places
> funding for computer system in a reserve account, pending resolution
of
> concerns about the computer item.  The Property Appraiser's Office
would
> have to do a budget amendment to secure release of the funds.  Revenue
> subsenquently informs the Property Appraiser's Office that the
contract
> does not meet minimum standards.
> 
> September 10, 2001 -- Property Appraiser signs new contract with
vendor,
> which meets minimum standards.
> 
> May 15, 2002 -- Revenue sends a letter to the Property Appraiser
> indicating that the agency's concerns about the computer system have
been
> resolved.

-----Original Message-----
From: Shane Hill [mailto:shill002@tampabay.rr.com]
Sent: Friday, May 24, 2002 10:27 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Graduation


Mr.Bush    
   I am the student whom wrote you last July and you helped me find a school thank you again. I wanted to share with you my letter I had to write on " who inspired me to get where I am today" here is what I wrote. I graduate on may 29 your presence would be wonderful!
    

                                                                                 May 21, 2002                                                                                                                         

                                                                                              

 

I would have never made it through High School if it was not for the help and support from the Governor of Florida. When I realized that I had made a bad decision with dropping out of High School and moving out on my own. With working forty hours getting no where in my life living pay check to pay check. I knew at that time in my life that I needed to go back to school to get my education. I had contacted the Governor by e-mail explaining my situation. Within twenty four hours I had been contacted by the head of Pinellas county schools and I had a follow up letter from the Governor. He sent me emails through out the year asking how I was doing and encouraging me to further my education.

 If it was not for the inspiration I received from Governor Jeb Bush. I would not be where I am today.

 

  

Shane B. Hill

-----Original Message-----
From: Secretary Moore [mailto:secretary@mail.dc.state.fl.us]
Sent: Friday, May 24, 2002 10:58 AM
To: 'debandken@peoplepc.com'; 'jscarborough@levinlaw.com'
Subject: Michelle T. Bolin #P05007


Governor Bush has asked that I respond to your letter regarding your
daughter, Michelle T. Bolin.  

The following information is provided addressing each of the concerns
raised
regarding the care of your daughter, 
Michelle
Bolin.

1.	There was a problem once with her catheter wherein the bag was
not
completely clamped off.  This was rectified immediately.  The nurse that
consistently takes care of Inmate Bolin says that she has never once
laid in
urine and if there were any problem with the catheter, she would have it
rectified immediately.

2.	Inmate Bolin's dressings are changed twice daily by staff that
are
extremely conscientious regarding the use of universal precautions due
to
the high number of patients with communicable diseases.  We have found
no
evidence of packing being left in her wounds.  The lack of infection in
the
wounds is evidence that the dressings are being changed properly.  

3.	An appointment was made to evaluate her for possible surgical
repair
of the ulcer, however, it was decided that it required healing from the
inside out due to the size of the ulcer.  These ulcers develop because
of
the pressure caused by sitting or lying.  She has been instructed to
move
frequently from side to side and to avoid sitting for extended periods
of
time.  Inmate Bolin has been offered an overlay mattress and inflatable
wheelchair cushions to assist in the prevention of these ulcers.  Inmate
Bolin has good upper body strength and can move with minimal assistance,
however, she refuses to change position often for hours at a time and
has
refused the use of the overlay mattress.  The staff have made repeated
attempts to establish patient compliance with this issue to no avail.

While at NFRC, she was also evaluated for repair of an alleged bone
infection, but it was determined there was none to be repaired.
Therefore
the surgery was cancelled.  However, she is in no way about to "die from
lack of care".  The referenced "hole in the intestines" is due to the
colostomy site.

4.	Appointments with the doctors have been made regularly through
the
course of the year with the first appointment being scheduled on
February
20, 2002.  A follow-up appointment was scheduled for a month later,
however,
Michelle refused to attend.  Her appointment was rescheduled for two
weeks
later but had to be moved to a later date as the doctor was not in the
clinic that day.  The April 10, 2002 appointment was kept while she was
in
the hospital.

5.	Inmate Bolin's wheelchair was left at Lowell CI to be repaired,
which has occurred.  In the interim, she has been provided with a ROHO
cushion, which is air inflated to prevent pressure sores.  We have no
indication that a grievance had to be filed to initiate the repairs.

6.	The DOC does has 5 female facilities in Florida.  The only
female
institution in North Florida is Gadsden C.I., and it is not rated for
her
medical needs.  Lowell CI is rated for her security level and medical
needs
and has been determined by our Classification Office to be the most
suitable
location for her at this time.  In addition, due to her disciplinary
history, she is not eligible to request a transfer closer to home.  

The Department has taken great care to address Inmate Bolin's medical
needs.
Her transfer to NFRC, the department's medical facility, is evidence of
that.  She is very much in control of her faculties and must take an
active
role in her personal care.  At times, she has chosen not to comply with
the
medical instructions given her, however, we can not force an inmate to
comply with the doctors directions.    

Please let me know if you need further information.

From:	LieutenantJack@aol.com
Sent:	Saturday, May 25, 2002 12:06 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Just Sayin' Hi and Thank you!

Dear Jeb:

I would guess that as a political figure, you get a lot of friendly emails requesting things from you.

This is not one of them.

I hope it means it's not destined for the trash can without reading but no, I have no real requests, and if I did, I'd generally keep it to myself because that's how I am.  I don't normally write to politicians (after the boilerplate form letters from Jim Davis the congresscritter (yes, I am a Freeper, no secret there), I don't bother.) but I felt that you are a special case and worthy of both support and praise.

But I have been a resident of this State for 12 years now.  I came in 1990 to get away from the abysmal political situation in Los Angeles to start a new life somewhere where laws made at least a little sense.  When people nit pick about this and that, I have learned to simply smile and enjoy the fact that they CAN nit pick about the little things, instead of "enjoying" a crime-ridden, corruption-ridden police state that the People's Republik of Kalifornia has become.

I was afraid of it happening here with Br'er Lawton at the wheel.  I'm sorry he died, but I never knew him personally and I think his politics sucked.

I want to thank you for fighting the good fight.  For standing up and taking it in the chops every time someone gets pissed off at what you do.  I do not envy you in the least, because I only have a minor inkling of the "damned if you do, damned if you don't" situation you must deal with every day.  And to have no time to yourself to be a human being (with cameras on you all the time, you can't even pick your nose without someone watching...how embarrassing!) that, I imagine can get pretty damn stressful.  I know it would drive me nuts.

So when you're having one of those frequent "Sucks to be me" days, I want you to remember that at least one little constituent in Tampa is not just rootin' for ya, but really does appreciate what you have done, and what you are trying to do.  I know that no matter how much good you do for education, someone will blame you.  No matter how hard you try to right the wrongs and injustices of government, someone will squall that they were cheated.  I know we can't win the societal pissing contest that politics is.  But someone has to stand up for the people and be our representative, our voice.  Not some self-appointed media talking head who thinks he knows best, but a man whom the population has ELECTED, for whatever reason (I know some pretty stupid reasons for voting for people...don't ask how), to be their voice.  You are our elected voice, and I think you're doing pretty darn good.  Not that my opinion matters a heck of a lot.  I don't make big claims to anybody.  I don't have lots of money to donate to causes.  I just live here.

Thank you, Jeb.  I'm glad you're my Governor.

Very Truly Yours,

Steven B. Cox
Tampa, FL

SAT. MAY 25, 2002

RE: ADAM GRATE MEDIATION IN POLK COUNTY

MR. STETLER,

   WHEN WE FIRST SPOKE ON THE PHONE YOU ASSURED ME THAT A MEDIATION MEETING 
COULD BE HELD AT A NEUTRAL SITE, A LIBRARY WAS AN EXAMPLE, AS I TOLD YOU 
THAT THE SCHOOL BOARD ON FLORAL AVE. IS "ENEMY TERRITORY". SO A NEW 
LOCATION, POSSIBLE THE MULBERRY LIBRARY, WILL NEED TO BE FOUND.  ALSO, ADAM 
MAY WELL BE IN THE HOSPITAL THIS WEEK FOR THE SURGERY TO REMOVE AND BIOPSY 
THE TUMOR IN HIS FACE. A MAY 31ST MEETING WILL HAVE TO BE RESCHEDULED TO THE 
FIRST FRIDAY THE SCHOOL DISTRICT CAN ATTEND. I AM SORRY FOR ANY 
INCONVENIENCE ADAMS CONDITION MAY CAUSE.

    ALSO, AS FAR AS WHO IS TO COME.  PAT BARNES, PRINCIPAL OF MULBERRY 
MIDDLE SCHOOL (MMS) DOES NOT NEED TO ATTEND AS ADAM WILL UNDER NO 
CIRCUMSTANCES ATTEND MULBERRY MIDDLE SCHOOL JUST FOR ONE OF MANY 
REASONS........ IT IS DETRIMENTAL TO HIS HEALTH. IF THE DISTRICT INSISTS SHE 
ATTEND THEN THE PRINCIPAL OF LAKELAND HIGHLANDS MIDDLE SCHOOL (LHMS), JOEL 
WHIDDON, MUST BE PRESENT TO TESTIFY TO THE LAYOUT OF LHMS.

   I WENT TO LHMS AND HAD NO OPPOSITION WHATSOEVER WHEN I TOOK PICTURES OF 
THE CLINIC. WHEN I WENT TO MMS (THE SCHOOL YEAR WAS OVER FOR STUDENTS BUT 
SCHOOL PERSONNEL WERE ON CAMPUS AND IT WAS OPEN AND KIDS WERE PLAYING ON THE 
GROUNDS) AND WAS TRYING TO TAKE PICTURES OF THE CLINIC AREA AND BATHROOM TO 
BRING TO THE MEDIATION MEETING FOR COMPARISON OF CAMPUS' FOR LRE, PAT 
BARNES, SAID I COULD NOT TAKE THE PICTURES I NEED. WHEN I WENT OUTSIDE TO 
TAKE PICTURES OF THE DISTANCE FROM THE MAIN CAMPUS OUT TO THE WING WHERE 
CHORUS IS HELD, PAT BARNES CAME OUT AND SAID I COULD NOT TAKE ANY PICTURES.  
I HAD ALREADY TAKEN CAMPUS PICTURES TO DEPICT THE OUTSIDE CAMPUS OF MMS VS 
INSIDE CAMPUS OF LHMS.  I NEED FOR YOU TO CONTACT SHERWIN HOLMES FOR HIM TO 
CONTACT MRS. BARNES TO STOP HER ABSURD DEFENSIVE BEHAVIOR.  I SEE NO 
REASONABLE REASON THAT VIDEO/PICTURES TO DEPICT THE DIFFERENCES IN CAMPUS' 
SHOULD NOT BE BROUGHT TO THE MEETING. PICTURES COULD ONLY MAKE THE MATTER 
MORE CLEAR FOR THE MEDIATOR. I ASSUME THAT THAT IS WHY MRS. BARNES OBJECTS 
BUT SHE MUST BE FAIR AND THINK OF WHAT IS IN THE BEST INTEREST OF THE 
STUDENT AND NOT FUNDING ISSUES.

   I HAVE ONE MORE QUESTION THEN I WILL CLOSE.  WILL PARTICIPANTS OF THIS 
MEETING ALL BE TOGETHER TO TALK ALL AT ONE TIME, OR CAN WE HAVE INDIVIDUAL 
COMMUNICATION BETWEEN MYSELF, THE MEDIATOR, AND ONE PERSON AT A TIME?

    THANKS FOR YOUR TIME AND HELP. I AM SO GLAD THAT PEOPLE LIKE YOU DO THIS 
TYPE OF INTERPLAY. IS IT NOT SORRY THAT SCHOOL DISTRICTS, STUDENTS, AND 
PARENTS NEED PEOPLE LIKE YOU TO DO THIS WORK?  IT IS SUCH A SHAME THAT ADAM 
MISSED A WHOLE SCHOOL YEAR BECAUSE I WAS TOLD THAT ADAM MUST BE ENROLLED IN 
A SCHOOL TO GET THIS MEDIATION AND IT WAS NOT UNTIL MARCH THAT SOMEONE ELSE 
IN THE DOE INFORMED ME THAT THAT WAS NOT THE CASE.  WE COULD HAVE DONE THIS 
MEDIATION BACK IN SEPT.2001 AND ADAM WOULD NOT BE IN A POSITION THAT HE MAY 
HAVE TO DO 6TH GRADE FOR THE THIRD YEAR. BUT THEN AGAIN, FROM OCT. 2001 
UNTIL FEB.2002, I HAD BEEN TOLD BY MR. RAY ELLIOTT THAT HE WAS SETTING UP AN 
"ARBITRATION" MEETING. IT WAS NOT UNTIL FEB. 26, 2002 THAT I WAS TOLD THAT 
THE SCHOOL DISTRICT HAD DECIDED NOT TO HAVE AN "ARBITRATION" MEETING MONTHS 
BEFORE. THAT WAS THE DAY THAT JOE ADAMS, THE SUPERVISOR FOR POLK COUNTY 
SCHOOL DISTRICT STUDENT SERVICES AND THE SUPERVISOR OF RAY ELLIOTT, TOLD ME 
IN DUSTY PAYNES, THE ASST. SUPERINTENDENT OF POLK COUNTY SCHOOL DISTRICT, 
"CYNDI, YOU HAVE BUT ONE OPTION AND THAT IS TO HAVE ADAM ENROLLED BACK AT 
MMS, AND MMS IS YOUR ONLY OPTION OF SCHOOLS, OR TOMORROW WE WILL FILE 
PAPERWORK TO PROSECUTE YOU". TRUST ME THAT IF I DID NOT FEAR THE LOSS OF MY 
SOLE INCOME TO SUPPORT MY SONS, GOVERNMENT ASSISTANCE, I WOULD HAVE LET THIS 
GO COURT AND OUT TO THE PUBLIC.  ALL THIS AND WE COULD HAVE HAD MEDIATION 
BACK IN SEPT. 2001.

   LOOK FORWARD TO HEARING FROM YOU.

CYNDII GRATE
POLK COUNTY
DISTRICT 14

-----Original Message-----
From: Arthur E. Rose [mailto:artrose17@yahoo.com]
Sent: Friday, May 24, 2002 6:15 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: FCAT Suggestion


Hi, Jeb:

I have a suggestion that I would like you to seriously
think about.  The FCAT is given too early.  The kids
now have the idea that once they've taken the test,
school ends for the year.  I have spoke to a lot of
educators about this and they feel the same way.

Suggestion:  Give the FCAT the end of May (perhaps the
3rd week in May).  Scores will be sent to schools the
middle of August.  Students will find out their grade
placement only a week or two before school begins. 
Schools will receive their grades the latter part of
August.  We really have to do something about this.

Thanks for listening and enjoy your weekend.  -Art

Sir, 
your reply only serves to show me how incomplete your investigations are and,
how incompetent your agency really is.

My letter to Jeb stated that we feel that your agency the DPR is trying to completely white wash this issue and that it would soon be exposed by the national media.

Additionally,
I truly believe that the Governor should stop forwarding my letters back to the DPR for a reply 
and take some immediate action in this matter.

Here's why,
for the record over the past year and a half  42 victims plus have come forward having filed complaints with the Tampa Police Department the DPR, Hillsborough consumer protection agency and with the (AG) Attorney Generals offices.
Each passing day this list of victims only grows longer.

Fact 1
Both the (AG) and the consumer protection agency have referred all of them back to the DPR because of the jurisdiction issues that I referenced in my first letter. 
.

Fact 2 
The DPR has known about these scams for over two years and it has failed to take any action what so ever
to protect the consumers or Florida citizens / tax payers from this fraud. 

The Point,
The show goes on!

Fact 3
we're talking about 20,000 dollars or more a week taken in by the use of fraud in this scam and once again we have documented that the DPR has failed to act to protect the interest of the (public) consumers or, the interest of the State of Florida's tax payers. 

The Point,
 The DPR is covering up for it's incompetence or,
it's an accomplice in allowing this scam to continue and that's called corruption.
We're all being ripped off via a DPR issued license to steal!!!   

Additionally, before you clear the DPR of any wrong doing you should review all the past correspondence  from the DPR that we have gathered over the last two years as contained within my records because it will not only shock you but it will effectively serve to take down the agency so don't patronize me while you  to further attempt to continue this cover up.

Furthermore, in a confidential letter to us the DPR suggested that we file a civil case because they were powerless to close down these offending agencies or to get any refunds for the victims of one of this states largest scams.   

Fact 4
The total dollar losses here are much bigger then in the Miss. Cleo case......................

Within letters, and email the DPR has admitted that they are unable to enforce the laws of this state. 
The DPR left a paper trail that the media has followed.
My creditability was never in question.
Please rest assured that I wouldn't make these serious allegations unless,
I had the evidence to fully back up my charges. 

If you had (really cared) to properly research this matter you should have contacted us because,
obviously your only getting the covered up version of the (lack of facts) from the DPR.

Additionally,
 on that note you should have called the investigator from the consumer protection agency that made these (off the record statements) to me and you should talk to the investigators at the Florida Attorney Generals office that have also referred directly to this matter before you deny that this was ever the case. 
I also have several letters from the Attorney Generals office regarding this very matter. 
Please note that other law enforcement agencies have stated to us that they stand ready to help these victims and the DPR with this matter if the DPR cares to do it's job of enforcing the State statues that they have been charged with enforcing. 


Fact 5
Your agency is charged with enforcing the State Statutes and you haven't done your job in the last two years and these victims would have lost their rights under the statute of limitations to get any refunds. 

(a) Did you notice the States Attorney's offices of any of these crimes? 
(b) Did you bring any action to shut down these scams or to collect any restitution for the victims? 
(c) Did you notice the state IRS about unreported revenue and unreported sales taxes?

                                                             I rest my case.


But mark my words,
The media will act to take down the incompetent head of the DPR and all of her like flunkies.

I truly wish for state hearings on this matter because as we all know that you can't have the fox guarding the chicken coop. 


Sincerely, 
Mr. Rick West      

............................................................................................................................................................................

Dear Mr. West: 

Governor Jeb Bush has provided the Department of Business and Professional Regulation your most recent correspondence regarding a complaint involving a talent agency in Hillsborough County. I would like to address some of your e-mail to the best extent possible. 

Upon receiving your e-mail, I personally contacted the department's general counsel, the director for the Division of Professions, the current and former prosecuting attorneys for talent agents and the lead investigator in charge for the Division of Regulation in Hillsborough County. I do understand you may have spoken to some of these individuals about the case, nevertheless, it was my objective to be confident all possible means and resources were being used to resolve your complaint in an expeditious manner. It is important to note that any pending investigation is prohibited from public disclosure until 10 days after probable cause has been found and an administrative complaint is filed by the Department. Unless those events have occurred, it would be unlawful for me to discuss the details of that complaint. 

From my research, I have found no evidence that anyone in the Department has hindered or obstructed the efforts of any law enforcement officials in Hillsborough County. As a matter of course, information collected by our investigators is immediately forwarded to the appropriate local authorities if criminal wrong-doing may be involved. 

As you may know, as a matter of effective prosecution, it is the department's view that if there is a pending civil case against a licensee, it is often better to wait for the outcome of that case and then pursue an administrative complaint rather than initiate a complaint during that process. This is because a civil judgment may often be used to establish an additional violation.

Finally, I truly believe that the department has properly marshaled its resources to investigate your case and others similar to yours in the most effective manner. We certainly appreciate and value the information you have and continue to provide as it continually improves our ability to pursue potential improper licensed activity. In the near future, I am confident you will be satisfied with the effort put forth by our investigative and legal team. 

If you have additional concerns, please contact our head prosecution attorney for professional licensees, Gail Scott-Hill at (850) 922-0907. 

Thank you for your support and understanding. 

 
Geoffrey Becker
Deputy Secretary
Florida Department of Business & Professional Regulation
725 South Bronough Street
Tallahassee, Florida 32303
OFFICE:  (850) 921-7271
FAX:         (850) 921-4094
CELL:       (850) 443-8801

Please note: Florida has a very broad public records law.
Most written communications to or from state officials
regarding state business are public records available to the
public and media upon request.   Your e-mail communications
may therefore be subject to public disclosure.

-----------------------------------------------------------------
Jennifer Sergent: Congress may spend $100 million to promote tourism despite industry's 'road to recovery'
-----------------------------------------------------------------
(5/25/02 Naples Daily News)
-----------------------------------------------------------------
WASHINGTON — Amid reports that the travel industry is "on the road to recovery," Congress is still considering legislation to spend $100 million to help states promote tourism. 

Three-quarters of Americans said the 9/11 attacks wouldn't dampen their summer travel plans, according to an AP poll released Thursday. And the Travel Industry Association of America is forecasting an increase in travel for this summer season. Florida tops all other states on vacationers' destinations, the group said. 

Florida Republican Mark Foley, co-chair of the Congressional Travel and Tourism Caucus, testified Thursday that the travel industry is "hemorrhaging" and in desperate need of a federal kick-start. 

The need doesn't seem to be as desperate in Florida, however. Using a combination of state and private funds, the state's tourism corporation will complete a $76 million advertising campaign next month that started in early October. 

In years before the terrorist attacks, the Visit Florida corporation would spend "maybe $25 million" in a year, spokesman Tom Flanigan said. 

"This has been an absolutely monumental effort without precedent," Flanigan said. 

The state recorded a 19 percent decrease in visitors during the fourth quarter of last year, the first decrease ever in a 10-year span during which tourist numbers increased each year between 5 and 8 percent. 

The first quarter of this year wasn't as bad. The decrease in visitors was just 4.5 percent from the same time last year. 

"We're still not on par yet," Flanigan said, but the numbers were "a vast improvement" over last year's fourth quarter. 

Other promising indications for Florida tourism include record numbers of auto traffic into the state, based on the numbers of tourists coming into the state's highway visitor centers, Flanigan said. Those numbers are 8 percent ahead of last year. 

"I would suspect that we're doing better than most other U.S. destinations," he said. "Our pace of recovery is better than the norm." 

************** 

IT'S NOT EVERY DAY that a U.S. senator climbs up on the couch to greet a constituent. 

But Sen. Bill Nelson, who is 5-foot-10 1/2, found it necessary to do that Thursday when he was asked to pose for a picture with 6-foot-10 Miami Heat center Alonzo Mourning. 

Height jokes aside, and once they were both properly seated in chairs, the conversations shifted to children's issues, the focus of Mourning's extensive charity work. 

Mourning was in Washington to lobby for $1 million in federal funding for a youth center in the Overtown section of Miami. Mourning wants the center to be a model for future endeavors across the state and nation, because it would target and monitor at-risk youth and families. 

Only one in 12 students in Overtown graduate from high school, Mourning said, adding that "people have ignored it for too long." 

That's where Congress comes in, he said. 

"We've tap-danced for some private dollars," he said, "but it's going to come down to: we need some government money." 

"This isn't a YMCA," Mourning said, chortling at the notion. "We've got plenty of those." 

This center would pick up where the state case workers leave off — or never appear, for that matter. Employees will keep track of the kids and their families, serve as role models, and help them stay in school and on the right track. 

"We're going to try to get everyone involved in the development of these kids," Mourning said. 

Nelson set up a conference call with Mourning's congresswoman, Rep. Carrie Meek, D-Miami. Meek admonished her Senate colleague to request the million dollars for the 2003 budget of the Department of Housing and Urban Development. 

" 'Zo has to have this right away," Meek told Nelson. "You pledge to get the money he needs." 

"You know the watchword over here," Nelson said to Meek. "Whatever Carrie wants, Carrie gets." 

But in a year when budgets will be tight and the government is running a deficit, Nelson and Meek face an order taller than even Alonzo Mourning. 



Jennifer Sergent is the Washington correspondent for the Daily News. Computer users may write to her at sergentj@shns.com, or at the Naples Daily News, P.O. Box 7009, Naples, Fl., 34101.

Subject: Mine to grow near pristine river. St. Petersburg Times 5/25/02


Mine to grow near pristine river
State environmental concerns won't halt mine, but push back cement plant
opening.
By JULIE HAUSERMAN, Times Staff Writer
C St. Petersburg Times
published May 25, 2002

BRANFORD -- Four years after Gov. Jeb Bush canoed the aqua-blue
Ichetucknee River and vowed to protect it, his administration is about
to permit a nearby limestone mine to grow by eight times despite ongoing
environmental violations.

The mine is part of the Suwannee American Cement plant near Ichetucknee
State Park, a controversial project that Bush and the Department of
Environmental Protection denied in 1999 but approved a year later after
the company sued.

The state permit will allow the mine to grow from 100 acres to 800 and
operate for 100 years.

Permitting the mine expansion is so politically sensitive that Bush and
David Struhs, secretary of the DEP, abruptly slapped new restrictions on
the cement plant after the St. Petersburg Times began asking questions.

Bush initially said he was unaware of the mine expansion, although the
DEP has been reviewing the permit for two years. After a briefing, he
and Struhs decided to permit the mine but bar the cement plant from
opening for two years. The plant was supposed to open late this year.

Delaying the plant opening allows the state to "turn the mining story
into the object lesson you want it to be," Struhs said Bush told him.

The lesson: The state's hands are tied by weak laws.

In March, DEP inspectors discovered that air quality monitors at the
cement plant construction site hadn't worked for months. The monitors
were supposed to measure background air quality before the plant opened.
The company paid a $16,000 fine.

That violation will delay the plant's operating permit, Struhs said.

The company expressed surprise at the decision and said it had been
working with the state on the problem. "We've gotten the problem
solved," said Jim McLelland, spokesman for Anderson Columbia, Suwannee
American's parent company.

But it's not the only violation, records show:

In August 2001, sinkholes opened under a stormwater pond on the plant
property. The company alerted DEP and hired an engineer, who found a
pond was dug 2 feet deeper than the state permit allowed. More sinkholes
could form, the engineer said, creating a "natural pathway for
unfiltered surface water to mix with groundwater." The company filled
the new sinkholes with concrete, but the engineer noted: "The potential
for future collapse . . . will continue to be a factor." The DEP didn't
fine the company.

Suwannee American has a small cement plant at the construction site to
make material to build the new plant. In February, state inspectors
discovered that equipment to catch pollution from the small plant had
blown off. The company paid a $4,000 fine.

The company has had other violations in the Panhandle. In February 2001,
the DEP fined Anderson Columbia $178,000 for pollution at a construction
project on Highway 98 in Santa Rosa County. The company is challenging
the fine.

On Wednesday, the company agreed to pay $3,250 for pollution from road
work on Interstate 10 in Escambia County.

Four years ago, Struhs and Bush said a company's environmental record
should be considered when it applies for a permit. Struhs said road
builder Anderson Columbia had such a bad environmental record that it
was too risky to allow the cement plant in a water-rich part of Florida.


"Air quality permits will not be issued to demonstrated high-risk
applicants in high-risk areas at this DEP," Struhs wrote in a memo.

Struhs later said the DEP was on shaky legal ground because loopholes in
state law make it hard for the DEP to deny permits based on a company's
record. Facing a lawsuit, the DEP reversed itself and issued the permit.


During secret negotiations, the DEP extracted concessions from the
company, including an agreement to sell another mine the company owned
in Columbia County to taxpayers for $23-million to protect the
Ichetucknee headwaters.

But that mine is 21/2 times smaller than the one the company now wants
to build. The company quietly applied for a permit for the bigger mine
in October 2000, four months after it got the cement plant permit.

On Thursday, Struhs told the St. Petersburg Times that he and Bush had
reviewed the company's record and decided to delay the cement plant's
operating permit. They planned to act next month but accelerated the
decision because of the newspaper's inquiries.

"What really drove our decision was not wanting to have our issuance of
the mining permit misperceived as overlooking what our obvious and
well-known compliance problems are with this company," Struhs said.

On May 1, the state published a legal notice about its intention to let
the mine expand in the twice-weekly Suwannee Democrat in Live Oak. The
time for public comment expired this week.

A few local environmentalists knew about the bigger mine, but didn't
mount much opposition.

For one thing, their fight against the cement plant had been frustrating
and bitter. At one point, protesters chained themselves together outside
the governor's office. Florida Attorney General Bob Butterworth
intervened on behalf of the citizens, and lost.

The citizens who filed suit against the cement plant were shunned in
Suwannee County, where leaders wanted the 100 jobs and property taxes
the plant would provide. After the citizens lost, Suwannee American sued
the citizens to make them pay the company's legal bills. A judge
refused.

"We tried to find a way to challenge it, but the mining regulations in
the state are extremely lax," said Kathy Cantwell, chairwoman of the
Suwannee-St. John's chapter of the Sierra Club.

Struhs agrees. "We cannot legally deny the permit to expand the mine,"
he said. "We've got to change the laws."

This year, Struhs lobbied legislators to make environmental history
count when a company applies for a permit, but the bill didn't go
anywhere. Bush didn't publicly push for the law, as he did with other
legislation.

In Suwannee County, neighbors worry that the giant mine will threaten
underground water. Heavy equipment will tear limestone out of the earth
near the Ichetucknee, Santa Fe and Suwannee rivers -- all ranked as
Outstanding Florida Waters. Ichetucknee Springs State Park draws 200,000
visitors a year. The DEP's mining bureau says the mine "is not
perceived" as a threat to the park.

Groundwater beneath the mine flows toward the Santa Fe River, not the
Ichetucknee, state scientists say. The Santa Fe connects with the
Suwannee and flows underground for part of its length. The state is just
starting to study how water moves in the area. The mine will be 2 miles
from the Santa Fe at its closest point.

"Will the mine affect the flow of groundwater? Absolutely," Struhs said.
"Will it contaminate the groundwater? That depends on how you define
contamination."

The permit says if the company punches through limestone, workers will
stop, report it and plug the hole.

"When they mine, they are going to break through these caverns," said
Svenn Lindskold, president of Save Our Suwannee, an environmental group.
"When a dragline that's working below the surface breaks through, who is
going to know? Who is going to call? How are they going to plug it?"

On an empty stretch of U.S. 27 near Branford, the cement plant's giant
smokestacks are rising above the treeline.

"It's going to be the big landmark in the area," said Clarence McNamee,
a nearby resident who challenged the plant.

The plant will burn coal and tires and release about 3,100 tons of
pollutants every year, including 97 pounds of mercury, which
environmentalists say could taint fish in the three nearby rivers. The
DEP says the plant will have more pollution controls than any other
cement plant in Florida.

Among those who tried to stop the plant, there's bitterness about
allowing heavy industry in one of Florida's finest places.

The DEP issued the cement plant permit in secret negotiations with the
company, prompting charges of back-room dealing. The company's chief
negotiator was Steve MacNamara, a top aide to then-Florida House Speaker
John Thrasher. DEP staffers later complained that they thought MacNamara
was representing Thrasher, and didn't know he was also on Anderson
Columbia's payroll. The state Ethics Commission found probable cause
that MacNamara violated ethics laws. He is appealing.

Anderson Columbia has figured in several political scandals. At one
point, it had two lawmakers on its payroll, former House Speaker Bolley
"Bo" Johnson and former Lake City Rep. Randy Mackey. Both were convicted
of tax fraud for failing to report Anderson Columbia payments. Johnson
served time in federal prison and Mackey is free while he appeals.

"This was a highly political case," said Patrice Boyes, a Gainesville
lawyer who represented plant opponents. "It's kind of hard for citizens
to combat that kind of pressure. The speaker of the House's aide was on
the company's payroll. It leaves one with a bitter taste of cynicism."

From:	Sandra Darling <jtsd@bellsouth.net>
Sent:	Sunday, May 26, 2002 9:12 AM
To:	crnavoices-post-tango@topica.com; CRNAalert-post-tango@topica.com
Cc:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Board of Medicine Surgical Care Committee Meeting

I am passing this letter along to everyone from a CRNA who attended the Board of Medicine's Surgical Care Committee meeting in Tampa yesterday.  It is sad that the anesthesiologists have taken over our practices and we didn't even get the privilege of selling our individual practices since they just walked in and took them from us.  I know that the anesthesiologists who have taken over my offices, which I spent 21 years building the group, don't even know the proper techniques of inserting LMAs or just feeling comfortable in the office setting.  I believe it will only be a matter of time before the deaths begin happening again.  I have heard that there have already been a few hospital admissions.  There were no problems after the safety rules went into effect from CRNAs.  After all, we are the ones who administer the anesthesia and they usually just watch us work.  I am leaving the State on July 1, 2002 to work in New Hamphsire and will continue to monitor Florida from my computer.  I wish everyone the best and hope that something can happen legislatively to stop an unelected board from destroying health care in Florida.  If I were the Governor I would change the appointed members of the BOM and ask the leadership in the House & Senate to "fix" the law so the power of the BOM did not exceed the Legislature.  Take care and I will see you all at the FANA meeting. 
Sandra Darling 


>Dear Colleagues, 
>   
>I had the privilege of attending the meeting of the BOM surgical care committee meeting and hate to be the barer of bad news but the Committee voted 3 to 1 to leave things the way they are and not to reverse the anesthesia rule to the way it was prior to April 15th.  Four out of five committee members heard strong testimonies from our side and initially the vote was tide Dr.Gustavo and Dr. Kent were for reversing the rule and Dr Miguel (?) an anesthesiologist and Dr. Nigel (ER doctor) voted to leave things the way they are.  Dr. Tom Andrews an anesthesiologist with JLR medical and the newly elected president of the FSA argued that CRNAs were not ethical and did not have the best interest of the patient in mind if they thought they should be doing anesthesia without the supervision of an anesthesiologist. He also argued that until the BOM stopped CRNAs from doing Level 3 anesthesia patients were dying by the 100's in Florida. Another anesthesiologist from South Florida argued that even though things have improved and there have not been anymore deaths in the offices per se, that was not enough data to permit the committee to recommend that the ban on level 3 for CRNAs be lifted.  They kept arguing that the BOM n>eeded to wait until more data could be collected, however for that data to show that things have truly improved from what the BOM had done up to the point of April 15th CRNAs would need to be permitted to continue to do level 3 anesthesia in order to indeed show that the outcome would be the same. But no one addressed that issue in my opinion and skirted around it. 
>   
>The arguments were strong from our side but in the end MDs backup MDs in that Dr. Gustavo wanted the FAS and the FANA to set down and come to an agreement on indirect supervision of CRNAs in the offices by Anesthesiologist. His argument was that surgeons did not have the anesthesia expertise to supervise CRNAs even though our side said that surgeons would be required to complete 8 hours of Anesthesia training (pharmacology and difficult airway management) every two years. He further stated that he wanted CRNAs to do what they were trained to do (general anesthesia) yet admitting that he had little experience with working with CRNAs. He then changed his vote to leave things as they are and hope that Dr Tom Andrews could persuade the FSA to bang out an agreement with the FANA and maybe come to some agreement on indirect supervision. 
>   
>How indirect supervision is going to do anything beats the hell out me.  As bad as Tom Andrews hates CRNAs and wants to see them go away or become slave labor under the FSA , I don't see this happening.  I know him personally and if he had his way CRNAs would go away forever throughout the United States. He is a believer of MDA anesthesia only. 
>   
>I personally feel that FANA or Florida CRNAs in order to bring attention to this issue and get all the cards out on the table is to do something so drastic that it will hit the Governor, the legislature and the BOM squarely between the eyes and get their attention that "Huston We Have A Problem."  Sorrow but it is now 1:38 AM and I am getting punchy not to mention being mad as hell about the outcome. 
>   
>I WOULD PROPOSE THAT WE, ALL CRNAS IN FLORIDA HAVE A 24 HOUR SICK OUT THROUGH OUT THE ENTIRE STATE!  WE CAN THEN SHOW THEM THAT WITHOUT US ANESTHESIOLOGIST CANNOT PROVIDE THE SERVICES.  I think then the governor will be forced to take measures to end this.  At this point what do we have to lose. The next thing will be that we can't work at all without an anesthesiologist to supervise us. 
>   
>I am thinking very seriously about turning in my Florida license and moving to another state and chalk all this up to a learning experience.  We have played with kid gloves, we have danced around the truth but are afraid to say what the problem really is, money hungry anesthesiologist trying to increase their pocketbooks in a marketplace of decreased reimbursement and the only way they can do that is to take away our livelihood and control the CRNAs right to practice according to the laws of this state and it is all done under the disguise of PATIENT SAFETY. Once they have us unable to work anywhere without them our incomes will drop. They will decide what you will make per hour if you think that $42.00/hour (that is what Dr. Tom Andrews' group pays their CRNAs) no time and half for overtime just a straight $42.00/hour is low just wait, you will be making what you made as an ICU nurse.  If you don't believe me just let this happen and I will tell you "I TOLD YOU SO" 
>   
>Since, I spoke bluntly but truthfully before the BOM and in front of Dr. Andrews I am sure that my days of working in Florida or at least within 100 plus miles of home are numbered.  I say that because I contracted with his group and after the AA issue and my trip to speak with my Senator in Tallahassee my contract with that group was cancelled abruptly without cause. Here today gone tomorrow. It is a cut throat business. 
>   
>SO WHERE DO WE GO FROM HERE? 
>   
>Milton Taylor, CRNA, BS, BA 
>
>  
>
>
>
>
<<<<

From:	Patricia Strohmeier <pgstroh@earthlink.net>
Sent:	Sunday, May 26, 2002 10:51 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Osceola County Needs You


Dear Governor Bush:  Osceola is the largest growing County in Florida and is projected as such for 5 years.  I am a Principal's secretary and have been for 11 years.  I have seen this county go from a small town to a busy city.  The students ratio to teacher in our classrooms (4th grade) is 31 to 1.  We do not have the funding for smaller ratios.  Please take a look at Osceola County and understand that we need more money to help our students and relieve our teachers.  
 
We have been receiving the lowest amount per capita for school construction in the state for the last five years and we need new schools.  As soon as we build them, they are filled to capacity.
 
I appreciate anything that you can do for us.
 
Thank you,
 
Patricia A. Strohmeier
2624 Belmont Place
Kissimmee, Florida 34744

-----Original Message-----
From: Mary Ellen [mailto:meware@ij.net]
Sent: Thursday, May 23, 2002 12:00 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Provision 386 of the legislative budget


Carlton Manor is a community based group residential treatment program for
severely emotionally disturbed children. We currently have 16 children ages
7-15 in two therapeutic group homes of eight each, and 10  therapeutic
foster care placements. Our agency has been providing cost efficient,
therapeutically effective treatment to the residents of Pinellas County for
20 years. We offer intensive family therapy as part of our program, and
parents care for their children every weekend with the goal of teaching
parents ways to reduce the incidence of disturbed behavior and improve their
parenting skills. Our goal is to reinforce the child's membership in the
family and avoid out of home placement.

We have been funded through Sun coast Region ADM funds, matching funds from
the Juvenile Welfare Board and other resources. Provision 386 effectively
will close our facility  and our  children  will be left without services or
will require transfer to an institutional setting(SIPPS). A number of our
families are not Medicaid eligible and could  be placed in the position of
considering relinquishing their parental rights to the state to receive
treatment through the SIPPS program. Others will not qualify for SIPPS and
will be left only with home-based services which have already been proven
ineffective with these children.

In a Capitol ALERT from the Florida Council for Behavioral Healthcare DCF's
Sue Ross is quoted as saying that she and her staff will be meeting with
Family Safety staff to review options for developing residential treatment
settings and other services for children who do not meet SIPP criteria or
who are being discharged from SIPP.  We are already in place and provide
these exact services.  We have a proven track record. Why eliminate
programs, and then start over?
Please change the language in this provision and block the  transfer of  $16
million from the PRTS budget to the SIPP services, and the transfer of funds
from already sadly lacking children's services to forensic beds in jails.
Thank you for considering  a budget change....... For the children's sake.
Mary Ellen Ware LCSW Clinical Director, Carlton Manor

people so you gave them this email address in case
they needed further help.My situation is that I am in
kidney failure.I have what is formally known as End
Stage Renal Disease.Under the Medicare health plan
there is a paticular set of guidelines for this
disease.It states that after three months of continous
dialysis I am entitled to Medicare benifits.My start
date for dialysis was March 1,2002.Under these
guidelines my benifits should go into effect June
1,2002.This should be the case,however it is not.Mr.
Alexander from the Social Security office(863-683-0611
ext.226)has my case.Mr Alexander has been noncompliant
from the beginning.He does not return calls and never
seems to have an answer as to why so many problems
have occured in my recieving benifits.Anne at Adam

with us.She has had to call Mr. Alexander herself many
times to straighten out errors and oversights.Here is

before or on May 22,2002.The first I heard from him is
the call that I made to his office today.He says that
my benifits are not set up and that it is the
Baltimore office's fault.A month ago he assured Anne
that everything was in place.Now he is saying that my
benifits are not set up and that there is nothing he
can do.My medicaid coverage becomes only a supplement
as of June 1,2002.My life sustaining dialysis
treatment is $3000.00 per month not including the
medications , doctors appontments, and possible
hospital visits.On top of this, I need to have the
access in my arm fixed,which requires surgery,which no
one will do without Medicare.I have a port cath in my
chest that I recieve Dialysis through right now.This
cath is only good for six month,I've already had it
four.It also has to stay in another four weeks after
my arm is fixed so that my arm will heal.I also have
an appiontment with Lifelink for a workup for a
transplant on Tuesday,May 28,2002.They needed to see
the Medicare card to process me through and put me on
the list.If I do not get my dialysis treatment,I WILL
DIE.My father was laid off last week and we are
struggling to keep a roof on our head.I am twenty-two.
I am a college student. I am the typical girl next
door.All I want is what I am entitled to.I want to
live.I want to graduate college,I want to get a good
job and contribute to the American system.I am hoping
that you can help.I know that by you taking the time
to come down here to a relatively small city and
really listen to the people you must be a very
compassionate man.I plead with you to find it in your
heart to help me.Thank You.

-----Original Message-----
From: marioaj [mailto:marioaj@mail.dsli.com]
Sent: Thursday, May 23, 2002 11:54 AM
To: fl_governor@eog.state.fl.us
Cc: Hilda; Humberto Sanchez; Jan Bergemann; Robert Janauskas;
dreamangel5668@yahoo.co
Subject: I am pleading on behalf of a friend. We really need your help.



Dear Governor,

I am writing on behalf of a great number of citizens that are about to lose their homes in the Miami, Miramar area.  They are about to undergo foreclosure procedures from an unscrupulous Homeowner Association (HOA).  These citizens have been fighting for the last four years to protect themselves from a group of corrupt individuals that have been trying to steal their homes, their dreams, their hopes, all that they have worked for with so much sacrifice, and everything else the American Dream is all about. 

In this country, I have been able to realize many of my dreams, but I have also experienced first hand how it almost turned into a nightmare after buying my first home. A few months after buying my house, to my surprise, I began to be harassed by one of the two HOAs that my house belonged to, threatening to sue me for ridiculous and frivolous reasons.  To make a long story short, after realizing that I was not the only victim of their attacks, I was able to rally support from a great number of homeowners, and at the annual elections, for the first time since the HOA was formed in 1983, we got enough people interested to get a quorum and were able to throw out the tyrannical HOA, and put a brand new board.  In my efforts to rally support from my neighbors, I also became a member of the other HOA in my community, only to find out that one person (the president) controlled all the affairs of that board and had an unusually great interest in foreclosing on as many homes as possible.  I opposed him on foreclosing on 15 homes, just to become his worst enemy, to the point that I was almost jumped on the street by him and another individual (I opened a police report but he did not hit me, and I had no witnesses, so I could not press charges).  

Since then, I have learned of the widespread nature of this problem.  Homes are being foreclosed by unscrupulous HOAs at an alarming rate all over the USA, from California to Florida and everywhere in between, targeting low-income families, widows, and the elderly, especially if a home has a considerable amount of equity to maximize their ill-obtained gains when foreclosing on them.  These corrupt individuals, under the pretense that they are interested in the well being of homeowners, have especial interest groups lobbying at the federal and state level to make sure law is passed to protect their own interests, creating loopholes they can use to perpetuate their evil acts.  In my view, the most dangerous of these loopholes is the law that allows them to place liens and foreclose on someone’s home.  This loophole, and the fact that it is not currently required to have a jury decide on the validity of a foreclosure (as is actually mandated in the Seventh Amendment of our Constitution) makes it very easy for these heartless and corrupt individuals to abuse the system, and ultimately hurt many of us.  Despite all of this, I believe that there is hope because there are many ways to solve this problem, such as a porososed Mandated Property Reform Task Force.  I could share some more possible solutions with you, but it would make this letter way too long.  However, whenever you have some time, please check some of the possible solutions at: http://www.ccfj.net/Proprightscomm.htm, an organization of which I am a committee member. 

Finally, I would like to share with you what actually inspired me to write this letter.  A couple of days ago, I spoke with Tay, a homeowner that is about to lose her home, unless a miracle happens.  She is a single mother of six.  Her youngest, only six, has seen how sick she has gotten worrying over the possibility of not being able to provide a roof under their heads.  All that she has worked for all her life is just about to crumble right in front of her, but she keeps the faith and tries to cheer her children, assuring them that there is a God, that justice will prevail, and that somehow they will not lose their home.  In his innocence, her youngest asked her what the word justice meant.  She went on to explain the meaning of the word.  After she had finished, he told her that he wanted to leave this country because it did not have justice.  She has been crying since.  The day I spoke with her, she was very sick, and could barely speak.  When she told me what had happened, I felt very sad, and could hardly contain my tears.  I know how that kid felt.  I felt the same way when I was a kid seeing the injustices I lived in my native country, Nicaragua.  The USA, and what it stands for was my only hope, and it is the only hope for many kids around the world.  This hope seems to be vanishing before our own eyes.  My wife is about to have our first born, and now more than ever, I vow to fight the evildoers that are destroying and corrupting this country.  We must defend this country to keep alive the flames of hope and freedom that it represents.

I know how busy you must be, the many worries you must have, and I would like to thank you for taking the time to read my letter.  I would really appreciate your help on this matter.  I want to assure you that I am keeping you, your family, and especially your brother in my personal and family prayers.  May God bless you and our country.


Regards,

Mario Jimenez Jerez

-----Original Message-----
From: Victor Rose <vicr@adelphia.net>
To: Jeb Bush <jeb@jeb.org>
Sent: Mon May 13 18:03:18 2002
Subject: Tenure for teachers tranferring from one county to another

Dear Governor Bush:

I hope this finds you and your family do well.

Not so long ago, I heard that you were going to allow teachers from one
county to transfer to other counties in Florida, without losing any
tenure.   Has this been put into effect?

As you know, my fiancé Donna, teaches fourth grade in Broward County and
she would like to relocate closer to our home but Donna does not want to
lose of any of years.  Can you let me know the status of this issue?
Right now, Palm Beach will allow you to transfer 10 but Donna has been
teaching for 12 years.

Palm Beach County has their job fair this Friday and I would like to
receive a response to this specific question by Thursday.

Best regards,

Vic Rose

	-----Original Message----- 
	
	
	Bush vetoes DCF aid bill that allowed
	fundraising
	BY CAROL MARBIN MILLER
	
	As controversy continued over Gov. Jeb Bush's administration of the Department of Children & Families, the governor on Friday vetoed a bill, which passed the Legislature unanimously, designed to help social service
	administrators receive private donations.
	 
	The bill, introduced in the House by Rep. Kenneth A. Gottlieb, would have allowed the DCF to create a fundraising arm to solicit and accept contributions from companies and individuals. It passed the House and Senate without a single 'no' vote.
	 
	In a letter to Secretary of State Katherine Harris Friday, Bush said he rejected the bill because it was contrary to his core beliefs against big government.
	 
	''One of the most important goals of my administration is to reduce and streamline government in order to maximize services,'' Bush wrote. ``To achieve that goal I have emphasized the importance of partnering with communities and the private sector, and transforming our health and human service delivery system from one that is government-based to one that is community-based.
	 
	''Encouraging state agencies to reinforce themselves through the establishment of direct-service organizations expands and promotes government and therefore is counter to this goal,'' Bush wrote.
	 
	Gottlieb, a Miramar Democrat, was palpably upset by the veto.
	 
	''He doesn't give tax money [to social services], and now we can't even give voluntary money,'' he said. ``From the goodness of your heart, you can't even give a contribution.''
	 
	The veto comes at a time when the DCF is facing a firestorm of criticism following the disappearance of 5-year-old Rilya Wilson from state custody perhaps 16 months ago. The girl is still missing.
	 
	Gottlieb's bill would have created ''direct support organizations'' for the DCF and the Department of Elder Affairs. The not-for-profit groups would have had the ability to accept private money on behalf of the government agencies. Florida State University and the University of Florida have several such fundraising arms.
	 
	An analysis of the bill by the House Committee on Child & Family Security said the proposal had no apparent downside.
	 
	''The legislation creates a vehicle for receiving money to benefit each department and its programs and projects,'' the report stated. ``The provision allowing the corporation to raise funds to accomplish its purpose should be to the benefit of each department, which does not presently have
	such authority.''
	 
	Gottlieb said he was particularly concerned with the plight of Floridians who are disabled when he wrote the bill. About 9,000 disabled Floridians are on a waiting list for a variety of services, and the lawmaker had hoped the fundraising arm might help the DCF bring in new money to help them.
	 
	In recent weeks, however, Gottlieb was hoping Floridians would be moved to donate in order to help the state better care for foster children. ``If you read about Rilya Wilson, you might want to donate money to the program so that this doesn't happen again.''

los actos en que intervengo -ahora estoy muy de moda- y he traído a almorzar a
Alex Penelas, Raúl Martínez, Manny Díaz y otros, a las oficinas del Edificio de
los Leones, 550 Biltmore Way, Coral Gables, Piso 11. para que les expliquen las
actividades de la empresa.
Venevisión Internacional pertenece a la Organización Cisneros, es una coporación
norteamericana, distribuye filmes en español con títulos en inglés en EEUU, hace
presentaciones teatrales  y produce programas de televisión para Univisión los
que también vende en Latinoamérica, Europa y Asia, en un gran total de 102
países.
Luis Villanueva, Presidente de VV Internacional, me ha pedido que lo ayude a
saludarte; en una visita que hagas a Miami, o en un almuerzo en estas oficinas,
o en visita que hagamos a Tallahassee. Como Villanueva viaja bastante, en el
caso de tú acceder a esta solicitud- te agradeceríamos una anticipación de la
fecha.
Esta gestión no conlleva propósito alguno comercial, político o de cualquier
índole lucrativa.  Sólo el honor para Villanueva de conversar con alguien de tu
jerarquía y al que admira.

PUNTO Y APARTE

en tus visitas a Miami.

4 -Escrito y publicado el mayor número de artículos sobre W en la campaña
presidencial.
5- Merecido por esta campaña una carta manuscrita de W.
6- Peleado hasta con los puños para que el conteo de votos fuera justo.

Gracias por la atención que me prestes. El primer punto es mi trabajo y tu ayuda
me ayuda. El segundo es mi corazón.

-----Original Message-----
From: Jerry_Antine@fpl.com [mailto:Jerry_Antine@fpl.com]
Sent: Monday, May 06, 2002 4:23 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Mentally Challenged Son 


Dear Governor Bush,

Last year, my family and I moved to Florida for a better quality of life. I
met my wife in Orlando when I was stationed at McCoy AFB in 1962. The USAF
transferred us to other states during the Vietnam War and my 23 year
enlisted service.   We returned to Florida in 2001 after being gone for 38
years, 23 of those years in the USAF, 3 years attending college in New
Mexico, and 12 years of employment with MCI in California.  In October of
2000 Florida Power and Light  offered me a management position working in
their new start up company, FPL FiberNet with an office in West Palm Beach.

My wife and son arrived at West Palm Beach in May of 2001.  Since June of
2001 we have been working with the Department Of Children and Families. For
the past 10 months we have been trying to get funding for our 34-year-old
autistic son (Shannon Lee) so he can join a program to help him in
development and to help us with respite care. Shannon has no physical
impairments in mobility.  He loves to participate and be part of programs
during the day.  Before moving here from Southern California, we spoke with
the Department of Children and Families.  They assured us there would be
support and activities available for our son.  After our move we met with
the department agency here in West Palm Beach.  Our son was evaluated and
accepted as a client.  The shocking news that has since followed is hard
for us to accept.  We were told there is no funding and Shannon is on a
waiting list that may be as long as three years before he will be funded.

I observed your speech last week about your family issues.  I was
impressed.  My wife and I also display our feelings when we talk about our
son.  We are having a hard time seeing him sit at home every day with
nothing to do and no development program.  We are writing to you to see if
there is anything that can be done.  Your assistance would be appreciated.

Also, regardless of Shannon's issue, we believe you are the right person
for the job of Florida Governor.  You will have our support at the polls.

Sincerely,

Harry J. and Edith E. Antine
10442 Trailwood Circle
Jupiter, FL 33478
561-743-9908

To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Hispanic Conservative Coalition


Jeb,
Great seeing you this morning.  As I mentioned, I'm working on putting
together an educational/civic-oriented group designed to help Hispanics
better understand how through the application of conservative principles to
their lives, they can truly live the "American dream".  We've discussed
putting together meetings where a component of each will be to impart very
real and logistical application of concepts to empower people to live their
lives.  While is it non-partisan, the goal is to apply Republican principles
of self-sufficiency, hard work, education, etc., so that people do not
become hooked to the dependency formulas that are way too prevalent in our
society - esp. for minorities - formulas which prevent them from ever fully
accessing all that America has to offer.  Ultimately, we are also interested
in helping them identify leaders/politicians which support these principles.
While I'm not sure what the name may be, I'm leaning to the Hispanic
Conservative Coalition.

As I mentioned to you this morning, I'd like a letter from you supporting
the concept and encouraging the development of this organization.  Moreover,
if we could coordinate it, your agreement to attend the "coming out" press
session.  

Finally, thanks for your support, trust, and belief in principles that will
benefit all Americans.

Carlos J. Reyes, Esq.

-----Original Message-----
From: Richard Harrow [mailto:tss.crharrow@worldnet.att.net]
Sent: Sunday, May 26, 2002 2:16 PM
To: Jeb Bush; Jeb Bush
Subject: Florida Health Insurance 


Dear Governor Bush,

I heard that you recently signed a bill that would greatly raise the
Health Insurance premiums for the small business person. I was unaware
of this bill being considered so I was not able to express my views
earlier. 
I and my wife have a small, Manufacturers Representative, sales business
that I started in 1986. After the first couple of years, the business
grew to the level where I could employ 2 additional sales people.
However, several years ago, the cost of doing busines, mainly the costs
of Federal Taxes, S/S, Insurances and Health Insurance, got to the point
where I had to downsize and terminate these two salemen.  
Around that time, my Health Insurances Costs rose to a point where I
started to look for an alternate insurance plan. I am 60 years old and
have had a continuing health problem for the last 8 years which
precludes me from getting Individual Health Insurance coverage. My only
recourse is a small group, business policy, Insurance for myself plus my
wife as a dependent. Fortunately I found an agent, who makes very little
commision on such a policy, who came up with an insurance company and
policy that had a much reduced premium and provided the medical
coverages that I needed at an affordable cost. However, the cost of this
insurance has continued to increase every year since I started the
policy, having gone up 65% in the last 2 years alone and more than
doubling in the 4 years that I have had this Insurance Coverage. Now I
understand that I may be faced with another 50% or more premium
increase. How is a small business like mine suppose to survive when all
of my income is being used to pay my State and Federal Government
obligations and my Health Insurance? At the current rate of increses,
these costs will soon exceed my company's total income. I need to keep
my company going as a viable business so I can continue to get my
Medical Insurance coverage. I will not be able to qualify for medicare
or medicaid for another 6 years. Where are the funds to pay my
obligations and Health Insurance to come from for these next 6 years?

With the cost of all my insurance continually rising, I have always had
the impression that the State of Florida has caterred to the Insurance
Industry. I am sure that they provide significant amounts of funding for
political campaigns. 

Contrary to every politicians' Rhetoric, the Small Business Person has
received the BRUNT and Biggest Negative Impact of the changes in the
Federal and State Tax and Insurance Laws.  

I have been a loyal Republican Supporter on both the State and Federal
level for over 3 decades. Lately all I am seeing from Republican
Administrations is more personal abuse for the small business person. I
am seriously considering giving the Democrats a chance in the next State
elections and will be promoting this with my small business friends
throughout the state. 

Is it the Insurance Companies that are going to re-elected you as
Governor, or is it the people of this state that will be casting the
votes at election time? Unless something can be done with the burden
placed on independent business people by this insurance Fiasco, I for
one will be campaigning against your re-election. 

Sincerely,

C. Richard Harrow
President
Tech Sales Specialists, Inc.

From:	msilva@orlandosentinel.com
Sent:	Monday, May 27, 2002 9:41 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	In poll, Central Florida's Hispanics favor Gov. Bush

From: Mark Silva

Electoral Dynamics II

--------------------
In poll, Central Florida's Hispanics favor Gov. Bush 
--------------------

By Mark Silva
Sentinel Political Editor

May 27, 2002

TALLAHASSEE -- Gov. Jeb Bush holds an advantage over Democratic rivals among Hispanic voters in Central Florida, according to his campaign's polling of the region crucial to his re-election.

This could provide an important re-election base for Bush, who already enjoys overwhelming support among the Republican-rich Cuban-American community of South Florida.

Both state and national Republican parties are attempting to build that base, with political analysts reading gains for the GOP in the U.S. Justice Department's move to make polling places more accessible for Spanish-speaking voters in Orange and Osceola counties.

The Bush campaign's survey in the critical "Interstate 4 corridor" of Central Florida focused for the first time on Hispanics not of Cuban origin. The Democratic Party was more popular than the GOP among those surveyed, yet most thought Bush is "a different" kind of Republican.

"These voters are critical in a very swing area of the state," said Neil Newhouse, a Virginia-based Bush-campaign pollster. Bush "has a personal appeal among Hispanics that seems to overcome traditional partisan anchors. He seems to connect much better with these voters than the average Republican."

Bush's own popularity -- 60 percent of Hispanics surveyed approve of the job he is doing -- is one factor in his apparent lead among these voters.

Three-quarters of those surveyed were aware the governor speaks Spanish, Newhouse noted, and most knew his wife, Columba, is Mexican.

A widespread unfavorable view of his leading Democratic rival, former U.S. Attorney General Janet Reno, is another factor.

In addition, Reno's chief challenger among Democrats, Tampa-area attorney Bill McBride, remains largely unknown among Hispanics.

Democrats are counting on this fast-growing voting bloc to give their nominee an edge against Bush in November, the state party focusing much of its "outreach" to new voters this year on Hispanics.

"In the past, too many candidates have taken the community for granted," said Mo Elleithee, Reno campaign manager. "Janet is not only making an effort to reach out to them in her campaign, but also make it clear that they will have a role in her administration."

Race will 'tighten up'

Bush may have a name-brand appeal today, Democratic Party spokesman Ryan Banfill said, but as his candidates start debating issues, Hispanic voters will take notice: "When the campaign is engaged, and people are given a choice between what Gov. Bush has to offer and what our candidate has to offer, then this race will begin to tighten up."

Yet this bloc offers fertile ground for Florida's bilingual governor -- who voices his own appeals in Spanish-language TV ads -- his campaign counting on 12 percent to 14 percent of the vote coming from Hispanics, with Cuban-Americans accounting for just half.

In addition, the Republican National Committee and Bush administration in Washington have set out to claim a greater share of the nationwide Hispanic vote, which Democrats have long claimed.

The party is airing a monthly television show on Spanish-language stations in select markets, including Orlando. And now Justice is threatening both Orange and Osceola counties with lawsuits regarding their lack of assistance for Hispanic voters at polling places in 2000.

GOP makes Hispanic inroads

The president "has made improving his standing among Hispanic voters a priority," said Dario Moreno, a political scientist at Florida International University in Miami. While the Justice lawsuits may not be political, Moreno said, "The political effect is what's interesting."

Nationally, GOP efforts appear to be yielding results.

The New Democratic Network, an assembly of moderate congressmen, released a survey last week showing the president's approval among Hispanics has grown from 38 percent in November 2000 to 76 percent in May.

Democrat Al Gore carried nearly two-thirds of the Hispanic vote in 2000, but the Democratic survey by Coral Gables pollster Sergio Bendixen shows President Bush and Gore might split the vote in a match today.

Hispanics account for 11 percent of the fast-growing population in a swath of Central Florida ranging from Tampa Bay to Daytona Beach -- as much as 18 percent in Tampa's Hillsborough County, nearly 19 percent in Orange and 29 percent in Osceola.

These voters traditionally have given Democrats an edge on Election Day -- Gore carried Orange County in 2000, the first time a Democrat claimed Orange since Franklin Roosevelt.

"We're not approaching the state as a monolith," Newhouse said. "The population in the state is no longer just Cubans, but also Puerto Ricans and others. We decided to take a real good, hard look at the growing, non-Cuban Hispanic voter."

In its unprecedented, targeted survey of Hispanics in the Orlando and Tampa "media markets" -- counties along I-4 from Tampa to Daytona -- the governor's campaign found that the most likely voters identify themselves in threes: 31 percent Democratic, 29 percent Republican, 27 percent independent -- but the independents strongly lean Democratic.

Alexandria, Va.-based Public Opinion Strategies interviewed 400 likely voters April 17-21.

Among them, 61 percent were Puerto Rican, 12 percent of Mexican origin, 7 percent Colombian, 4 percent Dominican, 7 percent other South Americans, and 10 percent other Hispanics.

The results carry a possible margin of error of plus or minus 4.9 percentage points.

Education is top concern

The I-4 survey found:


- Education ranked as the No. 1 concern, as it did among all voters, with crime ranking second, the economy third.


- More Hispanics held a favorable impression of the Democratic Party -- 59 percent of those surveyed -- while 47 percent held a favorable impression of the Republican Party.


- Yet 71 percent held a favorable impression of Gov. Bush, 17 percent unfavorable, while 44 percent viewed Reno favorably, 32 percent unfavorably.


- McBride was largely unknown: 71 percent never had heard of him, while 12 percent had a favorable impression, 3 percent unfavorable.


- In a match-up of Bush against Reno: 51 percent supported Bush, 23 percent Reno, with the rest leaning toward one or undecided. In another match-up, Bush got 50 percent, McBride 18 percent.


- Most thought Bush is committed to improving education -- 69 percent. And many said he understands the needs of Central Florida's Hispanic community -- 60 percent.


- Asked whether Bush "is different from most Republicans when it comes to Latino/Hispanic issues," 57 percent said yes. Most -- 76 percent -- were aware that Bush speaks Spanish.

Governor hits road for votes

"I don't think [Bush] is in much danger of losing," said Miranda Luis, a retired state health officer in Tampa who lived for most of his life in Puerto Rico. "I don't see the opposing candidates making much headway."

Bush has campaigned for the Hispanic vote, joining Puerto Rican activists at a recent luncheon at Brisas del Caribe, an Orlando eatery.

Among them was John Quinones, a lawyer running for the Legislature.

"I think what people like about the Republican Party is it provides the opportunity for you to succeed," said Quinones, who moved from Puerto Rico to Orlando 14 years ago.

Reno also has campaigned for the vote.

Last month, Reno walked through Hunter's Creek, an upscale new development in south Orange County, with several Hispanic students from Cypress Creek High School. They met Graziella Figueroa, who moved from New Jersey a year ago.

"I have one big question: the school problem," said Figueroa, complaining of a lack of after-school tutoring for a child with a reading problem.

Hearing Reno explain that she will "go out to the people and persuade the people" to spend more money on education if necessary, Figueroa said Reno has her vote.

"Oh, yes," she said. "Definitely."

McBride, too, has campaigned throughout the I-4 corridor, which his campaign counts on to provide nearly 40 percent of the vote in the Democratic primary Sept. 10.

But while McBride and Reno compete for the Democratic votes of Hispanics in their primary contest, Bush, already comfortable with his Republican base, is targeting the very same Democrats in November.

"The incumbency and the lack of a primary gives him the luxury of focusing on swing voters from the get-go," Bush pollster Newhouse said. "That's an extreme advantage."

Mark Silva can be reached at msilva@orlandosentinel.com or 407-420-5034. 

Copyright (c) 2002, Orlando Sentinel 

Visit OrlandoSentinel.com

From:	Zoraida Maldonado <drz@bellsouth.net>

To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	we need help

Our county is one of the fastest growing in the state.  We need funds to not only build schools, but to also supply the classrooms and, most importantly, hire the highly qualified teachers needed to work with the growing numbers of students.  Our district has one of the largest ESOL populations and we must be appropriately funded if we are to serve the needs of all our students to the levels they deserve. Osceola County is projected to have the fastest growing school system for the next five years.  We need to prepare the students already in our schools and the expected increase in student population as well.  Osceola County has received the lowest amount, per capita, for school construction in the state for the past five years in spite of the exponential growth.  Yet we have one of the highest percentages of students in charter schools in the State.
 
We have used all measures in our power to meet our ever increasing costs to meet critical needs in our county such as:
 
- Levying a full 2 mills
- Sharing in the Local Option Sales Tax
- Levying the highest School Impact Fees in the State
- Levying additional mills for a School Construction Bond Issue
- Established seven charter schools
- Using all effort index dollars
- Using all classroom 1st dollars
 
 
I urge you to support the funding in the Budget in Section 28 on page 416 for fast growing counties now!  
 
Thank you, Zoraida Maldonado
