Summary of Events concerning the Homestead Senior High School


Earlier in April a fire had been caused by students of the Homestead Senior High School threatening the 2200 and 2400 court of San Remo Circle. The reaction of Homestead Senior High School's principal on TV ( I do not remember which channel she was on) stating that she refused to view the issue of her students causing a potential fire hazard to the San Remo community as she did not believe that the youth involved were attending her school motivated me to videotape all ongoing activities to undoubtedly assure that the students in question ARE attending the Homestead Senior High School. I have videotaped students leaving the school grounds using a hole they had cut in the fence at the end of the football field allowing them access to an area close to San Remo 2400 Court. I suspect they will continue to smoke back there as that was the reason a fire had been ignited before. Not only did I tape students "escaping" the school grounds, I also taped them on their way back to the school cafeteria for lunch. To make matters worse I have footage on a student leaving the school grounds using the hole in the fence, mentioned above, during his PE class with a teacher present. To really demonstrate how negligent Homestead Senior High School treats security matters I have gathered footage on two students performing sex on the bleachers in the center of the football field in broad daylight (about noon). They went undisturbed for at least 30 minutes with their activity. I have addressed this matter on numerous occasions with the assistant principal Mr. Todd Meiklejohn who tried his absolute best to improve the situation. Apparently the problem lies within the principal Ms. Leal, who seems to not support Mr. Meiklejohn and also seems to underestimate the depth of the security-problem of her school as she does feel it necessary to have security out on the football field. Just about an hour before I taped the sex session on the 24th of May 2002 I was in Ms. Leal's office and had informed her about ongoing sex sessions on the bleacher in the center of the school's football field. Just as I feel that all possible avenues have been exhausted, I have addressed Mrs. Lois Jones to pass this information on to individuals possessing the necessary contacts and power to improve matters at Homestead Senior High School and therefor eliminating a major hazard for the San Remo Community. I will certainly make the videotape available upon request. 


I am looking forward to finally resolving this situation.

-----Original Message-----
From: jay greene [mailto:onedopey@hotmail.com]
Sent: Monday, May 27, 2002 12:41 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: to whom it may concern


To Whom It May Concern:

I was born in Florida, raised in Florida and went to school in Florida. I have my whole family in Florida and now, I must move out of Florida to California or New York or even to Canada just to be a film producer which is what I have always wanted to be. 

This might not concern you now, you may have some huge budget problem or some pending bill that you feel is the most important thing in Florida right now. Think about this, Florida is where the first real film giants came in the beginning of the last century, the government messed that up and they went to California. Today the multi billion dollar business is in need of expansion and here is the Florida climate and the fact that NY and Florida are in the same time zone, letting phone calls with financiers and producers happen at decent hours. All we need is for the present government to go read the history books and learn from the mistakes of the past.

Florida is a low budget state right now because most of the talent has to be flown in from NY and LA. If we started making films like a real state then the talent pool would fill up and the property value would rise and the state tax situations would dissipate. All because you pick up a new customer for the state and most of this revenue would be redirected Canada projects for the next few years.

All I want is to stay here and be a world famous film producer /actor like Mel Gibson has done. It seems that the organizations that operate the film world don't think Florida is the place for great filmmakers to come from.

We need to bring the playing field here in order for the world to see what we can do. Ladies and Gentlemen it is worth the fight in the midst of adversity to gain the future we all deserve.

Sincerely J.C. Greene


  _____

Sandra, & Milt, 

Thank you very much for your efforts on our behalf the past 2 yrs. The people in the know, i.e. the surgeons and nurses who work in the offices where I have provided anesthesia the past 10 yrs., are very unhappy with the inexperience and incompetence of the anesthesiologists who they were forced to hire to replace me after April 15. The BOM ruling will probably make the CRNA shortage worsen. It seems there are just too many anesthesiologists in NJ and FL and I for one am moving on to where my services are more needed and appreciated. 

Paul Lee, CRNA

1) Panel Diversification - Will you add some more members to blue ribbon

to address
a horrific situation who had some baseline of experience as i was
seeking a
fast review and recommendation.  With this initial strong, specific
report,
recommendations I would expect some additional community leaders to be
on
the report back from dcf in early sept.

2) Direct Service Organization Veto - This was raised at Sun panel, why
a
veto - Kate said DCF did not need a centralized pool of funds which this
leg
would allow, because dcf has ability to set these organizations up at
local
level - should be viewed as a  way to build local awareness, knowledge
and
involvement - so ability is focused on local level and should be
coordinated
with community based care set up and delivery

3) Adoptions are up, but could be higher - Due to state rules/laws many
kids
in permanent guardianship cannot be adopted - ie placement in perm
guardians
whom are gay, also some permanent placements (even in rodrika sit) are
not
able to adopt due to background of caregivers --

4) Is this all about more money? - Many of recommendations are not about
more money, but about better use of resources with goals and
accountabilities and a focus on moving along community based care
programs.
Need to really look at real numbers for training, ways to work to ensure
training is part of curriculum at social welfare programs offerred at
education institutions - so when they finish college degree they do not
have
to spend weeks in training they could of learned in school = sister
jeanne
thinks this could be helpful and offerred to set up a mtg statewide with
deans of social work colleges to ensure when they graduate they are
ready to
hit the streets immediately.  Base pay increases????  Service First -
the
support of the panel to support service first intent is welcome -
specific
performance metrics, accountability all important

5) Blue Ribbon Panel - calls for Special Session - are you going to call
for
a special session as requested ???"  Many specific suggestions and
deadlines
are set out in recommendations, will work with District 11/dcf team to
ensure guidelines met as outlined, then will review based on
implementation
lessons learned by  Miami Dade/District 11 application to entire system.
From there we will work with leg leadership to determine best forum to
pursue: LBC or organizing session in November.  Much can and will be
done
before legislators meet next March, we need them to be involved and they
will be.

6) Calls for Gov Support of Judge K and Charles Auslander - Report
speaks to
need for continuity of leadership, 6 secretaries in 9 years is part of
the
problem, as sister jeanne said....but specific deadlines have been set
by
this blue ribbon panel and Kate and her team committed to those dates -
She
/they understand seriousness of committent and know ramifications of
known
committments not met.

7) Guaridan ad litem - Think we can build on Blue Ribbon Panel
recommendations to specifically address the concerns addressed in the
history of this program working with courts, dcf and guardians to come
up
with a better program and goal to find/identify/train a guardian ad
litem
for every child in system.....thru new panel, new ideas of recruitment
(faithbased, lawyers and non lawyers, etc etc)

8) Community Based Care: Clearly where system of care needs to get -
helps
all the way around, local involvement, local ownership of problems,
local
awareness, local solutions led.....each can be reflective of their local
community etc

9) Panel very very focused on case load number of per child vs per
investigation(multiple number/children) = want our numbers to show on
both
caseload counts and investigation counts as per child vs how they are
done/.counted today -- this will affect NUMBERS yet again, all they way
across board....DCF appropriations for this area based on caseload and
then
FTE's assigned -- this could/would change.....I think panel focus is
where
gov focus (read frustration:) has been....you may be asked re this, just
want you to understand implications on budget......


Not sure i can think of anything else at this point in time.....
Time to go and find a barbeque

-----Original Message-----
From: Art Collins [mailto:artcollins@imcingular.com]
Sent: Monday, May 27, 2002 3:33 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Rilya and Technology


The report you will officially receive tommorrow is good I'm sure. But,
if I may, let me expand upon the recommendations with a specific idea.

With the nation highly aware and sensitive to the use and effectiveness
of technology, a comprehensive technological solution to caring for
Florida's children in state custody, could be the silver bullet to
making this issue go away short term and solving the challenge long
term.

Consider viewing this issue as a "Homeland Defense" matter, where you as
Florida's Governor are working to protect our most valuable resource.
Florida's children.

Envision for a moment. A black box similar to a FEDEX package tracking
unit. This unit has a built in digital camera, a recognition touchscreen
and a wireless link to a  fingerprint and photograph database of all the
children in the care of the state.

Each month, the case worker would visit the child's site. Once there,
photograph and touchscreen fingerprint images would be taken from the
child and matched immediately with central database records to confirm
monitoring of the child. Cellular technology would be used to
triangulate the transmission to pinpoint and confirm the child's
physical location. Brief typwitten reports made onsite containing
relevant info would be immediately transmitted to headquarters.

Unalterable time stamps would reconcile the photgraph, fingerprint,
report and location records taken by case workers to ensure
authenticity.

Exception reports would be created for supervisor's, managers, the
Agency head and you as Governor based upon predefined parameters,
paricularly where norms were violated. Need to know parameters would be
set for the various levels of reporting.

I understand that some of the so-called missing children are in run away
status. Though it may be controversial, a White House ID like tracking
chip could be placed in a unremovable stylish bracelet for flight risk
children.

Th point is to create a "ZERO TOLERANCE" system. It would be the first
of its kind in the nation. All the technology exist today.

One of my technology team member firms currently makes black boxes for
the CIA, NSA and other federal security agencies. They happen to be a
minority owned firm. I would be glad to bring them to town to consult
directly with you and others in designing a solution. These are just my
initial thoughts. Let me know if I can assist.

Art Collins
Public Private Partnership, Inc.
215 South Monroe Street, Suite 130
Tallahassee, FL 32301
(850)561-0762 office
(800)947-2066 pager

1701 Pennsylvania Ave., N.W., Suite 960
(202)785-4049 office
(202)364-2749 fax
www.pubpriv.com

From:	SIMONE TALARICO <AUNTMONE@msn.com>
Sent:	Monday, May 27, 2002 9:23 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Re: CS/SB160 (Wassermann-Schultz)

Dear Governor Bush,
On behalf of the patrons of the dog tracks and poker rooms in Florida, I would like to encourage you to SUPPORT the Senate Bill 160.
Greyhounds are dogs that must run - it is their nature - and they enjoy it.  Greyhounds have very sweet dispositions and make wonderful pets when their careers are over.  It is with this BILL 160 that more greyhounds will be adopted.  Through the SUPPORT of this  legislation, the greyhounds adoption program will be mandatory at ALL dog tracks.  As it is now, more animals are killed in just one humane society shelter than all the greyhounds in the United States.  For this reason alone you should SUPPORT BILL 160.  The POKER ROOMS at the tracks have numerous employees that will be unemployed if the card rooms close.  Increasing the stakes of the poker games will not only bring in more people, but also more revenue to the state of Florida, rather than out to SEA.  I don't think you would want me and the entire staff of the Daytona Beach Kennel Club Poker Room on unemployment.  Our town is a tourist town and work is hard to come by, so about 30 people would definitely make a good dent in your unemployment status.   I AM THE SOLE SUPPORT FOR MY FAMILY - MY HUSBAND CAN NOT FIND A DECENT JOB.  Please do not put me on unemployment - I don not want to be out on the street.  I love working at the Dog Track - really I do not want to have to look for another job.                          Please, Please, Please. SUPPORT BILL 160.                                                            Simone Talarico - AUNTMONE@MSN.com

  <http://www.uniontrib.com/images/black.gif> 
 <http://signonsandiego.master.com/texis/master/search/similar.html> FIND RELATED	


By Seth Hettena
ASSOCIATED PRESS 

May 24, 2002 


SAN DIEGO – An Egyptian-born financial analyst charged in a nationwide stock swindle may have known about the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks and tried to profit from them, a federal prosecutor said Friday. 



  <http://www.uniontrib.com/news/nation/terror/images/020524elgindy.jpg> 


Union-Tribune file
Amr "Tony" Elgindy 

Amr I. "Tony" Elgindy telephoned his broker on Sept. 10 and asked him to liquidate his children's $300,000 trust account, Assistant U.S. Attorney Ken Breen told a federal judge at Elgindy's detention hearing. 

"He made a comment predicting the market would drop to 3,000" at a time when the Dow Jones stock index was at 9,600, Breen said. "Perhaps Mr. Elgindy had pre-knowledge of the Sept. 11 attacks. Instead of trying to report it, he tried to profit from it." 


Elgindy, 34, of Encinitas, was ordered held without bond on charges of racketeering, extortion and obstruction of justice. Before issuing the order, Magistrate Judge John Houston said he was going to "disregard" the suggestion that Elgindy had anything to do with the terror attacks. 






	From the Union-Tribune archives: 
*	Sept. 19, 1999: Gaming  <http://www.uniontrib.com/news/nation/terror/19990919-056-gamingfi.html> firm faces long odds in shaking shady ties 

*	June 27, 1999: Ex-judge  <http://www.uniontrib.com/news/nation/terror/19990627-111-ex-judge.html> Hoti escaped assassins at last minute 

*	May 28, 1999: Kosovo  <http://www.uniontrib.com/news/nation/terror/19990528-315-kosovore.html> refugee escapes assassin's bullet 

*	Feb. 13, 1999: USATalks  <http://www.uniontrib.com/news/nation/terror/19990213-648-usatalks.html> resumes trading; share price plummets to $1 

*	Jan. 30, 1999: SEC  <http://www.uniontrib.com/news/nation/terror/19990130-278-sechalts.html> halts trading in San Diego's USATalks.com for now 
  

  <http://www.uniontrib.com/images/trans_1x1.gif> 	

Elgindy, wearing a tan jumpsuit, did not speak during the hourlong hearing. 


His attorney, Jeanne Knight, said Elgindy did call his broker to make a trade, but the timing was coincidental and the market had been dropping for months. 


"It seems like the government, for lack of factual evidence, has decided to smear my client with terrorist innuendoes," Knight said. "This is smacking of racial profiling." 


Breen made his accusations as prosecutors tried to convince Houston that Elgindy was a flight risk and should be denied bail. 


Elgindy, one of five defendants in the case, was arrested May 22 on an indictment issued by a grand jury in Brooklyn, N.Y. 


In exchange for money, two FBI agents used confidential databases to provide Elgindy and other coconspirators with information on publicly traded companies, the indictment said. 


Elgindy allegedly spread negative information on the companies on his Web site and to subscribers of his e-mail newsletter, InsideTruth.com, while betting that the companies' stock would go down. 


In one case, a former FBI agent searched the agency's confidential National Crime Information Center database and discovered the criminal history of a top executive for a company called Nuclear Solutions, the indictment said. The same day, Elgindy began sending e-mails calling the executive "a convicted felon," then sold the company's stock short, the papers added. 


Earlier this week, FBI agents raided Elgindy's $2.2 million mansion. Inside, agents said they found tens of thousands of dollars in cash and gold coins. The government is seeking to seize his fleet of cars, which include a Rolls Royce, a Jaguar and a Humvee. 


If convicted of all counts, Elgindy faces a maximum 65 years in prison.

From:	Jeb Bush
Sent:	Monday, May 27, 2002 7:34 PM
To:	'cjwh466@bellsouth.net'
Subject:	RE: Education and reading

Dr. White, thank you for writing. We have asked teachers and many others in developing our strategy for improved reading. Our plan is based on providing assistance for teachers regarding the latest research and give them support. Your point concerning  control of the classroom is a good one. I am sick and tired of kids (and worse, parents!) who disrespect teachers as sport. I wish I could waive a magic wand and solve that problem but I am open to productive suggestions. 

Jeb Bush

Please note: Florida has a very broad public records law.

regarding state business are public records available to the

may therefore be subject to public disclosure. 



-----Original Message-----
From: cjwh466@bellsouth.net [mailto:cjwh466@bellsouth.net]
Sent: Monday, May 27, 2002 5:33 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Education and reading


Governor:

After seeing a program that discussed the importance of reading which included both you mother and father, I was taken by your devotion to literacy. I retired from the USN in 1985 in Washington DC. I have a photograph in my den of both your father and President Regan saying best wishes on this important occasion in my life. I truly admire both men and what they accomplished for this nation.

After retiring from Florida as a Corrections Officer in Orange County, I tried teaching for about two years in Orange County, Florida. I finally resigned in disappointment for two reasons:  First, you cannot teach children who refuse to learn and second, you cannot teach children not withstanding how good you may be, unless  you can somehow maintain discipline in your classroom. Discipline that is quick, stern but also delivered in such a way as to have the child's best interest at heart.

Governor, I have had children refer to me in the most colorful terms possible. They used words in public that were unheard of thirty years ago. I have had my portable hit on so hard that pictures fell off the wall and deputies had to be called for assistance. I have heard mothers and fathers intimidate teachers in such a way as to actually make them fear for their lives. I have seen writing assignments in high school that belonged in the early years of middle school. If you complained the system saw to it that nothing got done.

I believe as you do that reading is fundamental to all of education. If you cannot read, then you are doomed to failure and ultimately will end up in the criminal justice system.

Governor, please allow me to offer you a suggestion.  Rather then implement different policies, ideas or concepts regarding the value of education from people who are preceived as experts, let's try something different. I believe that most answers to many of our social problems can be found from ordinary citizens who perform that kind of work. Stated differently, let's ask the teachers about their opinions, what's wrong and how to correct it. You might be surprised at what you hear.

I'm here to assist you if you are sincere...

Sincerely yours,



Dr. Charles J. White

-----Original Message-----
From: Sam Ard [mailto:sard@ashlawfirm.com]
Sent: Monday, May 27, 2002 11:36 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: invasive plants


I'm not sure if the tropical soda apple money in this year's budget was meant for public or private lands.  

The FDEP money is directed by s.201.15, FS, where 2.28% of documentary stamp taxes are earmarked for invasive plant control.  Up until the Florida Forever program passed, the aquatic and upland control dollars were appropriated by separate line items.  All dollars to be spent seem to be tied to public lands, only:

201.15  Distribution of taxes collected.--All taxes collected under this chapter shall be distributed as follows and shall be subject to the service charge imposed in s. 215.20 <http://www.leg.state.fl.us/Statutes/index.cfm?App_mode=Display_Statute&Search_String=&URL=Ch0215/Sec20.htm> (1), except that such service charge shall not be levied against any portion of taxes pledged to debt service on bonds to the extent that the amount of the service charge is required to pay any amounts relating to the bonds: 

(6)  Two and twenty-eight hundredths percent of the remaining taxes collected under this chapter shall be paid into the State Treasury to the credit of the Aquatic Plant Control Trust Fund to carry out the purposes set forth in ss. 369.22 <http://www.leg.state.fl.us/Statutes/index.cfm?App_mode=Display_Statute&Search_String=&URL=Ch0369/Sec22.htm>  and 369.252 <http://www.leg.state.fl.us/Statutes/index.cfm?App_mode=Display_Statute&Search_String=&URL=Ch0369/Sec252.htm> . 

369.22  Nonindigenous aquatic plant control

369.252  Invasive exotic plant control on public lands

 

2002-03 Budget language:

1474A SPECIAL CATEGORIES

TROPICAL SODA APPLE CONTROL

FROM GENERAL REVENUE FUND . . . . . . . . 103,000

 

1625 SPECIAL CATEGORIES

CONTROL OF INVASIVE EXOTICS

FROM INVASIVE PLANT CONTROL TRUST FUND . . 33,434,647

FROM GRANTS AND DONATIONS TRUST FUND . . . 800,000

 

Hope this helps.

Sam

From:	H. William Heller <hheller@stpt.usf.edu>
Sent:	Monday, May 27, 2002 9:40 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	CB/SB l60 "The Debbie Wasserman-Schultz Act"

Dear Governor Bush,

Derby Lane, owned by the St. Petersburg Kennel Club, Inc., has for years
been a generous donor to the University of South Florida St. Petersburg
through its return to charities programs.  The funds have helped
students and supported programs in many ways and it is now our
opportunity to seek your help to permit them to continue to contribute
to institutions like ours and many other charities I could name as
well.  I serve on the boards of many of the latter and know firsthand
the benefits each receives from Derby Lane and so I very respectively
ask for your support of CS/SB l60.  The Bill will grant authority to
conduct a special Greyhound "Adopt a Pet Day" to raise funds for the
promotion of greyhound adoption.  Greyhounds make fabulous pets and your
efforts to make them more adoptable will bring joy to many adults and
children throughout Florida.  The Bill includes other benefits for Derby
Lane which will help it generate even more dollars for the many
charities it now benefits in St. Petersburg and Pinellas County.

I thank you in advance for your support of CS/SB l60 and especially for
your continuing support of teachers and higher education.  We appreciate
and need this support.

Warmest best wishes,

H. William Heller


From:	sdarcy <sdarcy@ucnsb.net>
Sent:	Monday, May 27, 2002 10:17 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Funding DCF
Attachments:	Card for sdarcy

Dear Governor Bush,
Excise tax on retail beer, wine & liquor sales is not a popular idea,
particularly to the liquor/distributor lobby.  However, this type of
excise tax would assist in funding the needed funding for DC & F and the
upcoming recommendations and assist in maintaining funding services
under contract with the ADM office.
    By now, your eyes are probably rolling up into your head as anyone
mentions a tax creation in an election year.  I firmly believe that beer
should not competitively priced with soda.
     A lottery ticket named "Save the Kids" would be another magnificent
boost if the funds were allocated to DC & F.  Simply, all health and
human services programs rise and fall with revenues; we need to
stabilize that funding -- and THAT needs to be a platform issue.
    There is a significant amount of data from SAMHSA, CSAT and other
federally funded studies that reveals that nearly 90% of all alcohol
consumed is by just 10% of the population.  These are the persons whose
children go into foster care or at least DC & F supervision.
    My residential treatment agency, Community OutReach, in DeLand has
undergone a 10% decrease in contract funding that we simply cannot
afford and maintain services.  I need not tell you the staggering
numbers we have on the books for those who simply need an assessment,
let alone direct service.
   As always, I appreciate your fine work, your responsiveness to the
diverse needs of this state, and your commitment to substance abuse
services.

Sincerely,
Sam Darcy, MA, CAP
From:	Sandra Darling <jtsd@bellsouth.net>
Sent:	Monday, May 27, 2002 10:23 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Dr Leon, a letter pleading our case



Govenor, another letter you may have an interest in reviewing.  Sandra Darling 



>From: "Milton Taylor"   
>
>
>Mid-Florida Anesthesia Services, PA 
>
>Milton E. Taylor, CRNA, Pres. 
>
>102 View Point Place 
>
>Winter Springs, FL 32708 
>
>407-718-5658 
>
><mailto:mtaylor24@cfl.rr.com>mtaylor24@cfl.rr.com 
>
>  
>
>  
>
>  
>
>May 27, 2002 
>
>
>  
>
>  
>
>Gustavo G. Leon, MD 
>
>351 NW LeJeune Road 
>
>Suite 105 
>
>Miami, FL 33126 
>
>  
>
>Dear Gustavo G. Leon, 
>
>  
>
>On 25 May 2002 I had the honor and privilege to speak before your committee in Tampa and I appreciate that opportunity and I thank you for it.  On the record let me say that I applaud, as does so many, the Board of Medicine putting rules and regulations in place to clean up office surgery in Florida.  However, the B.O.M. over stepped its bounds when you placed the anesthesia rule into effect banning Nurse Anesthetist from continuing to provide safe quality anesthesia. Anesthesia was not the problem and did not need fixing. 
>
>  
>
>Dr. Leon, since you are not familiar with Nurse Anesthetist and their history, let me take a brief moment to tell you a little about us.  As you already know and have heard many times, we have provided safe quality anesthesia in hospitals, surgery centers, and offices for over 100 hundred years. Now stop and think about that, 100 years, if we did not practice safe quality anesthesia how could we ever survived that long.  If we did not provide safe quality anesthesia why has my malpractice insurance decreased in cost to me over the past 10 years.  What you are hearing Sir from the Anesthesiologist is all rhetoric to convince the B.O.M. to place such strong controls on office anesthesia that it will force the CRNA back into working for them or out of the state altogether.  As I stated before the committee, if it really were a Patient Safety issue that they were concerned about, then why were they fighting so hard and spending so much money to bring a lesser-trained anesthesia provider into Florida? 
>
>  
>Now, you have stated for the record that you did not want to hear economics brought into the meeting, so that was the way it was, however, let me assure you Sir, that is the whole agenda of the F.S.A. under the disguise of Patient Safety.  Lets take a minute and review the facts that are well known: 
>
>
>  
>	 * Reimbursements from Medicare and H.M.O. etc. have dropped. Medicare use to reimburse Anesthesiologist 1.5 times the allowable for each CRNA an Anesthesiologist supervised and I use the term supervise loosely, usually only on paper.  So if one Anesthesiologist directed 5 Nurse Anesthetist it was good money.  However, HCFA realized that Nurse Anesthetists were capable, well trained and did not need supervision and now reimburse the Anesthesiologist the same as a CRNA and they can no longer bill 1.5 times the allowable for supervision.  
>
>  
>	 * As HMO, PPO and other insurance groups came into being in the 80s reimbursements once again dropped and the Anesthesiologist found they had to do more cases in order to maintain their incomes and standards of living. So they began to find creative ways of doing that, one of which was to form a subgroup of doctors called Intensivist which take care of critically ill patients in the ICU, while yet others branched off into pain management.  
>
>  
>	 * As the anesthesiologist started taking on the other jobs they began to hire Nurse Anesthetist to do the cases in the operating rooms, taking them from hospitals, who employed Nurse Anesthetist directly to run their Operating Rooms. The hospitals now losing their anesthetist to the anesthesiologist groups had no choice but to contract with the anesthesiologist groups to provide that service, once again increasing the Anesthesiologist income.>  
>
>  
>	 * >Still looking for more ways to increase or maintain incomes Anesthesiologist began looking for other ways to make money. If you look at the A.S.A. web page you can find committee reports that discuss Office Based Anesthesia as being an untapped resource with recommendations to pursue that arena.  However, now for the first time Anesthesiologist fined that they are now in direct competition with nurse anes>thetist who developed office anesthesia into a fine art.  Nurse Anesthetist had been doing anesthesia in offices for 75 years.  The Anesthesiologist also come to realize how lucrative it is in that the patients pay you 100% of your fee and you dont have the expense or paper work of billing.  
>
>  
>	 * When the BOM began looking at the issues with office surgery here in Florida they found that it was in need of fixing from a surgical standpoint, yes, I expect that anesthesia could use some fine-tuning as well. The moratorium was put into place and those offices that had been doing it right complied with all the rules. I personally bought all the resuscitative drugs that the B.O.M. required including Dantrolene, alone that is a two thousand dollar investment. I personally have invested $40,000.00 in drugs and equipment to make sure that both of the offices I did anesthesia in met or exceeded the B.O.M. requirements. When the ban was lifted things improved, with Nurse Anesthetist still doing what they do best, and have years of training and experience doing. I personally do 1,500 plus-cases a year in offices and hospitals.  
>
>  
>	 * Now with the B.O.M. looking into and setting guidelines to control and monitor office based surgery the Florida Society of Anesthesiologist saw an opportunity to take over the Office Based Anesthesia Business. They decided to go to the B.O.M. with lies, false and poorly done studies in an attempt to make what was happening in offices look like it was anesthesia related and that Nurse Anesthetist could not and should not be doing it with out them.  This way, they could have the B.O.M. be the bad guys and literally 
>	steal our practices from us.  That is what the B.O.M. did with this ruling, like a thief in the night you stole my practice and my $40,000.00 investment and gave it to the Anesthesiologist.  
>
>
>  
>	 * Dr. Leon, I should have known in my heart that the B.O.M. and the F.S.A. is a good old boys club and that you would side with the F.S.A. But, down deep inside my gut I kept thinking that with all the evidence showing Anesthesia was not the problem and that the studies were bogus and that Nurse Anesthetist were doing office anesthesia longer than anesthesiologist and doing it well, or once again we would have never lasted in offices for 75 years, that honesty and integrity would prevail and the B.O.M. and particularly your committee would have done the right thing and reversed the level three rule back to what it was prior to April 15, 2002.  
>
>  
>	 * Now as for your suggestion for indirect supervision, which is a noble idea, but it will never work.  Why should the F.S.A. go to indirect supervision when you have already given them full supervision, meaning that I cant work without them being present, that is exactly what they wanted.  And, if they must be present and the surgeon has only one or two cases, then what do they need me for?  Also, why should I have to pay or share my fee with an Anesthesiologist for doing nothing except saying that he is supervising. If a Nurse Anesthetist gets into trouble he cant wait for the anesthesiologist to come from across town or his office to give him help.  
>	>Besides, a Nurse Anesthetist is trained to respond to any emergency that arises. Do you think that for a moment that millions of anesthetics given in the United States are all supervised by anesthesiologist, who somehow saves the patient from life threatening problems in the O.R., I hope not.  Nurse Anesthetist are saving lives day in and day out and until now have never boasted or been recognized for it. We have just gone about our work and careers doing what we are trained to do. It is well known that Nurse Anesthetists provide more than 65% of the anesthetics in the United States and a large percentage of those are Nurse Anesthetists working alone or with other Nurse Anesthetist.  
>
>  
>Now last but not least lets look at the safety record of Anesthesiologist. I personally know of two deaths in the last year that were cause directly by Board Certified Anesthesiologist. The first was from Dr. Tom Andrews, President Elect of the F.S.A., own group.  One of the Anesthesiologist decided to put a central line in his anesthetized patient and in the process traumatized the vessel and failed to recognize the problem until the patient cardiac arrested from hemorrhaging. The patient could not be resuscitated as I recall and died on the table.  The second case was just last month when two Board Certified Anesthesiologists failed to properly monitor a healthy 60-year-old male undergoing routine shoulder arthroscopy.  The patients temperature was not monitored during the case by the first anesthesiologist and the second anesthesiologist came to relieve him failed to monitor that modality as well. On emergence the patient was so hypothermic that he went into ventricular fibrillation and after approximately one hour was revived but suffered irreversible brain damage and died in the ICU a couple of days later.  But, since we live in an imperfect world I guess if you are a board certified anesthesiologist with MD behind your name such malpractice is OK however if this happened to a Nurse Anesthetist everyone says we should be supervised or Crucified and license revoked.  It is a sad day when one group uses it power to convince their colleagues, who have legislative authority, to use that authority to take away another groups right to practice under the laws of the state and thereby stealing their businesses and their ability to provide for their families.  That Sir is exactly what the A.S.A. and the B.O.M have done. 
>
> Therefore Dr. Leon I implore you to re-weigh the facts and do what is right under the laws of this state and remove this unjust and unnecessary rule. I feel that I have been tried and found guilty of a crime that I did not commit and sentenced to die and stripped of all my rights.  The Administrative law judge was correct and he saw the truth, I hope you will find it in your conscience to do the right thing and get this ruling reversed.  If you are not willing to do this, I will be forced to relinquish my Florida license and seek a state where I can practice what I was trained to do, as some of my colleagues have already done. 
>
>  
>
>Respectfully, 
>
>  
>
>  
>
>  
>
>Milton E. Taylor, CRNA, Pres. 
>
>Mid-Florida Anesthesia Services, PA     
>
>   
>
>  
>
>  
>
>

From:	Dolores Walker <walkerd@osceola.k12.fl.us>
Sent:	Tuesday, May 28, 2002 7:22 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Budget

Dear Gov. Bush,  

I am the Guidance Secretary at St. Cloud Middle School in the School
District of Osceola County.  I am also a Florida native.   I see every day
the overcrowding in the classrooms.  How many students were in your
classes when you were in school?  20?, 25?  Try 30 or 38 now.   And that
amount is only going to get bigger.  I understand that there is the
possibility of Osceola County School District receiving 8.5 million
dollars from the state legislature to help our fast growing county. 
(Section 28 page 416)  Please do not veto this item.  

Osceola County has had the fastest growing school system in the state for
the past five years, and is projected to have the fastest growing school
system for the next five years.  We have received the lowest amount, per
capita, for school construction in the state for the past five years. 
Osceola County has one of the highest percentages of students in charter
schools in the State.  We are the only county in the state that has
exhausted all local sources for school construction.

Your record so far in the area of education for Florida schools has not
been what I would call "exemplary".  Please let this item pass in the
budget.  It may be your saving grace for the next election.  I know it
would help me see you in a different light.  

Sincerely, 
Dolores Walker  


From:	Robert Janauskas <wishfer@worldnet.att.net>
Sent:	Tuesday, May 28, 2002 7:42 AM
To:	Larry Cretul; Andy Kesselring; Parnell Townley; Randy Harris; Steve Henning
Cc:	Rep. Jerry Melvin; My Florida; Cliff Stearns; Bob Graham; Karen Thurman; Rep. Will S. Kendrick; Senator Rod Smith; Senator Richard Mitchell; Senator Anna P. Cowin; Senator James E. "Jim" King, Jr., Majority Leader; Rep. Edward L. "Ed" Jennings; Rep. Carey Baker; Rep. Joe H. Pickens; Rep. Perry C. McGriff; Rep. Hugh H. Gibson; Rep. Dennis K. Baxley; Rep. Nancy Argenziano; John Lund; Gordon Johnston; City Of Ocala; Chris English
Subject:	Library Books for Children? 

Importance:	High

Recipients Suppressed 
 
Dear Board of County Commissioners, 
 
We didn't pay too much attention when the subject of two particular books were being discussed which you've approved for placement in our public library. We apologize for our distraction.  
 
Although we have not read the books, i.e., "It's Perfectly Normal" and "Deal With It," we heard descriptive statements and revelations of actual drawings from these books on a recent broadcast of the John Lund Show on WOCA 1370 Radio Talk Show. 
 
We commend John and WOCA for telling it like it is and wish this information had been available earlier to the Citizens of Marion county. 
 
If these books were sold in a retail outlet without a cover and not kept behind the counter they'd violate current statutory mandates of protecting under age buyers from accessibility to pornographic material. These books are outrageously graphic and should not be available to our children.
 
If you haven't read these books and viewed the drawings we urge you to do so and place this issue on a future agenda for a public hearing.
 
We understand our county attorney advised commissioners; failure to approve access would lead to a lawsuit in violation of freedom of speech and/or press. We're certain he has advised commissioner's similarly on other issues which the board ignored but the final decision is the perogative of the board. 
 
If the board can expend funds to engage outside legal services for a myriad of issues why was it reluctant to challenge these books? Can you provide the justification for, seemingly, contributing to the moral decay of our children in Marion county?  
 
We understand we are 'Bob & Geri come lately' but we believe; if the general public knew what John told us last week they'd be willing to challenge access. Marion county can and should set the precedent in Florida which will surely have repurcussion's in our nation. We suggest you do so as expeditiously as possible. 
 
Incidentally, we've learned but don't have the name of a similar book being considered for access to children by the library advisory board. 
 
The time has come to stop this nonsense! 
 
Thank you for your consideration in this matter. We look forward to your reply. 
Sincerely, 
Robert E. & Geraldine C. Janauskas 
5395 SW 81st Street 
Ocala, FL 34476-3751
(352) 237-0781
 
From:	Silvia Zapico <szapico@valencia.cc.fl.us>
Sent:	Tuesday, May 28, 2002 8:15 AM

Cc:	reply@kissimmeechamber.com
Subject:	Help for Osceola Schools

Governor Bush:

Thank you very much for the new programs and the support that you have given to Education.  Indeed you are the "Education Governor".  As a Republican and your supporter, I firmly believe that you are doing a great job.  

Today, I write to you because the children of Osceola County need your help.  Please grant $10 million to help the fast growing counties. As a resident of Osceola county, I honestly can tell you that we are in desperate need of the $8.5 millions that we would receive of these funds. These funds will be dedicated to build new schools.

Our county, Osceola,is the fastest growing county in the state of Florida  The projections are, that we will continue being the fastest growing for the next five years. In contrast, Osceola county has received the lowest amount, percapita, for school construction in the state for the past five years.  Please do not veto the these critical funds that will help the fastest growing counties in Florida.

Osceola County has exhausted all other local resources for school contruction. The truth is that we need to put more funds into schools for our children. They are the future of our county and the future of this nation.  We are in need of additional resources to educate them.

Please, do not hesitate to contact me if you have any comments or questions about this request.  I work for Valencia Community College, Osceola Campus and I believe that Education is the key to the future of this county and of our nation.  I also firmly believe in providing our students with a K through 20 program, with seamless transitions.

Sincerely,

Silvia Zapico, Ed.D.

From: sjnelson51@aol.com [mailto:sjnelson51@aol.com]

In a message dated 5/24/02 9:18:33 AM Eastern Daylight Time, Brewser.Brown@MyFlorida.com writes:
   

For context, the State is always trying to do better and needs to do better,
but the total overhead - people, paper, buildings, etc...for FL DOE is less
than 1/2 of 1 percent of the k-12 operating budget, which will be about $13
billion for fiscal 2002-2003



     Brewser,
          Marie Dinon is on the board of directors of IVBE, she wrote the post which you responded to. I appreciate what she's stated, that being that much of the education dollars support the top level administration. However, I do recognize what you've written (above) and appreciate the information. If any administration has worked diligently to reduce overhead at the top it has been Jeb's. I have spent much time defending him, and his education efforts over the years.
          I do worry about the upcoming election. I don't think I could stand it if Jeb did not win re-election. I think I'd feel inclined to give up on the whole education reform movement...the Republican ed-reform movement that is.
          My goal is to continue to seek de-centralization of education across the board. So much waste occurs in the districts themselves, yet they often hold the cards when it comes to what information reaches the public.
         I don't blame stagnant FCAT scores on the Bush administration and the recent financial problems of the state. I blame teachers who have focused more on the socialization of kids rather than the academic instruction of them. So many are under-trained, some lazy, with the philosophy that children are self-directed learners. Well, maybe some are but the majority are not!
         The curriculum is still woefully inadequate in many ways. Classrooms are rife with actvities and copious "projects" that have little learning value. Sorry to sound so redundant, but the STW philosophy has denegrated classroom instruction over the years.
          Many schools and teachers have basically tried to "employ" without pay parents to check homework, grade tests, in the schools. Now I appreciate parental participation and the need for it, but teachers are not aware of a child's shortcomings if another person is checking their work. In Brevard, students in middle school have been commissioned to enter grades into a computer database. Does this sound wise? It turned out that the teacher decided that getting help in her work was more important than finding some academic exercise for the students to do.
       Anyway, IVBE will be supporting Jeb to the maximum degree. He is still our only chance to force a money hungry ed-system into accountability.
        God Bless You,
                Shelley Nelson

-----Original Message-----
From: Willett, Andrea [mailto:WilletA@mail.doe.state.fl.us]

>  -----Original Message-----
> From: 	Thompson, Linda  
> Sent:	Thursday, May 23, 2002 3:44 PM
> To:	'MUMZYOF5@aol.com'
> Cc:	'Brewser.Brown@MyFlorida.Com'; Coxe, Betty; Willett, Andrea
> Subject:	school
> 
> Dear Ms. Tongue:
> Thank you for your message to Governor Bush concerning Take Stock in
> Children Scholarships for children in home education programs.   Your
> questions have sparked some very interesting discussion.  As you are
> aware, Take Stock in Children is an independent private agency, so I
> called their new Executive Director, Marcus Christian, to ask him about
> your question.  Currently, Take Stock does not have a policy concerning
> home education and scholarships.  However, this issue has come up several
> times recently so the Take Stock state office is working on developing
> one.
> In order for students to receive scholarships through Take Stock in
> Children, they must maintain a certain grade point average and also have a
> mentor who is seen in the school setting.  Take Stock also requires that
> the student be on a college bound academic track.   These factors will
> have to be considered before the agency can make a final policy.  It seems
> that in order to have total assurance that your son will have access to
> his scholarship through Take Stock, he would need to stay enrolled as a
> public school student until a decision is made.   Your local Take Stock in
> Children agency will be the best one to help you keep up with what policy
> the agency sets.  You can also contact the state office at:
> Take Stock in Children
> 50 North Laura Street, Suite 1238
> Jacksonville, Florida 32202
> 904/791-7518
> www.takestockinchildren.com
> Once again, thank you for your question and I wish you the best of luck in
> your decisions about the education of your children.
> Linda G. Thompson, Director
> Office of Family Involvement
> Florida Department of Education
> 850/487-3521
> 
>

  <mhtml:mid://00000183/!http://www.tampabaylive.com/images/zpix.gif> 	
	
	


Disappointed models sue agency
a 28 News report 4/29/02
related story:  <http://www.28news.com/stories/020215model2000.shtml> Modeling agency accused of making false promises (2/15/02) 


  <mhtml:mid://00000183/!http://www.tampabaylive.com/images/stories/0429model3.jpg> TAMPA - Dozens of angry would-be models claim their agency ripped them off, and Monday they took their fight to court. 


This modeling agency has been in the spotlight since a 28 Investigates report back in February. Tampa police, the Department of Professional Regulation and even the governor's office started investigating. But one of the victims didn't want to wait for results, so her family is suing Model 2000. 


Christy West lost her dream of hitting the big time as a model, but she hopes to win in court. Her parents spent $855 to start Christy's modeling career, but all they got were photographs- no modeling jobs. 


"She continued to tell me how beautiful Christy was. And that she was exactly what they were looking for and she guaranteed I would make that money back in no time," testified Christy's mother. 


"Yeah she got me all excited. She told me about all these jobs. She promised me," testified Christy. 


  <mhtml:mid://00000183/!http://www.tampabaylive.com/images/stories/0429model.jpg> Nancy Sniffen, right, owns Model 2000. Through her lawyer, she denied the allegations. 


"Well, it's just incorrect. It's false. She is selling photographs, but lots and lots of people get jobs." 


The victims in this case say it's not about the money. They want to win to try and put Model 2000 out of business. It turns out dozens of customers complained about the same treatment. 


28 Investigates paid the owner a second visit after the state joined the investigation. Sniffen refused to talk, but now she has to answer to a judge. 


The victims feel Model 2000 is a photo mill, that the owner makes money by selling them pictures but never gets them modeling jobs. The owner's attorney admits she does make money that way, but claims she makes more money placing people in modeling jobs. 


Sniffen will testify when the trial continues later this week.

----- Original Message ----- 
From: Conley, Jon <mailto:Jon.Conley@LASPBS.STATE.FL.US>  
To: 'vicr@adelphia.net' 
Sent: Tuesday, May 28, 2002 9:03 AM
Subject: Teacher Tenure Language change



New Language (page 1319, SB 20-E)


Section 1012.33, (3)

 (g) Beginning July 1, 2001, for each employee who enters into a written contract, pursuant to this section, in a school district in which the employee was not employed as of June 30, 2001, for purposes of pay, a district school board must recognize and accept each year of full-time public school teaching service earned in the State of Florida or outside the state and for which the employee received a satisfactory performance evaluation. Instructional personnel employed pursuant to s. 121.091(9)(b)3. are exempt from the provisions of this paragraph.

 Old

Chapter 231.36 (3)

(g)  Beginning July 1, 2001, for each employee who enters into a written contract, pursuant to this section, in a school district in which the employee was not employed as of June 30, 2001, for purposes of pay a school board must recognize and accept each year of full-time teaching service for which the employee received a satisfactory performance evaluation. This provision is not intended to interfere with the operation of a collective bargaining agreement except to the extent it requires the agreement to treat years of teaching experience out of the district the same as years of teaching experience within the district. Instructional personnel employed pursuant to s.  <http://www.leg.state.fl.us/Statutes/index.cfm?App_mode=Display_Statute&Search_String=&URL=Ch0231/index.cfm?App_mode=Display_Statute&Search_String=&URL=Ch0121/Sec091.htm> 121.091(9)(b)3. are exempt from the provisions of this paragraph.

Jon Conley 

Office of Policy and Budget, Education Unit 
Executive Office of the Governor 
488-4512

-----Original Message----- 
From: Thomas, Brad 
To: Pfeifer, Pam; Turbeville, Greg; Arduin, Donna 
Sent: 05/28/2002 9:30 AM 
Subject: Ventura vetoes pledge bill/FTU edit. nails him 

Tuesday, May 28, 2002 

Last modified at 8:15 p.m. on Monday, May 27, 2002 
PATRIOTISM: Bad timing 
Minnesota Gov. Jesse Ventura used incredibly poor judgment in discussing 
legislation that would have required public school students to recite 
the Pledge of Allegiance at least once a week. 
The bill had little meaning other than expressing post-Sept. 11 
patriotism, because it allowed school boards to opt out. 
Nevertheless, Ventura vetoed it, saying patriotism should be voluntary. 
Unfortunately, he also said a pledge requirement would be 
indoctrination, similar to Nazi Germany telling youths to hail the Third 
Reich, or the Taliban in- structing Afghan children to chant 
anti-American slogans. 
It isn't the same. The pledge is a positive message to support freedom, 
not an indoctrination to hate others. Ventura's timing couldn't have 
been worse, with new reports surfacing daily of fresh attacks on the 
United States being planned by enemies of this nation. 
Ventura's proclivity toward outrageous speech may have been endearing 
during his days as a "bad guy" professional wrestling announcer, but 
they are out of place as the chief executive of a state.

From:	David Foy <foydnoles@hotmail.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, May 28, 2002 10:49 AM
To:	alan.florez@myflorida.com
Cc:	Jeb Bush; sam@fsa1.org; jason@fsa1.org
Subject:	Tuition Veto Information

Dear Alan,
Hello. I promised I would get back with you on some additional data relating 
to tuition in Florida.

The main premise surrounding this issue (has been and always will be) - what 
does tuition cost in Florida relative to other states? Well, that has been 
the problem. Policy-makers have been receiving inaccurate information about 
Florida’s ranking on tuition and fees relative to other states for over 20 
years. The Division of Colleges and Universities has reported that Florida 
is 48 out of 50 nationwide for in-state post-secondary public undergraduate 
tuition and fees, citing the Washington State Higher Education Board 
National Comparison Survey on Tuition and Fees.

This survey does report Florida as 48th; however, the survey only takes into 
account six of the State University System institutions. A further analysis 
(by FSA staff) shows that Washington only provided a comprehensive analysis 
on tuition and fees for four out of the 50 states. In fact, the Washington 
survey only reviewed 264 of the 610 four-year public post-secondary colleges 
and universities, or 43 percent. Washington officials have stated that their 
survey has not taken into account any new public universities entering the 
mix over the past 30 years and that the original universities were chosen 
for their likeness to state of Washington institutions, not as a national 
indicator.  This survey and its information is useless to Governor Bush!

Now the question is, does the Governor want to use this flawed data to 
decide tuition policy in Florida? Does he want to listen to the university 
presidents when they say, Florida's tuition is cheap relative to the other 
states. I highly doubt it, because the university presidents are using the 
Washington Report, which is ripe with errors and omissions.

The Florida Board of Education recently created a Task Force to deliberate 
on Florida's tuition policy, the Bright Futures Program, the Florida Prepaid 
Program and the overall financing of higher education in Florida. Why was 
the Legislature so quick to give this power to the trustees prior to the 
FBOE having an opportunity to receive recommendations from the Task Force? 
Why are the policy-makers not waiting for Secretary Horne's recommendations?

This is a huge policy change for the state of Florida - providing appointed 
officials with control over tuition. Shouldn't the state conduct a 
comprehensive analysis prior to making this policy change?

If the Governor approves the 10 to 20 percent tuition increase, he will be 
making that decision based on the premise that Florida is cheap (48 out of 
50) relative to other states. The Washington Report and its data is 
incomplete and I can say with much confidence that the Governor will be 
making a mistake for a large majority of Florida's college students and 
parents.

Thank you for letting me share this additional information. I hope all is 
well.

With Warm Regards,

David K. Foy
Executive Director
Florida Student Association, Inc.
1311-B Paul Russell Road, Suite 203
Tallahassee, FL  32301
(850)877-7500 (850)877-6898 Fax
dave@fsa1.org

From:	Kisshawk@aol.com
Sent:	Tuesday, May 28, 2002 11:13 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Help for Osceola County School Construction

Dear Governor Bush:

I know that you are currently reviewing the budget for next year which 
includes a $10MM appropriation for school construction in the fastest growing 
school districts in the state.  Of that $10MM, $8.5MM is for school 
construction here in Osceola County.  I also know that you are aware that 
Osceola County is the fastest growing school district in the state and it is 
predicted we will continue with this dubious distinction for at least the 
next five years.  Our growth is so huge we need to add a classroom a day for 
every day of the school year just to stay even -- much less reduce class size 
-- and we are way behind in making that happen.

I would therefore ask you to please approve the $10MM and therefore the 
$8.5MM that would go to Osceola County.  Though it will not build one whole 
school, it will go a long way to help build one, and we need all the help we 
can get.  The need is tremendous and we have exhausted all local sources of 
construction funding.  Your attention to this matter, as the "Education 
Governor" would be greatly appreciated.

Sincerely,

Mary K. Cooper

Kissimmee, FL.  34744

From:	Carol Quick <quickca@kua.net>
Sent:	Tuesday, May 28, 2002 11:34 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Funding for fast growing counties

Mr. Bush,  
 
I am a teacher in Osceola County.  I urge you to approve additional funding for Osceola County's incredible growth.  The Osceola County school system has been the fastest growing district in the state for the past five years.  Every time I make my daily trek to work, I am amazed at the new growth and development along the way.  In the past four years, my drive time to work has nearly doubled because of the increased construction and traffic.  
 
Even though we are growing at a tremendous rate, Osceola County has received the lowest amount, per capita, for school construction in the state for the past five years.  We also have one of the highest percentages of students in charter schools in the state.  Our county has exhausted local sources for school construction:  levying a full 2 mills, sharing in the Local Option Sales Tax, levying the highest School Impact Fees in the state, levying additional mills for a School Construction Bond issue, establishing seven charter schools, using all effort index dollars, and using all classroom first dollars.  
 
I urge you to stand behind your promises of educational improvement and provide the extra funding necessary to educate the children in our fastest growing districts. 
 
Thank you. 
 
Carol Quick
From:	Steve Zimmerman <Szimmerman@pcnh.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, May 28, 2002 11:33 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Greyhound adoption

Dear Governor Bush,

I recently wrote to you about my support for the greyhound adoption 
bill on your desk. I am enclosing a copy of a story I am running this 
Friday on greyhound adoption. It is written in the first person (or 
greyhound) as my greyhound Dottie would have written it.
Everything in the story is true and factua.
I hope you find it insightful.

Best regards,

Steve Zimmerman
The News Herald

It’s a wonderful greyhound life

By Dottie the Greyhound
As told to her human Steve Zimmerman

I just love when today comes each year. For today is my birthday. My 
name is Dottie and I turned 10 years old today.
Now you might be asking yourself how a greyhound would know it is 
her birthday. I know because of the cake and ice cream I had today. Every 
year on the same day for the past six years since I came to live with my 
humans, I have gotten cake and ice cream. And today was the day.
The funny thing is, I turned 10 (that is 70 in dog years) but these two 
humans still talk to me like I was a puppy down on the farm. Oh well, you 
know what they say. A human is only as smart as his greyhound lets them 
be.
When I raced, my human, Steve, watched me every time. He watched 
me run into the six dog one time and then run into the four dog the next 
time. Needless to say, I was not the best racer. My late sister Genie was the 
runner in this family.
When I came into the human’s home, she was already there and was 
queen of the house. Or sometimes she was the evil stepsister to my 
Cinderella. She was a strange dog. She had to be fed first and always had to 
be the first to choose where she would sleep for the night.
She usually got to sleep with the female human Sharon in her bed, 
which relegated her male human Steve to another bed in the house. That 
meant I had the choice of either the couch or the loveseat. And as I am 
kind of tall for a girl, I usually chose the couch.
But I do have to give Genie some credit. She was totally responsible for 
me coming to live with the humans.
She was an only dog and she wanted some company. So when the 
humans would go to work, Genie would take all the canned foods off the 
shelves and stack them in the living room and sleep with them.
That made the humans think that she needed a companion. So when I 
ran into the three dog during a race and hurt my leg, I got to go home with 
Steve and Sharon. Boy, was I lucky.
I came into a house where the humans were already greyhound trained. 
They knew that if they were on the couch and Genie or I wanted to get on 
there to sleep, they had to move. All we have to do is give them the evil eye 
and they get up and move.
I must admit though that I am not as worldly as Genie was and that got 
me into a couple of strange situations.
Like the time I accidentally walked into the bedroom while Steve was 
trying to make Sharon taller (as if she wasn’t tall enough already!). She 
was sitting on him and on first glance; I thought this looked very 
interesting. So I rested my head on the end of the bed and waited to see 
how tall Sharon would get.
Well, Steve happened to look down and see me with my head resting on 
the foot of the bed staring at them and he started to laugh, which caused 
Sharon to laugh and fall off him. I was not sure what was so funny and 
soon tired of being laughed at so I turned and left the room.
But I got my revenge. Steve had bought a big bag of these little 
triangular candies they called kisses. Well, he left them on the counter in 
the kitchen when they went out and I decided to taste them.
I took the bag off the counter and took each kiss from its wrapper and 
ate every last one of them. Even though Genie was there with me in the 
house, that’s my story and I’m sticking to it.
When my humans came home, they discovered the empty bag and the 
wrappers and became very concerned. I heard them call my doctor and 
ask him if I was okay.
They could have just asked me. Other than walking and talking a little 
faster, I felt great. When Steve got off the phone with my doctor, he told 
Sharon that if I wasn’t dead in an hour, I would be okay.
Dead, ha! That day was the only day I ever beat Genie in a race around 
our big back yard. On that day, I could have beat Secretariat in a race.
Well, things have been changing around the house lately. Genie, who 
was 14, went to sleep a few months ago. I knew something was wrong 
when she started to forget my name during our talks. Steve said she had 
doggie Alzheimer’s disease. My doctor told me, and the humans, that 
actually can happen in dogs.
When Genie left us, some great people showed up at our door 
unannounced and left a male greyhound named Mike for my other brother 
Caper and me.
Caper came to us a couple of years ago after being abused by a mean 
trainer in Massachusetts. That trainer beat Caper and his four brothers 
with a bullwhip. As they were very scared of humans, they did not race and 
could not be adopted so they had to be put to sleep.
Steve saw Caper in his new Florida kennel acting very scared and asked 
the trainer who had taken Caper from the mean trainer what was wrong. 
After hearing the story, he told the trainer to bring Caper to our house.
It took two years of leaving him alone to find his way to the humans. 
But now he is playing with us, walking the humans on their leash and 
acting like a real greyhound.
Lately, my leg has been hurting me real bad. So last week the humans 
took me to see my doctor Bruce. I don’t think he or the humans have 
figured out we greyhounds understand English. But we do.
I heard Doctor Bruce say I have cancer and they could take my leg to 
stop the disease from spreading. Now I don’t know about you, but I think a 
three-legged greyhound must look awfully funny.
Luckily, my humans said no and decided to bring me back home whole. 
When we got in the car, Steve was very upset about my being sick and was 
crying. But, in my own inimitable way, I cheered him up. I gave him a big 
slobbery kiss right on the lips.
My leg has been getting worse every day but I knew it was about time for 
that cake and ice cream so I wanted to stay around for one last taste.
Now that my birthday is over, I guess it is time for me to join Genie at 
the big racetrack in the sky. Before she left me, she told me that if there 
was lightning outside, that meant that she had won another race. I have 
been counting and Genie has won six times already. I hope I am better at 
racing this time around so I can light up the sky for Mike and Caper.
Well, I am going to go tell the humans it is time for me to make room 
for another deserving retired racer in their home. I hope they get another 
female so that Sharon has someone to take her side in a fight. Steve 
already has a big head and if they have three more males in the 
house...well you paint your own picture (can someone say Mr. Potato 
Head?).
But before I go, I need to tell them that they should not be sad for me. I 
have had a great life and can’t wait to swap stories of life as an adoptee 
with all the other former racers in doggie heaven. I bet they’ll all get a big 
hoot from my making Sharon taller story.
Greyhound adoption has been the greatest invention since the couch or 
loveseat (or maybe cake and ice cream). I can’t thank my trainers, Kirk 
and Julie, and my humans, Steve and Sharon, for giving me such a great 
opportunity to live a royal life.
People who adopt greyhounds are the best. So let me say in closing to 
everyone who has adopted or is about to adopt a fellow greyhound, thank 
you very much.
Greyhound adoption is a very easy and worthwhile endeavor. There are 
two greyhound adoption agencies in the area plus some trainers on the 
track do their own adoptions.
The Ebro Greyhound Park operates an adoption program on the track. 
And Jennifer Cullen operates Valentine Adoptions out of her home in 
Washington County.
The adoption process is very easy. All you need to do is contact the 
track or Cullen and an application can be sent or picked up. Once the 
application is completed and returned, and your references and home has 
been approved, you will be matched up with the perfect greyhound.
It is suggested you have a fenced in yard to give your greyhound room to 
exercise. With Cullen, it is a requirement while with the on track 
adoption, greyhounds can be adopted to those without a fence. You do not 
need a large security fence, as greyhounds as a rule do not jump. A cattle 
fence fully enclosed is acceptable.
Also, some greyhounds are compatible with cats or other animals. So if 
you already have another dog or a cat, that does not disqualify you from 
adopting a greyhound.
Cullen has her greyhound adoptees spayed or neutered, has all shots 
given and has the greyhound’s teeth cleaned before she completes the 
adoption process.
With Ebro’s adoption center, if the greyhound is not spayed or 
neutered, you must sign a form saying you will do so. And, if for any 
reason the adoption does not work out, the greyhound must be returned to 
Valentine Adoption Center or the track adoption center.
To adopt a greyhound, call Tammy Hess at the Ebro Greyhound Park 
at 234-3943 or Jennifer at Valentine Adoptions at 850-265-6667.
Note from Steve:
We did adopt a female greyhound, Coffee, after Dottie’s death. And 
after Caper suddenly died in 1998, we took in another female, Mimi, 
leaving Mike and myself a definite minority in the home.

-----Original Message-----
From: Linda [mailto:thirdeyegrafix@earthlink.net]
Sent: Sunday, May 26, 2002 10:28 AM
To: Alachua Greens; Linda Young; Kathy Cantwell; Matt Hurst; Louis Clark; Holly Leber; Dwight & Joanne Adams; Irma Harris; Sierra member; Sierra member; Cynthia Chestnut; Roberta Gastmayer; David Auth; Linda Pollini; Board of County Commissioners; chris bird; Struhs, David; Brumberg, J. Benjamin; Florida Radio Networks; Florida Radio News; floridagreens council; High Springs Herald; Jacksonville; letters lake city reporter; Pensacola News Journal; Sally Warrick; Sarasota letters; Sun Sentinel; Skipper Hammond; Saint Petersburg; Tallahassee Democrat; Tampa Tribune; Weekly Planet
Cc: Busy Kislig Shires; town square
Subject: Ichetucknee Cement Plant Delay


Gainesville Sun Article, May 25, 2002 by Sun Staff Writer, Ron Matus: 

 A State Agency Maintains that Suwannee American Cement has not Obeyed the Terms of a 1999 Settlement: 


    State environmental officials and the company building a cement plant near the Ichetucknee River are clashing again, this time over air pollution monitoring data the company agreed it would have before the plan t could open. 
    In an unusually blunt letter to the company Friday, the Department of Environmental Protection said without the data, company plans to operate the controversial plant are "in serious jeopardy." 
    Officials with Suwannee American Cement fear the latest dispute with DEP may delay the plant's opening as long as two years, with millions of dollars in lost sales. 
    "You're talking about a $100 million investment here," said company spokesman Jim McClellan. 
    At issue is a 1999 settlement agreement between Suwannee American and DEP. 
    The agency agreed to give the plant a permit--and reverse a decision to deny the permit five months earlier--in return for a list of concessions, including a company promise to provide more than two years" worth of background air pollution data before the plant starts burning coal to make cement. 
    The data would allow the state to compare pollution levels before and after the plant begins to operate. 
    Suwannee American says it hasn't been able to provide the data because two sophisticated pollution monitors it bought from an Atlanta company in 2000 turned out to be, in the words of Suwannee's consultant, "lemons." 
    "If we knew we were going to have the continuous problems...we would have gotten some other monitors," said John Koogler with Gainesville-based Koogler & Associates. 
    Koogler said he finally "got the bugs worked out" in March, which would give the company nine months' worth of data before the plant's anticipated opening early next year. 
    The company promised 27 months worth of data in the settlement. 
    In March, DEP fined Suwannee American $15,000 for not having the monitors up and running as promised. 
    On Friday, it issued an ominous warning. 
    "Because this data collection requirement is intended to provide important baseline air quality information before the plant becomes operational, your ability to bring the plant on line is in serious jeopardy," wrote DEP Deputy Secretary Allan Bedwell to plant manager Robert Sagmeister. 
    "While additional legal notices regarding this issue are forthcoming, do not make plans or have any expectations to test or operate the plant in question until this issue is resolved." 
    The letter's tone rattled company officials. 
    "This didn't just come out of left field," McClellan said. "This came out of the cheap seats." 
    Koogler called it "a Friday afternoon shocker." 
    McClellan said the company was trying to arrange a meeting with DEP as soon as possible to "find some reasonable solution." 
    "The question that needs to be asked is: Are we holding up this business and these jobs for legitimate scientific reasons," he said, "or is this an arbitrary time period?" 
    DEP Secretary David Struhs could not be reached for comment Friday afternoon. 
    Other DEP officials who were reached said they could not comment or were not familiar with Bedwell's letter. 
        The flare-up is the latest round in a 3 and one half year battle between DEP and Suwannee American, an affiliate of Lake City road builder Anderson Columbia Inc. 
    In June 1999, DEP stunned environmentalists by denying a permit, saying the company could not provide "reasonable assurance" it would operate the plant safely because of Anderson Columbia's long list of environmental violations. It was the first time DEP had denied a permit on those grounds. 
    But the settlement agreement was announced five months later. Now the plant is under construction off U.S. 27 in Suwannee County, 3 miles west of the Ichetucknee River and 40 miles north of Gainesville. 
    It will burn 100,000 tons of coal and used tires each year and employ 80 people. 
    The monitors required in the settlement measure particulates, dust-like pollutants that can cause lung problems if inhaled. 
    Koogler said the monitors collected data while they were on the fritz, just not as much as DEP requires. There is still enough information for the agency to know what typical background levels are for particulates in that area, he said. 
    Getting data over a longer period of time will allow DEP to see the ups and downs in pollution levels during different seasons, when winds, rain and other weather conditions come into play. 
    The latest development surprised both critics and supporters. 
    But Tallahassee activist Linda Young, a leading opponent of the plant, remained skeptical about DEP's intentions. 
    "Don't believe it for a second," she said about the agency's new attitude. 
    If DEP intended to enforce the settlement agreement, it would have jumped on the company just a few months after it was signed, when Anderson Columbia was being cited for environmental violations on a road project in the Panhandle. 
    The dispute in that case remains unresolved and likely to head to court. 
    The Friday letter is "posturing and bluffing and boob-dazzling the public," she said. "When the rubber hits the road, they're going to cave to political pressure." 
    At least one Suwannee County commissioner who strongly supported the plant gave DEP a thumbs up. 
    "I'd have a problem if DEP allowed a company to open without meeting the agreement," said Commissioner Doug Udell. As for the jobs, "You can't miss what you don't have," he said 
_______________________________________________________ 
Ron Matus can be reached at (352) 374-5087 or ron.matus@gainesvillesun.com

(Below is a copy of the advertisement now being published in national higher education newspapers for your information)
 
FLORIDA BOARD OF EDUCATION

CHANCELLOR, DIVISION OF COMMUNITY

COLLEGES

Florida is in the midst of sweeping education reorganization. 

Florida's entire education system is being transformed into a new seamless

K-20 system; breaking new ground by uniting heretofore separate delivery

systems of public schools, community colleges, and universities under one

governance board. These newly developed relationships offer new and

exciting opportunities to (1) develop policy in a cohesive and strategic

manner, (2) work collaboratively with all education sectors, (3) allocate

resources according to K-20 priorities, and (4) deliver important education

services cooperatively and effectively.

The Florida Board of Education

invites nominations and applications for the position of Chancellor of

Division of Community Colleges. The successful candidate must possess

significant demonstrated and proven effective leadership experience;

preferably with education institutions or a high level position in an

education related organization. Applicants must have distinguished

themselves in higher education policy, administration or management. 

Master's degree required; doctorate or other terminal degree preferred. 

 

For best consideration application materials should be received prior to

June 7, 2002. Review of applications will begin immediately and continue

until an appointment is made. Application materials should include a

letter addressing how the candidates' experiences match the position

requirements, a curriculum vita, and the names, title, email and business

addresses, business and home telephone numbers of at least five references,

which include faculty, administrators, and community leaders. Submission

of materials as an MS Word attachment is strongly encouraged. Individuals

wishing to nominate candidates for the position should submit a letter of

nomination, including the name, position, address, and telephone number of

the nominee. Requests for information, written nominations, and application

materials should be directed to: 

Jan Greenwood, Ph.D.

Vice President

From:	Mary Johnson <johnsonm@osceola.k12.fl.us>
Sent:	Tuesday, May 28, 2002 1:49 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Fast Growing Osceola

Dear Governor Bush,

For the past five years, Osceola has been the fastest growing county in
Florida.  During the next five years, we're again projected to be the
fastest growing county.  I'm writing to ask you to not veto the money that
the legislature has approved to help us cope with this uncontrollable
growth of one classroom a day. 

*Osceola County has received the lowest amount, per capita, for school
construction in the state for the past five years.

*Osceola County has one of the highest percentages of students in charter
schools in the State.

* Osceola County is the only County in the state that has exhausted all
local sources for school construction:
- Levying a full 2 mills
- Sharing in the Local Option Sales Tax
- Levying the highest School Impact Fees in the State
- Levying additional mills for a School Construction Bond Issue
- Established seven charter schools
- Using all effort index dollars
- Using all classroom 1st dollars

This money would be a tremendous help in ensuring the best education that
we can give to our students.  Please don't veto this much needed funding.

Thank you!

Mary Johnson
OASIS Volunteer Program Specialist
Osceola School District
407 870-4080
