From: SteveJeana@aol.com [mailto:SteveJeana@aol.com]
Sent: Tuesday, May 28, 2002 9:02 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: alia.faraj@dca.state.fl.us; steve.seibert@dca.state.fl.us
Subject: Steve's BIG BULLET POINTS ON GROWTH MANAGEMENT
Dear Governor,

As promised, here are some "big picture" thoughts on the gm bill....based on speeches given during the last few weeks.

1.  Most significant reform of growth management since the law's enactment in 1985.

2.  Remarkable consensus built to support the bill.  Unanimous vote in House, nearly so in Senate.  Democrat and Republican supported this bill, as did the Florida Homebuilders and 1000 Friends of Florida, the Florida Chapter of the American Planning Association and the Community Developers, the Save the Manatee Club and the Florida Agricultural Coalition, the League of Cities and the Association of Counties.  Unusual coalition for such a contraversial subject.

3.  Many good ideas in bill (it is 156 pages long), but most important elements are better school planning and better water planning...

     a. We have about 18 months for every school board, county commission and city in Florida to enter into an Interlocal Agreement.  The Agreement must address where schools are planned to be built and where they are planned to be closed, what infrastructure will be needed to serve the schools, where the community's growth is planned to occur and how these local governments will resolve their disputes.  Exactly how school boards and local governments address these issues is not mandated; the requirement that they enter into an enforcable agreement is. (Legislature funded $550,000 to DCA to implement these plans; Governor had asked for $3 million, but its good to actually fund a planning initiative)

     b. In like fashion, cities and counties must work with Water Management Districts to better plan for their water supply.  Local governments must integrate the WMDs' Regional Water Supply Plans into their comprehensive plans and must develop a 10 year workplan for building enough water supply to serve current citizens and projected population growth.

4.  The bill contains provisions which,
-reduce bureaucracy
-contemplate new funding sources for school construction
-broaden a citizen's right to contest a land use decision
-strengthen manatee and natural resource protection through "boating facility siting plans"
-and calls for a better analysis of annexations and local government service delivery.

5.  The bill is a significant step forward; true reform, however, will be determined by commitment of local leaders to these planning initiatives...

6.  Certain legislators truly helpful:
-Sen. Constantine understands the subject matter and guided the bill, from the beginning, through the Senate
-Senators Lee and Pruitt very helpful in giving advice in how to deal with Senate
-Rep. Murman filed the "school planning bill" in the House and was a solid supporter throughout the process
-Rep. Carassas filed the other portions of the bill and held off unfriendly amendments; he's a city attorney by trade, so is knowledgable about the issues
-Rep. Bennett was a consistent supporter and spoke for the bill on the floor...he also agreed to hold off unfriendly amendments
-Rep. Atkinson added the "educational facilities benefit districts" section and spoke for the bill on the floor
-Rep. Henriquez was consulted regularly (he's a planner by trade) and he urged Democrats to support the bill on the floor

...once we know who will be attending the bill signing(s), we will provide additional details.

Governor, for your consideration...I did not go through the proper PIO channels with this email.  It supplements the very detailed information you will receive from others.  You're the man-see you Friday.

Steve

property, suggested that the buildings be removed.  We also had removed
these strucures in preparation for the County to implement the "Long Branch
Park" resource management plan.  County efforts are being refocused so
plans for this area are currently on hold.

At this time I am unable to construct a pole barn or other buildings on the
Long Branch parcel until management guidelines for the property are agreed
upon by the District and the County.

Dear Sir or Madame,
Greetings on behalf of the Bithlo Citizens Advisory  Council, Chairman,
Cory E. Goodman.

I am writing to request permission to erect a  weather shelter on the
public land which was purchased by your agency several  years ago.
I was provided permission to access the property  from Doug Voltolina while
he was in charge of the parcel located south of Bithlo  on the Econ river.
At the time,several buildings were on the property  which served as weather
shelters for our residents.
Shortly after Doug was promoted to Brevard county  the buildings were
demolished, even though Pete Henn promised that a pole barn  would remain
to serve as a shelter. Not only was the pole barn destroyed, but in
addition, a horse stable, log cabin and tool shed were destroyed for no
apparent  reason. Leaving the children and other residents of our community
without any  shelter on the property.

Although I do not understand or agree with the  demolition of the
buildings, I am writing to inquire what process our community  would have
to follow to erect a new shelter, at no cost to the taxpayers, for  our
children to use in the storms that are sure to come this  summer.
I myself was caught in a storm a few weeks ago and  ruined a very expensive
saddle, due to not having a shelter from the  storm.
Again, I will provide the labor and material to  erect a small pole barn
type shelter, similar to those on the St. Johns River,  which are used by
the public in foul weather, with your permission.

I thank you in advance for any advice and guidance  you may provide in this
matter.

Respectfully yours,
Cory E. Goodman, Chairman
Bithlo Citizens Advisory Council
258 S. County Rd. 13
Orlando, Florida 32833
(407)568-8323

Subject: DGA Production Centers





May 23, 2002




Memo to:  Florida Filmmakers & friends
From:         Rick Pamplin
RE:            DGA Production Centers

I received a letter from the Directors Guild of America (DGA) today informing me of the following:

The DGA is revising areas currently designated as production centers.

Effective July 1, 2002, the following area will no longer be considered production centers:

                                     1. Dallas, TX
                                     2. Boston, MA
                                     3. Miami, FL
                                     4. Orlando, FL
                                     5. Atlanta, GA

The DGA production centers effective July 1, 2002 will be:

                                     1. Los Angeles, CA
                                     2. Chicago, IL
                                     3. San Francisco, CA
                                     4. New York, NY
                                     5. Wilmington, NC
                                     6. Vancouver, BC Canada
                                     7. Toronto, ON Canada                                     

All Florida DGA members must pick one of the above seven production centers as their new "local employment address."

Thought you would be interested.

RRP

> Ms. Matthews/Mr. Gaske:
> 
> The Governor and Secretary Harris are receiving numerous emails from
> Florida production professionals regarding this issue.  And they are not
> very nice.  There is a very simple way that your organization can address
> this issue, as it is quite serious. 
> 
> Write an open letter to the film industry and explain to them your bid
> process, let them know that Florida companies were given the opportunity
> to bid on this particular production job.  Assuming that this was a
> typical state agency open bidding process, I will assume that
> Florida-based production companies were given the opportunity to respond
> to your bid, and did so.  In this letter, share with the industry how many
> vendors responded (in-state and out-of-state), explain your selection
> process.  Share with them where, when and how your organization posts its
> production bids should there be a future opportunity.  Share with them
> your record of hiring Florida-based production vendors, and your
> commitment to give Florida-based production companies and workers a chance
> to earn your future business.
> 
> Both Visit Florida and Florida Citrus responded to this issue in this
> manner.  It does help to at a minimum, acknowledge the industry's
> concerns, and keep them on the radar screen for the future.
> 
> Our office would be more than happy to distribute your letter
> industry-wide.  Please forward it to my attention, and we will help to
> make better a rather unfortunate situation.
> 
> Best,
> RDM
> 
> 	 -----Original Message-----
> 	From: 	Mattingly, Rebecca  
> 	Sent:	Tuesday, May 21, 2002 6:02 PM
> 	To:	'jmatthews@dos.state.fl.us'; 'fgaske@mail.dos.state.fl.us'
> 	Cc:	Hugg, Ally
> 	Subject:	Video on Political History and Governance in Florida
> 
> 	Ms. Matthews/Mr. Gaske:
> 
> 	I received news yesterday that the office of the Florida Secretary
> of State has hired a production company in Washington, DC, to assemble a
> video on political history and governance in Florida. Will you please
> provide me with a confirmation, if this has actually occurred?
> 
> 	With open and fair bidding, and with all things being equal, the
> issue of keeping production dollars and jobs in Florida, which originate
> from state resources has been a hot and contentious issue in Florida's
> motion picture industry for many years. Currently Florida has numerous
> statutes, which address the desire of this state to support the
> development, growth and well being of Florida companies by giving them
> preference in the awarding of state contracts. Two of the most relevant
> are:
> 
> 	F.S. 287.082 - Commodities manufactured, grown, or produced in state
> given preference.
> 
> 	F. S. 287.084 - Preference to Florida businesses.
> 
> 	Local production companies are harmed in several significant ways as
> a result of this practice. First, tens of thousands of dollars in salaries
> and profit markups are paid to the out-of-state production company every
> time it is awarded a contract.  Second, these dollars could have stayed in
> Florida, and used to help a Florida company cover expenses and to support
> the creation and maintenance of Florida jobs.
> 
> 	In some ways more damaging is the ability of an out-of-state
> production company to then feature the commercials funded by Florida state
> agencies on their promotional show reels.  This creates the impression
> that Florida companies were, or are not good enough to do Florida state
> business. In addition, these show reels can be used against Florida
> companies in the competition for current or future bids. 
> 	Last summer, Visit Florida and Citrus Commission produced two
> commercial productions, via the use of out-of-state production entities.
> When industry professionals alerted me to the issue, I then alerted Mr.
> Bud Nocera, COO and head of Marketing for Visit Florida, who immediately
> replaced a foreign production company with Floridians within 24 hours of
> my call to him.  In addition, Visit Florida's advertising agency is
> committed to working with our office on any future radio and/or television
> shoots.   Mr. Bob Morrissey, head of marketing for the Citrus Commission
> responded in the same manner.  The industry, as well as I, appreciate
> their immediate attention and action.  I strongly urge the Florida Dept.
> of State, Division of Historical Resources to do the same.
> 	In 2000, the Governor asked our office to compile a report on the
> 2000 and 2001 production data from Florida's state agencies and economic
> development programs. This was to both to improve our working relationship
> with them, and to learn about their production data.  In our data
> collection, we also invited state agencies to provide us with their
> production bid information which we could then distribute to industry via
> our website and list serves.  All of the state agencies and programs
> willingly participated in our report and we hope to compile it on an
> annual basis.  
> 	During the last two years, the Office of Film & Entertainment has
> sought to close the gap between the film production industry and the
> advertising industry.  Last year, we created the Production Partners
> Program, which is a networking and communications program created to
> encourage and foster the working relationship between Florida's
> advertising and the film & entertainment industries.  By forging grass
> roots activities between local American Advertising Federation (AAF),
> District 4, Florida Club chapters and local film offices, the goal of the
> Production Partners program is to encourage cross utilization of
> resources, information and job sharing between both industries thereby
> strengthening Florida's economy by keeping production business "at home."
> 	The Office of Film & Entertainment has also created a promotional
> program called Florida Discounts & Deals. This program will promote the
> various discounts and special deals (i.e. hotel deals and other special
> offers) that are being offered around the state, which could possibly be
> helpful or useful to the film industry.  To date, we have nearly 100
> vendors, hotels, etc. participating in this program.  In fact, it was your
> Washington DC production vendor that contacted one of our Florida-based
> vendors regarding the use of stock Florida footage for your video.
> 	After the September 11 tragedy, many of Florida's critical
> industries suffered tremendous jobs losses.  From tourism and aviation, to
> the motion picture industry sector the state's efforts to save and protect
> these industries went into high gear.  Governor Bush continued his focus
> on this issue by drafting personal letters and emails to all of Florida's
> tourism organizations, state's agencies, including Florida Cabinet
> agencies and Florida advertising agencies urging them to keep their
> production jobs and dollars in Florida.  Perhaps this communication was
> not shared with your particular division.  Further, the Senate Committee
> on Commerce and Economic Opportunities continued to raise awareness of
> this issue by conducting a hearing on the practice of state agencies
> utilizing Florida-based production and advertising resources.
> 	If you have a production bid for a commercial, or a still
> photography shoot, give Florida vendors consideration before you look out
> of state.  Send us your bids, and we will make them available to
> Florida-based production vendors on our website. The workforce is
> experienced, the infrastructure strong.   Our homegrown businesses,
> services, talent and resources play a vital role in contributing to
> Florida's economy.  The Office of Film & Entertainment, located within the
> Governor's Office of Tourism, Trade, and Economic Development, is your

(http://www.dc.state.fl.us/oth/vtour/index.html) was selected as a Hot Site
in today's edition of USATODAY.com a free and highly popular news service on
the World Wide Web.

		Just as we do with top-rated movies and TV programs, we look
daily for Web sites that are likely to be sure hits with readers -- sites
that seek to astound and delight, inform or amuse -- by exhibiting something
remarkable in graphics, content or both.

		Check out our Tech section at
http://www.usatoday.com/life/cyber/cyber1.htm to find your listing, either
today in the Hot Sites page or later in the archive of previous days' Hot
Site reviews.

		Feel free to tell the online world by displaying our "Hot
Site" logo. If you decide to do so, please put the following hyperlink code
in your document rather than downloading our gif. That helps protect our
copyright and also provides a convenient way for your readers to see what we
said about you. Here's the code that includes our pulsating gif:

		<A HREF="http://www.usatoday.com/life/cyber/cyber1.htm"><IMG

TODAY AWARD"></A>

SRC="http://www.usatoday.com/life/cyber/usatstat.gif" ALIGN="BOTTOM"

Cc:	Gil Ziffer (E-mail); Guy Spearman (E-mail); Sasha Erickson (E-mail)
Subject:	Social Norms - USA TODAY

In case you missed today's USA TODAY I wanted to forward today's USA TODAY
piece on Social Norms Marketing.  This approach continues to be an important
and effective approach being used to address college drinking issues. 

The kids are all right 'Social norming' may be the strategy to keep them
that way 
By Karen Thomas
USA TODAY 
Are kids really that bad? 
Nine out of every 10 college students have never damaged property because
they were drunk or high. Three out of four have never blown an exam or
school project because of drugs or alcohol. Ninety-nine percent of students
who drink do not have unwanted sex. 
Most kids don't go out and get trashed every night. 
Each year, more students choose to abstain from alcohol. Fewer choose to
smoke and do drugs. 
Death by alcohol-related accidents or suicide is rare. 
The widespread impression that the norm for today's young people is drunken
debauchery simply isn't true. Most kids are OK. It's the best-kept secret on
college campuses, and a growing number of experts believe that keeping all
this good news quiet is doing far more harm than good. 
Parents are often the most unaware, and they fear the worst when they send
kids off to college, says Michael Haines, a substance-abuse expert at
Northern Illinois University in DeKalb. Students today take very seriously
the risks of drinking, he says, ''yet parents are being sold a bill of
goods, with kids portrayed in number-crunching stories as drunken, reckless,
careless boozers.'' 
Haines is the father of a grassroots movement among prevention educators
called ''social norming,'' and it's gaining fast favor on college campuses.
The premise is quite simple, but completely at odds with today's accepted
practice of scaring teens away from risky behaviors. 
Social norming operates on this notion: If the general impression is that
most kids don't drink alcohol, then those who do drink will drink less, and
fewer will start drinking in the first place. The key is to not over-report
the incidences of dangerous drinking that occur, and to broadly promote the
general good health of students so that it is perceived as normal not to
drink. 
At least 30 college campuses nationwide, including the universities of
Arizona, North Carolina, Oregon and Missouri, Rutgers University and 23
campuses of the California State University system, have joined the social
norming bandwagon to curb drinking among students. Dartmouth, home of the
Animal House legend, is currently in the market to hire an educator with
social norming experience. 
The philosophy has begun trickling down to high schools and middle schools
and has been expanded to target other risky behaviors, including smoking. 
It's viewed as an odd duck among health and safety educators, who
traditionally have been a polarized group of ''those who think we should
just crack down because people are dying and those civil libertarians who
preach 'kids will be kids,' '' says Drew Hunter, executive director of the
Bacchus & Gamma Peer Education Network, a Denver-based coalition of 1,000
colleges and universities that deals with health and safety issues. 
Campuses in general have seen little change in student drinking patterns,
despite comprehensive and consistent anti-drinking programs, Hunter says.
The social norming effort is showing results ''by promoting health, not
death and destruction.'' 
Easier said than done, says E. Scott Geller, psychology professor at
Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University in Blacksburg, who is
less encouraged and feels ''more hard evidence is needed that it really does
decrease alcohol consumption campuswide.'' A social norming project there
has been successful at reducing student drinking, ''particularly among
women.'' But ''when we measure drinking at frat parties, we're not seeing
much of a change.'' The environment at those brotherhood blowouts, he says,
''overpowers social norms.'' 
Nationwide, Haines says, ''the simple norm is that most students are
drinking moderately, if at all, and are not harming anyone, and they'll
(mature into) effective, capable people.'' 
The social norming program works by simply reframing the same data that
traditionally highlights the minority of students who are boozing up heavily
and presenting it with a focus on the majority who aren't. The statistics
most often used on a national level are those from the ongoing Harvard
School of Public Health College Alcohol Study, National College Health
Assessment and the Core Alcohol and Drug Survey, all of which look at
college drinking patterns. The annual Monitoring the Future Study focuses on
students in grades 8, 10 and 12. 
Campuses develop their own norming programs by polling students and feeding
back to them -- in the form of posters, pencils, Frisbees and bumper
stickers -- data about the majority who aren't drinking, smoking or engaging
in other risky behavior. 
Funny thing, though, is that most students are surprised, since most
students -- like most parents -- think most kids are drinking and smoking.
That simply fuels the problem, says Lydia Gerzel Short, who is behind the
nation's first social norming program for high school students. Her
three-year program in two DeKalb County high schools has seen drinking and
smoking drop significantly faster than the national trends. 
With prom season in full swing, she says, many kids are getting subtle
messages from parents and teachers suggesting drinking is the norm.
''Parents will tell them, 'I know everyone will be drinking, so don't drink
and drive.' Teachers will tell them, too: 'I know everyone will be drinking
. . . ' But everyone won't be drinking. Most won't,'' she says. Yet kids who
hear those well-meaning mantras think, ''I want to fit in. I want to
belong.'' 
''Misperceptions create a silent majority,'' says Jan Gascoigne, director of
health promotions with Bacchus & Gamma, which last fall launched a
six-campus project with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to
study how social norming might curb college smoking. When the University of
Washington in Seattle polled students in 1999, it found that students
believed nearly 95% of the student body smoked. In reality, about one-third
were smokers. 
''Social norming breaks down that perception,'' says Gascoigne. ''If I'm a
student, and I think 95% of everybody smokes, there's a perception that
that's what people do here. Potentially that becomes my behavior because I
want to fit in.'' 
The drop in the rate of student smoking at the University of
Wisconsin-Oshkosh after last year's social-norm marketing campaign was so
astonishing, officials are reluctant to release the data nationally because
some population quirk may have skewed the numbers. The results: a 29% drop
in student smoking, or one out of three smokers quit. 
''We're saying, 'Whoa, we're a bunch of local yokels from Oshkosh,' '' says
Mike Altekruse, a counseling center psychologist. ''Maybe a cohort of
non-smokers came through, or maybe some DARE program really worked? It's a
little premature to say we're a great success.'' 
Like many colleges and universities that try social norming,
Wisconsin-Oshkosh turned to it as a ''last resort'' because nothing else was
making a dent in student drinking and smoking, Altekruse says. ''We
well-meaning health educators . . . just keep giving them knowledge that
it's unhealthy, and we hope they'll quit drinking. But they don't.'' 
Hunter is optimistic: ''We've begun to see with the social norming
movement,'' he says, ''that schools that have added that component have seen
significant reduction in drinking rates.''

From:	SFOXROSELLINI@aol.com
Sent:	Tuesday, May 28, 2002 6:24 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Funding for the Coconut Grove Playhouse

Support Funding for the Coconut Grove Playhouse!

Dear Governor Bush

As a member of its Board of Trustees I support the appropriation item number 3130A that provides for operating funding to the Coconut Grove Playhouse in the amount of $500,000.  The entire Dade Delegation and their colleagues in Tallahassee support it as well. The Playhouse is one of the cultural jewels of not only Miami-Dade County but of our state.

The Playhouse was built in 1926 as a Paramount Movie theater. It was converted to a legitimate theater in 1956.  In 1926-27 my great-grandfather developed a technology that put sound on film and thus the talking motion picture was born.  He went on to develop a company that is known today as 20th Century Fox. It had 2000 movie theaters around the country.   Today, 4 remain; the Fox in Atlanta, St Louis, Detroit and San Diego all have been converted to live theaters. We have helped in saving each.  

Each one has major ongoing local and state support.  This funding appropriated by the legislature is vital to the survival of the Playhouse.  The Playhouse and all of the theaters have become vital cultural hubs in their cities and economic engines in their areas. 

Please support this appropriation.

Thank you for your continued support of the Coconut Grove Playhouse.

Sincerely,

Susan Fox Rosellini
Director
William Fox Jr. Foundation

-----Original Message-----
From: Rick Michaels <rmichaels@ceaworldwide.com>
To: Jeb Bush <jeb@jeb.org>
CC: Slater Bayliss <slater@jeb.org>; Chris Hart (E-mail) <hart.chris@leg.state.fl.us>
Sent: Tue May 28 16:15:32 2002
Subject: Florida Driver License - Security

Governor Bush,

Fred Dickinson of the Department of Motor Vehicles is considering an advanced encrypted and compressed barcode to be placed on Florida driver licenses.  Remarkably, Florida is one of eight states without barcodes on driver licenses.

The SSI system, developed by a company in Birmingham who principally contracts to US Intelligence agencies, is very advanced and allows several pages of information and biometrics to be included - fingerprints, etc.

It is worth considering this technology not only for public safety aspects, but higher level security for certain locations (airports, ports, etc.)

Best regards,

Rick

From: Robert Hosmon <rhosmon@miami.edu>

In the past two months, my students have:

Won the grand prize for best newscast at the National Broadcasting
Society convention (in competition with 93 other university entries).
They're won the grand prize in that category five times in the past ten
years.

Won the best newcast award from the Florida Associate Press.  A first
for us; FSU is always a major competitor.

Won two prestigious, national "Telly" awards for production of "UMIQ," a
college quiz program, and "42nd Street Uncovered," a documentary.
Open to all cable and satellite television production, this is not a
student competition.

In addtion three of my journalism students won highly competitive summer
fellowships, one from the Freedom Forum (a $1000 scholarship and a paid
internship at the Louisville Courier-Journal), the Academy of
Alternative Journalism (funded by newspapers like The Village Voice and
The New Times,  the fellowship includes a free summer's study at
Northwestern's Medill School of Journalism and a $3,000 stipend; over
800 students applied for 10 openings), and the National Gay and Lesbian
Task Force (which includes a $5000 scholarship and a job writing for the
media about the pending election to repeal Miami-Dade's Human Rights
Ordinance).

It's so much fun to have this job.  Hope all is well with you.

Bob

Governor Bush,
   I'm currently volunteering for a local organization called MainStreet
Perry. The organization's goal is to improve business and tourism in
Perry and Taylor County.
   We're in the processing of applying for a grant to renovate an old
train depot and turn it into a visitors center and business incubator.
It's a good project for a good cause, and I'm hoping to get your support
on it. All I need from you is a signed letter of support for the
project. We're gathering these from a variety of officials, including
folks like Allen Boyd and Will Kendrick.
   Is there someone in your office with whom you can put me in contact
to handle this? I can send them a couple of sample support letters and a
copy of the grant (it's fairly short). They can draw up a brief letter
of support for you to sign, if you're willing. It shouldn't take more
than about 15 minutes of an assistant's time.
   Hope you can help.

 <http://www.sptimes.com/2002/03/26/news_pf/TampaBay/Agencies_build_up__da.shtml> printer version 	




Agencies build up, dash modeling dreams



Authorities are investigating modeling agents who charge big fees for photos and promise jobs that don't materialize. 


By TIM GRANT, Times Staff Writer
© St. Petersburg Times
published March 26, 2002 

  _____  


TAMPA -- At 79, Lois Krebs is not the typical runway fashion model. But she thought she might find a place in ads that appeal to senior citizens. 


"I had a notion I could do what I saw other people my age doing on television," said Krebs, a great-grandmother. 


The first agent she met at Models 2000 Inc. told Krebs she had a distinctive look that companies want to sell their products. When Krebs got no work there, she tried another agent at Boom Talent & Modeling Agency, who also fed her hopes for a successful modeling career. 


Krebs says that between the two agencies, she paid about $1,200 for photographs they said she needed to launch her career. But they quit calling after she bought the photographs. And a year later, Krebs still has no work as a model. 


Her story is common in Tampa Bay's talent and modeling community. 


A handful of agencies here have gained a reputation for making money off expensive photographs after promising to find modeling work for people who have little chance of being models. 


Now Krebs and about 40 others who bought photographs at Models 2000 have written affidavits supporting a Hillsborough County civil lawsuit against its owner, Nancy Sniffen. And Tampa police say they are conducting a criminal investigation of the agency at 4844 W Gandy Blvd. 


"I want her shut down and I want restitution paid to the other victims," said Rick West, a retired Detroit firefighter, who is suing Sniffen on behalf of his 17-year-old daughter Christy, who paid $855 and got only photos, not jobs. 


Sniffen, who also uses the last name Keogh, declined to comment for this report. 


Although there are no complaints against Models 2000 on record with the state agency that oversees the talent and modeling industry, dozens of customers say they have aired their grievances with the Department of Business and Professional Regulation. 


Some also have complained to the Tampa Police Department, prompting a criminal investigation that began last year, said police spokeswoman Katie Hughes. She said the department will not comment on the case in progress. 


A spokesman for the state Attorney General's Office said authorities in Tampa have received complaints about Models 2000, but because state law gives DBPR jurisdiction over modeling agencies, that agency will handle the case. 


West and other former customers of Models 2000 said they have been contacted by an investigator from DBPR, though officials at the state agency will not confirm a formal probe. 


The lawsuit West filed against Sniffen in March 2001 accuses her of fraud, trickery and misrepresentation. 


According to West's lawsuit, Christy answered a newspaper ad in January 2000 seeking teen models for print, movie and fashion work. It seemed like a job with high pay and travel opportunities. She ended up paying $855 for photographs, but Sniffen never got her a modeling job. 


"I said that's a lot of money and we can't afford it," said West's wife, Fiona, who was with her daughter at the interview with the agency. "But (Sniffen) said Christy would make that money back in no time because she had a partner in Atlanta connected with J.C. Penney Co., who could get Christy in the catalog." 


West said he eventually asked Sniffen to refund the money and she refused. When he learned that the state would not order a refund, he filed a lawsuit and began looking for other unhappy customers. 


Using the Internet and word-of-mouth, he found about 40 of them. Several informed J.C. Penney that Sniffen had promised them jobs with the company. 


Alan Langer, a lawyer for the department store chain in Dallas, wrote Sniffen on July 13, 2001, ordering her to stop using the retail company in her sales pitch. 


"As you know, such representations are false," the letter said. 


One of the people West found was Gina Hughes, a former Models 2000 customer who also was busy locating former customers. 


Hughes said she paid $1,040 for photographs of her 3-year-old daughter, Gabriella. She said her bank refunded $700 after it investigated her complaint. Now she wants to keep others from going through what she did. 


She remembers the people she met the day of her daughter's photo shoot at Models 2000: a farm worker who hoped her daughter could help generate income for the family; a single mother with her preschool son; and a beautiful Brazilian woman who did not speak English. 


"I saw the people who were there and I just think they need their money back," Hughes said. 


According to state law, talent and modeling agents are not supposed to charge models for anything, including photos, seminars or consultation. An agent's income is supposed to come solely from commissions received through finding work for models. 


In Carrollwood, modeling agent Di Paulson has had multiple complaints against her in recent years for selling photos and other products through a second company that she ran inside her Boom Talent & Modeling office. Paulson has since moved her business to Safety Harbor. She did not return telephone messages seeking comment. 


Publishers of the Florida Bluesheet, an industry newsletter in Orlando, hear many of the complaints about bad business practices throughout the state. They say Tampa Bay has a few agencies that give the area a bad name. 


"We get more complaints from Tampa than Miami, which is surprising because Miami has more agencies," said Gersh Morningstar, Florida Bluesheet's publisher. 


Morningstar said many complaints involve agents slow to pay models after a job. With Models 2000 and Boom Talent & Modeling, the complaints almost always involves people who say they have paid for overpriced, poor-quality pictures with hopes of modeling careers that didn't happen. 


One Tampa modeling agency that consistently gets jobs for its clients is Alexa Model & Talent at 4100 W Kennedy Blvd., which has been in business since 1988. 


"We make our money off people working," said owner Susan Schwabinger. "We don't just take anyone on as a model because if they don't work, we're not making money." 


Still, she said she cannot always predict which models will make it big. "There are no guarantees," she said. "This is the most unpredictable business in the world." 


-- Tim Grant can be reached at 269-5311 or at grant@sptimes.com.

   <mhtml:mid://00000123/!http://www.sptimes.com/nav_graphics/rust.gif> 


From:	Jeb Bush
Sent:	Tuesday, May 28, 2002 7:05 PM
To:	Thelma W Parker
Subject:	RE: Lack of water in Florida

Ms. Parker, thank you for writing. We are doing something about it as you say. First, we are spending hundreds of millions of dollars (double the money before) on water protection and restoration projects. Secondly, on Friday, I am signing a growth management law which is the most comprehensive reform since the law was created in the 1980's. Included in this bill is a requirement of communities to include water resources as part of the development process. In addition, during my watch, we have complied with a law for the first time that gets the management districts to establish minimum levels and flows that will help us on a long term basis. We have done all of this during a severe draught that has strained the state immensely. 

I appreciate your writing and rest assured I take what you say seriously.

Jeb Bush 

***********************************************************
Please note: Florida has a very broad public records law.
Most written communications to or from state officials
regarding state business are public records available to the
public and media upon request.   Your e-mail communications
may therefore be subject to public disclosure. 



-----Original Message-----
From: Thelma W Parker [mailto:twpgg@juno.com]
Sent: Tuesday, May 28, 2002 1:25 PM
To: bush@eog.state.fl.us
Cc: Jeb Bush
Subject: Lack of water in Florida



Dear Governor bush,

        With much respect, I write to you because I am very worried about
the water situation in my state.  I really do believe you could do
something about it, if you tried.

        As you know, the lakes are drying up and there is a definite
water shortage.  I read recently that in six years we would have no more
water to use.  What are you doing about it?  Are you trying to do
anything?

        Why don't you see that no more building permits are given out to
developers and others who want to build.  Each time a house or apartment
is built, water will be used for drinking, cleaning, flushing toilets and
other things.  There is plenty of housing available without building any
more, until the water shortage is corrected.  

        Why are lakes still being drained when there is a storm, etc. 
This is ridiculous.  I was born in Daytona Beach, Florida.  I am now 80
years old and know of how life has been in the past, in this wonderful
state.  Years ago water was not taken from the lakes and there were no
major problems.  Now, my son-in-law cannot get his boat out of the shed
because it is dry.  

        I have lived a long time and I am smart.  I have learned.  I have
been aware of the changes going on in Florida.  Most of it is because of
greed.  Yes - - - - GREED.  You heard me.  Greed is the biggest culprit. 
All people can think of is making that almighty dollar.  They do not care
about the consequences of their deeds, as long as they get the money.

        A few months ago, I wrote to you about our land being gouged. 
Forests are being eliminated because of constant building of apartments
and housing, which is not needed.  The wild animals will soon have no
place to live.  You did not even give me the courtesy of answering my
letter.

        You are our Governor.  I voted for you but am very disappointed
is what is going on in Florida.  PLEASE GET BUSY AND DO SOMETHING ABOUT
IT.  I am pleading with you, sir.  

        I do hope you read this letter, for once.  I feel like your aides
do not give you things to read.  To me, this letter is very important.  

        Thank you for all you are doing for Florida.  

        Very sincerely,


        Thelma W. Parker
       
 190 Hibiscus Way
        Leesburg, Florida   34748
From:	Jeb Bush
Sent:	Tuesday, May 28, 2002 7:11 PM
To:	Thompson, Sandra 
Subject:	RE: Barbara Wilcox referral fup

so it is county run? I will check into this.

Jeb Bush 

***********************************************************
Please note: Florida has a very broad public records law.
Most written communications to or from state officials
regarding state business are public records available to the
public and media upon request.   Your e-mail communications
may therefore be subject to public disclosure. 



-----Original Message-----
From: Thompson, Sandra [mailto:Sandra.Thompson@morganstanley.com]
Sent: Tuesday, May 28, 2002 12:29 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: RE: Barbara Wilcox referral


My understanding is it's part of a 99 year lease (Lease #2564(?)) from TIIF
in 1971 which was amended in 2001 to include the spit of land (North Anclote
Sandbar) in question.

-----Original Message-----
From: Thompson, Sandra [mailto:Sandra.Thompson@morganstanley.com]
Sent: Friday, May 24, 2002 9:51 AM
To: 'Jeb@Jeb.com'; Jeb Bush
Subject: Barbara Wilcox referral


5/24/02

Governor Bush-

I recently spoke with Barbara Wilcox, my (favorite) aunt, asking her
advice
with an issue and she suggested I contact you to ask for your
assistance.
Just within the last 48 hours it has become obvious that time is of the
essence.

I have lived in Pinellas County and boated in the Gulf waters for over
20
years.  There are a number of islands which are part of the Gulf Islands
Geo
Parks System that many boaters visit and enjoy.  We (the boaters) have
peacefully co-existed with the various animals and shorebirds since
nature
created these islands.

Recently the Parks Department has begun to actively regulate and
restrict
our usage basing their actions on unsubstantiated data.  Signs have
appeared
"overnight" and law enforcement has begun patrolling the islands.  At
issue
are NO pets, NO overnight camping, NO camp fires, NO alcohol, NO
overnight
anchoring close to some of the islands.

"S.O.S." or Save Our Sandbar, a grass roots group of boaters was formed
to
explore the validity of the Parks claiming and enforcing jurisdiction on
the
islands.  As a result of group members contacting our elected officials
and
attending local government meetings a proposal was offered by the Parks
Department which we interpreted as a starting point for resolution to
this
issue. Discussion of the proposal was the main item on the agenda of our
May
22nd meeting.

In addition to a lawyer S.O.S. has retained to advise us on our options,
two
representatives from the Parks Department were at the meeting.  Since we
were to discuss our legal and non-legal options, the two gentlemen were
asked to leave.  I was in ear shot of the entire conversation and once
the
situation was explained, the two men left -it was all very amicable.
 
The very next morning the Fish & Wildlife Department showed up on the
North
Anclote Sandbar, erected signs and roped off a fairly large portion of
the
island.  They also informed boaters anchored there that this weekend
(Memorial Day) they would be heavily patrolling and enforcing the
restrictions.

Whether the actions of the Fish & Wildlife Department were in
retaliation of
the Parks Department representatives being asked to leave, who knows.
But I
fear this is going to escalate into something big and ugly...FAST.  Egos
are
taking over and emotions are starting to run high and unfortunately
those at
the extreme ends of this issue are going to push this past negotiating
and
into the courts.

I know you are an extremely busy man (oh, and thanks for keeping our
phone
bills down) but this issue cuts to the very core of citizens' rights to
enjoy where we have chosen to live and recreate.  Any intervention or
assistance on your part would be immensely appreciated.

Sandra L. Thompson
727/799-5819
727/452-5916

From:	Public Opinion Strategies <info@pos.org>
Sent:	Tuesday, May 28, 2002 5:20 PM
To:	info@pos.org
Subject:	Latest E-Answers: Congress Awaits Mid-Term Grades
Attachments:	Attachment information.; e18.pdf

While students around the nation finish term papers and final exams, 
Congress won’t receive its report card from the voters until 
November. The volatile political environment since September 11th is 
wreaking havoc with prognosticators’ predictions. Voters’ opinions of 
Congress itself have fluctuated wildly. From a thirty year high of 
85% approval in October 2001, Congressional job approval ratings have 
fallen back to pre-attack levels (along with a host of other key 
indicators). Today, 54% of American voters approve of the job 
Congress is doing, actually down one point from August 2001.

From:	Richard Harrow <tss.crharrow@worldnet.att.net>
Sent:	Tuesday, May 28, 2002 9:05 PM
To:	Hansen, Michael
Cc:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Re: Health Insurance Follow up

Dear Mr. Hansen,

Thank you for responding to my email, on behalf of Governor Bush. Your
detailed explanation of the bill is appreciated. However, I am one of
those individuals that have health problems so I have no other options
for getting alternate, lower cost, Health Care Insurance. My policy
renewal does not come up till next April. If the increase stays within
the 25% you indicated as the first increase, I may be able to tolerate
it for an additional year. If the increase is higher, I will probably be
contacting you again next year.

Sincerely,

C. Richard Harrow
Tech Sales Specialists, Inc


> "Hansen, Michael" wrote:
> 
> Dear Mr. Harrow:
> 
> Thank you for your e-mail to Governor Bush regarding SB 46E relating
> to health care.  The Governor has asked me to reply on his behalf.
> 
> Senate Bill 46-E includes a provision that has been characterized as
> allowing health insurers and HMOs to increase rates for self-employed
> individuals by 50%. What the bill actually allows is for small group
> carriers to separate the experience of small employer groups with less
> than two employees (one-life groups) from the experience of small
> employer groups with 2-50 employees for purposes of determining the
> rate. But, the rates for one-life groups may not exceed 150 percent of
> the modified community rate determined for small employer groups with
> 2-50 employees. For one-life groups who are insured on July 1, 2002,
> the limit is phased-in by being capped at 125% for the first renewal,
> and 150% for subsequent renewals.
> 
> Small group carriers are required to establish a modified community
> rate for policies sold to small employers. This means that the claims
> experience of all small employers written by a carrier must be pooled
> together so that each small employer is charged the same rate, as
> adjusted for geographic location and the age, gender, number of
> covered family members, and tobacco usage of each employee.
> Additionally, the rate may be raised or lowered up to 15% based on the
> health status or claims experience of the small employer.
> 
> Florida is one of few states that require small group carriers to
> guarantee-issue coverage to employers with less than two employees,
> including sole proprietors and self-employed individuals, which is
> limited to a 31-day open enrollment period in August of each year.
> Most states require guaranteed-issue only to employers with 2-50
> employees. The Florida law further requires that the claims experience
> of all small employers be combined in establishing the modified
> community rate. This has resulted in rates for one-life groups not
> being adequate to cover claims costs. Carriers consistently report
> that claims costs for one-life groups exceed premiums, typically by
> about 35%. This results in higher premiums for employers with 2-50
> employees, greater than needed to cover their claims costs, in order
> to subsidize the losses for the one-life groups. Another fallout is to
> discourage carriers from writing any business in the Florida small
> group market, which have steadily decreased in number from 116 small
> group carriers in 1997 to only 26 small group carriers identified by
> the Department of Insurance as currently writing coverage.
> 
> All parties agree that the problem of adverse selection exists with
> one-life groups. A single individual is able to control the decision
> of whether to buy health insurance for himself or herself. Therefore,
> persons most in need of coverage will buy it, causing claims costs to
> be higher than the average claims costs for employers with 2-50
> employees. Separately pooling one-life groups simply assures that all
> one-life groups will pay premiums that reflect their combined actual
> claims costs. But, the rate cannot exceed 150% of the rate for
> employers with 2-50 employees, so if costs reach this level, there can
> still be some subsidization from the larger employers.
> 
> All insurers and employers are currently experiencing a renewed cycle
> of increased costs and premiums countrywide. Rate increases of 20% to
> 30% are not uncommon, as medical costs increase and investment income
> decreases. There is no question that additional rate increases on
> one-life groups will be very difficult for many persons to afford. In
> terms of numbers of persons affected, for calendar year 2000, the
> Department of Insurance reported that for those carriers who were able
> to break out their small group enrollment by one life group vs. other,
> that 49,665 one-life groups represented 34.8 percent of total 141,801
> small employers insured. But in terms of covered lives, the one-life
> groups (and their covered dependents, totaling 101,643), represented
> only 8.2% of the 1,238,961 covered lives in the small group market.
> (There were 1,343,779 total covered lives in the small group market
> after adding those carriers that were not able to break out their
> one-life group enrollment.) Therefore, rates are likely to increase
> for about 100,000 persons and are likely to decrease for over 1.1
> million persons, due to this legislation.
> 
> One option for an affected sole proprietor is that if he or she is
> healthy enough to qualify for a medically underwritten individual
> health insurance policy, it is likely to be cheaper than a
> guaranteed-issue small group policy. Also, the legislation that passed
> (SB 46-E) includes a provision allowing carriers the freedom to offer
> small group policies with different deductibles, co-payments, and
> annual or lifetime maximum benefits, that would be cheaper than the
> current standard benefit plan and basic benefit plan that they also
> must continue to offer. This should result in lower cost options to
> all small employers.
> 
> I hope this information is helpful.
> 
> Mike Hansen
> Health and Human Services Policy Coordinator
> Governor's Office of Policy and Budget
> 850-488-7734
> 
> ---Original Message-----
> From: Richard Harrow [mailto:tss.crharrow@worldnet.att.net]
> Sent: Sunday, May 26, 2002 2:16 PM
> To: Jeb Bush; Jeb Bush
> Subject: Florida Health Insurance
> 
> Dear Governor Bush,
> 
> I heard that you recently signed a bill that would greatly raise the
> Health Insurance premiums for the small business person. I was unaware
> 
> of this bill being considered so I was not able to express my views
> earlier.
> I and my wife have a small, Manufacturers Representative, sales
> business
> that I started in 1986. After the first couple of years, the business
> grew to the level where I could employ 2 additional sales people.
> However, several years ago, the cost of doing business, mainly the
> costs
> of Federal Taxes, S/S, Insurances and Health Insurance, got to the
> point
> where I had to downsize and terminate these two salesmen.
> Around that time, my Health Insurances Costs rose to a point where I
> started to look for an alternate insurance plan. I am 60 years old and
> 
> have had a continuing health problem for the last 8 years which
> precludes me from getting Individual Health Insurance coverage. My
> only
> recourse is a small group, business policy, Insurance for myself plus
> my
> wife as a dependent. Fortunately I found an agent, who makes very
> little
> commission on such a policy, who came up with an insurance company and
> 
> policy that had a much reduced premium and provided the medical
> coverages that I needed at an affordable cost. However, the cost of
> this
> insurance has continued to increase every year since I started the
> policy, having gone up 65% in the last 2 years alone and more than
> doubling in the 4 years that I have had this Insurance Coverage. Now I
> 
> understand that I may be faced with another 50% or more premium
> increase. How is a small business like mine suppose to survive when
> all
> of my income is being used to pay my State and Federal Government
> obligations and my Health Insurance? At the current rate of increases,
> 
> these costs will soon exceed my company's total income. I need to keep
> 
> my company going as a viable business so I can continue to get my
> Medical Insurance coverage. I will not be able to qualify for Medicare
> 
> or Medicaid for another 6 years. Where are the funds to pay my
> obligations and Health Insurance to come from for these next 6 years?
> 
> With the cost of all my insurance continually rising, I have always
> had
> the impression that the State of Florida has catered to the Insurance
> Industry. I am sure that they provide significant amounts of funding
> for
> political campaigns.
> 
> Contrary to every politicians' Rhetoric, the Small Business Person has
> 
> received the BRUNT and Biggest Negative Impact of the changes in the
> Federal and State Tax and Insurance Laws.
> 
> I have been a loyal Republican Supporter on both the State and Federal
> 
> level for over 3 decades. Lately all I am seeing from Republican
> Administrations is more personal abuse for the small business person.
> I
> am seriously considering giving the Democrats a chance in the next
> State
> elections and will be promoting this with my small business friends
> throughout the state.
> 
> Is it the Insurance Companies that are going to re-elected you as
> Governor, or is it the people of this state that will be casting the
> votes at election time? Unless something can be done with the burden
> placed on independent business people by this insurance Fiasco, I for
> one will be campaigning against your re-election.
> 
> Sincerely,
> 
> C. Richard Harrow
> President
> Tech Sales Specialists, Inc.

Dear Governor Bush: 

Thank you for the quality time you spent with me and the rest of the Save-A-Friend group last week.  Although I regret to say that I did not fully appreciate it at the time, I cannot adequately express how valuable your input was.  Following our meeting, and throughout this past week, the Save-A-Friend team went back to the drawing board and modified the program so that it can work on a state-by-state basis.  In fact, the program may even work better given the realities of the governmental/political structures we have to interact with. 

Of course, we would like Florida to be the first state and for you to be at the forefront once the program is in place and has demonstrated its effectiveness.  There is no question in my mind, Governor, given my many years of experience, that this program works and will work for Florida! 

I would like to keep you updated as we continue to fine-tune the program to better fit a state-by-state approach.  In fact, the Save-A-Friend group would very much appreciate the opportunity, in the near future, to again meet with you and brief you on the modified program, prior to us also presenting it to Education Commissioner Charlie Christ and key members of the state legislature, as you suggested. 

Incidentally, with your permission, the Florida plan will include all state two and four year colleges in addition to K-12.   

Once again, thank you for your interest and feedback. 

Best Wishes, 

Murray Levine

-----Original Message-----
From: Beatrice <beatrice@nivets.com>

Posted on Sat, May. 25, 2002

Bush has no claim to 'education governor' title
By Dan Gelber
SPECIAL TO THE DEMOCRAT

The same month that Gov. Jeb Bush kicks off his campaign to convince voters
that he is Florida's "education governor," the national rankings for
education spending were released. This year, the year that Gov. Bush boasts
of a billion-dollar budget increase, Florida has attained, for the first
tim=
under any governor's watch, the ignoble position of having the lowest per
capita spending on public education in the entire nation. Dead last.

Undaunted, the governor claims his "increase" in school funding
demonstrates=20
his commitment to public schools. That recently released FCAT scores
evidenc=
his successes. The irrefutable data, however, suggests that under Gov.
Bush,=20
Florida's public schools have never been in worse condition.

This year, Florida's high school seniors' ACT and SAT scores have fallen to
their lowest point in a decade. Among the 50 states, Florida's high school
graduation rate is now 49th, with only Alabama scoring worse. Our
student-teacher ratio ranks 43rd and Florida's teachers are paid nearly
$5,000 below the national average .

The governor's "billion-dollar increase" in education funding is illusory
an=
misleading and won't solve anything. The recently approved education budget
doesn't account for an 88,000 increase in new students or factor in a
2-percent inflation rate. Nor does Gov. Bush calculate his substantial
budge=
cuts occurring in last year's special session.

After all is said and done, his 2002 budget increase in K-12 is actually a
$73 million decrease in per student spending. Further, in crafting his
education budget, he utilized some irresponsible and short-term funding
strategies that will only serve to postpone - until after his re-election
bi=
- additional shortfalls. By bolstering his election year budget with
nonrecurring funds, he guarantees Floridians a multibillion-dollar hole in
our budget next year.

Similarly, Gov. Bush's reliance on this years recently released FCAT test
results to show schools are performing better under his watch is also
misleading. The FCAT was never intended to be a report card for our public
schools. The FCAT, as it was originally conceived and used, was merely a
diagnostic tool utilized by teachers to help them assess how well some
basic=20
skills were being learned.

It does not calculate many of the factors that any parent would want to
take=20
into account when measuring the quality of a school such as student/teacher
ratios, school safety, and teacher training and salaries. Nor does it
factor=20
in the socioeconomic background of students and the availability of
resource=
that differ widely from school to school. Overemphasis on the test as a
grading instrument for schools has resulted in schools "teaching the test"
a=
the expense of all else.

But for Gov. Bush's purposes it works fine. Given how badly Florida's
school=
and students compare to other states on national standardized tests and in
nearly every recognized benchmark of school achievement and performance,
the=20
FCAT scores may be the only measuring tool inaccurate enough to award
Florida's schools a passing grade. Yet, rather than admit that Florida's
schools need greater attention and resources, the Bush administration
relies=20
upon an infirm grading instrument to claim our schools are improving.

In fairness, success in education reform demands the type of intensive,
long-range approach and resources that doesn't bear fruit between election
cycles. Perhaps some day a governor of Florida will truly meet the issue
wit=
a bold plan that electrifies our citizens and gains their support.

Rather than create some pretend formula for declaring educational
successes,=20
Floridians need a real route that measures true performance. That's how you
earn the title "education governor."


----------------------------------------------------------------------------
=-

--
Dan Gelber, D-Miami Beach, can be contacted by email at
gelber.dan@leg.state.fl.us.

http://www.orlandosentinel.com/news/local/state/orl-loceducation24052402.sto
=y

McBride dares Bush to debate education
By Mark Silva
Sentinel Political Editor
May 24, 2002
TALLAHASSEE -- Fleshing out details of a $1 billion plan for public
education -- and new taxes to pay for it -- Democrat Bill McBride
invited Gov. Jeb Bush on Thursday to debate him "up and down the state."
McBride, a Tampa-area attorney, explained his goals for education in
advance of the leading Democrat in the governor's race, former U.S.
Attorney General Janet Reno.
"All the political people say, 'Don't propose taxes.' I don't think
that's right," he said. "I want the people to know that I will propose,
that I will go to the people of Florida and tell them, 'I think we've
got to get new revenue.' "
McBride's pitch comes as Bush campaigns by boasting of his own
commitment to education. Bush secured $1 billion in new school spending
from the Legislature this year, capping a $3 billion increase during his
term.
Critics complain that Bush's 27 percent increase in spending has barely
kept pace with growing school enrollment and inflation and merely offset
some of the state budget-cutting forced by the recent recession.
But the Governor's Office, anticipating McBride's criticism, was ready
with an analysis of spending over four years showing that while
enrollment has increased 10.5 percent, Bush's increases still equate to
a 15 percent gain per student.
"I'll debate him up and down across the state," said McBride, keeping
from criticism of Reno. "I'm running against Jeb Bush."
While Bush boasts of cutting taxes, McBride proposes raising some: His
spending plan for smaller classes, higher teacher pay and pre-schooling
for "at-risk" 4-year-olds, is largely based on a new 50 cent per-pack
tax on cigarettes.
"It is my greatest hope and desire that Bill McBride will run on a
platform exclusively designed on taxes -- 'If elected, I, Bill McBride,
will raise your taxes,' " said Lt. Gov. Frank Brogan, Bush's
running-mate.
Although McBride relies on a tax increase unlikely to pass Florida's
Republican-run Legislature, McBride says lawmakers will come around if
he is elected. Reno, who also speaks of smaller classes, has not yet
proposed how to pay for them.
Reno will unveil a plan for education soon, said Mo Elleithee, campaign
manager.
Reno will spend much of the next two weeks making fund-raising calls,
preparing for a June 7 event featuring actor Martin Sheen. Bo Diddley
and Friends will entertain at The Biltmore Hotel in Coral Gables, and
Reno will bring Sheen to Orlando the next day.
McBride, planning 32 fund-raising events in June, was raising money in
Tallahassee on Thursday at a $250-per-person reception whose hosts
included some of the lawyers from Holland & Knight, the firm he ran
before running for governor.
For education, McBride proposes another $1 billion after the basic costs
of growing enrollment are counted:
Pre-kindergarten schooling for "at-risk" 4-year olds, at a cost of $150
million a year. Eventually, he says the state can offer pre-K for all.
At least two years of "small-class instruction" -- no more than 22
children in a room -- in kindergarten to Grade 3, at a cost of $300
million.
Pay raises for teachers, raising the average salary by $2,500 a year,
bringing salaries up, but still shy of the national average. It costs
$434 million.
Remedial tutoring for children failing state achievement tests, and
eliminating Bush's use of student testing to assign grades to schools:
$100 million.
More construction, drawing on existing revenue from Florida's lottery,
$100 million, to support $1 billion in bonds.
To pay for this, McBride proposes drawing most of his new money, $565
million, from a 50 cent increase in cigarette taxes, now 33.9 cents per
pack.
He proposes finding another $100 million by holding the line against
"turkeys," hometown legislative projects. He says he can find another
$136 million in cost savings that Florida TaxWatch has identified and
$206 million going to other government spending.
He also claims he can close $101 million of "indefensible" loopholes in
the tax code. This includes a $50 million credit for companies covering
private school tuition, a $24 million break for new businesses buying
machinery, $7 million in airport exemptions, $5 million for contact lens
manufacturers and $3 million for hotels that offer complimentary meals.
Mark Silva can be reached at msilva@orlandosentinel.com or 407-420-5034.
Copyright © 2002, Orlando Sentinel

From:	kenneth.morefield@dot.state.fl.us
Sent:	Tuesday, May 28, 2002 9:51 PM
To:	rlevitt1@tampabay.rr.com
Cc:	Jeb Bush; tom.barry@dot.state.fl.us
Subject:	FFN Response

This is in response to your electronic letter to Governor Bush dated May
24, 2002, in reference to the Florida Fiber Network and the Department=s
actions on the proposals received from Florida Fiber Network, Inc. (FFNI)
and Aptus Corporation (Aptus).

First, please let me provide a little background on the subject.

In  March,  2000,  the Department issued a Request for Proposals to solicit
proposals  for  a  lease  of  limited  access rights-of-way in exchange for
fiber-optic  telecommunication infrastructure for the Department=s use  and
which  would  also allow the lessee to use the rights-of-way for a private,
for-profit  commercial  network.    A fundamental tenet for such a lease is
the  financial  responsibility  of  the  lessee.   Section 337.251, Florida
Statutes,  and  the  implementing  rules  and  policies  require  that  the
Department  determine that a proposer demonstrate that it has the financial
capacity  and wherewithal to undertake a project before  such rights-of-way
are leased.

Of  the  five  proposals received in response in the RFP, FFNI was selected
for  a  lease.   Based on its assertion that it had the financial capacity,
but  needed  some  time  to  effectuate  a  final  financial  program,  the
Department,  on  July 14, 2000, granted FFNI the lease, and provided ninety
days  for  it  to  produce  a  viable  financial  program.   After  several
extensions  of  time,  the  Department, in accordance with the terms of the
lease,  terminated  the lease with FFNI on May 14, 2001, for FFNI=s failure
to obtain the necessary financing.

On  October  27, 2001, FFNI, filed an unsolicited proposal based on the RFP
and  its  earlier  proposal,  again  asserting  that  it  had the financial
capability to undertake the project.  As required by statute the Department
provided  public  notice  of  this  unsolicited  proposal and invited other
entities  to  submit  competing  proposals.  Aptus filed such a proposal on
January 31, 2002.

FFNI  in  its  unsolicited  proposal  and again at the Oral Presentation on
March  28  asserted  that  it  had the financing necessary to undertake the
project  and  would  provide  proof  within a week, but no later than April
17th.   Aptus  stated  that it needed ninety days to put together its final
financing program.

In  the Department=s Agency Action of April 22, 2002, both the FFNI and the
Aptus  proposals  were selected for further negotiation.  Because of FFNI=s
representation  that  it  could  provide  proof of its financial capability
within a week, the Department gave FFNI ten days to demonstrate that it had
secured   the   financing   that  it  had  proposed,  and  which  could  be
independently  verified  by  the  Department.   On  May  2,  FFNI filed a A
Commitment  Memorandum,@  which had been executed by Florida Fiber Network,
Inc.  (FFNI),  The  Oxford  Financial  Group, and Global Arbitrage, Inc. on
April  9,  2002.   This  ACommitment@ by its own terms was subject to being
withdrawn  on  April  26,  if the financing arrangements were not closed by
then.   The  Department was unable to verify the continued validity of this
commitment  or  that  the  entities  involved  had  committed the financial
wherewithal  to effectuate the financing.  Hence, the need for the May 10th
letter  that  Acaught@  your  attention  on  the  Department=s Web Site and
ostensibly prompted the subject e-mail to the Governor.

With  this  background, you must understand, the Department has been overly
patient  and  very  fair  in  allowing  FFNI time to arrange its financing.
However,   after  several  failed  attempts,  the  Department needs to take
prudent action, and avoid expending more state resources unwisely.

In  the  April  Agency  Action, the Department gave both FFNI and Aptus the
right  to  continue  forward  to  negotiating   the  lease-- there being no
prohibition  for  the  Department  from entering into two leases.  FFNI was
given the shorter time period because that is what FFNI proposed.

As  to  your  contention  the Department somehow favors Aptus is erroneous.
The  record  is clear that the Department has treated both proposers fairly
and   even-handedly.   These  proposals  were  examined  and  evaluated  by
technical,  engineering, financial, and legal experts within the Department
with  the  assistance  of  knowledgeable consultants.  The Agency Action is
predicated on their collective recommendations that had resulted from their
independent professional judgement.

I  must take issue with your allusion that an Aptus sub-contractor has been
allowed  to  provide undue influence with the Department or with me in this
matter.   That  firm  is but one of several subcontractors to Aptus.  There
are  former  Department  employees  on the teams for both proposers.   Both
proposals  were  evaluated  on  their  merits,  and  both were selected for
further negotiations.

In answer to your specific questions, I respond as follows:

     1.    AThis@  was  awarded  to  FFNI.   Upon  compliance  with its own
promises, the Department was ready to proceed to the final document.
     2.    The  Department  is  Aworried@  about funding because it has the
fiduciary duty to protect state resources.  If a proposer shows that it has
the wherewithal to complete the installation of fiber, the Department would
allow  it  to  proceed.   But, the situation with FFNI, is its inability to
demonstrate that it has funds to start, let alone the financial ability, to
complete, the first segment.
     3.   There is no conflict of interest.  The Department=s decisions are
based  on  the collective advice of experts and professionals in accordance
with applicable statutes and rules.
     4.    The  Department  has  not  offered Aptus, or any other provider,
rights  over FFNI.  FFNI has the same, equal rights granted by the statute,
as  any other entity. The Department is diligently proceeding to accomplish
the fiber-optic project in accordance with the requirements of the statute.
The  Department  fully  expects  that entities that file proposals with the
Department  to  be  able to fulfill the representations in those proposals,
e.g.  FFNI=s  representation  that  it  had the financing and would provide
proof thereof within a week.

If you take the time to review the documents (all of which are available on
the  Department=s  Web  Site), I am sure you will come to the understanding
that  the  Department=s  decision in reference to the subject was conducted
fully  in  compliance  with  the governing statutes, and that the facts and
circumstances  set  forth  in  each  of the proposals justified the actions
taken.

If you have further questions,I will be glad to discuss them with you.

From:	Phyllis Hayward <phayward@tampabay.rr.com>

Thanks for the update Trudy.  I haven't read the whole report, but I would have really liked to see the issue of relative placements addressed in the sense of ensuring the relative IS a relative.  We had a similar situation as foster parents in Leon County in 1999 where a young child was placed from our home with who they thought was the sister of the father.  We had strong evidence to show that the father wasn't really the father- so the Aunt wouldn't have been the Aunt.  DCF folks told us then that could very well be the case, they don't test paternity -unless two or more fathers present themselves.  They have to rely on who is on the birth certificate. Well of course the mother would have listed him as she was being abused by this strongman. I still wonder about this child as we suspect it was the father that almost killed the child twice (at 2 months and 8 months old)- he had the motivation as the mother had cheated on him and the baby was from another man.  Now, with his sister having the child he will see that child and probably have many opportunities to further hurt that child.  Mom signed off her rights as she wouldn't talk and cooperate- she was too afraid to.

I understand this was also the case with Rilya's placement.  I hope they initiate and enforce determining paternity and relational placements to ensure the safety of the children.  I don't believe these are isolated issues.  
 
Phyllis

From: jpetkov248@aol.com

Mary,

Thank you as usual for getting this information to our people.  

I was there this morning when the Governor arrived and we spoke briefly.  I told him the bottom line was that without the foster parents the system would be in shambles!  That we need to empower the foster parents to do their job for the children without fear and intimidation.  I told him that we MUST be included as an equal partner in all aspects of DCF/private providers working together.

I told him that our foster parents are professional people in the community and unless treated with respect and communicated with we will continue to loose them. And the bottom line is that the children will suffer.  I told him that had foster parents been listened to this might not have happened.

This was the best I could do in the few minutes I had to speak with him.  I was very appreciative of Doreen Rutledge in allowing me those few minutes and the opportunity for my husband, myself and our adopted girls to meet Governor Bush.  I was told he listens to the people before the administration, so lets see.

I have never been involved in a Blue Ribbon panel before so I have no experience to draw from.  I must say I was impressed by the amount of information DCF provided the Panel.  I learned a lot about the money issues and all the "strings" attached.  I believe the four panel members are some of the most caring child advocates we have here in Miami and that they WILL make sure their recommendations are carried out.  I have great faith this report will NOT be placed on a shelf and collect dust.  I can tell you that my husband and I, along with Juli and Michael Millsap will do our best to represent the foster parents and push for this report to make a difference.

Bev. you asked about the suggestions, they are the mediation board, business and faith support of the alliance, background checks for the **relative and non-relative caregivers, fingerprints in each child's file, and dated cameras for quarterly pictures.  Sorry I did not get back to you sooner. (**the background checks on the relative and non-relative caregivers is what is new, yes we as foster parents have as always had to have background checks, doing the all the relative and non-relative placements already in existence is going to be a monumental task as well as expensive. )

AS far as the worker and the supervisor on Rilya Wilson's case.  I believe the Panel made it clear that she and the supervisor are clearly to blame.  I have never personally worked with Muskelly, but I have had many children in that Unit and worked with WIllie Harris the supervisor.  I personally believe them to be completely responsible and not to be scapegoats for administration.

I hope I have been able to provide some insight to these proceedings and will keep  you posted on how we do here in District 11.

Trudy in Miami

-----Original Message-----
From: Miguel Milanes [mailto:Miguel_Milanes@dcf.state.fl.us]
Sent: Tuesday, May 28, 2002 4:31 PM
To: Sarah B Robinson; owen_roach@dcf.state.fl.us;
tim_bottcher@dcf.state.fl.us
Subject: AP wire story -- REPORT


(this email is from Shawnna Donovan. Please send to PIOs as an FYI.
This
story was written by Cathy Wilson, AP in Miami).

Governor endorses low-cost solutions to child-welfare problems

Posted: May 28, 2002 03:58 PM
MIAMI (AP) -- Gov. Jeb Bush endorsed a low-cost approach Tuesday to
solving
some of the problems cited by a panel examining the case of a 5-year-old
child in state care whose disappearance went unnoticed for 15 months.

Bush promised to comply with the panel's report and work with lawmakers
on
costlier issues that will take more time.

"We know that we can do better and we have work to do," he said. "We
have
made significant progress in a very difficult, challenging, complicated
area of public policy."

Bush was reacting to a 28-page report issued Monday by a committee he
assigned to investigate the state's handling of Rilya Wilson, 5, who is
still missing a month after her disappearance was noticed.

Bush called the wide-ranging report "a good solid blueprint" for change
in
the state Department of Children & Families and endorsed the agency's
leadership by Kathleen Kearney despite calls by others for her
resignation.
Bush issued an executive order to name a new group to pursue changes
that
don't need legislative approval and report back in late September.

Key long-term recommendations by the panel include increasing the pay
for
new child-protection workers and providing $1.5 million for full
criminal
background checks on 62,000 existing caregivers.

But Bush said he was "wary" of the panel's call for a special
legislative
session to address the needs of Florida's abused and neglected children.
And when asked if he supported higher pay, he said it would be part of
an
overall review of employee retention, training and benefits.

Bill McBride, a Democratic candidate for governor, supported the idea of
a
special session, saying, "The state cannot wait for another tragedy to
act
decisively."

On pay raises, state Rep. Carlos Lacasa, R-Miami, the chief House budget
writer, said, "If we're going to pay, then we're going to have to start
looking at the revenue side or we're going to have to take money out of
infrastructure."

State Rep. Cindy Lerner, D-Miami, complained that some of the
recommendations already are in place as state law or department policy
but
are not followed in full, notably required monthly visits to the 44,000
children in state care.
Democratic state Rep. Frederica Wilson of Miami said she realistically
expected "nothing" to happen in response to the panel's report.

"There's a child missing who could possibly be dead," she said. "I don't
even think that the community awareness has been heightened."

The National Coalition for Child Protection Reform based in Alexandria,
Va., on Monday called the report "nearly 100 percent useless," blaming
Kearney's approach to child welfare in part for an increase in deaths
under
her tenure.

The review panel faulted two low-level state workers and Rilya's
caretakers
for the girl's long-unnoticed disappearance but also said DCF
shortcomings
were "manifest."

Bush said he hopes to see criminal charges come out of police
investigations of allegedly fraudulent reports filed by state employees
and
the caretakers.

Some of the panel's short-term recommendations include photographing
children every three months, having them come to court every six months
and
immediate notification of police when a child is missing. DCF took a
week
to formally report Rilya missing.

Rilya was an infant when she was taken by the state from her homeless,
crack-addicted mother. She was placed with Geralyn Graham, who claims to
be
Rilya's grandmother, and her sister Pamela Graham in April 2000.
Geralyn Graham filed for food stamps on behalf of Rilya as recently as
March. But Graham now says Rilya was taken from her home by someone
purporting to be DCF worker in January 2001.

(Copyright 2002 by the Associated Press. All Rights Reserved. This
material
may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.)
