My Dear Governor Bush: 

In 1977, I lost my Girlfriend, Miss Lauren Rae Wagner. She was kidnapped near her home by two men, Kenneth Bianchi, and Angelo Bueno, who were later dubbed as the Hillside Strangler. There method to gain control of their 16 victims, was to use a Badge in a Wallet and tell the victims, some of who were Prostitutes that they were being arrested. 

The above referenced website actually sells all kinds of Badges and emblems anyone could use to play Policeman. Several are Badges from the FMP, the FHP, the FDLE, several County Sheriff, and City Police Badges. I have even seen advertisement to sell FHP Door Decals and Lightbars. With everything that is going on their in Florida with a run off election in November, you do not need this!

From: CAucoin11@aol.com <CAucoin11@aol.com>

Subject: Film Production

Governer Bush,
I am a very well respected and usually busy Production Manager in the film 
industry in Orlando Florida.  I have a very extensive resume 7 pages long and 
have worked on many well known feature films, tv movies and commercials over 
the last 10 years.  I am also the owner of a local film production company.  
I have not worked on a local Florida commercial in three months.  As for 
feature films and tv, the last film i worked on was in 1999.  As for my 
production company: Ha! Florida keeps giving those jobs to out of towners.  
The lack of film production in this state is a serious issue for so many 
families.  We have lost our careers and livlihoods.   Florida is no longer 
considered a production hub.  Florida seems to be going backward.  I am aware 
of the Canadian incentives that have created runaway production.  However, 
Florida needs to match these financial incentives offered by the Canadians as 
well as other states.  
A bill died in the Legislature this year that would have given producers who 
film in Florida a rebate of up to $2 million on expenditures made in this 
state.  Why did this bill die??  Are you going to step up to the plate and 
move this industry forward so that FLORIDA is again a great place to live and 
work for film professionals?
Carla Aucoin

Below with david struh's edits---we have also worked out strategy for

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE				   CONTACT: ELIZABETH
HIRST
WEDNESDAY, MAY 29, 2002
(850) 488-5394
	


GOVERNOR BUSH JOINS PRESIDENT AT WHITE HOUSE TO TAKE 
HISTORIC ACTION PROTECTING FLORIDA FROM DRILLING
~~Agreements protect Florida's beaches and the Everglades ~~ 

	WASHINGTON D.C.-- This morning at the White House, President
George
W. Bush made an unprecedented commitment to Florida Governor Jeb Bush,
permanently protecting both Florida's beaches and the Everglades from
oil
and gas drilling.  

Previous environmental protection commitments focused on stopping the
expansion of new oil and gas exploration and development in Florida.
Today's action will actually buy back existing privately-owned and
previously-leased rights to oil and gas interests.  

The President's actions include a negotiated agreement between the
federal
government and five petroleum companies to effectively extinguish all
existing rights to drill just 25 miles off of Florida's northwest coast
near
Pensacola, in an area known as Destin Dome.  This area has long been
recognized as the most likely to see oil and gas development off of
Florida's coast and has been the subject of ongoing federal litigation.

At the same time, the President and Governor announced an agreement for
the
National Park Service to purchase privately held oil and gas rights
within
the Big Cypress National Preserve, the expansive Everglades ecosystem in
South Florida immediately adjacent to Everglades National Park.  These
interests were retained by the Collier family when the Preserve was
established in 1974.  This announcement effectively shuts down any
potential
for new oil rigs in the Everglades.

Today's White House visit by the Governor completes an unparalleled
"Environmental Trifecta" for Florida.

Almost one year ago, the President and Governor revealed a proposal to
make
their respective administrations the first to eliminate plans for any
new
offshore drilling off of Florida's coast.  As a result, the federal
government reduced plans for new oil and gas lease sales off of
Florida's
west coast by 75% -- for the first time ensuring no new development
within a
true 100 mile perimeter off the Florida coast.  Previous administrations
had
acquiesced to drilling in areas less than 100 miles away, west of the
Florida-Alabama state line.


(more)


GOVERNOR AND PRESIDENT TAKE HISTORIC ACTION PROTECTING FLORIDA FROM
DRILLING-Page Two

In addition, on January 9, Governor Bush joined President Bush at the
White
House to co-sign, one year ahead of schedule, the first enforceable
agreement to ensure that the Everglades receives all of the clean water
it
will need as restoration progresses in the future.

Today's announcement by the President and Governor builds on these two
historic accomplishments by committing substantial federal resources to
eliminate pre-existing environmental risks to Florida's coastal
resources
and the Everglades.

"The actions we are taking today to preserve Florida's environment are
truly
unprecedented," said Governor Bush.  "Today, thanks to the President's
support, we are reversing the momentum of nearly half a century in
Florida
and guaranteeing the preservation of our environment-based economy and
quality of life."

The negotiated agreement with Chevron, Conoco, Murphy Oil, ExxonMobil
and
Samedan to eliminate existing plans to drill off of Florida's
consistently
top-ranked beaches will cost the federal government approximately $102
million.  The agreement with Collier Resources to prevent the
development of
hydrocarbon resources in the Everglades is valued at approximately
$120-million.

"The President and Governor Bush have negotiated a defining moment in
Florida's environmental history," said the Secretary of Florida's
Department
of Environmental Protection, David Struhs.  "America's best beaches and
America's Everglades are now better protected than ever before for this
and
future generations."



# # #

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE				   CONTACT: ELIZABETH
HIRST
WEDNESDAY, MAY 29, 2002

GOVERNOR BUSH JOINS PRESIDENT AT WHITE HOUSE TO TAKE 
HISTORIC ACTION PROTECTING FLORIDA FROM DRILLING
~~Agreements protect Florida's beaches and the Everglades ~~ 

	WASHINGTON D.C.-- This morning at the White House, President
George
W. Bush made an unprecedented commitment to Florida Governor Jeb Bush,
permanently protecting both Florida's beaches and the Everglades from
oil
and gas drilling.  

Previous environmental protection commitments focused on stopping the
expansion of new oil and gas exploration and development in Florida.
Today's action will actually buy back existing privately-owned and
previously-leased rights to oil and gas interests.  

The President's actions include a negotiated agreement between the
federal
government and five petroleum companies to effectively extinguish all
existing rights to drill just 25 miles off of Florida's northwest coast
near
Pensacola, in an area known as Destin Dome.  This area has long been
recognized as the most likely to see oil and gas development off of
Florida's coast and has been the subject of ongoing federal litigation.

At the same time, the President and Governor announced an agreement in
principle to purchase privately held oil and gas rights within the Big
Cypress National Preserve, the expansive Everglades ecosystem in South
Florida immediately adjacent to Everglades National Park.  These
interests
were retained by the Collier family when the Preserve was established in
####.  This announcement effectively shuts down any potential for new
oil
rigs in the Everglades.

Today's White House visit by the Governor completes an unparalleled
"Environmental Trifecta" for Florida.

Almost one year ago, the President and Governor revealed a proposal to
make
their respective administrations the first to eliminate plans for any
new
offshore drilling off of Florida's coast.  As a result, was the federal
government reduced plans for new oil and gas lease sales off of
Florida's
west coast by 75% -- for the first time ensuring no new development
within a
true 100 mile radius off the Florida coast.  Previous administrations
had
acquiesced to drilling in areas less than 100 miles away, west of the
Florida-Alabama state line.


(more)


GOVERNOR AND PRESIDENT TAKE HISTORIC ACTION PROTECTING FLORIDA FROM
DRILLING-Page Two

In addition, on January 9, Governor Bush joined President Bush at the
White
House to co-sign, one year ahead of schedule, the first enforceable
agreement to ensure that the Everglades receives all of the clean water
it
will need as restoration progresses in the future.

Today's announcement by the President and Governor builds on these two
historic accomplishments by committing substantial federal resources to
eliminate pre-existing environmental risks to Florida's coastal
resources
and the Everglades.

truly
unprecedented," said Governor Bush.  "Today, thanks to the President's
support, we are reversing the momentum of nearly half a century in
Florida
and guaranteeing the preservation of our environment-based economy and
quality of life."

and
Samedan to eliminate existing plans to drill off of Florida's
consistently
top-ranked beaches will cost the federal government approximately $102
million.  The agreement with Collier Resources to prevent the
development of
hydrocarbon resources in the Everglades is valued at $###.

"The President and Governor Bush have negotiated a defining moment in
Florida's environmental history," said the Secretary of Florida's
Department
of Environmental Protection, David Struhs.  "The citizens of our state
and
our many visitors will benefit for years to come as they enjoy Florida's
pristine outdoors."

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE				   CONTACT: ELIZABETH
HIRST
WEDNESDAY, MAY 29, 2002
(850) 488-5394
	


GOVERNOR BUSH JOINS PRESIDENT AT WHITE HOUSE TO TAKE UNPARALLELED ACTION
PROTECTING FLORIDA FROM DRILLING
~~Agreements protect Florida's beaches and the Everglades ~~ 

	WASHINGTON D.C.-- This morning at the White House, President
George
W. Bush made an unprecedented commitment to Florida Governor Jeb Bush,
to
permanently protect both Florida's beaches and the Everglades from oil
and
gas drilling.  

Previous environmental protection commitments focused on stopping the
expansion of new oil and gas exploration and development in Florida.
Today's action will actually buy back existing privately-owned and
previously-leased rights to oil and gas interests.  

The President's actions include a negotiated agreement between the
federal
government and five petroleum companies to effectively extinguish all
existing rights to drill just 25 miles off of Florida's northwest coast
near
Pensacola, in an area known as Destin Dome.  This area has long been
recognized as the most likely to see oil and gas development off of
Florida's coast and has been the subject of ongoing federal litigation.

At the same time, the President and Governor announced an agreement in
principle to purchase privately held oil and gas rights within the Big
Cypress National Preserve, the expansive Everglades ecosystem in South
Florida immediately adjacent to Everglades National Park.  These
interests
were retained by the Collier family when the Preserve was established in
####.  This announcement effectively shuts down any potential for new
oil
rigs in the Everglades.

Today's White House visit by the Governor completes an unparalleled
"Environmental Trifecta" for Florida.

Almost one year ago, the President and Governor revealed a proposal to
make
their respective Administrations the first to eliminate plans for any
new
offshore drilling off of Florida's coast.  The result was the federal
government reducing plans for new oil and gas lease sales off of
Florida's
west coast by 75% -- for the first time ensuring no new development
within
100 miles of the Florida coast.



(more)


GOVERNOR AND PRESIDENT TAKE UNPARALLELED ACTION PROTECTING FLORIDA FROM
DRILLING-Page Two

At the beginning of this year, on January 9, Governor Bush joined
President
Bush at the White House to co-sign, one year ahead of schedule, the
first
enforceable agreement to ensure that the Everglades receive all of the
clean
water they will need as restoration progresses in the future.

Today's announcement by the President and Governor builds on these two
historic accomplishments by committing substantial federal resources to
eliminate pre-existing environmental risks to Florida's coastal
resources
and the Everglades.

"The actions we are taking today to preserve Florida's environment are
truly
unprecedented," said Governor Bush.  "Today, thanks to the President's
support, we are reversing the momentum of nearly half a century in
Florida
and guaranteeing the preservation of our environment-based economy and
quality of life."

The negotiated agreement with Chevron, Conoco, Murphy Oil, ExxonMobil
and
Samedan that will eliminate existing plans to drill off of Florida's
consistently top-ranked beaches will cost the federal government
approximately $102 million.  The agreement with Collier Resources that
will
prevent the development of hydrocarbon resources in the Everglades is
valued
at $###.

"The President and Governor Bush have negotiated a defining moment in
Florida's environmental history," said the Secretary of Florida's
Department
of Environmental Protection, David Struhs.  "The citizens of our state
and
our many visitors will benefit for years to come as they enjoy Florida's
pristine outdoors."



# # #
Elizabeth E. Hirst
Press Secretary
Office of Governor Jeb Bush

trovillion.allen@leg.state.fl.us; diaz-balart.mario@leg.state.fl.us; richardson.curtis@leg.state.fl.us; mindingall.dorothy@leg.state.fl.us; fiorentino.heather@leg.state.fl.us; harrington.lindsay@leg.state.fl.us
Subject:	Blue Ribbon Panel report!

Florida Leaders,
Just this morning when out for my daily walk with my girlfriend I was sharing 
how excited I was that Florida's failure to invest in the adequate protection 
of our most vulnerable, the children, was now receiving national attention 
and surely immediate action would follow.  

I was so disappointed and dismayed when I got home only to find it front page 
news that a special session was not to be called to address this urgent issue 
even after a very compelling and thorough report from the Blue Ribbon Panel 
(great work for such limited time!).  

As an involved community volunteer who has served on multiple state and local 
boards for organizations that champion children's causes, I am aware that 
there has been some relatively recent improvement in funding for DCF.  I am 
also well aware though that we have unreasonable expectations from a severely 
overburdened system.

I plead that each of you take the time to look deeply into the child 
protective service realities in your community.  Go out with a case worker.  
See first hand the daunting challenges.  There is no doubt in my mind that 
you will come to the same conclusion as this panel did and that is, that in 
addition to some important policy adjustments, more funding will be 
necessary.

These children did not choose to be abused and/or neglected.  How can we 
possibly in good conscience allow this continued suffering?  How many 
children must literally be beaten to death before we consider this a crisis 
situation?  It's sickening.

On behalf of all of the children, we demand action and we demand it now!
thank you for your time and God bless
Rhonda Effron
Board Member Florida Children's Campaign
Board Member Florida Federation of Women's Clubs
Board Member of local PTA
Board Member of Orlando Junior Woman's Club
stay home mother of three

From:	V. John Brook, Jr. <vjohn@tampabay.rr.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, May 29, 2002 10:35 AM
To:	Jeb Bush; Jane Harper
Subject:	Community Based Program Cut

Dear Governor Bush:

As a long time Board Member of Family Resources, Inc. in Pinellas County 
and an attorney who has dealt with his share of juvenile cases, both 
delinquent and dependent, I have seen programs come and go. 
 Unfortunately it is usually programs that are desperately needed that 
seem to go.

The Family Services Planning Team program along with a number of other
community services are in jeopardy of being cut unless you take action.  
There has been a last minute fund shift in the state budget that was not
discovered until last week.  About $16 MILLION DOLLARS will be transferred from community-based residential and therapeutic services to fund acute institutional services that serve only Medicaid eligible children.  Another $2.5 MILLION has been
cut and shifted to Adult Mental Health services.

Over the years, both the State and providers have worked in partnership to
develop innovative, less restrictive, cost effective, community based
alternatives to institutional care.  This whole system is at risk.  Many
children and families are in great need of these community-based
interventions and most if not all of these services will be lost if this
line item is not vetoed by you.

Please veto this item and don't take us back 20 years in the past as I have seen happen so many times with services to children and families.

Thank you for your time.

John Brook
Attorney at Law

April 26, 2002

The Honorable Governor Jeb Bush
Executive Offices of the Governor
The Capitol, Tallahassee, FL 32399-0001

Honorable Governor, Dear Jeb:

After our visit with you in your Carol Gable office in May '96 Mr. Ralph Bistany and I have been watching your success as Governor and FL education pioneer and reformer. We are proud of our tiny part in supporting you from the start.

With the attached material I wanted to update you briefly about our own success in the charter school arena. It basically describes our US rollout model in Springfield, MA, which Margery Hemsing-Rankin visited in November '96.

It particularly highlights the successes of disadvantaged Hispanic students. Here is my question and modest request:

Could you or your office help us with any contacts or recommendations in a Latin American country? We would like to acquire or establish a private (or public) school with a residential section for seamless student and teacher exchanges within an identical and proven SABIS® curriculum and instructional system. As you know better than most people, English proficiency for Hispanics and Spanish knowledge for all US citizens is so very vital for individual and our entire society's future wellbeing. That's why all our charter school students take Spanish from Kindergarten on.

Your consideration and advice would be much appreciated.

Best wishes and regards,

Udo E. Schulz 
VP Business Development
SABIS® Educational Systems, Inc.

From:	Charles Lee <chlee2@earthlink.net>
Sent:	Wednesday, May 29, 2002 2:46 PM
To:	Coleen Castille; FL DEP TAL; David Struhs; Jeb Bush; Bob Sparks; Hirste@Eog. State. Fl. Us
Subject:	Audubon Press Release on Big Cypress/Destin Dome issue...

> Contact: Stuart Strahl
Email: sstrahl@audubon.org
Phone: 305-371-6399

AUDUBON PRAISES PRESIDENT GEORGE BUSH & GOVERNOR JEB BUSH ON ENDING OIL DRILLING THREAT


May 29, 2002, Miami, Florida-Audubon of Florida praised the commitment made by today by President Bush George W. Bush in response to the Governor Jeb Bush and State of Florida's longstanding opposition to oil drilling near the environmentally fragile coastal estuaries. Audubon also applauds the proposed acquisition of mineral rights to halt oil drilling in the Everglades Ecosystem.

The agreement was negotiated by the federal government and several oil companies to remove existing rights to drill 25 miles off of Florida's northwest coast near Pensacola, an area known as the Destin Dome.  

In addition, the federal government will purchase privately owned mineral rights within three environmental sensitive areas of the greater Everglades ecosystem: The Big Cypress National Preserve, the Florida Panther National Wildlife Refuge and the Ten Thousand Island National Wildlife Refuge. The agreement mandates that the National Park Service will purchase the rights form the Collier family, which currently owns the rights.  Today's announcement precludes any potential new oil & gas exploration in the Everglades.  "This is a major step forward in protecting the Big Cypress and the Greater Everglades Ecosystem. Oil drilling was reluctantly accepted as a compromise when the Big Cypress Preserve was created by Congress 28 years ago, and finally bringing it to an end will significantly reduce the possibility of endangered habitat from being negatively impacted by gas and oil extraction", said Dr. Stuart Strahl, Audubon of Florida's CEO & President.

"Audubon and its chapters have long opposed drilling in Florida's nearshore coastal waters," Strahl continued, "The leadership shown by the President and Governor Bush in removing the threat of drilling from the Destin Dome is great news to all Floridians who care about the health of our estuaries and coastal waters", he concluded.

Purchase of the Big Cypress Mineral Rights will require congressional action, either to appropriate cash, or exchange rights for other mineral interests. Audubon is committed to assure that the outcome of such congressional action will take place while protecting all sensitive environmental resources.

###

Sent:	Wednesday, May 29, 2002 3:09 PM

Subject:	card rooms

We have received letters from industry folks agreeing to the voluntary compliance for the two restrictions that they will codify next Session: noon to midnight and card rooms only in facilities with live racing.

Regarding next Session's bill: Senator King is trying to reach you; Rep. Byrd would like speak with you (813-719-0854).

From:	EFALES <EFALES@TAMPABAY.RR.COM>
Sent:	Wednesday, May 29, 2002 3:33 PM
To:	flagov@myfla.com
Cc:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Please help veto HB1307

Dear Governor:
    Please Veto HB 1307.         You can't just not sign the bill, we will never get back our access, it 
has to be a Veto. We will have time to be involved in the process. It was not 
fair the way we were kept ignorant of the amendment until we knew too little, 
too late. It is not fair to the people to loose 80% accessibility in existing 
buildings. It is not fair to the building owners-increased liability and law 
suits for denial of access to goods and services and jobs.
    Under current law, Florida builds once, we build it right, and it is 
accessible to all people. There are no problems. With your signature, they 
only have to pay 20% of the cost of construction for "us". Construction cost 
is segregated, we are valued at 20%. It is wrong. We cannot get a job on a 
second floor with no lift. We will cost taxpayers more money. We will not 
spend our money on the second floor with no lift, bad for Florida business. 
    ADA encourages a state to be stronger in accessibility depending on the 
needs of it's population. We are a host state. We need. We are a retirement 
state. We need. We are a state with a high voting population of people with 
disabilities. We need. We have stronger laws - this amendment takes away our 
strength. Don't let it happen, give us a chance to defend our laws-Veto 
HB1307, they will invariably try again next year, but it will be a fair 
fight. Nothing is lost with the Veto, people's lives are irreversibly changed 
with it. Veto on HB1307 = Strong Florida.
With thanks and blessings,
Angel Watson

We are looking for assurance that our Florida Statutes listing our more 
stringent accessibility laws were not changed, amended, altered, deleted
or defaulted to Federal Code in any way. We need to know that no one has 
changed the privileges and rights afforded to Floridians that we worked so 
hard for. Please veto HB 1307. 



This bill was totally designed to benefit no one other than builders
and developers.  What little good there is in it is far outweighed by
the bad!

From:	Lisa.Snell@reason.org
Sent:	Wednesday, May 29, 2002 3:52 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	A Rant on Education Privatization

Jeb,

My house is located in a rural area of Riverside County. When my family moved into the neighborhood, we had to decide who would pick up our trash every week. There were seven different trash haulers. We asked the neighbors which company they recommended and we picked one. We had to provide our own trashcans and every week our trash was picked up. We didn't spend much time thinking about our trash service. Then two years ago Riverside County decided this was too confusing for residents. They "competitively" bid out the countywide trash collection and selected a trash hauler for all the residents in the county. The new trash company gave residents new trash bins and recycle bins. But the company consistently "forgets" to pick up our recyclables. Sometimes 3-4 weeks have gone by without the recycle truck coming out to our house. They rarely keep to their collection schedule. We have complained to the company. We have complained to the county. But unless the company fails on a grand scale it is unlikely anything will change. Perhaps in four more years when the contract is up, the county will have another competitive bid and select a different trash hauler. I liked it better when we could choose between the seven companies serving our neighborhood. 

But this is a minor problem compared with the government-run school in my neighborhood. Today I went to http://www.greatschools.net to see how the school that my kids will never set foot in was doing and to confirm the fatal flaw (for parents like me) in the No Child Left Behind act (NCLB). I quickly confirmed three facts I already knew about my neighborhood school: 

1. Overall Test Score Performance: Below Average--This school has a rank of 4 out of 10 on the 2001 Academic Performance Index. 

2. Performance Compared to Similar Schools: Well Below Average--This school has a rank of 2 out of 10 compared to similar schools. 

3. Test Score Improvement: Met Its Improvement Targets.  

Here's the flaw: my school is "below average" or "well below average" depending on which measure you use as a benchmark, yet it is meeting California's low requirements for adequate yearly performance (AYP). As far as the NCLB act is concerned my school is improving. This school will never be labeled a failing school and there will never be a right of exit for students who do not want to attend a "below average" or "well below average" but not "failing" school. In twenty years, give or take a decade, this school might meet California's target of 800 points on the Academic Performance Index. Students at this school and other schools in my district will never even receive the extra reading-tutoring voucher that kids at failing schools will get. And these kids need some extra reading help. My school district has an average of 48 percent of students scoring above the 50th percentile on the Stanford 9 in reading.  

The education situation in my neighborhood is more critical than the poor-performing trash collector. Unless parents can afford to "buy" their way out, they will be stuck with low performance for a long time. Unlike the poor-performing trash collector, El Cerrito Elementary's contract will most likely never run out.

This is why education privatization is better than the status quo. It introduces some accountability into the system. An education service provider, like Edison, has a contract with actual requirements for performance. And when they fail to meet those performance measures everyone hears about it and some districts or schools cancel their contract. That's the point, and it shows privatization works better than the status quo.

But this minor improvement over the status quo should never be confused with a real education market with competition and choice. The media confuses the two all the time.  Take this sentence from the Financial Times last week covering the Philadelphia school privatization: "The plan marks the biggest trial of school privatisation, the controversial approach that pits advocates of public education against free-market reformers."  

Privatization is usually equated with a free-market in the press and by most education reform activists. Yet, privatization is only a poor proxy for competition in education. Even when a school is privatized, that school does not face a true market test. The kids that go to the privatized school in Philadelphia, for example, will be the same kids who went to the public school last year.  And if Edison or their counterparts fail, then those same families will send their kids to the next government-selected school the next year. The parents never exercise choice and the schools, whether private or public, are not threatened by the right of exit of the school children they serve.  

While Edison and other education service providers are arguably more responsive than the public school providers, ultimately the government agency and not the parent is their customer.

When I think of this dilemma, I remember two speeches I heard back to back at the Association of Education Practitioners and Providers conference last summer at USC.  Chris Whittle gave a speech on Edison's model of national schooling companies and economies of scale. Jack Clegg, the CEO of Nobel Learning Communities, gave a speech on why public education needs a new heart made up of school choice, where parents pick the school that most fits their child's needs.  At the time I thought it was striking how the themes in the speeches matched the companies'  business models. Chris Whittle has tried to go national by wooing large school districts and ramping up several schools at a time based on government contracts to run multiple schools. Jack Clegg, on the other hand, has grown by attracting parents to his schools--one school at a time.  Guess which company's stock has a higher value? Guess which company is meeting the market test without a government sanction?

Now don't get me wrong, I work for a think tank that has advocated privatization for thirty years. Just last week the Financial Times called me a "pro-privatisation advocate."  I applaud Edison. I'm impressed they have lasted this long in the brutal world of labor negotiations and government contracts. The recent Gray Davis/ California Teachers Association brouhaha proves that teacher's unions eat their own kind. And as Checker Finn said yesterday in an editorial in his Education Gadfly about Edison, "Never forget that the teacher unions HATE Edison and the other EMO's and are doing their best to subvert and bankrupt all such ventures. . . . they so look forward to dancing on its grave."


I applaud Chris Whittle and find it fascinating that Edison has lasted this long.  They have, partly because they have a superior product, and when the product is well implemented and the contract goes their way, student achievement goes up. Ultimately though, this is a poor proxy for real competition and choice. In a real free market system, Edison wouldn't need a well-written contract to ensure that they could properly implement their business model. Instead, they would need customers that were willing to support their model and enroll their children.  

When school districts, school boards, or state governments choose an education service provider, it is no different than the city choosing your trash hauler or your cable service. If you have a complaint, you are at the mercy of the government agency that selected the provider. Likewise, if you like Edison, and the school board does not (think San Francisco), you are still at the mercy of the government agency.  Either way the government is still choosing.

I can't hire a trash company that actually picks up my trash and I can't find a local government school that can teach my kids to read. But at least with the school situation, I can pay a private school in downtown Riverside, The Growing Place, to teach my kids to read. The law prevents me from hiring a different trash hauler. Things could be worse. And for many kids, things are worse.


Thanks for your continued support of Reason's education program.


Best,

Lisa 

Lisa Snell
Director Education Program
Reason Foundation
3415 S. Sepulveda Blvd. #400
Los Angeles, CA 90034
www.reason.org
www.RPPI.org
www.reason.com
310-391-2245

-----Original Message-----
From: Fred Dickinson [mailto:Dickinson.Fred@hsmv.state.fl.us]
Sent: Wednesday, May 29, 2002 1:48 PM
To: myersm@doacs.state.fl.us; rhodest@doacs.state.fl.us;
gallaghert@doi.state.fl.us; tornillor@doi.state.fl.us;
castilc@eog.state.fl.us; Jeb Bush;
patricia_a_romig@mail.dbf.state.fl.us;
robert_f_milligan@mail.dbf.state.fl.us; lewisr@mail.doe.state.fl.us;
lgoodson@mail.dos.state.fl.us; secretary@mail.dos.state.fl.us;
charlie.crist@myflorida.com; kent_perez@oag.state.fl.us;
paula_wood@oag.state.fl.us
Subject: Memorial Weekend Crash Fatality Stats


The 2002 Memorial Day Preliminary Traffic Fatality Report indicates a dramatic reduction in highway deaths from the previous holiday period in 2001.  The 2002 preliminary total stands at 15 deaths, which is a 57 percent decrease from the preliminary 35 deaths that occurred in 2001.  Attached is a preliminary fatality report.

This dramatic reduction can be attributed to several factors.  Currently, the Florida Highway Patrol, along with the rest of Florida's law enforcement community, is aggressively participating in the Click It or Ticket  campaign that continues through June 2, 2002.  This media blitz and zero tolerance approach regarding seat belt and child restraint violations will prove that using the vehicle's occupant protection system will save lives.  

Colonel Chris Knight also instructed all personnel who are regularly assigned to administrative duties to work the road this past holiday period, thus increasing visibility.  The FHP also continues with its Statewide Overtime Activity Reporting program.  This program allows troopers to work an additional 24 hours of overtime within a 40-hour workweek.  

At the last Cabinet meeting, Attorney General Butterworth asked about the percentage of crash fatalities that were not buckled up.  In 2001, there were 2,081 fatalities in seat belt equipped vehicles.  Of those, 1,325 were not buckled up, or 64 percent.  This is an improvement from year 2000 in which 68 percent were not buckled up. 

Fred O. Dickinson
Dept. of Highway Safety & Motor Vehicles

Governor,

Below is a news release concerning our soldiers arrival at Ft. Stewart, GA.
The major training exercise is underway.  The convoy movements went very
well.  I have appointed Gen Watson as the Multi-State Task Force Commander
and am pleased to report that he is doing quite well. His tactical
perspective is well known.

We had significant problems Friday night getting 22 train cars of Abrams
Tanks and Armored Personnel Carriers through the "switch" at Waycross, GA. I
called Mr. Jeff Crowe of Landstar Corp who put me in touch with the senior
leadership at CSX railroad.   CSX did everything we needed...made it happen
and the tanks arrived in time for the exercise.

I just spoke at a Memorial Day service....reminded the attendees of the
superior job being done by our President and that "help has arrived".

Doug

> 
> Florida Guard Units Arrive Safely at Fort Stewart
> 
> 	Over 5,000 Florida National Guardsmen have arrived at Fort Stewart,
> Ga, near Savannah, for the Florida guard's major annual training period
> this year.
> 	They started rolling in Friday evening and by the time the final
> vehicle passed through the gates at Fort Stewart two days later, 22
> convoys, totaling more than 800 pieces of rolling stock, had arrived for
> the Rehearsal Annual Training, a major exercise for Florida's 53rd
> Infantry Brigade.
> 	Stretched along the interstate for miles, units scattered across the
> state from Miami to Pensacola came via convoy or piled into 40 commercial
> buses for the long trip north.
> Units from other states as far away as New Hampshire and New Mexico came
> by commercial and military air. Tanks, tracked vehicles, and heavy
> equipment were shipped in by rail.
> 	And most importantly, everyone arrived safely.
> Maj. Martin Hersey, Safety Officer for the exercise, said, "With all the
> holiday traffic, we've had no reports of accidents.  From a safety
> standpoint this is a big step toward the success of our mission."
> 	The Florida soldiers, along with guard and reserve units from 12
> other states and Puerto Rico, comprise a multi-state task force supporting
> the 53rd Infantry Brigade's annual training.  This year's exercise is
> preparation for the task force's participation at the Joint Readiness
> Training Center at Fort Polk, La. next summer.
> 		Once the final convoy was on post, Brig. Gen. Jimmy Watson,
> the Multi-state Task Force Commander, said, " I'm pleased that all the
> units arrived safely. It speaks of the soldier's level of readiness and
> professionalism that they made this extensive movement without accident."

From:	Ross Doman <rdoman@state.wy.us>
Sent:	Wednesday, May 29, 2002 4:13 PM
To:	rwdoman@yahoo.com
Subject:	PRESS RELEASE FROM THE WYOMING DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH
Attachments:	bushgeringer.jpg

May 29, 2002

*** FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE ***

Note to Editors: 
The following is the photo cutline for the picture that moved with this email: Photo credit is from Ross Doman / Wyoming Department of Health, but use or do not or change  per your policy; your needs:

Florida First Lady, Columba Bush, and Wyoming First Lady, Sherri Geringer, embrace on Wednesday in Jackson at the Third Annual Alcohol Education Showcase where they spoke on the far-reaching negative impact of underage drinking. Mrs. Bush and Mrs. Geringer are promoting the First Spouses Initiative - a partnership of 36 current and former First Spouses throughout the United States taking steps to prevent underage alcohol use. 

***

Sherri Geringer hosts Florida First Lady Columba Bush at alcohol education conference in Jackson

JACKSON, WY - First Ladies from states separated by thousands of miles stood arm in arm on Wednesday in Jackson to discuss the debilitating and often tragic consequences of underage drinking.

Sherri Geringer hosted Florida First Lady Columba Bush at the Third Annual Alcohol Education Showcase which brought together about 150 people representing law enforcement, schools, and community activists. The attendees gathered to strategize on battling the rising tide of underage drinking in Wyoming where reports indicate one-third of the state's high school seniors engage in binge drinking during any two week period.

"The fact is, it's illegal for anyone under the age of 21 to drink any alcoholic beverages," said Geringer. "But the law is not enough. Adults have to get involved so we can shake this cultural attitude that drinking is just another rite of passage."

Bush said that she informs Florida's youth about the dangers of alcohol and drug abuse by visiting at least two schools every month throughout the state as well as delivering the message to prevention programs and community events.

"Our children are in need of a positive message," Bush said. "Life is too important to let alcohol and other forms of substance abuse interfere with their studies, their happiness, and their futures."

The deaths of the eight University of Wyoming students at the hands of drunk driver Clinton Haskins - who was sentenced for the crime earlier this week - was at the surface of much of the conference dialogue in Jackson.

"Last September, eight U.W. students were killed by a drunk and driving ninth student," Geringer said. "This was an act of violence unprecedented in our state's history - and a cultural failure for Wyoming. Law enforcement records show how many times Clinton Haskins was caught driving drunk before the incident, but no records exist on how many times he was not caught, or how young he was when he took his first drink, or how many times someone looked the other way when his drinking was out of control."

"How many 15- to 20-year olds were drinking that night?," she asked. "And how many others engaged in risky behavior? How much potential was lost that Saturday night in our state?"

The Leadership to Keep Children Alcohol Free brings public awareness to the issue of preventing early alcohol use by 9- to 15- year old kids. Geringer is a member of the Leadership Committee of the national initiative launched two years ago that involves 36 current and former governor's spouses. 

Diane Galloway, the substance abuse administrator for the Wyoming Department of Health said that over $4.4 million in grant funding will be available to Wyoming communities this fall. The grant announcement will be made on June 6 and those interested should call 800-536-4006.

The event was sponsored by the Wyoming Department of Health Substance Abuse Division and funded by a grant from the Office of Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention.


-end-

For more information, contact:
Ross Doman, Public Information Officer, Wyoming Department of Health, (307) 631-0699.

From: lb24fan [mailto:lb24fan@cfl.rr.com]
Sent: Wednesday, May 29, 2002 12:01 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Nanny Bill/Educational System/


 
Dear Jeb, (PLEASE READ ALL OF THIS…VERY IMPORTANT!!!!)
 
We are extremely disappointed that you actually signed the Nanny Bill into law. You have helped to create a new monster that is even more devastating to Florida families than our current corrupt Social Services organization. I hope you will remember this when the horror stories start hitting the media…and believe me, it’s gonna hit the fan, and you will be responsible for the ensuing mess.
 
In fact, we are extremely disappointed that our government officials are so very uneducated in the area of child raising altogether. The public school system is an absolute shame and more money, all the money in the world, will not fix it. Teaching methods are still being used that were put in place at the turn of the LAST century, over 100 years ago. Except that now, rather than teaching the three R’s, the schools are teaching our children that it’s OK to be gay, there is no wrong and right, there are only gray areas…something called “humanism”, and basically destroying families in their wake of destruction. What’s going on in today’s public schools is like something in a Frank Peretti book…the devil is busier these days…time is definitely very short.
 
Are you aware that America’s school system was based on that of the German’s, with the goal of “educating” their people for factory work? The same system is still in place today in this country. Sure, add a few computers and you can call it “modernizing” our schools, but it doesn’t change the fact that public schools are failing SO MANY people…yep, kids are people…and that no amount of money will fix things. Until kids have a reason to want to learn, and until education is offered in a way that kids want it, the system will continue to degrade into further despair. What do you, yourself, learn today that someone is making you learn? I’ll bet you enjoy learning about things your WANT to learn about, are interested in…why should it be any different for our kids??? Compulsory attendance needs to be completely removed from education. Through thousands of years, it has been a known fact that making a kid do anything only leads to resentment and a big fight…remember how it was/is with your kids? How many times have you heard, “You can’t tell me what to do!!”?
 
And we’re sick to death of hearing about “testing”…more testing…it’s the cart before the horse. What is important, children learning or taking tests, being taught based on tests, being taught how to take tests? How many tests have you taken as an adult, Jeb? Why are the children in this country being taught to take tests? Tests don’t measure their true intelligence…tests simply determine how good they are at taking tests. Most kids know an awful lot of stuff that just isn’t on a test…it doesn’t mean they’re stupid and definitely not learning disabled. Research has shown, time after time, that after high schoolers have crammed for finals, even the ones who ace the tests forget most of the material within 9 weeks post-testing. What did they learn? To pass a test. Is this learning, real learning? ABSOLUTELY NOT!!!!! Real learning sticks with you forever, like riding a bike…you never forget.
 
Case and point – When our son was in the third and sixth grades, he was tested for learning disabilities. Both times he tested above average, very high in language skills, yet his teachers didn’t think he would ever amount to much, oh, and they said he was very disorganized. We pulled both our kids out of school at the end of our son’s sixth grade year and our daughter at the end of fourth grade to home school. Last year, our son graduated a year and a half early with a 3.52 GPA. He was immediately hired to be the “computer brain” for a locally based missionary organization, New Missions, who serve in Haiti and the Dominican Republic. One of the founders’ sons hired Justin after watching him in his volunteer work at Orlando  <http://www.orlandometro.com/> Metro, a Bible Study meeting that takes place at First Baptist of Orlando <http://www.firstorlando.com/> , a church that seats 10,000 people and has a very large media system. Justin is the youngest person to ever operate the computerized lighting system at that church and he learned the system and worked it solo after just six short weeks (that’s six nights) of observing the church’s Lighting Director. Justin became Metro’s Lighting Director for the next year, until the Metro Director decided he was better suited to help run the whole thing and promoted him to Leadership. Justin then created a Communications Team and headed it up for nearly a year…all before he turned 18 years old. Remember, Jeb…his teachers said he’d never amount to anything…was disorganized... We couldn’t be more proud of him!!! Justin’s employers are in awe that he “just soaks this technology stuff up like a sponge.” Justin was never learning disabled and neither are most of the kids that get labeled with that “loser” term.
 
Jeb, the public schools are in a desperate state. Government leaders need to get educated on what real learning is and should be…if they’re truly concerned about what kind of people will be “running the show” twenty years down the road.
 
There’s a short video that would be great for you to see…it’s only 59 minutes in length, yet contains so much about this country’s history, including education. It’s called, “America’s Godly Heritage” by David Barton. David Barton is founder of WallBuilders <http://www.wallbuilders.com/> , an organization dedicated to the restoration and rebuilding of the values on which America was built and which, in recent years, have been seriously undermined. As stated by George Washington, David believes that “the propitious [favorable] smiles of heaven can never be expected on a nation which disregards the eternal rules of order and right which heaven itself has ordained.” You can order the video here - http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/search-handle-form/103-7377467-0293448. It would be well worth your time to view it, at least once. My family has received a great blessing from watching it, as well as confirmation on what we know is wrong with the public school system and why we removed our children from its fatal grasp…yes, fatal…schools are killing children’s natural curiosity and natural inclinations to learn.
 
One other wonderful educational tool (one of many) is the book, “In Their Own Way” by Dr. Thomas Armstrong. Research has shown that there are seven known intelligences, or learning styles:
 
1.	Linguistic Intelligence 

2.	Logical-Mathematical Intelligence 

3.	Spatial Intelligence 

4.	Musical Intelligence 

5.	Bodily-Kinesthetic Intelligence (these are the kids who just can’t sit still in school, and shouldn’t be) 

6.	Interpersonal Intelligence 

7.	Intrapersonal Intelligence 
 
Schools only address #1 and #2. The rest of the kids either find a way to muddle through or get stamped learning disabled. Very interesting, don’t ya think? I’ll bet you just learned something new…read the book for more great stuff!
 
We’re very sorry for Florida families who will be subjected to the Learning Gateway/Nanny Bill. We’re very thankful that we won’t be having any more children under this kind of oppression but we will continue to work in defense of young couples who want to start families under this new regime. It’s like we’re going backwards, back into the middle ages, with this lack of knowledge and removal of freedoms and rights that were presumed safe in the USA…it’s a grim future.
 
Most Sincerely,
 
Lisa Butler
Orlando, FL
http://home.cfl.rr.com/jg24fans

-----Original Message-----
From: Mary Kay Cariseo [mailto:mkcariseo@fl-counties.com]
Sent: Wednesday, May 29, 2002 4:07 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: Mary Kay Cariseo
Subject: CS/HB 1341 Community Redevelopment Agencies


Dear Governor Bush,
 
I understand that CS/HB 1341 is due for your consideration tomorrow.  I would like to restate our support for this legislation.
 
The counties sought the legislation to address problems that we are seeing at the local level, particularly with regard to the formation of new CRAs.  The present law allows a CRA to be formed solely if there is "inadequate parking," which I think you will agree would allow a CRA to be formed in many areas of the state which would not be considered "blighted areas" in any other manner.  In addition, present law sets a subjective standard for whether the proposed CRA constitutes a threat to the public health, safety and welfare.  The legislation addresses these statutory deficiencies, and requires that in order for a new CRA to be formed that there be substantial findings of "blighted area" based on objective and specific criteria.  The addition of more objective criteria will help ensure that the public purpose intended for CRAs will be served.
 
In addition, the bill grandfathers existing CRAs from the new requirements unless they propose to expand their boundaries.   The bill represents a compromise reached after substantial discussion with all interested parties.  Furthermore, if the bill does not become law, we anticipate the formation of many new CRAs between now and the time the Legislature returns, which could have a substantial, negative, and long-term impact on county finances.
 
Please contact me if you have any concerns about the bill.
 
Mary Kay
Florida Association of Counties

I am writing as a member of the Workforce Florida, Inc., Board of Directors,
an appointment I accepted from you in July of 2000.

Florida law indicates that your appointees to the WFI Board serve for
two-year terms and that the Governor has authority to re-appoint existing
members upon completion of their terms.  The purpose of this e-mail is to
let you know that I would like to be re-appointed to the Board for another
two-year term, beginning in July of this year.

I believe the past two years have been very productive and successful for
Workforce Florida, Inc., under the careful and sage guidance of Chairman
Toni Jennings, and they've also been both challenging and rewarding for me
personally.  My service on the Board has allowed me to follow through on my
protracted involvement in reforming Florida's workforce development system,
which I began as a representative of the business community with the Florida
Chamber of Commerce.

My commitment to improving Florida's workforce system has become an ongoing
responsibility that continues to this day.  I would be very happy to
continue my service as a member of the WFI Board.

I have delivered this message to your office at the Capitol as an actual
letter, which I have copied to your Appointments Office so that I might be
provided with instructions for establishing myself as eligible for
re-appointment.  I can be reached by voice at 224-1585, fax at 222-0398, or
email at abrown@carltonfields.com.

you at your convenience.  Please contact me if I can ever assist you in any
way.

-----Original Message-----
From: Thompson, Sandra [mailto:Sandra.Thompson@morganstanley.com]
Sent: Friday, May 24, 2002 9:51 AM
To: 'Jeb@Jeb.com'; Jeb Bush
Subject: Barbara Wilcox referral


5/24/02

Governor Bush-

I recently spoke with Barbara Wilcox, my (favorite) aunt, asking her
advice
with an issue and she suggested I contact you to ask for your
assistance.
Just within the last 48 hours it has become obvious that time is of the
essence.

I have lived in Pinellas County and boated in the Gulf waters for over
20
years.  There are a number of islands which are part of the Gulf Islands
Geo
Parks System that many boaters visit and enjoy.  We (the boaters) have
peacefully co-existed with the various animals and shorebirds since
nature
created these islands.

Recently the Parks Department has begun to actively regulate and
restrict
our usage basing their actions on unsubstantiated data.  Signs have
appeared
"overnight" and law enforcement has begun patrolling the islands.  At
issue
are NO pets, NO overnight camping, NO camp fires, NO alcohol, NO
overnight
anchoring close to some of the islands.

"S.O.S." or Save Our Sandbar, a grass roots group of boaters was formed
to
explore the validity of the Parks claiming and enforcing jurisdiction on
the
islands.  As a result of group members contacting our elected officials
and
attending local government meetings a proposal was offered by the Parks
Department which we interpreted as a starting point for resolution to
this
issue. Discussion of the proposal was the main item on the agenda of our
May
22nd meeting.

In addition to a lawyer S.O.S. has retained to advise us on our options,
two
representatives from the Parks Department were at the meeting.  Since we
were to discuss our legal and non-legal options, the two gentlemen were
asked to leave.  I was in ear shot of the entire conversation and once
the
situation was explained, the two men left -it was all very amicable.
 
The very next morning the Fish & Wildlife Department showed up on the
North
Anclote Sandbar, erected signs and roped off a fairly large portion of
the
island.  They also informed boaters anchored there that this weekend
(Memorial Day) they would be heavily patrolling and enforcing the
restrictions.

Whether the actions of the Fish & Wildlife Department were in
retaliation of
the Parks Department representatives being asked to leave, who knows.
But I
fear this is going to escalate into something big and ugly...FAST.  Egos
are
taking over and emotions are starting to run high and unfortunately
those at
the extreme ends of this issue are going to push this past negotiating
and
into the courts.

I know you are an extremely busy man (oh, and thanks for keeping our
phone
bills down) but this issue cuts to the very core of citizens' rights to
enjoy where we have chosen to live and recreate.  Any intervention or
assistance on your part would be immensely appreciated.

Sandra L. Thompson
727/799-5819
727/452-5916

My name is Harold Wheeler and I am the Director of the Monroe County Tourist

your brother when he was running for Governor of Texas for the first time at a

CVB on South Padre Island at the time.  President Bush has brought a level of 
patriotism back to this country that we haven't seen in a long while and I am 
proud of his Presidency.  I have also met and been with your father a number of 
times at the George Bush/Cheeca Lodge Bonefish Tournament in Islamorada.  We 
are a major sponsor of the tournament.

Now that I have set some kind of familiarity, please let me get to the point of 
writing you personally.  Monroe County, which represents all the Florida Keys 
and part of the Everglades National Park on the mainland, is an important co  
mponent of the Florida tourism program.  We are among the top in tourist 
development tax revenue collections in the State.  We also were one of the 
founding members of the Visit Florida partnership program. Our County and 
myself, feel very strongly that we should have representation on the Florida 
Commission on Tourism.  There are six (6) positions within our Southeastern 
region and there is no one from the Florida Keys.  I would ask that you 
consider my name to represent Monroe County on the Commission.  The Commission 
plays an important role on the direction in which tourism promotion is 
developed in Florida and I believe I can bring something to the table or I 
wouldn't ask for the appointment.

I appreciate your time and your consideration.  Thank you very much.

Harold D. Wheeler
Monroe County TDC
Florida Keys & Key West

FYI-  On August 7 Carole and I are headed for the Nigu River on the North Slope of Alaska, just above the Brooks Range for a 10 day raft trip to the Arctic Ocean. Oh, the irony!

----- Original Message -----
From: "Cliett, Cheryl" <Cheryl.Cliett@MyFlorida.com>
To: <vicr@adelphia.net>
Cc: "'Jeb Bush'" <jeb@jeb.org>; "Brown, Brewser"
<Brewser.Brown@MyFlorida.com>
Sent: Wednesday, May 29, 2002 5:25 PM
Subject: RE: Still waiting to hear from your staff fup


Vic,
In the 2001 Session, the Legislature passed CS/CS/HB 1193, which required
school districts to treat years of teaching experience outside the district
the same as years of teaching experience within the district, for purposes
of pay.  The district school board was required to recognize and accept each
year of full-time teaching service for which the employee received a
satisfactory performance evaluation.  The provision was not intended to
interfere with collective bargaining except to the extent it required the
agreement to treat years of teaching experience out of the district the same
as years of teaching experience within the district. The provision did not
apply to a retired teacher from the Florida system coming back to work.  The
provision did not apply to teacher already employed in a district, but only
to those teachers who were entering into contracts with district in which
they were not employed as of June 30, 2001. (s. 231.36(3)(g), F.S.)

This year in the School Code Rewrite bill, SB 20-E, which passed during
Session 2002-E, the language was clarified.  Teaching experience must have
been in a public school but can be either in the state of Florida or outside
the state.  The language "not intended to interfere in collective bargaining
agreement" was eliminated.  (SB 20-E, page 1319, lines 19-28)  *** The new
school code rewrite does not take effect until January,2003

Districts have creative ways of implementing this legislation.  You need to
call the district to find out exactly why, they are not planning to give
full credit.

If you need additional information, call 850/414-6694 - Florida House of
Representatives, Council for Lifelong learning or the Florida Department of
Education, Bureau of Educator Recruitment & Professional Development (850)
922-9750

Hope this helps!

Cheryl Cliett
Teacher-in-Residence
Executive Office of the Governor

Governor,
 
I spoke to Commissioner Bronson today on the issue.  A lot of the money will be spent to develop biological controls for the plant.  Florida has been designated as the lead state in the southeast to come up with and implement a control procedure, and our risk is that if we don't other states won't accept our cattle.

From:	Leonard Cooperman <lcooperm@tampabay.rr.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, May 29, 2002 7:06 PM
To:	Jeb Bush

From:	Dr. Joanna M. Clekis, LMHC <joanna.clekis@verizon.net>
Sent:	Wednesday, May 29, 2002 10:18 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Alcohol, Drug Abuse, and Mental Health/DCF (PRTS) Purchased Residential Treatment Services dollars. 

May 29, 2002

 

The Honorable Jeb Bush

The Capitol

Tallahassee, FL 32399-0001

 

Dear Governor Bush:

 

I am sending this letter with the hope that you will take action to prevent the elimination of the children’s mental health treatment services now provided through Alcohol, Drug Abuse, and Mental Health/DCF (PRTS) Purchased Residential Treatment Services dollars. 

 

Programs for severely emotionally disturbed children and their families that will be eliminated include residential treatment, therapeutic group homes, therapeutic foster care programs, in-home counseling, outpatient counseling, aftercare components and case management services.  The families that utilize these services will be unable to get these intensive mental health services in any other way.  Many of these families do not have Medicaid and their insurance does not cover these services. 

 

Most families are not able afford the $300.00 a day cost of a residential program for their child. If these services are not available to these severely emotionally disturbed children, they will continually be in and out of mental health crisis stabilization facilities, juvenile commitment programs, or possibly follow through with their homicidal and/ or suicidal threats. 

 

The parents of these children will be very frustrated with their inability to provide the level of care their child needs. Without the necessary support system these parents will most probably feel the need to relinquish custody of their child to the state to get their child the help they need. This type of desperate measure has been used in the past and was found to be ineffective and much more expensive both in human and financial terms. The goal of the Purchased Residential Treatment Services program is to keep families intact and to teach the necessary skills to help their children to become productive adults.  

 

Throughout the state thousands of severely emotionally disturbed children have been treated in cost-efficient therapeutically effective programs funded through the State of Florida. The funding shift awaiting the Governors signature will eliminate many   programs that currently assist families when mental health crises occur and support the child being maintained in the community. These are the very services that prevent children from requiring deep end and very expensive institutional placements. 

 

Please Governor Bush, take the necessary action to restore this funding and stop the transfer of PRTS funds to Medicaid.  The children and families of this state who do not qualify for Medicaid assistance are counting on you.

 

Sincerely,

 

Dr. Joanna M. Clekis, LMHC
Jessica Leigh Clekis
Chelsea Clekis

-----Original Message-----
From: Sandy Faulkner [mailto:sfaulk@tampabay.rr.com]
Sent: Wednesday, May 08, 2002 12:36 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Department of Children & Families


Dear Jeb,
 
I regret that I have to write you this e-mail at a time when you are
already faced with mounting problems with the Department of Families and
Children but a problem arrived on my doorstep unexpectedly and I can't
just turn away.  
 
Over the weekend, Debbie brought a co-worker, Stefani home to join our
family for a Sunday BBQ. Debbie had expressed concern for this girl
because she had no parents and said her landlord wasn't very nice to
her, so we decided to have her join us for a family day.   During the
day, Stephani, who is 16,  told us about the exorbitant rent her
landlord was charging her.  She explained that she pays over $600 per
month rent for a room in the home of an employee (case worker) of the
Department of Families & Children.  In addition,  the woman charges her
extra for food, telephone and other incidentals, and gets angry when she
has to pick Stefani up from work.   
 
If that wasn't bad enough, last night, the woman told the girl to "Pick
up your sh#$ and get out!!"   Being 16, the girl the only person she
knew she could call, a 19-year-old former foster sister to come get her.
She was picked up and spent the night with her foster sister.  To make
matters even worse, the landlord/caseworker, reported the girl as a
runaway today, and then had the girl's only means of communication, her
cell phone (that Stephani pays for) shut off.
 
Before her phone was shut off, Stefani called Debbie  asking her what
she should do.  Debbie handed the phone to me, and I have spent an
entire day trying to find this girl some help.  To me, this is an
inexcusable situation . . . certainly not as heinous as that of the
missing 5-year-old, but certainly of major concern when those in charge
of  protecting these kids are the ones taking advantage of them.
 
I have contacted a family court judge, the public defender's office, the
state attorney and Gus Bilirakis's office and am awaiting replies.
When I spoke with the State Attorney's office I was told I needed to
contact the girl's caseworker.   When I explained that the problem was
with one of the case workers in the same office, they still insisted
that I would have to talk with the case worker if there is a problem.
It seem to me, that calling the case worker who placed the girl with a
co-worker who is charging this girl rent plus is liking asking the "wolf
to watch the hen house!"  I was so baffled by the response, that I asked
the person at the State Attorney's office if there was anyone who looked
out for children in these situations and the answer I received was "I
don't know.  You have to call the case worker."    
 
I'm sure there are all kinds of rules and regulations that I don't know
and probably wouldn't understand.   But what I do know is that this
"case" is not a number but a child, without any parents, who is working
hard to maintain an 3.5 GPA in High School, works 30-40 hrs a week, and
is being grossly taking advantage of by the very people who should be
looking out for her.   I can't even explain how disgusted and frustrated
I am.
 
I realize you can't get involved in all the individual cases all around
the state, but considering the current scrutiny of this department, I
wanted to share this situation since it seems to involve employees of
the department using their positions in an improper way.
 
I will continue to work with the professionals locally until we can find
a suitable solution for Stefani.  My only concern is that I am leaving
on Monday for a trip to Washington D.C. with Debbie & Lisa. Although our
main purpose of the trip is for Debbie to visit Georgetown University
where she is seriously considering applying to the  School of Foreign
Service, we plan to send a couple of extra days touring the city, since
neither of the girls have ever visited before.  We planned the trip
early so when Debbie returns she can begin her search for a summer
job/internship or volunteer position with an agency or organization
associated with International or Latin American Relations to further
explore her possible career choice.   
 
Although I'm really excited and looking forward to taking Debbie & Lisa
to Washington, I am very concerned with leaving Stefani.  I hope we can
get her situation resolved before I leave on Monday, but I'm not very
optimistic at this point.  
 
Regardless of what happens with the Department and Stefani's immediate
situation, I have decided that I will continue to meet and work with
Stefani and be an adult she can trust and count on.  She seems to be a
remarkable young lady who has dreams and goals and appears to have the
strength of character to overcome her difficult childhood to achieve
them.  I only I hope I can help her see them come true.  
 
Thank you for listening.   
 
 
Sincerely,
 
Sandy Faulkner

Dear Governor Bush:
 
I am writing to request your consideration to maintain
a special project in the State's budget for this
coming year.  The project in question is in the
Education budget, line item 5B, SER/SABER for
$300,000.
 
Your commitment to the education of every young person
in Florida is more than well documented.  However, in
recent weeks, we have seen what can happen when our
State's youngest fall through the cracks of our
society's systems.  This project helps keep and
recover young people at-risk, or who have already
fallen through the cracks of our education system.
 
Setting these young Floridians back on their
educational track is critical to their lives and the
economy of their families, communities and our State.
 
 Governor, I respectfully request that you maintain
this small item in the Education budget for the State
of Florida.  I have seen what this organization can do 
and it is worthwhile to fund.

From:	Beth Darrell <bdarrel@us.ibm.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, May 29, 2002 10:19 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Veto budget - save my son!

Importance:	High

Dear Jeb,
I was saddened and outraged to hear about the last minute political
maneuver with the state budget regarding the cut of $2.5 million dollars
from the Department of Children and Families' children's purchased
residential treatment services (PRTS) and the additional transfer of $16
million dollars to the Statewide Inpatient Program (SIPPS), a newly
developed program designed to server only Medicaid eligible children!

My son, Wesley, is 11 years old and will graduate from the 5th grade next
Wednesday.  He was diagnosed when he was 6 with severe ADHD, ODD, and
recently was found to be bipolar.  We have been in individual and family
counseling and seeing a psychiatrist for his medications, ever since he was
first diagnosed.  We have worked with the public school system to provide
the appropriate learning environment for him without preventing the other
students learning needs.  Each year his behavior got worse.  By the time he
was in 4th grade, in October 2000, we had to home school him because he was
not able to control himself at school.

I don't know if you can understand the frustration and hopelessness a
parent feels when they see their child, full of potential, unable to
realize that potential, while they are doing everything they know to do.
We are a middle-class family so we are fortunate to have good benefits and
be able to see the multitude of specialists Wesley's situation requires.
But we were really blessed when Wesley became eligible to reside at Carlton
Manor.  Carlton Manor is a residential home for at-risk boys that provides
a highly-structured environment, and individual, group, and family therapy.
Carlton Manor is funded through the Suncoast Region ADM funds with some
matching funds from the Juvenile Welfare Board and other resources.

Wesley lives with us, his family, on the weekends.  He has been living at
Carlton Manor since July 31, 2001, and last grading period received
straight A's!  Quite an improvement from home schooling the year before!!
But Carlton Manor has also helped the family through family counseling and
observing what works in the group home.  Wesley is expected to "graduate"
(come back home) in the next few months.  I don't know what we would have
done or what Wesley would have become without this program.

I urge you not to approve the budget and lose this program.  For boys like
my son and their families, it is the only hope they have to learn to cope
in the world with their challenges.  If you would like any more information
about this facility, please do not hesitate to contact me.  My home phone
is (727) 375-9464, and the address is:

Beth Darrell
4404 Gem Ct.
New Port Richey, FL  34655

Thank you for letting me take up your time and expressing my concern.  This
is the first time I have felt so strongly about an issue.


Beth Darrell, e-COMET Administration and Support
Telephone:  813-356-4674  t/l 697-4674
Address:  3031 N. Rocky Point Drive West, Tampa, FL  33607
Maildrop 612A    Cubicle 608H

e-COMET website:  http://9.75.29.7/ebiz/deployment/

-----Original Message-----
From: ARGENZIANO.NANCY <ARGENZIANO.NANCY@leg.state.fl.us>
To: Jeb Bush <jeb@jeb.org>
Sent: Wed May 29 23:20:12 2002
Subject: RE: veto

  

Dear Governor Bush,

      I am obviously having problems with my computer, so will rely on cut and paste.

    Your apology regarding the lateness of your office’s contact appears genuine, and I appreciate that.  

    However, if you believe that the water management district governing board and basin board members are sufficient alone to reflect the concerns of the citizens, then I fear you may be too remote from the grass roots universe which I hear from every day.  Perhaps you are being misled or are otherwise unaware of the actual relationships between the real people and the bureaucracies.

     There have been several bills in the past few years – Panasoffkee, Lake Harris (no matter that they are without a basin board), Okeechobee – reflecting that the bureaucracies tend to placate, task force and study to death, but not get anything done.  Citizens are demanding more empowerment and participation in common bureaucratic practices, in particular those of the WMDs, which are perceived as autocratic, and this bill would have allowed participation with those boards and agencies in reporting back recommendations to the legislature, thus making them feel members of a democracy.  And, of course, in paying for those bureaucracies, legitimately they are entitled to participation.  The present system is not working Governor, which may be why these types of bills have been passed (in HB 374’s case, unanimously).  In the committees this year in particular, legislators voiced a sentiment that they want a legislative fix regarding the structure of the water management districts, and particularly the non-elected governing boards.  The discussions were substantial and in depth, primarily because legislators are hearing from their constituents.  

   If you think that the governing boards have been solving problems, look into the St. Johns WMD waste of $25,000,000 of P-2000, SOR and CARL funds, and missing equipment, and SWFWMD’s recent fiasco in spending $1,200,000 for a $600,000 job, in which they by-passed the competitive bidding process.

   I have been fighting inflated bureaucracies for years, doing so regularly as a member of the general government appropriations committee.  This bill is not to inflate bureaucracy or to grow bureaucracy.  It was to empower citizens to hold bureaucracies accountable.

   I wish I had the chance to talk with you before the veto, and share with you several years of  citizen input, which was the impetus for the bill.  Without having that information, and perhaps only having the territory-protecting view of the bureaucrats, the veto was a mistake.

      Sincerely, 

      Nancy Argenziano            

-----Original Message-----
From: Jeb Bush [mailto:jeb@jeb.org]

To: ARGENZIANO.NANCY
Subject: RE: veto


I am sorry that Hayden didn't contact you sooner. He should have and I thought your office had been contacted about the bill previously. 
 
The reasons for the veto were stated in the letter. I believe in our very own universe that this was the right thing to do. We have basin boards and a water management district board and that should be enough to get citizen input which I know is important. 
 
Again, I apologize for you hearing about this after the fact. 
 

Jeb Bush

Dear Governor Bush: 

     I just received word from my office - word left on my answering machine at 4:58 Friday afternoon, by Hayden Dempsey - that you had vetoed HB 374, the Citrus Hernando Waterways bill.

     While I am disturbed by the actual veto - after all, in some universe there may have been a rational basis - I am still more disturbed by the specious after the fact notification and lack of courtesy in discussing the matter with me.  After all, I only worked on this matter with the citizens for two years, perhaps knew a thing or two, and could easily have contravened the veto message rationale.

      Oh yes, I am confused why you permitted passage of Senator Cowin's bill, with language and purpose identical to HB 374, and based thereon.  Apparently Lake County residents can input, but not those in Citrus and Hernando. 

Nancy Argenziano

From:	Showcase Marketing <shocase@verizon.net>
Sent:	Thursday, May 30, 2002 7:40 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Budget Cuts - Emotionally disturbed children

May 29, 2002
 
The Honorable Jeb Bush
The Capitol
Tallahassee, FL 32399-0001

Dear Governor Bush:

I am sending this letter with the hope that you will take action to prevent the elimination of the children’s mental health treatment services now provided through Alcohol, Drug Abuse, and Mental Health/DCF (PRTS) Purchased Residential Treatment Services dollars. 

Programs for severely emotionally disturbed children and their families that will be eliminated include residential treatment, therapeutic group homes, therapeutic foster care programs, in-home counseling, outpatient counseling, aftercare components and case management services. The families that utilize these services will be unable to get these intensive mental health services in any other way. Many of these families do not have Medicaid and their insurance does not cover these services. 

Most families are not able afford the $300.00 a day cost of a residential program for their child. If these services are not available to these severely emotionally disturbed children, they will continually be in and out of mental health crisis stabilization facilities, juvenile commitment programs, or possibly follow through with their homicidal and/ or suicidal threats. 

The parents of these children will be very frustrated with their inability to provide the level of care their child needs. Without the necessary support system these parents will most probably feel the need to relinquish custody of their child to the state to get their child the help they need. This type of desperate measure has been used in the past and was found to be ineffective and much more expensive both in human and financial terms. The goal of the Purchased Residential Treatment Services program is to keep families intact and to teach the necessary skills to help their children to become productive adults. 

Throughout the state thousands of severely emotionally disturbed children have been treated in cost-efficient therapeutically effective programs funded through the State of Florida. The funding shift awaiting the Governors signature will eliminate many programs that currently assist families when mental health crises occur and support the child being maintained in the community. These are the very services that prevent children from requiring deep end and very expensive institutional placements. 

Please Governor Bush, take the necessary action to restore this funding and stop the transfer of PRTS funds to Medicaid. The children and families of this state who do not qualify for Medicaid assistance are counting on you.

Sincerely,

Jean B. DuPuy

Most families are not able afford the $300.00 a day cost of a residential program for their child. If these services are not available to these severely emotionally disturbed children, they will continually be in and out of mental health crisis stabilization facilities, juvenile commitment programs, or possibly follow through with their homicidal and/ or suicidal threats. 

The parents of these children will be very frustrated with their inability to provide the level of care their child needs. This type of desperate measure has been used in the past and was found to be ineffective and much more expensive both in human and financial terms. From:	Secretary@doh.state.fl.us
Sent:	Thursday, May 30, 2002 9:12 AM
To:	alexander22300@aol.com
