Subject:	FW: An opportunity to help Alexander Siebert

Dear Ms. Siebert: 
Thank you for your email of May 22, 2002 telling me about your son Alexander.  I was concerned when I read in your email that you have been experiencing difficulties in working with the Infants and Toddlers Early Intervention Program.  At the same time, I was pleased to learn that you have been able to establish a positive and supportive relationship with the local Children's Medical Services (CMS) Network.  I encourage you to continue working with Heather Pepper, your CMS case management nurse to ensure that Alexander receives the medical supports and services that he requires. 

I hope that you will continue to work with the local Early Intervention (EI) Program to develop a Family Support Plan that appropriately addresses Alexander and your needs.  Dr. Michael Haney, Division Director for Prevention and Interventions, has assured me that staff from the Early Intervention Unit are working with you and local EI Program staff to address your concerns.  I understand that a Family Support Plan meeting for Alexander has been scheduled for early in June and that representatives from the CMS Program Office, the local EI Program and the local CMS Network will participate.  I am certain that with your advocacy and the expertise of this team we should be able to identify and respond to Alexander's needs.

I am always interested to hear from the families that we serve and again thank you for writing to me.  I am encouraged that the CMS Network and local CMS Early Intervention Program will be able to work together with you to address Alexander's medical and developmental needs. Let me know if I can be of any further help. 

Sincerely, 
John O. Agwunobi, M.D., M.B.A. 
Secretary 

-----Original Message----- 
From:   Alexander22300@aol.com [mailto:Alexander22300@aol.com]

Subject:        An opportunity to help Alexander Siebert 

Dear Dr. Agwunbi,                                                     5/22/02 
I am writing today with regard to my little boy, Alexander.  He has been in the service of your department for almost two years now.  Originally he was diagnosed with developmental delay and he received physical therapy.  Alexander did not thrive and actually became more delayed in physical therapy and he required speech therapy and occupational therapy.

Since our initial intake into early intervention my son's care has been neglected.  I have made many requests, I have pleaded for assistance, I have even offered to take early intervention staff out to lunch but alas I was left with no recourse but to file formal complaints.  To date my complaints go unresolved.  Dr. Haney has a copy of everything I have sent and I will avail myself to you to answer any question you may have regarding Alexander, his condition, and my complaints.

Tragically, my son has been diagnosed with Leigh's disease; a mitochondrial disorder that's hallmarked by necrotizing brain tissue.  He literally has a degenerative brain disease in which he will only become worse.  He is terminally ill.  Phyllis Sloyer can also verify this information.  More tragically is the apathetical treatment he received in early intervention and the failure to address my formal complaints in order to help Alexander.

Today provides you with the opportunity to help Alexander, help early intervention services be a prevention and early in intervention model, and minimize future problems.  Alexander's FSP has been in noncompliance now for almost two years but more importantly Alexander has not received the services he needed to be identified early.  Please seize this opportunity to help my son, Alexander.

Thank you for your time and consideration, 
Elizabeth Siebert

Subject:	Blue Ribbon Panel Report

Dear Florida Leaders,

I want you to know how strongly I personally feel that the funding for the Dept of Children and Family needs to be re-vamped. Although there has been improvement in this area, the system is still over burdened. Please take the necessary action and call a special session to address this issue brought forth and outlined in the Blue Ribbon Panel Report.  Please make this a priority and become informed on a personal level.  We rely on our leaders to represent us and to pass legislation and budget at appropriate levels of funding needed to protect our children.

We have got to protect and finance our most precious assets "our Children"  they are our future.  We need to take action and make this a priority.

Sincerely,
Susan Grabhorn

From:	Terry L. Rice <tlrice@adelphia.net>
Sent:	Thursday, May 30, 2002 10:06 AM
To:	Phil Parsons
Subject:	Re: 8.5 Sq. Mi. - Justice approaches
Attachments:	L-Corps-8.5-000628(FINAL).doc; L-MWD-May-000823 (FINAL).doc

Phil ... thanks for the encouraging words ... they are greatly appreciated
for we with the Miccosukee Tribe don't experience many positive reactions to
our work ... for whatever reason, deference goes to others who often are
guided by whim and ulterior motives ... "trust responsibility" is ignored
... the experience and insights of the only group that lives in the
Everglades are dismissed without due consideration.  As our last resort,
we have learned that federal judges do listen best ... we actually wish
there was an easier way but there doesn't appear to be right at the moment.

Do want to clarify that the law suit is an 8.5 SMA citizens action not a
Tribal suit ... but the Miccosukee Tribe has stated over and over that the
clear words of the law say that the Secretary of the Army is directed to
construct a flood protection project and that any other plan would only
result in a "dead-end excursion" and further contribute to the destruction
of Tribal land and other natural areas, in addition to continuing the
flooding the people of Miami-Dade County ... 2 examples attached.

We hope that the ruling will enhance our credibility, as you suggest, and
encourage giving our voice a greater role in decision making ... we hope it
will inspire quick, decisive, rational action to get Mod Waters done by
building the congressionally approved 1992 Corps plan ... we hope that
Corps leadership rejects the false arguments that pushes them off track and
quickly chooses to "construct a flood protection project" for the people of
the 8.5 SMA as directed by Congress.  Hope springs eternal but history
does temper our expectations, as I'm sure you understand.

When this Magistrate's recommendation is adopted by
the judge, the Corps has a clear authority, justification, and means to get
the job done quickly ... hope they realize that the survival of the Tribe's
way of life depends on it and takes quick, decisive action.  But the Federal
government's initial response to the Magistrates recommendation is far from
heartening ... I have not read it personally but I've been told they argue
that "construct" doesn't mean "construct" (deja vu Clinton) ... that the
current administration would dig this deep to find a way to condemn property
that will move 102 families out of their homes, and this when they've been
given a way out of this quagmire, is hard for me to figure ... but I've quit
trying to figure a long time ago. I guess human nature rules and the first
response is vindication  ... there I go figuring again.

Sincerely, Terry

From:	Charlotte Lucier <floridaredwolf@hotmail.com>
Sent:	Thursday, May 30, 2002 10:24 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Juvenile mental health bill

Mr. Bush, 
I cannot believe that you would sign a bill taking away the mental health programs and funding for juveniles. It is bad enough that help is limited but to take it away from the children is wrong. You and all the other people in government need to wake up and smell the coffee. You vote pay raises for congress and senate but don't give a damn about the children until they have overflowed the juvenile justice system or killed someone. And even then you don't care. The system is a joke and all your promises are for naught. I used to think you had good ideas but now I think you are like the rest of the wealthy in this country and care more about your own (the rich) than the people who actually work for a living, and struggle to survive on a daily basis. Go out there and take a 5.50 an hour job with no benefits and no food stamps and tell me how you could even begin to live. You have never done without anything in your life nor has anyone in the Bush family. If one of your family has a mental health issue you have the resources to send them to a PRIVATE FACILITY for treatment and hush it up; what about the rest of us humans? Look on the street- over half are people who need mental health services and Ronald Ragen turned them out of the palces they were getting help. If you sign this bill and stop funding or stop extended programs then expect more juvenile offenders and expect more violence because of  the lack of treatment needed to treat/teach these children to be a sucessful, productive part of society. Please do not deny the children anymore than is already denied them. It is bad enough that Florida is noted for its' lousy education system which is why I am leaving after graduation to teach out of state for less money.  The schools and other programs, for juveniles, should be TOP prority, not oil and gas in the gulf. We care so little for those who will choose to lead this nation in the future and we are definately not equal. I would not even be considered equal to you no matter if I have a degree or not. You need to go out there, away from the wealthy, upper class and see what REALITY is, $2.89 to 3.69 a gallon for milk, in case you don't know. After paying for it all,  mental health is the last thing you can afford for your child if you are a minimum wage worker or single parent. For the sake of the stateand the nation wake up! DO NOT SIGN THAT BILL! DO NOT VOTE ANOTHER PAY RAISE! GIVE THE CHILDREN A CHANCE TO LIVE A NORMAL LIFE OR GOD HELP WHO CHOOSES YOUR NUSING HOME- WHOOPS- FORGOT- YOU ARE WEALTHY ENOUGHT TO AFFORD PRIVATE CARE! 
 
 MENTAL HEALTH IS JUST AS IMPORTANT AS PHYSICAL HEALTH. THANKS!
 
PS Please read these books  ODD GIRL OUT (recently written) and The Bell Jar (by Sylvia Plath); then you might have an idea of what it is like to cope, daily, with a mental illness that has no cure only treatment that may or may not be successful. We just try to survive.

From:	Beruvides, Marcelo <MBeruvid@allstate.com>
Sent:	Thursday, May 30, 2002 11:00 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	EDUCATION BUDGET, LINE ITEM 5B, SER/SABER


The Honorable Jeb Bush
Governor of Florida
The Florida Capitol
Tallahassee, Florida


Dear Governor Bush:

I am writing to you on a matter that I feel is of great importance to young
Floridians in need of help.

A special project in the State's budget for this coming year,  SER/SABER, is
up for consideration.  This project helps keep and recover young
people-at-risk or who have fallen through the proverbial cracks of our
education system.  Having been involved with the SER organization over the
past 14 years, I can personally vouch for the importance and relevance of
this project and what it means to the young Floridians that avail themselves
of it's value.  We have seen what can happen when our young fall through the
cracks of our society's systems.  Setting these young people back on track
is critical to their lives, their families, our communities and our State.  

Your commitment to the education of our youth in Florida is well documented.
I respectfully request you consider this item positively and keep it in the
Education budget for the State of Florida.


Respectfully,

C. M. Beruvides
3121  SW  82 Ct.
Miami, Fl  33155
mberuvid@Allstate.com

From:	Simnszz@aol.com
Sent:	Thursday, May 30, 2002 12:38 PM
To:	john.mica@mail.house.gov
Cc:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	US Airways

Dear Representative Mica:

I am concerned about delays of loans to airlines in danger of bankruptcy.  As a resident in the Orlando area, I hope you do not thwart efforts to secure loan approval for US Airways.  Loans were promised after 9/11.  Those loans are desperately needed and should be provided without delay.  Instead of helping airlines devastated by 9/11 events and subsequent security measures, elected leaders seem to be spending tax dollars on everyone in the world except the airlines.  This jeopardizes the jobs of thousands of workers.  The cost to taxpayers will be loss of taxes and the need for massive amounts of federal funds for unemployment, retraining programs, etc. The trickle down effect will be a weakened economy.  The emotional effect hurts families who lose income, medical benefits, retirement benefits, and perhaps lose their homes, as well.

US Airways is the #2 airline in Orlando.  Thousands of local citizens will be effected when US Airways goes bankrupt.  Airline employees, employees in airline support services, and members of the tourist industry will be negatively impacted if US Airways goes bankrupt.  Representative Mika, you are one of the most influential voices in deciding loan approvals for the airlines.  Please hear the voice of thousands of your constituents who want to keep their jobs.

There seems to be no legitimate reason to delay promised loans until October when those loans are needed now.  US Airways is not asking for a hand out such as ones provided to struggling countries worldwide or to special interests groups asking for subsidies.  It is a LOAN to an AMERICAN company hit hard by an act of war against our country...a company that employs thousands of ordinary citizens who pay taxes and mortgages, save for retirement, and hope to put their kids through college, etc. Please push for immediate approval of necessary loans and do not let politics influence any decision to delay.  

Florida voters expect elected officials to be honest in delivering the promises they made.  History shows that nothing angers voters more than a breach of trust. A delay of loan approval will cost thousands of jobs.  If loans are later approved to other airlines after a major airline goes bankrupt, it will appear politically motivated and demonstrate callous disregard for thousands of employees impacted by layoffs.  Such actions will be examined carefully by voters in future elections.  

Please reconsider your outspoken position on this matter and show that the promises made after 9/11 were not merely hollow promises.  After 9/11, there was a sense of unity, efforts to help our country heal, and lack of partisan bickering.  It showed how great this country can be when good leadership is provided.  Now more than ever, that leadership is needed to keep jobs and help local economies recover from the horrific events of 9/11.

Please do what is best for the thousands of people in Central Florida and across the nation who depend on airline related jobs.  Promote and vote for immediate airline loan approvals for US Airways.  Show the people who elected you that you care about them, their jobs, and the future of the # 2 airline in Orlando.  Thank you.

Most sincerely,
Paul Simon
3165 Hanging Moss Circle
Kissimmee, FL 34741
(407) 518-1801

million dollar cut for The Department of Children and
Families.The Purchased Residentail Treatment Services

adult mental health patients. If we give them help now

From:	Catherine <lmft2b@yahoo.com>
Sent:	Thursday, May 30, 2002 2:06 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Purchased Residential Treatment Services 

May 30, 2002

Govenor Jeb Bush
The Capitol
Tallahassee, FL 32399-0001

Dear Governor Bush:

I am sending this letter with the hope that you will
take action to prevent the elimination of the
children’s mental health treatment services now
provided through Alcohol, Drug Abuse, and Mental
Health/DCF (PRTS) Purchased Residential Treatment
Services dollars. 

Programs for severely emotionally disturbed children
and their families that will be eliminated include
residential treatment, therapeutic group homes,
therapeutic foster care programs, in-home counseling,
outpatient counseling, aftercare components and case
management services.  The families that utilize these
services will be unable to get these intensive mental
health services in any other way.  Many of these
families do not have Medicaid and their insurance does
not cover these services. 

Most families are not able afford the $300.00 a day
cost of a residential program for their child. If
these services are not available to these severely
emotionally disturbed children, they will continually
be in and out of mental health crisis stabilization
facilities, juvenile commitment programs, or possibly
follow through with their homicidal and/ or suicidal
threats. 

The parents of these children will be very frustrated
with their inability to provide the level of care
their child needs. Without the necessary support
system these parents will most probably feel the need
to relinquish custody of their child to the state to
get their child the help they need. This type of
desperate measure has been used in the past and was
found to be ineffective and much more expensive both
in human and financial terms. The goal of the
Purchased Residential Treatment Services program is to
keep families intact and to teach the necessary skills
to help their children to become productive adults.  

Throughout the state thousands of severely emotionally
disturbed children have been treated in cost-efficient
therapeutically effective programs funded through the
State of Florida. The funding shift awaiting the
Governors signature will eliminate many programs that
currently assist families when mental health crises
occur and support the child being maintained in the
community. These are the very services that prevent
children from requiring deep end and very expensive
institutional placements. 

Please Governor Bush, take the necessary action to
restore this funding and stop the transfer of PRTS
funds to Medicaid.  The children and families of this
state who do not qualify for Medicaid assistance are
counting on you.

Sincerely,

Catherine A. Urban
Resident of Florida

From:	Dana, Pam <pam.dana@myflorida.com>
Sent:	Thursday, May 30, 2002 2:32 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	FW: Minute Maid/Coca-Cola plant in Auburndale
Attachments:	Coca Cola Polk-rec.doc; Coke info.doc

Follow Up Flag:	Follow up
Due By:	Thursday, May 16, 2002 5:00 PM
Flag Status:	Flagged

We have the flexiblity to offer $100K Closing Fund to Coca Cola to address sales tax differential found in Florida as compared to Georgia.  As this seems to be a sticking point for the company...which EFI has vetted and says is the case...are you okay with using Closing Fund to ensure their Auburndale expansion?  Briefing below.
 
 
 
-----Original Message-----
From: Wilson, Wynnelle 
Sent: Wednesday, May 29, 2002 6:16 PM
To: Dana, Pam
Subject: FW: Minute Maid/Coca-Cola plant in Auburndale


EFI has been following up on this project and feels that there is a need here for a small QACF award.   Before send a formal recommendation they want to be sure you  (and the Governor if you need to discuss it with him) are comfortable with a recommendation.  Crystal is working up some notes on the issue, but Coke is going to need at least an indication that we will support QACF by next Wed., so I want to give you a heads up.  Attached is the content of an e-mail from Coke explaining the Florida disadvantages and a copy of the QTI recommendation memo outlining the project (QTI already approved).  We will have a draft of the QACF recommendations tomorrow or Friday, but basically we are talking about 300 jobs at $41,739 for a new beverage manufacturing facility ($120 million investment) in Auburndale/Polk County.  Georgia has some strong tax advantages (explained in the attachment) and Coke has strong ties to Georgia.  
 
We have an uncommitted balance in the QACF appropriation of $125,000 (assuming Citicorp goes through) ,  and they are requesting $100,000.
 
I think we discussed this briefly last week, but wanted to let you know it is moving a long.  
 
-----Original Message-----
From: JackMyers@polk-county.net [mailto:JackMyers@polk-county.net]
Sent: Tuesday, May 14, 2002 10:45 AM
To: jeb@myflorida.com
Cc: citymanager@Auburndalefl.com; JimKeene@polk-county.net; tghiz@na.ko.com
Subject: Minute Maid/Coca-Cola plant in Auburndale



Dear Gov. Bush:

Thank you for your rapid response to our request for assistance from the FDOT on the road grant for the proposed Minute Maid/Coca-Cola plant in Auburndale.  As you are aware, Coca-Cola proposes to construct a $120 million non-carbonated beverage plant in Florida or Georgia. Company officials tell us that Georgia is really putting the squeeze via incentives on Coke to build the large (400 high-paying jobs) facility in their home state.  As you know, the extra incentives that Georgia can offer are the exemptions on all purchases of manufacturing machinery and equipment, not just purchases at initial start-up. Coca-Cola has calculated that it will cost an extra $100,000 in sales tax in Florida if they locate here.

It has come to our attention that you have a discretionary fund -- the Quick Action Closing Fund -- to help put Florida on top in close deals like this one. We sincerely request that you allocate these funds to the Coca-Cola Company to win this project for our great state.  As always, we appreciate your continued support for the community and economic development of Polk County.

Your friend, Jack Myers, Chairman, Polk County Board of County Commissioners.

From:	Armstrong, Bunny <BunnyA@advocacycenter.org>
Sent:	Thursday, May 30, 2002 2:33 PM
To:	florida_governor@myflorida.com; Jeb Bush; jeb@myflorida.com
Cc:	greg.turbevile@laspb.state.fl.us; alan.florez@myflorida.com; kevin.tang@myflorida.com
Subject:	veto 1307

Dear Governor Bush:
The following are excerpts taken from a letter emailed you on May 22, 2002:

*	I also have grave concerns about the process by which this amendment was slipped into this bill.  I contacted an ADAWG member, Mr. J. R. Harding, before the bill passed and requested the bill number.  On 3/21/02, I received an email response that states, "Unfortunately, I cannot fulfill that request." 

*	I also contacted Mr. Rick Dixon, Executive Director, Florida Building Commission, Department of Community Affairs (DCA), on 3/12/02 and inquired of DCA's involvement and requested the bill number.  He responded via email - "The Commission is not pursuing legislation this year so groups running their own initiatives are not compelled to ask whether their amendments to bills are acceptable to us."  Oddly enough, Ms. Julie Shaw just publicly announced that DCA was one of the five industry organizations she negotiated with regarding the amendment.

*	During her presentations, [at the Florida Building Commission meetings] Ms. Shaw stated that she had researched past waiver applications from the Florida specific requirement for vertical accessibility and found that the majority of the waivers granted were based on an average of 20% of the cost of the alteration/renovation. Counterpoint:  What Ms. Shaw did not say that was raised on public record is that her research of the 20% average was applicable to vertical accessibility only.  If signed, this bill/amendment provides that the estimates for the 20% rule will now extend to include parking, signs, curb cuts, ramps, doorways, thresholds, door hardware, floor surfaces, bathrooms (stalls, accessible toilets, countertops, grab bars, door hardware, faucet hardware, pipe insulation, turning radius, accessible dispensers, and sinks and countertops), display cases, counters, physical access to goods and services, audible and visual alarms, compliant payphones, TDD telephones where applicable, water fountains, and more - areas already covered under 28 C.F.R. 36.403 (f) (2) (I) (ii) (iii) (iv). Applicants will NOT have to provide vertical accessibility because they have applied the 20%, as just illustrated. Also look at 28 C.F.R. 36.403 (g) (1) &(2) - order of applying the 20%. 

*	Ms. Shaw has stated that she did not "want to open up the code" --- 553.509 Vertical Accessibility.  Counterpoint:  Reread paragraph seven [the paragraph before this one] - this amendment combines the Florida specific requirements for vertical accessibility with all other requirements of federal law; in essence, it is a covert way of nullifying F.S. 553.509. [bolding added]

Sincerely,
Bunny Armstrong,Chair
Accessibility Advisory Council
Florida Building Comission

representatives and senator to support our position for next session. If we 
loose then, it is at least fair.

safety concern of the inspector process, or access to second floor shops and 
jobs for people?

> From: 	Phillips, Mike  
> Sent:	Thursday, May 30, 2002 1:45 PM
> To:	McInerney, Tom
> Subject:	Brief on DOT stop and INS Arrests
> 
>  <<Churat.jpg>>  <<Michel.jpg>> On May 29, 2002, at approximately 12 noon,
> a Department of Transportation officer conducted a traffic stop on a
> tractor trailer that was pulling a vehicle carrier/trailer at I-10 and
> Chaires Cross Roads.  The tractor did not have a tag on it and did not
> have a Federal DOT fuel permit.  DEA initially responded to the scene for
> possible assistance with suspicion of narcotics trafficking.  The North
> Florida DSTF was subsequently contacted and responded to the scene for
> assistance with the investigation.
> 
> Once the truck was stopped the officer became suspicious because the
> driver who was identified as NAMPOL CHURAT (AKA: Tiger), Thailand/male,
> DOB: 2/23/68, only had a Texas CDL and no paperwork to prove his
> citizenship, etc.  He said that he had a green card and work permit, but
> was not carrying them.  
> 
> The passenger, who was identified as MICHEL ABOUJAOUDE (further spellings:
> MICHEL ABDOU ABOU JAOUDE and MICHEL ABOUJEE) Lebanese/male DOB: 1/1/58 had
> a Texas Class C driver's license.  It was learned that MICHEL was the
> owner of the truck and trailer (car carrier), but had just sold it to a
> Lebanese friend (MAROUN ALROUMY) who lived in West Palm Beach.  MICHEL
> stated that they were delivering the truck and trailer from Houston to
> West Palm Beach.  MICHEL did not possess the proper Immigration
> documentation, but he did have a Lebanese and a Canadian passport.    
> 
> When the driver was interviewed he was not very familiar with his
> passenger/owner of the vehicle although he had known the passenger for six
> (6) months and was hired to drive the truck since he had a CDL license.
> This caused the officer to become suspicious and asked for consent to
> search, which he was given.  During his search the officer located a
> Bushnell Night vision monocular and a hand held Magellan GPS.
> Additionally, he located a Southwest Airlines passenger itinerary and
> receipt.  The receipt indicated he had flown from Houston to Baltimore and
> then on to Buffalo, NY on May 15, 2002 and was to return to Houston via
> Buffalo, NY on May 30, 2002.  However, during the interview he stated that
> this trip was never taken due to a change in plans.  
> 
> DOT had there K-9 respond to the scene and after a thorough inspection did
> not alert to any narcotics.  A further check of the vehicle was done with
> a fiber optic scope, with negative results. 
> 
> Furthermore, during the road side investigation it was revealed that the
> VIN attached to the tractor was not the original VIN number.  It had been
> replaced with a VIN number from a newer model wrecked tractor.  This
> caused DOT to seize the tractor and auto carrier.  All of this information
> will be forwarded to the local SAO.  Once they review the information they
> will make the determination to charge MICHEL ABOUJAOUDE. 
> 
> INS responded to the scene and determined that both subjects were out of
> status.  Subjects were arrested and taken to the Leon County Detention
> Facility. 
> 
> It was also learned during this investigation that the MICHEL ABOUJAOUDE
> subject had been interviewed by the FBI in Texas post 9/11.  The basis of
> the interview was to find out what he knew about a fugitive.  During their
> contact with him they determined that he was a legitimate automobile
> salvage dealer.  However, they must not have checked his immigration
> status.
> 
> 
> 
> SAS Mike Phillips

From:	Guy Cooley <gcooley@childcarepinellas.org>
Sent:	Thursday, May 30, 2002 3:38 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Support of SB 1550

Dear Governor Bush:

Coordinated Child Care of Pinellas, Inc. has been actively supporting local
quality child care initiatives for over 30 years.  We are soliciting your
help in the campaign for quality child care for all children by signing SB
1550/Silver/Ausley Child Care Training/Articulation Bill into law.

The provisions in SB 1550 not only raises the level of professionalism, but
ensures that the children in child care homes are offered a strong
school-readiness foundation by increasing to 45 clock hours the required
introductory training course, revising the minimum training requirements to
include training in brain research and computer technology, and requiring a
competency examination upon successful completion of the required trainings.

Your support of SB 1550 would be greatly appreciated.  If I can ever been of
any assistance to you regarding any early education or child care issue,
please do not hesitate to contact me.

Guy M. Cooley
Executive Director
Coordinated Child Care of Pinellas, Inc.
(727) 547-5706
gcooley@childcarepinellas.org

From:	srmiller@sjrwmd.com
Sent:	Thursday, May 30, 2002 4:39 PM
To:	Cory
Cc:	constantine.lee.web@leg.state.fl.us; FEENEY.TOM; Guetzloe@aol.com; allen.bob@leg.state.fl.us; Jeb Bush; william.potter@ocfl.net; chairman@ocfl.net; district5@ocfl.net; jbillman@orlandoweekly.com; mpynn@orlandosentinel.com; brummer.fred@leg.state.fl.us; pjohnson@orlandosentinel.com; orlando@amcity.com; smaxell@orlandosentinel.com; mthomas@orlandosentinel.com; CMSMicro@aol.com; knappfamilyPDX@aol.com; joy.wright@ocfl.net; johnson.randy%leg@sjrwmd.state.fl.us; JEckdahl@sjrwmd.com; LDennard@sjrwmd.com; Peter_Henn@district.sjrwmd.state.fl.us
Subject:	Re: PETER HENN / Request for weather Shelter for children of Bithlo, onEcon river.


Mr. Goodman,

Please allow me to introduce myself. My name is Steve Miller and I serve as
the Director of the Division of Land Management for the St. Johns River
Water Management District.  Your e-mail was forwarded to me for response.
I would like to answer some of your questions and correct some
misinformation you seem to have received.

As Mr. Henn explained to you in his e-mail, the buildings removed from the
Longbranch Park tract were both a hazard and an attractive nuisance.  Their
removal was necessary and justified.

Mr. Henn has not "refused to assist" the community of Bithlo but he
represents the District, and the District is working to provide
recreational access and facilities on nearly a half million acres in 19
counties.  The District has built a number of inclement weather shelters on
various conservation areas.  We continue to do so as we can.  Not every
acre, nor every tract, can be developed  for recreational access at the
same time since staff and funds are limited.  The challenge is not merely
building the facility, but also providing adequate oversight and security
so that the illegal activity experienced in the old camp does not recur.
In the case of Longbranch Park, Orange County is the lead manager and will
be developing the recreational access. The District is assisting the County
by providing limited oversight until the County's plans are implemented.

Adjacent to the Longbranch Park tract, the District has provided
recreational access and some limited facilities, including primitive camp
sites, at the Hal Scott regional Park and Preserve.  In fact, portions of
the Longbranch Park tract are accessible by foot, bicycle and horseback
from Hal Scott.

Your allegations against Mr. Henn concerning "an under the table deal"
alarm me and I would ask that you either provide proof or stop slandering
Mr. Henn.  If you continue without any evidence to support your claim, I
will be forced to refer the matter to the District's Office of General
Counsel.

Regarding the boat launch at SR 50, the District continues to work toward
its construction.  Because of the wet nature of the land, the engineering
and permitting has been more difficult and time consuming.  We are awaiting
the last permit and plan to finish the airboat launch this year.

If you have questions, you may contact me directly at (386) 329-4399.

From: LccPraise@aol.com <LccPraise@aol.com>

Sent: Thu May 30 15:40:19 2002
Subject: Waiver stats

Hi all,
    The governor just got snowed. I warned Kevin Tang the statistics Julie 
handed out at the Council meeting were laughed at. Anyone that is familiar 
with the process will recognize the numbers are stacked to appear to prove 
this is what the commission is using the 20% currently. Neil Melick, our 
Center for Independent Living rep for statewide organizations sent you this 
email last week:
   As for the determination that waiver cases being approved were
   primarily those with more than 20% disproportionate cost and
   waivers denied were less than 20%, that is probably a correct statement
   - if we are talking about  those cases approved by the Commission and
   not by recommendation of the Council and if the statistics were taken
   prior to January 2002.  Since then, the Council has done a better job in
   making recommendations and giving time to comply.  Since
   January, I know that the majority of the vertical accessibility
   cases have been granted with condition that vertical accessibility be
   provided within a specified time.  None of   these cases even dealt with
   disproportionate cost.  With the signing of HB 1307, this type of option
   would not be   available and vertical accessibility will not be
   obtained.
Is the Governor thinking we are all lying? All the people in Florida who have 
called, emailed and faxed are ignorant? I am beyond disappointed that none of 
his staff truely represented the position of people with disabilities in 
Florida. Now all of you are responsible for the grave injustice done to us, 
because we took the time to call you and email you and fax you to let you 
know of the problem, and nothing was done. Our vertical accessibility laws 
made our state better. The Veto just made it nothing to be proud of for us.
Angel Watson

From:	Barbara Robinson <clarkba@osceola.k12.fl.us>

Dear Governor Bush:

As a teacher in Osceola County, I see our desperate need for the funding
for fast-growing counties, and I would like to send you my personal
request to please support that funding as we are in dire need of it.  In
fact, our school is under construction as I write this e-mail, and we have
suffered many budget cuts due to the September 11 attack.

I was teaching the day of the attack, and your brother was at a Florida
school in Sarasota.  I said a prayer for him and for our great nation that
day, and I pray now that you will continue to support us in our
fast-growing needs in such a diverse community.  It is with pride that I
am able to say a story I wrote along with six of my students' stories will
be published in a book to be released this summer by WordWalker Publishing
and Obadiah Press titled 911:  THE DAY AMERICA CRIED.  My story is titled
911:  A Cry for Tolerance, and out of dozens of submissions, only six of
my students' work was chosen, but six I am very proud of because they
young Americans take pride in their way, the only way they could help,
through the 'power of the pen' and the 'power of the written word' with
the September 11 attack.  The proceeds from the book will all be donated
to the Todd Beamer Foundation and neither the students nor myself are
making any money from this project, but money is not why we wrote those
stories.

I can also proudly say that my students used their creative minds and
thinking skills and produced a four-color professional paperback book
titled VOICES OF THE DENN JOHN WRITING DRAGONS ON THE ROLLER COASTER OF
LIFE with a special section dedicated as a memoiral tribute to the
September 11 victims and their families.  We are proud of our great
nation, and as Americans, we did what we could in our own way to show it!

I hope you will seriously consider my request, and I know in my heart God
hears my prayers!  If you ever happen to read the story I wrote, you will
understand why I can say that.  By the way, I read Barbara Bush's story in
CHICKEN SOUP FOR THE MOTHER'S SOUL and loved it.  I read it to my students
in class as I am a strong advocate of using the books as oral-reading
models and writing prompts.

Sincerely,
Barbara J. Robinson
Educator and Author
Teacher, Grades 6, 7, & 8
Denn John Middle School
Kissimmee, Florida

From:	Jeb Bush
Sent:	Thursday, May 30, 2002 7:24 PM

Subject:	Re: final version of the letter for HB 1307

Sent from my BlackBerry Wireless Handheld (www.BlackBerry.net)


-----Original Message-----
From: Turbeville, Greg <Greg.Turbeville@LASPBS.STATE.FL.US>
To: Jeb Bush <jeb@jeb.org>
Sent: Thu May 30 18:12:04 2002
Subject: final version of the letter for HB 1307




May 30, 2002

The Honorable Katherine Harris
Secretary of State
PL02, The Capitol
Tallahassee, Florida 32399-0250 


Dear Secretary Harris: 

I hereby transmit to you, with my signature, Council Substitute for House Bill 1307, entitled:

	An act relating to Building Code Development. 

There are many sound reasons to sign this bill.  Council Substitute for House Bill 1307 contains numerous provisions to streamline application of building code issues.  Florida should be proud of its achievement to develop and implement a uniform building code.  The code went into effect on March 1st of this year.  The bill provides a process for nonbinding decisions, expedites hearings, and provides higher standards for local amendments to the code.  Further, it authorizes the option for a building owner to use private providers to conduct plan reviews and building inspections.  The bill also contains provisions passed in Senate Bill 990 regarding the privatization of elevator inspections.  On the whole, the provisions in this bill are aimed at facilitating the application of the new code.

However, a provision was added, which has raised great concern among persons with disabilities.  Under current law, when renovations occur to an existing building, the building must meet Florida accessibility requirements.  This requirement, at times, creates a disincentive to renovation and reuse due to disproportionate costs of the accessibility requirements.  This bill would modify current law to provide a brightline test to determine economic hardship in the granting of waivers regarding vertical accessibility in existing buildings.  As Florida's cities age, it is important to promote the continued use and rehabilitation of buildings to maintain an active community and vibrant economy.  However, the people who live in our communities are key to making this happen.  Florida has made great strides to address the needs of our residents and visitors with disabilities.  While we must address the issues of renovating buildings and providing access to all, we should strike an appropriate balance.

The Honorable Katherine Harris 

May 30, 2002

Page Two


A review of waivers granted indicates that this bill does not significantly alter current practice.  In some cases applicants were required to comply with conditions over time.  However, there is no provision for the enforcement of these conditions.  Further, other waivers were granted with conditions not related to cost.  The standards under the new law have not changed for these types of cases.

I have heard from many individuals who have expressed concerns with the application of this new provision.  Florida's specific accessibility requirements still require access to all levels above and below ground, exceeding the federal vertical accessibility requirements, which are limited to primary function areas.  I wish to state my position that the Accessibility Advisory Council and the Florida Building Commission should apply these provisions with great scrutiny and with an aim toward ensuring accessibility for all our residents and visitors.

A good example of how this provision can be applied, while still ensuring access is provided, occurred at the May 2002 meetings of the Accessibility Advisory Council and the Florida Building Commission.  An applicant submitted a request for a waiver regarding vertical access.  The building was being converted from apartments to a non-profit charter school.  The project costs were estimated at $305,000, with the elevator costs estimated at between $133,000 and $148,000.  The Council identified an alternative and less costly means to provide this access.  The applicant agreed to provide vertical accessibility to the second floor through the Limited Use Limited Application Elevator.

I believe this balance is achievable, and my administration will see it accomplished.  The bill calls for the Florida Building Commission to develop recommendations with input from the disabled and development communities concerning the rehabilitation and use of existing structures.  I encourage them to look at this issue and recommend any changes that they feel are appropriate to achieve the sensible middle ground between the industry's input and the need for accessibility in the renovation of our buildings.

In the final analysis, however, Council Substitute for House Bill 1307 is sound legislation deserving of my signature.  For this reason, and the other reasons set forth herein, I hereby sign it.

Sincerely,




Jeb Bush




<<Letter re- HB 1307.doc>>

In reply to your question about the use of the funds for the Emporwerment

These programs are an integral part of the efforts to revitalize the

----- Forwarded by ROSA SUGRANES/Iberia on 05/29/2002 10:21 PM -----
                                                                                                                                       
                      WWBKFinnie@AOL.CO                                                                                                
                      M                        To:       rsugranes@iberiatiles.com                                                     
                                               cc:                                                                                     
                      05/29/2002 04:23         Subject:  (no subject)                                                                  
                      PM                                                                                                               
                                                                                                                                       
                                                                                                                                       




Thanks Rosa for your efforts.

The Empowerment funds will be utilized in the following manner:
$1.4M to acquire, renovate and expand parking linked to a community based
shopping center in Overtown. This project is linked to an EZ joint venture
with Bank Of America to support the first new construction of single family
housing activity in Overtown over thirty years.

$1.3M will be utilized to support a commercial development initiative
linked to the Freedom Tower facility on Biscayne Blvd. We are seeking to
stimulate the development of a hotel and/or a commercial building attached
to the existing structure. This investment will supplement an existing
allocation of $100,000 in pre development funding form the empowerment
zone. Our focus here is on Miami's central business district.

$1.5M will be utilized to support infill housing development in East Little
Havana. Our activities in the area may be linked to the East little Havana
CDC as well as our neighborhood assembly.

The balance of the funds (Appx. $800,000) will be utilized for
contingencies and administration.

Thank You !
Bryan Finnie
kfinnie@miamidade.gov

-----Original Message-----
From: P.S.Brady [mailto:psbrady@tampabay.rr.com]
Sent: Thursday, May 30, 2002 9:00 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Waterways Bill Veto


Dear Governor Bush,
 
I was appalled and surprised at your veto of the Waterways bill.  I thought you were in touch with the needs of Citrus county to restore our chain of lakes and protect our water resources by the excellent changes you made to the Southwest Florida Water Management District with the appointments of Al Coogler and Sam Lyons.  I thought the positive moves that have come from improved relations with the District indicated a new  future for our lake system and gave you the final credit.
 
The Tsala Apopka chain of lakes are vital to the economic health of Citrus County.  Although this bill would not have initially done anything to restore these lakes to health at least it was an attempt to begin.  We need action desperately and we needed it yesterday!
 
I have always supported the Republican Party and you had my vote, but how can I support you for Governor again when you vote against the very issues closest to my own heart -- restoration of the Tsala Apopka chain of lakes.
 
The only person who seems to have the true concerns of the people of our area in her heart is Nancy Argenziano and you don't seem to understand that and give her the support she deserves.  The money we have to give to the Party will go to her. 
 
I hope you will do something to help our lakes soon and restore my confidence in your ability to lead our state.
 
Sincerely,
 
Patricia S. Brady
Inverness, FL

-----Original Message-----
From: dmbarber@wfeca.net [mailto:dmbarber@wfeca.net]

Subject: FCAT test


Governor Bush:
    I am a concerned parent of 2 healthly, smart, happy boys. I am concerned about the FCAT test that the children take in the schools. I DISAGREE with the test.  I do not think that a child should be under the pressure of taking 1 test that determines if he graduates are not.  I realize that they have the chance of taking the test more than once after the 10 grade if they do not pass it the 1st time.  However that makes no differnece to me.  Both of my boys are A B students. One of them does very well on test.  However the other one does not test well at all.  He has never nor probably will ever score high on the FCAT test.  Please do not ask me if he has a learning disability. I am saying that because I have called the Department of Education-- I have talked with teachers and just about everyone I know to talk to concerning these test and when I state that he is a poor tester that is the 1st thing that I am ask. I have prayed long and hard concerning these test and I beleive that even if both of my boys tested well and scored high, I would still disagree with them.

-----Original Message-----
From: Anterro Graham [mailto:anterro@bellsouth.net]
Sent: Thursday, May 23, 2002 5:32 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Following up from our Last email
Importance: High


Governor Jeb Bush
PL 05 The Capitol
400 South Monroe Street
Tallahassee, FL 32399-0001

Dear Governor Bush,

I was introduced to you back on August 13, 2001 by Seth Gordon at the
Wyndham Hotel in Miami at a Special Breakfast meeting held by the
Technology
Group of the Greater Miami Chamber of Commerce. As a member of the
Chamber's
Trustee Board, I spoke on "If you build it, they will come" as I
represented
my former employer Dynegy, Inc. in the capacity of VP Sales for the
Americas. As I mentioned then, you have been built as our Technology
Governor and I applaud you for your efforts. Since then our focus has
changed from just serving Florida's technology needs but also to include
our
country's need for security and the accessibility of information.

As an example, Dynegy, Inc. recently eliminated 60% of its
telecommunications sales force and is restructuring its corporate
operations
to sell off its network assets. These are business decisions that are
predicated on the events of September 11th. But with change comes
opportunity.  After that breakfast meeting you sent me a very touching
email
that offered your support whenever I needed it. With the effect of
September
11th, it has made me realize that I am ready to pursue another
challenging
situation and ask for your assistance at this time.

I would like to request your help in bringing to the table an additional
group of investors or financial institutions to participate in a project
that my team has been working on. Our product is much like DOS and
Windows
from Microsoft.   At least 85% of all computers have the windows
operating
system.  Global Diversity, using its new patented technology, can reach
a
licensing agreement with Microsoft, AT&T, Dell and others, to use its
technology in conjunction with all the new computers sold and reach all
legacy or present hardware systems. Our technology can reach what was
once
thought to be an impossible sector of the public, "the Last Mile" for
those
in the public sector who still has copper wiring.  We have the
capability to
send audio and video data over this copper wire at broadband band speed
and
then store it in a real time retrieval format.

 As Governor, you have access to a wide range of knowledge concerning
investors, capital and financing.  We would like to leverage your
contacts,
and as such, we are requesting a referral and or introduction with
possible
investors, financial institutions or other institutions in the next week
or
so. I would also inquire as to any funding sources from the State of
Florida
that might be used towards this type of project.  We fully understand
you
cannot make commitments for or to any parties.  But as our Governor,
your
introduction carries with it great respect.    We are only seeking an
audience.  Our project must and will stand on its own merit.  The
Structure
is sound or it is not.  The technology is sound and works or it does
not.

The complete funding requirement for this project is $200M.   We are
seeking
to allocate this project into 4 phases of $50M over the next 18 months.
This project is seeking to comply with the Patriot Act and SEC Economic
Recovery Task Force, with CEO Link.  We can provide a real time
computerized
storage and retrieval infrastructure system that facilitates automatic
and
failsafe disaster recovery. This will make our nation's Financial
Systems
and other critical data driven industries effectively resilient to
heinous
terrorist's attacks such as 9/11. This kind of technology infrastructure
is
much needed for our economy to combat and flourish in the current
climate.
We have received a verbal commitment from another financial group that
will
match any investment over $5 Million, dollar for dollar.  We have
secured
insurance coverage from a top five insurance company to guarantee the
full
return of all principle invested in our project, through an Investment
Advisor.  This advisor also has access to the New Market Tax Credit
through
the use of CDE's to offer a 39% tax credit for investment in our project
as
it qualifies under the criteria.  (As the CDE is a federal tax credit is
does not decrease the tax generation of Florida tax revenue) Our
business
plan is very sound and structured to work with the masses of already
installed computer hardware.  We presently have government contracts and
private contracts, but at this time do not have the cash flow to
complete
these ventures to expand our business.  The opportunity is within our
reach,
but yet just a fingertip away.  This opportunity will increase the
States
tax base as it brings commerce from industry to our State, and jobs.

With this matching investment and federal tax credit, we can execute a
well-thought, well-organized company that would bring about tremendous
economic development opportunities for a region for which you serve.
Placing Florida on the map for an economic boom in jobs and revenue.  As
the
philosophy of private sector is what generates economic growth, and this
concept has been promoted by the republican party, it is our intention
to
also develop a sound contribution process, by using a percentage of
profits
from this venture to develop contributions to an IRC 527 who will
facilitate
contributions towards election and re-election processes for Republican
political candidates.

This will also facilitate a substantial consistent fund-raising vehicle
from
an Orlando based minority company with the ability to grow to the size
of a
Microsoft in a very short period of time.  We have the business plan,
the
mixing of financial investors, the ability to secure these investors
with a
guarantor and the federal legislation to make this project work.  At
this
time, no other company can provide the service that our technology can
accomplish.  As you know, the DOS system ran out of money and Bill Gates
bought that technology and became the US richest man.  Here we have
African
Americans who have this same type of technological new wave of
technology,........we just cannot let this get away from our hands.  As
the
present Governor and your brother the present President, seeking ways to
reach out to African Americans, what better way to reach out and touch
this
sizable constituency.  All we are asking is that with your knowledge
base of
financial persons and institutions, that as requested by a citizen of
the
State of Florida that we be introduced or referred by you or your office
to
people who have the power to make decisions for development of a State
industry.

I understand this might be a stretch for me asking you for help, but
please,
if there is any thing that you can do, or any person or groups that you
can
refer us to, I would, my family would and African Americans all across
this
country would be forever in your debt.

Attached to this letter, you will find a summary of the Global Diversity
project along with a White Paper that highlights the core storage
technology
our company provides.  Time is of the essence; I have a 30-day window
from
our initial investor to fund this project.  Your support and any
assistance
that you could provide would be greatly appreciated.

Sincerely,
Anterro Graham
Anterro Graham
President/ CEO
Passeres Systems
12472 Lake Underhill Road
Suite 201
Orlando, FL 32828
Email: anterro@bellsouth.net

-----Original Message-----
From: Crs012001@cs.com [mailto:Crs012001@cs.com]
Sent: Thursday, May 30, 2002 9:01 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: WORK COMP TASK FORCE



The Honorable Jeb Bush 
Jeb@jeb.org 
Office of the Governor 
The Capitol 
Tallahassee, Fl 

May 28, 2002 


Dear Governor Bush: 

   I read with interest the announcements of your creation of a Commission on Workers' Compensation Reform.  As you know from the correspondence received by your office throughout the past year injured workers throughout this state are in desperate need of immediate assistance with enforcement of laws pertaining to  the current system and are equally desperate for reform for the future. 

    VOICES is an organization of and for injured workers.  We actively participated in the Legislative Session(s) this past year and we sincerely want to be a part of the solution to fixing a very broken system.  We feel that because we have lived through both the good and the bad of Workers' Comp we are uniquely qualified to offer positive solutions that we believe will help injured workers and employers. 

     While you have appointed representatives of the attorneys who assist us, and representatives of organized labor who represent workers before and after they are injured on a multitude of issues, we feel that it is very important to have a member of the Commission who is an injured worker and who is connected to an organization of injured workers that is fully dedicated to the crisis that injured workers are in.  I respectfully request that you appoint me, as the President of VOICES, to serve in this role.  It would truly be an honor and a privilege to be a part of finding solutions that work for everybody.  Governor, I look forward to hearing from you on this very important matter. 


Sincerely, 


  Mary Bailey, President 
  VOICES, Inc.

-----Original Message-----
From: MKREEBER@aol.com [mailto:MKREEBER@aol.com]
Sent: Thursday, May 30, 2002 2:39 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Protecting Florida's Children


I applaud your efforts to look at how best to protect children left in the 
State's care. I do believe that better salaries and better training for the 
workers ( including the newly privatized ones) are part of the solution as 
well as a checks and balances system to verify the childrens' welfare and 
whereabouts.
Left out of the equation so far, however, is prevention.  The problem is that 
children are being born in increasing numbers to parents who haven't the 
foggiest idea or concept of responsibility on  how to take care of them nor 
any reasonable means to do so, i.e. drug and alcohol addicted, teen school 
dropouts, mentally disabled etc.
Working with these populations to require family planning goals would be 
controversial but I believe it is necessary. Every drug treatment program 
should include information on not having children until you have kicked the 
habit. Every stay-in-school program the same.
Blaming the problem solely on the state agency that is charged with dealing 
with consequences rather than attacking the causes will never do more than 
slighly alleviate the problem.
What do you think?
Mary K. Reeber

-----Original Message-----
From: Phyllis Kalifeh [mailto:pkalifeh@fcforum.org]
Sent: Thursday, May 30, 2002 3:48 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Child Care Training Bill


Dear Governor Bush,

A bill that was passed during the legislative session, SB 1550 - the
Silver/Ausley child care training bill, was sent up for your signature.
The child care resource and referral network throughout the state of
Florida wholly endorses this bill and recognizes the potential of this
legislation to improve child care quality.

We are extremely pleased with your interest in supporting the school
readiness of Florida's children.  This bill will require that those who
take the introductory required training and who work in licensed child
care programs be required to demonstrate their acquisition of the
information through a test or competency exam.  These are the people
charged with providing the care and school readiness of Florida's
children.  This is minimal.  In other industries and occupations, we
would not even question such an examination.  In fact, hair dressers and
nail technicians have to demonstrate more competence than those who care
for our youngest and most vulnerable citizens.

If we are going to improve the system and expect positive outcomes for
our children, we have to pay attention to those who are on the front
line with them daily.  I have personally  taught these courses.  It was
often frustrating to know that participants could sleep through the
classes and still receive their certificate that allowed them to work in
a licensed child care program.

Please help us "raise the bar" by signing this bill on behalf of
Florida's children.  I would be happy to provide more information.

Thank you.

Phyllis Kalifeh

-----Original Message-----
From: Elizabeth Fago [mailto:efago@hqmmail.com]
Sent: Thursday, May 30, 2002 5:02 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Nursing home lease bond legislation


Dear Jeb,

We are supposed to close on the acquisition of a nursing home operated
by IHS, which is in bankruptcy.  However,  we just learned that HB59E,
which is the bill that would provide an alternative to obtaining a lease
bond for nursing homes, has not yet been signed.  Lease bonds are
unobtainable in this industry, and we were planning on paying the fee
provided for in the bill in lieu of the bond.   We are told that we
cannot obtain a license without the bond, because the bill has not been
signed.

I would greatly appreciate it if you would let me know if you have any
suggestions regarding how we may proceed, or any estimate on when the
bill is likely to be signed.

I may be reached at 561-745-5600 (home) or 561-371-6647 (mobile).  Thank
you very much for your assistance, and I look forward to hearing from
you.

Best regards,
Elizabeth Fago
Chairman,  Home Quality Management, Inc.

-----Original Message-----
From: ORSWF@aol.com [mailto:ORSWF@aol.com]
Sent: Wednesday, May 29, 2002 8:29 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: The nursing shortage


Dear Governor Bush:

I recently read an article regarding the serious nursing shortage in the state of Florida and the steps you were taking to help alleviate that shortage. As an operating room nurse in Ft. Myers, I, too, am concerned over the state of nursing in Florida.

There is no such thing as "season" in Ft. Myers, anymore. Lee Memorial Health System, HealthPark in particular, is busy year round. We have a very dedicated team, nurses, techs, poa's, alike. We work long hours and take many hours of call while dedicating ourselves to the care of fellow citizens. While it is admirable that you and others are trying to help by providing reimbursed tuition, and financial assistance in order to attend nursing school, it is important to note why the shortage exists.

Nurses, like teachers, are grossly underpaid. It is hard to believe that two of the most important professions are paid such " minimal" salaries. Don't get me wrong: I wouldn't change my profession for anything. I became a nurse four years ago at the age of 51. When I left New Jersey 11 years ago, I was making $16.50 per hour as a collections clerk for a large trucking firm. Last year, I finally surpassed that salary, after two years of nursing school and three years of part time attendance for my pre-requisites. Inflation is a part of the future, but the nursing salaries have not kept up with the rise in the cost of living. I always joke that slavery is still alive and well and living in the south. While our cost of living in Florida hasn't quite caught up with the Northeast, it is not that much cheaper anymore to reside in Florida. The salaries, however, of nurses and teachers is still way under what is considered decent. Healthcare workers provide a much needed job, but are not paid what they are worth. 

So, while I applaud what you and others are trying to accomplish to provdide Floridians with much needed nurses, please try to see what you can do about the salaries for the nurses. Pretty soon, the number of nurses will dwindle because we simply aren't paid enough for what we do and what we give. While we must maintain a license and are held responsible for our actions, we are not paid for the responsiblities we take.

Thank you.

Saundra Falk, R.N.

-----Original Message-----
From: smilemkr@mpinet.net [mailto:smilemkr@mpinet.net] 
Sent: Monday, May 20, 2002 8:26 PM
To: fl_governor@eog.state.fl.us
Subject: Retirement peom


I've written a poem in honor of my 30 years of service to Osceola County
Florida that I would like to share with you. I plan to retire in July of
2003.  I wrote to you and President Bush about 14 months ago inviting you to
come to St. Cloud to visit our Accelerated Math lab at Lakeview Elem.
School.  This is the best program I have ever seen or used for teaching
math.  The offer still stands if you would like to visit sometime.  
 
Either way, please enjoy the poem.  Get a hanky.
 

                                                Memories

	As I look back over these past 30 years,

	I've come to realize some of my fears.

	That one day I would no longer reach,

	Hundreds of children that I love to teach.

	Retirement looms closer with each passing day,

	I won't get to take them outside to play.

	I will miss showing them the wonders of space,

	And trying to beat them in a 100-yard race.

	Multiplication is something I will miss most,

	Beating my time is a reason to boast.

	Step right up, take a watch in your hand,

	Can you race against time, and beat the old man?

	I will miss lining up and heading for lunch,

	Eating was fun to be part of that bunch.

	I enjoyed seeing their enthusiasm and smiles,

	As the kids entered and walked down the aisles.

	My heart swells with pride, my feelings are blessed,

	When a grown student says, "You were the best.

	I had you in third grade a long time ago,

	You taught me to love math and I miss you so."

	To all the students I've taught in my profession,

	I just wanted to say "Thanks, but I have a confession.

	I couldn't have done it without:

	            Your willingness to learn,

	            Your acceptance of me as your
teacher,

	            The respect you showed me,

                                And your desire to be the best that
you could be."

 

By: Robert Yates

Osceola County Schools

1972-2002

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 
 <http://www.fiftiesweb.com/slow.htm>  
From:	EMG <garc1099@bellsouth.net>
Sent:	Thursday, May 30, 2002 10:58 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Re: Hello

Governor, 
 
Thank you. I too am concerned about that as well as the fact that 1/3 of our high school 10th graders failed the FCAT. I have asked Dr. Johnson to chat with me about this. I expect to receive an answer either tomorrow or certainly by Monday. I will share with you the content of the discussions
 
Rep. Arza and I have discussed his vision on stopping social promotion and holding all parties accountable to a child's test results.
 
On another note, at the request of the Dept of State ( I was flattered that I received a call from Ambassador Huddleston's office) asking me to meet with her today at the Breakers. Of course I met with her. She wanted to know if I would be interested in working on the following matter with her at the direction of President Bush.
 
To rebut Cuban children blaming us on the poverty levels in Cuba, they send on a monthly basis 2 sacks of Cuban rice to the DoS with a note reading "Mr. President, because of the US we are lacking in these types of essential food for us."
 
Ambassador Huddleston wanted to chat about how we could send back a stronger message. I suggested we have American children send books to Cuban children empowering them to experience the education we have here (with exception of this history exam here in PBC).
 
She loved the idea and modified it by saying books on "How to Start a Business" would be a direct hit to Castro. She said Cubans want to have a business and many do in the black market but lack the experience or fundamental aspects of running a business......
 
Anyway I thought I'd share with you the idea and perhaps it would be of use to you for the campaign here in South Florida. It obviously needs some tweaking, but I am looking forward to working on it...
 
Thanks again, 

Ed Garcia

-----Original Message-----
From: Paz Carmen-ECP007 <Carmen.Paz@motorola.com>
To: 'prepaid@fsba.state.fl.us' <prepaid@fsba.state.fl.us>; Jeb Bush
<jeb@jeb.org>
Sent: Fri May 31 01:31:08 2002
Subject: Discrimination against Catholic Schools

Hello,

I was told that now because of the "10% of all public school kids get
into Florida State colleges law", it is now almost impossible for a
private / Catholic school child to get into a popular school such as
University of Florida or FSU regardless of their grades and SAT scores.
Is this true? I have already purchased the pre-paid college plan for my
son ( 4 years old). Is there any priority given to pre-paid student
admission at all? What does the 10% law state exactly? Can those 10% get
into the school of their choice, or is it on an availability basis?
Also, what is to stop kids switching to public schools during the last
month of their senior year, so they have a better chance of getting into
college? Finally, when is the 529 plan going to be available?

Maybe this policy wasn't thought out very well? I'm all in favor of
helping minorities and underprivileged kids get into school, but not at
the expense of people who plan, and save, and sacrifice. Looks like we
need to expand our capacity at the university level to be able to live
up to the promise we have made to educate the top 10% + educating the
people who think ahead & sacrifice so that their kids get a better
education, and become an even greater asset to the community. 

regards,
c

M. Carmen Paz
Engineering Process Manager
iDEN Subscriber Group, Motorola, Inc.
8000 West Sunrise Blvd.
Plantation, FL 33322

-----Original Message-----
From: Garcia, Charles [mailto:cpg@mysterling.com]
Sent: Wednesday, May 29, 2002 9:05 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: Jim Horne
Subject: Chancellor of Public Schools



Dear Jeb,

I wanted to drop you a note about Major General Cliff Stanley, a man of
extraordinary honor, integrity and most importantly, leadership skills
demonstrated in a more than 30-year career in the military.  I had the
honor
of serving with him as a White House Fellow in your father's
administration.
For a significant part of his military tenure, his focus has been in the
area of education.  I believe that his unique combination of leadership
skills and educational experience make him an exceptional choice for the
position of Chancellor of Public Schools.

Cliff is bright, bold, and articulate and has risen to become the second
highest-ranking African American in the United States Marine Corps.  He
is
planning to retire in mid August 2002.  Briefly stated, Cliff has had
nothing short of a remarkable career.  His success and accomplishments
at
every endeavor he has set his mind to not only speaks volumes for his
talents and skills in situations and environments that can be considered
directly comparable to the requirements essential to the position of
Chancellor of Public Schools, but demonstrate clearly and compellingly
his
ability to work not only as a leader, but as a team player.

Cliff is the former Commanding General of what was the largest military
base
in the Marine Corp.  With a population of nearly 250,000 military
personnel,
for all practical purposes he can be viewed in this capacity as its
mayor.
He forged political ties with national and state elected officials, won
approval for housing development and was instrumental in the base’s
military
and civilian population being incorporated as part of a city, an
unprecedented accomplishment that led to increased revenue for the city,
as
well as better schools, roads and housing.  The military base had two
school
systems that Cliff was directly responsible for. For these myriad
accomplishments, in his honor the park next to City Hall was named after
him.

Cliff also has front line experience as a teacher.  He not only is
currently
responsible for all education and training for the entire Marine Corps,
more
than 240,000 marines, but he has taught at the United States Naval
Academy
and was previously in charge of the Marine Corps distance education
program.
Cliff is also media savvy. He earned his stripes in the field while in
charge of all public relations for the entire US Marine Corps.

In terms of character, integrity and morality, a Chancellor of Public
Schools is in a rare and wonderful position to be an example to our
state’s
impressionable and vital young citizens.  Cliff is an excellent role
model,
for all students, and certainly minorities.  I will share with you a
brief
tale of character and morality that I believe demonstrates qualities and
traits that children, as well as their parents, can appreciate and learn
from.

In 1975, Cliff was in Maryland at the public event with his wife, Roz
and
other family members, when sniper fire broke out.  When the smoke and
pandemonium cleared the killer had left his uncle dead and his wife, who
was
also shot, in critical condition.  Roz survived this racially motivated
attack but was paralyzed and to this day remains wheelchair bound. Cliff
escaped the bullets that day but carries the personal pain as well as
the
victories that often accrue to survivors of life and death
situations—and in
this case, the concept of commitment was born out of the tragedy
suffered by
his wife, to whom he remains faithfully married to this day and with
whom he
has a beautiful successful daughter -- Angie.  Cliff went on to have a
stellar career, and no doubt his sense of commitment is as much a part
of
his persona as the fibers of muscle he used to carry his wife to safety.

When you meet Cliff, and I hope at a minimum you take the opportunity to
get
acquainted, I think you will see that he is not only a gentlemen, but he
is
unequivocally a man of honor.  He has learned respect for people as well
as
institutions in some of this country’s most complex, challenging and
politically charged environments.  Most importantly, as an African
American
in the U.S. Marine Corps, in a racially difficult time, he rose to great
heights in the crucible of leadership.

I am confident that Major General Cliff Stanley could continue his
extraordinary service as a forthright commander on our behalf on the
education war that your administration is so boldly waging in Florida.
You
are probably also familiar with a recent trend across the United States
of
many cities and schools systems hiring former military officers to lead
struggling educational institutions to victory.   Major General John C.
Fryer, superintendent of Duval County Public Schools in Jacksonville,
Florida, served more than 30 years in the U.S. Air Force.  I believe
that
Cliff will proudly and successfully work with Jim Horne to wage an
education
campaign that serves both you and the students of this state with pride,
honor and most importantly, success.

Sincerely,

Charlie Garcia

From:	Rexatious <rexy@ij.net>
Sent:	Friday, May 31, 2002 9:21 AM
To:	Curry, Rex
Subject:	free gun-lockers for courthouses

    A Lawyer’s group is offering to provide free gun lockers wherever
state and/or federal laws are changed to allow gun lockers for the
public at courthouses.  Utah already has a law that requires courthouses

to provide gun lockers and The Lawyer’s Second Amendment Association
(LSAA) thinks Utah has a good idea that can spread with the
Association’s help.
    “We want to help provide lockers for the general public.” said
Attorney Rex Curry, a spokesman for LSAA and a member of the Libertarian

Party  “And of course, lawyers will also be able to use such lockers.
We will start wherever we can start in our ongoing effort to improve 2nd

amendment rights for anyone and everyone across the country.”
    Many states already allow concealed carry of firearms by the general

public, and many people have the right to carry concealed firearms, and
gun lockers will help achieve the purpose of CCF laws.
    “The law and the lockers are intended as a protection.” Curry said
“It's more dangerous for people to leave guns in cars or hide them
behind bushes.”
    “The recent past has caused government to treat citizens as the
enemy,” said Curry “We are helping to restore trust between public
officials and the general population.  And we want to improve the
publics perception of lawyers as supporting freedom, not destroying it.”

    The Utah law is in section 76-8-311.1 of the Utah Code and can be
viewed on the internet at
http://www.le.state.ut.us/~code/TITLE76/htm/76_0A026.htm
    The part that applies to courts is at
http://www.le.state.ut.us/~code/TITLE78/htm/78_0B007.htm
    The LSAA praises Arizona as another state that provides methods for
checking or storing firearms at government buildings as described in the

Arizona Republic.  A related article is at:
http://www.azcentral.com/news/articles/0515GunCheck15.html
    The offer of free gun lockers isn’t for states that already have
lockers, says Curry.  It’s to help new states join the trend.

For more info contact: The Lawyer’s Second Amendment Association (LSAA)
and Rex Curry
Attorney at Law, at P.O. Box 8816, Tampa, FL 33674-8816; 813 238-5371
rexy@ij.net


78-7-6.   Rules -- Right to make -- Limitation -- Security.
     (1) Every court of record may make rules, not inconsistent with
law, for its own government and the government of its
officers; but such rules must neither impose any tax or charge upon any
legal proceeding nor give any allowance to any officer
for service.
     (2) (a) The judicial council may provide, through the rules of
judicial administration, for security in or about a courthouse or
courtroom, or establish a secure area as prescribed in Section
76-8-311.1.
     (b) (i) If the council establishes a secure area under Subsection
(2)(a), it shall provide a secure firearms storage area on
site so that persons with lawfully carried firearms may store them while

they are in the secure area.
     (ii) The entity operating the facility with the secure area shall
be responsible for the firearms while they are stored in the
storage area referred to in Subsection (2)(b)(i).
     (iii) The entity may not charge a fee to individuals for storage of

their firearms under Subsection (2)(b)(i).
     (3) (a) Unless authorized by the rules of judicial administration,
any person who knowingly or intentionally possesses a
firearm, ammunition, or dangerous weapon within a secure area
established by the judicial council under this section is guilty of a
third degree felony.
     (b) Any person is guilty of violating Section 76-10-306 who
transports, possesses, distributes, or sells an explosive,
chemical, or incendiary device, as defined by Section 76-10-306, within
a secure area, established by the Judicial Council
under this section.

-----Original Message-----
From: Samuels Bettye [mailto:Samuels-Bettye@dol.gov]
Sent: Thursday, May 30, 2002 4:13 PM
To: 'Brian.Yablonski@myflorida.com'
Subject: FW: Florida grant
Importance: High




Brian, 

Secretary Chao would like to inform you that the State of Florida has been awarded a $945,945 dollar grant from the Migrant and Seasonal Farmworker Youth Program.  This program is designed to strengthen the ability of youth, ages 14-21, to obtain or retrain employment or to stabilize their employment by providing related assistance.  This program is integrated and coordinated through the workforce investment system.  These funds will be transferred from the Department of Labor to the Florida Department of Education next week.  

In addition, we want to make you aware the President Bush has proposed in the FY 2003 budget the consolidation of the Migrant and Seasonal Farmworker Program into the overall workforce investment system.  This program will no longer be offered as a national categorical program, but will be available to those states who want to continue this program through their local workforce investment boards.

If you have any questions please don't hesitate to call. 

 Bettye Samuels 
Congressional and Intergovernmental Affairs 
Office of the Secretary 
U.S. Department of Labor 202-  693-4621

anyway because it looks bad on an overcrowded school to fail a student.

3rd grade, per Sylvan Learning Center (at $40.00 per hour) and her teacher,

they're passing her anyway.  Again, can't make the overcrowded, non-educated 
teachers/schools look bad!
