From:	Tang, Kevin <Kevin.Tang@MyFlorida.com>
Sent:	Friday, May 31, 2002 10:06 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	FW: bldg code


> Thank you Governor.  Angel Watson is a very nice lady who tells a very
> one-sided story.  I have discussed Ms. Watson's concerns with Jim Richmond
> and Al Bragg at DCA and with Julie Shaw of the ADA Working Group, and we
> all believe these concerns are rather sensationalistic and overblown.  Ms.
> Watson, Neil Melick, and the PVA are well-intentioned, kind people.
> However, their arguments, even in the attachments you forwarded to me are
> self-defeating.  Here is one excellent example from Neil Melick's letter:
> 
> As for the determination that waiver cases being approved were   primarily
> those with more than 20% disproportionate cost and
> waivers denied were less than 20%, that is probably a correct statement -
> if we are talking about those cases approved by the Commission and not by
> recommendation of the Council and if the statistics were taken prior to
> January 2002.  Since then, the Council has done a better job in making
> recommendations and giving time to comply.  Since January, I know that the
> majority of the vertical accessibility cases have been granted with
> condition that vertical accessibility be provided within a specified time.
> None of these cases even dealt with  disproportionate cost.
> 
> This very argument admits that the waiver applications cited have nothing
> to do with disproportionate cost.  The standards for waivers that are not
> based on disproportionate cost have not changed under the new law.  The
> standards for these types of applications are exactly the same.  Only
> applications based upon disproportionate cost (where accessability costs
> exceed 20% of the aggregate cost of other renovations during the previous
> year) have changed.
> 
> Angel Watson has made an additional argument to me in our phone
> conversations:  Architects will now create their designs to assure that
> accessability will cost more than 20% of renovation cost (by designing the
> structure to make accessability difficult and expensive).  That is a
> stronger argument.  However, the accessability council and the building
> commission can force the applicant to look at less expensive means of
> obtaining accessability.  Moreover, if architects and builders do engage
> in activity designed to accrue a waiver, we can address this by rule or by
> amendments to this legislation in the future.
> 
> Governor, I'm sorry for responding in such lengthy fashion.  I believe
> there is one more important issue for you to consider.  I believe you
> should request that DCA amend Chapter 34 of the administrative code so
> that the council and commission consider the total cost of a business's
> renovations over the previous three years when considering waivers based
> upon disproportionate cost.  As it stands now, under Chapter 34 of the
> administrative code, the council and commission may only consider the
> aggregate cost of renovations during the previous 12 months when
> determining whether accessability costs exceed 20% of renovations (e.g. if
> a business does 4 renovations over a 24 month period - 2 renovations
> during the previous 12 months and 2 more in the 12 months before that -
> each in the amount of $100,000, the council and commission would only be
> able to consider the last 2 renovations in determining whether costs
> exceed 20%.  Under this example, that would mean 20% of $200,000 or
> $40,000.  If a 36 month period were used, all four renovations would be
> considered and the 20% figure would not be reached until costs exceed
> $80,000.  Thus, the 36 month period would provide substantial additional
> protection for the disabled community).  In this manner, the disabled
> community would receive protection from businesses who conduct their
> renovations in piecemeal fashion in order to avoid complying with vertical
> accessability laws in Florida.
> 
> I recommend an increase to 36 months (as opposed to 24 or 48 months),
> because that is the standard under the ADA for calculating whether a
> business should receive a waiver based on disproportionate cost.  Also,
> the DCA is in the midst of its code revision process right now.  A letter
> of request from you at this time would be perfect timing to show your
> concern for protecting the disabled in Florida while also receiving rapid
> compliance with your request.
> 
> Would you like me to draft a letter requesting this change for your
> review?  If you have any questions, I would be happy to discuss this with
> you further. 488-3494
> 
> Kevin Tang
>

> Sent:	Thursday, May 30, 2002 6:21 PM
> To:	Tang, Kevin

>

From: Moore, Tim [mailto:TimMoore@fdle.state.fl.us]
Sent: Thursday, May 30, 2002 9:05 PM
To: Kim Bahrami (E-mail); Breeden, Bob
Cc: Kathleen M. Shanahan (E-mail); Jeb Bush
Subject: FW: Interesting Info. on California Hack


Kim.....as you can see below, the intrusion into the California State
Network was   apparently  facilitated, in part, by a lack of senior
level
leadership's involvement and follow through with their IT folks.  

To make sure we are not similarly effected, i would suggest you send a
strong and very specific memo to each agency head reminding them of the
need
for them to personally review the safeguards in place in their
respective
systems, especially our pension and financial systems.  While i know you
have been working this issue for sometime, i think a reminder from
either
you or the Governor would be well placed.

Pls let me know how i can help.

tim

-----Original Message-----
From: Breeden, Bob 
Sent: Thursday, May 30, 2002 6:36 PM
To: Moore, Tim; 'Bahrami, Kimberly'; 'Moore, James (Tim)'
Cc: Owens, Brenda; 'Shanahan, Kathleen'; Ramer, Phil
Subject: RE: Interesting Info. on California Hack


Commissioner and others:
This evening I have been successful in reaching the Commander of the
Sacramento High-Tech Crimes Taskforce that is conducting the
investigation
into this matter.  While he is limited in what info he can release at
this
point, he did give me the following information:
1) The computers that were intruded upon are not unique in nature.  He
stated that there are over 4000 computers of this kind in use in the
U.S.
today.
2) The vulnerabilities that were exploited to access the personal data
were
very well known.
3) The computers in question were running operating systems (OS) that
had
not been updated or patched in a long time.  At least two (2) patches
for
the OS in operation had been released by the manufacturer and had not
been
loaded on the machines in question.
4) The managers of the agencies in question were trusting their IT
managers
and staff to conduct basic maintenance of the system and thought that
same
had been conducted.  The managers were very surprised that their systems
were not patched.  The commander said that this was very basic "computer
hygiene" that had been neglected.
5) Two of the computers that were violated were sitting outside of the
firewalls and thus totally unprotected.  
The commander indicated that when they could talk more about the
specifics
of this case they would call me back and give us greater details.  In
the
interim, I would suggest that all Florida agencies ensure that they are
closely following the Trusecure guidelines that would have prevented
this
situation.
SAS Bob Breeden
FDLE Computer Crime Center
850-410-7057

> Hackers may have hit 265,000 state workers
> By Sam Stanton -- Bee Staff Writer
> Published 1:37 p.m. PDT Friday, May 24, 2002
> Computer hackers gained access to the California state government's
> computer systems in April and sensitive financial and personal
information
> about as many as 265,000 state workers, officials said Friday. 
> The electronic assault on payroll and other records was discovered by
the
> Sacramento Valley Hi Tech Task Force, which determined that none of
the
> information has been used illegally so far. 
> Despite that, agents with the task force, which includes the
Sacramento
> Sheriff's Department and the FBI, have launched an investigation into
the
> security breach and are searching for the hackers, The Bee has
learned.
> Sources said the hacking involved the state's Stephen P. Teale Data
> Center, which is based in Rancho Cordova and provides technical
computer
> assistance to many state departments. Authorities also believe the
state
> Department of Education computer system may have been accessed
illegally. 
> The security breaches have gone on for the past several months,
officials
> said, and gave the hackers access to Social Security numbers, last
names
> and first and middle initials of 265,000 state workers ranging from
judges
> and politicians to clerical workers. 
> However, authorities said there was no indication yet that the
information
> had been used by the hackers. 
> Despite that, authorities said there is grave concern over the ease
with
> which the hackers entered the computer systems, and that work by the
task
> force found that few of the security procedures that are supposed to
be in
> place actually are used. 
>

VIA FACSIMILE:  (850) 921-9077

Dear Governor Bush:

I was both pleased and perplexed to learn that you have chosen Orange County
as the location where you will sign into law the recently passed Growth
Management bill. 

I am pleased because Orange County is wrestling with many growth related
issues and has been at the forefront of tackling one of the most pressing of
those issues - overcrowded schools.  Therefore, it is an honor that you
would choose Orange County for this event.

Nonetheless, I am perplexed because the Orange County Board of County
Commissioners recently unanimously passed a resolution petitioning you to
urge the legislature to revisit several detrimental aspects of the growth
management bill during the recently completed special session and, to my
knowledge, we have never received a response from you or your office
regarding our concerns or petition.  

To reiterate the concerns expressed in our resolution, the judicial review
component of the bill will, at a minimum, stifle public involvement and
undermine the public's ability to provide valuable input into the decisions
made by local governments.  Furthermore, Section 163.3194 of the Growth
Management bill obstructs local governments' ability to deny permits for
landfills. And, on a matter with which you are very familiar, we continue to
support your previous efforts to encourage other counties to follow Orange
County's lead in denying applications to land-use changes and rezoning
applications where the result would be to exacerbate school overcrowding.

The Honorable Jeb Bush
May 30, 2002
Page 2




In light of your decision not to seek changes during the special session and
to sign this bill into law tomorrow, please reconsider our concerns about
the detrimental aspects of this bill.  Please send a letter urging the
legislature to amend, during the 2003 legislative session, the sections of
the bill that obstruct both the ability of the public and local government
to ensure compatible, responsible land-use decisions in the future.

Thank you for your commitment to the citizens of the State of Florida and
your favorable consideration of this request.  We stand ready to support
your continued efforts to foster growth management legislation that reduces
school overcrowding.

Sincerely,




Teresa S. Jacobs

TSJ/tp

c:	Richard Crotty, Orange County Chairman
	Orange County Board of County Commissioners
	Ajit Lalchandani, County Administrator
	Tom Wilkes, County Attorney
	Dick Spears, Legislative Chairman, Orange County Homeowners
Association
	Bob Brown, President, Orange County Homeowners Association
	Donn Prendergast, Webmaster, OCINS

From:	Connie Frank <FrankC@dor.state.fl.us>
Sent:	Friday, May 31, 2002 10:49 AM
To:	cps1@flash.net
Cc:	billmonroe@aud.state.fl.us; JIMDWYER@aud.state.fl.us; Jim Zingale; Jeb Bush; Robert_F_Milligan@mail.dbf.state.fl.us
Subject:	Re: Floating Homes
Attachments:	opn98-0009.txt; opn91-0062.txt; opn90-0012.txt

Ms. Anderson:

I am attaching two opinion letters (90-0012 and 98-0009) which address
the issues to which you refer.  According to the opinion letters:

The floating home or floating structure is considered TPP.  As such, it
is not eligible for homestead exemption because the Constitution limits
the homestead exemption to real property.  

Opinion letter 91-0062 has been attached as relevant to your inquiry
about uniformity when taxing mobile homes.  According to this opinion
letter, the mobile home or park trailer is taxed as real property when
the owner has permanently affixed it to the land he owns.  Again the
homestead exemption can apply if the mobile home is considered real
property.

Regarding other exemptions that may be applicable, it is difficult to
respond without knowing specific circumstances.  Please refer to the TPP
guidelines, section V. page 29, to determine if any situation applies to
your client.  Not mentioned in the guidelines but, perhaps, applicable,
is section 196.202, F.S., regarding widows, widowers, blind and disabled
exemptions that apply to TPP. 

Also, according to sections 328.68, 328.69, and 328.70, F.S., (prior to
1999, found in Chapter 327, F.S.) if the floating homes qualifies as a
vessel, it is exempt from TPP tax but is subject to a vessel
registration fee.

I hope this information is helpful.  

>>> "cps1" <cps1@flash.net> 05/30/02 07:26AM >>>
Connie Frank -

A taxpayer has asked for information about "floating homes," which are
being taxed as tangible property in his county. He asks if it is legal,
and whether there are any exemptions applicable to floating homes .

If it is legal, it seems to me to be not uniformly applied. Please
comment on this aspect, since mobile homes appear to be treated
differently while the principles of both seem to be exactly identical.

And, it is legal, then would not homestead and other such exemptions be
applicable if a floating home is a permanent residence in Florida and is
taxed? Please comment on this.

I request your responses asap by email. 

Thank you.

SHEILA M. ANDERSON
Principal/Realtor
COMMERCIAL PROPERTY SERVICES, INC.
Licensed Real Estate Broker
305-372-9200

Doris:

Leah Schad, past SFWMD governing board member and past president of the
Audubon Society of the Everglades, is in the hospital.  She was very active
in getting the initial draft of the Northern Palm Beach County plan
together.   She was operated on yesterday afternoon at Good Sam for breast
cancer .  The operation went well and she had reconstructive surgery. She is
in Room 278A.  She is in some pain and just wants to sleep today.  She would
welcome anyone who just wants to say hello or pop their head in and say
hello but she is not up to long conversation.  She will be in the hospital
until Sunday or Monday then home.   The address of Good Sam is 1309 North
Flagler, WPB 33401 and phone number is 655-5511.  

Leah's home address is 3634 North Flagler Dr., WPB, 33407-4403 and her home
phone is 848 9984.

-----Original Message-----
From: MZientz@aol.com [mailto:MZientz@aol.com]
Sent: Friday, May 31, 2002 9:28 AM
To: mccarty@doi.state.fl.us; Jeb Bush; Crowelle@DOI.State.Fl.Us;
Crs012001@cs.com
Subject: Workers Compensation Reform Commission


Hon. Governor,
       I believe that there needs to be input from VOICES to the reform 
commission. I believe that input needs to be consistent. I believe that a 
representative from VOICES, the same designated person, should be able to 
attend each commission session and have the opportunity to be heard and to 
organize a coherent and non-redundant presentation by injured workers. 
       I believe the efficient operation of this important commission can be 
achieved by appointing Mary Bailey, President of VOICES as a designated 
representative of injured workers. I do not believe the commission needs to 
be expanded nor any current appointee replaced. I do believe that funds 
should be allocated for travel and other per diem so that Ms. Bailey could 
afford to attend each session and participate in the commissions work. 
       The commission studying workers' compensation issues must not hear 
scattered horror stories from injured workers, they should hear the VOICE of 
injured workers as presented in a coherent and consistent manner.
       I urge you to make Mary Bailey a non-voting "member" of the commission 
or a member of the staff with full access, travel and per diem allowance. 
Thank you, 
       Respectfully,

       Mark L. Zientz, Esq. 
       Member of the Board of FWA, Member of the Board of WILG, Member of the 
Executive Council of the Workers' Compensation Section of the Florida Bar, 
Arbitrator for the Workers' Compensation program of the NFL players Assn. and 
the NFL Management Council, Recovering Workers' Compensation Defense Attorney 
(1979-1994).

-----Original Message-----
From: Dave Schiltz (Doc) [mailto:dschiltz@tampabay.rr.com]
Sent: Friday, May 31, 2002 8:43 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: HB374


I was very disappointed in your veto.  The existing structure for protecting lakes in eastern Citrus county has been a dismal failure.
 
We moved to FL 3 years ago to a home on Floral City Lake.  The drought is not the only reason that water levels have been low, but I won't get into all the details.  The only time SWMD released any water, we got 7 feet in 2 weeks and it killed all our fish.  In a matter of months it's all gone again.
 
Citizens have very little opportunity to try to influence the bureacracy.  To my knowledge they've never had any public forums where they make themselves available and provide information.  If it wasn't for TOO FAR, my opinion is that the devestation would be worse.  You cannot imagine the demoralizing effect this situation has had on lake/canal property owners - although you may be aware of the economic impact.

-----Original Message-----
From: Milton & Berthy Aponte [mailto:apontemb@juno.com]
Sent: Friday, May 31, 2002 8:54 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: Missmartica@hotmail.com; Karen Unger; Mike Hanna
Subject: Grass roots forum


Hola Jeb:

As you know, this next June 10 there will be a Grassroots conference for
people of ALL disabilities in Orlando.  I understand that the Secretary
of State will also be attendance to celebrate Florida's national historic
accessibility voting bill.  National historic, because it exceeds federal
requirements, and is accessible to all disabilities.  I also understand
that when that is taking place in Orlando, you will be having a ceremony
about the same bill, but that the advocates that drafted that bill will
not be able to be there because they will all be in Orlando at the
grassroots forum.  Is there any possibility that you could conduct your
planned ceremony in Orlando?  I think is important that people of all
disabilities feel your presence.  Because most of them are democrats,
this is a good time for you to show your presence with them as well. 
PLEASE talk to people from your External Affairs about it.  I am copying

From:	FL_DEP <FL_DEP@dep.state.fl.us>
Sent:	Friday, May 31, 2002 11:29 AM
To:	Jeb Bush; christopher.flack@myflorida.com
Cc:	Joyner, Mike
Subject:	Soda Apple / Ard

Governor:
The tropical soda apple problem is principally a problem on privately owned
ranch lands, not on public lands.  Of over 500 applications received by DEP
from public land agencies, only one sought assistance for this problem.  

The issue at hand is a $103,000 budget item at the Dept. of Agriculture for
IFAS to work on developing a biological control (i.e., a bug) for this
nuisance plant.  It is important to put this in perspective.

Based on other experiences developing biological controls, we expect this to
be a 5 to 10 year effort that will cost $10 to $15 million.  While every
little bit will help, $103,000 really will not make not much of a difference
to this effort.

I think the question is: "If the $103,000 is cut from the Agriculture budget,
could DEP TRANSFER some of its resources to IFAS for this purpose?"

I would advise against this because: 1) the amount will not make a material
difference; 2) this is principally a problem on private, not public lands; 3)
IFAS has never sought resources from DEP's trust funds for this purpose
before; 4) should we create this precedent, IFAS will likely come back every
year looking to tap these Florida Forever dollars for this project to assist
a particular group of private landowners; 5)IFAS can apply through the
existing competitive application process for funding for this project, as
they currently do with other invasive species management projects.

Finally, the fact that neighboring states may quarantine Florida cattle
before allowing them to be transferred to pasture is not going to be
influenced by whether or not $103,000 is or is not spent on a long-term,
multi-million dollar research project.  (In fact, Texas already quarantines
Florida cattle for 17 days so that all othe Soda Apple seeds pass through the
animal before they are transferred to Texas ranches.)

Mike Joyner knows more about this and has spoken to Chris Flack about this.
They are available if you have any questions.

If the $103,000 cut is critical for other purposes, then I would make the cut
from Agriculture's budget.  If it is not, I would leave it in since I know it
is a priority for Commissioner Bronson who himself has personally dealt with
the problem of Soda Apples.  

I would not create the precedent of transferring DEP's Florida Forever
dollars to IFAS for this type of research project.  IFAS can, of course,
apply for funding from this program as any other public agency.

Department of Commerce was notified today by attorneys for Mexican growers that they are pulling out of suspension agreement on tomatoes. Our growers as well as Commerce official are shocked, after all we had all hoped to renew the agreement.

Commerce will revert back to investigation of dumping action with dumping margins of 18%. The case will ultimately go to the USITC where the Mexicans are confident they will win. The Florida growers are saying the Mexican government is backing their growers, the Canadian Government is backing their growers, where is the Bush administration going to be on this?

-----Original Message-----
From: NativeLandscapes@aol.com [mailto:NativeLandscapes@aol.com]
Sent: Friday, May 31, 2002 11:43 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: re: Ichetucknee River Cement Kiln


Governor Bush,
I applaud your recent environmental progress regarding Gas and Oil Drilling in the state of Florida, but you can't stop there.  The Ichetucknee River is one of the most beautiful in the world, and a tremendous tourist attraction drawing 200,000 visitors per year, which are vital to local businesses.  By approving the construction of a cement kiln 3 miles from the river you risk destroying one of the premier outdoor recreation areas in the state.  The emmisions from the it's smokestacks will harm the river which already has high advisory levels of mercury.  The increased truck traffic to the area can only cause damage to the river and it's surrounding habitat which supports many species of rare wildlife.  I first canoed the Ichetucknee River when I was 1 year old with my parents and I am still amazed by its beauty.  
So Please Reconsider This Potentially Disastrous Decision.
Thank You For Your Time
Bob Seashore
Native Landscapes
Landscape Architecture & Environmental Planning
NativeLandscapes.com

-----Original Message-----
From: Milani, Rodolfo [mailto:rodolfo.milani@csfb.com]
Sent: Friday, May 31, 2002 10:10 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: THIS IS AN ABSOLUTE DISGRACE



Half right in history gets A 
By Kimberly Miller, Palm Beach Post Staff Writer
Thursday, May 30, 2002
Palm Beach County high school students taking a new standardized history exam this week need to answer just over half of the 100 questions correctly to get an A grade on the test; to earn a B, only 39 correct answers are required.
In fact, to pass the test with a D, a student needs to answer only 23 questions correctly.
The new final exam for American and world history classes was developed by school district officials to ensure students learn state required lessons that include history about women, Africans, African-Americans and the Holocaust. The questions -- including about 15 on African-American history -- are multiple choice. The history program has been required since 1999.
The 100-question tests -- specific to Palm Beach County -- replace the individual final exams that teachers create themselves. The district, which recommended the scale, sent letters to schools giving them the option to use it on the new test. Many said they will, while teachers in some schools said the issue has not been discussed yet. It will be for this year only.
But some teachers were concerned about the low passing scale, especially for students who missed 10 days or more of school during the year and had to pass the test to show "mastery" of the subject, or fail the class. Does answering 29 to 38 questions correctly out of 100 to get a C show mastery, some asked.
"I don't think if you administer a valid test and a kid misses half of the questions, that they should pass," said Thomas O'Brien, a social studies teacher at Lake Worth High School. "I think there is unwarranted panic on the part of some people who feel like they didn't want to be ambushed."
The typical grading scale awards an A for 90 percent or more questions correct, a B for 80 percent to 89 percent correct, a C for 70 percent to 79 correct and a D for 60 percent to 69 percent correct.
To fail the new standardized history exam this year with an F grade, a student would have to miss 78 of the 100 questions. 
School board member Debra Robinson, who introduced the idea of using a standardized history exam last fall, said she's OK with the grading scale this year, because it's the first time the district is using the exam.
Final exams are worth 20 percent of a student's grade. It's possible, Robinson said, if a student failed the new test, to fail the class for the year.
"This is the year of change and transition and it's really, in my mind, the warm-up year," Robinson said. "When you have massive change, it takes people time to adjust."
Robinson said she also heard concerns from teachers who felt they didn't get information about the exam until it was too late to adequately prepare their students.
Ana Meehan, executive director of academic programs, said teachers should have received, in January, sample tests, African and African-American history lessons, and charts of deadlines on what needed to be taught and when. A handful of schools that used the exam in a pilot program first semester received the information before school started.
Also, Meehan acknowledged, most of the information given to teachers covers subjects that they should have been teaching anyway, based on the Sunshine State Standards. The state standards outline exactly what a student should learn at each grade level. 
The scores from this year's test will be evaluated and changes to the test or scoring scale could be made, Meehan said. 
"We're hoping this year to get baseline data from the scores, but also information from teachers such as whether the test is aligned to the textbook," Meehan said. 
William T. Dwyer High School Principal David Culp questions the low passing rate on the grading scale. He understands it's the first year for the history test, but said even a student guessing at most questions should get 25 percent right. 
"If I have an educated guess, I could get 30 to 40 percent correct," he said.

Rodolfo E. Milani
Director
Private Client Services
CREDIT SUISSE FIRST BOSTON
Barclays Financial Center
Suite 1400
Miami, FL 33131

May 31, 2002


VIA FAX:  321/255-9550
Your Views
FLORIDA TODAY
P.O. Box 419000
Melbourne, FL  32941-9000

Your May 19 special report, "School funding:  Is it a crisis?" provided an
exhaustive yet nevertheless incomplete and misleading portrait of Florida's
funding commitment to public education.  

It's true that public education saw deep cuts in the early 90s.  But it is
Florida's more recent funding record that should be most relevant to your
readers and most important in evaluating whether our schools are currently
in "crisis."  These are the facts about Florida's public schools over the
past four years:

Funding is up.  Our four-year funding record - in the aggregate, per
student, with inflation, however you want to count it - is better than that
of either of my predecessor's two terms.  And while real
(inflation-adjusted) per-student spending in Florida declined over the eight
years of the previous administration, under our watch, it has gone up.
Per-student funding was even up last year, despite the economic slowdown and
terrorist attacks.  In Brevard County, for example, we have increased public
school funding by 24 percent over four years, or 17 percent per student.

Your special report repeatedly compares where we are now with where we were
10, 12 or 15 years ago, but not with where we were just four years ago.  You
repeatedly compare Florida with other states - using apples to oranges
comparisons, by the way - but not Florida today with Florida four years ago.
It is Florida's four-year funding record that is most relevant, and most
extraordinary.

Can we spend more?  Should we spend more?  Yes, which is why I look forward
to soon signing a state budget that will provide a $1.1 billion increase for
Florida's public schools.  This represents a one-year increase in total K-12
funds of 9 percent and a per-student increase of 6 percent, a rate two to
three times the projected rate of inflation.  In Brevard County, that works
out to an additional $265 per student next year.

The true "crisis" in Florida's educational system is that no matter how much
we spend, some still see spending as the primary (or even the sole)
criterion for judging excellence in our public schools.  Student achievement
is the key, and any funding increase is squandered if it does not yield
greater achievement and greater accountability.

Fortunately, under the A+ Plan and our other visionary reforms, Florida's
student achievement is rising.  FCAT scores in many areas show great
improvement - including in Brevard County -- and this year we have raised
school grading standards because our teachers, administrators, parents and
students excelled under the original standards and proved they are ready to
meet the next challenge.

The "crisis" in Florida's public schools lies behind us, not in front of us,
unless we return to the policies that created the crisis in the first place.



Sincerely,



Jeb Bush

Please note: Florida has a very broad public records law.

-----Original Message-----
From: Arduin, Donna [mailto:Donna.Arduin@LASPBS.STATE.FL.US]
Sent: Friday, May 31, 2002 9:58 AM
To: Bratina, Jill; Yablonski, Brian; Jeb Bush
Subject: FW: Revenue/spending data--TODAY'S ARTICLE





-----Original Message----- 
From: Langston, Don 
Sent: Friday, May 31, 2002 9:32 AM 
To: Hirst, Elizabeth 
Cc: Arduin, Donna; Turbeville, Greg 
Subject: FW: Revenue/spending data--TODAY'S ARTICLE 


the following article appeared today discussing the newly released Commerce data. 

http://www.floridatoday.com/!NEWSROOM/localstoryA20458A.htm 

I have several comments: 
(1) Though this may not really matter that much, the article says the revenue numbers are taxes per capita.  This is incorrect.  These are all revenues, including federal funds.

(2) This is a crude interstate comparison, in which no adjustments are made for interstate differences in: 
        --cost-of-living or cost-of-inputs, 
        --functional responsibilities between state and local governments (looking at combined state and local government spending and revenues solves this problem)

        --demographic composition. 

Failing to adjust for demographic composition can be particularly important with respect to school spending.  Because Florida's school aged population as a percent of total state population is low compared to the U.S. average, a simple per capita comparison makes Florida spending look artificially low.  

The conclusions drawn from a simple per capita comparison of state government only, is methodologically questionable.

From:	Concerned Parent <stoptheslaughter@hotmail.com>
Sent:	Friday, May 31, 2002 2:07 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	DCFS Blue Ribbon Panel
Attachments:	@GRIEVANCES--  Short List.rtf; @Manufactured Allegations.rtf; @Neighborhood Letters.rtf

May 29, 2002

Governor Jeb Bush,

In an act of complete and utterly disgusting malfeasance, my
fourteen-year-old child was seized under color of law by a
Department of Children and Family Services protective investigator
who seemed to be more interested in her own personal agenda of
increasing the number of placements made with openly gay custodians,
than she was in the safety and well being of my child.  My son was
forced to go into the custody of a malicious, predatory, conniving,
pedophilic homosexual who had ALREADY been reported to the DCFS for
his inordinate attempts to "LURE" my child.

The man had no job and hadn't worked in nearly a year!  He lived at
the apartment of a local stripper who worked at Club Madonna at
South Beach.  Neighbors say she also worked as a prostitute.  Many
of the neighbors, not only reported these things to the DCFS and the
Florida Abuse Hotline, but they also reported that these two
unmarried, DCFS-chosen "Caregivers" (NEITHER of whom was an American
Citizen) were regularly using illegal drugs and having Ecstasy
Parties in their apartment!

The Miami Beach Police Department, subsequently, informed me that
this pedophilic homosexual was under investigation for the sexual
molestation of my child.  This man has since fled to avoid being
brought in on "pedophile" charges - and, now, cannot be found.  The
stripper has disappeared as well, it seems.  The DCFS came before
the Honorable Judge Cindy Lederman and said that they were moving my
child: because the Caregiver's mother had taken sick; and, therefore
this Caregiver had to leave the United States - so he would be
returning to his own country to see his sick mother.  This was
absolutely and completely false information!

While under the care of these DCFS-recommended Caregivers, my child
was repeatedly offered drugs and even "FORCED" to inhale drug smoke,
on at least one occasion.  The DCFS had already been made well aware
(by many concerned people from our neighborhood) of the imminent
dangers of this placement.  They responded by pompously * YELLING *
at me in the court room of Judge Lederman that the homosexual would
NOT BE SEXUALLY MOLESTING MY CHILD and that there was nothing
illegal about their placing my child with a stripper/lap
dancer/alleged prostitute.  The DCFS contended that this foreigner
(who, it was arrogantly bragged, could bring in
one-thousand-dollars-OR-MORE-a-night from her "catering" business)
could provide a better, more wholesome home for my child.

Both the stripper and this pedophilic homosexual reported that they
were making their living by working as "food caterers," when they
had asked for Custody of my child.  The DCFS investigative
protector, her DCFS Supervisor, and the accompanying Police Officer
all witnessed the evidence of this blatantly fraudulent report that
had been made by these two prospective Caregivers.  This unlawful
fraud, all the warning calls from the neighbors, and the obviously
questionable characters of these two prospective Custodians WERE
PURPOSELY OVERLOOKED and CONVENIENTLY IGNORED; and they were given,
at the recommendation of the DCFS, legal custody of my child.

THE ABUSE OF MY CHILD STILL CONTINUES, even now, under the
State-paid care of the DCFS!   My child, since being moved from the
pedophilic homosexual's custody, has been BEATEN UP and EVEN HAD HIS
EAR TORN!  No one seems to care!  Certainly, the DCFS is not going
to make these things known to the public.  My child was forced, by
the DCFS, to live in five different locations and was required to
attend three different schools within the first five months of his
"protective" care.  Now, he's failing in school and has decided that
he no longer even wants to go to college.

It has been eight months; and I still have not been allowed to
present my side of the story, in court - nor have I been allowed to
visit my child, a single time.  I have been repeatedly threatened,
at the instigation of the DCFS, that if I even try to speak a single
word in my defense in the court room - then, they will have me
arrested on the very spot (right in the court room, itself!).

The DCFS even made a concerted attempt to pursue a course of
"malicious prosecution" against me for my efforts to try and protect
my child from their irresponsible, negligent and abusive placement.
They actually brought formal charges against me and tried to have me
arrested for reporting my fears - of the possible dangers of their
placement - to the Florida Abuse Hotline.  The police, thank God,
saw the absurdity of these malicious charges and threw them out!

The DCFS still holds my child and staunchly refuses to allow him to
appear in court, to refute the false and slanderous allegations
still being held against me. The reason given by DCFS is that a
court appearance would be "too stressful" for my child (even though
he has specifically asked to be present).  There is no Guardian ad
Litem, that I know of, on the case; and there seems to be no way to
halt the DCFS' relentless abuse or to defend ourselves against their
spiteful, venom-spitting, ass-covering lies and continual
falsification of reports.

The first five times I went to court there were FOUR DIFFERENT
JUDGES presiding!  SEVEN different lawyers have ALREADY handled my
case.  Once, I had TWO State-appointed lawyers assigned to my case
AT THE VERY SAME TIME (for nearly a month) - one of whom, I had no
idea had even been assigned to represent me.

I now have no money and, therefore, cannot carry out the necessary
depositions; because my last State-appointed lawyer failed to show
up for the Pre-trial Hearing and has, repeatedly, refused to give me
an appointment for legal counsel.  This lawyer was appointed to my
case on Feb 26th of 2002.  It's now almost June, and this
State-appointed lawyer has only seen me once (back on April the 9th
of 2002) - for 20 minutes!  He has stubbornly refused to give me
another appointment; admitting that what they pay him is nothing but
"chicken-feed."  This man gets regular referrals by being on the
Juvenile Dependency Wheel (and probably, in reality, doesn't want to
"rock the boat" of his employees by revealing the abusive atrocities
that have been perpetuated against my son, during the DCFS' handling
of this case).

I HAVE NO HOPE; unless someone hears my plea for help --- against
this out-of-control, all-powerful, child welfare system that is
malevolently destroying our society, family by family, with their
un-assailed incompetence and spiteful "manufacturing" of slanderous
allegations to support their ever-growing "Abuse Industry," which
has so out-stripped it's original purposes that it is now, in many
cases, actually waging an unjustified and certainly unwelcome "war"
against the good citizens of our State.

Thank you,
                            Harry S. DuVal, Jr.
                            200 South Shore Drive, #11
                            Miami Beach, Florida  33141

                                PHONE:  (305) 865-1206


* * *ENCLOSED* * *
       PLEASE FIND: THREE ATTACHMENTS.

>ONE is a two-page summary of the DCFS' malfeasance , concerning my
particular case. (a twenty-page summary of this case is also
available upon request)
>>THE SECOND is a one-page compendium of half of the absurdly
"manufactured" allegations that the DCFS used to justify the
removal of my child into their "protective" custody.
>>>THE THIRD contains several letters from neighbors who were
witness to the situation.


* * *ADDITIONAL INFORMATION* * *
and many other letters from those in our neighborhood are also
available, upon request.

* * *ALSO, I WOULD WELCOME AN INTERVIEW* * *
with any investigative reporter who may find this case to be of
interest.

Subject:	Re: We have just begun to fight.

For all those that worked on HB 1307,
    Governor Bush has signed HB 1307. :**(
    I want to thank you all for standing by your convictions and always 
keeping what is best for individuals with disabilities and the people of 
Florida as your driving force. Personally, I am Republican, and can't tell 
you how devastated I am with Governor Bush and his staff for the signing of 
HB 1307. I believed he would always put the concerns and safety of the people 
of Florida first. 
    There were so many emails and faxes and letters sent from our community. 
There is a letter that is supposed to be distributed with the bill, and I 
suppose there will be an explanation, but to take our community backwards 
toward discrimination and unequal access is inexcusable. The way this 
amendment got on the bill is unacceptable. There was nothing on the bill that 
had to go through this session, and our lives will be irreversibly changed 
because of the inaccessibility that the bill will allow.
    For those of you who tried to bring it to the Governor's attention, 
Thank-you. I appreciate the time and the heart that went into your efforts. I 
wish he had veto'd the bill, but since he hasn't, I'll let you know if there 
is anything we can do to recover the lost accessibility. 
    Please forward to anyone you know that had the integrity and fortitude to 
help individuals with disabilities keep Florida's accessibility standards.
Blessings,
Angel Watson
Accessibility Coordinator 
for Caring & Sharing Center for Independent Living, Inc.

From:	Dana, Pam <pam.dana@myflorida.com>
Sent:	Friday, May 31, 2002 2:54 PM
To:	Smith, Kelley; Sasser, Charla
Cc:	Jeb Bush; Hampton, Betty; Shanahan, Kathleen; Muniz, Katie
Subject:	NATTER BIO and GULF COAST RANGE COMPLEX Plan
Attachments:	GULF COAST RANGE COMPLEX PA PLAN.doc; AdmiralNatterbio.doc; NavyPress.doc


Below, please find a copy of Admiral Natter's bio for Governor's meeting on
Tuesday morning at 8:15.  

Admiral Natter's visit with Governor is a courtesy call.  He can be expected
to brief the Governor on Navy's plans to utilize Florida-based assets to
conduct preparedness training (Key West, Pensacola, Eglin Range, and Avon
Park).  We have been working with the Navy (and to some extent Eglin AFB)
for over a year on bringing increased training missions to the state where
feasible. Upwards of $700 million in next few years is expected to come here
as a result.  Attached, please find a press release by Governor on this
issue. 

Also attached below is a Navy public affairs plan addressing their proposed
use of the Gulf Coast Range Complex.  The Navy put this together per my
request so that we could jointly use it to address any potential issues
regarding future Navy use of the range.  I have arranged for Katie, Liz,
Brian, Lisa, and David to meet on Tuesday morning with the Atlantic Fleet
Public Affairs Officer while Governor is with Admiral Natter to discuss any
outstanding concerns, issues, scenarios, etc.

Finally, on Monday, I am hosting a community-based meeting in Bay County
where Admiral Natter and Tyndall AFB leadership will meet with community and
business leaders.  This meeting will be followed by an editorial board where
local press can ask relevant questions pertaining to Navy co-training with
Air Force on Eglin range--and how that will impact Tyndall area.  This
meeting came about as a result of an email that William Harrison sent to the
Governor with concerns that Tyndall would be negatively impacted by shared
services use of range.  Since that email, we have resolved all concerns and
this community meeting should be a love fest.  Governor is credited with
being responsible guy who resolved this well for all concerned.

From:	Lewis, Celeste <Celeste.Lewis@MyFlorida.com>
Sent:	Friday, May 31, 2002 3:29 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Cc:	Shanahan, Kathleen; MANAGEMENT
Subject:	Weekly Report

We received 5,460 e-mails and 1,331 letters.

Hot topics:  continue to receive legislative related correspondence
including:  SB160 (Debbie Wasserman-Schultz Act) - folks wanted veto--once
it was vetoed, folks were calling praising the Governor; SB1844 (Economic
Development) citizens were disappointed that the bill was signed stating it
"invaded family privacy;" SB1262 (Public Health Emergency) citizens
requesting veto, comments include, "it's unconstitutional, and the illegal
search and seizure is one step away from communism, and dictatorship...no
government should have the power to step in and take someone's property
away...it takes away from families and freedom;" and HB1307 (Building Code)
disabled community against legislation and building industry for
legislation.  Appropriation items include support for Osceola County
education, Nehrling Museum and Gardens at Palm Cottage Gardens, Hispanic
Theater Guild in Miami, and Foundation for Dreams, Dream Oaks Camp (Florida
Jaycees).

We are still receiving correspondence and calls on the Rilya Wilson case and
DCF issues in general--some phone callers are threatening to go to the media
as leverage to try and have their cases handled differently.  

Organized campaigns include: Stop the raids of Florida Forever Program,
Don't allow polluted stormwater to be dumped into the Everglades, Follow
through with your conservation promise, The time for strong manatee
protection is now, Florida Bass Conservation Center/Please support line item
2036C, and Federal Farm Bill (Section 10302) --encourage President to veto.

Federal issues include relationship between Cuba and U.S. (most from South
Florida and most support the embargo) and immigration issues.

Blast e-mails with veto message on SB160 and the press release regarding
"Protecting Florida from drilling" also went out from this office to
citizens who had previously e-mailed on the subject.

Have a great weekend!

Celeste

Please note: Florida has a very broad public records law.

regarding state business are public records available to the

-----Original Message-----
From: Rick west <producer45@worldnet.att.net>
To: Jeb Bush <jeb@jeb.org>
Sent: Fri May 31 16:06:52 2002
Subject: here's the complete story.........COPY> ...Tampa News

Dear Sirs,
 we have a great story for your investigative news team. 
This is going on during the states massive budget cuts.

My name is Rick West and I’m the PSA chairman for the Tampa chapter of the Florida Motion Picture and Television Association and my daughter Christy was a victim of an on going Modeling agency scam in the Tampa bay area.
By Networking with another victim Mrs. Gina Hughes> 813-685-6094 and with help from the Florida Bluesheet a concerned trade publication 
>407-292-7458 we learned about #42 other victims within Florida and in Georgia.  

We have uncovered a clear pattern of fraud that prays on the dreams of the children and adults both young and old in Tampa and Atlanta.

Now here’s the real story. 
It’s been well over a year since the ST. Pete Times exposed the fact that the Department of Professional Regulation in Tallahassee whom is charged with enforcing the talent agency licensing laws under Chapter 468 of the State Statute and the DPR has failed to do so allowing these scams to continue unabated.  
Additionally, we have uncovered an agency that fails to bring any action to protect the public when violations of law are reported to them. 

Case in point,
 Model 2000 Inc. ran a continuous advertisement under the General help wanted section of a local newspaper for modeling and acting jobs. 
When people phoned them they were told to come in for an interview. 
At the interview they filled out an employment application, which also asked if they had any current comp cards and which they were promptly told that they needed to have done for these jobs. 
To sell these expensive 800.00 plus comp cards
many people were promised and guaranteed modeling assignments with the JC. Penny Company for their catalogs and they were told that “they would make back the comp card fees in no time” along with other such employment. 
Model 2000 Inc. claimed to have an Atlanta partner who handled this for the JC. Penny Company and most clients were given a list of other agencies to send the comp cards to. Model 2000 inc. claimed to send them out too.

Most of the victims reported that they were never called for any auditions and or, jobs by Model 2000 Inc. or by anyone else.
And after repeated phone calls to them some were told “that things were slow right now” while they ran the continues help wanted ad or that Model 2000 Inc. didn’t remember them or that they needed to buy more comp cards from Model 2000 Inc. 
And, when 50% of the comps cards that we sent out came back we called agents who told us that the comp cards were of a poor quality and that agents only keep one and throw the rest way. 
Clearly, contrary to state law,
 Model 2000 Inc. makes money from these comp cards and not by commissions.  

 We later discovered that Model 2000 Inc. had an un-registered office in Atlanta and we obtained a letter from the JC. Penny legal counsel stating that Model 2000 Inc.
 must stop using the JC. Penny name because they had no right to do so.
They were in fact offering non-existent jobs.
   
And, we later learned that Model 2000 Inc. was in direct violation of Chapter 468 because they didn’t give clients the required contracts or fee schedules and they didn’t keep client contact records nor did they post the required information in the business. 

 What they were doing was running a photo service outside of the offices on Gandy ave during hours that they weren’t listed to operate in according to their filed combo commission schedule/ hours of operation. 
 Chapter 468 prohibits these agencies from charging photo or registration fees yet every client was sold these expensive comp cards.
And, Model 2000 Inc. has a photo service occupational license. 

Model 2000 Inc. tried to tell Judge Eric Meyers that photo receipts were valid contracts. Judge Meyers ruled that both parties did not dually sign them nor were they the contracts required under chapter 468. 
However, verbal contracts are legal in Florida so Model 2000 Inc. will be held accountable for their pattern of promising the advertised non-existent employment.  
 
We have obtained a letter from a photographer who was an employee of Model 2000 Inc. regarding Model 2000 Inc. selling these to people that didn’t meet the industry requirements to Model.
 
This Photographer stated that he and the makeup person were paid 25.00 per person to take these photos. 
We found that the average printing cost was 100.00 and most people paid over 800.00 each for these comp cards. 
We learned that the photo receipts needed to show sale tax on it and they don’t. 
And, we learned by discovery that Model 2000 Inc was shooting 10-20 people a weekend for these comp cards at 800.00 ave. each but that they were only reporting making 6k and 9K for the last two years.  
This is ripping off Florida’s  children and the tax payers too.  

The DPR states that the complainants must use their forms and must contact them.  
We have learned that both the BBB and the DPR have suppressed prior complaints made against this company.

The Tampa Police Departments Economic Crimes Unit has interviewed many of the victims however the DPR refuses to contact them regarding these complaints of grand theft and fraud yet they claim to protect this states consumers.
 The State Attorney will get this case.




Most of the victims were kids that have been ripped off here. 
We learned that other talent agents sit on the regulating board and they admit to having limited power because they can’t get restitution nor shut down such scams. 
Therefore, these agencies have a state license to steal.

 
We have an upcoming civil trial in Tampa and have filed criminal complaints with TPD, the DPR and with the Florida Attorney Generals office. 
The Florida Attorney General said that we did every thing right but I learned that they wondered why the DPR who was charged with handling the case wasn’t doing anything for the 42 reported victims of this scam.
We received a letter from the DPR that they were waiting to take action until the civil case was over. 
The staff Attorney for the DPR explained that it was because they didn’t want to file in piece meal. 
Criminal action isn’t civil action so they should charge the business with fraud.
Other states have closed down these scams and the companies have moved to Florida. Any wonder why? 

We know that there are many more victims in the Tampa area so we are asking for your help with this urgent matter. 
I have a file that’s a foot thick with documents regarding supporting evidence to backup all statements and claims made within this letter. 
Sincerely,
 Rick West  727-862-0133

The Cultural Center Of Charlotte County is in the process of renovating and expanding our 33 year old facility in Charlotte County.  This facility includes a 418 seat theater, Library, Educational classes and Senior activities Lounge.  It is staffed by a small number of paid employees and over 850 volunteers that serve over 350,000 visitors each year in its food service program, activities, shows and events.

Dear Governor Bush;

I manage a beverage manufacturing facility located in Osceola County and as
a corporate citizen of the county our company supports the State Legislature
approved moneys of $10 million to support school systems in Florida's
fastest growing counties and trust that you will seek ways to help make this
happen.  

Our plant employs a large percentage of people who reside in Osceola County
and many of these folks have school age children who will benefit from these
appropriations today and in their future school years.  In addition, we rely
heavily on the local population base to draw upon for future employment
needs as we hope to grow our business in the near future.  Having young
adults come out of local schools well prepared for the work environment for
today and for tomorrow not only benefits our business but also benefits the
economy of Osceola County as well as the State of Florida.

I appreciate the opportunity to be able to share this message with you and
trust that these moneys will made available to those counties experiencing
rapid growth so that our young people coming out of school will be well
prepared to step in and carry on the economic development of Central
Florida.



Sincerely,

Roger W. Dickey, Plant Manager

From:	Kumar Mahadevan <kumar@mote.org>
Sent:	Friday, May 31, 2002 5:11 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Cc:	bushj@eog.state.fl.us
Subject:	Cultural Facilities Funding (Line 3140A)




Dear Jeb:

On behalf of Mote and other cultural organizations in the state, we urge
you to support funding for the Cultural Facilities Program for
FY2002-03.

Cultural facilities grants are competitive, peer-reviewed and require
matching funds as a pre-requisite.  100% of the funds are passed
directly into the local economy where they promote job creation and
enhance tourism.

Mote's $500,000 request for cultural facilities grant was rated number
one in the state and we have already raised substantial matching funds.

Thank you for your consideration.

Kumar

From:	pete&tammie pollard <tpollard@strato.net>
Sent:	Friday, May 31, 2002 5:30 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Cultural Facilities Funding

Jeb: We have recieved word from the Division of Cultural Affairs at Dept. of State that you are that 
you are contemplating a veto of the Cultural Facilities Program. We have already called your staff and voiced our concern, but this is to you personally.
 
Please reconsider. We have two projects in rural Highlands County on that funding list. Both non profit organizations have a major impact on our quality of life and the economy. The Theatre Project in Lake Placid will mount an outdoor production depicting Florida history and the Highlands Little Theatre Project will allow for stabilization of their building and expansion of their facilities, allowing them to serve our expanding population. This is the only program available to provide this assistance. Highlands County is an underserved area and needs the help the Dept of State makes available through the Cultural Facilities program.
 
We understand the difficult decisions that you must make each year with the adoption of a budget. Especially this year. But this program creates construction jobs and improves our quality of life factors. These programs also provide educational opportunities in the arts for our youth, an area that is always the first to go during tight fiscal years. The cultural organizations throughout the state are picking up the slack in that area from School Boards.
 
Thanks for your time and consideration.
 
Pete Pollard
Sebring, Florida

From:	RadicalMGC@aol.com
Sent:	Friday, May 31, 2002 6:35 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Film and television incentives

Dear Governor Bush:

As President of the Orlando Chapter of the Florida Motion Picture and 
Television Association (FMPTA) I have written to you and various members of 
the legislature on at least two other occasions to express our collective 
opinion regarding what the State of Florida is doing to help keep what is 
left of our Florida film and television industry from vanishing completely.  
Now I feel I must do so again.

The following article tells me that the Governor of California is a genuine 
supporter of his state's entertainment industry.  The California Legislature 
seems to be backing him up with an incentives bill that will help level the 
playing field between that State and foreign countries, such as Canada, who 
are avidly luring away American film production through government subsidies 
and incentives that make it far more economical to film there, even with all 
the snow and cold weather.  

The Directors' Guild of America (DGA) just modified their list of designated 
Production Centers, and Florida is glaringly absent from this list.  However, 
two cities in Canada are on it.  Apparently, there's not enough production 
going on here (outside of commercials and videos, which were not counted in 
the  DGA's calculations) to warrant such a designation.  For an industry that 
is reported to bring some 3.9 billion dollars into Florida businesses every 
year, we don't seem to be making much of an impression!

California is getting organized to fight this "runaway production."  But we 
in Florida cannot rely on the West Coast to fight our battle for us -- after 
all, as far as they  are concerned, Florida is part of the problem.  We're 
another example of runaway production, and as soon as they've won the battle 
against Canada, they'll be coming after us -- provided, of course, that we're 
still here.  

Florida has to save itself, and we need our political leaders behind us.  
Next session, the Legislature needs to take up the incentives bills again -- 
and if there are any adjustments to be made in the overall funding, they need 
to be made in an upward direction.  We're not trying to get fat off the 
public trough; we're just trying to survive in an environment rife with 
unfair subsidies and uncaring accountants.  

You have said time and again that you support our film and television 
industry.  Then why do we continue to see State offices hiring out-of-state 
production companies to produce documentaries and commercials, funded by our 
taxes, when there are plenty of qualified production houses here in the State 
of Florida?  It's time the leadership of the State got behind this industry, 
to which it owes so very much, and stopped acting as if it doesn't exist.  If 
you're ignoring this industry in hopes that it will go away, believe me, it 
will -- and so will all the jobs and income (and taxes!) that it brings to 
the State.

If California can rally to save itself, why can't Florida?

Sincerely,

Mike Conrad
President
Orlando/Central Florida Chapter, FMPTA

News Article follows:

Calif. law to aid film production gets major boost

LOS ANGELES (Reuters) - California lawmakers Wednesday gave a boost to a law 
meant to curb the number of film and television producers heading out of 
state for work and taking millions of dollars in spending power with them.

With only one dissenting vote, the California State Assembly passed a bill 
that provides for a 15 percent tax credit on the first $250,000 of qualifying 
wages for all movies and TV programs with budgets between $200,000 and $10 
million.

The measure must still be approved by the state Senate and signed by Gov. 
Gray Davis, who has proposed his own tax incentive plan to keep film and TV 
production in the state. If enacted, the law could take effect as soon as 
January 1, 2004.

The bill is aimed at stemming the tide of so-called "runaway" film and TV 
production to states outside of California and countries outside the United 
States.

The California bill closely mirrors two federal proposals in the U.S. Senate 
and House of Representatives. It is aimed at movies and TV shows with low- to 
mid-level budgets made mostly by independent producers who then sell those 
programs to the major TV networks and Hollywood studios for distribution.

Those producers can shave 20 percent to 30 percent or more from the cost of 
programs through tax incentives given by countries such as Canada, which is 
getting the lion's share of runaway film and TV production.

"Wage-based tax incentives allow California to remain competitive when vying 
with other states and countries for production," said Joseph Aredas, 
chairperson of the California Coalition for Entertainment Jobs, a group 
supporting the bill.

A study issued last December by the Los Angeles-based Center for 
Entertainment Industry Data and Research showed that in 2000 the number of 
films with budgets between $5 million and $50 million made in Canada rose to 
31 from 16 in 1999.

The overall economic impact from runaway production was some $1.8 billion in 
business revenues and 22,400 jobs lost.

Those figures were for movies only.

A separate report issued by the U.S. Dept. of Commerce in 2001 showed that 
film and TV runaway production cost the U.S. economy $10 billion a year.

6:00PM
 
GOVERNOR BUSH,
 
ADAM WAS ADMITTED TO THE HOSPITAL TUESDAY BECAUSE OF A LUMP (THOUGHT TO BE AN INFECTION OF A LYMPH NODE) BUT A CAT SCAN SHOWS THAT THERE IS A "MASS .  AS YOU CAN IMAGINE........... I AM SCARED AND HAVE BEEN AT THE HOSPITAL BY ADAMS SIDE 24/7 SINCE TUESDAY.  TODAY, I CAME HOME TO DEAL WITH THIS CRAP THAT DISTRICT 14  IS CONTINUING TO  PUT ME THROUGH. THIS LETTER TO YOU IS MY LAST EFFORT.  IF YOU CAN OR WILL NOT  DO SOMETHING, PERSONALLY, (BESIDES TELL SOMEONE ELSE TO DO SOMETHING WHICH HAS ALREADY NOT WORKED AS CARL LITTLEFIELD WAS NOT HELP AT ALL )   I WILL JUST HAVE TO TAKE ADAM OUT OF THE DISTRICT 14  DEPARTMENT OF CHILDREN AND FAMILIES  (DCF)  DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES (DD)  PROGRAM BECAUSE THEY ARE MAKING MY LIFE A LIVING NIGHTMARE.   HE GETS NOTHING FROM THIS DEPARTMENT OF THE GOVERNMENT ANYWAY.  AS A SINGLE MOTHER OF 17 YRS OF 2 SONS, ONE WITH ADD AND ADAM BORN WITH SPINA BIFIDA (DEVELOPMENTALLY DELAYED AND PARAPLEGIC),   MY LIFE IS HARD JUST TRYING TO FOOD AND CLOTHING ON THE LESS THAN $9000.00/YR. I GET FROM THE GOVERNMENT MUCH LESS THE FACT THAT TO GET THEM A FREE AND APPROPRIATE PUBLIC EDUCATION IS NON EXISTENT. EVERY DAY IS A BATTLE AND I CAN NOT BATTLE  THIS AGENCY ANYMORE.  I AM BEGGING YOU TO TAKE ACTION TO GET THIS DISTRICTS DCF DD PROGRAM TO SETTLE THIS ISSUE.   EVERY TIME I HEAR FROM THEM,  THEY CHANGE THEIR STORY AS TO ADAMS CASE.   NOTHING WILL PROCEED FOR ADAM UNTIL THIS IS SETTLED AND THEY REFUSE TO GIVE MONIES BACK TO ME THAT ARE DUE ME BY A VOTE OF OUR FAMILY CARE COUNCIL (FCC).
 
FOR SEVERAL YEARS NOW THE DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES  (DD) PROGRAM (ERIC OLSEN) HAS FOUGHT BACK AND FORTH WITH ME ABOUT $1631. THAT BACK IN 1999 ADAMS CASE WORKER SENT TO ME BECAUSE I WAS ON ABC VOUCHERING.  THE MONEY WAS SENT TO GO TOWARD MAKING ADAMS BATHROOM WHEELCHAIR ACCESSIBLE. (COST WILL BE $5000.00 OR MORE TOTAL)   THE DISTRICT WAS REQUIRED TO OBTAIN MORE THAN ONE BID AND WHEN I GAVE THAT PAPERWORK FROM A MAN WHO WORKED AT HOME DEPOT  TO LINDA COLKITT, ADAMS CASE WORKER AT THE TIME,  I TOLD HER TO JUST HOLD ON TO IT BECAUSE THE MAN WAS GOING TO USE HIS 13 YR. OLD SON TO HELP HIM AND I WANTED TO CHECK TO SEE IF THIS MAN HAD A CONTRACTORS LICENSE.  TEN DAYS LATER A CHECK FOR THE $1631. ARRIVED JUST AS ALL MY OTHER ABC VOUCHER MONIES HAD ARRIVED.  
 
IN A MEETING TO SIGN ADAM ONTO MED WAIVER IN MAY. 2000, WITH MARK YOUNG , THE DISTRICT 14 DD PROGRAM MANAGER (WHO WAS ACTING AS ADAMS SUPPORT COORDINATOR (SC) AT THE TIME.... HE QUIT DCF DD IN DECEMBER 2001) I REMINDED MARK THAT I HAD TO PAY VIA CREDIT CARD THAT $1631. TOWARD THE TOTAL COST WHEN THE BATHROOM WAS REMODELED.   WHEN ADAM GOT ROBIN NASON AS A SC IN  OCT. 2000 AND SHE CAME TO UPDATE ADAMS HAB PLAN,   I AGAIN REMINDED HER THAT I WOULD NEED TO PAY $1631.  TOWARD THE  BATHROOM WHEN THE DISTRICT ACTUALLY DID THE REMODELING.  I REPEATEDLY BEGGED ERIC TO SETTLE THIS MATTER BY LETTING ME PAY THE MONEY WHEN THE WORK WAS DONE AS I HAVE NO WAY TO GET $1631. CASH TO HAND TO THE DISTRICT.  HE HAS REFUSED AND AT A MEETING AT THE DISTRICT OFFICE ON MARCH 29, 2001, IN WHICH ROBIN NASON WAS FIRED FOR INCOMPETENCE,  LINDA BROPHY STATED TO ME,   "ALL OF ADAMS SERVICES WILL HAVE TO BE DISCONTINUED UNTIL YOU PAY US BACK THE MONEY"  NO MATTER HOW MANY TIMES I CALLED GARRETTS,  THE MEDICAL SUPPLY STORE (FROM MARCH 2001 UNTIL APRIL 2002 ...EXCEPT FOR JAN. 2002 WHEN MARK HAD QUIT AND SOMEONE APPROVED ONE MONTH) THAT WAS CONTRACTED TO SEND ADAMS SUPPLIES, APPROVAL WAS NEVER GRANTED. NOTHING ON ADAMS  HAB PLAN OR APPROVED ON HIS COST PLAN WAS IMPLEMENTED DURING THAT TIME.  LINDA BROPHY TOLD ME TO SEND RECEIPTS FOR THE MONEY AND I DID. IN A LETTER DEC. 2001, MARK YOUNG TOLD ME THE RECEIPTS WERE "UNACCEPTABLE'.  ERIC TOLD ME TO "SEND RECEIPTS FOR WORK DONE" SO I CALLED, FRANK MURILLO OF PRO-TEX CONTRACTING,  THE CONTRACTOR THAT ROBIN NASON HAD HAD COME OUT AND SUBMIT A BID IN MAY OF 2000.  HE CAME HERE ON APRIL 3, 2002 AND THE FOLLOWING OCCURRED:
 
    1.  THAT WEDNESDAY, HE AND 2 EMPLOYEES LOOKED AT THE BATHROOM & ASK  ME WHAT NEEDED TO BE DONE AND I TOLD HIM AND TOLD HIM I ONLY HAD $1631. TO DO THE  WORK ( A DOORWAY FROM ADAMS ROOM TO THE BATHROOM, A SINK WHEELCHAIR ACCESSIBLE AND AN EXHAUST FAN) AND I ASK FRANK WOULD THAT BE ENOUGH AND HE STATED"FOR YOU I WILL DO IT FOR THAT".
 
    2.  HE HAD ME MEET HIM AT HOME DEPOT AND HE FILLED A CART WITH SUPPLIES.  I TOLD HIM AT THE STORE THAT THE SINK HE BOUGHT WAS WRONG AND THAT THE DOOR HE WANTED ME TO PURCHASE WOULD NOT WORK.  HE MADE ME BUY IT ANYWAY. (THE DOOR,  SINK, FACET, AND EXHAUST FAN HAD TO BE TAKEN BACK BY ME THE NEXT DAY AND EXCHANGED .... WHICH COST ME $90.00 MORE.) THE SUPPLIES THAT DAY WERE CHARGED TO MY CREDIT CARD.  FRANK MURILLO LEFT ME THERE IN LINE TO PAY.
 
   3.  APRIL 3RD,  FRANK MET ME BACK AT MY HOME AND I GAVE HIM THE PAPERWORK FROM HOME DEPOT FOR THE SUPPLIES AND HE LOOKED AT THE PAPERWORK AND ON THE INSIDE OF HIS FOLDER,  DID THE MATH TO TAKE THAT AMOUNT OFF OF THE $1631. WHICH LEFT $1307. WHICH FRANK PROCEEDED TO TELL ME THAT HE REQUIRED AT LEAST 1/2 OF THE TOTAL THAT DAY AS A DEPOSIT.  HE TOOK MY CREDIT CARD AND CALLED HIS OFFICE AND CHARGED THE $1307. TO MY CREDIT CARD.  I TOLD HIM I WOULD TRUST HIM SINCE HE WAS PAID IN FULL INSTEAD OF JUST 1/2 AS A DEPOSIT. 
 
  4.  HIS EMPLOYEE SHOWED UP AT MY HOME THE NEXT DAY, THURSDAY, REEKING OF BOOZE AND I CALLED FRANK RIGHT AWAY.  AN HOUR LATER,  FRANK CAME AND TOLD ME "IF YOU WANT ANY WORK DONE, THEN THIS MAN IS THE ONLY ONE WHO CAN WORK TODAY OR YOU GET NO WORK DONE". HE TOLD ME THAT THE EMPLOYEE, MIKE, HAD TOLD HIM THAT HE HAD BEEN TO A PARTY AND DRINKING UNTIL 3:00 AM BUT HAD NOT BEEN DRINKING THAT MORNING.  I HAVE ENOUGH EXPERIENCE TO SAY THAT THIS MAN APPEARED TO BE UNDER THE INFLUENCE AN I TOLD FRANK THAT I DID NOT WANT MIKE TO RUN ELECTRICAL WIRING IN MY HOME THAT DAY.  FRANK TOLD MIKE NOT TO DO ANY ELECTRICAL WORK AND TOLD ME THAT CLAY WOULD COME AND DO THE ELECTRICAL WIRING THE NEXT DAY.  WHEN CLAY WAS NOT HERE BY 10:00AM,  I CALLED FRANK AND HE INFORMED ME THAT NO ONE COULD COME THAT DAY WHICH WOULD LEAVE NO AVAILABLE SINK ALL WEEKEND FOR THE BOYS.  I REMINDED FRANK THAT MIKE HAD NOT DONE MUCH WORK THURSDAY AND HE TOLD ME THAT I SHOULD HAVE NEVER HAVE LET MIKE IN THAT THURSDAY AND IT WAS MY FAULT.  HE THEN TOLD ME AGAIN NO ONE COULD COME THAT DAY.   HE TOLD ME TO GET SOME ONE ELSE TO FINISH THE JOB.  I TOLD HIM THAT HIS MAN HAD CUT THE DOORWAY 38 1/2" INSTEAD OF 36" AND THAT HIS MEN WOULD HAVE TO FIX THE MESS.  FRANKS MAN PUT 2X4S UNDER THE SINK TO HOLD IT UP AND I COMPLAINED SO THERON MADE SOME CABINETS WHICH WERE HORRIBLE (SIZE REQUIRED THAT THE SINK JUST SAT ON  THE SIDES OF THE  CABINET,  THE SINK COULD NOT BE CENTERED, AND THE COLOR WAS NOT AT ALL COMPATIBLE TO ANY WOOD IN OUR HOME MUCH LESS THE WOOD MIRROR CABINET ABOVE THE  SINK.   ON MAY 1ST, FRANK FINALLY HAD THERON JUST PURCHASE THE SINK STAND THAT I HAD TOLD FRANK AT HOME DEPOT ON APRIL 3RD, THAT I WANTED AND HE HAD REFUSED.  I KNOW NOW THAT FRANK BOUGHT JUST THE MINIMUM SUPPLIES AND CHEAPEST SUPPLIES IN  ORDER TO INCREASE THE LABOR MONEY HE WOULD GET.
 
  4.  MAY 2, 2002  HIS MAN, THERON, FINISHED INSTALLING THE STAND AND SINK AND LEFT STATING THAT HE WAS FINISHED AND NOT GOING TO RETURN.   
 
THE WORK IS AWFUL.   ANOTHER CONTRACTOR IS  TO BE HERE  TOMORROW MORNING CONTACTED BY ADAMS NEW SC  TO FINISH TO MAKE THE BATHROOM WHEELCHAIR ACCESSIBLE .....   (I AM GOING TO CALL AND CANCEL THIS APPOINTMENT AS I WILL NOT LEAVE ADAM ALONE AT THE HOSPITAL AGAIN WHEN IT IS OBVIOUS TO ME THAT THIS DISTRICT DD DOES NOT INTEND TO SETTLE THE MATTER OF THE $1631. NO MATTER WHAT I DO AND DO NOT INTEND TO  PAY FOR WORK TO PROCEED TO FIX THIS BATHROOM AND PUT IN A ROLL IN SHOWER FOR ADAM TO BE INDEPENDENT NOR INTEND TO REIMBURSE ME THE MONIES FROM THE FND CONFERENCE)..... THIS NEW CONTRACTOR TOLD ME HE HAS PICTURES OF FRANKS PRIOR JOBS THAT  HE USES FOR STATE WORKSHOPS THAT SHOW WHAT CAN HAPPEN WHEN YOU USE THE WRONG CONTRACTOR. HE TOLD ME TO NOT TOUCH ANYTHING AND HE WILL TAKE OF GETTING THE BATHROOM DONE RIGHT FOR ADAM TO USE. DD IS SUPPOSE TO COVER THE COST OF THIS.
 
  5.  FRANK MURILLO WENT UP IN FRONT OF THE CONTRACTOR LICENSING BOARD ON MAY 9TH.  HE DID NOT COME BUT HIS LAWYER GOT THE CHARGES DROPPED BECAUSE THE MAN WHO FILED THE CHARGES TOLD ME THAT FRANK PAID HIM OFF WITH $3000.00.  FRANK MURILLO  HAS HAD HIS CONTRACTORS LICENSE TAKEN FROM HIM BEFORE THIS AND NO ONE SEEMS TO KNOW HOW HE GOT ANOTHER LICENSE  TO MAKE MONEY (HIS LICENSE IS UNDER HIS SONS NAME AS I UNDERSTAND IT NOW).... ANYWAY, I TELL YOU ALL THIS TO MAKE YOU UNDERSTAND HOW THIS DISTRICT 14 DEPARTMENT OF CHILDREN AND FAMILIES (DCF) DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES PROGRAM TREATS THEIR CLIENTS AND THE FAMILIES WHO LOVE THEM AND CARE FOR THEM...... THIS MAN NOW HAS TOLD DD LIES BY STATING THAT HE NEVER SAW THE PAPERWORK FROM HOME DEPOT TO DEDUCT THE COST OF  SUPPLIES FROM THE $1631. TO GET THE $1307. THAT HE CHARGED ON MY CARD AND HE STATES THAT HE RETURNED $200.00 TO ME WHICH HE DID NOT AND NOW THE DCF DD PROGRAM ON TOP OF THE $1700. I HAVE ALREADY INCURRED ON MY CREDIT CARD FOR THIS WORK, DEMANDS THAT I GIVE THEM $200.00...... WHY WOULD DISTRICT 14 DD PEOPLE CALL ME A LIAR BECAUSE I WROTE BACK TO BRENDA BRYAN WHEN SHE WROTE TO ASK  THE DETAILS AND I EXPLAINED TO HER EXACTLY WHAT I HAVE TOLD YOU.... THE TRUTH ON MY LIFE AND THE LIVES OF MY SONS......... FRANK TOOK THE PAPERWORK AND CONFIRMED THE COST OF SUPPLIES  AND DEDUCTED THAT COST FROM THE $1631. TO GET THE $1307. LABOR COSTS.... I EVEN SENT A LETTER TO FRANK DETAILING THE EVENTS AND STATED IN THE LETTER THAT HE WAS TO SEND ME WRITTEN DOCUMENTATION IF HE DID NOT CONCUR WITH THE EVENTS AS I STATED.  I NEVER HEARD FROM HIM AND EVEN THOUGH I SENT A COPY OF THIS LETTER TO BRENDA BRYAN,  THAT IS NOT ENOUGH TO END THIS NIGHTMARE.   I FAXED BRENDA FROM THE HOSPITAL THAT THEY CAN TELL FRANK TO SEND THE $200. DIRECTLY TO THEM AT DD AS I DO NOT W NT HIS MONEY NOW....... I AM FORCED TO FILE SEPARATE COMPLAINT PAPERWORK TO TAKE THIS MAN IN FRONT OF THE BOARD AGAIN  AND TAKE TIME TO GO BACK IN FRONT OF THE BOARD AGAIN  MYSELF...... MORE TIME I CERTAINLY DO NOT HAVE.
 
MY QUESTION TO YOU IS THIS......WHAT WILL YOU DO?  I HAVE BEEN LIVING ON MY LAND IN POLK COUNTY SINCE FEB. 99.   EXCEPT FOR DIAPERS AND SOME OTHER MEDICAL SUPPLIES (WHICH HAVE NOW ALL BEEN DENIED) ADAM, AS A DD CLIENTS IN THIS DISTRICT HAS GOT NOTHING SINCE FEB. 99.  SINCE COMING TO POLK COUNTY, I HAVE HAD IN HOME RESPITE CARE ON ALL 4  OF ADAMS ANNUAL HAB PLANS AND HAVE NOT RECEIVED ONE DAY.  ALL I HAVE BEEN   OFFERED IS TO TAKE ADAM TO SOME FOSTER HOME BUT SINCE ADAM MUST CATHERIZE FOR RESIDUAL URINE EVERY 4 HOURS,  I WILL NOT TAKE HIM INTO AN UNKNOWN ENVIRONMENT TO HAVE SOMEONE NOT QUALIFIED CATHERIZE HIM ON SOME COMMUNITY TOILET.  IT SEEMS TO ME ACCORDING TO WHAT I HAVE HAD TO ENDURE IN THIS DISTRICT SINCE FEB. 99,  THAT THIS DISTRICT HAS ONE THING IN MIND AND THAT IS HOW THE DISTRICT CAN DENY SERVICES AND SPEND THE LEAST AMOUNT OF MONEY, IF ANY, FOR A CLIENT.   DELMARVA IS NOW IN ITS SECOND YEAR OF THE NOW 4 YEAR CONTRACT OF 3.9 MILLION/YEAR TO MAKE CONDITIONS BETTER FOR THE POPULATION OF PEOPLE WITH DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES IN THE STATE OF FLORIDA, BUT AS OF YET THEY HAVE NOT DONE ONE THING TO MAKE ANYTHING BETTER FOR ADAM.  I CAN NOT EVEN GET MINUTES OF THE LAVISH, LUXURY MEETINGS THAT THESE PEOPLE KEEP HAVING AROUND THE STATE "TO MAKE DD SERVICES BETTER" .  ANOTHER INSTANCE (DELMARVAS 3.9 MILLION/YEAR AND THE PEOPLE OF THE IQC) OF A LOT OF PEOPLE MAKING BIG BUCKS IN SALARIES AND A LOT OF THEIR TRAVELING ALL OVER THE COUNTRY PAID FOR BY THE STATE OF FLORIDA.................. BUT NOTHING DONE FOR THE PEOPLE THEY ARE HIRED TO SERVE.
 
IT IS NOW 12:45 AM ON MONDAY... I HAVE SPENT VALUABLE TIME AWAY FROM ADAM WHO IS LYING IN A HOSPITAL BED RIDDLED WITH FEVER TO COME HOME AND REACH OUT TO YOU FOR HELP........................ PLEASE LET ME HEAR FROM YOU.................... PLEASE .
 
CYNDI GRATE
EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR
CAREGIVERS ORGANIZED FOR PHYSICALLY IMPAIRED STUDENTS (COPIS)
DISTRICT 14 FAMILY CARE COUNCIL MEMBER
