---attached letter follows---
 
Thursday, May 09, 2002
 
RE: New generations of safe landfill containments that can pinpoint the liner leaks, contain the escaping leachate, and repair the leaks, allowing landfills for the first time in history to be able to be maintained.
 
Dear Sir or Madam,
 
In the 10 years of the R.C.R.A. rules becoming law, every aspect of the way this nation and industry addresses its waste has dramatically improved to better protect our environment, except for landfill containments. The same basic landfill design and technology used 10 years ago is still used today, and all past and present day landfills contain a serious flaw. 
The current landfill designs and systems lack the ability to monitor their barrier liners. The lack of ability to accurately monitor their lining systems prevents today’s lining systems from being maintained. Any science or technology that does not have the ability to accurately evaluate it’s own integrity in regards to its intended purpose and usage by using reliable checks and balances, is flawed and incomplete. The current need for improved landfill science and technology becomes apparent when it is estimated that out of all of the disposal methods used today, 47% of all waste generated goes into landfill containments.
After 10 years of research and development, there is a new science and technology that will allow all new landfills, containments, and their liners to be maintained. I have created a web presentation of the ENSTECH system, showing how the system works in a typical landfill application, on www.enstechinc.com <http://www.enstechinc.com/>  . The web presentation will show how the ENSTECH system will work in pinpointing the leaks, and then contain and repair the leaks in municipal, industrial, hazardous, and cold radioactive landfills. It must be understood that until the ENSTECH system’s development, no previous containment technology has had the ability to accurately find, contain and repair any leaks.
Not shown in this web presentation is the Enstech high heat resistant metal lining system. For an example of the liner module made of heat resistant metal, refer to the diagram at  <http://www.enstechinc.com/diagram.jpg> http://www.enstechinc.com/diagram.jpg . As you watch the web presentation, in your mind, replace all the plastic lining and piping with nuclear grade stainless steel or titanium. This containment system can be used under heat generating sources in industrial manufacture, such as hot caustic or cooling tanks. The same system can be employed under heat generating nuclear material and waste, such as radioactive water, sludges, and solids including used nuclear fuel rods. By using this simple design change, the public and government alike can be assured that no radioactive waste or material has escaped from the containment. The same critical assurance can be made that no out-of-containment water will leak back into the containment. With the development of the Enstech high-heat lining system comes the ability to safely contain and monitor hot waste and materials.
I have sent this same letter to Administrator Whitman, asking for her help in establishing this new containment system as Best Available Control Technology (BACT). I have also asked for her help with all E.P.A. programs and awards that will apply in bringing this technology to this nation. I hope to gain written permission to use the E.P.A. logo endorsement that has been given to other such technologies.
Please review the presentation and write me back with your thoughts and suggestions regarding this new technology. I look forward to your response regarding this matter. 
 
 
 
 
 
Thank you,
                                         
 
 
Burt Hampton, C.E.O.

P.O. Box 1557

Magnolia, AR 71753
(870)-234-1421
burt@enstechinc.com 
burt@enstechlabs.com 
 
 
 
From:	Shalena Dickinson <sdickins@bellsouth.net>
Sent:	Friday, May 31, 2002 10:46 PM
To:	Jeb Bush

Hello.  I am just your average, tax-paying citizen who also happens to be a graduate sutdent and social worker.  I am really concerned with a lot of things that have been going on recently with DCF, the cutting  of funding for group homes for children, etc.  We always hear the negative about DCF.  I have read your Blue Ribbon Panel's suggestions.  Not bad.  However, unless adequate funding is diverted to social services (and not just DCF), things like this will continue to happen.  I worked at DCF in District 13 during the Kayla McKean disaster.  I am still involved with the child protection system in a different capacity, with a different agency.  I have worked the front lines, behind the scenes, etc.  Lack of funding, lack of ways to  encourage retention of employees (i.e.m - cutting tuition waivers for sate employees to better themselves and further their professional development and enhance their skills), lack of professionalization of the agency as a whole (requiring social service professional instead of anybody (Any Body) to fill a vacant position, these are just a few of the issues that plague DCF and other agencies.  Even with adequate funding for a long-term period (with no cuts) it would take several years or more to rejuvenate and revamp the child welfare system in Florida.  Just as there are incompetent people without ethical and moral consciences, there are just as many and many more caring, devoted, hard-working men and women that believe in our children and their right to be protected and nurtured.  They certainly don't work for the state of Florida for the wages, job incentives, etc.  We need to prioritize our budget and figure out what is important.  Where are all of the children going to go when funds for residential treatment are cut?  Back home?  In the community?  Into DJJ facilities?  Into the already beleaguered foster care system?  There are so many issues that I could go on and on, however I won't.  Just wanted to drop a line and say my small piece.  Thank you for your time.

Sent: Friday, May 31, 2002 5:11 PM
To: PRESS OFFICE; Jeb Bush; Shanahan, Kathleen; Tinker, Teresa;
Turbeville, Greg
Subject: DCF DOCUMENTS-TV STORY


Confidential records sold at DCF auction

Thousands and thousands of confidential files left in an abandoned
building
where the public was invited in for an auction. A reporter from 10 News
was
able to purchase boxes containing some of these records that the public
should never have been allowed to see. The incident shows apparent gross
negligence by the Department of Children and Families

 
56k Modem | High-Speed
 
 
The auction was held Thursday at the W.T. Edwards Building that housed
local
DCF offices for several years. When the agency vacated the building, the
records were left behind.

All over the building were signs that said "shred all", as well as
printed
on the boxes. Obviously, the contents were never shredded. Anyone who
registered for the auction could have bought these boxes.

The problem is that confidentiality is the cornerstone of child
protection.
Workers are told they are never supposed to break confidentiality. When
district headquarters abandoned their old building to move. The agency
seemed to forget that rule.

When the Department of Children and Families was questioned about the
records, a spokesman said it was not their fault, but the auctioneer who
made the mistake of selling them is responsible.

Auctioneer Tom Hicks says people from the department walked through the
building several times. They were completely aware of what was being
sold.
They opened the doors to the offices. When he asked prior to the auction
if
there was anything they didn't want him to sell, they asked for the
building
blueprints 

DCF says it is firing the auctioneer because he shouldn't have sold the
files, and they are halting the auction. The auctioneer says he has a
contract for what's called an absolute auction, which means everything
in
the building is sold.

Governor Jeb Bush says he's angry and upset that the Department of
Children
and Family services allowed thousands of confidential records to be put
up
for public auction.

He thanked 10 News for bringing it to his attention and asked if he
could
take possession of the records.

10 News turned them over to him and he says the other records we bought
will
be shredded Monday. He says DCF needs to take responsibility for the
mistake.

--END--
 

Elizabeth E. Hirst
Press Secretary
Office of Governor Jeb Bush

-----Original Message-----
From: Brantley, Michelle K. [mailto:brantlem@fdhc.state.fl.us]
Sent: Friday, May 31, 2002 7:09 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: 'Michael.Hansen@LASPBS.state.fl.us'
Subject: Family CAFE Request for Assistance relating to DME


Governor Bush,

I understand that you received a copy of flyer protesting the Durable
Medical Equipment (DME) Competitive billing process and an attached letter
expressing concerns signed by Dolores (Lolly) Gonzalez. The flyer includes a
picture of Dolores with her 20 year old medically complex son, Oscar
Gonzalez. We tried to contact Oscar and his family to offer assistance with
DME needs, but both very politely refused to discuss any issues relating to
DME. It turns out that Oscar is one of witnesses for the plaintiff who has
filed a protest against the Agency for issuing the DME request for
proposals. The family has been advised by legal counsel not to discuss any
issues relating to DME. In the meantime, we reviewed Oscar's current
services and provider claims to ensure that his health care needs are fully
addressed.

> Oscar is currently receiving 24 hour skilled nursing care due to multiple
> chronic conditions.  Our notes indicate that he suffers from
> Werdnig-Hoffman disease, has a tracheostomy, is ventilator dependent,
> requires the use of a customized wheelchair, and appears to have some type
> of colostomy problems.
> 
> His Medicaid-funded DME and supplies include a Bear-33 ventilator, O2
> stationary and portable, suction machine stationary and portable,
> nebulizer, hospital bed, customized wheelchair, ambu bag, suction
> catheters, and gloves.  The customized wheelchair was paid by Medicaid in
> 1998.  Within the next year, he will be aging out of the Children's
> Medical Services system and transition planning is underway.
> 
According to provider DME Medicaid claims for Oscar, the provider the family
uses is called Pedi-Stat.  All of Pedi-Stat's claims have already been paid.
We do not have any record of pending requests or claims on Oscar's behalf at
this time. If Oscar's needs change, we will continue to provide assistance
necessary to ensure access to quality health care.

While AHCA appreciates the concern of DME providers, families and
recipients, particularly on the needs of children, the services procured
under the RFP will continue to be of the same or higher quality then
provided under the existing system.  Additionally, as all proposers are
existing Medicaid providers, and AHCA is going to confirm that none of them
have had fraud or abuse issues. The contractors will be providers who have
proven reliability in delivering high quality goods and timely services to
the medically needy population.  

Please don't hesitate to contact me if you need additional information or
assistance on this situation.

Sincerely,

Shelly Brantley
Chief, Health Systems Development
Agency for Health Care Administration

 



>

Update as of 6pm today.

Good news for students!

The current enrollment (participation #)
of students in McKay for this year
(2001-2002) was 5000.

As of today, we have 5114 students
indicating they will be participating
in the program for coming year 2002-2003.

We have exceed current 
enrollment figures, and we are one
month early (first qtr deadline is
July 1, with 3 other chances during
rest of the year...)

This is good indication that parents:
A.  Want choice
B.  Are opting for this program
C.  Are pleased and remaining with
the program.

We have 300% increase from
year 1 in private schools participating.

400% increase in student participation
from year 1.

School Yr. 2002-2003 is year 3.

Other info...

We received 525 calls from parents
yesterday.

Approximately 250 calls today.

We are averaging a daily
call rate of 230 calls, and the
letters sent to potentially eligible
students (300,000) are just now
arriving in homes.

The calls may indicate (then)  
that information
is getting to parents and they are 
responding with interest, even if they
have not yet received letter.

Hits to web site are steady.

-----Original Message-----
From: Kerry Mullen [mailto:kmullen@boggycreek.org]
Sent: Friday, May 31, 2002 2:54 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: govt@floridanurse.org
Subject: nursing shortage


Jeb, 
Thanks for taking the time to meet with us on Tuesday about the nursing shortage. It was a pleasure to meet you. I have been thinking about it a lot and came up with an idea that I would like you to consider. Being a pediatric nurse practitioner I think a lot about the health and well-being of the children of this state. I do believe that having school nurses makes a huge difference in the health maintenance of school-aged children, but that is not all that they do. They are also a great role-model for the children. We talked about having nurses go to schools to talk up nursing as a profession. Why not assign school nurses to every school and have them also present nursing as a profession to the students via the classroom and by example? I think that this would be a great way to promote nursing from a very young age. What do you think? I'd be happy to help in any way that I can to see that this gets presented as an option. 
Also, I would like to invite you to my place of work and play, the Boggy Creek Gang Camp. The camp is for kids with chronic and life-threatening illnesses and we operate year round. You should come and check it out sometime and see what nurses love to do with their volunteer hours. 
Thank you for your time, 
Kerry Mullen, CPNP, ACRN
Nursing Director, Boggy Creek Gang Camp
(352)483-4200 x270

From:	Wilton Rooks <wilton@rooks.com>
Sent:	Friday, May 31, 2002 9:00 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Cultural and Historic Importance.

Governor Bush,
Perhaps a monster was created when the system of sending  money to Tallahassee for redistribution back to the source of the money (local communities) was created. But that is the system we have and we have to make it work!
 
If local communities get short changed on the return of money for important projects, then the system won't last.
 
Of primary importance to local communities - especially historic communities dependent on tourism - is the ability to maintain, support and enhance our cultural and historic heritage. For St. Augustine, it would be the kiss of death to starve these important aspects of our community. Without history and meaning historic interpretations, St. Augustine is nothing. 
 
I urge you to sign the legislation on your desk for Preservation and Cultural Monies allocation. Those funds are important for all of us.
 
Wilton Rooks
St. Augustine, Fl

-----Original Message-----
From: DAdkins777@aol.com [mailto:DAdkins777@aol.com]
Sent: Friday, May 31, 2002 6:49 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: paulw@falamail.org
Subject: DCF Problems


Gov Bush 

It would appear that at DCF government knows best!  I received a disturbing call today from some assisted living facility administrators in the suncoast region, they said they left a meeting with DCF staff and were told that the people in charge at mental health in Tallahassee had issued an "order" to remove all the mental health consumers that are enrolled in the Florida Assertive Community Treatment (FACT)Program from licensed limited mental health assisted living facilities. 

I have asked DCF for a policy clarification on the utilization of licensed limited mental health assisted living facilities.  I just think it is not the place of government to spend so much time trying to determine or channel where people should live or not live.  Why not allow the market place to determine the most appropriate setting where people should live.  I believe that government should just step out of the way and let consumers, their families and case managers select the housing setting that suits their needs.  In stead government and the FACT teams are referring people to the housing settings that they believe are in their best interest. I think government should simply the whole thing and just make available to consumers what the options are and then step out of the way, this would allow the free markets to do their thing without being manipulated by DCF. 

In Jacksonville I received a call from a concerned social worker wanting to know why the local FACT team was sending everyone to a boarding home licensed under the divsion of hotels and rest   ( ie Honey Babes) instead of a licensed ALF?  I could not answer the social worker's question, Honey Babes does not offer any protections under a bill of rights and these facilities are often considered undesireable for consumers.  I suspect it has to do with the fact that placements at Honey Babes are less expensive than placement in a licensed ALF. 

In addition to active governmental interference with the marketplace I am not sure that the people currently running the adult mental health system have any understanding that they cannot discriminate against thousands of small and minority business owner because they hold a bias against ALF care.  There is no systemic data or other information that indicates a widespread breakdown in the ability of licensed limited mental health assisted living facilities ability to care for their residents. Licensed limited mental health ALFs are a great enconomic deal for the consumer and taxpayer the current rate of $27/ day is perhaps one of the most cost effective housing alternatives available to consumers and the taxpayers. 

I know you appreciate the value of open market competition and the liberty that comes along with our free enterprise system of commerce.  The situation at DCF has become so problematic it really requires someone with clear sense of direction to stop the nonsense.  Thank for taking a look and helping the DCF find its way. 

Kindest Regards 

Douglas D. Adkins 
Executive Director 
Dayspring Village, Inc. 
PO Box 1080 
Hilliard, Florida 32046 
904-845-7501

-----Original Message-----
From: SWANNFL@aol.com [mailto:SWANNFL@aol.com]
Sent: Friday, May 31, 2002 6:02 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: fund raiser


Dear Governor,
It was so nice to talk with you last night at the Melbourne event. Jim is sorry to be out of town.

I was ecstatic to hear about the deal you made on the off-shore drilling, and to hear you say that Republicans care about the environment, some of our local folk need to be reminded of that! Thank you for your support of the land preservation funds, you are right, it sets a bad precedent and will further erode the trust of the voters.

I promised to let you know which Cultural Affairs item not to cut, this is a problem with caring, involved people, we have too many issues! We have a proposal in Cultural Facilities for $250,000 for a match for an Eckerd Family grant of $500,000 for an Educational Complex at the Brevard Zoo, or East Coast Zoological Society.

The short story of the proposal is that we are building three classrooms at the zoo for a "Zoo School" which will allow us to house the 5th graders at three low performing schools. We have had one working at the zoo for 5 years and the results are outstanding. We have tracked the progress of the students and they have significantly improved gradesand test scores. Behavior is better and attendance is up. This has become a national model for "at risk" kids. As you know, this is the emphasis of the Eckerd programs, and we feel that this school has shown as you said, all kids can learn and should have the opportunity to succeed.
This is really the short version and we would be glad to give you more information or provide a tour. I understand that you are in a very tough position and appreciate all that you are able to do.
Thank you,
Jonnie Swann

From:	Jeb Bush
Sent:	Friday, May 31, 2002 9:40 PM
To:	'Shalena Dickinson'
Subject:	RE: 

Shalena, there has not been any cuts in funding for group homes for children. That is not true. In fact, we have expanded funding for threapuetic group homes from next to nothing to $26 million in two years. Do you know that we have doubled the funding for the child welfare system in four years time? that is a fact.
 
Adoptions have increased dramatically. The kids in foster care are down since we are getting them in permanent homes a lot quicker. Case loads are down. We are making progress because of the reforms we have made (there is much more to do!) and the dramatic increase in funding. 
 
thanks for writing.
 

Jeb Bush 

***********************************************************

regarding state business are public records available to the
public and media upon request.   Your e-mail communications
may therefore be subject to public disclosure.

From: Shalena Dickinson [mailto:sdickins@bellsouth.net]
Sent: Friday, May 31, 2002 10:46 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: 


Hello.  I am just your average, tax-paying citizen who also happens to be a graduate sutdent and social worker.  I am really concerned with a lot of things that have been going on recently with DCF, the cutting  of funding for group homes for children, etc.  We always hear the negative about DCF.  I have read your Blue Ribbon Panel's suggestions.  Not bad.  However, unless adequate funding is diverted to social services (and not just DCF), things like this will continue to happen.  I worked at DCF in District 13 during the Kayla McKean disaster.  I am still involved with the child protection system in a different capacity, with a different agency.  I have worked the front lines, behind the scenes, etc.  Lack of funding, lack of ways to  encourage retention of employees (i.e.m - cutting tuition waivers for sate employees to better themselves and further their professional development and enhance their skills), lack of professionalization of the agency as a whole (requiring social service professional instead of anybody (Any Body) to fill a vacant position, these are just a few of the issues that plague DCF and other agencies.  Even with adequate funding for a long-term period (with no cuts) it would take several years or more to rejuvenate and revamp the child welfare system in Florida.  Just as there are incompetent people without ethical and moral consciences, there are just as many and many more caring, devoted, hard-working men and women that believe in our children and their right to be protected and nurtured.  They certainly don't work for the state of Florida for the wages, job incentives, etc.  We need to prioritize our budget and figure out what is important.  Where are all of the children going to go when funds for residential treatment are cut?  Back home?  In the community?  Into DJJ facilities?  Into the already beleaguered foster care system?  There are so many issues that I could go on and on, however I won't.  Just wanted to drop a line and say my small piece.  Thank you for your time.

-----Original Message-----
From: Jerry_Antine@fpl.com [mailto:Jerry_Antine@fpl.com]
Sent: Monday, May 06, 2002 4:23 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Mentally Challenged Son 


Dear Governor Bush,

Last year, my family and I moved to Florida for a better quality of
life. I
met my wife in Orlando when I was stationed at McCoy AFB in 1962. The
USAF
transferred us to other states during the Vietnam War and my 23 year
enlisted service.   We returned to Florida in 2001 after being gone for
38
years, 23 of those years in the USAF, 3 years attending college in New
Mexico, and 12 years of employment with MCI in California.  In October
of
2000 Florida Power and Light  offered me a management position working
in
their new start up company, FPL FiberNet with an office in West Palm
Beach.

My wife and son arrived at West Palm Beach in May of 2001.  Since June
of
2001 we have been working with the Department Of Children and Families.
For
the past 10 months we have been trying to get funding for our
34-year-old
autistic son (Shannon Lee) so he can join a program to help him in
development and to help us with respite care. Shannon has no physical
impairments in mobility.  He loves to participate and be part of
programs
during the day.  Before moving here from Southern California, we spoke
with
the Department of Children and Families.  They assured us there would be
support and activities available for our son.  After our move we met
with
the department agency here in West Palm Beach.  Our son was evaluated
and
accepted as a client.  The shocking news that has since followed is hard
for us to accept.  We were told there is no funding and Shannon is on a
waiting list that may be as long as three years before he will be
funded.

I observed your speech last week about your family issues.  I was
impressed.  My wife and I also display our feelings when we talk about
our
son.  We are having a hard time seeing him sit at home every day with
nothing to do and no development program.  We are writing to you to see
if
there is anything that can be done.  Your assistance would be
appreciated.

Also, regardless of Shannon's issue, we believe you are the right person
for the job of Florida Governor.  You will have our support at the
polls.

Sincerely,

Harry J. and Edith E. Antine
10442 Trailwood Circle
Jupiter, FL 33478
561-743-9908


From:	michael noe <mnoe@cfl.rr.com>
Sent:	Friday, May 31, 2002 11:34 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	OSCEOLA COUNTY SCHOOLS

Mr. Bush,
 
I am writing in reference to page 416 section 28. PLEASE do not cut our budget, Mr. Bush. It seems that every year we get cheated because we are a small school district. Mr.Bush, I am not sure if you are aware that we are THE FASTEST growing school district in the state (and many more housing developments still being built) but we get the LEAST amount of funding per capita for school construction. What is wrong with this picture? I have a 9 yr old son and he had 29 students in his class last year. That is WAY too many kids for a third grade class. I strongly urge you not to cut our budget. Thank you for reading this.
  
Gayle Martin
St.Cloud, Florida
